column5: The self-absorbed offspring are oblivious to the possibility that schlumpy old Poppy might have problems of his own. Itâ€™s not real clear how seriously weâ€™re supposed to be taking all of this, but more important is that no one here is particularly likable, which makes it hard to care about all the whining. â€œThank you for a very nice meal,â€ù a young child says in one scene, eager to get away from the squabbling grown-ups. â€œMay I please be excused?â€ù Youâ€™ll know how the kid feels.

It might be time for a moratorium on movies in which a family gathers for a revelatory holiday meal. â€œCold Turkeyâ€ù has some fine actors who put effort into their roles, but itâ€™s getting harder and harder to care about or laugh at adult characters who have botched up their affluent lives and are still obsessed with events from childhood.

The film, written and directed by Will Slocombe, looks in on the Thanksgiving of a family presided over by Poppy (Peter Bogdanovich), who spends most of the movie listening to his grown children asking him for money. This particular Thanksgiving is destined for disruption because his daughter Nina (Alicia Witt) has shown up for the first time in years. Another daughter, Lindsay (Sonya Walger), is also on hand, as is their half-brother, Jacob (Ashton Holmes), and Poppyâ€™s second wife (Cheryl Hines).
As artificial as the inseminations it celebrates, â€œDelivery Manâ€ù is a soggy comedy more focused on stimulating your tear ducts than your funny bone.
â€œDelivery Manâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Physical disability is used as a sentimental prop, and Chris Pratt is used to keep us in our seats.

Movie concepts donâ€™t come much higher, and Mr. Vaughn â€” master of the helpless â€œWho, me?â€ù gaze â€” shuffles through this brazenly manipulative ode to fatherhood with doughy passivity. Creepily stalking his unwitting offspring (a phalanx of attractive millennials resembling Coca-Colaâ€™s famous â€œIâ€™d Like to Teach the World to Singâ€ù ad), David can barely attend to a pregnant girlfriend (Cobie Smulders), a salivating press and a debt to the mob. No wonder he spends so little time driving that truck.

Rejiggering his recent French-Canadian film â€œStarbuck,â€ù Ken Scott serves up yet another example of todayâ€™s most prolific movie character: the grown man trapped in the aspic of adolescence. This time heâ€™s David Wozniak (a listless Vince Vaughn), a pot-growing loser barely competent enough to drive his familyâ€™s meat-delivery truck. Back in the day, however, Davidâ€™s more than 600 sperm donations resulted in almost as many conceptions (perhaps the energy unneeded by his brain simply migrated south) and now some of them are suing to learn his identity.

More exhausted than a new parent, â€œDelivery Manâ€ù is propped up by the gifted Chris Pratt, who plays Davidâ€™s best friend with a comedic subtlety unearned by a script that never thinks to wonder whether â€œsperm donorâ€ù and â€œfatherâ€ù are even the same thing.

A funny scene in which Najlah visits the station with her girlfriends shows that Ms. Nashef can get belly laughs, but the bulk of the filmâ€™s humor is quiet and observational, like the efforts of Samiâ€™s cousin (Mike Batayeh) to jazz up the station with tacky products. The largely unknown cast is surprisingly good, and a secondary plotline in which Samiâ€™s mother (Mary Assel) struggles with her grief is delicately handled.

When his father is killed in a robbery, Sami (E. J. Assi) takes over running the family gas station in a tough part of Detroit, a future he didnâ€™t want. He spends his workdays inside the cage, the bulletproof enclosure that protects him from the mean streets and also serves as an allegory. Sami appears resigned to an uneventful life until he meets Najlah (Nada Shouhayib), who sells phone cards to the station. Their chaste courtship, conducted in the cage and despite opposition from both families, is beautifully etched.

â€œDetroit Unleadedâ€ù is about as gentle as comedies come these days, commendably so. Rola Nashef, the director, who was born in Lebanon and raised in Michigan, wasnâ€™t interested in the slapstick and vulgarity that pass for humor in most films. By avoiding those noisy distractions and staying within the confines of her sparse story, she has created a surprisingly affecting examination of one aspect of the Arab-American experience: the dissonance between American hookup culture and home-country traditions.

One problem with Mr. von Harderâ€™s project is his decision to shoot in deepest winter, when the city and its environs are an indistinct gray-and-white expanse, at least as captured and flattened-out here. While itâ€™s not necessary for the film to rival the mesmerizing devastation of, say, the Alberta tar pits surveyed from above in â€œPetropolisâ€ù or the dazzling toylike distortions of Olivo Barbieriâ€™s cityscapes, a more disciplined composition and control of tempo would help.

Burkhard von Harderâ€™s â€œDie Narbeâ€ù (â€œThe Scarâ€ù) bears witness to the legacy of the Berlin Wall in rather literal-minded fashion by filming the wallâ€™s perimeter from a helicopter. Far from tapping Germanyâ€™s especially rich and haunted interplay between architecture and memory, the movie suggests, most immediately, that not all aerial photography is equal.

Mr. von Harder inscribes this storied geography with audio quotations from Willy Brandt, Walter Ulbricht and others, and what sound like recordings of crank calls to the Stasi. Together they give the sense of listening in on history, but over all, â€œDie Narbe,â€ù scored with music-as-wallpaper by F. M. Einheit, comes across as more of an extravagant gesture than a fully realized artistic conceit.
The biggest irritant is an intrusive, semi-minimalist score by Michael Nyman that drapes the mundanity in arty trappings.
Moment by moment, it all adds up. The scenes of the family huddling and hugging, greeting and parting, and reaffirming primal bonds are quietly moving.

Michael Winterbottomâ€™s elusive family drama â€œEverydayâ€ù was filmed in two-week periods around Christmas over five successive years in a rural Scottish village. Its central character, Karen (Shirley Henderson), is a lean, intense working-class woman whose husband, Ian (John Simm), is serving time for an unspecified drug-related crime.

But the vagueness of the movie, written by Mr. Winterbottom and Laurence Coriat, seems a deliberate strategy to focus on the quotidian aspects of the ties that bind. We observe the preparation of meals and the childrenâ€™s school days, and we follow Karen as she takes the train to the prison, sometimes accompanied by all four children and sometimes by only the boys, who idolize their dad. In a disturbing moment that has no reverberations, one of the boys finds his fatherâ€™s rifle and carries it into the woods.

Contributing to the movieâ€™s tone of documentary realism is that the children are played by real-life siblings, Shaun, Katrina, Stephanie and Robert Kirk. (They are unrelated to Mr. Simm and Ms. Henderson.) As the film follows the family in carefully spaced reunion scenes at prison and at home when Ian is allowed to visit, â€œEverydayâ€ù bears a distant, if unmistakable, resemblance to Michael Aptedâ€™s â€œUpâ€ù documentary series. Those films revisit the same people every seven years to reveal the often astounding changes in their lives.

Karen canâ€™t completely hold in her anger, doubt and frustration. Twice, she cracks and lets Ian know how tough her life is. When he returns to his cell after a visit and plops on his bunk bed and stares into space, you sense the boredom and despair underlying his bonhomie during family visits. When the couple spend some precious moments alone, it is obvious that Karen and Ian are still deeply in love despite everything.

Because only one year separates the Christmases in â€œEveryday,â€ù and the dates are not clearly noted, the changes in the family â€” even the childrenâ€™s growth â€” are not strikingly noticeable from year to year. Confusing matters further, the names of places are never given, and it is often difficult to comprehend the charactersâ€™ Scottish accents.

Karen grimly supports the coupleâ€™s four children by working several jobs, including as a barmaid. While Ian is away, she carries on an ambiguous, quasi-domestic relationship with a family friend. At a certain point, Ian telephones home with the unhappy news that his sentence will be extended for a short time because he was caught with a tiny amount of hashish. The look on Karenâ€™s face says it all: How could he? But she swallows her rage.

The movieâ€™s problems are its ambitions. With awkward slow-motion effects, clunky transitions and pregnant zooms that seem conspicuously in the wrong speed or otherwise a little off, Mr. Oliverâ€™s film aims for a glossy mainstream aesthetic without the budget or skills to match. In addition to being a showcase for actors, the movie is most successful as a quintessentially New York film in which the characters are even more neurotic and comic than usual and the plot hinges dramatically on a subway station closure.

Jack, the hero of Jono Oliverâ€™s debut feature, â€œHome,â€ù is balancing his dosage of antipsychotic medicine while seeking an apartment in New York for less than $600 a month. This seemingly impossible hunt is endured with humor and sensitivity, as well as minute pangs of suffering, thanks to a stunning performance from Gbenga Akinnagbe (Chris Partlow in â€œThe Wireâ€ù) in the story of Jackâ€™s efforts to leave a group home where heâ€™s lived for many years.

With its touching portrayal of the relationships between the patients and health care workers, â€œHomeâ€ù resembles something more like a low-budget â€œAwakeningsâ€ù (without the focus on pharmaceutical solutions) than last yearâ€™s screwball, maniacal â€œSilver Linings Playbook.â€ù Mental illness is presented here as something by turns endearing, surprising and frightening. A jarring realism comes both from Mr. Oliverâ€™s script and the performances by an ensemble of brilliant character actors, including James McDanielâ€™s portrayal of a doctor and Joe Mortonâ€™s turn as Jackâ€™s father.

The moral of â€œContracted,â€ù Eric Englandâ€™s slight but intelligently assembled horror movie, is hard to miss. After Samantha (Najarra Townsend), a lesbian, meets a man at a party and uncharacteristically has hazy, unprotected sex with him in a car, she awakens the next day with an advancing case of â€” you remember â€œWorld War Z,â€ù right? Letâ€™s call this V.D.Z. Living at home in a fractious relationship with her mom (Caroline Williams) and applying to college, Samantha soon finds to her disgust that her eyes are growing opaque; teeth, fingernails and clumps of hair are coming off; a nasty lesion is growing on her lip; and her appetite for human flesh is mounting.

The terrors of slow metamorphosis have been rendered in other fright films, notably in David Cronenbergâ€™s â€œThe Flyâ€ù; Mr. England summons a similar dread, making shrewd use of a meager budget and talented actors, including Katie Stegeman as Samanthaâ€™s estranged girlfriend and, in a turn as the one-night partner, the horror writer-director Simon Barrett (â€œV/H/Sâ€ù). For her part, Ms. Townsend, with the help of a skilled makeup team, capably portrays a descent into living death.
The ending to this fable misses the opportunity for broader metaphorical resonance, but getting there has its own unnerving rewards.

Mr. Gondry was introduced to Mr. Chomsky by watching several documentaries, including â€œManufacturing Consent: Noam Chomsky and the Mediaâ€ù (1993). Eventually, the two men met and talked, and talked some more, a dialogue that led to â€œIs the Man Who Is Tall Happy?â€ù Mr. Gondry decided to animate their conversations to reveal â€” in a Chomsky-ian move â€” the filmmaking process that ordinarily remains hidden for the viewerâ€™s pleasure (and manipulation). Using old-fashioned, hand-drawn animation; a bright, pulsing palette; and live interviews shot with a 16-millimeter film camera (a Bolex â€” hurray!), Mr. Gondry lays bare his own process as well as his intellectual anxieties as he gently questions and sometimes prods the admirably patient Mr. Chomsky.

Among their topics is the sentence that gives the movie its title and that Mr. Chomsky has used, by moving one word, to argue that the linguistic information children receive is insufficient to explain how they acquire the grammar of language. â€œIt seems plain,â€ù Mr. Chomsky has written, â€œthat language acquisition is based on the childâ€™s discovery of what, from a formal point of view, is a deep and abstract theory â€” a generative grammar of his language â€” many of the concepts and principles of which are only remotely related to experience by long and intricate chains of unconscious quasi-inferential steps.â€ù

Noam Chomsky is, well, Noam Chomsky: the linguist, philosopher and spectacularly prolific author â€” he has more than 100 books to his name â€” whoâ€™s often better known for his leftist politics. Born on Dec. 7, 1928, Mr. Chomsky belongs to that rare American species, the public intellectual, and his website, www.chomsky.info, testifies to the breadth and depth of his impact in a section called â€œWritings on Chomsky.â€ù Here, you can find more than 100 articles that chart his life, interests and controversies in terse, headline form: from â€œChomskyâ€™s Revolution in Linguisticsâ€ù (1972) to â€œThe Pariahâ€ù (1985); â€œConscience of a Nationâ€ù (2001); â€œDoes Noam Chomsky Hate America?â€ù (2003); and â€œAfter Multiple Denials, CIA Admits to Snooping on Noam Chomskyâ€ù (2013).

One of the pleasures of the movie, though, is that Mr. Gondry remains acutely tuned into these passages, which he addresses with a startling openness and a lack of directorial ego. This is a movie that celebrates the life of a great mind and makes a case for the mind that knows less but keeps on asking.

An easygoing, sometimes tough-going meander through the world of ideas, the animated documentary â€œIs the Man Who Is Tall Happy?â€ù finds the French director Michel Gondry playing wide-eyed student to none other than Noam Chomsky. Theyâ€™re a charmingly unpredictable, appealing match. Mr. Gondry, best known for films like â€œEternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mindâ€ù and â€œThe Green Hornet,â€ù has occasionally dipped into documentary, with titles like the expansive â€œDave Chappelleâ€™s Block Partyâ€ù (in which the comic hosts a rocking Brooklyn block party) and the considerably more hermetic â€œThe Thorn in the Heartâ€ù (about Mr. Gondryâ€™s aunt and her son).

Blissfully unconventional as a documentary and as an intellectual endeavor, â€œIs the Man Who Is Tall Happy?â€ù wonâ€™t tell you everything youâ€™ve always wanted to know about Mr. Chomsky, but its modesty is one of its strengths, along with Mr. Gondryâ€™s entrancing, vibrant illustrations. Both go a long way toward smoothing over some rough patches. Mr. Chomsky speaks in a low, generally unmodulated voice that can border on the soporific, especially when he drifts into abstraction.
When Mr. Chomsky diagrams the title sentence with a marker to reveal its grammatical structure, Mr. Gondry makes those words come richly, cogently, to life.

An endless smear of cross-fades links the filmâ€™s interviews and sightseeing highlights, overlaid with song. Arab residents express legitimate (and, to many residents of changing urban areas, familiar) concerns about their hometown, part of which was deemed a Unesco World Heritage site. But the film feels like a work of community advocacy.

The title refers to a local rite of passage: leaping off the cityâ€™s sheer, 30-foot-plus walls into the waters below. But other than a diverting montage â€” including what looks like a cannonball-jump cam â€” most of this casually constructed film is given over to the pitfalls of urban development and the unresolved tensions between Arabs and the comparatively recent Israeli government. (Riots erupted in 2008.)

The ancient city of Acre, Israel, speaks â€” or at least an Arab subset of its population does â€” in â€œItâ€™s Better to Jump.â€ù Gentrification spurred by public policy and private investment is on the march in this walled town (also known as Akka) on the countryâ€™s northern coast, leading its longstanding Arab residents to fear a loss of identity. Artists, teachers, a restaurateur and a Brown University professor say their piece, politely but firmly, in this rambling talking-heads documentary directed by Gina M. Angelone, and Patrick Alexander Stewart and Mouna B. Stewart, who are husband and wife.

Historical footage of Kennedyâ€™s speeches and other events are interspersed with interviews with historians and writers (Evan Thomas, Peter Kornbluh, Gareth Porter); former Kennedy aides (Dan Fenn and Tazewell T. Shepard Jr., who has since died); Khrushchevâ€™s son Sergei; and Kennedy and Khrushchevâ€™s interpreters from their Vienna summit. A brief section reviews Kennedyâ€™s much-debated policy on Vietnam. Here we see paperwork showing that, at the time of his death, he wanted the United States advisers out.

Early in his presidency, John F. Kennedy feared that in the face of a conflict he might not be in full control of the warmongering operatives in his government. The nuclear threat was palpable, and, as Cory Taylor explains in his well-researched documentary â€œJFK: A President Betrayed,â€ù Kennedy had learned his lesson with the Bay of Pigs invasion. (According to the film, narrated by Morgan Freeman, he blamed himself for not asking the C.I.A. the right questions.)

While the filmâ€™s subtitle screams conspiracy, the documentary only mildly suggests that the assassination of the president was an inside job. Fifty years later, this is one of many additions to the Kennedy catalog. Although itâ€™s more suited for the small screen, it is a worthy entry nonetheless.

The military leadership and some senior advisers thought it would make the United States look weak to reach out to our enemies. Kennedy, however, said, â€œnever fear to negotiate.â€ù This information is well known. What Mr. Taylorâ€™s documentary skillfully examines is how Kennedy subverted these leaders, using emissaries to approach Nikita Khrushchev and Fidel Castro, and how he tried to change a staid approach to foreign policy.
A man of few words is drawn to a family with few blessings in â€œThis Is Where We Live,â€ù a dusty drama about soldiering on without giving in.

And while Ryan Boothâ€™s camera draws a lovely bleakness from the parched Texas landscape, its lens is too often focused on the wearying logistics of Augustâ€™s care. As he is hauled repeatedly from shower to car to bed, I was less worried about his welfare than about the suffering of the actor playing him.

Into this den of wretchedness comes Noah (Marc Menchaca, who also wrote the screenplay and directed with Josh Barrett), a secretive handyman hired by Diane to be her sonâ€™s companion and caretaker. But though the developing bond between the two men â€” one of whom is virtually nonverbal â€” is credible and even touching, the storytelling is too oblique to reel you in. Hints of past tragedies flit across the screen, their specifics withheld in favor of present-day hardships.

Unfortunately, some soldiering will be asked of the viewer, as spending time with characters this miserably off is an endurance test in itself. Set in an arid patch of Texas Hill Country, the film hovers protectively around Diane (C K McFarland), a hardworking matriarch whose grown son, August (Tobias Segal), has cerebral palsy, and whose husband (Ron Hayden) has early-onset dementia. Rounding out this falling-apart brood is a shiftless daughter (Frankie Shaw) with an obnoxious attitude. Given all that, being dirt poor is the least of Dianeâ€™s problems.
â€œThe Christmas Candleâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for the unseasonable recognition of human mortality.

The film has a diligent homeyness (apart from hastily wrapping up the story of an unwed mother introduced at the beginning), and it takes delight in around-the-town bits of business and words like â€œchasubleâ€ù and â€œcodswallop.â€ù Susan Boyle turns up to sing and play a church wardenâ€™s wife. But despite the storyâ€™s Christian resonance and Richmondâ€™s Advent sermons, a few swapped words could yield a passable Santa Claus tale.

When the skeptical Rev. David Richmond (Hans Matheson) takes a post in the parish, he grows intent on displacing the candle as a kind of false idol. For a while, he wins people over by doing chores and home repairs, but then he nearly sets his flock aflame after pridefully installing electric lighting in the church. The character lights up most when visiting a fetching shopgirl (Samantha Barks, who evokes the millennial more than the fin de siÃ¨cle).

The residents of the English village Gladbury in the period holiday film â€œThe Christmas Candleâ€ù might as well be bustling about in a snow globe for all their dimples, yuletide obsession and quaint, consumptive coughs. This film â€” adapted by John Stephenson, a former vice president and creative supervisor of Jim Hensonâ€™s Creature Shop, from the book by the prolific preacher Max Lucado â€” relates the weak-tea parable of a town that receives a wish-giving candle every 25 years from an angel.

The Mike Leigh stalwart Lesley Manville plays the candlemakerâ€™s wife, all aflutter over the angelâ€™s gift, which she and her husband have the duty to bestow. Every family in town has some complaint meriting attention: blindness, muteness, spinsterism.

Mr. Quintero, who lives in Los Angeles, researches the songs, often on the Internet, to authenticate the argot and the gory details of the thug life and feed the narcocorrido genre, which flourishes on both sides of the border and beyond. The film doesnâ€™t explore the history of this outlaw folk music, with its roots going back to the 1930s. These unsophisticated polkas and waltzes sound as stylistically remote from hard-edge, beat-driven hip-hop as any music could be.
â€œNarco Culturaâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for grisly, graphic images of violence and drug-taking, and brief nudity.

The eerie lack of traffic in the city suggests an occupied territory whose residents are so frightened of the kingpins that they hide indoors. Business has fled the city since kidnapping, extortion and murder became rampant. The horrific statistics compare the murder rate in JuÃ¡rez (thousands every year) with that of El Paso, cited here as one of Americaâ€™s safest cities.
â€œWith an AK-47 and a bazooka on my shoulder/Cross my path and Iâ€™ll chop your head off/Weâ€™re bloodthirsty, crazy and we like to kill.â€ù

â€œNarco Culturaâ€ù feels like two short films sandwiched together to make a feature. One is a shallow pop-music documentary focusing on Mr. Quintero. The other is an equally superficial portrait of the embattled Ciudad JuÃ¡rez, across the border from El Paso. There is nothing here that hasnâ€™t been more thoroughly documented in other studies of the drug-related crime that grips JuÃ¡rez.

If you donâ€™t know Spanish and hear this rollicking waltz, it sounds more like a happy wedding song than a celebration of murder. But thatâ€™s a contradiction built into the Mexican folk style known as narcocorrido, in Shaul Schwarzâ€™s documentary â€œNarco Cultura.â€ù

As presented by the film, the content of these deceptively jolly guitar-and-accordion-based songs â€” performed by Edgar Quintero and his Mexican-American band Buknas de CuliacÃ¡n â€” is hard to reconcile with their traditional Mexican flavor. One talking head calls narcocorrido the â€œnew hip-hop,â€ù for its unabashed glorification of the violence of Mexican drug lords. The movie has several scenes of audiences excitedly singing along as the band performs these stories of murder and mayhem.

This part of the film focuses on Riccardo Soto, an intrepid forensic investigator known as Richi, who has lost several colleagues to murder. The camera accompanies Mr. Soto to crime scenes, and there are many shots of dead bodies and bullet-riddled cars. The evidence he amasses is rarely produced in court for fear of lethal reprisal. By now, itâ€™s hardly news that, in JuÃ¡rez, the criminals are winning the Mexican governmentâ€™s war against the cartels.

The teenage Philomena (Sophie Kennedy Clark) becomes pregnant in 1952 and is sent to a convent in Roscrea, Ireland. She spends several years in virtual slave labor, working in the convent laundry. It is part punishment and part compensation to the nuns who looked after her during childbirth. These prisonlike convent laundries, where shamed parents exiled their â€œbadâ€ù daughters, were the subject of Peter Mullanâ€™s 2002 film, â€œThe Magdalene Sisters,â€ù and of a Joni Mitchell song.

Ms. Dench, who is more accustomed to playing cool, imperious matriarchs than twinkling little old ladies, knows exactly how far to push the inherent cuteness of her role without it curdling into shtick. Her Philomena, for all her surface prudishness, shyly admits to having happy, guilt-free memories of the liaison that got her in trouble. Even more surprisingly, she professes a matter-of-fact acceptance of homosexuality. Her equanimity on the subject may be a little far-fetched given her age and background, but her independent spirit suggests that such an attitude is not beyond the realm of possibility.

The film widens its focus when Martinâ€™s sleuthing reveals the probable whereabouts of Anthony, who worked for the Reagan administration. Philomena insists on accompanying Martin when he flies to Washington. The movie canâ€™t resist finding comedy in this unlikely team. Philomena, a devotee of romance novels, tries Martinâ€™s patience by relaying the plots of the novels she reads. Instead of visiting the Lincoln Memorial, she would rather watch the movie â€œBig Mommaâ€™s Houseâ€ù on television at the hotel. Martin is arrogant, bordering on boorish in his pursuit of the story, and Mr. Coogan does an impressive job of muting his comedianâ€™s instincts to paint him as intimidatingly brusque.

Ms. Denchâ€™s dignified performance and the screenplay â€” adapted by her co-star Steve Coogan and Jeff Pope from Martin Sixsmithâ€™s 2009 nonfiction book, â€œThe Lost Child of Philomena Leeâ€ù â€” stabilize a volatile blend of ingredients. In less confident hands, the film could have been a mawkish, rambling tear-jerker.

The girls are allowed to see their children only one hour a day, and Philomena is forced to sign a contract agreeing never to inquire into her sonâ€™s whereabouts. In the filmâ€™s most anguished scene, she is beside herself as she watches from a convent window as the child, Anthony, is whisked away in a car by a wealthy American couple. The 3-year-old boy had been sold for 1,000 pounds.
â€œPhilomenaâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for some strong language and sexual references.

Even through improbable moments and abrupt changes of pace and tone, Ms. Dench and Mr. Coogan hold the movie together and pull forward a story that ends where it began. In giving equal weight to Martinâ€™s skepticism and Philomenaâ€™s faith, it manages to have its cake and eat it too.

Fifty years later, Philomena, in her 70s, meets Martin Sixsmith (Mr. Coogan), a onetime BBC foreign correspondent who was later ousted as a spin doctor in Tony Blairâ€™s government and is now obliged to support himself with freelance journalism assignments. Martin, a cynic and an atheist, persuades an initially reluctant Philomena to cooperate with him on a magazine article telling her story. When they visit the convent, they are coldly informed that all records from the time were destroyed in a fire.

In â€œPhilomena,â€ù Judi Denchâ€™s portrayal of a stubborn, kindhearted Irish Catholic trying to discover what became of the toddler she was forced to give up as a teenager is so quietly moving that it feels lit from within. A major theme of this film from Stephen Frears is forgiveness. Ms. Denchâ€™s Philomena Lee glows with the radiance of someone serene in her faith despite inhumane treatment by the church. That she makes you believe her character has the capacity to forgive provides the movie with a solid moral center.

â€œPhilomenaâ€ù has many facets. It is a comedic road movie, a detective story, an infuriated anticlerical screed, and an inquiry into faith and the limitations of reason, all rolled together. Fairly sophisticated about spiritual matters, it takes pains to distinguish faith from institutionalized piety. It also has a surprising political subtext in its comparison of the churchâ€™s oppression and punishment of unmarried sex â€” what the conventâ€™s harsh mother superior denounces as â€œcarnal incontinenceâ€ù â€” with homophobia and the United States governmentâ€™s reluctance to deal with the AIDS crisis in the 1980s. Philomena recalls sensing that her son, even when he was a tot, would grow up to be gay.

When â€œThe Hunger Games: Catching Fireâ€ù opens, its lethally resourceful teenage heroine, Katniss Everdeen, is crouching in a forest, surveying a terrain as pristine as the one once scouted by American Indians. However pastoral, this isnâ€™t the forest primeval but the very edge of free land outside the impoverished zone in which Katniss (Jennifer Lawrence) and her relatives, friends and the other starved souls labor for Panem, the authoritarian state built on the ruins of North America after a catastrophic war. Itâ€™s here that she hunts game to feed her family and where this startlingly new pioneer â€” with her bow and arrows, leather jacket and boots, primitive individualism and totally awesome strength of character â€” was forged.

A thrillingly atypical heroine, Katniss is the heart, soul and bloodied embodiment of the series and the primary reason that both the book and screen versions soar above the usual adventure-fiction slag heap. Like most cultural sensations, which invariably owe part of their success to their recognizability (familiarity breeds revenue), â€œThe Hunger Gamesâ€ù builds on stories deep in our collective databanks, from the Greek myth of the Minotaur to the fall of Rome, and â€œSurvivor,â€ù the seemingly indestructible reality TV franchise. Like the 2000 Japanese movie â€œBattle Royale,â€ù to which it bears some resemblance, â€œThe Hunger Gamesâ€ù works because it hits that sweet spot where classical myth meets contemporary anxiety to become a pop mind-blower.

â€œCatching Fireâ€ù isnâ€™t a great work of art but itâ€™s a competent, at times exciting movie and it does something that better, more artistically notable movies often fail to do: It speaks to its moment in time. â€œThe mythic America,â€ù the literary critic Leslie Fiedler memorably wrote, â€œis boyhood.â€ù One of the things that â€œThe Hunger Games,â€ù on the page and on the screen, suggests is that the myth is changing. Boys (and men) are still boys, of course, including in movies, but the very existence of Katniss â€” who fights her own battles, and kisses and leaves the boys, only sometimes to save them â€” suggests cultural consumers are ready for change, even if most cultural producers remain foolishly stuck in the past. Itâ€™s unlikely Katniss will lead the real revolution the movies need, but a woman can dream.

For now, though, as the story builds and builds and sometimes drags, and the studio squeezes the franchise for all itâ€™s worth, Katniss primarily needs to irritate Snow, which finds Ms. Lawrence throwing variations of her scowl in Mr. Sutherlandâ€™s direction, while his caterpillar eyebrows jitterbug above his trademark silky-sinister smirk.

Metaphors aside, the games are principally a heavy stick that Panem, led by President Snow (an amused Donald Sutherland), uses to keep the progressively restive populace in check. President Snow is the big bad daddy of the series, the patriarchal heavy whom Katniss â€” who more or less took her own fatherâ€™s place, after he died â€” is destined to overthrow. Something is in the air, she realizes in â€œCatching Fire,â€ù when she glimpses seditious graffiti and other signs of dissent.
â€œThe Hunger Games: Catching Fireâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Murder and mayhem.

The script, by Simon Beaufoy and Michael deBruyn (a pseudonym for the screenwriter Michael Arndt), effectively distills the novel to the essentials from Katniss and Peetaâ€™s victory lap, which involves a visit to the Capitol and the other districts, includes batted lashes and chaste kisses, and finally leads to the main event: a new round of games that pits past winners against one another in an ultimate death match called the Quarter Quell.

There, on a simulated island created by the new head gamemaster (an uncomfortable-looking Mr. Hoffman), Katniss and Peeta make friends as they fight foes and endure buckets of blood, poisonous fog, shrieking monkeys and, in a scarily visceral scene, birds that mimic the voices and screams of the combatantsâ€™ loved ones, as if they were under torture.

Like a lot of middle sections, â€œCatching Fireâ€ù at once expands on the first part of the series and functions as a feature-long teaser for what will happen next. Shortly after the movie gets going, after Katniss has stashed away a rabbit from one of her snares and cozied up to Gale (Liam Hemsworth), one of her uneasy love interests (sheâ€™s the reluctant party), she is sent on a victory tour with the second one, Peeta (Josh Hutcherson). In the first â€œHunger Games,â€ù Katniss and Peeta won the annual contest of the title, a match that pits a girl and a boy, 12 to 18, from each of the 12 Panem districts against one another in a battle to the death, a setup that speaks to its young adult fans and takes adolescent bullying to gladiatorial extremes.

Mr. Lawrence gives â€œCatching Fireâ€ù a tougher, less sentimental feel this time around â€” there appears to be more kissing but less mooning about â€” that fits the material and Ms. Lawrenceâ€™s gift for projecting unaffected indomitableness. The actress is more expressive here than she was in the first movie, where her lack of convincing affect, including clenching fear, was at odds with the violent stakes. Thereâ€™s no indeterminacy here, either in her performance or the direction, which both go a long way to clarifying Katniss and turning a girl with a bow into the charismatic figure she was always meant to be. (Itâ€™s nice, too, that the consistently appealing Elizabeth Banks, as the kaleidoscopic kook Effie Trinket, is allowed to deliver an actual performance this time.)

â€œCatching Fireâ€ù is the follow-up to â€œThe Hunger Gamesâ€ù and the second in what will be four movie adaptations of Suzanne Collinsâ€™s fantastically successful book trilogy. (The studio behind the series, Lionsgate, is splitting the final book into two flicks.) Itâ€™s largely satisfying as far as screen adventures go, and comes fully loaded with special effects and action scenes, and embellished with the usual brand-name character actors, including the new arrivals Philip Seymour Hoffman, Jeffrey Wright and Amanda Plummer. It also has a different director, Francis Lawrence (replacing Gary Ross), who showed he knows his way around the post-apocalypse with the Will Smith vehicle â€œI Am Legend.â€ù (Given Katnissâ€™s increasingly valiant trajectory, that title would have been apt for this dystopian romp.)

Despite dropping the occasional personal tidbit â€” like Mr. Stewartâ€™s profound dyslexia â€” this time capsule of â€™70s sideburns and shaggy haircuts is no biopic. Rather, itâ€™s a vintage flashbulb moment of two men at the peak of their talents, one on his way to securing his second world championship, and the other between the twin triumphs of â€œRosemaryâ€™s Babyâ€ù and â€œChinatown.â€ù A charming coda of contemporary footage finds the friends reviewing Mr. Stewartâ€™s late-career role in improving the safety standards of a sport that, he says, once killed two out of three drivers.

Cleverly timed to ride the exhaust of Ron Howardâ€™s rubber-burning â€œRush,â€ù the film watches its two stars (and longtime friends) enjoy practice laps, a fancy dinner and a hotel breakfast. Conversation is largely confined to technical details as Mr. Stewart â€” Scottish brogue and preternatural calm to the fore â€” explains the circuit, every gear shift, manhole cover and hairpin bend burned in his memory. In the background, celebrities and royals drift in and out of the frame, and racing luminaries, among them FranÃ§ois Cevert and Graham Hill (both now deceased) compare notes on the impending race.

The combination of fast cars, gorgeous men and Monte Carlo sounds a lot like heaven, but Frank Simonâ€™s â€œWeekend of a Championâ€ù will appeal mostly to motor-racing enthusiasts and movie archaeologists. Covering four days in May 1971, when the director Roman Polanski accompanied the Formula One champion Jackie Stewart to the 29th Monaco Grand Prix, this newly restored and updated documentary offers a minor sidebar to two major careers.
â€œIn the 1970s, motor racing was dangerous, and sex was safe,â€ù Mr. Stewart says, grinning. Mr. Polanski, somewhat ruefully, has no choice but to agree.

The only problem with that Times Square hallucination, with its spinning camera and swirling color, is that it feels too short, which is true of the movie over all, despite the dragginess brought on by its thin plot, clichÃ©s and bouts of overfamiliarity. And as you listen to the gorgeous â€œHush Child (Get You Through This Silent Night)â€ù or a blow-the-roof-off version of Stevie Wonderâ€™s â€œAsâ€ù â€” the executive music producer is Raphael Saadiq â€” it becomes increasingly clear that the entire movie probably should have been sung. Because, at her best in â€œBlack Nativity,â€ù Ms. Lemmons, who also helped write some songs, has found a way to exalt the past while remaining rooted in the present in a movie that flirts with nonrealist theatricality even as it barrels right toward old-fashioned cornball entertainment.

â€œBlack Nativityâ€ù uses its songs to advance the story â€” characters simply begin singing their hopes and fears â€” but it also uses them to represent both Langstonâ€™s reality and his fantasies. Thereâ€™s always a degree of blissful unreality when someone starts warbling in the middle of the street in a musical, as happens in this movie. Or when Aretha â€” Ms. Bassett sings! (kind of) â€” has an imaginary duet with Naima through the magic of montage, the scene cutting between the women in different cities. But thereâ€™s something particularly liberating in musical dream sequences, in which anything can go and sometimes does, as when Langston dreams up a Nativity in Times Square with camels and turbaned celebrants in a sequence that mirrors Hughesâ€™s own creative process.

To open the play up, or maybe dust it off, Ms. Lemmons has jettisoned much of the originalâ€™s inner workings, including its comic shepherds, heavy sermonizing and Hughesâ€™s staging instructions. Here, the time is now, and the place is principally Harlem. Itâ€™s there that the teenage Langston (Jacob Latimore) is sent by his struggling single mother, Naima (Jennifer Hudson), to spend Christmas with his grandparents, the righteously overbearing Rev. Cornell Cobbs (Forest Whitaker) and his warmer half, Aretha (Angela Bassett). A stranger to his grandparents â€” the plot hinges on a family quarrel â€” Langston moves in grudgingly, wearing the mask of masculine cool even as he sings â€œMotherless Child.â€ù As the camera sweeps across 125th Street and past old Harlem and new, Langstonâ€™s world opens, and mysteries hover at the edge, including one named Loot (a quietly charismatic Tyrese Gibson).
â€œBlack Nativityâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Thereâ€™s a gun, but, otherwise, this is squeaky clean.

Directed by Kasi Lemmons, â€œBlack Nativityâ€ù is itself a reworking of the Langston Hughes â€œgospel song-playâ€ù of the title. Originally called â€œWasnâ€™t That a Mighty Day!,â€ù the play relates the Nativity story with all black characters, telling it partly through traditional carols and spirituals â€” from â€œJoy to the Worldâ€ù to â€œMy Wayâ€™s Cloudyâ€ù â€” as well as through passages from the Gospel and Hughesâ€™s writing. â€œThereâ€™s fire in the east/Thereâ€™s fire in the west/Thereâ€™s fire among the Methodistsâ€ù is one of its funnier lines. Only two narratively thin acts long, it commences with Jesusâ€™ birth and ends with songs and sermons that, for better or worse, suggest what itâ€™s like to be in church. (â€œThereâ€™s nobody like the Lord!â€ù) When it opened off Broadway in 1961, with a cast including Marion Williams, it turned the audience into a congregation.

An actress turned director of â€œEveâ€™s Bayouâ€ù and â€œTalk to Me,â€ù Ms. Lemmons has a tough time finding her tone. From scene to scene, the actors are good and then less so, while the direction wavers from assured to unsteady. The setup in Baltimore, where Naima and Langston are facing eviction, is unpromisingly static, as are Ms. Hudsonâ€™s and Mr. Latimoreâ€™s performances, which both improve dramatically when they start singing. Ms. Hudson is an innately warm presence whoâ€™s still finding her way as an actress, but she generates so much good will that even when sheâ€™s not letting loose that torrent of a voice, she holds your attention. The same goes for Mr. Latimore, whose character leads with his petulant childâ€™s chin but follows through with beseeching eyes.

Sometimes it takes just one thing â€” a gesture, a look, the quality of light on a face â€” to fall for a movie. For me, that moment came in the musical â€œBlack Nativity,â€ù when several characters, including a young couple â€” Jo-Jo and his very pregnant companion, Maria (Luke James and Grace Gibson) â€” sing a sharply reworked â€œSilent Night.â€ù â€œThey say this is your punishment for such poor judgment,â€ù Maria sings on a cold Harlem night. â€œHow you gonna feed it?â€ù That line slips by quickly, but with that two-letter word â€” â€œitâ€ù â€” the movie ferociously closes the gap between one homeless child born into poverty and all the forgotten rest.

The older coupleâ€™s relationship, a brooding face-off played out in the cold comfort of their well-appointed home, is overshadowed by choppily assembled intrigue and the martyrizing of Ye. Mr. Chenâ€™s camera placement often feels too much like a bid to mix things up (as strained as some of the fireworks in the WikiLeaks feature â€œThe Fifth Estateâ€ù), and the occasionally goofy soundtrack cues seem to have been bought in bulk. While the film tackles an admittedly slippery contemporary moment, its grasp is weakened by divided attentions and unwieldy approaches.

Chen Kaige, who remains best known for directing the Cannes prizewinner â€œFarewell My Concubine,â€ù shouldnâ€™t be faulted for attempting a state-of-the-nation look at China today with his new movie, â€œCaught in the Web.â€ù But this story of cyberbullying and its discontents, though harboring flinty truths and staffed with popular domestic stars, is a messy collision of strained portrayals, semi-comic incidents and tear-jerking tactics.

In Mr. Chenâ€™s movie, an executiveâ€™s assistant, Ye Lanqiu (Gao Yuanyuan), is tormented by mobs on the web after a budding reporter films her denying an elderly man a seat on a bus. Per an unnecessarily overloaded premise (the film is adapted from a popular novel about the Internet, â€œHuman Flesh Searchâ€ù), the source of her irritability is unimpeachable: a diagnosis of cancer. The witnessâ€™s sister, a journalist and producer (Yao Chen, a social-media phenomenon in China), picks up the story but does not know that her live-in boyfriend (Mark Chao) has been hired by Ye as a companion for her last days on earth. Meanwhile, Yeâ€™s understanding but imperious boss (Wang Xueqi) lords it over his wife (Chen Hong) after she tries to turn the screws over suspected hanky-panky with Ye.

There is a palpable nostalgia in this 40-year-old film (comparable with what can be found in Raymond Depardonâ€™s 2008 documentary â€œModern Lifeâ€ù), but it may also resonate among 21st-century devotees of the agrarian and the artisanal. With their hand-rolled cigarettes, free-range chickens and pour-over coffee, Jules and FÃ©licie would be the coolest kids in Brooklyn.

Both were born in 1891, but they represent a way of life that is much older. Jules, a blacksmith, works with a hand-cranked bellows and a battered metal stove, hammering out hasps and hinges with an ease and precision that represent generations of handed-down know-how. His labor has an almost musical quality, enhanced by Mr. Benichetiâ€™s sharp and subtle sound design.

Mr. Benicheti, who died in 2011, was in his 20s when he began working on â€œCousin Jules,â€ù and in spite of the age of its subjects, it is full of the ambition and passion of youth. It is also hemmed in by its formal conceits. There is almost no dialogue, and it is hard to tell whether the narrowness of the coupleâ€™s existence is being observed by the filmmakers or imposed by the editing process. It is clear that they are taciturn, practical people, but the filmâ€™s insistence on their self-reliance, and their isolation from modernity, feels exaggerated after a while, especially when a significant death goes unmentioned.

â€œCousin Julesâ€ù played at a few North American festivals shortly after it was completed, but its technical demands were beyond what most art-house theaters could handle. The digital restoration opening on Wednesday at the Film Forum â€” the movieâ€™s first American commercial release â€” conveys the rich images and subtle sounds that Mr. Benicheti and his crew captured during their visits to a rugged farmstead in the hills of Burgundy, the home of Jules and FÃ©licie Guiteaux.

Modern documentary filmmaking has been often defined by speed and portability. That was true in the late â€™50s and early â€™60s, when lightweight machinery helped give birth to the cinÃ©ma vÃ©ritÃ© and direct cinema movements, and it is certainly true today, when smartphones and tiny digital cameras turn everyday life into a collective vÃ©ritÃ© project.

But there have always been anomalies, films that use slower, more cumbersome methods to contemplate reality. One of these is â€œCousin Jules,â€ù Dominique Benichetiâ€™s slow and quiet study of French rural life, shot from 1968 to 1973 in a sumptuous wide-screen format with stereo sound.

The first part of â€œCousin Julesâ€ù follows the couple through a day that is most likely the composite of many such days: chores punctuated by lunch in the kitchen and afternoon coffee in the barn. Jules and FÃ©licie are residents of what is sometimes called â€œla France profonde,â€ù a steadfast agricultural domain that has existed in parallel, and sometimes in opposition, to the industry and cosmopolitanism of Paris and other French cities.

Do they have friends? Any other family? Political opinions? Religious beliefs? In suspending such questions, and in subordinating the reality of their lives to what is in effect an art project, the filmmakers treat Jules and FÃ©licie as exotic specimens rather than fellow citizens. There is no doubt that this condescension is unintentional, but it is also hard to miss. â€œCousin Julesâ€ù is in many ways a wonder to see and hear, but there is less to it than meets the eye.

The sisters become estranged when Anna falls in love at first sight with Hans (Santino Fontana), a too-good-to-be-true prince from a neighboring kingdom, and Elsa forbids them to marry. With one wave of Elsaâ€™s hand, eternal winter descends on Arendelle. She is so horrified by her destructive gift that she retreats to a remote ice palace atop a mountain.

â€œFrozen,â€ù for all its innovations, is not fundamentally revolutionary. Its animated characters are the same familiar, blank-faced, big-eyed storybook figures. But they are a little more psychologically complex than their Disney forerunners. Its princesses may gaze at a glass ceiling, but most are not ready to shatter it.
Thatâ€™s a little outside of natureâ€™s laws!
â€œFrozenâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for some action and mild, rude humor.

Allegorically, â€œFrozenâ€ù lacks the purity and elemental power of a classic myth like â€œBeauty and the Beast,â€ù but at least its storytelling is fairly coherent, and its gleaming dream world of snow and ice is one of the most visually captivating environments to be found in a Disney animated film. There are moments when you may feel that you are inside a giant crystal chandelier frosted with diamonds.

As Arendelle suffers through the deep freeze, the resourceful Anna, who still loves her sister, is determined to track down Elsa, who she believes can reverse the spell. Thus begin Annaâ€™s adventures in mountain climbing. Along the way, she meets Kristoff (Jonathan Groff), a rugged ice dealer who guides a reindeer-driven sleigh. During their â€œWizard of Ozâ€ù-like quest, they are joined by Olaf (Josh Gad), that sweet, wisecracking snowman.

Those are among the unconventional characters in the new Disney 3-D animated movie musical, â€œFrozen,â€ù very loosely based on the Hans Christian Andersen fairy tale â€œThe Snow Queen.â€ù They are significant departures from tradition in a film that shakes up the hyper-romantic â€œprincessâ€ù formula that has stood Disney in good stead for decades and that has grown stale. Treacly, kissy-kissy endings are not enough anymore. Nowadays, a princess has to show her mettle and earn her happily-ever-after stripes.
Like his peculiar brain-dear.

It all takes place in the fictional Scandinavian land of Arendelle, whose king and queen die in a shipwreck, leaving the country in the hands of Elsa (the voice of Idina Menzel), the elder of two daughters. This blond, high-strung princess has a secret problem. If she isnâ€™t extremely careful, everything around her freezes when she takes off her protective gloves and waves her hands. Elsaâ€™s best friend is her impulsive redheaded younger sister, Anna (Kristen Bell), whom she nearly freezes to death by accident.
So heâ€™s got a few flaws.

If â€œFrozenâ€ù still has one foot planted in 19th-century childrenâ€™s literature, good and evil are not so clear-cut. The title character of the original fairy tale was evil. Her 21st-century descendant is merely confused and scared. As always, love is the solution to everything. When nothing can thaw the icy heart of the frightened Elsa, love does the trick, but in this case it is sisterly loyalty and devotion rather than romantic attachment.

It canâ€™t be accidental that â€œFrozen,â€ù with its two female leads, one voiced by the original Elphaba in â€œWickedâ€ù (Ms. Menzel), has a lot in common with that Broadway juggernaut and seems ready-made for theatrical adaptation. For this journey, instead of a broomstick, take mittens, snow boots and steaming hot chocolate.

â€œFrozenâ€ù has eight original songs by the married team of Kristen Anderson-Lopez and Robert Lopez, musical theater veterans whose blend of playful wit and sentimentality here comes closer than any score for a Disney animated film to capturing the charm of the Alan Menken-Howard Ashman collaboration in its glory days. One song, â€œFixer Upper,â€ù sung by a bunch of trolls promoting the charms of an imperfect eligible bachelor to a picky princess, is genuinely amusing:

A beautiful princess with magical powers that she canâ€™t control; an adorable snowman, with buck teeth and a carrot for a nose, who longs to sunbathe because no one ever told him that heat melts ice; a picture-perfect prince who is revealed to be a scheming, opportunistic cad.
So heâ€™s a bit of a fixer-upper,

Is it significant that Jennifer Lee, who directed â€œFrozenâ€ù with Chris Buck, is billed as the first female director of a Disney animated feature film? Perhaps. Ms. Lee is credited as the screenwriter of a story that she and Mr. Buck developed with Shane Morris. That screenplay cautiously incorporates some slangy contemporary argot, but its tone is never desperately hip in the manner of the â€œShrekâ€ù movies. Most of what fun there is revolves around Olaf, a classic Disney sidekick.
His thing with the reindeer.
â€œHomefrontâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Guns, drugs, expletives.

Thereâ€™s another big Plot Point, but this one happens off screen: Philâ€™s wife conveniently dies, which finds him retiring from the D.E.A. and moving to Louisiana, that land of Spanish moss and filmmaking tax incentives, with his 10-year old, Maddy (Izabela Vidovic). There, Phil plays mother and father to Maddy, while they settle into a handsome, sprawling house and ride their horses under the atmospherically weeping trees. Thereâ€™s even a Romantic Interest (Rachelle Lefevre) to suggest that Phil may, you know, one day heal. But then Maddy ends up in a fight with a school bully, whose mother, Cassie (Kate Bosworth), then comes a-howling. Itâ€™s unclear whether Maddyâ€™s fight is the first Plot Point or if Philâ€™s fight with the boyâ€™s father is, but it all leads to the Hero Facing His Problem.

Thereâ€™s a lot of plot, some of it nonsensical, and a lot of action, some of it risible. The story opens with Mr. Stathamâ€™s character, Phil Broker, in a fright wig and biker clothes, pretending to be a heavy. An undercover drug enforcement agent, Phil is soon waving a gun in a darkly lit, jaggedly patched-together gun battle that pits bikers against the law and ends with his being threatened by a biker kingpin. This is basically a Hells Angels-style version of â€œIâ€™ll get you, my pretty, and your little dog, too.â€ù It also appears to be what screenwriting gurus like Syd Field call the Inciting Incident. In other words, Something Happens that sets the plot on its nutty way, and the director, Gary Fleder (â€œKiss the Girls,â€ù â€œRunaway Juryâ€ù),competently connects the programmatic dots.

Nothing says Thanksgiving like a beat-â€™em-up written by Sylvester Stallone in which Jason Statham gets to knock the stuffing out of James Franco. If you think thatâ€™s a spoiler, youâ€™ve either never seen an audience-pandering movie or the poster for â€œHomefront,â€ù which shows a snake-eyed Mr. Franco glowering, in what appears to be hell, under an image of the stern-looking Mr. Statham overlaid with an American flag and embracing a child. The movie is as blunt an instrument as the poster, but itâ€™s also crammed with enough moving parts and unexpected distractions (Winona Ryder as a â€œmeth whoreâ€ù) to make it an indefensibly enjoyable piece of exploitation hackwork.

Superficially, this would be the apparently inbred cretins who populate this rural American freak show and are either doing or making meth amphetamine. First among these is Cassie, a hollowed-out harridan who sics her meth-making brother, Gator (Mr. Franco), on Phil. The men are a ridiculous match in an increasingly preposterous movie â€” a fine Ms. Ryder plays Sheryl, Gatorâ€™s partner in meth and corn-pone accents â€” but Mr. Franco rolls his eyeballs with just enough commitment in his dinner theater version of the charismatic Southern psycho. All crazies, it seems, lead back to Robert Mitchum in â€œThe Night of the Hunter.â€ù Itâ€™s hard not to think that Mr. Franco, an irrepressible sly boots, took this role only so that he could get beaten up by Mr. Statham â€” well, that and the paycheck.

And the second half of â€œOldboyâ€ù succumbs to his confusion as it tries to infuse a busy plot with tragic intensity. Mr. Brolin is at his best when Joe is still confined in that creepy hotel room, where he evolves from shaggy self-pity toward disciplined determination. This transformation â€” for which the actor gained and lost a lot of weight â€” is the most haunting and touching part of the movie, the only part that strikes a genuine chord of feeling.

I wonâ€™t say too much about that, except to note that Mr. Brolin has some nasty encounters with Samuel L. Jackson and Sharlto Copley, and that Mr. Lee tries his hand as a choreographer of stylized, super-bloody violence. Some of the fight scenes are staged with the gaudy flair of musical dance numbers, and at times they approach the grisly, brightly hued surrealism that is Mr. Parkâ€™s specialty.
â€œOldboyâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Blood, gore and skin.

After an epic bender, Joe wakes up in a tidy hotel room from which there is no escape. Meals â€” usually a pint of vodka and some Chinese takeout dumplings â€” are delivered through a slot at the bottom of the door, and a wall-mounted television marks the passage of time with news events that are as familiar to the audience as they are mystifying to Joe.

The question that propels â€œOldboy,â€ù Spike Leeâ€™s kinetic and colorful new movie, is â€œWhy?â€ù Why has somebody â€” for a long time, we donâ€™t know who â€” taken the trouble to kidnap Joe Doucett (Josh Brolin), an alcoholic advertising executive, and lock him up in a fake hotel room for 20 years? Why has Joe been framed for a murder and then, after making a mental journey to madness and back, set free?

Afterward, there are action, swearing, sex and frenetic exposition. Mr. Parkâ€™s â€œOldboy,â€ù based on a manga by Garon Tsuchiya and Nobuaki Minegishi, has a baroque back story that Mr. Lee struggles to keep on the right side of preposterousness. If you have seen the earlier version, you can occupy yourself with point-by-point comparisons. If not, you may find yourself swerving between bafflement and mild astonishment, wondering how a movie that works so hard to generate intensity and surprise can feel so routine and bereft of genuine imagination.

The result is often puzzling but rarely lifeless. The action begins in a smudgy, rain-soaked city (not quite New York, but not quite not New York, given a metallic griminess by Sean Bobbittâ€™s cinematography), through which Joe barrels in a state of drunken desperation. A raging alcoholic and an all-around jerk, he seems richly deserving of whatever humiliations lie in store. But the punishment he receives seems disproportionate to his overall worthlessness, and this discrepancy is part of the filmâ€™s mystery.

Once he is out, there are a few Rip Van Winkle-ish winks at how much has changed. â€œWhere are all the pay phones?â€ù he wonders at one point, and he is mystified by smartphone ringtones. Helping him with these technical difficulties â€” and with other problems â€” is Marie (Elizabeth Olsen), a social worker who also awakens Joeâ€™s protective instincts. Tormented by his failure to keep his wife and young daughter safe before his captivity, he wants to atone, as well as to take revenge on his captors.

A related question would be why Mr. Lee devoted so much time and labor to remaking a South Korean revengerâ€™s tale, originally directed by Park Chan-wook, that has acquired a passionate cult following in international fanboy circles. Reviewing the original in The New York Times in 2005, Manohla Dargis noted Mr. Parkâ€™s stylistic debt to past and present filmmakers, including Stanley Kubrick, Luis BuÃ±uel and David Fincher. Mr. Lee, a true original who sometimes wears his influences on his sleeve, is thus in the potentially awkward position of replicating a movie notable for its imitations of other movies.

Vengeance â€” as a dramatic device, an excuse for mayhem and an emotional catalyst â€” has always been his particular obsession. But it has not figured prominently in Mr. Leeâ€™s work. His heroes tend to be proud and purposeful, but also ambivalent. What makes characters like Mookie in â€œDo The Right Thingâ€ù and Monty Brogan in â€œ25th Hourâ€ù interesting is their capacity for hesitant reflection in the midst of action. Joe Doucett is simply confused.
Directed by Sini Anderson
Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.
1 hour 12 minutes; not rated

To a certain extent, the building up feels like pent-up recompense for the hostility that Ms. Hanna faced and confronted. From early poetry performances through Bikini Killâ€™s â€œgirls to the frontâ€ù shows, sheâ€™s shown singing and advocating for a womanâ€™s right to be her own protagonist and antagonist. Band members and leading lights fling out one-liners and dish tidbits from the scene.

Kathleen Hanna, the feminist punk hero of the 1990s and beyond, is the main event of the fast-moving documentary â€œThe Punk Singer.â€ù Directed by Sini Anderson and co-produced by the music video veteran Tamra Davis, the film is less about music than it is a celebration of Ms. Hanna: most famous as the frontwoman for the poster band Bikini Kill and later for Le Tigre. Though freshly rendered with lively interviews and concert video clips full of prickly, lo-fi energy, Ms. Hanna and her message of empowerment are disappointingly translated very nearly into a cult of personality in this filmâ€™s idolizing portrayal.

Ms. Hanna herself appears in new interviews and in footage showing her dealing with the effects of Lyme disease. (The illness led to her uncharacteristic quiet during the mid-2000s.) The film shifts gears from the Bikini Kill parts to depict her climb back into the spotlight (doted upon by her husband, Adam Horovitz of the Beastie Boys). The poignancy of being betrayed by her body, after fighting for the prerogative of its use and portrayal, is the filmâ€™s subtlest undercurrent.
Ms. Hannaâ€™s creativity and force are catching. But other voices are needed to evaluate her achievements with a fuller sense of cultural context and perspective.

The adventure is related partly through the eyes of Carrie Lee, an American lawyer and the sister of the filmâ€™s director, Wendy J. N. Lee, causing it to sound too often like an interloperâ€™s travel video. And much is made of the fact that the trekkers picked up litter as they walked: more than 800 pounds. Thatâ€™s a little more than a pound per person, for 450 miles of walking. Hmm.
1 hour 12 minutes; not rated

â€œIt is with the simple message to reduce and reuse that the trekkers push forward,â€ù the narrator, Daryl Hannah, says, a catchphrase that seems incongruous and somewhat condescending in a region whose inhabitants seem to have very little. The purpose was no doubt more spiritual than the film conveys; if so, the execution doesnâ€™t do the effort justice.

The film records a 450-mile walk by 700 people, an event intended to promote environmental responsibility in a region where glaciers are showing the effects of climate change. The trekkers were led by the Gyalwang Drukpa, a Buddhist spiritual leader, but included people from a variety of faiths and nationalities.
Directed by Wendy J. N. Lee

â€œPad Yatra: A Green Odysseyâ€ù documents a very long walk by a large group of people whose eco-friendly intentions were no doubt good. But the film has an adventure-travel feel that leaves you wondering if this trek through the Himalayas mostly benefited the people who were doing the trekking.
In English and Tibetan, with English subtitles
Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

The film not only explores the fruitlessness of trying to stabilize shorelines that nature prefers to keep in flux, but it also looks at issues like who benefits from, and who pays for, these expensive efforts. None of it sounds equitable or rational.

Someone in â€œShored Up,â€ù a thought-provoking documentary about the folly of shoreline construction in the Hurricane Sandy age, compares beach replenishment to the sentence of Sisyphus: pile up the sand, only to see it washed away; repeat endlessly. By the end of the film, you get the sense that the job of trying to raise an alarm about this subject is also an exercise in futility. â€œAngels Singâ€ù is a music video disguised as a holiday movie, populated by musicians disguised as actors. â€œMandela: Long Walk to Freedomâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for scenes of intense violence, sexual content and strong language.

Mr. Elba doesnâ€™t look much like Mr. Mandela. He is considerably beefier. But he has the same sharp, hyper-alert gaze that acknowledges the worldâ€™s horrors while looking above and beyond toward a humanitarian ideal. He also captures Mr. Mandelaâ€™s distinctive accent with an uncanny accuracy. Mr. Elba is completely convincing as a natural leader with a ferocious drive. His lowest moment comes when he is forbidden to leave the island to bury his eldest son.

If the lack of specifics about politics is frustrating, how could it be otherwise? Mr. Mandelaâ€™s biography and South African history are so rich and inextricably linked that it is impossible to reduce it to a nearly two-and-a-half-hour movie without it feeling rushed and incomplete. â€œWinnie Mandela,â€ù Darrell J. Roodtâ€™s recent much inferior film, in which Mr. Mandela made only brief appearances, had the same problem.

The performances of Mr. Elba and of Naomie Harris â€” who plays his wife Winnie, a volatile firebrand whose simmering anger can erupt at any moment â€” give a crucial human dimension to this streamlined, panoramic, would-be epic. The Mandelas are the only significant roles in a movie in which everyone else, including white South African leaders, is a bit player.

â€œLong Walk to Freedomâ€ù warms up once Mr. Mandela is released from prison, warily reunites with Winnie and negotiates an end to apartheid with the white power structure. The compelling scenes of the Mandelas, no longer youthful, bitterly disagreeing over policy and separating, are so powerfully acted that every accusatory glance exchanged by the couple conveys accumulated years of struggle and sacrifice. Intransigently radical, Winnie Mandela endorsed retaliation against black South Africans who collaborated with the apartheid regime. One scene shows a young man about to be burned alive. During this final third, the film comes the closest to shedding its lofty airs.

Mr. Elbaâ€™s towering performance lends â€œLong Walk to Freedomâ€ù a Shakespearean breadth. His Mandela is an intensely emotional man whose body quakes in moments of sorrow and whose face is stricken with a bone-deep anguish. The carefully chosen words in his eloquent declarations of principle, spoken with gravity and deliberation, are deeply stirring.

Minutes later, he is a dashing hot-shot defense lawyer and amateur boxer, whose first wife, Evelyn, leaves him because of his womanizing. He meets his match in Winnie, and they are immediately aware of themselves as a power couple bound together in a common struggle for racial equality.

Mr. Mandelaâ€™s dalliance with violence leads to his arrest and sentence of life imprisonment on Robben Island, where he breaks rocks in a quarry. The movie speeds through his prison years, taking just enough time to show the diabolical ways that punishment is meted out and small privileges extended. When he and his fellow African National Congress leaders arrive there, they are obliged to wear shorts. He wages a successful campaign for the prisoners to be given long pants, a symbolic but small victory. Thatâ€™s how the movie picks and chooses its humanizing moments, and there are enough to keep its tone from seeming stuffily reverent.

â€œLong Walk to Freedomâ€ù sustains the measured, inspirational tone of a grand, historical pageant. Events that are worth films of their own are compressed into a sweeping, generalized history. Gripping, dynamically choreographed scenes of street violence are harrowing but short, as the story hurtles forward at breakneck speed.

Still, to their credit, Mr. Chadwick (â€œThe Other Boleyn Girlâ€ù) and the screenwriter, William Nicholson, who adapted the script from Mr. Mandelaâ€™s autobiography, have created a movie with the flow and grandeur of a traditional Hollywood biopic. â€œLong Walk to Freedomâ€ù barely glosses Mr. Mandelaâ€™s youth. We meet him as a teenager in his Xhosa village completing a ritual initiation into manhood.

Hard moral decisions weigh heavily. And in â€œMandela: Long Walk to Freedom,â€ù Justin Chadwickâ€™s stately screen biography of Nelson Mandela, the British actor Idris Elba conveys the agony as well as the nobility of Mr. Mandelaâ€™s quest for South African racial equality. Much of that pain is suppressed rage at the cruelty and injustice of apartheid. As Mr. Mandela looks beyond the fury of the moment and calculates the cost of urging violence, you sense his frustration at having to make the only reasonable choice and taking the high road.

When the Canadian director Peter Mettler narrates â€œThe End of Time,â€ù his experimental documentary about human perception of time, there is a feeling of listening to a recording of a hypnosis technique. He travels to Switzerland, Hawaii, Detroit and India to ask people, â€œWhat is time?â€ù The answers often sound like statements made by teenagers pondering the essence of everything while on drugs. A woman who is part of a gardening and landowning group in Detroit perceives time as round rather than linear, which pleases her, since itâ€™s â€œmore like the things I aspire to be, like the bees.â€ù

His images of galaxies, mandalas, particle accelerators and glowing red lava become his real subjects. He uses music and sound to control the pace, to slow time, as if cinema were a form of enforced meditation.

Itâ€™s easy to mock some of these platitudes, and itâ€™s to Mr. Mettlerâ€™s credit that he never does. His questions are answered with more questions, because words seem ultimately useless in his query. What is more interesting is listening to the pacing of his subjects. Mr. Mettler leaves in pauses for thoughts and transitions rather than editing answers into sound bites. He also edits the words into an associative, aural abstraction: an overlapping narration that is out of sequence yet in sync. â€œWho knows,â€ù one subject says. â€œWho knows?â€ù another asks.

On the movieâ€™s terms, heâ€™s super cool â€” one adversary refrains from killing him because heâ€™s â€œa fantastic guy.â€ù And Mr. Dhulia wants us to believe in Rajaâ€™s honesty, especially in contrast to the on-the-take politicians and police.

Mr. Cooper edits like a pedagogue, at times bluntly hammering his ideas, as in a sequence in which he toggles between one of Rodneyâ€™s bloody fights and Russell hunting a deer with his Uncle Red (Sam Shepard). Like the editing, Mr. Shepardâ€™s casting is predictable, almost formulaic, and it underscores Mr. Cooperâ€™s weaknesses as a filmmaker. Thereâ€™s nothing wrong with Mr. Shepard as a performer here and most anywhere, and thereâ€™s often a lot thatâ€™s right. Heâ€™s fun to look at, for starters â€” you could spend hours tooling along the byways etched into his elegantly weathered face â€” but too many directors use him as simplistic shorthand for American masculine decency, like the last of the Mohicans if the Mohicans were old white dudes, which is perhaps, finally, Mr. Cooperâ€™s point.

The ex-con, the lost soldier, the dying town â€” Mr. Cooper stacks the deck fearlessly, as if thoroughly unaware of all the male melodramas, bruised brothers, broken working-class families and dying American towns that have populated screens for decades. Whatâ€™s unusual about Mr. Cooper, though, and also appealing, is that he recycles clichÃ©s so un-self-consciously. He borrows plenty from other movies (â€œThe Deer Hunter,â€ù â€œWarriorâ€ù), but unlike the postmodern pasticheur who gets off on his own clever allusions, he steals without irony or self-protecting quotation marks. As a consequence, much as he did with his directorial debut, â€œCrazy Heart,â€ù he brings an old-fashioned conviction to the material. The goods may be canned, but the sincerity with which he delivers them can make them hard to resist.

That sincerity also appears to have had a salutary effect on the actors, who all lift the film higher than its scripted words and actions. Mr. Affleck, with his bantamweight frame, broken singsong voice and furtive gaze, often registers as simultaneously younger and older than he is, like someone who, having never made it fully through adolescence, is already edging into his dotage. He can come across as intensely vulnerable on screen, which nicely works for a broken man like Rodney and makes his relationship with Russell all the more emotionally fraught. Mr. Bale, happily unencumbered by his Batman mask, opens Russell up gradually, bringing the characterâ€™s emotions â€” a flicker of regret, a twitch of anger â€” to the surface one pale, faint, filigreed movement at a time.

Russell may not have time for politics, even if Mr. Cooper wants to at least gesture in a certain post-American Century direction. Yet itâ€™s unclear for a long time what he means to say. Written by Mr. Cooper and Brad Ingelsby, â€œOut of the Furnaceâ€ù opens quietly with belching smokestacks and dust motes dancing in penumbral interiors, only to shift dramatically with a ghastly car crash that lands Russell in prison. By the time heâ€™s released, his girlfriend, Lena (ZoÃ« Saldana), has dumped him; thereâ€™s been a death in the family; and his younger brother, Rodney (Mr. Affleck), has devolved from a sad case to a hopeless one. With four tours in Iraq behind him and a habit of gambling away money he doesnâ€™t have, the angry, lost, confused Rodney has become a street fighter, bloodying his knuckles in bouts arranged by a local fixer, John Petty (Willem Dafoe, working his death mask grin to excellent effect).
â€œOut of the Furnaceâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Dead deer and men.

Things get worse, as expected. Anxious to make more money, Rodney insists on fighting in bouts arranged by a mountain desperado from, of all places, New Jersey. That would be Harlan DeGroat (Mr. Harrelson), one of those forces of evil who blaze through movies dispensing weird wisdom and brutalizing punishment while enlivening their every scene. Mr. Harrelson is an intensely physical actor whose performances feel as if they were radiating from each fiber of his being, from deep within his tightly coiled muscularity to his light-bulb head (his characters come across as dim but they invariably burn bright), and he makes Harlan feel wild, wired and alive. The character is a conceit â€” the villain as biblical plague â€” but heâ€™s an ideal counterpoint to Russellâ€™s slow burner.

The film is set in Braddock, Pa., a steel town turned ghost town, around the onset of the economic downturn. Itâ€™s the kind of place where dilapidated clapboard homes line the sagging streets, and where you can find a mill worker like Russell Baze (Mr. Bale) nursing a drink while Edward M. Kennedy praises Barack Obama at the 2008 Democratic National Convention. Russell scarcely looks at the television, but the director, Scott Cooper, lingers on Kennedy long enough for you to hear the money quote: â€œI have come here tonight to stand with you to change America, to restore its future, to rise to our best ideals, and to elect Barack Obama president of the United States.â€ù

In movies, the working class often serves as a sacrificial emblem of the failure of the American dream, one that these days is often embellished with lovingly photographed decay and an elegiac air. Set in a corroded stretch of the Rust Belt, â€œOut of the Furnaceâ€ù ups the ante with a story of two blue-collar brothers â€” a steel mill welder and a former soldier â€” who are as totemic as the figures immortalized in a Works Progress Administration mural. â€œImplantedâ€ù is an ambitious first feature from Thomas Verrette about Ethan, a young man trying to recover lost memories while being treated by his father, a doctor.
