Winners do not interest them. Thereâ€™s no success like failure, and failureâ€™s no success at all. That observation was made by Bob Dylan, like Joel and Ethan Coen, a Jewish kid from Minnesota and, like them, possessed of a knack for conscripting the American popular art of the past for his own idiosyncratic genius. His art, like theirs, upends easy distinctions between sincerity and cynicism, between the authentic and the artificial, and both invites and resists interpretation.

Llewynâ€™s repertoire and some aspects of his background are borrowed from Dave Van Ronk, who loomed large on the New York folk scene in its pre-Bob Dylan hootenanny-and-autoharp phase. Oscar Isaac, who plays both Llewyn and the guitar with offhand virtuosity, is slighter of build and scowlier of mien than Van Ronk, with a fine, clear tenor singing voice. But in any case, this is not a biopic, itâ€™s a Coen brothers movie, which is to say a brilliant magpieâ€™s nest of surrealism, period detail and pop-culture scholarship. To put it another way, itâ€™s a folk tale.

Unlike Barton Fink, Llewyn is a genuinely talented artist. Unlike Larry Gopnik in â€œA Serious Man,â€ù he is not merely the innocent, passive victim of cosmic, domestic and professional malpractice. He is, to some extent, the author of his own fate. â€œYouâ€™re like King Midasâ€™s idiot brother,â€ù says Jean (Carey Mulligan), a fellow folk singer whose nest Llewyn has fouled, offering a precise and scatological explanation of just what she means.

They are the equivalent of goblins and monsters, placed in the path of the hero to strengthen his character and test his resolve. But since this is a Coen brothers film, it is predestined that Llewyn will fail and that we will laugh both at and with him as he deals with a world full of cretins, including the one he sees reflected in the windows of the subway train.

His world, though, is also an enchanted place, animated by the dark, nimble magic of the Coens and their collaborators. The production designer, Jess Gonchor; the art director, Deborah Jensen; and the cinematographer, Bruno Delbonnel, conjure a Manhattan of faded denim and espresso-bar steam, a wintry island that we might recognize from old album covers. And amid the smart pastiche and the sly, carefully constructed jokes there is a thread of real emotion, a strain of melancholy deeper and more mysterious than mere sympathy.

â€œIf it was never new, and it never gets old, then itâ€™s a folk song,â€ù Llewyn Davis says, brandishing his guitar during a set at the Gaslight. Thatâ€™s a pretty good definition, one that certainly applies to â€œHang Me, Oh Hang Me,â€ù the chestnut that opens â€œInside Llewyn Davis,â€ù Joel and Ethan Coenâ€™s intoxicating ramble through Greenwich Village in 1961, before the neighborhood was annexed by New York University and Starbucks.

The catalog of Llewynâ€™s lapses is extensive and fills the spectrum from casual bad manners to epic jerkiness. He makes the hostess (Robin Bartlett) cry at a dinner party in Morningside Heights, swears in front of his young nephew in Queens, heckles other acts at the Gaslight and has a habit of getting women pregnant, including Jean, who is romantically and harmonically attached to a singer named Jim (Justin Timberlake). The only misdeed that seems to trouble Llewynâ€™s conscience at all is letting an orange cat escape from an apartment where heâ€™s crashing. Itâ€™s almost as if he thinks that rescuing the animal will make up for everything else he has done.
â€œInside Llewyn Davisâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Profanity and existential confusion.

One of the insights of â€œInside Llewyn Davisâ€ù is that hard work and talent do not always triumph in the end. Like most of the Coensâ€™ movies, this one sidesteps the political turmoil of its period, partly because it is a fable, not a work of history. (The public affairs of the time get a shout-out in the form of a goofy novelty song called â€œPlease Mr. Kennedy,â€ù a barely topical sendup of the space race and the New Frontier.) But there is nonetheless a strong, hidden current of social criticism in the brothersâ€™ work, which casts a consistently skeptical eye on the American mythology of success.

But if Llewyn is an archetype, he is also a familiar kind of Coen antihero, the latest face in the gallery of losers, deadbeats and hapless strivers the brothers have been assembling, over 16 features, for nearly 30 years. These dudes are usually at the mercy of other people, a hostile universe and their own stupidity. Above all, they are the playthings of a pair of cruel and capricious fraternal deities whose affection for their creatures is often indistinguishable from contempt.

The musical performances do more than enrich the movie; they complete it. Two in particular deliver on the promise of the title, illuminating the strange way that borrowed words and chords can tap into reservoirs of otherwise inaccessible feeling. When Llewyn sings â€œThe Death of Queen Janeâ€ù at an audition and â€œShoals of Herringâ€ù in his fatherâ€™s room at a rest home for retired seamen, you feel the full weight of his humanity, even though he is really just doing his job.

Llewyn is a fairly unpleasant guy, though the other inhabitants of his world are not much better. The nice ones â€” a couple of tall, affable singers (Stark Sands and Adam Driver, suggesting Tom Paxton and Ramblinâ€™ Jack Elliott), a kindly Columbia sociologist (Ethan Phillips) and the unsuspecting Jim â€” serve as targets for his sarcasm. The rest are mostly a parade of grotesques, including music promoters, union officials and an imperious, drug-addicted jazzman (John Goodman) whose company Llewyn must endure on a long car trip.

The story â€” a wobbly, circular journey to nowhere in particular and back, with stops in Chicago, Queens and the Upper West Side â€” is nearly as old as narrative itself. An important character is named Ulysses, whose ancient wanderings inspired â€œO Brother, Where Art Thou?,â€ù the Coensâ€™ earlier venture (also in the company of the music supervisor T Bone Burnett) into American vernacular musical traditions. The loneliness and romance of the traveling life are echoed in the ballads, sea chanteys and blues reveries that Llewyn and his fellow chirpers like to sing. The lyrics palpitate with the pain of loss and leave-taking: â€œIâ€™m 500 miles from my homeâ€ù; â€œIâ€™ve been all around this worldâ€ù; â€œFare thee well, my honey, fare thee well.â€ù Llewyn, still grieving over the death of his musical partner (heard singing in the voice of Marcus Mumford), is a bit more prosaically adrift, stumbling from one friendâ€™s couch to another, wearing out his welcome faster than his shoes.

So I wonâ€™t speculate further on what â€œInside Llewyn Davisâ€ù might mean. But at least one of its lessons seems to me, after several viewings, as clear and bright as a G major chord. We are, as a species, ridiculous: vain, ugly, selfish and self-deluding. But somehow, some of our attempts to take stock of this condition â€” our songs and stories and moving pictures, old and new â€” manage to be beautiful, even sublime.

Sympathy may not be what Llewyn deserves. He doesnâ€™t ask for it, and Mr. Isaac, a versatile character actor here ascending to the highest levels of his craft, refuses the easy road of charm. Like his character, he trusts his own professionalism and the integrity of the material. Llewyn is not a showman. He relies, sometimes foolishly, on the strength of his voice, his playing and the resonance of those old songs.
â€œThe fear of death might be described as the fear of not being able to become whom one had planned to be,â€ù goes one.

Early in â€œNight Train to Lisbon,â€ù Raimund Gregorius (Jeremy Irons), a stuffy academic, remarks that his wife left him because she found him boring. Oh how right she was!
â€œNight Train to Lisbonâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for a scene of violence and brief sexuality.

Raimundâ€™s odyssey begins when, by chance, he meets a young woman who is about to leap from a bridge to her death. He brings her to one of his classes, where she accidentally leaves her coat; in a pocket is a book by the Portuguese doctor and poet Amadeu de Prado, along with a train ticket to Lisbon. Raimundâ€™s curiosity is aroused by what he reads, and he boards the train.
After barely stirring to life, â€œNight Train to Lisbonâ€ù mercifully expires.

As played by Mr. Irons, leading a prestigious cast speaking English in an indecipherable mishmash of accents, Raimund undergoes a late midlife crisis. Impulsively abandoning his comfortable post as a teacher of classical studies in Bern, Switzerland, he travels to Lisbon.

Also delightful in this film, from the director Anthony Silverston, is the way the fantastic animation exaggerates the landscapes, colors, sounds and wildlife of the Great Karoo of South Africa. Real-life nature is presented as more exotic, detailed and deeply felt than any fantasy world.

Along the way, these misfits encounter various other isolated cults, from a family of meerkats living in a human-made animal sanctuary to a group of rock-dwelling rodents, known as dassies, on a mountain convinced that doomsday is nigh. A cruel and half-blind leopard (Liam Neeson) also crosses their path. The voice acting from talented American, British and South African performers (including Steve Buscemi and Sindiwe Magona) is zany and emotionally charged.

After a wise mantis gives him a map to a magic watering hole, Khumba (the voice of Jake T. Austin) heads out to find it. He is joined by a pair of wandering outcasts: the lonely and loving wildebeest Mama V (Loretta Devine) and the flamboyant ostrich Bradley (Richard E. Grant, â€œWithnail and Iâ€ù). A key musical number has Mr. Grant singing a campfire version of â€œI Will Surviveâ€ù with new lyrics: â€œI am ostracized.â€ù

â€œKhumba,â€ù the second feature from the South African animation studio Triggerfish, is a wondrous and slightly deranged story about oddballs embracing their differences. The titular young hero is a South African zebra who is born half-white in a gated community of chicly striped peers. The superstitious zebras conclude that Khumba is the cause of the drought that follows his birth. For them, no stripes mean no rain.

This debut feature documentary by the Safdies, who chronicled a memorably destructive parent of two in the semiautobiographical film â€œDaddy Longlegs,â€ù is like a dismaying coming-of-age movie in which little is learned beyond the fickle chemistry between dreams and business.

The early footage (shot by Adam Shopkorn) follows the teenage Mr. Cooke when heâ€™s a top-rated prospect at basketball camps. The towering but agile Mr. Cooke makes the game look easy, and heâ€™s cushioned by the support of a rich parental guardian in New Jersey. But strategic mishaps leave him lost in limbo (and in leagues smaller than the N.B.A.).
Like the 1994 documentary landmark â€œHoop Dreams,â€ù â€œLenny Cookeâ€ù measures out the years with a pensive jazz motif, but the film feels comparatively stuck on a couple of notes.

If history is often written by the victors, â€œLenny Cookeâ€ù suggests that there might be a certain mercy to fading from view. With the benefit of hindsight, and with a bonanza of documentary footage shot by someone else, the brothers Josh and Benny Safdie relate the cautionary tale of Lenny Cooke, basketball phenomenon turned ordinary person. Like ghostly chroniclers hovering near, they show Mr. Cooke during his rise as a high school prodigy in the early 2000s up through his spectacular snub at the 2002 N.B.A. draft and beyond.

In the final segments, shot more recently and raggedly by the Safdies, Mr. Cooke is shown living in Stony Creek, Va., gone to seed but not alone. The camera wallows in the sight of the man getting happily drunk at his own birthday party, and the sequence crystallizes a certain lack of depth in the film, despite its knack for inducing slow, sad shakes of the head.

Besides Mr. Rathboneâ€™s vocals, the film showcases Mr. Holmes, a musician as well as an actor, who does his own piano playing in the movie and also wrote it with Michael Kristoff, who directed. The story becomes less credible as it goes along. Bobby, for instance, appears to need no rehearsal time, yet he canâ€™t figure out how to be a lawyer by day while carving out two hours a couple of evenings a week to be a crooner.
So the music is the only draw here. The songs include several by Mr. Holmes, which are pretty good.

Jackson Rathbone, Jasper from the â€œTwilightâ€ù movies, has a pretty good singing voice, and he shows it off in â€œLive at the Foxes Den,â€ù a slight movie that could have been significantly better with a little story doctoring.

Mr. Rathbone plays Bobby Kelly, a promising lawyer who, after an accumulation of troubles at work, quits his job in favor of singing at a run-down lounge that was once a trendy spot. He bonds with the few regulars there, who include an older gay couple played by Elliott Gould and Bob Gunton, and forms a friction-laden friendship with the heavy-drinking pianist (Jack Holmes). These new pals all have back stories, some of which require Bobbyâ€™s legal expertise, and soon he is torn between singing and a return to his law career.

One of those whoâ€™s-the-murderer parlor games is a plot pillar of â€œMerry Christmas,â€ù an experiment in filmmaking by Anna Condo that itself feels like a parlor game, and not a particularly entertaining one.

Ms. Condo turned 10 actors loose with character descriptions but no script and let her cameras roll. The story is set in a Pennsylvania bed-and-breakfast at Christmastime, and most of the characters are supposed to be annoying bourgeois types. They start off engaged in a role-playing murder mystery game, costumes reminiscent of a French farce included. But dribs and drabs of their real personalities surface awkwardly: One, for instance, has plans to open a restaurant.

Improvisation appears not to be a strong suit of anyone involved; you can feel the actors looking for ways to force elements of their assigned character descriptions into the proceedings. Ms. Condo generates a little energy by introducing an apparently homeless man into the goings-on, but the other actors arenâ€™t able to make much out of the opportunity. Simply making a documentary about a real bed-and-breakfast murder mystery weekend would probably have yielded a more enlightening result.
â€œSwerveâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Murder and other bad things.

Every so often, however, Mr. Clarke, a very fine actor who can project deep menace without twitching a muscle or raising his voice, and has delivered memorable turns in movies like â€œPublic Enemiesâ€ù and â€œZero Dark Thirty,â€ù lets loose a slightly demented smile that suggests thereâ€™s a killer inside Frank. If only someone would spring him.

The fatalities and clichÃ©s escalate, as the wife plays the femme fatale, and the men run circles around one another amid the dust, blood and some tonally off, ill-conceived cutesiness. This includes the name of the town, Neverest, the site of some of the storyâ€™s moving parts and an assortment of marching bands that have competitively converged to blare and toot down the desolate streets. Thereâ€™s nothing funny, surreal or obviously meaningful about these bands, and itâ€™s mystifying what the writer and director, Craig Lahiff, thinks theyâ€™re doing for him. We march to different drummers? The band plays on? Thereâ€™s nothing going on, so why not toss in a trombone?

As the title of â€œSwerveâ€ù suggests, thereâ€™s a lot of driving, and cars and characters veer, though never far enough for either to arrive at some place, some narrative, thatâ€™s remotely new. David Lyons plays a stranger, Colin, who on his way to a job interview witnesses a two-car crash that leaves one driver shaken and the other without his head. From out of this wreckage, Colin plucks both a briefcase and a blonde, Jina (Emma Booth), each of which leads to more trouble. Jina has a jealous husband whoâ€™s also a sheriff, Frank (Jason Clarke), while the briefcase â€” the storyâ€™s other man trap â€” is being tracked by a murderous thug, Charlie (Travis McMahon).

â€œSwerve,â€ù a would-be thriller set in the Australian outback, throws a handful of familiar genre bits at the screen, including a very bad man, a menacing husband, a wily wife, a rootless stranger and a chunk of change. Certainly thereâ€™s promise in the setting, which with its swaths of desert and roads to nowhere evokes the violent sun-scorched world of â€œRed Rock West,â€ù John Dahlâ€™s 1993 cowboy noir about a chunk of change, a rootless stranger, a wily wife, a menacing husband and a very bad man. Yet to say that the films have similar parts is about as meaningful as pointing out that a 1970 Pontiac G.T.O. and a 1971 Ford Pinto both have internal combustion engines, when only one is worth the ride.

In avid pursuit of social acceptance, she recklessly compromises her reputation by giving herself too easily to boys, whom she allows to pass her around. Even when her hookups signal contempt and indifference, she maintains a defensive attitude of carefree bravado. Although her situation cries out for sensationalistic treatment, the movie is much the stronger for its restraint in the handling of serial encounters in which the balance of power steadily shifts away from Gili, especially after one of her dates films her on his cellphone, performing oral sex.

Late in the movie, when sex is forced upon her by the boysâ€™ chubby friend, Shabat (Niv Zilberberg), she doesnâ€™t say no or fight him off, and her reluctant compliance is heartbreaking and infuriating. The movieâ€™s observations of the wolf pack mentality of privileged teenage boys who view every conquest as proof of their prowess is casually devastating. There is no talk of sexual politics or even right and wrong in this hormonally overheated climate. Itâ€™s just the teenage jungle in the 21st century.

The teenage mating game, as portrayed in the smart, chilly â€œS#x Acts,â€ù is a perilous sport, and woe to the girl who doesnâ€™t abide by its tricky rules. The filmâ€™s protagonist, Gili (Sivan Levy), is a wide-eyed, flirtatious high school student whose family recently moved to an upscale neighborhood in Tel Aviv, which could stand for any affluent city where bored, sexed-up youths communicate via smartphone. Acutely aware of her outsider status, Gili, whose family is not wealthy, has her dates drop her off at a luxury apartment building across the street from her actual address. She seems to have unlimited freedom to come and go as she pleases.

For all the action on the screen, â€œS#x Acts,â€ù directed by Jonathan Gurfinkel from a screenplay by Rona Segal, is not titillating. It might be described as a cold-eyed inquiry into date rape, in which issues of consent and coercion are far from cut-and-dried, even though Gili is ultimately the victim. In her first encounter, Gili puts the moves on Tomer (Roy Nik), the sidekick of his cliqueâ€™s arrogant alpha male, Omri (Eviatar Mor), with whom she eventually hooks up.

Hours before a six-month research mission on Mars is about to end, the eight exhausted crew members of Tantalus Base, demoralized after having made no significant discoveries, are counting the moments until their voyage home. Everything changes when an ambitious officer (Goran Kostic) finds fossilized evidence of life during a lab test and leaves the base with another crew member to investigate. After taking a bacterial sample from the soil, they find themselves infected and transforming into zombies on the rampage.

Filmed in the Jordanian desert, â€œThe Last Days on Marsâ€ù portrays the planet as an uninhabitable wasteland shrouded in haze and susceptible to ominous, rolling dust storms. The outpost is a cramped hellhole in which the opening of an airlock signals imminent catastrophe. â€œThe Last Days on Marsâ€ù ultimately canâ€™t transcend its pulpy roots.

But once it turns into a horror movie, â€œThe Last Days on Marsâ€ù loses its originality and becomes the usual us-against-them battle between the dead and the undead. The most sympathetic character, Lane (Romola Garai), is a medic exposed to the bacteria who waits for the inevitable to happen, as Campbell gives her moral support.

Good on atmospherics but unimaginatively plotted, â€œThe Last Days on Marsâ€ù is a low-budget zombie movie whose observations of group psychology in high-stress situations fitfully signal higher aspirations. The feature film debut of the Irish director Ruairi Robinson, it was adapted by Clive Dawson from Sydney J. Boundsâ€™s short story â€œThe Animators.â€ù

The crew members arenâ€™t the usual cross section of hyper-efficient techies. The senior systems manager, Vincent Campbell (Liev Schreiber), is an anxiety-prone claustrophobe forced to confront his deepest fears. The most hardheaded character is the science officer, Aldrich (Olivia Williams), a dislikable cold fish. The screenplay does a reasonably good job of capturing the group dynamic of these backbiting astronauts, whose frayed nerves are exacerbated by a shared sense of futility.
â€œThe Last Days on Marsâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for gory violence and strong language.

Now, it is true that the story invites such displays of emotion. Terrible things happen: miscarriages, rape, a suicide, the raining of Serbian artillery shells and snipersâ€™ bullets on Sarajevo. But rather than intensify the impact of these intimate and public horrors, Mr. Castellittoâ€™s feverish directing style robs them of credibility. He seems distracted by the compulsion to make beautiful images and announce large and complicated feelings. He has mistaken his own artistic vanity for moral commitment.

The problem here is not beauty, but vacuity. Like many ambitious filmmakers, Mr. Castellitto seems to think that the gravity of a historical catastrophe will add luster to his project. But a serious subject does not in itself confer seriousness on a movie. On the contrary, it can make the film and everyone in it look silly.

The chronicle of this affair is unspooled piecemeal, via flashbacks from a visit Gemma makes to Bosnia many years later. She finds the city scarred but peaceful, while Gojco has grown silver-maned and fatalistic. Married to an Italian military officer (Mr. Castellitto), Gemma has a teenage son, Pietro (Pietro Castellitto, a son of the director), whose true parentage is the filmâ€™s central mystery, the explosive charge that all the fiery emoting will eventually detonate.

As an actor, Sergio Castellitto, a brooding and playful screen presence, especially in films directed by Jacques Rivette, is capable of impressive subtlety. As a director, though â€” notably of â€œDonâ€™t Moveâ€ù (2005) and now â€œTwice Born,â€ù both starring PenÃ©lope Cruz â€” he seems to go out of his way to discourage precisely that quality. A throbbing melodrama set partly during the Balkan wars of the early 1990s (and based on a novel by Margaret Mazzantini, Mr. Castellittoâ€™s wife), â€œTwice Bornâ€ù generously allows each member of its talented, cosmopolitan cast an opportunity to howl and scream and tremble and generally overdo it.

The two main characters, travelers who fall in love with each other (and with Sarajevo) in the years before the war, seem to be in the grip of a similar delusion. Gemma (Ms. Cruz) is an Italian graduate student researching the literature of the country still known as Yugoslavia. She falls in with a rowdy, soulful crowd of Bosnian-Bohemian stereotypes, who drink wine, smoke cigarettes, declaim poetry and swap lovers with life-affirming abandon. Even the wildest of them â€” a poet named Gojco (Adnan Haskovic) â€” seems calm next to Diego (Emile Hirsch), an American photographer who jumps around spouting spiritual encouragement with the verve of a fortune cookie come to frantic life.

Mr. Hirsch can be a charming performer, but as Gemmaâ€™s manic pixie dream-boy, he is close to unbearable. Ms. Cruz works very hard to hold up her end of their romance, which begins with date rape and proceeds through passionate avowals and equally passionate fights in both Rome and Sarajevo.

Whatever thoughtful instincts Mr. Castellitto might possess are undermined by his addiction to cinematic prettiness. A vicious rape is edited and lighted as if it were a bit of kinky Internet pornography. Someone dies by leaping into an exquisitely blue Mediterranean cove that could have been pulled from a cruise ship advertisement. The body of a sniperâ€™s victim is carefully posed, the blood a striking splash of color in a studiously earth-toned composition.

â€œTwice Bornâ€ù wants to be for the Bosnian conflict what Denis Villeneuveâ€™s â€œIncendiesâ€ù was for the Lebanese civil war: a fable of memory and atrocity with an embattled mother at its center. What is missing from this film is any sense of history or politics, except as a ready-made backdrop for sumptuous images and flights of make-believe suffering.
â€œTwice Bornâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex, violence and sexual violence.

Neither experiment eases her suffering, which Ms. Hollyman communicates with congealed movements and an unvaryingly flat affect, which match her coldly impersonal home dÃ©cor. These give the film a sad, dryly eccentric look that stops just short of alienating.

But Mr. Clark finds unexpected heart amid clichÃ© and frigidity. Alert to the way everyday responsibilities â€” like a child or an ailing relative â€” force us to sideline pain, he suggests that salvation is more reliably found by satisfying the needs of others than by indulging our own.

Perfectly situated in a bland Virginia suburb, this absurdist comedy â€” albeit walking a razorâ€™s edge â€” contemplates the dreamlike journey of Suzanne (Anna Margaret Hollyman), a stunned real estate agent whose husband has just been murdered. As an on-screen countdown begins to a Christmas she dreads, Suzanne numbs her grief with online shopping. But the computer provides access to more than ugly lawn ornaments; it also opens a portal to her husbandâ€™s secret life.
Holiday movies donâ€™t come much stranger than Zach Clarkâ€™s â€œWhite Reindeer,â€ù a cool, kinky tale of sudden bereavement, sexual adventure and hard-won hope.

Mirroring the seasonal themes of odyssey followed by rebirth, Mr. Clark guides his bruised widow to a recovery earned through unfamiliar eroticism and risk. Warily trying on more dangerous lifestyles, Suzanne forms a tentative bond with a struggling young stripper (Laura Lemar-Goldsborough) and joins suburban swingers for some uncomfortably floppy fun.

Katsutaka Idogawa, who was Futabaâ€™s quietly heartbroken mayor, recalls the economic benefits the Fukushima plant once brought to Futaba and the pride that residents felt in being a nuclear power center. But the official response to the evacuees, many of whom havenâ€™t been tested for radiation exposure, was so tepid that any trust has been broken. Some assume that they were exposed to dangerous levels of radiation long before the disaster. It should go without saying that Mr. Idogawa is no longer an advocate of nuclear energy.

The dread factor is one reason few will want to watch Atsushi Funahashiâ€™s new documentary, â€œNuclear Nation,â€ù about the effects of the catastrophe on everyday people. This modest film observes evacuees from Futaba, a small town near the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, making do in their temporary shelter. Partly because this version of the movie was drastically edited to 96 minutes from 145, it feels sketchy and disjointed.

Those whose lives were uprooted seem remarkably stoic, although anger simmers below their resignation at being buffeted by forces beyond their control. And, in one scene of a rally, they vent their frustration. Most of the evacuees, also known as nuclear refugees, are middle-aged or older people who have been relocated from Futaba to an abandoned four-story high school in Saitama, a suburb of Tokyo. Crowded in dormitory-like conditions, subsisting on bento box meals, they await word that never comes of when they might return to their homes in what is now a ghost town. Their numbers dwindle over the months, from more than 1,400 to fewer than half that, as they build new lives in new places.

â€œNuclear Nationâ€ù doesnâ€™t take the long view. It doesnâ€™t pretend to be knowledgeable about nuclear power or the politics of the disaster, although the Japanese government and the Tokyo Electric Power Company come off as untrustworthy and indifferent. If nothing else, the film will force you to reassess all the arguments for and against nuclear power.

â€œFukushima.â€ù The name of the nuclear power plant that was severely damaged in the March 2011 earthquake and tsunami that devastated coastal areas of northeastern Japan has become an ominous buzzword. Along with â€œChernobyl,â€ù it lurks in the backs of our minds as a symbol of the unthinkable. Maybe if we just forget, we tell ourselves, everything will somehow turn out all right. Yet, from most evidence, the crisis appears to be far from over.

Some of the saddest scenes show residents who are allowed to return briefly to pick up belongings. Donning protective gear and making the bus trip home, they are given two hours to collect sentimental treasures like wedding pictures and favorite pieces of clothing.

Once Irvingâ€™s and Sydneyâ€™s back stories are set in place, the movie is off and running. The two join forces personally and professionally after meeting at a party where Irving â€” resplendent in swimming trunks, gold chains nestling in a thatch of chest fur and a stomach that suggests heâ€™s far into his third trimester â€” works his magic. Mutually smitten, they begin swindling desperate people who, unable to secure legitimate bank loans, hand over wads of cash in hopes of receiving bigger advances. One mark turns out to be an F.B.I. agent, Richie DiMaso (Bradley Cooper, very good), who uses them to run a bigger con, one he hopes will bag politicians like a New Jersey mayor, Carmine Polito (Jeremy Renner, excellent), whose decency is tested by his ambitions.
â€œAmerican Hustleâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Corrupt politicians.

The movie tracks the scandal primarily from the points of view of Irving and Sydney, whose he-said, she-said voice-overs are interspersed with adenoidal dispatches from his stay-at-home wife, Rosalyn (Jennifer Lawrence). After setting the contemporary scene, Mr. Russell cuts back to Irvingâ€™s childhood, sketching in the con manâ€™s background with brief, funny scenes and a devil-may-care take on criminality that pointedly mirrors the trajectory of Henry Hill in Martin Scorseseâ€™s â€œGoodFellas.â€ù Like Paul Thomas Anderson, whose period bacchanal â€œBoogie Nightsâ€ù also borrows from â€œGoodFellas,â€ù Mr. Russell is a cinematic Son of Scorsese. Yet while his swooping cameras and motor-mouth characters follow in the virtuosic wake of Mr. Scorsese, theyâ€™re equally beholden to Mr. Scorseseâ€™s own influences, including the Golden Hollywood likes of the director Raoul Walsh.

Or perhaps Mr. Bale found pathos in Irving and dignity in this small, striving, vulgar manâ€™s life. Whatever the reasons, Mr. Bale, like some other stars who embrace playing ugly, feels as if heâ€™d been liberated by all the pounds heâ€™s packed on and by his characterâ€™s molting looks, an emancipation thatâ€™s most evident in his delicately intimate, moving moments with Ms. Adams and Ms. Lawrence. Hilarious and brassy, by turns reminiscent of Jean Harlow and Judy Holliday, Ms. Lawrence is a bountiful delight even in a smallish role, partly because of her magnetism and partly because Mr. Russell is one of the few American male directors working today whoâ€™s as interested in women as he is in men. This may be about a famous federal sting, but, like all of his movies, itâ€™s also a love story (or two).

Only the director here is David O. Russell, who, more than any other contemporary American filmmaker, has reinvigorated screwball comedy, partly by insisting that men and women talk to one another. To that end, that chatter, written by Mr. Russell and Eric Warren Singer, is fast, dirty, intemperate, hilarious and largely in service to the art of the con, specifically the Abscam scandal that almost incidentally inspired the story. The real scandal dates back to 1978 and an F.B.I. investigation into political corruption that found agents posing as wealthy sheikhs anxious to buy off public officials. (Abscam was short for Arab scam, or the nominally less derogatory Abdul scam.) The swindle netted a trove of greasy-palmed politicians, but also charges of entrapment.

Mr. Bale has long been a great actor, if not an especially likable screen presence â€” in this, heâ€™s the opposite of Ms. Adams and Ms. Lawrence, who are both talented and appealing â€” and heâ€™s leaned toward cool, even cold characters, mask or no mask. Itâ€™s a pleasure to see him warm up, soften up, not only because he looks as if he were having a good time, but also because heâ€™s extraordinary here. In the past, his performances have occasionally felt like a begrudgingly presented gift to the audience, as he offered us his technique while keeping the more recognizably human part of himself out of reach. Maybe Mr. Russell, who directed Mr. Bale in â€œThe Fighter,â€ù wore him down.

As Irvingâ€™s other better half, Ms. Adams, a virtuoso of perkiness, goes deeper here than sheâ€™s ever been allowed to. She showed an indelibly darker, more dangerous side in a supporting role in Mr. Andersonâ€™s â€œMaster,â€ù playing Lady Macbeth to a cult leader; she has a lot more to do in â€œAmerican Hustle.â€ù Like Irving, Sydney is a self-invention, one containing multitudes, from the former stripper she starts off as, to the elegant British noblewoman she pretends to be for the coupleâ€™s loan scams. With her bright eyes and alabaster gleam, Ms. Adams can look like a porcelain doll, a deceptive mien that helps complicate Sydney and turns an unpredictable character into a thrillingly wild one, whose ordinary scream is the howl of a wolf.

Mr. Scorsese once called Walshâ€™s 1939 post-World-War-I crime film, â€œThe Roaring Twenties,â€ù a â€œtwisted Horatio Alger story,â€ù a thumbnail description that also fits â€œAmerican Hustle.â€ù Corrupt politicos and a federal Venusâ€™ flytrap give the movie a veneer of topicality, and thereâ€™s plenty in it that matches up with the historical record, including the role played by Irvingâ€™s true-crime counterpart, a Bronx-born swindler named Mel Weinberg. Even so, Mr. Russell doesnâ€™t seem all that interested in veracity, and the movie opens with a playful assurance that â€œsome of this actually happened,â€ù a declaration that feels calculated to block off-point objections that some of it didnâ€™t happen. Details have been changed, and everyone, as is often the case in movies, looks younger and prettier, less lumpy and beaten down by life than the original players, even Irving and his magnificently tragic, trumped-up hair.

Irving Rosenfeld, the con man running the great scam in â€œAmerican Hustle,â€ù isnâ€™t, his mistress admits, much to look at. He has a belly the size of a beer keg and a torturously complicated comb-over that he arranges with the fastidiousness of a Michelin-starred pastry chef. Appearances are not everything to Irving (Christian Bale), but rather just part of the swindle that is his lifeâ€™s work, his passion and genius. The confidence game is his honey pot: Itâ€™s what lines his pockets, lights his fire and cigars, and has transformed the mistress, Sydney Prosser (Amy Adams), into his equal in theft and dissimulation, making her the Rosalind Russell to his Cary Grant in a romp thatâ€™s pure Scorsese screwball.

The attention that Irving bestows on his mop â€” the movie opens with him whipping it up into a spritzed froth â€” is emblematic of a life lived as a masquerade. There was something about him, Sydney says in voice-over, â€œhe had this confidence that drew me to him.â€ù A classic type as essential to the American Dream as Horatio Alger, if one whoâ€™s ditched honor in favor of hustling, Irving doesnâ€™t pull himself up by his own bootstraps; instead, he steals the boots off some stooge and then sells them back to their original owner at twice the price. He dwells in that shady space between faith and doubt, between our divinely given, legally sanctioned national confidence (â€œIn God We Trustâ€ù) and the deep, routinely vindicated recognition that itâ€™s all a con. (Never give a sucker an even break.)

â€œAmerican Hustleâ€ù giddily embraces the excesses of its era, from spandex to â€™staches, though itâ€™s a farce that speaks as well to this tarnished age. Some of its extravagances are purely decorative, and the costume and production designers, along with the hairstylist, must have had a blast. But all the shiny surfaces, the glitter ball and the gaudiness, also suggest a world in which everyone is anxious to shake off the post-Vietnam War, post-Watergate funk. The ghost of Richard M. Nixon hovers in the air; everyone is a fake and everyone wears a mask, even Richie, the F.B.I. agent with the Chia Pet perm. And then thereâ€™s Irving and Sydney. â€œWeâ€™ve got to get over on all these guys,â€ù she tells him, when the scam seems to be going south. They may have to do the hustle but theyâ€™ll be doing it together.

â€œBeatocelloâ€™s Umbrellaâ€ù could have been a terrible movie. In theory and largely in execution, it is little more than a promotional video for Kantha Bopha, a group of hospitals in Cambodia, and Dr. Richner, who has run them since the early 1990s. But what a guy! Dr. Richner and his staff have treated millions of children, many of them malnourished, severely ill or both, and the testimonials are effusive. â€œI wish he may have even more money in the next life,â€ù says a woman who has been told the doctor is wealthy. Actually Dr. Richner, born in Zurich in 1947, spends much of his time fund-raising. Sometimes, when patients are discharged, their families are given money for food or transportation.

We also see the doctor, seated in a hospital courtyard, playing the cello, exquisitely, encircled by tiny children and their parents. Film from the 1970s shows him as Beatocello, a clownlike character he created when he began playing the cello on European sidewalks beneath the red umbrella that became his symbol. An important part of his mission now, he says, is â€œto nurse the childrenâ€™s souls and the mothersâ€™ souls too.â€ù And music hath charms.

The King of Cambodia seems really nice in â€œBeatocelloâ€™s Umbrella,â€ù Georges Gachotâ€™s heart-melting documentary. He has a wide, warm smile, and he pats the childrenâ€™s heads when he visits them at the hospital. But the star here is Dr. Beat Richner, who is royal in his own rumpled, noble way.

The South Korean director Kwak Kyung-taek is from Busan, the setting for much of the action in â€œFriend 2: The Legacy,â€ù a sequel to his breakout gangster hit from 2001. Unlike the hardscrabble characters in his new movie, Mr. Kwak is from a family of doctors. He abandoned medical school to study film at New York University, and both his style and themes seem indebted to New York-based films by his fellow alumnus Martin Scorsese and by Francis Ford Coppola.

In addition to the copious flashbacks, there is an overly generous heaping of styles on display. It can be jarring when a flatly lit comic scene, as bright as a network sitcom, is followed by graphic violence. The tone is most successful when it is the least original: When Mr. Kwak apes the slow-motion, shadows and Catholic choral music familiar from Italian-American mob films, the tension and love between the two leads is effectively conveyed. The subtle anguish of performances by Mr. Yoo and Mr. Kim is a welcome addition to the gangster flick family.

That building is a New Orleans hospital during Hurricane Katrina. Oh, to have a consuming passion like theirs, you may sigh to yourself, as you study pictures of the golden couple, whose first film together, â€œPersona,â€ù was a masterpiece. â€œLiv, you are my Stradivarius,â€ù the great Swedish filmmaker Ingmar Bergman once told his most famous muse, Liv Ullmann, who knew him for more than 40 years and appeared in 12 of his films. Bergman died in 2007, but Ms. Ullmann, still radiant in her mid-70s, soldiers on.

â€œAfter a short time, I was confronted with his jealousy,â€ù which was â€œviolent and without boundaries,â€ù she recalls. When Ms. Ullmann and Bergman met and fell in love, she was 25, and he was 46, and each was married to another. They eventually had a daughter, but they never married.

Ms. Ullmann was happily surprised by Bergmanâ€™s approval of her Hollywood phase, in which she was unsuccessfully marketed as a successor to Greta Garbo. And when Ms. Ullmann appeared on Broadway in â€œA Dollâ€™s House,â€ù Bergman, who loathed traveling, flew to New York to see her.

â€œLiv and Ingmarâ€ù is divided into chapters: love, loneliness, rage, longing and friendship. Bergman built a wall on one side of the property to prevent them from being observed, and in Ms. Ullmannâ€™s words, the house became â€œalmost a prison.â€ù
By this time, their unruly passion had transmuted into the kind of deep, solid friendship shared by two people who have fought a war together and survived.

He allowed his anger to enter the work and would sometimes punish her. Once he forced her to stand frighteningly close to a fire. She describes shooting a scene from â€œShameâ€ù in a small boat in the bitter cold. Bergman was comfortably bundled up, while she nearly froze.

None of this Southern California hospitality â€” or the friendliness of her driver (an unusually sunny Paul Giamatti) â€” melts Mrs. Traversâ€™s determination to protect her creation from Disneyâ€™s whimsy. â€œI wonâ€™t have her turned into one of your silly cartoons,â€ù she declares. Novak) with objections about everything from casting to costumes to the grammar of the screenplay. â€œSaving Mr. Banks,â€ù released by Disney, is a movie about the making of a Disney movie (â€œMary Poppinsâ€ù), in which Walt Disney himself (played by Tom Hanks) is a major character. Walt and Mrs. Travers have that in common, and Walt, in a late, decisive conversation, explains that their job as storytellers is to â€œrestore orderâ€ù to the chaos of life and infuse bleak realities with bright, happy colors. Imagination, in other words, is a form of repression. Joy is a kind of denial. But the Disney version has proved more powerful, more seductive and, it almost goes without saying, more profitable.

It also revisits a proud moment in the companyâ€™s history: the making of â€œMary Poppins,â€ù at the time (the early â€™60s) the most expensive live-action film Disney had produced, and eventually one of the most lucrative and beloved. More precisely, â€œSaving Mr. Banksâ€ù recounts the consummation, in business and creative terms, of Walt Disneyâ€™s long courtship of P. L. Travers, the creator of Mary Poppins, played with spirited fussiness by Emma Thompson. Fans of the book and the earlier movie will know that Mr. Banks is the father of the children cared for by Mary Poppins, but even those entirely innocent of her previous literary and cinematic incarnations â€” if such people exist â€” will find this movie accessible and enjoyable.

Mrs. Travers, as she insists on being called, is a starchy, grouchy Londoner whose books have stopped selling. As it turns out â€” as we discover long before Walt does â€” the authorâ€™s own daddy issues are at the heart of her reluctance to play nice in the Disney creative sandbox. â€œSaving Mr. Banksâ€ù toggles between 1961 Burbank and a dusty village in Australia more than half a century before, when the future P. L. Travers was a little girl named Helen Goff (Annie Rose Buckley), nicknamed Ginty by her beloved father (Colin Farrell). The best parts of â€œSaving Mr. Banksâ€ù offer an embellished, tidied-up but nonetheless reasonably authentic glimpse of the Disney entertainment machine at work.
â€œSaving Mr. Banksâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Briefly glimpsed smoking, and scenes of death and illness.

But this is not just the tale of how the happy artisans of Hollywood and their boss soften the heart of an uptight Englishwoman (who was actually born in Australia). It is that, of course. The title comes from the fabulous, sexually suggestive 1960s pop song by Lee Hazlewood that he recorded with Nancy Sinatra, and that opens with â€œSome velvet morninâ€™ when Iâ€™m straight/Iâ€™m gonna open up your gate.â€ù The man knocking on Velvetâ€™s gate or just ringing her bell is Fred (Stanley Tucci). At the start of â€œThe Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug,â€ù the second part of Peter Jacksonâ€™s extended-play adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkienâ€™s childrenâ€™s book, Bilbo Baggins has a sword called Sting and One Ring to Rule Them All â€” eventually. We have a ways to go. â€œThe Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaugâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Middle-earth violence.

The good Mr. Jackson dukes it out with the bad throughout â€œThe Desolation of Smaug.â€ù There are, once again, too many busy, uninterestingly staged battles that lean heavily on obvious, sometimes distracting digital sorcery. But there are also pacific, brooding interludes in which the actors â€” notably Mr. Freeman, an intensely appealing screen presence â€” remind you that thereâ€™s more to Middle-earth than clamor and struggle. â€œThey were come to the Desolation of the Dragon,â€ù Tolkien writes partway through â€œThe Hobbit,â€ù in a line that conveys the stateliness of purpose of Bilboâ€™s journey and its foreboding, â€œand they were come at the waning of the year.â€ù For a few pleasurable moments, Mr. Jackson pauses at the edge of this poetic cliffhanger â€” and then barrels right over.

Thereâ€™s more, much more, including a layover in the Elven kingdom, where the imperious Elvenking, Thranduil (Lee Pace), gads about in flowing robes and locks like a petulant supermodel. Heâ€™s a bore and a drag â€” he imprisons the dwarfs and whines constantly â€” but Legolas, with his darting moves, is a delight, as is another Elven warrior, Tauriel (Evangeline Lilly). A filmmaker invention, Tauriel was created to femme up the nearly all-male world of the â€œHobbitâ€ù and is one of the better realized and welcome liberties taken with a book that Tolkien, who fought and studied among men, wrote between the two world wars. Once again, Martin Freeman plays Bilbo, the homebody hobbit who has been enlisted by a band of boisterous dwarfs to help reclaim their lost kingdom and vast treasure from a gold-stoned dragon, Smaug, voiced with hypnotic, sepulchral menace by Benedict Cumberbatch. (The casting for Bilbo and Smaug constitutes a reunion of sorts because Mr. Cumberbatch plays, dazzlingly, Holmes on the BBC television show â€œSherlock,â€ù in which Mr. Freeman holds the center as Watson.) When the movie opens, Bilbo, the dwarfs and the wizard Gandalf the Grey (Ian McKellen), are closing in on Smaug, who lords over the lost dwarf kingdom in Lonely Mountain. And how: Mr. Jackson, like many contemporary directors given enormous resources to play with, likes to pile it on. With â€œThe Desolation of Smaug,â€ù he has taken roughly five chapters from the middle of Tolkienâ€™s book and turned them into a relentless adventure tale, teaming with rowdy action, slavering enemies and Elven gymnastics. (It was written by Mr. Jackson, Fran Walsh, Philippa Boyens and Guillermo del Toro.) Because when he is good â€” as in the first â€œLord of the Ringsâ€ù and in scenes here and there in its sequels and in this movie â€” he is very, very good. But when he is bad heâ€™s a crushingly straight, unoriginal director who seems largely interested in topping himself with bigger, louder, more frenetic action and who all too often hits his beats as predictably as someone doing hack work for Jerry Bruckheimer.

Outspoken nonbelievers like Sarah Silverman and Ricky Gervais pop up occasionally to enliven this monotonous travelogue. At the beginning of â€œTricked,â€ù Jane Wells and John-Keith Wassonâ€™s exposÃ© of human trafficking in North America, the despicably smooth-talking Robert Money explains that all women are either prostitutes or whores. The soft-spoken Rain, recruited when she was 11, says she called her pimp Daddy Daycare because there were only minors in his stable. Other victims reveal just how seductive men like Mr. Money are to young women seeking affection and protection. (â€œBoyfriending inâ€ù is a common first step; the beatings come later.) The only guest who seems insulated is Claude (Guillaume de TonquÃ©dec), an unmarried trombonist and all-around nice guy who is Ã‰lisabethâ€™s best friend. But when Claude discovers that behind his back the others refer to him as â€œPlum,â€ù as in â€œsugarplum fairy,â€ù he responds with a revelation that is not what you might expect.

When Vincent (Patrick Bruel), a hotshot real estate agent and former playboy, announces that he and Anna (Judith El Zein), his partner of two years, are naming their baby Adolphe, the other guests are aghast because of the association with Hitler. Their increasingly heated argument turns vicious when Vincent perversely amends the spelling to Adolf with an F, and Pierre, a professor of literature at the Sorbonne, blows a gasket.

Pierre and his wife, Ã‰lisabeth (ValÃ©rie Benguigui), a middle-school teacher who cooks the elaborate dinner for five, have two children, Myrtille and Apollin, whose pretentious names are mocked in the crossfire. The evening becomes a roundelay of insults and accusations in which Vincent is denounced as selfish and Pierre as stingy.

The movie has intellectual snob appeal, especially for the French. These days, to what extent will American audiences react to allusions to Montaigne, Kant, Stendhal and Benjamin Constant, whose novel â€œAdolpheâ€ù inspires the prank?

The exuberance with which the film strips away its charactersâ€™ pretensions strongly resembles that of Yasmina Rezaâ€™s comedy â€œGod of Carnage,â€ù which became the much-more-inferior movie â€œCarnage.â€ù The smug, preening male characters bear the brunt of the satire.

â€œWhatâ€™s in a Name?â€ù was directed by Matthieu Delaporte and Alexandre de la PatelliÃ¨re, who adapted the screenplay from their original hit play. Except for Mr. Berling, the same actors play the roles they originated on the stage.

Laden with lessons but relatively low-key, â€œTyler Perryâ€™s A Madea Christmasâ€ù keeps a couple of stories roasting and turning on the fire. With the writer-director Adam McKayâ€™s popular brand of improvisation-aided absurdism returning next week in â€œAnchorman 2,â€ù it bears repeating that Mr. Perry is an inveterate ad-libber. At times, it seems as if he must have altered the course of the plot with a stray crazy word. Each new installment of Madea offers the mild perk of watching whoâ€™s allowed to respond (Larry the Cable Guy, Ms. Najimy and Ms. Horsford all roll along), and whoâ€™s supposed to keep a straight face through the storm of sass (Ms. Sumpter, for example).

With a character who can essentially say and do whatever she wants, you might expect a bit more. But Mr. Perryâ€™s Christmas movie is like a requisite Christmas album, and, sure enough, his customary musical finale comes with a sallow-looking farm boy raising â€œMary, Did You Know?â€ù to the heavens.

That said, Madea is not at her most liberatingly loony here, nor does the high-wire potential amount to much (unless you count a Nativity tale rephrased in terms of dogs, or the mention of â€œBeasts of the Southern Wildâ€ù). Despite the Southern origins of her name in â€œmy dear,â€ù Mr. Perryâ€™s character has in the past evoked the unbridled energies and perverse justice of another Medea, with an â€œe.â€ù But her Christmas outing finds her less demonic than mischievous.
