What makes it a Madea Christmas? In the latest visit from Tyler Perryâ€™s multimillion-dollar-grossing action-hero auntie, this modern-day Malaprop helps save a school, an interracial relationship, a bullied boy and a divided family, all while making fast friends with the white-trash royalty Larry the Cable Guy. Sheâ€™d save a man from a burning wreck, but somebody else takes care of that.

Instead, Madea presides over congenial antiracist messages in red-state country, which is represented somewhat frugally in terms of locations. Eileen turns out to have the most hidebound attitudes, passed on to Lacey in the form of guilty secrecy; the cardboard Conner and his wisecracking parents are models of copacetic colorblindness.

The only sane, diplomatic way to resolve the situation is for Madea to join Eileen on a surprise visit to her daughter, along with Laceyâ€™s ex from high school, a fund-raising broker. Also in attendance are Connerâ€™s enlightened hillbilly parents, Buddy (Larry the Cable Guy) and Kim (Kathy Najimy). The affectionate couple bond with Madea by being endearingly inappropriate.

Free of narration and adult interference, the children â€” in school, at play and in their tireless efforts to earn money for Marcia â€” tell their own story. Like the one preceding it, that story turns out to be as rewardingly rich, complex and heartbreaking as any fiction.

Filmed more than a decade later, â€œArgentinean Lessonâ€ù finds the couple, now married, and their two children in a remote Argentine village. While Malgosia once again gives language lessons, the section focuses on her 8-year-old son, Janek, and his close friendship with Marcia, a frighteningly industrious and self-reliant 11-year-old battling extreme poverty and a troubled family.

With his enthralling documentary â€œTwo Lessons,â€ù the Polish director and cinematographer Wojciech Staron fulfills a longtime plan to unite two separately filmed personal stories into a single work. The result is a captivating record of two journeys, two relationships and one familyâ€™s transformation.

As Malgosia draws closer to her students, recounting their customs and daily challenges in sensitive voice-over, she also grows closer to Mr. Staron, whose 16-millimeter images take on a shimmering intimacy. A simple shot of two hands forming a heart on a frozen windowpane, or a young womanâ€™s vibrant lipstick, conveys an affectionate wonder that warms the film. In this freezing, forbidding place, where icicles hang from buildings like silver stalactites, Malgosia discovers not only fellowship but also an unexpected contentment.

In the first section, â€œSiberian Lessonâ€ù (filmed in 1996), Mr. Staron accompanies his girlfriend, Malgosia, to the Lake Baikal region of Siberia, where she intends to teach Polish to the descendants of exiled Poles. The vacuum left by the collapse of Communism has not yet been filled, wages are paid erratically, and understanding â€œthe rhythm of the potatoâ€ù can mean the difference between life and death.

While maintaining a polite distance, the doctor is obviously attracted to her, and in one of their appointments he unexpectedly removes his shirt, lies on the examining table and hands her his stethoscope. While he obviously has an inappropriate attraction to Melanie, who is very pretty despite her baby fat, the movie doesnâ€™t judge him. His painful struggle not to succumb to temptation is handled with sympathy and understanding.

â€œParadise: Hopeâ€ù is the concluding chapter of the series, written by Mr. Seidl and his wife, Veronika Franz, which examines futile quests for happiness by two women and an adolescent girl from the same family over summer vacation. To say that â€œHopeâ€ù is the most tender and compassionate of the three is not to imply that itâ€™s warm and fuzzy but merely to note that it places the facetious misanthropy of the two earlier movies in a more kindly light. Instead of being contemptuous and sardonic, the portrait of inchoate adolescent longing in â€œParadise: Hopeâ€ù is poignant.

An underlying subject of all three films is longing and bodily shame. The grossly overweight Teresa imagines she can find pleasurable fulfillment and maybe even romantic love with impoverished African beach boys who sell their favors for money. But faced with women as physically unappealing as Teresa and her fellow tourists, a sexual response is not guaranteed, no matter how much money is offered.

With an unblinking realism, â€œParadise: Hope,â€ù like Mr. Seidlâ€™s previous films, contemplates the tyranny of what is nowadays sometimes referred to as â€œbody fascismâ€ù in a society that holds out nearly impossible ideals of beauty and youth. His movies force us to contemplate the weakness of the flesh and our susceptibility to desire with eyes wide open.

Hallelujah! Who knew that the Austrian filmmaker Ulrich Seidl actually has a heart? You might not have guessed that if all you have seen of his work are his punishing examinations of bourgeois Austrian life, â€œDog Daysâ€ù (2001) and the first two parts of his â€œParadiseâ€ù trilogy, released this year.

Anyone can identify with the growing pains of blond and chubby Melanie (Melanie Lenz), called Melli, a 13-year-old who is sent to a diet camp while her mother, Teresa, travels to Kenya on a sex tour (â€œParadise: Loveâ€ù). Meanwhile, her aunt, Anna Maria (seen glancingly in â€œHopeâ€ù), does door-to-door missionary work in Vienna (â€œParadise: Faithâ€ù) and confuses her loneliness with an erotic passion for Jesus.

Melanie makes one good friend, the older and more experienced Verena (Verena Lehbauer), with whom she embarks on a furtive trip to a nearby nightclub where she passes out drunk and narrowly avoids being raped. But the core of the drama focuses on Melanieâ€™s crush on the camp doctor, a fit, gray-haired man in his 50s whom she repeatedly visits with bogus complaints of stomach cramps.
Anna Maria, who cultivates an imaginary affair with Jesus, prays to the same crucifix with which she masturbates while flagellating herself.

The diet camp Melanie attends is an austere, quasi-military institution in a mountain forest in which the children are crowded four to a room in bunk beds. Most are at the excruciatingly awkward age of first kisses, games of spin the bottle and rebellion, expressed through nighttime refrigerator raids in which they steal beer and junk food. With their group calisthenics, the campâ€™s exercise routines are coldly regimental; the fitness coach (Michael Thomas) behaves like a drill instructor.
On one level, the trilogy is a hardheaded examination of modern Austria as an affluent post-Freudian society of guilt and repression that may be a hangover from the Hapsburg empire.

The sillier â€œAnchorman 2â€ù gets, the better it works. In other words, it pretty much belongs to Mr. Carell, as the transcendently dim weatherman Brick Tamland, and to Kristen Wiig, as Chani, a co-worker who turns out to be Brickâ€™s soul mate. Their romance lifts the movie into a realm of pure nonsense, and their graceful, inventive idiocy makes the rest of it look labored and overdone.

Some viewers may be bored, however, as this legend meanders down a few comic blind alleys. A movie like â€œAnchorman 2,â€ù in essence a very long character-based sketch, is always a hit-and-miss affair. The sheer density of the jokes guarantees a few laughs for every taste, though, and the loose, improvisational energy of the performers keeps things lively. The original cast members show the passage of time in their faces and bodies, with the uncanny exception of Mr. Rudd, the Dorian Gray of the New American Comedy.

The first â€œAnchorman,â€ù released in the summer of 2004, marked a watershed in the emergence of what French critics (who take such things very seriously) have declared a new golden age of American comedy. Directed, like the sequel, by Adam McKay and produced by Judd Apatow, it combined aggressive, obnoxious humor with disarming, childish sweetness and gave the world a handful of immortal catchphrases.

The new movie, meanwhile, recaptures the silly, sloppy spirit of its predecessor, minus the crucial element of surprise. Itâ€™s a frequently amusing, occasionally hilarious, rarely unpleasant grab bag of mild mockery and inspired lunacy, decked out with cameos from beloved comic performers and random celebrities. There is jazz flute-playing and a big news-team rumble, which fans will be glad to see but which donâ€™t have quite the same impact the second time around.

He is joined by the sidekicks from â€œAnchormanâ€ù â€” David Koechner, Steve Carell and Paul Rudd â€” and a few new faces. Meagan Good shows admirable gameness as Ronâ€™s designated straight man, his temporary love interest and the occasion for some pretend-provocative bouts of racial humor. The clueless, nervous white guy at an African-American family dinner is one of the oldest jokes in the book, and Mr. Ferrell and Mr. McKay donâ€™t exactly write a new page. But again, no one is likely to get too mad at Ronâ€™s jive talking or his old-school male chauvinism. You might as well object to his mustache.
â€œAnchorman 2: The Legend Continuesâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Just naughty enough for cable.

â€œAnchorman 2: The Legend Continuesâ€ù is in danger of being overshadowed by its own marketing campaign. The recent media appearances by Ron Burgundy â€” impersonated, if you need reminding, by Will Ferrell â€” have the quality of commercial performance art. He has been ubiquitous, hawking Dodge Durango trucks, accepting a tribute from a journalism school and matching wits with members of the profession he exists to lampoon. That television news has so eagerly embraced Ron Burgundy may be evidence that the â€œAnchormanâ€ù movies donâ€™t go far enough, satirically speaking. The man may be a vain, ethically obtuse, generally clueless buffoon, but it would not occur to him to allow a fictional character on his air to sell a product. Heâ€™s no George Stephanopoulos.

Which is not to say that Brick and Chani should have their own movie. Too much of any one thing would spoil the fun of the whole, which depends on quick transitions from one setup to the next and an overall sense of anarchic busyness. â€œAnchorman 2â€ù supplies that, as expected, even as it also feels like old news.

It has all stayed classy, even if itâ€™s not such a big deal anymore. This time, as the â€™70s shade into the â€™80s, offering new wardrobe and song-cue opportunities, Ron and his pals find themselves present for the birth of 24-hour cable news. Ron and his wife, Veronica Corningstone (Christina Applegate), have a young son (named Walter, as in Cronkite, played by Judah Nelson), but their relationship hits a snag when she is promoted over him at the network that moved them out of San Diego. Ron, his male pride wounded and his professional dignity challenged, goes into a tailspin that is halted when a cable producer (Dylan Baker) recruits him for a new all-news-all-the-time venture. â€œThatâ€™s the stupidest idea Iâ€™ve ever heard,â€ù Ron exclaims. That may be the smartest thing he has ever said.

The movie traces the mythic origins of the worst of modern cable news â€” the mindless jingoism, the split-screen shouting, the cluttered graphics, the breathless coverage of car chases and celebrity nonsense â€” to Ronâ€™s initiative. â€œIâ€™m the one who opened the bottle and let the genie out,â€ù he says proudly. But the whole point of the â€œAnchormanâ€ù franchise has always been that you canâ€™t stay mad at this guy. You can almost imagine â€” or at least wish â€” that the real people responsible for the coarsening of civic discourse are just dumb and lovable, rather than greedy and evil. Ron may be sexist, pompous, politically insensitive and hideously dressed, but Mr. Ferrell, with his lumbering frame and twinkling eyes, always tugs him back toward cuddliness.

Written by Mr. Jonze, â€œHerâ€ù features plenty of talk and comparably little action partly because itâ€™s a neo-classic boy-meets-operating-system romance and only one of them has a body. This is a minor setback as far as the characters are concerned, although only Samantha frets about it. If this profound existential difference doesnâ€™t worry Theodore, itâ€™s because isolation is his default state. Thatâ€™s both because of his own life-historical events, including his separation from his wife, Catherine (Rooney Mara), and because everyone around him seems more plugged in to their machines than to other people. He has one friend, Amy (Amy Adams), who lives nearby, and talks to only one colleague (Chris Pratt) in the office where he spends his days writing intimate letters for other people.
â€œHerâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Some voiced sex and fantasies.

At once a brilliant conceptual gag and a deeply sincere romance, â€œHerâ€ù is the unlikely yet completely plausible love story about a man, who sometimes resembles a machine, and an operating system, who very much suggests a living woman. Itâ€™s set, somehow of course, in Los Angeles, that city of plastic fears and dreams, in an unspecified time in the future. The machines havenâ€™t risen, as they have in dystopian tales like â€œThe Terminatorâ€ù series, but instead have been folded into everyday life. Theodore learns about the operating system from an advertisement and is soon running it on his home computer and phone. Before long, he and the software, which calls itself Samantha, are exchanging pleasantries, playing the roles of strangers fated to become lovers.

In â€œHer,â€ù everything is simultaneously familiar and unfamiliar, like all the voice- and gesture-activated software that Theodore uses at work and at play, as if his era had caught up to todayâ€™s prototypes. Mr. Jonze and his superb production designer, K. K. Barrett, havenâ€™t reinvented the world, only modestly embellished ours, as with their reimagining of Los Angeles (a role played by that city and Shanghai, with digital assistance). The city still sprawls to near-infinity, but itâ€™s now as vertical as Manhattan, and everyone travels by train, not car. The trains are a low-key, witty touch (and true science fiction), but they also let you see early on how lonely Theodore is even in a crowd.

There are times when â€œHerâ€ù has the quality of a private dispatch, like a secret Mr. Jonze is whispering in your ear. Part of the pleasure of the movie is its modest scale, its hushed beauty and the deliberate ordinariness of its story. In contrast to the hard shininess of so many science-fiction movies, â€œHerâ€ù looks muted, approachable and vividly tactile, from Theodoreâ€™s wide-open face to the diffused lighting and the ravishingly lovely sherbet palette splashed with mellow yellows, tranquil tangerines and coral pinks. This is a movie you want to reach out and caress, about a man who, like everyone else around him in this near future, has retreated from other people into a machine world. In â€œHer,â€ù the great question isnâ€™t whether machines can think, but whether human beings can still feel.

Samantha saves him from solitude, drawing him out of himself and then into life itself. The role was initially voiced by the British actor Samantha Morton, who, after the movie was shot, was replaced by Ms. Johansson and whose casting feels inevitable. Her voice isnâ€™t an especially melodious instrument, but itâ€™s a surprisingly expressive one (as Woody Allen has figured out) that slides from squeaky girlishness to a smoky womanliness suggestive of late nights and whiskeys. Itâ€™s crucial that each time you hear Ms. Johansson in â€œHer,â€ù you canâ€™t help but flash on her lush physicality, too, which helps fill in Samantha and give this ghostlike presence a vibrant, palpable form, something that would have been trickier to pull off with a lesser-known performer.

Itâ€™s a perfect tale for Mr. Jonze, a fabulist whose sense of the absurd informs his more broadly comic endeavors (notably his work on the â€œJackassâ€ù movies, including â€œBad Grandpaâ€ù) and the straighter if still kinked art-house films heâ€™s directed, like â€œBeing John Malkovichâ€ù and â€œAdaptation.â€ù If it has taken time for the depth of Mr. Jonzeâ€™s talents to be recognized, itâ€™s partly because of all the attention bestowed on Charlie Kaufmanâ€™s scripts for â€œAdaptationâ€ù and â€œJohn Malkovich,â€ù which announce their auteurist aspirations on the page. Itâ€™s perhaps unsurprising that Mr. Jonzeâ€™s third feature, â€œWhere the Wild Things Are,â€ù an emotionally delicate live-action adaptation of that Maurice Sendak book, was a visual knockout with a minimalist story and relatively little dialogue.

She sounds like the girl next door â€” young, friendly, eager. For Theodore Twombly (Joaquin Phoenix), the poetically melancholic hero in â€œHer,â€ù Spike Jonzeâ€™s exquisite new movie, that voice (Scarlett Johansson) is a lifeline to the world, which he has loosened his hold on since separating from his wife. The voice brightly greets him in the morning and, with a sexy huskiness, bids him good night in the evening. The voice organizes his files, gets him out of the house and, unlike some multitasking females, doesnâ€™t complain about juggling her many roles as his assistant, comfort, turn-on, helpmate and savior â€” which makes her an ideal companion even if sheâ€™s also just software.

â€œHerâ€ù is even harder to imagine without Mr. Phoenix, an actor who excels at exquisite isolation. Wearing a tidy mustache and horn-rimmed glasses that temper his good looks with a hint of Groucho Marx comedy, his Theodore â€” shoulders slumped and pants unflatteringly hitched up â€” presents a harmless, defeated picture. At his most memorable, Mr. Phoenix plays wounded, stunted souls whose agonies are expressed almost reluctantly in halting words and somatic contortions, as in his brutal performance in Paul Thomas Andersonâ€™s â€œThe Master.â€ù His work in â€œHerâ€ù is quieter, more openly vulnerable than in â€œThe Master,â€ù yet, surprisingly, as powerful because, once again, it feels as if his characterâ€™s solitude had been drawn from some deep, unarticulated place in Mr. Phoenixâ€™s own being.

Until April of this year, the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam, a peer of the Louvre, the Prado and the Hermitage, was mostly closed for almost a decade, thanks to an extensive, expensive and frequently controversial renovation. That hiatus, during which some of the finest Rembrandts, Vermeers and other masterpieces of Dutch art vanished from public view, would most likely be forgotten if not for â€œThe New Rijksmuseum,â€ù Oeke Hoogendijkâ€™s eye-opening, patience-testing new documentary. The film dwells on the logistical and bureaucratic details of the process, and if it does not exactly write a fresh chapter in the history of art, it stands as an exemplary study in the sociology of art administration.

But the reconfiguration of the entrance falls afoul of Amsterdamâ€™s bicyclists, a powerful and well-organized political interest group alarmed that a heavily traveled route through the center of the museum will become congested and unsafe. A proposed annex meets with opposition from city authorities, bids for construction are much higher than expected, and the architects grow increasingly demoralized. Meanwhile, the curators go shopping in hopes of expanding the Rijksmuseumâ€™s holdings in Asian and 20th-century Dutch art.

The movie does not entirely avoid succumbing to the frustration and inertia that are among its main subjects. Ms. Hoogendijkâ€™s method owes something to Frederick Wiseman, many of whose best films are portraits of complex, embattled institutions. But the need to keep the story moving forward robs â€œThe New Rijksmuseumâ€ù of the ethnographic richness of a Wiseman film, and you may find your curiosity about the workings of Dutch cultural politics saturated with many meetings and hearings still to come. By the time itâ€™s all over, though, you may want to book a flight to Amsterdam to see for yourself what 10 years of work and a half-billion dollars can accomplish.

Part 1 ends with something of a cliffhanger as Mr. de Leeuw resigns and moves to Vienna. His replacement is Wim Pijbes, whose unruly hair and chipper, sardonic manner do much to enliven Part 2. There are some other vivid characters, notably Jean-Michel Wilmotte, an imperious French designer who falls asleep in a meeting and proposes a forbiddingly dark color scheme for the gallery walls. But the main attractions are the museum itself and the glories of its collection, which slowly emerge from storage.

Beginning in 2005, when demolition is well underway and the original completion target of 2008 still seems possible, Ms. Hoogendijkâ€™s fly-on-the-wall account sprawls across four hours. (It will be shown at Film Forum in two parts, which can be seen consecutively for the price of a single ticket.) The main building, a magnificent pile of bricks designed by Pierre Cuypers and first opened in 1885, has been gutted. Bright galleries are planned, along with an entrance that is a source of great pride to the museumâ€™s director at the time, Ronald de Leeuw, and the architects, Antonio Cruz and Antonio Ortiz.

Marie, who is health conscious, drinks homemade smoothies and paddle-boards each morning. The camera gazes over the placid Pacific toward the horizon, where the bluish-pink light meets the sea. The setting is beautiful beyond words. Late in the film, the camera turns to survey the curving shoreline crowded with cottages that Marie and a friend, David (David Siskind), realize will disappear as the ocean rises. As David installs a pyranometer, which measures solar radiation, their conversation touches on global warming.

The cosmic and the microscopic are casually â€” and delicately â€” juxtaposed in â€œAll the Light in the Sky,â€ù an evocative, slightly melancholic movie directed and photographed by the prolific mumblecore auteur Joe Swanberg. This portrait of a middle-aged actress in Los Angeles who makes a decent living as a Hollywood bit player but worries about the future, is bolstered by the astoundingly natural performance of Jane Adams (â€œHappiness,â€ù â€œHungâ€ù). Her chipper, articulate character, Marie, is 45 and acutely aware of her professional shelf life. She lives in a comfortable Malibu home on stilts that hugs the Pacific Coast.

What plot there is revolves around a visit by Marieâ€™s 25-year-old niece, Faye (Sophia Takal), an aspiring actress. The two women compare the difference between breasts at 45 and 25, and you feel Marieâ€™s resignation to her decline with the passing of time. There is a party where Faye overindulges and Marie and her friend Rusty (Larry Fessenden) have a conversation in which he does spot-on Jack Nicholson imitations.

Without preaching, â€œAll the Light in the Skyâ€ù poses questions that are worth asking, even if we know the answers. Why do people build houses that they know will eventually be swallowed by the sea? How do we keep up our spirits with the realization that no matter what we do, there is no turning back the clock? Is it possible to deal with the future when itâ€™s all you can do to savor the beauty of the moment?

â€œAll the Light in the Sky,â€ù however, is neither a scientific tract nor a jeremiad. Its wisp of a screenplay, written by Mr. Swanberg and Ms. Adams, is augmented by the seemingly improvised dialogue of Marieâ€™s friends, including possible lovers past and future, who come and go.

â€œWhat you donâ€™t dare imagine, we dare to doâ€ù is the motto of the dream team known as â€œPersonal Tailor,â€ù a fantasy fabrication service (led by Ge You and Bai Baihe) that provides wealthy clients with a taste of the lives they have always wanted. No request is too outlandish (the â€œCustom Martyrdom Packageâ€ù will furnish you with a simulated Nazi interrogation, hunger strike optional) or too elaborate, even if the outcomes are not always as planned.

Messy in parts and at least 15 minutes too long, â€œPersonal Tailorâ€ù is also cunningly acted and lushly photographed (by Zhao Xiaoshi) in dazzling candy-bright colors. By the final section, however, as a wistful character apologizes to the planet for polluting its air and water, clear-cutting its forests and ravaging its grasslands, you may be a lot closer to crying than laughing.

It soon becomes clear, however, that this frothy Chinese comedy, gleefully directed by Feng Xiaogang, has more on its mind than mere jokes â€” though there are plenty of those, too. Arranged in a series of specific imaginary scenarios, Wang Shuoâ€™s wordy screenplay grows increasingly serious, taking satirical digs at Chinaâ€™s aging population and corrupt officials, and the dearth of artistry in its mass-market movies. This last gives rise to the filmâ€™s saltiest segment, in which an acclaimed director (Li Chengru), tired of being celebrated for the vulgarity of his films, desires a new life as an art-house favorite. Turns out that distinguishing high culture from low â€” even using a delicious parody of the Dogme rules of filmmaking â€” is a lot tougher than the team expects.

For much of â€œThe Pastâ€ù thatâ€™s precisely what they do, although, as in â€œA Separation,â€ù the fractured central relationship is part of a much larger chain of minor and major life dramas, which here include an illicit affair, traumatized children and a comatose patient. Mr. Farhadi has a nice, deliberate sense of narrative timing and an art-film directorâ€™s resistance to exposition. His characters talk a great deal, but the full meaning of their words isnâ€™t always readily apparent, at least at first. In the opening scene at the airport, Marie calls out to Ahmad, who canâ€™t hear her because theyâ€™re separated by glass. Itâ€™s a funny bit because it plays like a nod to Ms. Bejoâ€™s star turn in the silent film â€œThe Artist,â€ù but it also represents the coupleâ€™s essential divide.

And so it goes, as Marie and Ahmad play their respective parts, airing old grievances and fresh complaints. Yet even while Mr. Farhadi forces you to read between the lines, to parse every aside and scrutinize each sigh, heâ€™s busily loading the movie with plot. Marie turns out to be anxious for a divorce because sheâ€™s taken up with another man, Samir (Tahar Rahim), whoâ€™s moved into her house with his son, a heartbreaker, Fouad (Elyes Aguis). For Marieâ€™s youngest daughter, LÃ©a (Jeanne Jestin), these living arrangements have meant a new playmate in Fouad, but for Marieâ€™s eldest, a teenage beauty and pouter, Lucie (Pauline Burlet), the situation is inexplicably intolerable. Samir, meanwhile, has a wife who, as this world turns ever faster, is languishing in a coma.

The Iranian writer and director Asghar Farhadi has been down this path before, notably with his art-house favorite â€œA Separation.â€ù In that 2011 melodrama, the acrimony between an unhappily married husband and wife who, like shifting tectonic plates, create boundaries, cracks and fissures in their lives and those of everyone around them, including their emotionally rent daughter and an ailing relative. There are several more bad relationships in â€œThe Past,â€ù which opens in a French airport with Marie (BÃ©rÃ©nice Bejo) greeting her estranged husband, Ahmad (Ali Mosaffa), whoâ€™s arrived from Iran. Sheâ€™s asked him to return so they can divorce. From both the warmth and the awkwardness of their darting embrace â€” their bodies no longer intuitively fit together â€” itâ€™s clear theyâ€™re not done working things through.

Marie and Ahmad are scarcely out of the airport before they revert to relationship form, sniping at each other like the unhappy couple they are. Their fights and their movements are carefully choreographed: She takes the wheel first and, in an exchange thatâ€™s characteristic of Mr. Farhadiâ€™s oblique approach and increasingly telegraphed dialogue, asks Ahmad if she has enough room to back out. She does, but almost as soon as she goes in reverse, theyâ€™re nearly hit by a passing car. â€œWhat are you doing?â€ù Ahmad demands, although the same question could be asked of him. She may have asked the wrong question. (Is it safe?) But he also didnâ€™t volunteer the right answer. (Watch out!) After they stop to pick up one of her daughters (from an earlier marriage), Ahmad takes over the driving.
â€œThe Pastâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Domestic woes.

The narrative complications can be distracting, at times exasperating, but theyâ€™re finally irrelevant because Mr. Farhadiâ€™s filmmaking is so fluid, and the performers, Ms. Bejo, in particular, are so attractive. The story is nearly obscured by its schematic design (everyone doesnâ€™t just have his or her reasons; he or she is also guilty), but there are mysteries, surprises and complexities, notably in the representation of the children and in Ms. Bejoâ€™s thorny, layered performance with its strata of neediness, resentment and hope. As in â€œA Separation,â€ù Mr. Farhadi shows a masterly gift for moving his characters and camera through rooms that â€” with a raised voice, a violent exit â€” become stages in a ferocious domestic drama. But here, keep your eye on the littlest players, the small ones trembling in the wings.

The modest, run-down home at the center of â€œThe Pastâ€ù is filled with rooms that â€” much like the characters who are busily, sometimes leisurely passing through them â€” somehow feel cut off from one another. Set in a characterless Paris suburb thatâ€™s as physically and psychically distant from the City of Light as the moon, the movie is both a family melodrama and a relationship story, which perhaps inevitably means itâ€™s about love and loyalty, secrets and lies, and how the past, never being dead, just hovers around waiting to smack us upside the head. All this also makes it something of a haunted house movie, except that its characters are plagued by ghosts of their own design.

Clio Barnardâ€™s â€œThe Selfish Giant,â€ù named one of the best films of 2013 by the British journal Sight & Sound, takes place in and around the West Yorkshire city of Bradford. Suggested by an Oscar Wilde fairy tale, it concerns two boys, Arbor and Swifty, whose friendship is an oasis of warmth in a cold world. Arbor (Conner Chapman), the smaller and more volatile of the two, lives with his overwhelmed mother (Rebecca Manley) and a drug-addicted older brother (Elliott Tittensor). Swifty (Shaun Thomas), gentle and portly, is one of eight children in a family that seems perpetually perched on the edge of destitution, held together by his exhausted mother (Siobhan Finneran, perhaps recognizable to â€œDownton Abbeyâ€ù fans as Oâ€™Brien). Swiftyâ€™s father (Steve Evets), usually drunk and always angry, sells off rented furniture to pay the electric bill.

For todayâ€™s socially conscious British filmmakers, northern England is more or less what southern Italy was to the postwar neorealists: a landscape of social misery, both picturesque and harsh. Instead of a disenfranchised peasantry clinging to tradition in the face of modernity, contemporary British cinema finds a demoralized postindustrial underclass fighting for dignity at the margins of the global economy.

The tragedy that results is perhaps too strongly overshadowed. You can guess, pretty early, how the story will end. This is not just a spoiler problem, but also a conceptual, perhaps even an ideological, shortcoming. Intent on showing that Arbor and Swifty live in a world of radically limited possibilities, barely sustained by their families and failed by the state, Ms. Barnard locks them into a narrative prison. Their fates seem predetermined less by their circumstances than by the iron will and limited imagination of their creator.

School and home are wretched places, but the boys find some escape from the misery in the company of the horses that graze in the meadows at the edge of their public housing estate. Some of the animals belong to a scrap-metal dealer named Kitten (Sean Gilder), to whom Arbor and Swifty sell various kinds of junk. They start out with broken appliances and old bicycle wheels but eventually discover that the real money is in copper wire, which can be stolen from railroad yards and utility trucks and even â€” at great risk â€” taken from power lines and underground cables.

Ms. Barnard, whose first feature, â€œThe Arbor,â€ù was about the playwright Andrea Dunbar, captures the milieu and personalities of her characters with tact and sensitivity. The nonprofessional actors who play Arbor and Swifty have an easy, unself-conscious rapport, and convey both the bond between the friends and its gradual fraying. Kitten, who runs his favorite horse in open-road harness races, takes a particular interest in Swiftyâ€™s horse-whispering skills, provoking Arborâ€™s jealousy.

John Leguizamo provides the voice of the bird, Alex, and pairs nicely with Justin Long, who is the voice of Patchi, the taleâ€™s main character. Patchi is a pachyrhinosaurus who starts out as the runt of the litter but is destined for big things. He has a crush on a female named Juniper (Tiya Sircar), and their slowly blossoming romance is essentially a reworking of the one between Simba and Nala, those animated lions.

This family-friendly film combines computer-generated dinosaurs and real settings to tell a story of a herd on the move, struggling to survive and facing a leadership change complicated by budding romance. In other words, not unlike the struggle/change/romance story of â€œThe Lion King.â€ù Thereâ€™s even a bird acting as a sort of guide and troubleshooter.
â€œWalking With Dinosaursâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for vivid scary moments of fire and death.

Patchi also clashes with his brother, Scowler (Skyler Stone), and everything builds to a decisive moment of courage. The movie looks great, the writing is peppered with moments of wit, and thereâ€™s even an educational component built in as dinosaur facts are displayed on the screen. But be warned: There are genuinely frightening moments, because for a new leader of the pack to be needed, something bad has to happen to the old leader of the pack.
â€œThe Lion Kingâ€ù goes prehistoric in â€œWalking With Dinosaurs,â€ù a good-looking extension of the franchise that began as a BBC television series.

Written and directed by Vijay Krishna Acharya, â€œDhoom 3â€ù is very much the Aamir Khan show. Pushing 50 but playing 30 or so, Mr. Khan sounds only two notes here, glowering and goofy. But he holds the screen with his physicality, which is almost constantly on display, whether heâ€™s dodging cops or dancing. (Mr. Bachchan, by contrast, has no songs.)

He also crowds everyone else out of the story. (It would take a spoiler to say why.) The women get particularly short shrift.

â€œDhoom 2â€ù had fun with the mechanics of crime and crime fighting. This movie canâ€™t be bothered. But true to its franchise, â€œDhoom 3,â€ù which opened in more North American theaters than any previous Hindi film, features lots of bang-for-your-buck action sequences. Too many â€” after the first motorcycle chase, youâ€™ve seen all the directorâ€™s moves and most of Chicago.

As circus master, Sahir creates a show that is pure Bollywood. Muscles bulging, he flies on a rope like Tarzan, before landing onstage in a glossy production number with trampolines, gyrating bodies and fire. Needless to say, the Great Indian Circus wows â€™em in Chicago.
For all its New World-conquering bravura, â€œDhoom 3,â€ù in which tears are courted and destinies forged before the opening credits roll, canâ€™t hide its Hindi-film heart.

The hero of â€œDhoom 3â€ù isnâ€™t Indiaâ€™s top cop, Jai Dixit, whoâ€™s summoned to Chicago from Mumbai to catch a thief. Jai (Abhishek Bachchan) may be the seriesâ€™s franchise player, but in each â€œDhoomâ€ù film, a heroic guest villain has eclipsed him.

Katrina Kaif shows up to dance in Sahirâ€™s circus, but her character is a nonstarter. Then thereâ€™s the blond Chicago cop â€” â€œintelligence divisionâ€ù â€” who is so pro forma that even the movie canâ€™t sustain interest in her. She does, though, have this to say when the evil banker demands to know whoâ€™s been robbing him: â€œItâ€™s a thief, sir.â€ù

Future archaeologists, digging through the digital and physical rubble of our long-gone civilization in search of reasons for its collapse, will be greatly helped if they unearth a file containing â€œThe Wolf of Wall Street,â€ù Martin Scorseseâ€™s three-hour bacchanal of sex, drugs and conspicuous consumption. Then as now, the movie is likely to be the subject of intense scholarly debate: Does it offer a sustained and compelling diagnosis of the terminal pathology that afflicts us, or is it an especially florid symptom of the disease?

What they do is consistently appalling and sometimes very funny. The comedy in â€œThe Wolf of Wall Streetâ€ù can be deliciously brutal â€” an extended sequence in which Jordan and Donnie are so blitzed on Quaaludes that they can barely move is sure to join Mr. Scorseseâ€™s greatest-hits reel â€” but the movie laughs with Jordan as well as at him. And, intentionally or not, it makes a fetish of his selfish bad-boy lifestyle.

His first convert is Donnie Azoff (Jonah Hill, a manic, tubby Joe Pesci to Mr. DiCaprioâ€™s Robert De Niro), a middle-class nebbish who gathers a bunch of like-minded losers into a recognizably Scorsesean crew. (Eventually Jordanâ€™s dad, an accountant played by Rob Reiner, overcomes his initial reservations and joins the fun.) These guys are less violent than the mobsters of â€œGoodfellas,â€ù and also less preoccupied with supposed codes and traditions, but they are nonetheless a familiar testosterone brotherhood, and Mr. Scorsese cannot help but revel in their profane, hormonal vitality.
â€œThe Wolf of Wall Streetâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Naked women, naked greed.

This brings me back to the question I started with, which perhaps should be posed another way: Is this movie satire or propaganda? Its treatment of women is the strongest evidence for the second option. On his way up, Jordan trades in his first wife, a sweet hometown girl named Teresa (Cristin Milioti), for a blonder, bustier new model named Naomi (Margot Robbie), whose nakedness is offered to the audience as a special bonus. (Mr. DiCaprio never shows as much as she does.) The movieâ€™s misogyny is not the sole property of its characters, nor is the humiliation and objectification of women â€” an insistent, almost compulsive motif â€” something it merely depicts. Mr. Scorsese, never an especially objective sociologist, is at least a participant-observer.

Anyway, what makes â€œThe Wolf of Wall Streetâ€ù a vital and troubling document of the present is not so much Jordanâ€™s business plan â€” he tells us repeatedly that itâ€™s too complicated and boring to explain â€” as his approach to life. Itâ€™s a truism that every salesman sells himself, and as Stratton Oakmont grows, Jordan becomes an evangelist of easy money and unbridled pleasure. The ambitious brokers who flock to its trading floor are lured by the promise of huge bonuses and endless debauchery, but their enterprise is held together, above all, by the bossâ€™s charisma.

His camera has always operated partly in the service of his id. This is a virtue and a failing, since his best films register a passionate fascination with the frequently ugly worlds they depict, a reluctance (or inability) to step back. â€œThe Wolf of Wall Streetâ€ù is no exception, and in this case it may be unfair to demand from the director a clarity of judgment that virtually nobody else â€” in business, politics, journalism or art â€” seems able or willing to articulate.

From its opening sequence â€” a quick, nasty, unapologetic tour through its main characterâ€™s vices and compulsions, during which he crash-lands a helicopter on the grounds of his Long Island estate and (not simultaneously) shares cocaine with a call girl in an anatomically creative manner â€” to its raw, chaotic finish, â€œThe Wolf of Wall Streetâ€ù hums with vulgar, voyeuristic energy. It has been a while since Mr. Scorsese has thrown himself into filmmaking with this kind of exuberance. â€œGoodfellas,â€ù a sprawling inquiry into how some men do business, is an obvious precedent, and so is â€œMean Streets,â€ù an intensive study of how some men get into trouble. Even the occasional lapses of filmmaking technique (scenes that drag on too long, shots that donâ€™t match, noticeable continuity glitches) feel like signs of life. This movie may tire you out with its hammering, swaggering excess, but it is never less than wide-awake.

At the center of the whirlwind is Jordan Belfort, a crooked stock trader played by Leonardo DiCaprio, who has recently become the handsome cinematic face of extreme capitalism. â€œThe Great Gatsbyâ€œ (this yearâ€™s other major motion picture about a rich criminal with a mansion on Long Island) gave Mr. DiCaprio a chance to explore the romantic side of wealth. Playing a plantation owner in â€œDjango Unchained,â€ù he savored the sulfurous corruption of an older ruling class. As Jordan (a real person whose memoir is the source of Terence Winterâ€™s screenplay), he achieves a kind of superhuman shallowness. Jordan is forthright about the ecstasies of money â€” the pills, women, cars and other toys it allows him to buy, and above all the pure dopamine rush of acquiring more â€” and indifferent to anything else. Gordon Gekko, the lizard of â€œWall Street,â€ù proclaimed that greed is good. That sentiment is far too lofty for Jordan. What matters to him is that greed is fun.

Does â€œThe Wolf of Wall Streetâ€ù condemn or celebrate? Is it meant to provoke disgust or envy? These may be, in the present phase of American civilization, distinctions without a meaningful difference behind them. If you walk away feeling empty and demoralized, worn down by the tackiness and aggression of the spectacle you have just witnessed, perhaps you truly appreciate the filmâ€™s critical ambitions. If, on the other hand, you ride out of the theater on a surge of adrenaline, intoxicated by its visual delights and visceral thrills, itâ€™s possible you missed the point. The reverse could also be true. To quote another one of Mr. Scorseseâ€™s magnetic, monstrous heroes, Jake LaMotta, thatâ€™s entertainment.

As my colleague Joe Nocera has recently pointed out, the misdeeds of Stratton Oakmont â€” a relatively straightforward pump-and-dump scam built on the temporarily inflated value of often worthless stocks â€” have little in common with the elaborate, as yet mostly unpunished, schemes that wrecked the economy a decade after Jordan Belfortâ€™s downfall. The sums that Jordan and his pals rake in may be huge, and their methods unsavory, but they are small-timers operating on the fringes of real power and attracting the attention of law enforcement (embodied by Kyle Chandler, playing a meager hand as well as he can). The big fish, still swimming freely, can be found in â€œInside Job,â€ù Charles Fergusonâ€™s magnificent, indignant documentary on the origins of the financial crises, or in J. C. Chandorâ€™s â€œMargin Call.â€ù

After meeting Jordan at his saturnalian peak, we flash back to his beginnings as an eager newbie at a reputable firm, where he is introduced to the mysteries and pleasures of the trade by a gleefully Mephistophelean Matthew McConaughey. This is less a fall from grace than a rite of passage, and after the crash of 1987 flushes Jordan out of the real Wall Street, he finds a way to recreate its worst and most attractive aspects. Taking inspiration from a storefront penny-stock outfit, he conjures up a high-profile company with the fake blue-blood name of Stratton Oakmont.

Mr. Belfortâ€™s book is more boast than confession, and Mr. Winter (whose television credits include â€œThe Sopranosâ€ù and â€œBoardwalk Empireâ€ù) declines to treat his rise and fall as a fable of redemption. As portrayed in the movie, Jordan Belfort is a thoroughly despicable human being, but one whose charm â€” the ineradicable trace of melancholy furrowing Mr. DiCaprioâ€™s brow, the still-boyish openness of his smile â€” makes actively despising him almost impossible.

â€œGrudge Matchâ€ù walks a delicate tightrope. If the movie were to be truly funny, its stars would waddle around the ring, missing punches, gasping for air and making complete idiots of themselves. That version of â€œGrudge Matchâ€ù would belong to the now unfashionable â€œGrumpy Old Menâ€ù school of geriatric farce.

The characters are reasonable approximations of the actorsâ€™ screen personalities. Mr. Stalloneâ€™s Henry Sharp, a.k.a. Razor, is a sincere palooka who has made big mistakes in life but remains pure of heart. Bilked out of his earnings by a former promoter, he has toiled in a Pittsburgh shipyard until the call comes to get back in the ring.

Whatever life â€œGrudge Matchâ€ù stirs up emanates from the stars, stand-ins for macho couch potatoes everywhere who still dream of their athletic glory days. Mr. Stallone, 67, remains a hunk with shredded abs, although the changes in his face are alarming. There are only leftover traces of the sinewy physique that Mr. De Niro, 70, cultivated for â€œRaging Bull.â€ù

Old jocks never die; they just team up. One veteran action hero may not be able to open a movie nowadays, but put two or more shoulder to shoulder in the same film, as in the â€œExpendablesâ€ù series, and thereâ€™s gold to be mined and a senior male fan base to be activated. Thatâ€™s the shrewd marketing philosophy behind â€œGrudge Match,â€ù the overlong, drab, not-so-funny sports comedy that teams Sylvester Stallone and Robert De Niro as onetime boxing champions in an unlikely rematch 30 years after their last bout. Rocky versus the Raging Bull; how about that for a tagline?

â€œGrudge Match,â€ù though sprinkled with tepid jokes, isnâ€™t funny. A running motif is the nickname of Billyâ€™s son, B. J. (Jon Bernthal), who appears in the middle of the film and becomes his fatherâ€™s trainer. The screenplay belabors the meaning of those initials, one of which is â€œbutterscotch jelly beans.â€ù Alan Arkin as Razorâ€™s former trainer, Lightning Conlon, is clearly ready to serve sardonic comic duty, but the jokes are too feeble to land.

Mr. De Niroâ€™s Billy McDonnen, nicknamed the Kid, is a rowdy hard-drinking hothead and inveterate gambler who owns a successful car dealership and a restaurant. Their rivalry was big sports news back in the day, when they exchanged victories in their first two matchups. But on the eve of their tiebreaking bout, in 1983, Razor abruptly announced his retirement from boxing. Billy has been steamed ever since.

Programs like Cenegenics and slogans like â€œ70 is the new 50,â€ù not to mention erectile dysfunction medications, now dominate the senior male market in our never-say-die culture. Testosterone rules, as the grunts and bellows of Rocky Balboa and his ilk echo into eternity.
â€œGrudge Matchâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for sports action violence, mild sexual content and language.

What reunites them is a television special about their history that prompts a video game company to use their images. At a promotional event, taunts are exchanged and a fight breaks out. Caught on video, the scene goes viral on YouTube, and public pressure mounts for an actual rematch. Promising big bucks, Dante Slate Jr. (Kevin Hart), the son of the promoter who squandered Razorâ€™s earnings, coaxes them back into the game. Standing blankly in the middle of the fray is Sally (Kim Basinger), the blonde who got between Razor and Billy in their glory days.

â€œGrudge Match,â€ù directed by Peter Segal (â€œGet Smartâ€ù and the 2005 remake of â€œThe Longest Yardâ€ù) from a story by Tim Kelleher, who wrote the screenplay with Rodney Rothman, is more of an outline than a fleshed-out narrative. The back story, especially the romantic part, has no resonance. Ms. Basinger, now 60, is ravishing, but her character registers as little more than a speck in a PowerPoint presentation.
â€œ47 Roninâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for scary samurai stuff (swordplay, suicide) and monstrous, bloodthirsty creatures doing their thing.

Thereâ€™s a sober pace to this sometimes picturesque film: The dutifully arranged action building blocks and the meager story filler are ploddingly punctuated by landscape shots. But â€œ47 Roninâ€ù canâ€™t entirely paper over the void at its center, traceable partly to the shadowboxing of computer-aided filmmaking or studio tinkering. (Reshoots reportedly occurred, with changes including the placement of Mr. Reevesâ€™s character at the center of a climactic battle with a dragon.)

Variations on the filmâ€™s grim source tale have been produced in Japan since the 18th century, including on the screen by the likes of Kenji Mizoguchi and Kon Ichikawa. The historical basis lies in events at the beginning of that century, when a lord, Asano, was ordered to commit hara-kiri after a conflict with another lord, Kira. Asanoâ€™s masterless samurai, or ronin, set out to avenge him. Their assassination of Kira and subsequent punishment by the shogunate became a double-edged parable of loyalty and obedience.

Itâ€™s a culturally specific story perhaps destined for rewrites, at least when confronted with the bottom-line logic of keeping an American star front and center. Built into â€œ47 Roninâ€ù is the character of a lowly â€œhalf-breedâ€ù named Kai, respectfully played by Keanu Reeves and essentially the legendâ€™s true savior. The roninâ€™s leader, Oishi (Hiroyuki Sanada), recruits Kai in an effort to take down Kira, whose intended bride, Mika (Ko Shibasaki), Asanoâ€™s daughter, was once romantically linked with Kai.

Between the prospect of Hollywoodâ€™s sexing up a legendary Japanese story with rampaging C.G.I. monsters and the eager reports of a protracted production, there has been ample opportunity to hobble â€œ47 Roninâ€ù long before its warriors finally emerge in theaters. But say what you will about this fantasy adventure, set in â€œa land shrouded in mysteryâ€ù (per the opening voice-over), itâ€™s still a studio movie adaptation of a story that ends â€” centuries-old spoiler! â€” with mass ritual suicide. Credit due for that bit of faithfulness, I suppose â€” and Merry Christmas, by the way.

Taken as a blithe exercise in fantasy with historical trappings, the skewed results feel more inevitable than disappointing. â€œ47 Roninâ€ù falls in with a long line of exotic entertainments that have periodically seized American screens since the age of serials, in which the maneuverings of adaptation almost feel like part of the drama.

Providing fodder for fanciful special effects and 3-D imagery are a shape-shifting witch (Rinko Kikuchi, in an unsteady vamp), who helps Kira using extravagant conjurings, and a back story for Kai in an enchanted forest (apparently named after folkloric creatures called tengu). All these flourishes may reflect anxiety over whether the shame- and honor-based narrative would hold the attention of Americans, but they can be diverting.
â€œLone Survivorâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Intense combat violence and warrior profanity.

Mr. Berg focuses on providing a plausible, in-the-moment account of what happened, rather than reflecting on its larger meanings or political implications. But the structure of the story supplies some of that as the Western themes come to the surface. Here is a small band of white Americans in hostile territory, at once strategic overlords â€” with more firepower and better technology than their enemies could dream of mustering â€” and tactical underdogs. The local population is divided into enemies and allies, though their ongoing tragedy exists mostly off screen.

â€œI think this op is cursed,â€ù Axelson says, predictably and prophetically, and before the SEALs face physical danger they encounter a moral quandary. Discovered by a group of goatherds, including an elderly man and a young boy, they face an unpleasant set of choices, enumerated by Murphy and debated by the others. They can let the Afghans go, tie them up, or â€œterminate the complication,â€ù options that are discussed clearly and respectfully before the missionâ€™s leader renders his decision.

Soon enough, it is. The commanding officer (Eric Bana) gives a briefing and Luttrell, along with Michael Murphy (Taylor Kitsch), Axe Axelson (Ben Foster) and Danny Dietz (Emile Hirsch) are deposited by helicopter on a mountainside. Their target, a Taliban commander, is believed to be in the village below, and they hunker down in the trees waiting for engagement.

You can tell from the title that â€œLone Survivorâ€ù is not messing around. Spoiler sensitivity is for sissies and dilettantes: Real men face the inevitable with stoical resolve. So when the movie sends four guys on a dangerous mission, you can be reasonably certain that only one of them is coming back, and you already know (as soon as the credits are over) that it will be the one played by Mark Wahlberg.

The defining trait of â€œLone Survivorâ€ù â€” with respect to both its characters and Mr. Bergâ€™s approach to them â€” is professionalism. It is a modest, competent, effective movie, concerned above all with doing the job of explaining how the job was done. Afterward, you may want to think more about reasons and consequences, about global and domestic politics, but while the fight is going on, you are absorbed in the mechanics of survival.

The setting is Afghanistan in 2005, where we first meet a bunch of Navy SEALs enjoying the camaraderie of downtime between operations. Mr. Berg, who wrote the screenplay, loves military jargon and rough, manly humor, and likes to shoot scenes that have a rough-edged, naturalistic feel, with the dialogue mixed low so you have to sit up in your seat to catch whatâ€™s being said. None of it is especially momentous: jokes about wives and girlfriends back home; teasing a new guy (Alexander Ludwig); telling old war stories. The point is that these professional fighters take themselves seriously only when itâ€™s absolutely necessary.

The action on screen is bloody, intense and precise. Luttrell and his men fight bravely and fall hard against the rocks, their faces scraped and gashed by the impact. Their talk is relentlessly positive and dryly fatalistic at the same time. â€œWe good?â€ù â€œYeah, weâ€™re good,â€ù is a typical exchange, repeated until it becomes more a matter of protest than of reassurance.

The removal of suspense â€” beyond the not-trivial question of how and in what order the others will die â€” allows the director, Peter Berg, to concentrate on other, more important matters. Mr. Berg (â€œFriday Night Lights,â€ù â€œThe Kingdomâ€ù) is an unusually thoughtful action director, with the obvious exception of â€œBattleship.â€ù(What was he thinking?) â€œLone Survivor,â€ù closely based on a memoir by Marcus Luttrell (played by Mr. Wahlberg), is a combat movie with the spare, clean contours of an old Western, as attuned to ethical questions as it is to gunplay and hot pursuit.
â€œThe Invisible Womanâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian) for some sexual content.

â€œThe Invisible Woman,â€ù directed by Mr. Fiennes, takes its time filling in the blanks. Unlike the typical British period piece descended from the Merchant-Ivory school of Anglophile nostalgia, it purposefully conveys a 19th-century sense of time, which in the movie seems to pass much more slowly than it does today.

The screenplay by Abi Morgan (â€œShame,â€ù â€œThe Iron Ladyâ€ù) gently depicts the conflict between Dickensâ€™s appetite for the spotlight and his passion and concern for Nelly, whom he tries to protect by burning his letters. But they are seen together so often that gossip about them spreads even before their relationship is consummated.

Despite what this mysterious opening scene might suggest, â€œThe Invisible Woman,â€ù adapted from Claire Tomalinâ€™s 1990 biography, is not â€œThe French Lieutenantâ€™s Womanâ€ù redux, but the true story of Dickensâ€™s longtime clandestine affair with Nelly Ternan, who was 27 years his junior. They met in 1857 when Nelly, 18, was appearing in the Collins play â€œThe Frozen Deep,â€ù whose production Dickens oversaw. The great man was 45.

â€œThe Invisible Womanâ€ù reminds you uncomfortably of the degree to which Victorian society was a manâ€™s world. Virtuous women may have been put on pedestals, but woe to the woman who flouted the rules unless she was prepared to live outside society. One rebel who appears in â€œThe Invisible Womanâ€ù is Collinsâ€™s defiantly free-spirited mistress Caroline Graves (Michelle Fairley), whom Dickens takes Nelly to meet.

A brooding, enigmatic beauty strides across a beach in Margate, England, during the opening moments of â€œThe Invisible Woman.â€ù The year is 1885. In a nearby school, a group of boys, rehearsing a play by Wilkie Collins (Tom Hollander) and his friend Charles Dickens (Ralph Fiennes), awaits her return. We soon learn that the distraught woman, Nelly (Felicity Jones), is married to the schoolâ€™s headmaster, George Wharton Robinson (Tom Burke). As the filmâ€™s production notes put it, â€œFor Nelly, the rehearsals are igniting memories of a lost life, one that is still haunting her.â€ù

In one harrowing scene, a train carrying the couple â€” with Dickens traveling under an assumed name â€” derails, threatening to expose their affair. When the police direct the men on board to assist injured passengers, Dickens is reluctant to leave Nellyâ€™s side, but he does lest suspicions be aroused.

In a crucial role, Joanna Scanlan plays Dickensâ€™s wife, Catherine, the portly long-suffering mother of their 10 children. Far from being the embittered shrew you might imagine, she is a sensitive, supportive helpmate whose inner strength balances any shame and suffering. Like all the filmâ€™s characters, she is a complicated, multilayered human being. In other words, Dickensian in the fullest sense.

You may become impatient with the leisurely pace of â€œThe Invisible Womanâ€ù and its occasional narrative vagueness, but its open spaces leave room for some of the strongest acting of any contemporary film. Mr. Fiennes, best known to millions as Harry Potterâ€™s nemesis Lord Voldemort, gives his warmest, most full-bodied screen performance as Dickens, an irresistibly charismatic, tirelessly energetic celebrity who was the life of every party he attended.

Every personal decision and social gesture is consequential in Victorian society, in which the rules of propriety are strictly observed and a perceived indiscretion can destroy a womanâ€™s reputation. Despite the rowdy bonhomie that accompanied Dickens wherever he went, currents of fear and suspicion lurked behind the scenes.

Kristin Scott Thomas, in one of her least glamorous roles, plays Nellyâ€™s caring widowed mother who, realizing that Nellyâ€™s limited acting talent is a hindrance to a theatrical career, tacitly encourages the relationship as long as it is kept secret.

In an unsettling scene that reflects todayâ€™s increasingly harsh blame-the-victim attitudes toward the poor and homeless, Dickens pleads for compassion toward the desperate, orphaned children and prostitutes living on the streets of London. As much as Dickens is shown relishing the spotlight, he is ultimately revealed here as more magnanimous than narcissistic. And Mr. Fiennes, who often exudes an air of aristocratic reserve, is entirely persuasive as a hearty bon vivant.
In 1876, six years after Dickensâ€™s death, Nelly married Robinson, who was 12 years younger, and began a new life out from under the shadows of her secret liaison.

In depicting Nelly, â€œThe Invisible Womanâ€ù slowly fills in the outlines of its reticent title character. It isnâ€™t until the very end that you see Nelly in all her fullness, a radiantly vital woman happily settled. Ms. Jones gives a performance of extraordinary subtlety and delicacy. Observing her is like watching a plant whose buds slowly bloom over time. Her beauty recalls the young Susannah York in â€œLoss of Innocence,â€ù a.k.a. â€œThe Greengage Summer.â€ù

There is a contradiction here: An ordinary fellow should not have to be quite so special to win our admiration. And this version of Walter Mitty undermines some of the democratic whimsy that has made his story such an appealing and durable modern myth. He used to be one of us: a self-deluded dreamer charmed by his unruly creative powers, a willing prisoner of his appetite for escapism. But now our identification gives way to envy, and he is another one of those enchanted people the rest of us can only dream of becoming.
â€œThe Secret Life of Walter Mittyâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). A bit of crude humor and some rough action.

A relic of the analog world, Walter is in danger of being downsized out of a job as the magazine prepares its final print edition. His desperate efforts to locate a missing negative â€” and a mysterious photographer played by Sean Penn â€” lead him on a caper much wilder than anything he had dreamed up. Following cryptic clues (which Cheryl helps him decode), he travels to Iceland, Afghanistan and other far-flung places, and the movie becomes a lavish, surreal travelogue, blending digital effects with stunning landscape montages.

Or maybe not entirely. Though it is a celebration of modesty, there is also quite a lot of vanity in â€œThe Secret Life of Walter Mitty.â€ù (And quite a lot of corporate propaganda too, for Papa Johnâ€™s Pizza, Cinnabon and eHarmony, the online dating site represented by the irreverent, just-a-regular-guy-like-you presence of Patton Oswalt.) Mr. Stiller (working from a screenplay by Steven Conrad) is not content to be the hero of the story; he turns Walter into an almost-martyr and a would-be saint, a mystical self-help guru whose journey of self-discovery makes him better than everyone else, though of course he is too enlightened to say so.

In a world dominated by overgrown boy-men with runaway ids, Walter suffers from a highly unusual affliction: an excess of maturity. The first thing we see him doing is balancing his checkbook with a ballpoint pen. Though we might be tempted, at first, to suppose that his highly developed sense of responsibility is the result of a compulsive personality, we soon learn that it arises from personal tragedy. As a teenager, Walter lost his father, and ever since then he has worked to support his mother (Shirley MacLaine) and sister (Kathryn Hahn) and to hold onto a sense of security in an uncertain universe. Workplace bullies might make fun of him, mocking his nerdy clothes and self-effacing manner, but from the start this Walter is, for the audience, a magnet for our sympathy. Not Thurberâ€™s feckless Everyman or Kayeâ€™s holy fool, but a sad, decent guy in need of protection and love.

Walterâ€™s wild bouts of invention â€” he pictures himself leaping through the window of a burning building, tearing through the streets of Manhattan on a wild action-movie chase and doing other superhero-type stuff â€” represent some of the adventure he has sacrificed in a life of duty and drudgery. Employed in the photography department at Life magazine, he has a crush on a co-worker named Cheryl (Kristen Wiig, with her natural silliness in check and an adorable habit of crinkling up her nose) and a big problem with the new bosses, a squad of bearded, skinny-suited tech jerks led by Adam Scott.

It also, somewhat more riskily, tries to fold the kind of playful, wide-eyed high spirits familiar from the â€œNight at the Museumâ€ù movies into what is in effect a midlife melodrama. This is Walter Mitty by way of Marty, the soulful Bronx butcher played by Ernest Borgnine in the 1955 film that won the Oscar for best picture. Walterâ€™s most notable trait is the one that everyone else undervalues or takes for granted: his goodness. Walter is a low-key suitor, and Cheryl is drawn to him for his thoughtfulness and quiet sense of humor rather than for the alpha-male derring-do he secretly possesses. In one funny, poignant scene, he executes a series of impressive skateboard moves â€” real, not imaginary â€” while her back is turned. But showing off like that would be out of character in any case.

As imagined by Ben Stiller, Walter Mitty is a man out of step with his time. An archetypal daydreamer introduced to the public by James Thurber as a henpecked suburban husband and later impersonated on screen by Danny Kaye as a misunderstood, starry-eyed sweetheart with a lovely singing voice, Walter has evolved into a modern office drone with an unusually active fantasy life. He is also, in some respects, the opposite of just about every other comic hero in American movies today, including many played by Mr. Stiller. And â€œThe Secret Life of Walter Mitty,â€ù directed by Mr. Stiller (who takes the title role), has a dreamy, melancholy tone quite different from what you might expect to find in a big-budget holiday comedy.

What the movie does have is Johnna (Misty Upham), the Native American woman who is the target of Beverlyâ€™s opening monologue and who serves as cook, nurse, maid and silent judge for the rest of the film. If â€œAugustâ€ù were set a few states over â€” say in Mississippi â€” Johnna would be African-American, not so much for demographic as for symbolic reasons. She is a stereotype: the wise, patient, self-effacing Other on hand to serve as the audienceâ€™s surrogate and the writerâ€™s alibi, providing assurance that the play and its public are more enlightened than all these crazy white people weâ€™re busy gawking at.

Beverlyâ€™s disappearance sets in motion an especially loud and rambunctious variation on a tried-and-true theme. It goes without saying that nobody can beat Ms. Streep at this game. Remember Amy Adams in â€œJulie and Juliaâ€ù? Anne Hathaway in â€œThe Devil Wears Pradaâ€ù? Anyone at all in â€œThe Iron Ladyâ€ù? Sam Shepard kicks off the screen adaptation of â€œAugust: Osage Countyâ€ù with a foggy reference to T. S. Eliot and a succinct account of some of the family pathology that will occupy his kin (and the audience) for the next couple of hours. â€œMy wife takes pills,â€ù he says, â€œand I drink.â€ù Mr. Shepard is Beverly Weston, a poet living in a big, faded farmhouse in northeastern Oklahoma. Virgil and this woman, Claire, circle each other warily â€” she goes by Ms. Ibbetson at first â€” in a dance thatâ€™s partly about gaining the upper hand and partly about their respective weird habits. The detectiveâ€™s hands-on approach to organized crime extends to springing Otomo out of prison early, thus unleashing another warrior with accounts to settle. Beat Takeshi).

â€œBeyond Outrageâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for the ritual brutality of gangland warfare.

The men in Takeshi Kitanoâ€™s latest yakuza drama, â€œBeyond Outrage,â€ù are not ones for closure. Thatâ€™s largely because of Mr. Leiterâ€™s almost pathological modesty, as Tomas Leachâ€™s documentary, â€œIn No Great Hurry: 13 Lessons in Life With Saul Leiter,â€ù amply demonstrates. â€œMy own achievements are rather minor,â€ù Mr. Leiter, seated in his cluttered East Village apartment, insists genially, questioning the need for a film. Now considered among the very best of the New York School street photographers, and a leading exponent in the artistic use of color film, Saul Leiter came to this acclaim rather late. She pockets rolls of cash and has few qualms about the work, which she enjoys despite its risks. The Captain and his fellow smugglers are raffish slacker types who party hard in their spare time. Despite a rule never to mix business and pleasure, a mood of sexy camaraderie prevails.

Visually, the film tries the odd fresh perspective (such as an intimate view down on Hamlet, seated in thought), but this is offset by showy camera angles or mood-flattening lighting choices. Directed by Bruce Ramsay

Directed by Geoff Marslett

The girl in question is Allie (Trieste Kelly Dunn, excellent), a directionless young woman who suffers a violent mugging in her Brooklyn neighborhood. Warily skirting the pros and cons of gun ownership, â€œLoves Her Gunâ€ù wonders what constitutes a rational response to violence, and how we know when weâ€™ve crossed over into paranoia. The climax, though far from unexpected, still shocks, but itâ€™s Allieâ€™s emotional journey that lingers in the mind.

This practice, sometimes called bride kidnapping, is now illegal in Georgia, but it remains widespread in Central Asia, the Caucasus and other parts of the world. When it happens to Natia, Eka is horrified, but she seems to be alone in this reaction. Natiaâ€™s parents fight constantly, sometimes joined by her grandmother. If Ekaâ€™s apartment is a bit quieter, that may be because her father is in prison. At school, the teacher browbeats and humiliates her students before losing control of the classroom. Out in the street, citizens lining up for bread shove and swear at one another. There was much discussion, in the early â€™90s, of the importance of civil society in post-Communist countries, but civility is precisely what is missing from the society depicted by Nana Ekvtimishvili and Simon Gross, who wrote and directed this astute, observant film.

â€œIn Bloom,â€ù drawn in part from Ms. Ekvtimishviliâ€™s own memories, is tough and unsentimental, rather like Eka, and like some other films from countries once in the Soviet orbit. It was shot by the Romanian cinematographer Oleg Mutu with some of the same naturalistic clarity and subtle expressiveness that he brought to â€œThe Death of Mr. Lazarescuâ€ù and â€œ4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days.â€ù The two lead performances â€” Lika Babluani as Eka and Mariam Bokeria as Natia â€” are direct and unaffected, but also enigmatic in the way that nonprofessional screen acting can be in the hands of a sensitive director. The viewer has to guess at emotions that the characters themselves may not quite understand.

The filmâ€™s title refers both to Ekaâ€™s awakening conscience and to the fact that Natia, who looks older and is more outgoing, has begun to attract male attention. Her flirtation with a young man named Lado at first seems like an innocent adolescent romance. But then, instead of flowers or candy, he gives her a pistol and a bullet, with the promise of more ammunition when he can get hold of it. The gun passes back and forth between Natia and Eka, generating a good deal of suspense and symbolizing the latent violence that hangs over every aspect of the friendsâ€™ lives. But its specific purpose is to enable Natia to protect herself from being abducted and forced into marriage by another man.

Eka and Natia , the 14-year-old best friends at the heart of â€œIn Bloom,â€ù live in a place that seems to be crumbling at the edges. Itâ€™s 1992, and their homeland, the former Soviet republic of Georgia, is at war. The fighting, in the northern Abkhazia region, is far from the capital, Tbilisi, where the girls live, but the conflict pops up frequently in the adult conversations, at least when the grown-ups are not screaming and cursing about other things.

â€œIn Bloom,â€ù Georgiaâ€™s official entry in the best foreign language film Oscar sweepstakes, is one of a handful of recent movies about young women in modern patriarchal cultures. Like â€œWadjda,â€ù â€œFill the Voidâ€ù and â€œMother of Georgeâ€ù (to name three striking examples), it matter-of-factly lays out the predicaments of its characters, balancing a strong, implicit feminist sensibility with a sympathetic sense of the power of tradition.

As the storyâ€™s rotten center, Caleb (Sean Paul Lockhart) comes on like a sexy angel, but heâ€™s a walking nervous breakdown. But donâ€™t write off this gruesome work (seen last year at the Tribeca Film Festival) as a variation on a women-in-chains B movie. The photography of plants and animals (a bear waking from hibernation, a road-killed moose being cut up to fit in a trunk) is full of wonder. Visual details like these are too few, though, as Mr. Kroschel focuses on converting the simple pleasures of nature into missionary work for his cause.

â€œThe Grounded,â€ù a documentary by the Alaskan nature filmmaker Steve Kroschel, asserts that â€œgrounding,â€ù touching the earth with bare skin, could be a radical health-care breakthrough for ending pain. The residents of Haines, Alaska, where Mr. Kroschel has a wildlife rescue center, seem to find relief from conditions varying from backaches to snoring after apparently using unspecified grounding tools handed to them in crumpled paper bags.
How does this work? Why does this process enable people to understand, as Mr. Kroschel suggests, â€œthe mathematical consistencies of the design of everythingâ€ù?
And why is he shown running in slow motion with a moose calf while holding a bottle of milk?

Grounding can mean walking barefoot on grass or, as Mr. Kroschel does in one scene, taking a mud bath without water (essentially rolling around naked in the dirt). But what exactly is in those brown bags? Mr. Kroschel leaves this a mystery. Participants apparently plug into an electrical outlet, which connects to a bedsheet or their feet, but this process is shown fully only once.
Directed by Steve Kroschel

The filmmakerâ€™s maniacal enthusiasm is distracting. In discovering that the moose heâ€™s caring for prefers unpasteurized milk to pasteurized, his nonsensical narration is: â€œThe next step was an exercise in reality featuring true nutrition.â€ù

Aside from a Socialist realist-style billboard and some oblique remarks, â€œThe Rocketâ€ù avoids political complexities and specifics to concentrate on Ahlo and his everyday travails and adventures, including his new, romantically tinged friendship with a winsome, sad-eyed girl, Kia (Loungnam Kaosainam). She lives with her uncle, nicknamed Purple (Thep Phongam), an eccentric who, in homage to the singer James Brown, wears a deep purple suit and arranges his hair in a slick poof. Purple turns out to have a more interesting, far tougher and harsher history than his kitschy kookiness suggests, but â€” as is always the case with this movie â€” anything too ugly, depressing and politically pointed is soon muffled by adorable shenanigans and beauty shots of the landscape.

A pretty, somewhat sleepy and finally strange once-upon-a-time tale, â€œThe Rocketâ€ù is the story of a Laotian boy who transcends adversity, partly because, if weâ€™re being honest, few moviegoers would probably want to watch a film about a boy who doesnâ€™t (unless it is a documentary). It opens with a villager, Mali (Alice Keohavong), giving birth to twins, one dead. An older relative, Taitok (Bunsri Yindi), wants to kill the surviving child because, she insists, twins are bad luck. Mali successfully begs for the boyâ€™s life, and, after the dead newborn is clandestinely buried, the surviving child grows up to become the movieâ€™s plucky 10-year-old hero, Ahlo (Sitthiphon Disamoe).

The story is simple, blunt and vague. One day, a man in a military uniform passes out leaflets to local residents, who are summoned to a presentation at which itâ€™s announced that they will be relocated to make way for a dam. Suddenly, everyone is on the move, Ahloâ€™s family included, hauling their meager worldly goods across the lush countryside, vividly shot by Andrew Commis. A terrible accident thins the familyâ€™s numbers, a calamity that the insufferable, wretched Taitok pins on Ahlo. Even Ahloâ€™s father, Toma (Sumrit Warin), who clenches his fists at the boy, seems to fault him. Soon, though, there are other problems to contend with, including the pitiful makeshift camp to which the family is relocated with scores of other bewildered villagers.

What gives this movie its sting is that, despite Mr. Mordauntâ€™s insistent attempts at uplift, death hovers over this story at every single moment, from the truck filled with bombs on which the family hitches a ride to the eye-poppingly dangerous rocket contest that gives the movie its title. Here, every smile feels etched in sorrow.

This is the most recent movie from the Australian director Kim Mordaunt, whose last was the documentary â€œBomb Harvest,â€ù about an Australian explosives disposal specialist and Laotian children who gather bomb scrap metal. The prevalence of unexploded bombs is a running motif in â€œThe Rocketâ€ù and, in one of the sharpest, most effective scenes, a surreal interlude in an abandoned mountainside village, large missiles can be seen propping up homes.

But Ms. Gregorini is so entranced by her sullen heroine that weâ€™re forced to spend a great deal of time just gazing into her troubled blue eyes. Now 17, Emanuel still blames herself for being the cause of her motherâ€™s death during childbirth and is committed to paying that suffering forward. Disdainfully snippy with her stepmother (Frances Oâ€™Connor), sulky with her enabling father (Alfred Molina) and smart-mouthed with the cute boy (Aneurin Barnard) who unwisely pursues a friendship, Emanuel softens only with Linda (Jessica Biel), a new neighbor who swans around in hippie outfits cooing over her baby girl.

That said, preposterousness is far from the only problem in a film that portrays womanhood as womb obsession â€” a fixation that begins with Emanuel herself (Kaya Scodelario), an utter pill who long since should have been in therapy.

It soon becomes clear, though, that Linda is nursing her own mental health issues, embedded in a story that uses overwrought scenes of magical realism to couch psychosis as poetry and masochism as growing pains.
