â€œThe Legend of Herculesâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Fighting and killing, and some tasteful god-and-mortal coupling.

â€œThe Legend of Hercules,â€ù a new 3-D work of Classical beefcake scholarship, directed by Renny Harlin, is likely to be met with ridicule. At the crowded preview screening I attended on Thursday night in Manhattan, there were audible hoots of derision, which were, for the most part, well earned. But really, this movie, with its relatively modest running time and not-quite-household-name cast, is no more ridiculous than, letâ€™s say, the â€œThorâ€ù movies, and a lot less pretentious. It delivers what it promises, which is muscular guys in skimpy clothes fighting and howling, as well as some large-scale digitally enhanced battle sequences.

Herculesâ€™ real dad, of course, is Zeus, who, in this version, with the blessing of the goddess Hera, visited Queen Alcmene in the form of a bright light and a howling wind. She describes it to her husband a bit differently: â€œZeus came into my bed and blasted me with his seed to spawn a son to end your reign.â€ù

The 3-D is pedestrian. Now and then, an arrow seems to fly out of the screen, but usually, stuff floats down and across it: bodies, mostly, but also confetti and an odd, feathery substance. I donâ€™t think it was snow, but it might have been dandelion fluff, or maybe feathers drifting in from an off-camera pillow fight.

Hercules is played by Kellan Lutz, whose appearance is about as evocative of Greece as his name. Like Thor, this blond demigod is caught up in some family drama. His mother, Alcmene (Roxanne McKee) adores him; his older brother, Iphicles (Liam Garrigan), despises him; and the man who passes for his father, King Amphitryon (Scott Adkins), does not trust him.

Most of the dialogue is less memorable, perhaps so it can be easily dubbed for the global market. There is quite a lot of roaring, though, and some swooning and sighing, mostly courtesy of Hebe (Gaia Weiss), the Cretan princess beloved by Hercules and betrothed to his brother.

Charly and Wilhelm are the most overtly patriotic, but this is more passive acceptance of the reality they have grown up with than the fervent embrace of ideology. They are happy to participate in their countryâ€™s heroic destiny and only gradually come to realize that this will involve the murder of innocents, the betrayal of comrades and the destruction of their own ideals.

Both of them witness â€” and do â€” terrible things, as do the others. Friedhelm, the most sensitive of the group, is transformed into a cold and effective killer. Greta, having begun an affair with the Gestapo officer who took her music, becomes one of the Reichâ€™s top recording stars. Viktor, escaping from a train bound for Auschwitz, takes up with a group of fighters loyal to the Polish Home Army.

Their friends Greta (Katharina SchÃ_ttler) and Viktor (Ludwig Trepte) are far less shy, though their relationship is illegal, since Viktor is Jewish. But even an ominous visit from a Gestapo officer â€” who confiscates their records and warns Greta about the â€œrace shameâ€ù of dating a Jew â€” cannot quell the groupâ€™s youthful optimism. That will take a genocidal war.

This omission has the effect of at least partly restoring the innocence of the characters and of perpetuating the notion that ordinary Germans were duped by the Nazis and ignorant of the extent of their crimes â€” that they were as much Hitlerâ€™s victims as his accomplices and did not know what he was doing. They also suffered, after all, but there is something troubling about how the filmmakers apportion this suffering.

This has less to do with factual accuracy than with the way facts are shaped, juxtaposed and given emotional weight. The evil of the Nazis is hardly denied, but it is mainly localized within a few cartoonishly sadistic SS and Gestapo commanders, who are nearly as cruel to regular German soldiers as they are to Jews and Russians. There is also an element of moral relativism in the way the film portrays the Polish resistance, whose members hate Jews as much as the Germans, but with worse manners, and the bestial, rampaging members of the Red Army, who have no manners at all.

The characters are sharply drawn (by a lively and uniformly excellent cast), their contrasting temperaments providing a pleasing, if not terribly challenging, sense of human variety. Greta is high-strung and passionate. Viktor is wary, excitable and perpetually unshaven. Friedhelm is timid and bookish, a mamaâ€™s boy whose stiff-necked father favors the manly and decisive Wilhelm. He and Charly, fair-haired and upright, are like Nazi propaganda posters brought to life and softened up for modern, liberal audiences. They exude a quiet pride in their own virtue.

The artist, the intellectual and the Jew are all punished, for wantonness, weakness and naÃ¯vetÃ©, and pushed into extreme states of moral compromise. The chaste, self-sacrificing Aryans, the lieutenant and the nurse, though they are not without guilt, are the heroes of the story, just as they would have been in a German film made in 1943. The moral this time around is that they have, at long last, earned the worldâ€™s forgiveness.

None of the five friends are Nazi zealots, and none can see the catastrophe that is coming. Viktorâ€™s father, who served in the German Army in World War I and whose tailor shop was destroyed during the state-sponsored anti-Jewish vandalism of Kristallnacht, believes that his fellow Germans will come to their senses â€œonce they see how much they need us.â€ù

Sensationally popular in Germany â€” decidedly less so in Poland, where its depiction of anti-Nazi partisans as unkempt anti-Semites provoked public outrage â€” â€œGeneration Warâ€ù tries to assimilate the unfathomable barbarity of the years between the invasion of the Soviet Union and the fall of Berlin into the conventions of popular entertainment. Part melodrama, part combat action movie, the film, written by Stefan Kolditz and directed by Philipp Kadelbach, chronicles the lives of five friends who are presented as more or less typical young Germans.

This may, in the abstract, seem fair enough, but the film slips into a strange, queasy zone between naturalism and nostalgia. In effect, it is a plea on behalf of Germans born in the early 1920s for inclusion in a global Greatest Generation, an exercise in selective memory based on the assumption that itâ€™s time to let bygones be bygones.

Mr. Kadelbach, the director, has clearly studied the work of Steven Spielberg. He crosscuts deftly between scenes, alternating moments of tense violence with stretches of solitude and tenderness. Battles are staged with â€œSaving Private Ryanâ€ù-like intensity and precision, and the whole narrative â€” shifting from the mud and ice of Russia in winter to the wheat fields of Ukraine, the forests of Poland and the streets of the German capital â€” has a sweep and a vigor that recall â€œGone With the Windâ€ù and other old Hollywood costume epics.

Coming after the silence of the â€™50s and early â€™60s and the angry reckonings of the â€™70s and â€™80s, â€œGeneration War,â€ù emotionally charged but not exactly anguished, represents an attempt to normalize German history. Its lesson is that ordinary Germans â€” â€œOur Mothers, Our Fathers,â€ù in the original title â€” were not so different from anyone else, and deserve the empathy and understanding of their grandchildren.

â€œGeneration War,â€ù which was broadcast as a mini-series on German television last year, is perhaps more interesting as an artifact of the present than as a representation of the past. As the Second World War slips from living memory, as Germany asserts its dominant role in Europe with increasing confidence, and as long-suppressed information emerges from the archives of former Eastern bloc countries, the warâ€™s cultural significance for Germans has shifted.

There is good and bad on all sides, a dash of mercy mixed into the endless violence. But the suggestion that the Nazis were not the only bad guys in Eastern Europe in the early 1940s is undermined by the filmâ€™s disinclination to show the very worst of what the Nazis did. We see massacres of Jews by local militias in Ukraine under the supervision of the SS, but â€œGeneration War,â€ù for all its geographical range and military detail, steers clear of the death camps.

We first see them together in 1941, after closing time in a Berlin bar, smoking cigarettes, drinking Champagne and dancing to the forbidden strains of American jazz. Two brothers, Wilhelm (Volker Bruch, who provides some voice-over narration) and Friedhelm (Tom Schilling), are about to leave for the Eastern front. Wilhelm, dashing in his lieutenantâ€™s uniform, is confident that Stalinâ€™s armies will be vanquished by Christmas. â€œTowheads,â€ù a film written and directed by and starring Shannon Plumb, is a whimsical yet deeply disturbing story about the infantilization and isolation of a stay-at-home mom in Brooklyn. â€œStranger by the Lakeâ€ù is seductive and fascinating, but it is also a bit trapped in its own conceit, and in its carefully maintained emotional detachment. Names are supplied very late in the game, and identities â€” the mundane facts of work, life, family and friends â€” are left behind. Mr. Guiraudie, observing graphic sex acts, the swaying of trees and the motion of sunlight on water with equal delight and detachment, traces a dialectic of anonymity and intimacy. Michel, Franck and the others are at once in their natural habitat, doing what comes naturally, and participants in an elaborate and complex game of artifice and concealment.

The motives for the crime are never established, but the real mystery is everything that happens in its wake. Mr. Guiraudie, a French filmmaker whose earlier movies include â€œThe King of Escapeâ€ù and â€œThat Old Dream That Movesâ€ù (and who is the subject of a welcome retrospective starting on Friday at The Film Society of Lincoln Center), creates an atmosphere of dread and suspense out of the simplest narrative elements.

This is France, after all: a society fascinated by love and in love with rules. Very little is said as the men on the beach exchange glances and nods and then retreat into the woods for sex, and yet the scene has an almost solemn formality. Mr. Guiraudieâ€™s camera never moves beyond the lake and records the passage of time with fastidious precision. Each day begins with an aerial shot of the parking area, where we learn to identify Franckâ€™s black Renault, and also the red compact belonging to the victim.

Which one is the stranger? The filmâ€™s title (â€œLâ€™Inconnu du Lacâ€ù in French) is a deliberate tease, since it could refer to virtually anyone: Michel, certainly, and also Franck, but also Henri (Patrick dâ€™AssumÃ§ao), an apparently straight guy who sits on the rocks off to the side of the main beach, never disrobing or going in the water. Strangest of all is the police inspector (JÃ©rÃ´me Chappatte) who shows up asking questions about the drowned man.

The killerâ€™s name is Michel, and in the wake of the murder, he and Franck begin an unusually intense affair. Michel (Christophe Paou), who somewhat resembles a â€œMagnum, P.I.â€ù-era Tom Selleck, is not interested in pursuing the relationship away from the lake, but his devotion seems, if anything, more ardent than Franckâ€™s. The strength of their attraction seems to overshadow what Michel has done, and itâ€™s hard to tell if Franck is more alarmed or aroused by his new loverâ€™s potentially sociopathic tendencies.

He also has an unsentimental, sometimes chilly sense of the ways that ordinary human amorality, ethical confusion and sexual longing can turn banal circumstances into the stuff of high comedy. Gazing at a place devoted to the free play of lust â€” and gazing, as well, at bodies acting out their urges â€” he discovers codes and rituals, echoes of the social order that the men who come here try to shed, along with their clothes.

Not every mystery is a whodunit. In Alain Guiraudieâ€™s â€œStranger by the Lake,â€ù a murder takes place early on, in full view of the audience and a crucial witness, a young man named Franck (Pierre Deladonchamps). Franck has spent the afternoon â€” as he apparently spends many afternoons â€” on a stretch of beach that serves as a gay cruising spot. Earlier, he had a brief flirtation with a muscular, mustachioed swimmer, only to be shooed away by someone who seemed to be a jealous boyfriend. Whatâ€™s in a face? The first and final images in Godfrey Reggioâ€™s brooding, wordless film â€œVisitorsâ€ù are of a gorilla staring into the camera. Here, time slows to a near-standstill as the film peers into humanityâ€™s troubled soul, glimpsed through the individual faces, which sometimes appear to be studying us as intently as we are studying them. With the most minute of facial tics, an expression can change from sullen to amused, though it never seems happy so much as pleasantly distracted.

As you gaze at these individuals â€” of all ages, races and types, male and female â€” you realize how extraordinarily different one personâ€™s physiognomy is from anotherâ€™s. Each human is an autonomous little world, with a distinctive physical and emotional climate.

We first see Agnes â€” who prefers to be called Apple and is played by Vanessa Hudgens â€” chopping off her long, dark hair and storming out of the shabby apartment where she lives with her drug-addicted mother (Rosario Dawson, with her teeth an alarming shade of yellow and her emoting motor in overdrive). No aspect of Gloriaâ€™s experience is off limits for him, and some of the filmâ€™s most memorable moments are those a more plot-focused director might have omitted, like the party scene in which she listens to unidentified friends performing AntÃ´nio Carlos Jobimâ€™s â€œWaters of March,â€ù one of the loveliest songs ever written.

The more we learn about Rodolfo (Sergio HernÃ¡ndez), the more we might question her taste in men â€” a judgment confirmed during a family dinner with her ex-husband â€” but there is no doubting her curiosity or her confidence. The great accomplishment of â€œGloria,â€ù the Chilean writer-director SebastiÃ¡n Lelioâ€™s astute, unpretentious and thrillingly humane new film, is that it acknowledges both sides of its heroineâ€™s temperament without judgment or sentimentality. When Sosa returned to Argentina in 1982, the dictatorship, though still in power, had weakened, and she was welcomed as a national symbol of freedom. But the story, as related in the movie, has little narrative force.

Sosa, who died in October 2009 at 74, applied her gift to the politically charged music of the Nueva CanciÃ_n (New Song) movement in the 1960s that challenged dictatorships in Latin America and Europe. She was truly a voice of the people.

With her Indian features and straight black hair, she had the kind of face that might have been etched on a coin. Although her voice was lower, her purity of tone and intensity of emotion were not unlike those of the young Joan Baez, her closest American counterpart.

The most consistent outside voice belongs to David Byrne, who talks as if he were trying to explain the political power of folk music to a younger generation: how singing protest songs could get you jailed, tortured or killed.
The lack of background information and connective tissue makes the film feel incomplete. The most intimate personal moments deal with Sosaâ€™s depression, which once led her to stop eating.

Vilaâ€™s biographical documentary â€œMercedes Sosa: The Voice of Latin Americaâ€ù conveys eons of suffering and survival. The movie, which runs ragged by its second half, ends by embracing Pugâ€™s fantasy adventure, confounding the present and future like a scene in â€œOut of Sight.â€ù The sequence, about a raid to retrieve a bike, is one of the few times we hear Mr. Nathan, and his question to Pug says a lot about the movieâ€™s perspective: â€œHow would you do it?â€ù

Ms. Schneemann may have been both, even if pornography is such a dull, dreary word for a juicy film that insists that the display of female sexual pleasure â€” including a womanâ€™s pleasure in a male loverâ€™s body â€” can be at once cinematic and nonsexist. With its abstracted, fragmented, sometimes heavily obscured images of her and Mr. Tenney having sex, which Ms. Schneemann mixed in with other images of everyday life (petting a cat, running on a beach), â€œFusesâ€ù transcends commercial pornography and erotica to become something else entirely. In it, she doesnâ€™t just assert herself as a sexual being: Through her manipulations â€” she cut, taped, baked (!) and soaked the film in acids and dyes â€” she also inscribes ownership of her image and, by extension, her sexuality, onto its material surface.

Ms. Nitoslawskaâ€™s sotto voce asides and elliptical, associative approach â€” she intersperses her visuals with Ms. Schneemannâ€™s without necessarily identifying which is which â€” can be pleasantly lulling. Yet for those unfamiliar with the sweep and historical importance of Ms. Schneemannâ€™s work, the movie can also register as frustratingly hermetic, almost private, because so much is left unsaid, making it sometimes feel more like a private exchange than a shared one. Ms. Nitoslawska can also be pointlessly vague: â€œYou paint,â€ù she murmurs, â€œand you write, you perform, you film and you write.â€ù All true. Ms. Schneemann did â€” and does â€” all that and more, which is partly why â€œBreaking the Frameâ€ù is a tantalizing teaser for a story that still needs to be told.

Speaking in a hushed voice, Ms. Nitoslawska provides a skeletal biographical portrait while wandering around her subjectâ€™s handsomely lived-in country house, and peeking into rooms and old diaries that slowly bring a life into focus. Every so often, Ms. Schneemann, whose work insistently erases barriers â€” between the mind and the body, the raw and the cooked â€” speaks. You seize on every word.

Nicely immersive if largely uninformative, â€œBreaking the Frameâ€ù is best appreciated as a chance to spend time with the painter, filmmaker, author, performance artist and epic cat lover Carolee Schneemann (born 1939). One of the leading female figures of American avant-garde cinema, Ms. Schneemann is best known for â€œFusesâ€ù (1965), a gorgeous onetime scandal that features explicit images of her having sex with her partner, the composer James Tenney. â€œI can consider â€˜Fuses,â€™Â â€ù Ms. Schneemann once wrote, â€œnot simply as a film but in its revelatory cultural erotic intrusion â€” a vision (message) of genital sexuality and female pleasure which vitalized and agitated the art world.â€ù

Itâ€™s also a visually beautiful, hypnotic work that is said to have instigated a small riot when it was shown at the 1989 Moscow Film Festival as part of a sidebar on sexuality in American movies that also included Steven Soderberghâ€™s â€œsex, lies & videotapeâ€ù and Russ Meyerâ€™s â€œBeyond the Valley of the Dolls.â€ù After â€œFusesâ€ù first played in the festival, its later screenings were initially canceled; it was eventually shown, unannounced. Whether you view the former Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. as a well-intentioned hatchet man during the 2008 financial crisis, or a systemic enabler, or something in between, Joe Berlingerâ€™s documentary about him adds little to the conversation. The fugitive, whose picture is flashed on television, pressures Adele into taking him home, where he can hide out. â€œLabor Dayâ€ù is an embarrassing comedown for Mr. Reitman, the gifted director of â€œYoung Adult,â€ù â€œJuno,â€ù â€œThank You for Smokingâ€ù and â€œUp in the Air.â€ù Itâ€™s also absurdly prim. â€œWhat I want to talk about is crust,â€ù Frank gravely intones, as the camera, in one of the movieâ€™s many blatant examples of product placement, focuses on a package of Pillsbury flour.

â€œLabor Dayâ€ù seems designed for the crowd that devours Nicholas Sparksâ€™s romantic daydreams. â€œItâ€™s all about instinct,â€ù he counsels. â€œPay too much attention to recipes, and you forget how to feel.â€ù Then he declares, â€œPeople buy all these fancy gadgets, but sometimes the tool is right there attached to your own body.â€ù The fragile, voluptuous Adele begins to quiver perceptibly.

The movieâ€™s principal saving grace is Ms. Winsletâ€™s convincing portrayal of Adele, a despairing woman of low self-esteem just a twitch away from a nervous breakdown. In almost every other respect, this overbaked romantic hokum is preposterous.

â€œLabor Dayâ€ù occupies the same psychic territory as â€œPeyton Place,â€ù Grace Metaliousâ€™s heavy-breathing 1956 novel, later to be a movie and television series. During this melancholic moment of her life, she encounters the Forever Young photo studio and decides to have her portrait taken. When she exits, she becomes her 20-year-old self. â€œMiss Granny,â€ù a South Korean comic-fantasy film, begins with the recollection of a 73-year-old widow, Oh Mal-soon (Na Moon-hee), that before she had a son, she couldnâ€™t imagine living past 30. As Audrey, she joins her grandsonâ€™s heavy metal band and transforms it into a pop group, all while winning the affection of her grandson and a young man who runs an â€œAmerican Idolâ€ù-style television show. An older friend, meanwhile, recognizes that sheâ€™s her younger self.

This raucous, six-minute miniature evocation of the history of Disney animation is the briefest of the five Oscar nominees in the animation category of best short film. Whether seen in 3-D or not, it is pure movie magic.

And now that Hollywood packages the nominated shorts for theatrical release, they are attracting a growing audience. The other two Oscar short categories â€” live action and documentary â€” have also gained commercial traction as cable and public television have helped familiarize the public with films of varying length. And this yearâ€™s competing short documentaries reveal that for many topics, a well-made film of less than an hour can tell a compelling story.

The animated shorts are especially outstanding. Laurent Witzâ€™s â€œMr Hublotâ€ù portrays a surreal world dominated by old-fashioned, artfully designed heavy machinery. Its inhabitants are made partly of salvaged mechanical parts. The title character is an agoraphobic cyborg whose hermetic existence is upended with the arrival of a robot dog.

Visually as impressive is the Japanese animator Shuhei Moritaâ€™s mysterious, beautiful â€œPossessions.â€ù Set in the 18th century, it is a parable of healing in which a man, lost in the mountains, enters a world of discarded umbrellas and kimonos and proceeds to mend them. The story is inspired by a myth that after 100 years, tools and instruments attain souls and trick people.

The live-action nominees are not as uniformly entrancing. In the most ambitious â€” â€œThat Wasnâ€™t Me,â€ù by the Spanish filmmaker Esteban Crespo â€” the fates of an African child soldier and a Spanish aid worker intersect in ways that are both tragic and redemptive. The filmâ€™s depiction of altruistic Westerners who find themselves in the middle of a hell where children are ordered to kill to prove their courage is as harrowing as it is sadly believable.
The word for this yearâ€™s collection of Oscar shorts is variety.

The short-documentary category has an unusually strong number of compelling individual portraits. Jeffrey Karoffâ€™s â€œCavediggerâ€ù observes the ferociously independent artist Ra Paulette, who digs elegant caves that resemble cathedrals in New Mexicoâ€™s sandstone cliffs. The artist, in his mid-60s, is in the midst of grand 10-year project that he considers his magnum opus.

In Daniel Sousaâ€™s ghostly â€œFeral,â€ù a wild child discovered by a hunter in a forest is brought back to civilization, where he doesnâ€™t fit in. The sweetest animated entry is â€œRoom on the Broom,â€ù Max Lang and Jan Lachauerâ€™s fairy tale about a kindly witch (voiced by Gillian Anderson) who welcomes passengers â€” a cat, a bird, a dog and a frog â€” on her increasingly crowded broomstick.

Malcolm Clarkeâ€™s â€œThe Lady in Number 6,â€ù is an inspiring portrait of 109-year-old Alice Herz Sommer, a classical pianist, Holocaust survivor and boundlessly joyful optimist who spends most of her days playing Bach, Beethoven and Brahms.

Once upon a time, animation was thought of as a specialty craft, dutifully noted by the Oscars. In the age of computers, Pixar and blockbuster toons, innovative shorts can be steppingstones to major careers and are increasingly scrutinized as serious artworks on an par with photographic films. The respect they now command, I should add, is long overdue. At the same time, their quality continues to improve.

You may have seen the eye-popping 3-D animated Disney short â€œGet a Horse!â€ù In this spicy visual appetizer, which accompanies the megahit â€œFrozen,â€ù Mickey and Minnie Mouse and their friends Horace Horsecollar and Clarabelle Cow enjoy a hayride until the appearance of Peg-Leg Pete, who tries to run them off the road. As Mickey and Horace fight with Pete, these hand-drawn, black-and-white animated characters are forced through the screen, emerging as colorful CGI versions of themselves. A frantic battle royal ensues as a raft of Disney characters jump in and out of the screen and chase one another in circles.

Edgar Barensâ€™s â€œPrison Terminal: The Last Days of Private Jack Hall,â€ù made for HBO, is much darker, sadder portrait of old age, but not without nobility. Its subject is a terminally ill prisoner who served in World War II and was later incarcerated for killing a drug dealer. Filmed over six months inside the Iowa State Penitentiary, where an innovative volunteer hospice program run by fellow prisoners eased his final days, â€œPrison Terminalâ€ù debuts on March 31 on HBO.

The most ambitious selection of this category, Sara Ishaqâ€™s â€œKarama Has No Walls,â€ù is set in Change Square in Yemenâ€™s capital, Sana, where a peaceful demonstration demanding the fall of the countryâ€™s autocratic ruler, Ali Abdullah Saleh, turned into a blood bath in which government snipers killed 53 protesters. The film has a similar you-are-there immediacy to â€œThe Square,â€ù Jehane Noujaimâ€™s transfixing documentary of the tumultuous protests in the center of Cairo.

Peter Brookâ€™s productions of Shakespeare in the â€™50s and â€™60s are legendary. His subsequent work â€” â€œMarat/Sadeâ€ù and â€œThe Mahabharata,â€ù in particular â€” occupies a central place in the history of modern theater and represents a standing challenge to the psychological realism and social didacticism that have dominated the art form in Britain and America. His interest has always been in the ritual roots and mythical resonances of the theater, and the idea of acting he articulates in â€œThe Tightropeâ€ù has a primal, even mystical tenor. He speaks of access to a collective brain, of grasping the essence of time and of the ways the theater can offer a heightened experience of life.

At the beginning of the film, Mr. Brook explains that he usually refuses the request of those who want to watch his rehearsals: What could be more bothersome than a fly on the wall? Simon Brook used five hidden cameras, and the audience has a sense of witnessing intimate moments rather than watching a performance.

Wearing a bright orange shirt and holding forth in an accent that bespeaks breeding and education, Mr. Brook, edging toward 90, seems at first to be a gentle, grandfatherly teacher. He invites his pupils â€” of various shapes, sizes and backgrounds, speaking at least four languages â€” to undertake what looks like a fairly elementary, mechanical exercise. They are to walk across a large Persian carpet as if along a tightrope, maintaining balance and trying out whatever tricks or stunts strike their fancy. The most important requirement is that they convey a sense of reality, as if they were genuinely suspended in the air, their feet hugging a thin cord. After a while, it becomes clear that the tightrope is also a metaphor, standing for the existential risk inherent in every serious instance of playing.

As Mr. Brookâ€™s criticisms â€” never unfriendly, always candid â€” make clear, what the tightrope walkers are really doing is, well, everything: conveying emotion, telling a story, inhabiting a situation that demands limitless, almost impossible focus. And, of course, thatâ€™s only the beginning. Accompanied by music (including snatches of â€œThe Magic Fluteâ€ù) and supplied with rudimentary props (bamboo reeds, a few chairs, a book of matches), they explore short scenes and improvisations, always encouraged to find the concentration and imaginative daring of the initial high-wire acts.

At times, the faces of the actors under his command register confusion and frustration. Mr. Brookâ€™s words can flow almost effortlessly from plain practicality â€” stand here; walk that way; start again â€” to dizzying abstraction. The genesis of Mr. Jenisonâ€™s inquiry into Vermeerâ€™s technique was partly sparked by David Hockney and Philip Steadman, who both appear in the movie. Mr. Steadman wrote â€œVermeerâ€™s Camera: Uncovering the Truth Behind the Masterpieces,â€ù in which he argues, as others have before him, that Vermeer used a camera obscura to create his paintings. By using this apparatus at a certain angle, Mr. Jenison found he could paint a reflected image in great detail, capturing the originalâ€™s shapes and colors. He then recreated the room and figures in Vermeerâ€™s â€œThe Music Lessonâ€ù to see if he could make his own version. â€œIâ€™m going to try to paint a Vermeer,â€ù he says.

In other words, what they seem to be asking, though no one in the movie is so gauche to say it bluntly: Did Vermeer cheat his way into history? Certainly, Mr. Jenison doesnâ€™t put it that way, though he comes close. â€œItâ€™s possible,â€ù he says soon after the movie opens, that Vermeer â€œcould paint some pretty remarkable pictures without a lot of training. Itâ€™s possible that he was more of an experimenter, more of a tinkerer, more of a geek. And in that way I feel a kinship with him because Iâ€™m a computer graphics guy, and we use technology to make a realistic, beautiful image, and itâ€™s possible thatâ€™s exactly what Vermeer was doing.â€ù Here, Mr. Jenison tries to turn the possible into the probable.

Susan Sontag called interpretation the revenge of the intellect upon art. Something similar could be said of Mr. Jenisonâ€™s relationship with Vermeer, which, despite being couched in the nominally objective language of science, has the feel of a 21st-century rationalistâ€™s attempt to vanquish a 17th-century mystery. Mr. Jenison appears moved after seeing the original â€œMusic Lessonâ€ù in Buckingham Palace but, for all his efforts to recreate Vermeerâ€™s methods â€” he studies light, grinds his own pigments, builds a detailed set â€” he seems completely uninterested in Vermeerâ€™s art. That he doesnâ€™t see thereâ€™s a difference makes him a harder-working, better-bankrolled version of the clichÃ©d gallerygoer who looks at a Pollock and sees a finger painting instead of a revolution.

â€œTimâ€™s Vermeerâ€ù is a little documentary that tracks how one manâ€™s love turned into revenge. The title figure â€” well, one, anyway â€” is Tim Jenison, a scientist, inventor and restless hobbyist with deep pockets and famous friends, including Penn Jillette, who produced the movie, and Teller, who directed. In the 1980s, Mr. Jenison founded NewTek, a hardware and software company that scored an early success with the creation of Video Toaster, an affordable desktop video-production tool. Since then, this autodidact, now in his late 50s, has done this and that, including embarking on a multiyear odyssey to discover whether the movieâ€™s other, better-known, subject, the Dutch master Johannes Vermeer (1632-75), used any kind of optical tools when he created his extraordinary paintings.

Shooting in unattractive, hard-edge digital, Teller condenses Mr. Jenisonâ€™s years-long pursuit into 80 glib, alternately diverting, exasperating and tedious minutes. Along the way, you learn a little about art and a great deal about the familiar impulse to tame art and drain it of its mystery and power. At the beginning of â€œTimâ€™s Vermeer,â€ù Mr. Jillette, a jovial presence, says in voice-over that the â€œmagical qualityâ€ù in Vermeerâ€™s work has mystified many, partly because X-rays show no sketches under the paintings. â€œItâ€™s as if Vermeer,â€ù Mr. Jillette says, â€œwere some unfathomable genius who could just walk up to a canvas and magically paint with light.â€ù And everyone knows â€” perhaps professional illusionists most of all â€” that magic doesnâ€™t exist.

Julio falls alone but doesnâ€™t rise alone. A group of fellow workers immediately cluster around him, offering clucks of support and a meal. Lino Brockaâ€™s â€œManila in the Claws of Lightâ€ù begins with a whisper and ends with a howl. In between, there are grace notes, escalating horrors and the peripatetic journey of a country mouse, Julio (Rafael Roco Jr., later known as Bembol Roco), in the big city. Marcos. Brocka, a political activist as well as a prolific filmmaker, died in a car accident in 1991 at 52, and is ready for rediscovery.

The movieâ€™s palpable, deeply lived-in realism is among its great attractions, largely because the film isnâ€™t just a story about a young Filipino Everyman, but because itâ€™s also a de facto record of Manila in the 1970s. When the story opens, Julio has been in the city for about seven months. For most of â€œManila in the Claws of Light,â€ù Julio doesnâ€™t so much search for Ligaya as wait for her outside the building where he believes she now lives. As he stands under a street sign pointedly labeled Misericordia (Latin for mercy), Julio looks beseechingly up at the window where, every so often, he thinks he sees Ligaya. Meanwhile, there are protests in the street, and the city â€” or rather one agonizingly abject ghetto â€” is burning. Julio is waiting for something to happen even as Brocka himself â€” who was briefly jailed by Marcos in 1985 â€” was moved to action. You would think. Mr. Wheatley has cited Paul Verhoeven as an influence, and the relish â€œFieldâ€ù takes in religion, superstition and disease evokes the grit of Mr. Verhoevenâ€™s medieval wallow â€œFlesh + Blood.â€ù But that movie concluded tidily. Mr. Wheatleyâ€™s, regrettably, does not.

The writer-director John Huddles sets his ersatz science fiction on the final day of a philosophy seminar in Jakarta, Indonesia, led by a teacher (James Dâ€™Arcy) whoâ€™s pushing his students to the limit. Written by Mr. Clooney and his producing partner, Grant Heslov, â€œThe Monuments Menâ€ù slices off a sliver of a great World War II story and turns it into a lightweight entertainment that doesnâ€™t ask you to think too hard. The storyâ€™s real-life heroes were a group of curators, restorers, archivists and the like who served in the Monuments, Fine Arts and Archives Section, an Allied effort to protect Europeâ€™s cultural heritage. Nicknamed the Monuments Men, this group eventually included 350 or so men and women from 13 countries who were with the unit from 1943 to 1951. Its exploits have been related in various books, including â€œThe Monuments Men: Allied Heroes, Nazi Thieves, and the Greatest Treasure Hunt in History,â€ù written by Robert M. Edsel, with Bret Witter.

Now itâ€™s Mr. Clooneyâ€™s turn as Frank Stokes, an art historian and the storyâ€™s hub, to lead a charmingly quirky crew in a World War II operation to rescue Europeâ€™s artistic treasures from the Nazis. Stokes is the man for the job: He enters wrapped in a professorial air, wearing spectacles and a salt-and-pepper beard while lecturing President Franklin D. Roosevelt on the dangers posed to â€œthe greatest historical achievements known to man.â€ù These would be the artworks that the Nazis began systematically to steal â€” by emptying museums and confiscating work owned by Jewish collectors â€” soon after Hitler, that famously failed painter and lover of kitsch, took power.

It can be nice to spend time with these actors even when you donâ€™t believe their characters for a single second, and thereâ€™s no denying this movieâ€™s easy pleasures, including the guaranteed satisfaction that comes in watching, yet again, the Nazis go down in defeat. Yet because Mr. Clooney canâ€™t figure out what kind of story this is, he too often slips into pandering mode, including in his own performance, which is filled with too many smiles and speeches. He also gives himself the worst scene in the film: an encounter with a captured German, Colonel Wegner (Holger Handtke), who being an official villain â€” heâ€™s a Nazi, kills in cold blood and has thin lips â€” says something awful about Jews. Donâ€™t worry. Mr. Clooneyâ€™s character sets that guy straight because, you know, somebody has to.

Based on Mr. Edselâ€™s book, the film whittles the Monuments Men story down to a handful of ideal types, including Stokes, whoâ€™s based on George Leslie Stout, a conservator at the Fogg Museum at Harvard. Itâ€™s Stokes who rounds up the team members, each of whom is introduced in a short, snappy, comic scene doing what he does best: Matt Damon plays James Granger, a museum man first seen touching up a ceiling (prompting a Michelangelo joke); John Goodman, as a sculptor, Walter Garfield, enters hacking away at a hunk of stone like a John Henry Rodin. Bob Balaban, seen leading a rehearsal, plays Preston Savitz, an effete fussbudget who, I was surprised to learn, was â€œinspired byâ€ù Lincoln Kirstein who, among his many accomplishments, helped found the New York City Ballet.

Thatâ€™s too bad, because if thereâ€™s anyone who you expect to smarten up a joint, itâ€™s Mr. Clooney. The brain trust behind the original Monuments Men was staggering and included individuals who helped run some of Americaâ€™s greatest cultural institutions. At the very least you expect their fictional counterparts to exchange a little shoptalk and some thoughts on art, literature and the latest restoration techniques or maybe just gossip about Picassoâ€™s latest mistress. Kirstein brought George Balanchine to America (together they founded City Ballet and the School of American Ballet); was friends with the architect Philip Johnson; and was involved in the planning of Lincoln Center. Surely he did more than coo like a baby about the crackers in his care package, as Savitz does.

Mr. Balaban is adorable in that Bob Balaban way, somewhat elfin, and dry as Melba toast. He smiles through jokes and some physical comedy done at his expense, largely from Bill Murray, whose character, Richard Campbell, is a composite of several real Monuments Men including an architect, Robert Kelley Posey. (Mr. Murray plays â€œBill Murrayâ€ù just fine.) A captain, Posey served with Gen. George S. Patton and the Third Army, and was teamed up with Kirstein, a private first class also with the Third. Mr. Edsel describes Posey and Kirstein as an odd couple but brilliantly paired. Mr. Clooney literalizes the Felix and Oscar shtick and turns Savitz and Campbell into sweet, sentimentalized funnymen who all but bumble into their historic moment. Thereâ€™s nothing brilliant about them.

Mr. Clooney doesnâ€™t just simplify the characters; he also turns them into pleasantly innocuous caricatures that at times edge into cartoons. Despite a passing reference to John Wayne â€” and what feels like a hopeful invocation of Wayneâ€™s later work with Howard Hawks â€” the characters are less â€œEl Doradoâ€ù types and more like Cutie (Mr. Damon), Goofy (Mr. Murray), Starchy (Mr. Balaban), Boozy (Hugh Bonneville as Donald Jeffries), Frenchy (Jean Dujardin as Jean Claude Clermont) and Jewish Guy (Dimitri Leonidas as Sam Epstein). Cate Blanchett isnâ€™t quite Snow White, but her French frump, Claire Simone, enjoys a princess-at-the ball moment. (The character is a take on Rose Valland, a French museum employee turned Resistance spy who kept records of what the Nazis pilfered.)

And here we thought that George Clooney was this eraâ€™s Cary Grant even if, with his squinty smile and no-sweat insouciance, heâ€™s really closer to Clark Gable. As it turns out, Mr. Clooney seems to have been harboring a desire to tap into his inner Gregory Peck â€” noble, stolid, dull â€” as he does in â€œThe Monuments Men,â€ù which he both directed and stars in. It was Peck who led the team of World War II Allied saboteurs in â€œThe Guns of Navarone,â€ù one of those men-on-a-mission movies, a subgenre that includes everything from â€œThe Dirty Dozenâ€ù to the â€œOceanâ€™s Elevenâ€ù trilogy, which starred Mr. Clooney in a fizzier, less sanctimonious mode.

Directed by Yang Woo-seok

Mr. Songâ€™s titular character, also named Song, hustles his way to wealth as a real estate and tax lawyer, then falls into representing a student who was tortured into a false confession. He sheds some interesting light on the boss he was fated to serve. Somewhat boastfully, Murmelstein notes that he was one of only two Jews permitted in Eichmannâ€™s presence, and their association lasted seven years, from the German annexation of Austria until the end of the war. He challenges Arendtâ€™s famous account of Eichmannâ€™s personality: â€œHe was not banal. He was a demon.â€ù The Eichmann he knew â€” who participated in the desecration of a synagogue during Kristallnacht â€” was neither a mediocre bureaucrat nor an icy technocrat, but rather a corrupt and capricious gangster, motivated by greed and competitiveness as well as ideology.

Murmelstein likens himself to Sancho Panza, a practical man surrounded by fools, and to Scheherazade, who evaded death by telling stories, but no literary imagination could have created such an articulate amalgam of vanity, pettiness, courage and guile. â€œThe Last of the Unjustâ€ù is both impressive and maddening precisely because it fails (or refuses) to resolve the contradictions this man presents. â€œShoahâ€ù remains a heroic reckoning with the limits of collective understanding, but â€œThe Last of the Unjustâ€ù is something smaller, stranger and more paradoxical: the portrait of an individual whose actions still defy comprehension, and the self-portrait of an artist consumed by the past.

The Claude Lanzmann in those scenes is more reticent than the older version, allowing his subject, a prodigy of self-justifying volubility, to do most of the talking. But the filmmaker is nonetheless a notable presence: chain-smoking, fashionably dressed and surprisingly quick to chuckle and smile. He tells us in an early on-screen note that he came to love Murmelstein and to admire his truthfulness. At the end of the film, he throws his arm across the other manâ€™s shoulders, an embrace that can be seen as a gesture of forgiveness and solidarity, as one wily, ambitious adventurer recognizes another.

Murmelstein was an energetic participant in this dreadful project, one whose collaboration made him a hated figure after the war. Hannah Arendtâ€™s â€œEichmann in Jerusalemâ€ù notoriously accused Jewish leaders like him of complicity with Nazi crimes, and though Murmelstein was acquitted after a trial in Czechoslovakia, many Jews, including the prominent religious scholar Gershom Scholem, believed he should have faced the kind of justice received by his patron and tormentor, Adolf Eichmann. In 1975, Murmelstein was living in obscurity in Rome, where Mr. Lanzmann found him and conducted the weeklong series of interviews that form the bulk of â€œThe Last of the Unjust.â€ù

From time to time, as Murmelstein goes on about committees and procedures, transportation protocols and sanitation initiatives, Mr. Lanzmann must remind him that he is really talking about the death and displacement of thousands of people. And while Murmelstein takes pride in having saved the lives of many Jews under his authority, he is also oddly boastful about his competence in fulfilling Nazi directives. This was only partly a matter of survival; it is clear that he was also motivated by the equally basic human urge to do a good job, however evil the job in question may have been.

There are two Claude Lanzmanns on view here. One belongs to the present day: a silver-haired eminence, walking slowly through the grounds of Theresienstadt and explaining, in a rumbling, scolding baritone, what happened there. The hamlet was cynically used by the Nazis as a decoy to show concerned visitors (notably the International Red Cross) that the Jews in German-occupied lands were being treated decently, and Mr. Lanzmann sets out to anatomize the particular cruelty of this deception. It was not only that Theresienstadt, 37 miles from Prague, was a transit point for Jews who would be deported to the death camps in the East, but also that its facade of normalcy was maintained through terror and manipulation. The Nazi authorities forced the Jews to become accomplices in their own destruction and in the denial of it.

The questions proliferate. Is this man confessing or making excuses? Is the other man in the picture offering absolution or accepting an alibi? Are the present-day sections of the film meant to support the conclusions of the earlier interviews, or are they offered as implicit self-correction, belatedly addressing questions that were not asked before?

This challenge weighs heavily on his latest offering, â€œThe Last of the Unjust,â€ù which seems to focus, for nearly four hours, on the actions and reminiscences of a single man, Benjamin Murmelstein, a prominent rabbi in Vienna who became the last Jewish â€œelderâ€ù of the Theresienstadt ghetto. I say â€œseemsâ€ù because while Murmelsteinâ€™s animated, high-pitched speech and cherubic, bespectacled face dominate the screen, â€œThe Last of the Unjustâ€ù is also, unmistakably, about Mr. Lanzmann himself, and about his status as a leading interpreter of the Holocaust. It feels more personal than â€œShoah,â€ù â€œSobibor, October 14, 1943, 4 P.M.â€ù or â€œThe Karski Reportâ€ù in ways that are both fascinating and troubling.
â€œThe Last of the Unjustâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Detailed discussions of mass murder.

Murmelstein, his eyes barely visible behind thick glasses, his pudgy features surmounted by a thinning brush cut, is candid about his own adventurous nature, and also about the ambition that brought him to positions of authority in Theresienstadt and, earlier, in Nazi-controlled Vienna. At one point, he confesses to a hunger for power, though at another, he denies that he was â€œpower mad,â€ù and this kind of precise (or empty) distinction is fairly typical. His discourse is a flood of administrative detail â€” names, dates, meetings, orders given and received â€” brimming with annotations, digressions and punctilious self-corrections. This elaborate candor can seem like a form of evasion, as the recitation of small facts deflects our attention, and his, from the large and unspeakable question of his guilt.

How much of Eichmannâ€™s guilt does Murmelstein share? Near the end of â€œThe Last of the Unjust,â€ù Murmelstein says that while he and the other ghetto elders should be condemned, they should not be judged. This verdict sounds fair, but it is also puzzling. How can condemnation proceed without judgment?

Perhaps the most haunting and enduring feature of â€œShoah,â€ù Claude Lanzmannâ€™s nine-and-a-half-hour documentary â€” the closest thing to a definitive cinematic work on the Nazisâ€™ mass murder of European Jews we are likely to have â€” is its dogged commitment to the present tense. Filmed mostly in the 1970s in some of the places where the killing was planned and carried out, â€œShoah,â€ù released in 1985, relies on face-to-face, after-the-fact testimony rather than archival footage or dramatic reconstruction. It is thus simultaneously about the imperative to remember and the inadequacy of memory. A masterpiece of historical detective work, the film is also a philosophical exploration of a gap that has only grown wider in the years since its release.

But at the same time, that gap â€” the terrifying silence evoked by Mr. Lanzmannâ€™s shots of desolate landscapes â€” has been filled by a profusion of images, stories and memorials. The never-ending stream of post-â€œShoah,â€ù post-â€œSchindlerâ€™s Listâ€ù movies and books creates an illusion of memory, allowing us to believe that we know more than we really do. Mr. Lanzmannâ€™s subsequent films, culled from interviews contemporaneous with the making of â€œShoahâ€ù but not included in it, face the challenge of reasserting the strangeness, the uniqueness, the inexplicability of a historical event that has been rendered familiar and accessible.

Though the filmâ€™s abstractions can alienate, and intellectual connections are sometimes paid for in drained emotional heat, â€œMars at Sunriseâ€ù is a thoughtful and inventive look at a seemingly endless war. More than anything, the ambivalence written into the roles â€” and poignantly captured by the performers â€” seems to suggest that while taking sides is not impossible, it is almost certainly fruitless.

The foes are Khaled (Ali Suliman), a Palestinian artist, and Eyal (Guy El Hanan), the Israeli soldier who once detained and tortured him. Addressing the Israeli-Palestinian conflict through stylized compositions, nontraditional narrative and a stripped-down aesthetic, Jessica Habieâ€™s â€œMars at Sunriseâ€ù distills a war among many to a single, devastating duel.

Under its contemporary facade of buzzing cellphones and potty-mouthed insults, Bryan Poyserâ€™s â€œLove & Air Sexâ€ù is a traditional romantic comedy that is desperate to please. Although the main characters, in their 20s and early 30s, communicate mostly via text message, often in sexually graphic detail, they are the same vulnerable relationship seekers they have always been but with extra mileage on their pedometers.

The story follows two couples whose relationships have recently dissolved. But â€œLove & Air Sexâ€ù has a spontaneity and cheeky attitude lacking in Mr. Efronâ€™s film, along with spirited naturalistic performances that infuse the standard rom-com formula with a zany vitality.

â€œLove & Air Sexâ€ù is an affectionate insiderâ€™s tour of Austinâ€™s night life that could lure visiting hedonists to that Texas capital. Even when playing it safe and sweet, it conveys a bracing sense of adventure.

The screenplay, written by Mr. Poyser with David DeGrow Shotwell and Steven Walters, wittily deconstructs the etiquette of texting in romantic sparring matches whose feints and parries give the movie the flavor of a French bedroom farce. The newest wrinkle in the mating game is the popularity of air sex competitions, similar to air guitar contests, in which a participant â€” usually a young man â€” comically pantomimes his sexual technique to musical accompaniment.

In the language of Jeff (Zach Cregger), a slacker who dispenses tips on seduction to his buddies before a night on the town: â€œGirls guard the vagina. We have to guard the penis. Youâ€™ve got to let them know they canâ€™t have that. People always want what they canâ€™t have.â€ù He advises that making wounding remarks to a potential conquest will diminish her self-esteem and make her easier to seduce, because then she will be looking for â€œvalidation.â€ù Itâ€™s ugly, to be sure, but itâ€™s funny, and the tough women they pursue are no slouches at brutally dishing it back.

As in many indie comedies, the dialogue in â€œLove & Air Sex,â€ù Mr. Poyserâ€™s most commercial film, appears to spew without forethought from characters who devote considerable energy to cellphone strategizing: whether or not to respond to a text, how quickly to steer the conversation toward sex, and whether to play hard to get or aggressive.

In Steven Soderberghâ€™s â€œThe Limey,â€ù Terence Stamp played a British ex-con visiting Los Angeles to investigate his daughterâ€™s death, in a fish-out-of-water story owing a bit to Jacques Derayâ€™s â€œThe Outside Man.â€ù Who can say for sure if these films were on Brian A. â€œThe Lego Movieâ€ù captures both the delight and the frustration of this kind of play. The visual environment created by the filmmakers (Phil Lord and Christopher Miller of â€œ21 Jump Streetâ€ù wrote and directed; the animation is by Animal Logic) hums with wit and imagination. Although the images are computer generated, they move, for the most part, according to the pleasingly herky-jerky logic of hand-guided stop-motion. You are always aware that you are looking at a world of interlocking plastic blocks, an illusion enhanced in the 3-D version of the film. Smoke, sand and water are all made out of Lego, as are high-rise cities, pirate ships, mountains and a zone of free-form fantasy called Cloud Cuckoo Land.
â€œThe Lego Movieâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). A few almost-scary moments and almost-naughty words.

The story is a busy, slapdash contraption designed above all to satisfy the imperatives of big-budget family entertainment. There are fiery chases and hectic brawls, and a crowd of famous voices simultaneously enacting and lampooning the standard cartoon-quest narrative of heroic self-discovery. Pop-culture jokes ricochet off the heads of younger viewers to tickle the world-weary adults in the audience, with just enough sentimental goo applied at the end to unite the generations. Parents will dab their eyes while the kids roll theirs.

But of course that tension lurks in every box of Lego. Sometimes you want to execute a perfect copy of the thing depicted on the box; sometimes you want to challenge the laws of physics, aesthetics and common sense. Sometimes you want to pull it all apart and throw it on the floor. And sometimes you want to read a book.

The hero is a generic figurine named Emmet (Chris Pratt), who lives in a smiling conformist dystopia where the population follows the instruction manual, watches the same dumb television shows and listens to a peppy pop song (by Tegan and Sara) about how â€œEverything Is Awesome.â€ù Not unlike reality, you might say, and there are a few mild, and mildly hypocritical, satirical darts thrown at the mind-controlling tendencies of the corporate media-marketing-entertainment complex.

There is also a stew of kiddie-action elements: an ancient prophecy involving a wise wizard (Morgan Freeman) and a scheming supervillain (Will Ferrell); a plucky rebel (Elizabeth Banks) who recruits the baffled Emmet into the resistance; and a whole lot of chases and fights interspersed with jokes. Many of those also provide moments of whimsical brand extension, celebrations of the synergy embedded in the filmâ€™s title. Movies are one of the vehicles that bring children into the universe of modern entertainment, a place where merchandising, franchised intellectual property and archetypal narrative flow together endlessly. Lego is another such delivery system, where you can play with cowboys, ponies, Batman, Harry Potter and the whole â€œStar Warsâ€ù crew.

Binding â€œThe Lego Movieâ€ù together is a â€œMatrixâ€ù-like conceit that turns the whole thing into an allegory about the nature of creativity and the meaning of amusement. As such, it encounters an obvious contradiction, one that bothered the 10-year-old Lego maven who accompanied me to the press screening. The overt message is that you should throw out the manuals and follow the lead of your own ingenuity, improvising new combinations for the building blocks in front of you. But the movie itself follows a fairly strict and careful formula, thwarting its inventive potential in favor of the expected and familiar.

When I was young I lacked the patience and fine-motor skills to do much with Lego, but I spent a lot of time with friends whose bedrooms and basements bristled with elaborate, snapped-together spaceships and skyscrapers. There was always something of a gap between the care and imagination that went into the constructions and what you did with them after the building was done. Those intricate structures became, like just about everything else, stages for car crashes and action-figure duels. Now and then there would be a pause for an argument about who was the bad guy and what the rules were, and then the battle would resume until it was time for a snack.

The QuÃ©bÃ©cois director Denis CÃ´tÃ© throws a tight frame around his characters in â€œVic + Flo Saw a Bear,â€ù nearly boxing them in. That makes sense for this funny-eccentric, funny-scary story of two female ex-cons who having once been holed up together in prison are now holed up in a house in the deep woods. Thereâ€™s a once-upon- a-time feel to both the location and the movie, which had its premiere at the 2013 Berlin International Film Festival, where it won an award. The title may sound like a childrenâ€™s book and the bear may be metaphoric, but make no mistake: This is a story with surprisingly great, big teeth.

Something happens just before everything â€” the golf cart, adorable parole officer, (amusing) visit to a train exhibition and other carefully calibrated eccentricities â€” becomes overly cute. A stranger, Jackie (Marie Brassard), shows up and immediately insinuates herself into Vic and Floâ€™s lives, flashing a wild smile and trailed by a silent, hulking man twice her size.

For her part, Vic is waiting for her lover, Flo (Romane Bohringer), a somewhat younger, similarly life-toughened woman with long hair and strong appetites. The women settle in together or at least try to, moodily hanging out, smoking endless cigarettes and zipping around the deserted roads on a golf cart. Floâ€™s appetites â€” she also likes men and roams around the area picking them up â€” are one impediment. Another is Vicâ€™s parole officer, Guillaume (a wonderful Marc-AndrÃ© Grondin), a grave, sensitive young man whose officially authorized paternalism turns out to be something of a front. After initially swapping antagonisms and trading some comic hard-boiled talk, Guillaume and the women establish a curious friendship, creating a pocket of warmth amid the chill.

And, just like that, with only a mad smile and the unnerving sound of drums thundering on the score, Mr. CÃ´tÃ© completely flips â€œVic + Floâ€ù and transforms what seemed like a pleasant, seemingly predictable movie about a collection of eccentrics into a frightening tale of revenge. This isnâ€™t, it turns out, the usual once upon a time, but a story about the unknowns that can swallow us up.

The bear takes a while to show up. Mr. CÃ´tÃ©, a onetime film critic, isnâ€™t one to rush. He isnâ€™t keen on explanation or exposition, either, and likes to put his characters in a situation and then let his words, ideas and meaning gather gradually around them, like slow-rising water. The movieâ€™s arresting opener â€” a woman standing next to two boys on a bench, one of whom is playing the trumpet, badly â€” is exemplary of his deliberate, oblique, evocative approach. You donâ€™t know who these people are to one another, why the boys are dressed like scouts, why one is playing an instrument and why this woman with the crumpled face feels the need to critique his playing.

Sheâ€™s Vic, Victoria Champagne (Pierrette Robitaille), a blunt, no-nonsense type â€” thereâ€™s nothing bubbly about her â€” who has arrived in this part of rural Quebec to live in an old sugar shack with her ailing uncle, Ã‰mile (Georges Molnar). Looking very much like a defeated lion, with a resplendent white beard and fan of hair, Ã‰mile more or less lives in a wheelchair, unable to speak and cared for by a local, Charlot (Pier-Luc Funk). If there was once some kind of family feeling between Vic and Ã‰mile thereâ€™s no evidence of it now; he canâ€™t say, she doesnâ€™t. Her brother, Yvon (Guy Thauvette), is as tight-lipped. He just shows up, peels off some bills for Vic, hugs her and disappears.

Mr. CÃ´tÃ© spends a lot of time setting (and unsettling) the scene and a cool mood thatâ€™s literalized by the lovely blue palette. Thereâ€™s a story here, after a fashion, but mostly there are characters circulating around one another in a world thatâ€™s at once inviting and alienating. He moves the camera meaningfully, using camera movement to reveal things â€” as with an outdoor traveling shot across some woods that ends on some people â€” rather than to just mindlessly chase after his characters. Heâ€™s particularly fond of carefully composed still images in which the characters are arranged like figurines. This is a familiar strategy often used to accentuate deadpan comedy; here, Mr. CÃ´tÃ© uses it to create a sense that the characters are waiting.

The performances are not bad, though. Ms. Kazan, frantic and vulnerable, tries to keep Laurel/Audrey away from the clichÃ©s that lie in wait for her (them?) like ogres in a fairy tale. As an actress, she is always looking for new, appealing ways to be odd, and sheâ€™s good at finding them. Mr. Johnson, moonlighting from his grumpy goofball role on â€œNew Girl,â€ù seems to be refining a new millennial romantic archetype: the stoic, shaggy dream guy.

Then, as a result of a not-very-convincing car crash, Audrey dies and Laurel, mistaken for her sister, assumes her identity. She goes to the city, meets Audreyâ€™s married lover (Ron Livingston) and her bookish neighbor (Jake M. Johnson) and takes up Audreyâ€™s job selling real estate. The imposture is clumsy and tentative, which Laurel blames on amnesia from the accident.
â€œThe Pretty Oneâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex and swearing.

But there is something more than a little ghoulish about building a sweet, hipsterish romantic comedy on the grave of a dead sibling, and â€œThe Pretty Oneâ€ù wavers queasily between macabre humor and wide-eyed sincerity. You are urged to laugh and cry, but the best you are likely to manage is a polite, embarrassed smile.

â€œThe Pretty Oneâ€ù is intermittently charming, occasionally touching and entirely lacking in credibility. The script, in which self-consciously playful banter gives way to sudden floods of loud feeling, might have worked better as a string of emoji. Neither the comedy nor the melodrama works on its own terms, and Ms. LaMarqueâ€™s attempt to blend them is more awkward than bittersweet. The camera setups are as passive-aggressively deadpan as the dialogue, alternating between static wide shots and too-tight close-ups.

In â€œThe Pretty One,â€ù JenÃ©e LaMarqueâ€™s first feature, Zoe Kazan plays identical twins of contrasting temperament. Audrey, alluded to in the title, has a cute haircut, fashionable clothes and an exciting life in a city that might be Los Angeles. (The film is too coy to be specific about such things.) Her sister, Laurel, mousy and odd, lives with their widowed father (John Carroll Lynch) in a rambling house in a quirky town where she helps him paint copies of famous artworks.

Just days before his wedding, Nikhil finds himself in a bit of a bind: Not only does he need to prove his business savvy, and therefore worth, to his fiancÃ©e, but he also must keep her recently returned, long-estranged sister, Meeta, out of sight. Itâ€™s a recipe for failure. But in Vinil Mathewâ€™s â€œHasee Toh Phasee,â€ù the setup is also the perfect foil to what is an imperfect union.

Nikhil (Sidharth Malhotra) recognizes Meeta (Parineeti Chopra) as the young woman who left an impression on him years before. (She had strong ideas about cricket.) And in flashbacks to their childhood in Mumbai, they shared a knack for mischievously, yet ingenuously, testing the patience of their parents. Thereâ€™s no doubt that they â€” in this case, Nikhil â€” will spend the entire movie fighting what the audience already knows is their destiny.

Itâ€™s the treatment of her character, however, that is the biggest disappointment. Instead of heralding Meetaâ€™s initial nerdy quirkiness, the filmmakers turn her into a twitchy, blinking, prescription-drug-fueled hypocrite who extols a live-for-the-moment mantra but is afraid to face her own family and mistakes. What the filmmakers donâ€™t reconcile is how this hot mess of a woman in need of salvation managed to get a Ph.D. in chemical engineering, learn Mandarin and invent a special polymer.

While the film starts out as a seemingly fresh take on the romantic comedy, it is saddled with numerous contrivances and the clichÃ©d trappings of the genre: big weddings, wayward souls and quick-to-judge elders. Mr. Malhotra fares well as the pragmatic Nikhil, and Ms. Chopra shines despite the material.

Thereâ€™s more, although the soap-opera details of who did what and why to whom are formulaic and uninvolving. Mark Waters (who directed â€œMean Girlsâ€ù and â€œFreaky Fridayâ€ù; Daniel wrote â€œHeathersâ€ù) doesnâ€™t seem especially interested in the supernatural parts of â€œVampire Academy,â€ù and he clearly didnâ€™t have the budget to make what little hocus-pocus there is magical. He doesnâ€™t do much with the camera, but he manages the material with a winking irreverence that makes the movie breeze right along. And as Mr. Waters has in the past, he brings a conspicuous sympathetic touch to his handling of the younger performers, especially Ms. Deutch and Ms. Fry, but also Sarah Hyland as a school misfit and Dominic Sherwood as the regulation darkly brooding beauty.

The family line for the teenage flick â€œVampire Academyâ€ù may trace back to â€œDracula,â€ù but the recycling policy is strictly from â€œFrankenstein.â€ù Directed by Mark Waters and written by Daniel Waters, his brother, this genre rehash takes a helping of â€œHarry Potter,â€ù a measure of â€œMean Girlsâ€ù and elements from various teenage adventures, monster movies and queen-bee stories and recombines the borrowed parts into an unsurprisingly familiar tale. What is surprising is that while the patchwork whole creaks terribly in places, the parts also show signs of life.

Based on Richelle Meadâ€™s young-adult juggernaut, the movie cherry-picks components from the vampire mythology and repurposes them for mainstream appeal. The good vampires, the Moroi, may drink blood, but theyâ€™re also magical and, ridiculously, mortal. They can walk in the sun, although it helps to have gloves, shades and a fetching parasol. The Moroi arenâ€™t your great-grandmotherâ€™s Transylvania exotics, slipping like mist through open windows after dark: Theyâ€™re thoroughly modern, civilized types who meet their sanguineous needs by drinking from human volunteers in a gleaming white facility thatâ€™s the vampire equivalent of a juice bar.
â€œVampire Academyâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Some bloody violence.

The story centers on the teenage besties Rose (Zoey Deutch) and Lissa (Lucy Fry), who are bonded by blood and narrative contrivance. Rose is a half-human and half-vampire called a Dhampir, and the guardian in training for Lissa, a Moroi princess. When the movie opens, Rose and Lissa are on the lam, having run away sometime earlier from their school, St. Vladimirâ€™s Academy, because of some kind of complicated threat.
