These are the resident villains, the Strigoi, immortals whose red eyes suggest cheap special effects and hangovers. The Strigoi are trouble, but less so than some of the other kids.

Perched precariously at the intersection of race, religion and sexual identity, â€œThe New Black,â€ù Yoruba Richenâ€™s calm and nuanced exploration of African-American attitudes toward same-sex marriage, balances crude filmmaking with sophisticated insights.

Highlighting erroneous assumptions that prevented opponents of Californiaâ€™s Proposition 8 from cultivating black voters â€” for instance, that those who have been marginalized will automatically support the rights of other marginalized groups â€” Ms. Richen elucidates an entire spectrum of views, from actively egalitarian to reactively homophobic. Despite a seeming bias toward marriage equality, she appears to be motivated by a sincere curiosity thatâ€™s as empathetic to the concerns of religious leaders as to the pain of a young black lesbian whoâ€™s finally coming out to her beloved foster mother.

That scene, mirrored by the 2009 television disclosure of the gospel singer Anthony Charles Williams II â€” whose interviewer wants to know if heâ€™s waiting for â€œdeliveranceâ€ù from his homosexuality â€” cuts to the heart of the filmâ€™s essential humanity. As one contributor points out, same-sex couples are just doing what many African-Americans have already done: constructing families, however nontraditional, from whatever materials are at hand.

Though structured around Marylandâ€™s 2012 referendum challenging the stateâ€™s recently passed marriage equality bill (and tracing President Obamaâ€™s evolving stance on the issue), the film never allows political urgency to overwhelm its individual voices. Reaching out to both sides, Ms. Richen uses interviews, news footage and simple observation to show that black opposition to same-sex marriage is neither uniform nor prompted solely by church influence. As one interviewee explains, the extreme sexual abuses suffered by slaves have made sex an uncomfortable topic for many African-Americans, above and beyond any religious concerns.

Updating â€œRoboCopâ€ù was always going to be tough, if for no other reason than the originalâ€™s irony, and its future-shock visions have become todayâ€™s reality, from the downfall of Detroit to the embrace of privatization, the use of high-tech artificial limbs and the triumph of propaganda over public discourse. Radically unsentimental, the first film had a gleeful apocalyptic quality that made it feel like a feature-length version of the end of â€œDr. Strangelove,â€ù in which Slim Pickens hoots his way to doomsday. The new â€œRoboCopâ€ù has a star in the making with Mr. Kinnaman, an intensely sympathetic actor best known for the AMC series â€œThe Killing,â€ù and it also features a handful of excellent side players, including Gary Oldman, Michael Keaton and Jennifer Ehle. All thatâ€™s really missing here is a point of view.

Thereâ€™s more than a touch of Jesus to Mr. Verhoevenâ€™s RoboCop, who rises again to redeem us, more or less. (One of Mr. Verhoevenâ€™s recent projects is his book â€œJesus of Nazareth,â€ù which may become a movie.) This new version, directed by JosÃ© Padilha, largely ditches the religious undertones and instead plays up its title characterâ€™s humanity. RoboCop still saves, but his wife, Clara (Abbie Cornish), plays a more central role than her 1987 counterpart did. Like her hubby, Clara sheds tears â€” this is one damp production â€” but, unlike similar shoot-â€™em-ups, this film puts more steel in her character, even if it starts rusting when attention shifts to the coupleâ€™s son, David (John Paul Ruttan), one of those wide-eyed stand-ins for the movieâ€™s kiddie customers.

Every generation, apparently, gets the â€œRoboCopâ€ù it deserves, or perhaps desires. When the first one hit in the summer of 1987, Ronald Reagan was halfway through his second term as president and, as the movieâ€™s socioeconomic pokes and Star Wars program parody suggested, ripe for the lampooning. Set in a crime-plagued Detroit, Mr. Verhoevenâ€™s movie paints a vision of a failed American city scarred by derelict industrial zones and plagued by rampant crime, in which the only hope of salvation comes from privatization in the form of a corporation, OmniCorp. Helplessly overrun, the police are threatening to strike (evoking the air traffic controllers Reagan fired in 1981), when RoboCop (Peter Weller) clunks in, bombarding the town he also finally saves.
â€œRoboCopâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). The movie features gun violence.

The existential battle that rages through â€œRoboCop,â€ù a nicely cast, respectable remake of the wittily corrosive 1987 Paul Verhoeven film, is less the struggle between man and machine than between the originalâ€™s pop nihilism and the bottom-line commercialism driving this new vehicle. Once again, an ordinary man, a Detroit cop, Alex Murphy (Joel Kinnaman), is transformed by corporate interests into a cyborg after being critically wounded in the line of duty. And, as before, the reanimated creature walks and talks like a latter-day Frankensteinâ€™s monster, his recognizably human parts encased in an artificial carapace, although this version also mixes in tears with the bullets.

The larger-scale scenes, with their churning violence and conspicuously computer-generated elements and camera movements, will have you reaching for your video game controller. The only notable feature of these bludgeoning, enervating segments, a syncopated blur of hammering gunfire and dropping bodies, is how thoroughly they undercut the storyâ€™s nominal â€” or maybe just cynical â€” insistence on valorizing the human factor.

This is the first Hollywood movie from Mr. Padilha, a Brazilian filmmaker whose credits include the very fine documentary â€œBus 174â€ù and the very ugly exploitation flick â€œElite Squad.â€ù For the most part, he handles the smaller-scale action scenes in â€œRoboCopâ€ù competently, if unremarkably, and the closer he gets to the actors, the better.

Written by Joshua Zetumer (sharing credit with the original screenwriters, Edward Neumeier and Michael Miner), the movie has been pumped up, cautiously updated and cleaned up, with fewer expletives, if many more bullets. Among the other new attractions is a jingoistic television talk show host, Pat Novak, played by Samuel L. Jackson, who seems to have been tapped for duties so that he can deliver a bleeped Tarantino-esque obscenity. A corporate shill, Novak pops up every so often to provide intermittent commentary (and metacommentary), extolling red, white and blue militarism thatâ€™s as blunt as the action scenes. Mr. Jackson is a predictably crude, amusing instrument, even if his characterâ€™s ultra-conservative shtick is so familiar â€” Stephen Colbert mines much the same territory almost nightly â€” that the satire has no sting.

That leads to some matchmaking scenes, including a speed-dating sequence, that look borrowed from a zillion other movies of this ilk. But things perk up once Barry meets Melanie (Lucy Punch), a female version of himself in terms of inappropriateness.

For a gross-out movie, â€œSomeone Marry Barryâ€ù has a respectable number of genuinely funny moments. Over all, itâ€™s still kind of crass and lowbrow, showing a particular obsession with flatulence, but thereâ€™s a good-heartedness to it that somehow overrides your gut instinct to stop watching.

Mr. Labine and Ms. Punch find a workable comic chemistry, and the script by Rob Pearlstein (who also directed) gives Barryâ€™s buddies some amusing bits as well. Thereâ€™s nothing sophisticated or groundbreaking here, but the movie is a moderately good entry in the bro-grows-up genre.

Tyler Labine is Barry, a lunk who lacks the social filters most of us have and is thus constantly embarrassing his three best friends (Thomas Middleditch, Hayes MacArthur and Damon Wayans Jr.). They decide that the best way to solve this persistent problem is to find a wife for Barry, so that he can become her problem.

Written and directed by Chen Sicheng, who also plays the smitten clubgoer, the movie springs from a popular Chinese TV show (also starring Mr. Chen). Thereâ€™s a little effort to give each story its own tempo and style; you notice bits and pieces plucked from other movies or TV shows.

Love preoccupies us all, as the film proclaims, but another message comes through during a moviegoing scene when the name of the blockbuster director and entrepreneur James Cameron lingers on the theater screen: the hope of packing â€™em in.

The two kids are indeed pretty cute, but â€œBeijingâ€ù lurches and leaps past its better moments. The episodes involve generations of the lovelorn who are also related. One clubgoer falls for another, who becomes pregnant and has a pushy ex; a married woman learns about her husbandâ€™s affairs and goes partying; a middle-aged pair (Tony Leung Ka Fai and Carina Lau) meet in ostentatiously picturesque Greece for a tryst; a grandfather goes on blind dates.

The urban tales in â€œBeijing Love Storyâ€ù are shameless about conveying modern-age mores and old-fashioned sweetness. When two male friends speed down a road in a car, the cityscape is a riot of multicolored lights, and the techno music thumps as they fist-pumpingly exclaim, â€œThis is life!â€ù When two teenagers shyly get to know each other in another story, their hand-holding on a bus is played for its innocent romantic bliss.

Like a fresh ripple in the near-stagnant high school movie pool, Chris Nelsonâ€™s â€œDate and Switchâ€ù balances formula with winning performers, genuine humor and a generosity of spirit that this genre too often lacks.
â€œDate and Switchâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gateway drugs, dirty mouths and something known as the Foam Room.

â€œDo these guys know theyâ€™re living a clichÃ©?â€ù Matty asks, unimpressed; and though the swishiness surrounding him is all too stereotypical, itâ€™s to the filmâ€™s credit that Matty himself defies categorization. Supporting him with seasoned and natural performers (Dakota Johnson, as Mattyâ€™s former girlfriend and everyoneâ€™s decency gauge, is a standout), Mr. Nelson shapes a bighearted bromance whose sole message is that sex is confusing. And high school sex is the most confusing of all.

Proving that you donâ€™t mess with the classics, the plot unashamedly follows the traditional sex-before-senior-prom trajectory while adding its own idiosyncratic tweaks. (The sharp, peppy screenplay is by Alan Yang, a longtime writer and occasional actor and director on â€œParks and Recreation.â€ù) Losing their virginity, however, turns out to be more complicated than either Michael (Nicholas Braun) or his best bud, Matty (Hunter Cope, whose mobile features put you in mind of a younger Seth Rogen), expect.

â€œIâ€™m a gay dude,â€ù Matty announces, kicking off a wave of raunchy yet sweetly innocent scenes as both friends struggle to recalibrate their relationship. Loyally supportive of Mattyâ€™s orientation, Michael researches gay pornography and accompanies him to a gay club.

Shallow, timorous and unbelievable, alas, end up being more like it. Based on the 1979 Scott Spencer novel of the same tantalizing title (is â€œendlessâ€ù a happy vow or a threat?), the movie relates what is meant to be the kind of feverish love that sends people into shudders of ecstasy. This is the love, or should be, of Antony and Cleopatra, Scarlett and Rhett and the couple in the 1950 film noir â€œGun Crazyâ€ù who look at each other like â€œwild animals.â€ù This is the love, or should be, that burns, consumes and spurs Friar Laurence to warn Romeo: â€œThese violent delights have violent ends./And in their triumph die, like fire and powder,/Which as they kiss consume.â€ù

One problem with this love is that itâ€™s been difficult for filmmakers to translate it to the American screen, which has long been locked in the grip of a stultifying, Eros-killing Puritanism. In a superb film like â€œGun Crazy,â€ù which was made under strict industry self-cen6sorship, desire is expressed through innuendo, smoldering looks and the sublimating violence of erotically, ecstatically discharged guns. By contrast, American movies today often roil with orgiastic violence thatâ€™s a conspicuous substitute for sexual desire. That partly explains why this â€œEndless Loveâ€ù falls so flat, registering as more neutered than even the kitschy 1981 version with Brooke Shields directed by Franco Zeffirelli, now best remembered for those newcomers Tom Cruise and James Spader.
â€œEndless Loveâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). The only thing that burns is a house.

Thereâ€™s a promising edge to the opening of â€œEndless Love,â€ù which begins with a young man, David (Alex Pettyfer), speaking in voice-over about a young woman, Jade (Gabriella Wilde). Itâ€™s a high school graduation somewhere in Atlanta, and as the camera picks Jade out of the celebrating crowd, David reminisces about how heâ€™s been watching her for years. From the way he talks, he seems to have been watching her closely. Closely enough to suggest that heâ€™s been long nurturing a passion, perhaps an obsession â€” something deep, troubling and real.

Directed by Shana Feste (â€œCountry Strongâ€ù), this new â€œEndless Loveâ€ù doesnâ€™t have enough going on to make it memorably terrible: Banality is its gravest sin. Ms. Wilde and Mr. Pettyfer are very pretty (both have worked as models), and theyâ€™re certainly pleasant to look at, even if theyâ€™re also, often distractingly, too old for their roles. Jade is supposed to be 17 and sheltered, having spent most of her high school years giving comfort to her parents, Hugh and Anne (Bruce Greenwood and Joely Richardson), after the death of a son. Unlike Ms. Shields, whose status as a preternaturally sexualized child star imbued her with an otherworldly, almost celestial air (the celebrity who fell to Earth), the coltish Ms. Wilde mostly just suggests the supermodel next door. Ms. Feste responds accordingly and shoots Jade twirling and running as if she were in a commercial for an exciting new product. It isnâ€™t that people in love donâ€™t sometimes run ecstatically into the wind, but that the image, like so many shots and so many of the emotional moments, is so canned. When Jade and David do make love, itâ€™s on the floor in front of a fireplace; they also hold hands when they jump off a pier into some water. About the only original touch is how the script, by Ms. Feste and Joshua Safran, shifts the storyâ€™s weight to Hugh, whose love for his daughter smolders with all the weird, lunatic intensity thatâ€™s otherwise missing.
Itâ€™s all light as a feather, with Jeremy Leven, the writer and director, landing some good multinational jokes along the way.

He becomes engaged to Greta (Nora Tschirner), his longtime German girlfriend, an attractive flight attendant with a sharp sense of humor. But shortly thereafter, he is smitten by a lovely Frenchwoman, CÃ©cile (Louise Monot), who keeps appearing beside his bus at traffic lights, riding her bicycle.
â€œGirl on a Bicycleâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for a bit of bad language and a few flashes of nudity.

That leads to preposterous complications that have Paolo dashing back and forth between Greta and CÃ©cile, keeping Greta in the dark about why he is constantly disappearing. Itâ€™s a variation on one of the oldest comic setups: the two-dates-at-once conundrum. Here, an added wrinkle is that CÃ©cileâ€™s two young children also become part of the mix, as does Paoloâ€™s friend Derek (Paddy Considine).

Paolo (Vincenzo Amato) is an Italian living in Paris, where he drives a tour bus, peppering his narrative for the customers with asides explaining how Italy is superior to France in all sorts of ways.

If youâ€™re willing to believe the old moviemaking canard that beautiful, intelligent women are attracted to underachieving men with no ambition or prospects, then youâ€™ll find â€œGirl on a Bicycleâ€ù to be a sweet, often witty romantic comedy.

Still, the ups and downs of their affair arenâ€™t entirely lacking in credibility. They are so eager to be nice to each other, and to avoid conflict, that as the initial intensity of their connection starts to cool, there is nothing to replace it. They love each other but canâ€™t figure out what to do about it.

At times, it feels as if they are following instructions rather than acting out of genuine emotion. Danny resists commitment, but it seems to be because he thinks guys are supposed to do that, and Debbieâ€™s desire for domesticity seems similarly abstract. Ms. Bryant and Mr. Ealy are both warm, appealing actors, afflicted here less by an absence of chemistry than by thinly imagined circumstances. We learn a little bit about his job, less about hers and almost nothing about their families or interests. And there is not quite enough between them to fill in the blanks.

Bernie and Joanâ€™s intimate moments involve a lot of noise, a slap or two, a dentistâ€™s chair and a chicken mask â€” not all at once, but you get the idea. Debbie and Danny favor bubble baths, candles and Champagne. They also follow a more conventional relationship trajectory, starting out casually and then following the route from dating to cohabitation to pet adoption and beyond.

It is now 40 years since the first performances of David Mametâ€™s â€œSexual Perversity in Chicagoâ€ù and almost 30 since the play was made into a movie, starring Rob Lowe and Demi Moore and directed by Edward Zwick, called â€œAbout Last Night ... .â€ù Some things have changed (Mr. Mamet has evolved into a dyspeptic right-winger) and some have not (Mr. Lowe and Ms. Moore are still very good looking), but all in all, the thing holds up pretty well. Mr. Mametâ€™s title was always a bit of a misnomer â€” his jagged play is more interested in romantic confusion and emotional complication than in freaky bedroom matters â€” but his map of the crooked paths to heterosexual bliss remains useful and adaptable, even when softened and tidied up by Hollywood. The proof is in the new â€œAbout Last Night,â€ù a sweet, silly, semi-raunchy Valentineâ€™s Day confection directed by Steve Pink (â€œHot Tub Time Machineâ€ù).

This is sad, and sometimes a bit dull, even when Paula Patton briefly shows up as Dannyâ€™s toxic ex, Alison. You might say that Bernie and Joan are around to supply clownish distraction from the travails of their pals, but â€œAbout Last Nightâ€ù might actually work the other way around. The volatile, passionate, off-again-on-again Bernie-Joan situation may look like a train wreck, but it is really a corrective to the safe, sober and emotionally dishonest ways that Debbie and Danny behave together. Near the end, Bernie and Joan congratulate themselves on their honesty and sigh about how â€œdumbâ€ù the others are. Itâ€™s only funny because itâ€™s true.
â€œAbout Last Nightâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). For every chicken mask you see, thereâ€™s stuff you hear about and have to imagine for yourself.

The second pair, Bernie and Joan, are played by Kevin Hart and Regina Hall, and it is largely thanks to them that â€œAbout Last Night,â€ù which might have been a pleasant and forgettable date movie, is very often a raucous good time. The revised script is credited toÂ Leslye Headland, but many of the funniest parts seem to arise spontaneously from Mr. Hartâ€™s uncensored brain and fast-moving mouth. He can swerve from tears to mock outrage to anatomically detailed obscenities faster than just about any other comic performer working today, and in Ms. Hall he has found an excellent match. Watching the two of them hurl insults at each other is like witnessing verbal Muay Thai.

The energy between Bernie and Joan is mostly physical, though. Their drunken hookup foreshadows the meeting of Danny (Michael Ealy) and Debbie (Joy Bryant), who are dragged along on Joan and Bernieâ€™s first official date. Debbie is Joanâ€™s roommate, while Danny works with Bernie at a restaurant-supply company, and the new acquaintances sit quietly, sipping drinks while the other two get sloppy and stumble off to the restroom for a quickie. Danny and Debbie end up doing the same thing, but in the more decorous setting of Dannyâ€™s bedroom, with the usual soft lighting and gentle sighing of tasteful big-screen lovemaking.

Mr. Mametâ€™s perverts were blue-collar white Chicagoans, upscaled a bit by Mr. Zwick in the yuppie era and now reimagined as middle-class African-American residents of Los Angeles. Race is never an explicit theme in the movie, which you could interpret as tactful or utopian, but, in any case, the emphasis is on the comic difficulties faced by two couples, one sensitive and well behaved, the other outrageously naughty.

â€œI really feel a lot!â€ù declares Amy (Emma Roberts), a pushy 22-year-old aspiring poet in Scott Coffeyâ€™s smart but wince-inducing satirical comedy â€œAdult World.â€ù â€œI want to speak for all the people that suffer, that feel the pain that I feel.â€ù

Amy would be an insufferable character if she didnâ€™t have a softer, more vulnerable side underneath her grandiosity. In the stronger scenes, she sets her sights on gaining the approval of her literary idol, Rat Billings (John Cusack), a punk poet and fading â€™90s literary star who is teaching at a nearby university. His discreet attempts to avoid contact with Amy after she first approaches him are no match for her determination to become his protÃ©gÃ©e. She forces her way into his life by volunteering to be his unpaid housekeeper. Eventually, he reads some of her poems, which are predictably godawful. â€œI found them uniquely you,â€ù he says tactfully.

Amy sleeps under a poster of Sylvia Plath, and, in an early scene, she rehearses her suicide by sticking her head in the oven before deciding it would be â€œsuicidal plagiarism.â€ù She is absolutely convinced that literary glory is imminent, but she is approaching a dreaded personal deadline. â€œYou canâ€™t be a wunderkind after 22,â€ù she frets.

Mr. Cusackâ€™s sardonic, understated portrayal of Rat, who is not quite what he says he is, grounds the movie in a wistfully cynical realism. Rat turns out to be a pseudonym, and his official biography largely fictional. Fed up with Amyâ€™s neediness, he ultimately plays a cruel but helpful practical joke on her that jolts her into accepting reality, though not before she screams at him that sheâ€™s special. Those who have entertained delusions of literary grandeur will squirm in their seats.

Determined to conquer the literary world with her special mixture of genius and sensitivity, the naÃ¯ve, virginal Amy stomps out of her parentsâ€™ house in a small city (the movie was filmed in Syracuse in winter) after her father puts his foot down and refuses to continue supporting her. She takes the only work she can find, as an assistant to the manager of a pornographic bookstore, where she makes no secret of her contempt for the job. The screenplay, by Andy Cochran, is lightly seasoned with jokes about exotic sex toys that the store peddles.
â€œAdult Worldâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sexual content and some drug use.

â€œAdult Worldâ€ù is padded out with characters like Rubia (Armando Riesco), a transgender prostitute with a heart of gold on whom Amy prevails to take her in when she has nowhere to go, and Alex (Evan Peters, Ms. Robertsâ€™s fiancÃ© and a fellow star of â€œAmerican Horror Story: Covenâ€ù), the kindhearted store manager who patiently waits for Amy to come to her senses.

Having just achieved Hollywood leading man status in the remake of â€œRoboCop,â€ù Joel Kinnaman reappears as JW, a.k.a. Johan, in the Swedish gangster thriller â€œEasy Money: Hard to Kill.â€ù It is the second movie of three in a popular Swedish franchise that follows the criminal career of this wily, serpentine social climber from the provinces.

Because JW isnâ€™t the strutting, duplicitous peacock he was in the first movie, the role isnâ€™t as rewarding this time out. If the subtitle of the third movie, â€œLife Deluxe,â€ù is any indication, JW, the wheeling-and-dealing glamour boy, may make a comeback.

â€œHard to Kill,â€ù like its predecessor, is a gangster movie with a social conscience. It programmatically tries to humanize its characters, some of whom limply justify their criminal behavior by pointing out how hard they work to support their loved ones. Most are also aware that they have led miserable lives and feel guilty about the many ways they have failed those loved ones. They may be desperados, but, by and large, they are not the sociopaths who populate so many American Mafia movies.

Mr. Kinnaman, a Swedish-American actor, made his initial splash in the United States by playing a sullen police detective in the AMC series â€œThe Killing.â€ù And whether speaking English or Swedish, he is a star. With a slightly sinister, hooded charisma that recalls the young James Spader or Jonathan Rhys Meyers, he is a deeper actor than either and conveys a brooding secretiveness and suppressed volatility.

Acutely aware of class differences, ethnic stereotypes and discrimination, the gangsters are bitter but defiant about their outsider status. The most ruthless kingpin, Radovan (Dejan Cukic), a Serb, believes that many Swedes regard Serbs as the scum of the earth. The best that can be said of Radovan, a thoroughgoing villain, is that he values loyalty among his henchmen.

In the first movie, â€œEasy Money,â€ù JW parlays his charm and business education into an ill-fated career as a money launderer turned drug dealer for international criminals jockeying for advantage in the Scandinavian market. That movie is soon to be a Hollywood remake starring Zac Efron. A third entry has already been released in Europe.

The other lowlifes reveal their softer sides in their sentimental attachments to mothers, sisters and children. Mradoâ€™s obsession with his young daughter, whom he has betrayed many times by putting her in harmâ€™s way, is a touching portrait of a killer grotesquely clinging to the last vestige of hope and light in his rotten life.

In â€œHard to Kill,â€ù JW, having served three years in prison, escapes while on authorized leave. He attempts to regain his social foothold but finds all doors closed. He decides to go on the lam with Mrado (Dragomir Mrsic), a Serbian fellow prisoner, and reluctantly stakes his future on an outlaw existence.

For the second film, Babak Najafi has succeeded Daniel Espinosa as director. The structure here is more mechanical, and the ambience scruffier, as the complicated story shifts from one disreputable lowlife to another. Most of the characters (played by the same actors) are back. Like â€œEasy Money,â€ù this film ends with a final coming together of warring factions that fight it out as they grasp at a multimillion-dollar hunk of cash.

What we do not get is a neatly resolved case study. A single human personality is not like a locked door awaiting a key, but more like a perpetually shifting maze, through which a twisting, redoubling path might be found, though never an escape. The intellectual scrupulousness of â€œJimmy P.â€ù comes at the expense of dramatic power. It refuses sensationalism or suspense, which may at times cause the hush of the seminar room to fall over the theater.

As played by Benicio Del Toro â€” flattening vowels, biting at consonants, pushing his tall, square frame though postures of graceful anguish â€” Jimmy Picard, a World War II veteran and a member of the Blackfoot Indian tribe, is the picture of a noble soul in torment. He is both charismatic and pathetic, and he inspires in his therapist, a French anthropologist and psychoanalyst named Georges Devereux (Mathieu Amalric), a complex mixture of responses, including sympathy, rivalry and unabashed ethnographic curiosity.

But while the therapist may be an odd and fascinating specimen â€” and while Mr. Amalric is thoroughly at home in Mr. Desplechinâ€™s universe, having frequently served as the directorâ€™s alter ego and alter id â€” the patient is the point of this movie. At first, we hear only Jimmyâ€™s halting testimony as he answers Georgesâ€™s questions about his childhood, family life and wartime experience. But as the treatment progresses, flashbacks and dream sequences give literal shape and symbolic weight to episodes of fear, loss and thwarted love.

Rather than present Jimmyâ€™s symptoms â€” which include catatonic episodes and brutal headaches â€” as a puzzle to be solved, the film uses them as a springboard into the mystery of his personality. And while there is no magical, permanent cure in prospect, there is a sober, humane conviction that suffering can be diminished and life improved.

He arrives in the American heartland â€” by train from New York, where he has been pursuing a penniless Bohemian existence â€” carrying a lot of Old World baggage, not all of which is unpacked. The audience gathers some hints of trouble with the psychoanalytic establishment, and also of a grim wartime experience. Georges Devereux was actually born a Romanian Jew named Gyorgy Dobo, a fact that the movie hints at without fully exploring. Nor does it give too much information about the married lover (Gina McKee) who joins him in Kansas to add a bit of romantic bliss to what is already a satisfying professional sojourn.

Their relationship is at the center of â€œJimmy P.: Psychotherapy of a Plains Indian,â€ù Arnaud Desplechinâ€™s ruminative, gentle and absorbing new film. Based on the writings of the real Georges Devereux about a real patient, Mr. Desplechin (who wrote the screenplay with Kent Jones and Julie Peyr) tells a story that both challenges conventional movie images of heroic (or diabolical) therapists and reasserts the value of old-fashioned, talk-based, dream-focused psychoanalysis.

This is a calm film about strong emotions, but it does find a reservoir of intensity in the two central performances, in particular Mr. Del Toroâ€™s. â€œWinterâ€™s Tale,â€ù Mark Helprinâ€™s 1983 best seller, was the â€œGoldfinchâ€ù of its time: fat and ambitious, with a romantic view of New York City and an unabashed commitment to the kind of old-fashioned narrative abundance that seemed, then as now, to be missing from too much literary fiction. She is dying in this one, too. â€œ3 Days to Killâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Father of the year kills and tortures bad guys.

â€œAngels in Stardustâ€ù ends up being too tidy to be a great coming-of-age movie, but itâ€™s a decent one, with nice work by Alicia Silverstone as an indifferent mother and A J Michalka as her daydreaming teenage daughter, Vallie Sue.

On one level, â€œShoot Meâ€ù is a conventional celebrity profile, filled with loving testimonials from the likes of Alec Baldwin, Tina Fey and George C. Wolfe. Vintage photographs reveal the young Ms. Stritch as a blond, long-legged bombshell.

â€œIâ€™ll never have this,â€ù he says, and you know heâ€™s right. Itâ€™s as if he were tossing cold water onto the movieâ€™s moony fantasizing. Freedom, he reminds us, isnâ€™t always an option.

To describe Omarâ€™s circumstances as a dilemma would be much too simple, though at first, he seems to face a stark choice between equally intolerable options. Though Omar tries to find a way out of this predicament, the Israelis are always a step ahead of him, and everyone back home assumes that he has already turned collaborator.

Omar is so completely trapped that it becomes difficult to imagine how his story will end, a narrative blockage that symbolizes the larger impasse in which Jews and Arabs, whatever their specific allegiances, now find themselves. â€œOmarâ€ù does not offer the promise of a just or satisfying resolution, a fatalism all the more devastating given its realistic methods and humane, understated performances. The filmâ€™s final scene feels shocking and abrupt, but also chillingly inevitable, consistent with the logic of a situation that defies all reason.

Mr. Abu-Assad shows a world from which all trust has vanished, where every relationship carries the possibility â€” perhaps the inevitability â€” of betrayal and where every form of honor is corroded by lies. Omar grows increasingly dependent on Rami, and correspondingly suspicious of Tarek, Amjad and even Nadia. The future he had originally envisioned for himself, as a fighter in the Palestinian cause who could marry his sweetheart and take her to Paris on a honeymoon, comes to seem almost ridiculously naÃ¯ve.

Would it be insensitive to note that the current mess there, an ugly stew of religious, ideological, social and economic antagonism, has been a boon to ambitious genre filmmaking? Maybe so, but the miseries on the ground have recently provided the raw material for powerful on-screen storytelling by directors on both sides of the conflict. To cite just one other example, Yuval Adlerâ€™s â€œBethlehem,â€ù opening here next month, tackles themes very similar to those explored in â€œOmar,â€ù though with a slightly different dramatic emphasis. Both movies reveal the intimacy that can bind enemies and also the lethal fissures that can form among comrades.

And so he must somehow manage to salvage his reputation, protect his relationship with Nadia, remain on good terms with Tarek and Amjad, and stay out of the hands of the police. â€œIn Secret,â€ù the latest adaptation of Ã‰mile Zolaâ€™s â€œThÃ©rÃ¨se Raquin,â€ù opens with a dip in the water and quickly comes ashore with furiously galloping horses and sweeping camera movements. The galloping suggests urgency; the camera movements imply narrative grandeur, or maybe directorial ambition. The darkly muted colors, evoking gathering storms and winter chill, add a brooding note. The river that runs alongside the road like a parallel boulevard will probably mean something only to those who have read Zolaâ€™s book, a classic of literary naturalism, which was published in 1867 and greeted by one appalled critic as â€œa pool of mud and blood.â€ù

A theater and television veteran making his feature directing debut, Charlie Stratton opens â€œIn Secretâ€ù in fairy tale style with the motherless Therese, a child of around 8, being deposited by her father at the country home of her widowed aunt, Madame Raquin (Jessica Lange). Madame lives alone with her pale, sickly son, Camille, whoâ€™s around 10 and has either burrowed into the maternal bosom or been wedged there by his mother. Designating Therese as Camilleâ€™s guardian angel, Madame has the children share a bed, a forced intimacy that takes on new significance when â€” in a single, jolting edit that leaps across time â€” Mr. Stratton cuts from the children lying side by side in bed to the two doing the same as adults (now played by Elizabeth Olsen and Tom Felton).

More than a century and numerous films noirs later, that criticism sounds more promising than damning, which creates some obvious difficulties for a contemporary filmmaker. Times and tastes have changed, along with social mores and moral codes. And while Zolaâ€™s story of adultery, murder and madness was once a scandal â€” and a precursor to novels like â€œAn American Tragedyâ€ù and â€œThe Postman Always Rings Twiceâ€ù â€” it now sounds as familiar as an episode of â€œLaw & Order.â€ù Largely stripped of its shock, â€œThÃ©rÃ¨se Raquinâ€ù can approach its initial power only if the telling of the tale convulses with the same lunatic intensity that consumes Zolaâ€™s criminal lovers.

That, at any rate, might have been what it seemed like if you followed the news, and why it might also have been a surprise that progress seemed so slow in coming to Haiti as one earthquake anniversary followed the next. Four years after the disaster, newspapers continue to run editorials about a crisis that seems without end; in December the United Nations released a humanitarian action plan filled with charts, statistics and promises. The plan opens with a blunt question â€” â€œWhy continue supporting Haiti?â€ù â€” the answer to which feels self-evident. That same page of the plan includes some graphics ornamented with text that is both diagnostic (poverty, political instability, drought, landslides, malnutrition, vulnerability) and motivational (save lives and livelihoods, increase resilience).

In â€œFatal Assistance,â€ù the Haitian-born director Raoul Peck suggests with exacting detail and geopolitical sweep why such action plans may not be enough. Mr. Peck, whose fiction and nonfiction titles include â€œThe Man by the Shoreâ€ù and â€œLumumba: Death of a Prophet,â€ù made â€œFatal Assistanceâ€ù over a two-year period after the earthquake. In an interview (available at Indiewire), he has explained that he didnâ€™t plan to make a movie on this subject, but was led to do so out of frustration. He shot 400 hours of material that he has seamlessly winnowed down to a fast-moving 100 minutes that draw on talking-head interviews, people-on-the-street visuals, excellent (and excellently deployed) graphics and some archival material, including terrifying images of the earthquake while it happened.

Much has been written on the relief efforts and failures in Haiti since the earthquake, so itâ€™s a testament to Mr. Peck that he condenses a messy, complex story into a clear, graspable one. Even before the earthquake, Haiti had earned the dubious reputation as a  Republic of NGOâ€™s (for nongovernmental organizations) because of the sheer number of such groups â€” estimates range as high as 10,000 â€” working there. The need for aid after the quake seemed obvious given the devastation, yet as Mr. Peck starkly illustrates, the gulf between what was needed and what was initially provided was at times vast. That was the case with debris disposal: The capital of Port-au-Prince, he shows, had about 25 times the amount of debris that was at the World Trade Center after 9/11.

Mr. Peck doesnâ€™t appear in the documentary, but his point of view frames every image and is particularly evident in his insistence on foregrounding Haitian voices: Itâ€™s not for nothing that the first sights and sounds in â€œFatal Assistanceâ€ù are street scenes and a man describing the morning of the earthquake and its gruesome aftermath. (Mr. Clinton and Mr. Penn pop up every so often, but, pointedly, are not interviewed.) Mr. Peckâ€™s voice also emerges in personal reminiscences from him and a female friend, passages from which are read aloud, adding notes of sorrow and anger, poetry and politics. Eventually, through these passages and the interviews â€” including one with Jean-Max Bellerive, who resigned as prime minister in 2011 â€” Mr. Peckâ€™s focus tightens on the aid agencies.

The anthropologist Gina Athena Ulysse  has argued that Haiti needs new narratives. In an essay she wrote after the earthquake, she traced Haitiâ€™s â€œimage problem,â€ù as she puts it, to its revolution that saw the end of colonial rule, writing that â€œblack freedom, and the stereotypes of savagery that go with it, to this day remain central to how we talk about Haiti, represent Haiti, understand and explicate Haiti and Haitians.â€ù The bigger question, she continues, involves the role that these negative ideas play, including in policy papers. â€œFor indeed,â€ù Ms. Ulysse writes, â€œthere are certain narratives that allow us to remain impervious to each other by the way they reinforce the mechanics of Othering.â€ù In â€œFatal Assistance,â€ù Mr. Peck powerfully asserts Haitiâ€™s right to create its own story.

And yet sufficient money for disposal never arrives. The problem, as a Clinton staffer wryly explains, is that debris removal just isnâ€™t â€œsexy enoughâ€ù for some donors. The people who bankroll aid organizations want to build schools, for example, and a brochure with photos of smiling schoolchildren surely looks more appealing than trucks filled with broken concrete. Yet you canâ€™t build a school on a mound of rubble, which could be the subtitle of this movie. And so it goes, as one enraging, heartbreaking example follows the next The solution is at once complex and yet so simple it seems impossible that it needs to be stated: As one after another Haitian explains, the people themselves need to be involved in steering the destiny of their own nation.

Good intentions and billions of promised dollars only go so far. That, certainly, is one of the sobering truths in â€œFatal Assistance,â€ù a potent, persuasive and quietly furious documentary that examines how international aid agencies failed Haiti after the catastrophic 2010 earthquake. That disaster, which was followed by other calamities, including a cholera outbreak, left an estimated quarter-million people dead and more than a million temporarily or permanently homeless. People and organizations across the world pledged help, and money started to flood in along with journalists, religious workers, relief groups, Bill Clinton and Sean Penn.

At the same time she is threatened by her thuggish Stasi handlers, who insist that she not divulge her true identity. Squeezed from two sides, she finds her contented family life gravely imperiled. Ase, meanwhile, takes in events with a wary, stoical silence.

Starting in the 1960s, the Stasi, the East German secret police, recruited many of the grown-up progeny in East Germany as spies, sending them to Norway to be reunited with unsuspecting families. In some cases, the Stasi appropriated the identities of Lebensborn children and conferred them on East Germans trained in espionage before placing them with Norwegian families. Since many documents related to the program were destroyed, few records existed to attest to their identities as Lebensborn children.

â€œTwo Livesâ€ù is an absorbing, well-acted, moderately suspenseful mystery, although its time line of events is fuzzy to the point of impenetrability. If she were played a different way, Katrine would be an unsympathetic, diabolical monster. But the film portrays her as a victim of history who is increasingly desperate at the prospect of losing a family to which she feels she belongs.

The anxious, melancholic drama â€œTwo Livesâ€ù is the story of a woman caught up in the toxic backwash of long-ago events that exert a fearful grip on the present. Unholy forces shaped the double life of this woman, Katrine (Juliane KÃ¶hler, â€œNowhere in Africaâ€ù). Happily married and living in Norway, she has a secret past that merges two of the darker chapters of 20th-century European history.

â€œTwo Livesâ€ù is set in 1990, just after the fall of Communism. And although it has the somber tone and trappings of a spy movie, it is more a story of identity theft and its consequences than a cloak-and-dagger melodrama in the John le CarrÃ© mode. Loosely based on a novel by Hannelore Hippe and directed by Georg Maas, it unwraps the biography of this so-called Katrine, who after supposedly escaping East Germany by boat, was united with her supposed mother, Ase (Liv Ullmann), in Norway. Now Katrine is married to Bjarte (Sven Nordin), a Norwegian submarine captain with whom she is passionately in love; they live with their daughter (Julia Bache-Wiig), her baby and Ase, a dignified, taciturn woman with haunted eyes. We are tipped off that Katrine may be concealing her real identity: in an early scene, she visits East Germany in disguise and calls herself Vera.

Back home, Katrine is visited by Sven Solbach (Ken Duken), a lawyer who pressures her to testify in a lawsuit seeking reparations from the Norwegian government for the shunned Lebensborn offspring. She reluctantly agrees, but the dogged lawyer finds glaring omissions in her story. Katrine claims not to remember crucial details.

â€œTwo Livesâ€ù doesnâ€™t fill in enough of the blanks. We never learn what, if any, espionage operations Katrine participated in. But in a flashback, we meet the real Katrine, who found her way home while Ase was away and was greeted by her doppelgÃ_nger. In grainy color-saturated scenes, we also witness the real Katrineâ€™s flight from East Germany.

Beginning in the mid-1930s, the Nazi Lebensborn program to breed an Aryan â€œmaster raceâ€ù produced thousands of children, many of them procreated by members of the German SS in casual encounters with blond, blue-eyed women deemed racially pure. Because Norwegians, with their Viking ancestors, were thought to be an especially hardy breed, they were considered ideal specimens. Once these women gave birth in occupied Norway, their children were often taken from them and reared in special orphanages in Germany. After World War II, the taint of Nazism caused the mothers and the Lebensborn children remaining in Norway to face harsh discrimination.

Focusing mainly on the federal prosecution of Mark A. Ciavarella, a former juvenile court judge in Pennsylvania accused of accepting kickbacks from a for-profit detention center in exchange for providing a steady stream of young inmates, Mr. May patiently uncovers a more complex tale of cronyism, corruption and moral crusading. â€œNon-Stopâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Moviegoers with a fear of flying are also cautioned.

Itâ€™s a movie that embraces the nearly pedagogical predictability of lines like â€œWhereâ€™s Judas? You seen him?â€ù or â€œThomas, stop doubting.â€ù

Mr. Morgadoâ€™s Jesus is steadfast and has a generic charismatic glow but little feeling of depth; he seems like a visual supplement to his words. But the director, Christopher Spencer, and the producers Mark Burnett and Roma Downey (who also plays Mary) are obviously trying for a broad, nod-along appeal, smearing on a smidgen of gore as if mindful of the positively radical blockbuster â€œThe Passion of the Christ,â€ù and ending on a note of evangelism. Yet â€œSon of Godâ€ù may have hit the mark if part of the goal was to create a portrait flat enough to allow audience members to project their own feelings onto the screen.

The young men get pocket biographies in strenuously nostalgic voice-over. But these characters mostly feel less developed than Mr. Kretschmannâ€™s captain, whose unease is acknowledged, though his imperious superior could be lifted out of any number of World War II movies.

The director of â€œStalingrad,â€ù Fedor Bondarchuk, opts for a narrower focus than the novel: a sentimental celebration of stamina. â€œStalingradâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sometimes disturbing war violence and a sexual situation.

The credits of â€œStalingrad,â€ù a Russian-made 3-D film set during a pivotal battle in World War II, attribute the story to selected chapters from the panoramic novel â€œLife and Fateâ€ù by Vasily Grossman. The narratorâ€™s final few words express gratitude for the Soviet victory at Stalingrad, as indeed many millions might, but specifically for letting him never know what war was. Itâ€™s a curious way to end a film that seeks to memorialize by blunt force.

â€œThe Bag Manâ€ù has a surly temptress in Rivka (Rebecca Da Costa), a six-foot-tall stripper who claims to be Israeli and knows a lot more than she lets on. After disingenuously throwing herself on Jackâ€™s mercy, she eventually takes charge.
Convinced that he is a genius, Dragna loves to spout quotations from Hermann Hesse and from Sun Tzuâ€™s â€œThe Art of War.â€ù

Mr. De Niro plays Dragna, whose voluminous hairstyle â€” reminiscent of Paulieâ€™s â€™do on â€œThe Sopranosâ€ù â€” is also a reflection of his inflated ego.

But he is also a vicious sociopath and a financial scoundrel who specializes in currency speculation. In an early scene, he smashes the face of his daughter, who, while filling in for an assistant, accidentally pressed the â€œsendâ€ù button on her computer, losing Daddy a bundle. â€œThe Lunchbox,â€ù Ritesh Batraâ€™s debut feature, is a romance that takes place in Mumbai, but its style is more Hollywood than Bollywood, and Old Hollywood at that. The comedy is more wry than uproarious, the melodrama gently poignant rather than operatic, and the sentimentality just sweet enough to be satisfying rather than bothersome.

Meanwhile, Ila suffers from her busy husbandâ€™s indifference and begins to suspect that heâ€™s having an affair. (The awakening of her suspicion is wordlessly conveyed in one of many scenes in which Mr. Batra, with a visual discipline that shows more than a touch of Ernst Lubitsch, uses everyday objects and actions to convey emotion and meaning.) The lunches she prepares â€” with the advice of an unseen â€œAuntieâ€ù in the apartment upstairs â€” are meant to win him back. But because of a rare and unexplained glitch in the dabbawalla network, the stackable stainless steel dishes of her food arrive on Mr. Fernandesâ€™s desk. His brief notes of thanks (and also of criticism) begin a correspondence that quickly evolves from the exchange of pleasantries to the sharing of confidences.

This is not a new conceit. If you have seen â€œYouâ€™ve Got Mailâ€ù (itself inspired by Lubitschâ€™s â€œThe Shop Around the Corner,â€ù from 1940), you will find yourself on familiar ground. But the idea of two lonely souls connecting in a vast, modern metropolis, and remaining strangers even as their intimacy grows, has a durable charm. As do Mr. Khan and Ms. Kaur, islands of melancholy calm surrounded by silliness and noise. Their performances are not exactly subtle â€” nothing in â€œThe Lunchboxâ€ù is exactly subtle â€” but they are graceful and dignified in the manner of movie stars in an earlier, less aggressive age, ennobling the ordinary lives they explore. And Mr. Batra makes their story touching and credible, an urban fable of hope in the face of disappointment.
â€œThe Lunchboxâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Some mildly troubling moments.

Ila and Mr. Fernandes are already there, having arrived through marriage, inheritance or hard work, but neither has found much satisfaction. In the years since the death of his wife, Mr. Fernandes has buried himself in routines and wrapped himself in a cloak of misanthropy. The children in his neighborhood hesitate before asking him to retrieve an errant cricket ball, and Shaikh reports a rumor that he once kicked a cat into the street. â€œActually it was a blind man,â€ù he replies, and Shaikh is not entirely sure itâ€™s a joke.

That a warm heart lurks beneath his dour exterior is something the audience will assume right away â€” this is a comfortingly familiar kind of movie â€” but Mr. Khan (recently seen in â€œLife of Piâ€ù) does not make it too obvious, or show it too soon. He relishes understatement, occasionally allowing the characterâ€™s suppressed emotion to peek out from behind his quiet, standoffish demeanor. Mr. Fernandes is plagued, and eventually befriended, by Shaikh (Nawazuddin Siddiqui), the eager young man who is his designated replacement. Mr. Siddiqui has some of the needy, jumpy energy of a young Tony Curtis, making him a perfect comic foil for Mr. Khan. Shaikh, an orphan who subsists on a few pieces of fruit at lunch and an inexhaustible supply of positive thinking, represents the striving of poorer Indians scrambling toward the middle class.

The main characters â€” Ila (Nimrat Kaur), a neglected housewife, and Mr. Fernandes (Irrfan Khan), a widowed office worker nearing retirement â€” communicate through handwritten letters and home-cooked meals. Their world has been only lightly touched by the latest social and technological advances. Ila launders her husbandâ€™s shirts by hand and cooks lunches that are supposed to be delivered to him, via bicycle, rail and the shoulders of white-jacketed couriers (called dabbawallas), through Mumbaiâ€™s elaborate and storied meal-delivery system. Mr. Fernandes (whose first name, Saajan, is not uttered until very late in the film) labors at a wooden desk in a crowded workplace that is anything but paper free. For 35 years, without error or complaint, he has plowed through endless stacks of folders, keeping accounts with a ruler and pencil.

Four years after being in a car accident, Tommy Carter (Anthony Mackie) is an in-demand spiritual adviser drawing from myriad religions. On the eve of Tommyâ€™s major book tour his brother, Ben (Mike Epps), a feckless debtor, visits, seeking aid with his bills. Fortunately, Angel Sanchez (Forest Whitaker), a father with a young daughter (Ariana Neal), is more than willing to pay Tommyâ€™s $300-an-hour fee for help coming to terms with the death of his mother.

In the tradition of thrillers about unassuming acquaintances who turn out to be deadly (â€œMisery,â€ù â€œFatal Attractionâ€ù) comes â€œRepentance,â€ù a movie of modest means that nevertheless offers a fairly cohesive story and at least one standout performance. It may underplay an idea laden with potential, but at least that notion is present.

O.K., itâ€™s not so fortunate: Angel traps Tommy in Angelâ€™s New Orleans home and subjects him to physical and psychological torments, not least a demand that he confess his own sins. Eventually, Tommyâ€™s wife (Sanaa Lathan) and Angelâ€™s ex (Nicole Ari Parker) stop by, curious about the goings-on, as does Ben. But not before Mr. Mackie and Mr. Whitaker have conducted a bloody pas de deux, and the gifted Mr. Whitaker has demonstrated his remarkable facility with alternating endearing innocence and offhand malevolence.
â€œRepentanceâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for vivid but not protracted torture.

The director, Philippe Caland, effectively milks the setting, New Orleans, for all its humid, decadent atmosphere and adds just a pinch of the supernatural. But this is secondary to an implicit if unbelabored subtext. What lingers after the closing credits are not the gruesome details of Tommyâ€™s physical agonies but their meaning: the high cost to pay for being a false prophet.

They execute a fair number of estimable moves in â€œInterior. Leather Bar.,â€ù a sly conceptual coup dâ€™art and a deeply sincere exploration of masculinity and its discontents, with a little hot sex thrown in. The movieâ€™s ostensible point of departure is 40 minutes of graphic footage of S-and-M that the director William Friedkin was forced to edit out of â€œCruising,â€ù his 1980 thriller with Al Pacino, to avoid an X rating. Inspired by what they rather cryptically term the mythology of â€œCruising,â€ù Mr. Franco and Mr. Mathews have set out to reimagine this excised material.

The man in the black leather vest looks nervous. All around him, glistening half-naked men dance to the disco beat as smoke curls in the air. They writhe, touch and kiss, skin against skin, leather against leather. A guy in chaps pauses and locks his eyes on our nervous man. Here, looking is cruising, an overt exchange of desire: Itâ€™s about watching and waiting, and being conspicuously out of the closet and the thrilling promise of something more. Then the scene stops and the actors wait as James Franco and Travis Mathews, the directors choreographing this bacchanalia, plot their next move.

â€œInterior. Leather Bar.â€ù revisits the anxiety that swirled around â€œCruising,â€ù which was summed up by an extra who told Mr. Russo: â€œI donâ€™t want America to think that all gays are like that, and if this picture gets released, Iâ€™m afraid they will.â€ù If anything, those who decried â€œCruisingâ€ù overestimated its impact, including at the box office. The protests continued when the movie opened in 1980, but â€œCruisingâ€ù faded, as did Mr. Friedkinâ€™s career. The next year, federal health officials identified a new disease: AIDS. Men who might have protested against â€œCruisingâ€ù mobilized against AIDS and government inaction; fast-forward, and while discrimination remains, of course, the most public gay rights issue now is marriage equality.

To an extent, â€œInterior. Leather Bar.â€ù functions as a response â€” searching and serious, playful and teasing â€” to the mainstreaming of homosexuality in the United States. However much has been gained in the years from Stonewall to the fight for same-sex marriage, itâ€™s worth asking, as Mr. Franco and Mr. Mathews do, what has been lost. When Mr. Friedkin took a peek into the leather bars once upon a downtown time, he might have seen something that frightened him. Yet the men inside those bars were part of a self-defined, self-sustaining and vital group that, as the years and milestones pass, can seem in danger of losing a part of itself. Or maybe, as Mr. Franco and Mr. Mathews suggest, the lines have become so very blurred that labels like gay and straight are no longer remotely useful.

It is, he continued, â€œno more about gay life than Woody Allenâ€™s â€˜Manhattanâ€™ is about New Yorkers.Â â€ù Thatâ€™s funny and true even if â€œManhattanâ€ù is about a very specific idea of New York and its citizens, much like â€œCruisingâ€ù is about a very specific idea of what Mr. Friedkin reductively labeled the gay world.

Theyâ€™ve done just that in a movie about a movie that turns out to be something of an intellectual house of mirrors. Coming in a densely packed 60 minutes that could easily have been extended, â€œInterior. Leather Bar.â€ù â€” the title mimics a screenplay scene heading â€” is simultaneously an act of creation and deconstruction. Turning the cameras on themselves (relax, Mr. Franco keeps his clothes on), the filmmakers recreate the nominally lost material while also taking you into their process, including production meetings with their lead, the nervous man in the vest, Val Lauren, a friend of Mr. Francoâ€™s from his earlier acting days. Mr. Lauren isnâ€™t playing Mr. Pacino per se, but rather the character in â€œCruising,â€ù a cop whoâ€™s investigating the brutal murders of the gay male habituÃ©s of the downtown New York leather and cruising scenes.

Itâ€™s startling how much controversy â€œCruisingâ€ù stirred up among those who thought its representations would feed homophobic prejudices. People didnâ€™t just protest, they also rioted, by the thousands (well, maybe hundreds). In a 1979 article for New York Magazine, the activist Vito Russo â€” author of â€œThe Celluloid Closetâ€ù â€” visited both the set and the tumult. Mr. Friedkin insisted to Mr. Russo that his movie was simply â€œa murder mystery with an aspect of the gay world as background.â€ù

Mr. Franco and Mr. Mathewsâ€™s approach is by turns direct and oblique. They take you behind the scenes of their movie with seemingly real casting interviews and sequences in which Mr. Lauren expresses his concern about the project. â€œI like Jamesâ€™s mission even if I donâ€™t understand it,â€ù he says, echoing a complaint thatâ€™s been heard elsewhere about his friend. Mr. Franco himself doesnâ€™t make his mission clear in â€œInterior. Leather Bar.,â€ù but the movie comes into focus through its â€œCruisingâ€ù re-creations; discussions about gay identity and heterosexual discomfort with the same; and interludes that at times have a documentarylike texture and at other times register as explicitly staged.

The differences between these two outcomes seem very stark. In the first case, more particles are likely to be found, contributing to a detailed and orderly picture of the nature of things. In the second, the Standard Model will be thrown into chaos, and the stability of the universe itself may be called into question. It wonâ€™t be the end of the world, but for some theorists, it will feel that way.

The Higgs particle is named for Peter Higgs, one of the physicists who first posited its existence in 1964. (He shared the Nobel Prize in Physics last year.) It has a central role in what physicists call the Standard Model, a comprehensive account of, well, just about everything.

Fabiola Gianotti, trained as a classical pianist, oversees one of the Hadronâ€™s main experiments with a manner at once businesslike and artistic. Martin Aleksa is the father of two young children who are happily unimpressed with their fatherâ€™s work. Monica Dunford, an American postdoctoral fellow who runs and bicycles through the hills around CERN in all weather, demolishes the categories of nerd and jock. Sheâ€™s both and neither. (The prominence of women in this movie also quietly challenges the male domination of science, both in the popular imagination and, too often, in real life.)

The experimental physicists deployed on the Hadron work in the service of ideas formulated by their theorist brethren (shown in their Princeton and Palo Alto habitats, walking in the woods or writing on whiteboards). There are hints of collegial rivalry between the groups, and of competition among the theorists. Much of the background is explained by David E. Kaplan, a Johns Hopkins physicist who is a producer of the film. Mr. Kaplan helped commission Mr. Levinson (and also Walter Murch, the visionary editor of â€œApocalypse Nowâ€ù and â€œThe English Patientâ€ù) to translate science into cinema, and he proves an able and amiable guide.

The search for the particle itself led to the construction of the Large Hadron Collider at CERN â€” also called the European Organization for Nuclear Research â€” near Geneva, where much of the action in â€œParticle Feverâ€ù takes place, in the years leading up to a 2012 breakthrough. At CERN, practical science outstrips the dreams of science fiction as a machine shoots beams of particles around a long track. The hope is that their collisions will provide data indicating the presence of the Higgs.

â€œParticle Feverâ€ù is a fascinating movie about science, and an exciting, revealing and sometimes poignant movie about scientists. The Large Hadron Collider, after all, is a human endeavor, and the people who have devoted their lives to chasing the Higgs are a compelling and diverse collection of characters.

The physics that Mr. Kaplan and his colleagues practice is forbiddingly complex, comprehensible to most of the people in the film and to very few outside it. But his impromptu lectures and some nicely animated graphics make the basic issues reasonably clear, and delightfully dramatic. While the discovery of the Higgs may not have immediate consequences for the way we live, or applications in the world of technology and industry, its implications, according to â€œParticle Fever,â€ù could hardly be more profound. Through most of the film, the scientists are awaiting a specific bit of data, a single number that will either vindicate a theory of the universe known as supersymmetry or suggest the possibility of multiple universes.

A description of â€œParticle Feverâ€ù â€” Mark Levinsonâ€™s mind-blowing new documentary â€” must grapple with some issues of scale. This is a modest, compact movie about the largest imaginable subject: the structure of the cosmos.

Even if you recall (or Google) newspaper articles from the summer of 2012, when CERN made headlines, you may still hold your breath at the climax of â€œParticle Fever.â€ù What will the magic number be? Are we living in a supersymmetrical universe or a chaotic multiverse? I wonâ€™t spoil anything, but I can hardly wait for the sequel.

It tells the story of an enormous project, involving decades of labor, hundreds of millions of dollars and miles of Swiss real estate, devoted to finding something almost immeasurably small: the Higgs boson, a subatomic morsel believed by physicists to hold the key to understanding the universe. (Itâ€™s sometimes called â€œthe God particle.â€ù) The experience of watching the film can be vertiginous: You toggle between the tiny and the infinite, between eternity and the real time of the recent past.

The film is a tribute to the creativity and curiosity that drive scientific research, which is shown to be an imaginative as well as an empirical pursuit. It is enormously suspenseful, too, chronicling a period that included nearly catastrophic setbacks and public relations disasters, as well as progress. There was always a risk that the machinery would not work, that the beams would not collide properly, and that the Higgs would continue to hide at the theoretical center of the universe without empirical confirmation.
Mr. Kaplan is hoping for supersymmetry. His friend and sometime table tennis partner, Nima Arkani-Hamed of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, is in the multiverse camp.

Ms. Bening plays Nikki, an Angeleno whose upscale life takes a downbeat turn when, soon after the movie opens, her husband, Garrett (Ed Harris), drowns. Thatâ€™s a crushing blow, including for anyone looking forward to spending time with Mr. Harris. She goes on, she must go on, wandering alone in her designer home and staging other peopleâ€™s houses for sale. Five years later, while visiting a museum, Nikki spots a man whoâ€™s a double for her husband. Transfixed, she returns to the museum to search for the look-alike, visiting so often that she and a gardener end up on a first-name basis. Eventually, she and the lookalike meet and, after the usual shy smiles and foot shuffling, begin dating, which only really becomes interesting because the lookalike, Tom, is also played by (yay) Mr. Harris.
â€œThe Face of Loveâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Some very discreet lovemaking.

Sometimes itâ€™s best to forget a movieâ€™s story and concentrate on whatever else you can. If the camera movements donâ€™t seduce, something else might. Because while a director may not leave much of an impression narratively or visually, he or she can edge into your consciousness with how well the actors are making the thing work, despite its frayed, disjointed pieces. In the case of â€œThe Face of Love,â€ù the main attractions are Ed Harris and a deeply appealing Annette Bening as two â€” actually, make that three â€” characters brought together by fate and a screenplay that promisingly flirts with fantasy only to come crashing down to bummer earth.

His return has a salutary effect on both Ms. Beningâ€™s character and the movie. Nikki begins smiling, the mood lightens, and the possibilities seem to expand. Although Nikki is strangely incurious about the resemblance between the men (mostly, she seems stunned and grateful), the seasoned moviegoer â€” weaned on supernatural tales and adventure stories about twins separated at birth â€” may keep shuffling through the potentialities and ah-ha moments surely to come. That Tom is a painter must mean something, given that Garrett was an architect, even if thereâ€™s no hint of woo-woo weirdness from the director, Arie Posin, working from his and Matthew McDuffieâ€™s script. Yet nothing emerges, not a drop of surrealism, a modicum of mystery or even a nubbin of New Age nuttiness.

If there is a reason for Mr. Harrisâ€™s dual turn, the filmmakers have pretty much kept it to themselves, all the way to the jejune finish. On occasion, they suggest that Nikki is engaging in some magical thinking and, as her relationship with Tom deepens, they also imply that she may be losing it, which seems more than a little unfair, given the stunt casting. That Mr. Posin and Mr. McDuffie have stacked the deck against Nikki would be more irritating if Ms. Bening didnâ€™t immediately make this woman come so satisfyingly alive, breathing believable vitality and at times contradictory emotions into what might have otherwise registered as a blur or clichÃ©. She and Mr. Harris easily hold the movie together, but thereâ€™s no doubt that Ms. Bening could also prop it up all by herself.

Ward, who died in 1989 and whose brainy cartoons were staples of the early space age, has been dishonored by lame live-action movie versions of Rocky and Bullwinkle, George of the Jungle and Dudley Do-Right. Luckily, â€œMr. Peabody & Sherman,â€ù about a supersmart dog and his adopted human son, breaks the curse and respects the nutty, nerdy humor of the original. This DreamWorks Animation production, directed by Rob Minkoff (â€œStuart Little,â€ù â€œThe Lion Kingâ€ù) from a screenplay by Craig Wright, is not perfect, but it is fast-moving, intermittently witty and pretty good fun.

The recipe for modern family entertainment also calls for a dollop of strained sentimentality, here provided by challenges, internal and external, to Sherman and Mr. Peabodyâ€™s domestic harmony. After an incident at Shermanâ€™s school, a nasty bureaucrat named Ms. Grunion (Allison Janney) threatens to remove the boy from his dadâ€™s care. And Sherman himself (who is not very convincingly supposed to be 7) shows signs of rebelliousness. His genius father has always taken care of everything, which may have smothered the childâ€™s creativity.

At school, Sherman meets Penny Peterson (Ariel Winter; her parents are voiced by Leslie Mann and Stephen Colbert), a blond-haired, blue-eyed pixie who parrots incorrect information about George Washington in the classroom. Pennyâ€™s job in the course of the film is to be mean to Sherman, to get him into trouble, to be rescued by him, and then to marvel at his resourcefulness and bravery. During the airborne scene in Florence, she helps him become â€œthe first man to fly.â€ù The main historical women in the movie are the gluttonous Marie Antoinette and the frivolous Mona Lisa.
â€œMr. Peabody & Shermanâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Poop jokes and fights.

Mr. Peabody, voiced by Ty Burrell (Phil Dunphy of â€œModern Familyâ€ù), is a Harvard graduate, a Nobel laureate and a lover of puns. He and Sherman (Max Charles) live in a Manhattan penthouse equipped with a time machine called the WABAC. Devotees of the old series will recall the many trips the two-dimensional, hand-drawn father and son made into the past, and the silly (but not altogether ridiculous) history lessons that ensued. Somewhat younger viewers will be reminded of Bill and Ted, but, in any case, the best parts of â€œMr. Peabody & Shermanâ€ù are encounters with such storied figures as Marie Antoinette, Leonardo da Vinci, King Tut and the Trojan horse.

Much of the humor in these sequences is, in the modern manner, action-, celebrity-voice-over- and excrement-based, but enough of Wardâ€™s cracked erudition survives to make intellectually insecure grown-ups and precocious children feel smart. The adventures are built to justify the 3-D ticket upcharge, so there is a lot of roller-coasterish swooping and flying and falling. Most of it lacks the sublimity of â€œUpâ€ù or the gravity-defying rush of â€œHow to Train Your Dragon,â€ù but some of the sequences â€” notably, a flight over Florence in one of Leonardoâ€™s contraptions â€” are both funny and exciting.

All this is resolved in a teary, mercifully short set of speeches at the end, affirming the importance of family love and the need for even highly competent canine parents to recognize their childrenâ€™s independence. But while the filmmakers have updated jokes and themes about dogs and boys, their ideas about boys and girls have a musty, regressive feel.

It is odd that big-studio animators have taken so long to get to â€œFrozenâ€ù and to â€œBrave,â€ù and more than a little dispiriting that otherwise imaginative father-son stories like â€œMr. Peabody & Shermanâ€ù and â€œThe Lego Movieâ€ù default to sexism and tokenism. You would think they would be smarter than that, but I guess even a clever old dog has trouble learning new tricks.

If you think of â€œMr. Peabody & Shermanâ€ù as the latest attempt to turn small-screen baby boomer nostalgia into big-screen fun, you have plenty of reason to be afraid. Hollywoodâ€™s obsession with cashing in on old television shows has yielded a grim harvest â€” remember Nicole Kidman in â€œBewitchedâ€ù? Sorry to have reminded you â€” and the work of Jay Ward has been singled out for particular abuse.

So yes, a Wes Anderson movie, and hooray for that. At the moment, there are very few American filmmakers with the ability to articulate such an original, idiosyncratic vision and the means to express that vision so freely. There is a lot of integrity here and also a good deal of ambition. This is a movie concerned with â€” and influenced by â€” an especially rich and complicated slice of 20th-century European culture, and therefore a reckoning, characteristically playful but also fundamentally serious, with some very ugly history.

Throughout, we are in the fictional Republic of Zubrowka, a mountainous land that cartographers of various eras might have plotted on the distant marches of successive empires â€” Ottoman, Austro-Hungarian, Soviet â€” or else erased altogether. The main story is rendered in narrow, boxy dimensions that evoke the films of its era, which is the 1930s. But there are two frames around this narrative, which is in effect a flashback within a flashback. We start out in 1985, under a late-Communist gray sky in a town of cemeteries and statues. An aging writer (Tom Wilkinson) shoos away his grandson and recalls the time in 1968 when his younger self (Jude Law) stayed at the nearly empty, Iron Curtain-tacky Grand Budapest Hotel and became acquainted with its elegant and enigmatic proprietor, Mr. Moustafa (F. Murray Abraham).

On the surface, there is a lot more comedy. The main plot spins around an elaborate, Tintin-esque caper involving a stolen painting and a clan of vengeful Zubrowkan nobles. (Ms. Swinton plays the matriarch, Adrien Brody her viperous son and Willem Dafoe the fearsome family hit man.) Zero, a refugee from another made-up geopolitical trouble spot, falls in love with Agatha (Saoirse Ronan), a bakerâ€™s assistant with a Mexico-shaped birthmark on her cheek. I will refrain from saying too much more about what happens, or about who shows up in what capacity.

Itâ€™s a tough choice, but if I had to pick the most Wes Anderson moment in â€œThe Grand Budapest Hotel,â€ù it would be the part when inmates escape from a prison using tiny sledgehammers and pickaxes that have been smuggled past the guards inside fancy frosted pastries. This may, come to think of it, be the most Wes Anderson thing ever, the very quintessence of his impish, ingenious and oddly practical imagination. So much care has been lavished on the conceit and its execution that you can only smile in admiration, even if you are also rolling your eyes a little.

That hand casts an oblique shadow over â€œThe Grand Budapest Hotel.â€ù Hitler and Stalin donâ€™t exist in this kingdom of make-believe, but sudden eruptions of violence and the offhand mention of tragic happenings point toward a profound darkness just outside the frame. Mr. Anderson is no realist. This movie makes a marvelous mockery of history, turning its horrors into a series of graceful jokes and mischievous gestures. You can call this escapism if you like. You can also think of it as revenge.

That phrase occurs twice in the film and is the key to its intentions. In the real 1930s, places like Zubrowka were on the brink of inconceivable barbarism and unprecedented slaughter. A beautiful, fragile Central European civilization was all but demolished, surviving mainly as the ghostly object of nostalgic longing. Mr. Anderson embraces this nostalgia â€” for a bygone modernity of railway compartments, telegrams and handmade luggage; of louche aristocrats, discreet bellhops and ruddy-faced workingmen; of painting and poetry and psychoanalysis â€” but he also tries to work through it, to capture some of the vitality and peculiarity of a vanished world.

One of his guides in this enterprise is Stefan Zweig (1881-1942), the prolific and celebrated Viennese writer whose physical appearance and mercurial energy Mr. Fiennes pointedly evokes. While not specifically based on Zweigâ€™s work, â€œThe Grand Budapest Hotelâ€ù conjures some of its defining traits: quickness, compression and a highly refined sense of the nuances that separate comedy from tragedy.

For his part, Moustafa reminisces about his first days at the hotel, where he was a mere lobby boy known as Zero (Tony Revolori) and the place was dominated by its charismatic concierge, M. Gustave. Portrayed by Ralph Fiennes with high-stepping liveliness and an evocative mustache, Gustave is both courtier and sovereign, a devoted servant to the guests and the capricious, mostly benevolent ruler of the staff. He corrects their slightest lapses of deportment and lectures them endlessly at mealtimes. He is a lover of poetry and also of the elderly women who summon him to their suites, and maybe of a few men as well. Somehow, he is both an ascetic and a sensualist, highly disciplined and completely irresponsible. A thoroughly ridiculous man and at the same time â€œa glimmer of civilization in the barbaric slaughterhouse we know as humanity.â€ù
â€œThe Grand Budapest Hotelâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Naughty words and deeds, and some bloodshed, too.

Itâ€™s all a lot of fun, but it isnâ€™t only fun. Or rather, itâ€™s fun in the service of a subtle and sober argument. If Zweig is one of the filmâ€™s mid-20th-century, middle-European Jewish patron saints, another is Ernst Lubitsch, the filmmaker who left Berlin for Hollywood in 1922 and whose name connotes a peerlessly suave and humane comic touch. He functions in â€œThe Grand Budapest Hotelâ€ù less as an influence â€” Mr. Anderson is a much sloppier storyteller â€” than as a point of reference. On two memorable occasions, Lubitsch, without losing his sense of humor, confronted contemporary totalitarianism: in â€œNinotchkaâ€ù (1939), with Greta Garbo as a Soviet agent in Paris, and in â€œTo Be or Not to Beâ€ù (1942), with Jack Benny as a Polish actor performing for the Nazis.

â€œThe Grand Budapest Hotel,â€ù Mr. Andersonâ€™s eighth feature, will delight his fans, but even those inclined to grumble that itâ€™s just more of the same patented whimsy might want to look again. As a sometime grumbler and longtime fan, I found myself not only charmed and touched but also moved to a new level of respect.

There is no doubt that Mr. Anderson possesses a distinctive sensibility and a consistent visual style, and that instead of striking out in new directions, he tends to embroider and elaborate on familiar themes and pictorial habits. You will see many of them here: static, densely packed, fussily composed frames; traveling shots in which the camera glides alongside the characters like a low-flying bird; action sequences that refuse the usual digital hocus-pocus in favor of the older, artisanal magic of stop-motion animation, matte paintings and rear projection. You will also meet eccentric characters possessed by a kind of madcap melancholy, soulful and silly in equal measure. Some of them are played by actors you have seen elsewhere in the Anderson oeuvre, including Bob Balaban, Tilda Swinton and of course (albeit briefly) Owen Wilson and Bill Murray.

These films fight tyranny with irony, frivolity and unshakable charm. It goes without saying that those are inadequate and perhaps inappropriate weapons against tanks and secret policemen. But even now, with full, bloody hindsight, we can appreciate the lesson that lightheartedness and laughter can oppose the heavy hand of political oppression.

In previous movies, Mr. Zafar, who really is Pakistani (and a pop star to boot), has proved himself an able Bollywood hero. Here, called upon to be straight man and gag man, romantic lead and nice-guy advertisement for Pakistani decency, he mostly looks uncomfortable. That suits his character fine but doesnâ€™t lift the movie.
