Set in London, a safe distance from South Asia, â€œTotal Siyapaaâ€ù (â€œTotal Chaosâ€ù) is a kind of warmed over â€œMeet the Parents.â€ù Asha Singh (Yami Gautam) brings her fiancÃ©, Aman (Ali Zafar), home to meet her family, a crew that seems more malicious than madcap.

Can a Pakistani boy and an Indian girl find happiness together? Thatâ€™s the serious question posed by the Bollywood comedy â€œTotal Siyapaa.â€ù At least it would be, if the movie, directed by E. Nivas and written by Neeraj Pandey, didnâ€™t smother its story in uninspired high jinks.
As for Aman and Asha, their romance has to be taken on faith. Whether it can survive a hostile world is a question audiences wonâ€™t spend much time puzzling over.

And it needs a lift. The cramped first half, mostly in the Singh apartment, is crudely unfunny. (Mr. Zafar deserves hazard pay for a particularly awful scene in the bathroom.) Then the movie leaves the apartment, but it also wanders away from its themes. If Aman is gradually accepted by the Singhs (and is he?), it seems to be only because theyâ€™re so distracted by mishaps and gags.

For poor Aman, the Singh apartment is a house of horrors. Instead of saying hello, Ashaâ€™s little niece throws an orange at his head. Ashaâ€™s grandpa and brother spare no opportunity to insult Pakistan and Pakistanis. Grandpa even brings out a rifle from his army days that he used, he boasts, to kill Pakistanis. Whatâ€™s meant to be comic here is that the family doesnâ€™t yet know where Aman is from. Tee-hee.

Dougâ€™s wife, Kara (Michelle Monaghan), is a voracious go-getter who runs a spinning class and organizes the local Tour de Woodbury, a bike race named for the generic small town where they live. She always comes in first. The couple have a pudgy 12-year-old son, Ethan (Harrison Holzer), who is obsessed with ninja warfare and expresses his rebellion by depositing samples of his poop around school. The faculty is not amused, and the Varneys are summoned to a parent-teacher conference.

When first encountered, Mr. Rockwellâ€™s agreeably meek character, Doug Varney, suggests Walter Mitty without an imagination. In the language of 1950s sitcoms, he might be described as a â€œhenpecked husband.â€ù Doug is about to take over the pharmacy run by his bullying father-in-law, Walter (Ken Howard), who treats him with infinite disdain.

Dougâ€™s humdrum life takes a turn when he makes a pharmaceutical home delivery to Elizabeth (Olivia Wilde), a rich, unhappily married quasi-femme-fatale. In no time, she has persuaded him to unleash his inner wild man, and soon they are washing down pills with booze and bouncing off the walls.

Inside every milquetoast beats the heart of a tiger waiting to be released. All it takes to liberate the beast is a beautiful, seductive woman whose wiles can turn a mouse into a man. So goes the hoary, misogynist pop myth that drives â€œBetter Living Through Chemistry,â€ù a tepid but pleasant comic satire given a shot of contemporaneity by its writing and directing team, Geoff Moore and David Posamentier, and its star Sam Rockwell.

When Elizabeth confesses that she is bored to death with her husband (Ray Liotta), the movie threatens to become a parody of â€œThe Postman Always Rings Twice.â€ù But â€œBetter Living Through Chemistryâ€ù never becomes a full-fledged film noir. It reads as an unabashedly positive infomercial for gorging on the apparently risk-free, liberating products of Big Pharma. Mr. Rockwell, always an adept comic, plays Dougâ€™s metamorphosis lightly, and Ms. Wilde, for all her charms, refrains from portraying Elizabeth as a poisonous temptress. Their heat-free sex scenes are pure farce.

â€œBetter Living Through Chemistryâ€ù has its mildly subversive moments, especially when Doug bonds with his son by inviting him on a vandalizing spree. Most of the surprises are plot tricks in which he narrowly (and improbably) escapes disaster. For some reason, the story is intermittently narrated by Jane Fonda, whose character is identified as herself. Why is she there? Who knows? Her presence distracts more than it helps.

Nowadays, the movie implies, it takes more than a sirenâ€™s pheromones to enable a nice guy to develop a spine and morph into a sexy bad boy. This is the 21st century, after all. A little (actually a lot) of chemical assistance should be able to jump-start the transformation. All the better if that sleeping tiger is a druggist with ready access to pharmaceutical goodies.

Not for nothing does â€œBig Men,â€ù Rachel Boyntonâ€™s astonishing documentary about the 2007 discovery of oil off the coast of Ghana, open with a quotation on greed from the economist Milton Friedman. Dropping us into a perfect storm of avarice, this cool and incisive snapshot of global capitalism at work is as remarkable for its access as for its refusal to judge.

Back home, the 2008 financial downturn throws a wrench in the deal making (and in Mr. Musselmanâ€™s career), and new leadership in Ghana necessitates frantic renegotiations. While the big men fight for percentages, we travel to Nigeria to witness firsthand the trickle-down consequences of more than 50 years of oil extraction â€” and an estimated 400 billion petrodollars stolen or wasted. Apocalyptic scenes of poverty, corruption and violence greet us, a fever dream of Ghanaâ€™s possible future; but itâ€™s here, amid the chaos of destroyed pipelines and polluted townships, that the filmâ€™s disdain for overt blame pays off, turning what could have been a standard fat-cat shaming into a more nuanced portrait of universal self-interest.

Bringing to life a netherworld of shifting agreements and shuffling allegiances, â€œBig Menâ€ù unfurls a complicated story teeming with masked militants, well-fed politicians, reassuring suits and the desperate poor. To the filmâ€™s major players, whether the development of Ghanaian oil will be a boon or a curse to the nationâ€™s citizens seems irrelevant; when money is talking, those who have none also have no voice.

Tagging neither heroes nor villains, Ms. Boynton wonders instead who benefits from, and who is harmed by, the billions of dollars in play. Should the enormous risks and staggering costs of getting to â€œfirst oilâ€ù guarantee its finder â€” in this case, a small Texas start-up called Kosmos Energy â€” a sweetheart deal from the Ghanaian government? The amiable chief executive of Kosmos at the time, Jim Musselman, certainly hopes so; eager to satisfy his corporate backers, and with Ms. Boyntonâ€™s camera in tow, he schmoozes with West African royalty and glad-hands middlemen.

Through it all, in comfortable offices and on dirt roads, at lavish dinners and in crummy encampments, Ms. Boynton is there, her pointed off-screen questions revealing a swarm of competing concerns. As we saw in her first feature, â€œOur Brand Is Crisisâ€ù (2006) â€” about the involvement of American spin doctors in a Bolivian election â€” her style is careful, her mind curious and her approach open-ended. Vilifying no one, she and her wily cinematographer, Jonathan Furmanski, nevertheless nudge us to notice telling details: the heavy gold rings adorning the fingers of a Nigerian government official during a discussion of corruption and Mr. Musselmanâ€™s smooth deflection of a thorny taxation issue.

Her trip without a destination assumes a purpose when Muriel calls and asks Bettie to pick up her 11-year-old son, Charly (Nemo Schiffman), and drive him hundreds of miles to the country home of his paternal grandfather, a small-town mayor running for re-election. To Murielâ€™s surprise, Bettie agrees. But her willingness doesnâ€™t prevent Muriel from vicious, screaming attacks on her mother for myriad failures.

One day, Annie gives Bettie some bad news: Bettieâ€™s longtime lover (unseen in the movie) has fallen for a 25-year-old. Bettie is suddenly without an anchor. She was married decades earlier to a man who choked to death on a chicken bone. The marriage produced a bitter, volatile daughter, Muriel (the singer Camille), from whom Bettie is estranged.

The notion of an aging beauty who has lived long enough to transcend any obsession with her appearance is a theme that runs through â€œOn My Way,â€ù though Ms. Deneuve appears impeccably coifed and regal, except for a drunken moment at Le Ranch, where she tries on a pink Afro wig.

Just when â€œOn My Wayâ€ù seems about to be stranded in the middle of nowhere, Bettie and Charlyâ€™s fraught relationship gives the movie an emotional center and comedic drive. Mr. Schiffman is an adorable scene stealer, and the two play off each other beautifully. Even when Charly runs away, Bettie refuses to panic. No matter how seriously provoked, she never takes the bait.

Shoehorned into this overlong, agreeable mess of a film is a set piece in which Charly accompanies Bettie to a reunion of beauty contest winners from 1969 at a lakeside resort. Although thereâ€™s no essential reason for the scene â€” the assembled women, before being photographed, are instructed to suck in their bellies and lift their heads to minimize their double chins â€” this can be viewed in two ways. It is both a celebration of Ms. Deneuve as the eternal and quintessential French beauty and an acknowledgment that even eternal beauty has an expiration date.

To call Bettie unflappable doesnâ€™t mean she is unfeeling. Even when her world is falling apart, she maintains a semblance of composure. Her first impulse after the loss of her lover is to resume her former smoking habit. Her search for cigarettes turns into a road trip that eventually leads to the French heartland.

Bettie has a series of adventures in rural France, including an overnight hookup with Marco (Paul Hamy), a young man she meets in a raucous bar called Le Ranch. His fascination with her doesnâ€™t preclude his rudely remarking that she once must have been a great beauty.

Because Ms. Deneuve, 70, is in almost every scene, â€œOn My Wayâ€ù feels like Ms. Bercotâ€™s loving character study of a star who has always stood above the fray, a symbol of resilient Gallic femininity. It poses an implicit question: Aside from Bettieâ€™s working-class background, how different are the actress and her character? Although Bettie can be flustered, irritated and impatient, she soldiers through misfortune, impervious to insult and humiliation.
The gently fatalistic motto of â€œOn My Wayâ€ù comes down to three little words: â€œLive your life.â€ù

The word that best describes Catherine Deneuve in Emmanuelle Bercotâ€™s likable French road movie, â€œOn My Way,â€ù is unflappable. Her character, Bettie, who runs a failing bistro in Brittany, is a former regional beauty queen in her 60s who lives with her controlling mother, Annie (Claude Gensac).

Mere minutes into â€œDark House,â€ù it becomes depressingly clear that the deficit of imagination displayed by the title will not be made up for by the content. (One wonders why the makers even bothered to replace the original name, â€œHaunted.â€ù) Grabbing off-the-rack ideas â€” the creepy-crumbly mansion in the woods, the â€œDeliveranceâ€ù-style locals, the troubled young man with the weird psychic power â€” the director, Victor Salva, stuffs them into a plot of resounding silliness.

For Mr. Salva, this is a long way down from â€œJeepers Creepers,â€ù his respectable little 2001 frightener elevated by genuinely spooky moments and some semblance of logic. Here, instead of terror, we have vapid leads and supporting players who pause to have sex while surrounded by homicidal demons. Sadly, the only thing audiences are likely to find horrific is the acting. Or the possibility that any of these people might make another movie.

About which the less said the better, so I will merely remark that the aforementioned young man (Luke Kleintank), his heavily pregnant girlfriend (Alex McKenna) and a few interchangeable sidekicks head into those woods and a showdown both biblical and bonkers. Voices leak from heating ducts, bodies hang from a tree, and a three-legged dog makes a pointless appearance. None of which is as unintentionally amusing as the army of ax-wielding henchmen who advance in unison in a sideways crouch, like a chorus line of cave men from a Mel Brooks musical.
â€œDark Houseâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Heads are split, hearts are harvested, and a fetus is terrorized.

Mr. Villeneuve is for the most part less interested in solving that puzzle than exploring its implications, especially for Adam, the first guy we meet. He is a history professor who seems to lead a solitary, disciplined and less than entirely happy life. He lectures his students on Hegel and returns to the spare, high-rise apartment where he is sometimes visited by his girlfriend, Mary (MÃ©lanie Laurent). One night, while watching a DVD, Adam spots an extra who looks exactly like him. After a bit of Internet stalking â€” and some of the more traditional kind â€” he finds his way to Anthony, who lives in a better-furnished high-rise apartment with his pregnant wife, Helen (Sarah Gadon).

The double is an ancient and irresistible literary theme, especially beloved by philosophically minded scaremongers like Edgar Allan Poe, whose tale â€œWilliam Wilsonâ€ù is a concise classic on the matter. The idea of a second self â€” who might be the manifestation of madness, an allegory come to life or the result of a supernatural glitch in the order of things â€” is both frightening and fascinating. Movies make the conceit literal with the simple trick of using the same actor in two roles. Who can forget the two Kim Novaks driving James Stewart around the bend in â€œVertigoâ€ù?

Whether â€œEnemyâ€ù transcends its own gimmickry is an open question and may in the end be beside the point. Its style is alluring and lurid, a study in hushed tones and yellowy hues, with jolts of anxiety provided by loud, scary music (by Danny Bensi and Saunder Jurriaans). You may be left wondering about the giant spiders and the underground sex club that resembles an out-of-town tryout for an â€œEyes Wide Shutâ€ù stage revue, but you also might feel cheated if loose ends were tied up too neatly. There is only so much sense a movie like this needs to make, and this one succeeds in being divertingly clever and effectively creepy.

The resemblance between the two men is so precise that when Adam telephones Anthonyâ€™s house, Helen mistakes him for her husband. Anthony wears a beard, drives a motorcycle and favors leather jackets and sunglasses, whereas Adam is strictly a corduroy-jacket and Volvo kind of guy. He also seems a little nicer than his double, though perhaps not as much fun to be around. In any case, much of the fun in â€œEnemy,â€ù which is tightly constructed and expertly shot, lies in Mr. Gyllenhaalâ€™s playful and subtle performances. He was the best, most enigmatic part of â€œPrisoners,â€ù Mr. Villeneuveâ€™s somber thriller from last fall, and he continues to refine his quiet, watchful presence into a powerful and idiosyncratic acting style.
â€œEnemyâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex, nudity, spiders.

In â€œEnemy,â€ù Denis Villeneuveâ€™s adaptation of a novella by the Nobel Prize-winning Portuguese novelist JosÃ© Saramago, Jake Gyllenhaal plays two uncannily identical residents of an unnamed Canadian city. They are physically identical, in any case, but temperamentally distinct in ways that begin to suggest Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, to name another famous literary pair. And the question that haunts the film is whether they are really different people at all, or just sides of a single disordered personality.

Theirs is a match made in childrenâ€™s storybooks and other utopias. Ernest proves far nicer than his growl, yet is appealingly naughty. He Dumpster-dives, for one, but then heâ€™s also a bohemian with empty pockets, a lopsided grin and a love of music and play. Celestine is artistic, too â€” theyâ€™re European, after all â€” and also as responsible as she is kind. Her gentleness extends to her wide smiles, which, along with her shortened, rounded snout, hint of fur and muted dove-gray coat, make her look rather less rodentlike than she does in the books (where, frankly, she looks a bit like a rat). This softening emphasizes her touching vulnerability, as does her changeable size: Sometimes, as when sheâ€™s weeping in Ernestâ€™s arms, she can look terribly small. Some of us, it turns out, are mice, so itâ€™s good that some of us are bears.

Celestine meets Ernest after she becomes trapped in a garbage bin while looking for bear teeth. The next morning, the recently awakened, ferociously peckish Ernest discovers Celestine curled in the bin and almost eats her for breakfast. With some fast talk, agile moves and a slap across his snout that she follows with a conciliatory paw-shake, Celestine saves herself and then points Ernest to a sweet shop, where he feasts. (Bears will be bears.) After some amusing, unforced complications involving a bag of stolen teeth and a dental school, a patrol wagon filled with bear police, and mice cops that swarm with liquid grace, Celestine and Ernest go on the lam. This being something of a fairy tale, this means that the childlike Ernest and the parentlike Celestine just set up cozy house.
â€œErnest & Celestineâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Ernest growls, and he and Celestine run from the police.

One of the delights of diminutive characters like Celestine is that their tiny worlds suggest the presumed safe harbor of childhood even as their adventures foreshadow the perils, imagined and real, of adult life. The push and pull between little and big, child and adult, the nested protection of home and the uncertainties of the greater world are what stirs the heart in â€œErnest & Celestine,â€ù which turns on the improbable friendship that Celestine forms with Ernest, an adult bear. In the original French-language version, Celestine and Ernest are perfectly voiced by Pauline Brunner and Lambert Wilson; Mackenzie Foy and Forest Whitaker have been tapped for the English-language edition. Both versions are being released, rightly implying that the movie holds appeal for older viewers.

A tale of mice and bears, derring-do and dentistry, this lovely animated movie originated in a cycle of childrenâ€™s books by the Belgian writer and artist Gabrielle Vincent (1929-2000). The books have simple stories, titles like â€œCelestine and Ernestâ€™s Picnic,â€ù and Vincentâ€™s enchanting illustrations, which are characterized by graceful lines, muted colors and blurred edges that focus your attention on animals that, in their poignant delicacy, evoke Beatrix Potter. The screen character designs are broader and more overtly comic, but the three directors â€” Benjamin Renner, Vincent Patar and StÃ©phane Aubier â€” have retained enough of Vincentâ€™s charming vision that the movie feels intimate and personal, as if it, too, had sprung from a single hand.

The tiny gray mouse in the bright red coat scampers as quietly as a whisper. She lives in a land under a city of big if not especially bad bears, in a country where wee houses cling to walls, and itty-bitty mice row boats. On an ordinary day in this little land â€” as seen early on in â€œErnest & Celestineâ€ù â€” some mice will be out shopping; some will be riding elevators, and still others building muscles as they raise and lower the metal bars of mouse traps with vigor and precision. Tucked into one street, youâ€™ll find an orphanage that brings to mind Madelineâ€™s boarding school, but one with little mice like Celestine in straight lines instead of little girls.

Like Stuart Little, the Borrowers and other Lilliputian inhabitants of childrenâ€™s literature, Celestine lives in a miniaturized realm that mirrors ours in winsome detail. Yet she also navigates a larger world because sheâ€™s often out searching for bear teeth, which the mice use to replace their own incisors. She does so with great resourcefulness (ingenuity is one of the fictional orphanâ€™s birthrights), but sheâ€™s worryingly small. The bears have enormous teeth and claws, the better to eat something with â€” maybe mice. And Celestine, it soon emerges, adores bears, though mice are supposed to fear them. There isnâ€™t much of a moral to this story, but it does put a premium on individuality and pluck. Mostly, â€œErnest & Celestineâ€ù is an ode to the happiness that comes from being with those different from us.

Persona as armor is a common theme, with the transgender performer Rose Wood, whose characters sashay brilliantly across the identity spectrum, speaking movingly of physical and psychological attacks. Most people who have seen her powerful arms and deeply disturbing â€œSerial Killerâ€ù routine, however, are likely to think twice before taking her on.

Captured in front of dressing-room mirrors and appreciative audiences, the artists speak candidly about the issues of gender, sexuality and body image that inform their work. From Manhattan clubs to the Coney Island boardwalk, a collage of performance snippets reveals how explicit that work can be, but the director, Beth B, makes an effort to uncover the person beneath the exhibition. For the disabled artist Mat Fraser â€” the filmâ€™s most obvious link to burlesqueâ€™s sideshow roots â€” flaunting his imperfections is a way of redirecting anger and cementing self-acceptance.

Dancing on the wilder shores of burlesque, the eight performers profiled in â€œExposedâ€ù practice the kind of subversive cabaret that few non-city-dwellers are likely to have seen. Thatâ€™s too bad, because these confrontational comedians â€” however serious the message, itâ€™s always imparted with liberal dollops of humor â€” are experts at merging shock and showmanship.

â€œThere is freedom in vulgarity,â€ù the irrepressible Bunny Love tells us, swiping lipstick across her vulva during a delicious deconstruction of a Southern belle. There is also a great deal of joy, and while these lubricious entertainers are making political points by pulling American flags from unlikely locations, or dancing a beautiful dark ballet with a severed hand, theyâ€™re mostly just interested in showing us a really good time.

â€œOrdinary is best!â€ù a 14-year-old boy, Sumida (Shota Sometani), defiantly shouts. Sumida just wants to disappear. At this protest, his not-so-secret admirer, Keiko (Fumi Nikaido), stands up with glee. (Ms. Nikaido is terrific in this stalker role, like a cuter Sandra Bernhard in â€œThe King of Comedy.â€ù)
â€œNobody in the world has experienced atrocities like us Japanese,â€ù a teacher says to his class, encouraging them to chase their dreams.

While not as graphic as Mr. Sonoâ€™s other films, the violence here is unrelenting and from all sides. So when Sumida, with his doleful face painted like Jean-Paul Belmondoâ€™s in â€œPierrot le Fou,â€ù is driven to vigilante justice, itâ€™s understandable yet especially tragic.
â€œHimizuâ€ù is a futuristic, dystopian film set in the present. It was made by Sion Sono in 2011, soon after the earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster in Japan.

These two isolated individuals bond in a society coming apart at its foundation. Mr. Sono uses sound, a low, grumbling noise like an earthquake, to convey this chaos. He also gives the film a harrowing cacophony and a sense of trauma with sound effects, including subtle echoes.

Sumida lives in a shack beside a boat rental place. His violent parents are mostly absent, if not asking him for money. Heâ€™s looked after instead by a group of displaced vagabonds who camp out in his yard by the water. Keikoâ€™s parents, though wealthier, are even worse. Theyâ€™re building her a noose that they hope sheâ€™ll use.

In the United States, this piece of fiction could easily be reality: The stakes keep rising for those on both sides of the paparazzi cameras. In South Korea, where a number of celebrities have committed suicide in recent years, itÂ isÂ a reality. So it is curious that the screenplay turns this womanâ€™s tragic tale into a testosterone-fueled action adventure. (â€œTabloid Truth,â€ù its news release says, is the first South Korean film to address the tabloid culture in that country.)

In â€œTabloid Truth,â€ù the director Kim Kwang-sik explores the underbelly of a world that may sound familiar to fans of â€œHouse of Cardsâ€ù or â€œScandal.â€ù Here, journalists, political figures and businessmen (yes, all men) collude to shape public opinion and further their agendas. At meetings, they hatch up â€œnewsâ€ù (accuracy is not a guiding principle) that is disseminated via an exclusive stock market tip sheet, whipping the tabloids into a frenzy.

After a promising actress, Mi-jin (Ko Won-hee), becomes the focus of one of these reports â€” she is rumored to be having an affair with a married politician â€” she ends up dead, jolting her distraught manager, Woo-gon (Kim Kang-woo), into action hero mode. What starts as a dirt-digging expedition turns into a cat-and-mouse game, with a sadist fixer fond of breaking appendages.

While Kim Kwang-sik deftly renders the fight and chase sequences, the filmâ€™s unrelenting pace and tangled plot trump its limited efforts to address the feelings of despair or the broader moral issues at its heart.

For a guy who often plays nice, Jason Bateman sure knows how to wrap his lips around invective. He doesnâ€™t have an especially rubbery mouth, the kind that Jerry Lewis could stretch until it almost snapped, nor does it curl with the puckered elasticity displayed in the poster for â€œBad Words,â€ù a comedy about a guy who crashes childrenâ€™s spelling bees. Sometimes, he just opens wide, and out pops an expletive. At other times, he turns his nice-guy face toward the target, pauses for a beat or two while he sizes up the opposition â€” maybe sends out a decoy, like a faint smile or a deceptively inviting word â€” and then he slashes and burns. The kids take it hard.

It would be something to see Mr. Bateman go authentically dark (perhaps not that dark), but itâ€™s also enough just to watch him as he widens his eyes, furrows his brow and shows off his excellent timing. He does fine behind the camera, as well, even if with too many slow-motion interludes. But itâ€™s a fluid feature-directing debut, and he pulls the ensemble together smoothly: The performances are funny, appealing and, in the case of Allison Janney, as a spelling bee official, wonderful. A dowdied-down Kathryn Hahn has it tougher as Jenny, a reporter whoâ€™s chasing Guy for his story and occasional sex. Itâ€™s a pathetic role, largely because sheâ€™s a sad piÃ±ata made for the whacking simply because, it seems, the only thing worse than making kids cry is being a journalist.
â€œBad Wordsâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A feature-length blue streak.

One of the givens in â€œBad Words,â€ù a would-be gonzo comedy with a tough exterior and a marshmallow center, is that thereâ€™s something funny about making children cry. Squeezing tears is a talent that Mr. Batemanâ€™s bullying 40-year-old, Guy Trilby, has perfected as the unwelcome participant and universally loathed champion in a national spelling bee where everyone else is decades younger. He has his reasons, because, well, everyone does. (Heâ€™s wormed his way in through a loophole by claiming to have never graduated from the eighth grade.) Guy is a smarty-pants even if heâ€™s not as clever as he thinks. By the time he comes clean about his dirty words and deeds near the end, you may have already spelled O-e-d-i-p-a-l and moved on to p-s-y-c-h-o-b-a-b-b-l-e.

It scarcely matters, because the point of a movie like â€œBad Wordsâ€ù isnâ€™t psychological nuance or philosophical profundity, but the secondhand pleasures that are supposed to come from irresistibly disreputable characters engaging in socially unacceptable behavior. That, at any rate, is the idea, as the movie, which Mr. Bateman directed, takes Guy from contest to contest, and he spells and smarms his way to another victory. Along the way, the recipients of his broadsides start to seem so specifically targeted that they could join any number of antidefamation groups. He jokes about one boyâ€™s weight, tells a girl that sheâ€™s leaking menstrual blood before she takes the stage to compete, and quiets a hectoring mother by, among other digs, comparing her vagina to a â€œblown-out sweat sock.â€ù

By then, the movie has already started to soften, and Guy has begun hanging out with a chatty, sociable 10-year-old competitor, Chaitanya Chopra (Rohan Chand, a scene-swiping moppet). They meet cute aboard an airplane to the spelling bee finale when Chaitanya introduces himself, and Guy tells him to point his â€œcurry holeâ€ù elsewhere. This is followed by some back-and-forth, slap-and-tickle as Chaitanya, with what seems like pathological obstinacy, insists on befriending the surprisingly willing Guy. Itâ€™s an odd-couple hookup that, at least from a distance, could set off alarms, or would, if the movie, written by Andrew Dodge, were testing the borders of mainstream comedy instead of staying within its acceptable parameters. Ugly vagina jokes are O.K.; man-boy love jokes, ew, not so much.

But donâ€™t be fooled by Mr. Broadbentâ€™s genial sarcasm, Ms. Duncanâ€™s warm smile or the literary felicities of Mr. Kureishiâ€™s script. This is not a movie about the gentle aging of lovable codgers â€” â€œThe Best Exotic Marigold Hotelâ€ù in the shadow of the Eiffel Tower. Underneath Nick and Megâ€™s banter is a half-buried spring of rage and regret, and before the trip is over, it will flood into the open. His neediness and her restlessness seem less and less complementary. â€œIâ€™ve become a phobic object to you,â€ù he complains when she rebuffs his amorous advances, and she complains more and more vocally â€” and even violently â€” about his stifling need for safety and stability. All of a sudden, rather than participating in the celebration of a long marriage, we seem to be witnessing its end.

A mellow, playful, slightly melancholy atmosphere pervades much of â€œLe Week-End,â€ù the latest collaboration between the screenwriter Hanif Kureishi and the director Roger Michell. Surely the thin line Nick and Meg are walking is not between love and hate, but between contentment and disappointment. They set out on their holiday in possession of a collection of small, qualified triumphs: long careers as teachers (though Nickâ€™s has just ended on an unpleasant note), two grown sons (though one might be moving back in with them), enough money for this trip (though not perhaps the luxury they secretly crave).

Morgan invites Nick and Meg to a party that is both climax and anticlimax, and as such a testament to Mr. Kureishiâ€™s admirable habit of valuing revelations of character and setting more than the mechanics of plot. As they did in â€œThe Motherâ€ù and â€œVenus,â€ù he and Mr. Michell allow audiences the leisure to get to know the people in â€œWeek-End.â€ù We may even, at the end, want to know them better than we do, since, at the end, our sense of Nick and Meg â€” and of Morgan, who is more important than we might have thought â€” is both clarified and complicated. They still have such a long way to go.

But maybe â€” to equivocate further â€” itâ€™s just Paris, which can have the effect of making ordinary feelings seem somehow more intense and everyday thoughts more profound. Beyond its sights and its history, the city appeals to tourists inclined to a particular form of solipsism. Sensory and aesthetic pleasures are not indulgent but important: You can sit in a cafe and feel like a philosopher, or amble down a narrow street and fancy yourself a revolutionary. Your marital squabbles can turn into folies dâ€™amour. At the very least, you can pretend youâ€™re in a French movie.

Their dance of recrimination and reconciliation is interrupted by a chance encounter with Morgan (Jeff Goldblum), an old friend of Nickâ€™s from their student days at Cambridge. The contrast between the two men is almost too perfect. Morgan, lean, energetic and suavely dressed, is a happy sellout â€” a jet-setting policy intellectual with an apartment on the Rue de Rivoli, a best-selling book and a young, adoring, pregnant new wife. He admires Nickâ€™s integrity, though he doesnâ€™t seem to miss his own.

â€œLe Week-Endâ€ù is thoroughly and unassumingly British, but part of the baggage Nick and Meg carry is a generationally specific, politically tinged Francophilia. This is captured in a scene from Jean-Luc Godardâ€™s â€œBande Ã  Part,â€ù a still-vibrant document of youthful mid-60s restlessness, which Mr. Michell alludes to several times, including in his filmâ€™s lovely final shot. If Meg is itching for a different future, Nick is at times lost in a reverie of the past. While she sleeps, he stays up late in their hotel room, drinking minibar whiskey and listening to Bob Dylan on his iPod. â€œHow does it feel to be on your own?â€ù Heâ€™s terrified of finding out.

â€œYou canâ€™t not love and hate the same person,â€ù Nick says to Meg, the woman he has loved for more than 30 years. They are on an anniversary trip to Paris, celebrating a complicated but enduring and affectionate union. Nickâ€™s observation is more wry than anguished, and its implication of melodrama â€” evoking that famous â€œthin lineâ€ù sung about by the Persuaders and the Pretenders â€” does not seem to apply to him and Meg. Played by Jim Broadbent and Lindsay Duncan, they look like a modest, decent, likably scruffy couple, British baby boomers entering their sunset years with stoicism and good humor.
â€œLe Week-Endâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gallic behavior and Anglo-Saxon words.

Nick, a self-described â€œanarchist of the left,â€ù is nervous about money, and it is Meg who manages to turn conspicuous consumption into an act of rebellion. Upon discovering that the charming Montmartre hotel they recall from an earlier visit is more ratty than quaint, she upgrades them to a suite at a far grander establishment. When their credit card is declined after a lavish dinner, she organizes a dine-and-dash operation. She is a freedom fighter, though she may be fighting, above all, to free herself from Nick.

The De Leonâ€™s mastermind is a mysterious, talkative fellow known as the Monarch, an Internet phenomenon played with nutty exuberance by Michael Keaton. Exuberance is not a quality associated with Tobey Marshall (Aaron Paul, best known for his role in AMCâ€™s â€œBreaking Badâ€ù), a Mount Kisco mechanic who hopes to use the De Leon to settle some scores. A local hot shot named Dino Brewster (Dominic Cooper) stole Tobeyâ€™s girlfriend, Anita (Dakota Johnson), and then did some even worse stuff, stuff that wrecked Tobeyâ€™s business, landed him in jail and cost the life of one of his friends. Tobey glowers and sighs and speaks in a low, sorrowful rasp.

â€œNeed for Speedâ€ù is dumb and loud and sometimes technically impressive, which means that it is successful on its own terms. Whether it cashes in on the popularity of the games or of the much stronger and more imaginative â€œFast & Furiousâ€ù franchise, is a potentially interesting question but not really any of my business. Iâ€™m just along for the ride.

Based on a popular series of racing-themed video games, â€œNeed for Speedâ€ù sums up its appeal in the title. An energetic, unpretentious B movie â€” the kind best seen at a drive-in like the one in an early scene â€” it is devoted, above all, to the delivery of visceral, kinetic excitement. In the game, you are at the wheel. Watching other people drive is never as much fun, so the movie, directed by Scott Waugh from a script by George Gatins, supplies a few passenger seat distractions. In addition to velocity, you may need some emotion.

So â€œNeed for Speedâ€ù opens up a few generic cans of feeling, the ones labeled Betrayal and Honor. It stirs in characters a bit less distinctive than the average game avatar â€” a blue-eyed hero, a dark-haired villain, a few funny sidekicks, a girl â€” and sets them off in pursuit of something vaguely archetypal. â€œThis is about much more than racing!â€ù someone exclaims. But also much less.
â€œNeed for Speedâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Car crashes and rough language.

Anyway, the driving is fun to watch, though the 3-D does not add much to the immediacy. The three big races that structure the story are less inventive than the wild traffic violations that propel the hero and his pals from Mount Kisco, N.Y., to San Francisco, where a super-important illegal race called the De Leon is scheduled to take place.

Assisting Tobey in his quest for payback â€” for vindication, redemption and the keys to a million-dollar European car â€” are (in order of importance) a lovingly modified silver Mustang, a wisecracking friend who can fly a plane (Scott Mescudi), two other wisecracking friends who can do other things (Rami Malek and Ramon Rodriguez) and Julia (Imogen Poots), a woman who knows something about cars. Not that much, maybe, and sheâ€™s only allowed to drive once, but Ms. Poots is a good sport and a deft enough actress to find the balance of silliness and gravity that the movie requires.

Dull filmmaking and spiritless dialogue can together feel like a curse that hangs over actors, stifling their every other scene. Nominally a romantic comedy in the ethnic-family subgenre, â€œShirin in Loveâ€ù is a case in point, plodding along with the young Iranian-American writer of the title as she gets cold feet about marrying her fiancÃ©, a surgeon, and pursues the son of an interview subject.

Shirin (Nazanin Boniadi) works for a magazine run by her conniving mother (Anahita Khalatbari, all over the place) and still lives at home in Los Angeles. She visits a famous, reclusive author, Rachel (Amy Madigan), traveling up the picturesque coast to conduct an interview. There she gets involved with the writerâ€™s bright son, William (Riley Smith, who also contributed to the distractingly generic score). This decent young man works in a photogenically cluttered lighthouse.

Ramin Niami, the filmâ€™s Iranian-born writer and director, works to decorate the story with Iranian-American detail (colorful expressions, Persian bands). Yet he canâ€™t really sustain a flow. Itâ€™s the kind of movie that makes you zero in on and root for an actor (Ms. Madigan) as she tries to wring something real out of her lines, but thereâ€™s no saving this film.

As a female detective and her partner investigate, a story is told, in chapters, of a shy woman named Izumi (Megumi Kagurazaka) who is married to a successful romance novelist. To alleviate the boredom of waiting all day for him to return from his office, she gets a job passing out sausage samples at a grocery store. This is most certainly symbolic. It leads very quickly down a path that involves pornography, casual sex and, eventually, prostitution.

â€œGuilty of Romanceâ€ù is the third movie in Mr. Sonoâ€™s â€œHateâ€ù trilogy; the others are â€œLove Exposureâ€ù and â€œCold Fish.â€ù The situations Izumi finds herself in, particularly with Mitsuko, are barely tolerable scenes of abuse and violence. Yet most disturbing and fascinating is the mixture of Izumiâ€™s liberation with her degradation in this film, which plays like a more horrific version of David Lynchâ€™s â€œMullholland Drive.â€ù

â€œGuilty of Romanceâ€ù is a garish-colored noir by the Japanese filmmaker Sion Sono. Black shadows and bright green and pink lights set the tone of this sickening, lush mystery about two female corpses, each partly a severed human and partly a mannequin.Â (This is seemingly a nod to the real-life 1940s Black Dahlia case.)

Along this road, she meets a mentor, Mitsuko (Makoto Togashi), a brilliant yet damaged literature professor who moonlights as a streetwalker. She insists that Izumi demand money for sex if there is no love. When Izumi does so, Mitsuko tells her: â€œYou earned it with all of your body. Now the word Izumi Kikuchi has conceived a meaning.â€ù

Whatâ€™s missing, however, is legion. Long on censure and short on specifics, Mr. Williamsâ€™s critique tosses out terms like â€œgenetic predispositionâ€ù to addiction without explaining the science. A detailed cost-benefit comparison of prison and treatment would have been welcome, as would at least one countervailing voice amid the forest of talking heads. Instead, we have an actress promoting her addiction memoir and a litany of status quo criticisms that, however accurate, tend to obscure the filmâ€™s most valuable segments. Among these are an enlightening overview of the American recovery movement and a perceptive discussion of Alcoholics Anonymous that effectively repositions our understanding of its tradition of anonymity.

Heartfelt but hectoring, â€œThe Anonymous Peopleâ€ù needs more of the folksy pragmatism embodied by the recovery expert John Shinholser. With their boots-on-the-ground commitment to the hard work of rehabilitation, he and his peers seem to understand that attitudes are more likely to be changed by results than by celebrity confessionals.

Joining the stunned conversation surrounding Philip Seymour Hoffmanâ€™s recent overdose, â€œThe Anonymous Peopleâ€ù could not have appeared at a more opportune moment. But however good the intentions, this sluggish documentary about the stigma of substance abuse and the barriers to recovery never comes close to catching fire.

Claiming that addiction is Americaâ€™s most underfinanced public health problem, the director, Greg Williams, blames a criminal justice system that chooses incarceration over treatment; a news media that revels in drug-fueled celebrity meltdowns while cold-shouldering the productively rehabilitated; and a populace that, by and large, tends to view dependence as the wages of sin rather than an illness.

The plot gets a bit convoluted (Jonathan Sobol wrote the script and directed), and thereâ€™s never much doubt about Crunchâ€™s true intentions, but a quirky sense of humor keeps the film enjoyable. The supporting cast members are all over the place stylistically, though theyâ€™re fun to watch. Jason Jones of â€œThe Daily Show With Jon Stewart,â€ù turns up as an investigator. The always amusing Jay Baruchel is the sidekick Crunch brings in on the job. And, for those who like this kind of thing, a sculpture of a giant vagina plays a pivotal role.
Matt Dillon and Kurt Russell may not make the most convincing half-brothers, but â€œThe Art of the Stealâ€ù is a fairly amusing heist film with some sibling tension helping the story along.

Mr. Russell is Crunch Calhoun, who with his half-brother, Nicky (Mr. Dillon), is part of an art theft ring that is botching a job in Europe as the film opens. When things go bad, Nicky gives up Crunch to save his own hide, and Crunch lands in a Polish prison.
â€œThe Art of the Stealâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian) for language and a sculpturally explicit prop.
He gets out more than five years later, understandably miffed at Nicky, yet he still agrees to join up with him again for a big job involving an ancient manuscript.

Mr. Scanavino makes his stoner character a relatable human being who sticks to his guns even when heâ€™s not sure where that autonomy will lead him. Thatâ€™s a common predicament in the filmâ€™s rural milieu, which treats its varieties of independent-minded characters â€” including the confused, overwhelmed but resilient Atticus â€” with understanding. (Mr. Gilroyâ€™s last feature film, in 2000, was the sensitively acted â€œSpring Forward,â€ù starring Ned Beatty and Liev Schreiber.)

Raised off the grid and orphaned at 11, Atticus lives through more than one rough patch over the course of Tom Gilroyâ€™s â€œThe Cold Lands.â€ù This becalmed film, which was partly shot in a woodsy part of New York State, fails to crystallize until Atticus attaches himself to a dude who sells homemade trinkets.

We meet the well-mannered Atticus (Silas Yelich) when heâ€™s living with his overprotective, home-schooling mother (Lili Taylor) in humble circumstances. He is just learning to stand up to her when she dies. Taught to suspect the authorities and accustomed to living without power, he flees into the forest during the filmâ€™s middle, occasionally dreamlike, portion. When he falls in with Carter (Peter Scanavino), a Baja-sweater-wearing drifter with a kind heart, he finds security in decent company but also a continuation of hand-to-mouth living.
But Mr. Yelich is even more emotionally reticent than this central character requires, and â€œThe Cold Landsâ€ù feels as if it were just taking hold when it reaches the end of the road.
In this movie? Ha.
â€œYes, but I want the real thing.â€ù
â€œI want to see you,â€ù Damien says online.

While the horror film â€œThe Denâ€ù indulges in the hoary found-footage conceit and traffics in shopworn genre staples (dank hallways, claustrophobic subterranean lairs), it brings a new player to the party: the online video chat. And the movie, the feature debut of the director, Zach Donohue (who wrote the script with Lauren Thompson), does so with flair.

When a graduate student, Elizabeth Benton (Melanie Papalia), receives a grant to study video-chat culture, she commits 24/7 to a website, the Den, to conduct research. While at home, trolling among the characters online â€” an amusing, often unsettling gallery of eccentrics, exhibitionists and fetishists â€” she sees one murdered on camera. A police sergeant (Matt Riedy) is skeptical, of course, as are (initially) her boyfriend, Damien (David Schlachtenhaufen), and tech-savvy pal, Max (Adam Shapiro). Which only makes things easier for burlap-masked killers who hack into her computer and trace her every step, as well as those of her loved ones.
â€œYouâ€™re seeing me now,â€ù Elizabeth replies.
â€œThe Denâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violence, nudity, obscene language and an even more obscene lack of privacy.

Almost every image in this movie â€” from webcams, websites and laptop cameras â€” appears on a monitor. Scenes pulse with the Internetâ€™s speed and sprawl, aided by clever editing that pops. The effect is insular, off-putting and disconcertingly familiar.
â€œVeronica Marsâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Violence, fisticuffs and a high school reunion.

The current cultural directive to give the people what they want explains the existence of the â€œVeronica Marsâ€ù movie, a likable, unmemorable, feature-length footnote to the admired television series that became a cause when it was canceled in 2007. A sleuth from the fictional, filthy rich town of Neptune, Veronica traversed high school and college for three seasons, solving mysteries while cracking wise about the privileged locals. She looked like a Southern California cheerleader and alternately talked like Sam Spade and Noam Chomsky, a combo that made her televisionâ€™s very own Little Miss Sunshine and Noir.

What does Veronica want? Mr. Thomas suggests that even after graduating from law school â€” and with a seductive big-city job dangling before her â€” she yearns for Neptune and its sordid intrigues. The problem is that Mr. Thomas canâ€™t make the case or his story convincing. Itâ€™s clear why he and Ms. Bell are back, and thereâ€™s Loganâ€™s murder rap, of course. But itâ€™s hard to believe that Veronica, having matured into the totally together woman you always knew she would become, would honestly want to return to this pitiful small town other than for a visit with Dad.

That the theatrical release feels like a wrong move isnâ€™t about the nominal limitations of television, but rather its strengths. The original series hasnâ€™t aged; rather, like all good TV it feels perfectly preserved, like a butterfly in amber. Thatâ€™s principally because of the timeless righteousness of Veronica, who embodies the struggle of right over wrong and who, with wit and charmingly breezy cool, fights the mean girls and boys, the Botoxed queens and murderous kings of her neo-Versailles.

Itâ€™s nice to see Ms. Bell and some of the other â€œVeronica Marsâ€ù regulars making the rounds in Neptune, including her former sidekick, Wallace (Percy Daggs III), and her gal-pal Mac (Tina Majorino), the hacker who once conned the high school elite. Yet even without another episode to look forward to â€” and then another and another â€” their homecoming never sits right. Everything feels forced, from Veronicaâ€™s almost compulsive snappy patter to a class reunion that includes a sex tape and a brawl. A story thread involving Veronica and her current squeeze, Piz (Chris Lowell), is especially unpersuasive because it dies the moment that Logan appears before Veronica in his ill-fitting Navy whites and she name-checks â€œAn Officer and a Gentleman,â€ù a joke made unfunny by its obvious narrative telegraphing.

Veronica is back,Â having been resurrected by her creator, Rob Thomas, and its star, Kristen Bell, again in the title role, through a Kickstarter campaign that drew on the largess of its fans. Some 91,000 contributors, perhaps hungry for closure, ponied up the cash to bankroll a movie, raising $2 million in (pant, pant) under 12 hours on the way to $5.7 million. That may be chump change to Warner Bros., which owns the rights to â€œVeronica Marsâ€ù (and threw in more money), but the campaign makes a nice story even if legions of fans will be paying a multinational corporation dearly to see an old friend. As of Friday, the movie will be in some theaters but also a video on demand, so for $14.99 or $19.99 in HD â€” about twice an average movie ticket â€” they and everyone else can watch it the way that it should be seen: on TV.

Specifically, she was born to do this once upon a time week after week, with introductory teasers, a wry voice-over, narrative complications and those mini-cliffhangers called act outs or act breaks that precede commercials. The movie is something of an advertisement for itself in some franchise form or another, and while it doesnâ€™t exactly have act outs, Mr. Thomas, who wrote and directed, remains fond of mini-climaxes.

The story involves Veronicaâ€™s returning to Neptune to help out Logan (Jason Dohring), her onetime adversary and old boyfriend, whoâ€™s suspected of killing his rock-star girlfriend. Mr. Thomasâ€™s appreciation for over-the-top, prime-time-soap-opera-style entanglements â€” he went to school in Austin, Tex., and surely studied the florid TV show â€œDallasâ€ù â€” also remains intact.

She might want to extend that trip and nostalgically break out the Taser. She might even want to tie up some of the ends that have remained loose for the last seven years. But why would you want to go home again when you could just stream it on Amazon?

Yet while Veronica walks and talks the hard-boiled line she can be a soft touch. With her father, Keith (Enrico Colantoni, back too), she takes on cases for pay but also because she cares. Like Buffy Summers, her sister in bantam blond awesomeness, Veronica was born to do this.

The brothers eventually win the creation, in 1961, of the Xingu National Park, a preserve larger than Maryland. The film makes clear that not everyone agrees with the Xingu approach, that one answer does not fit all. But as natives maintain traditional lives there, they can integrate into the larger society, by their own choice and at their own speed.

A gripping account of a collision of cultures, â€œXinguâ€ù tells the inspiring true story of the three Villas BÃ´as brothers, who became the leading advocates for Brazilâ€™s Amazonian Indians, an effort that culminated in the founding of a mammoth tribal preserve.

Directed by Cao Hamburger, â€œXinguâ€ù begins in 1943, when the brothers â€” Orlando (Felipe Camarago), ClÃ¡udio (JoÃ£o Miguel) and Leonardo (Caio Blat) â€” sign up for Brazilâ€™s March to the West, an expedition to explore and open the interior for development. Smitten by the landâ€™s raw beauty, they are also fascinated by the indigenous people there.

Orlando, the eldest and a natural politician, defuses the tensions when they meet the Xavante, who have not seen white men before. When a flu epidemic kills half the tribe, the brothers vow to protect the natives from the forces of civilization that they represent. â€œWe are the poison,â€ù ClÃ¡udio says, â€œand the antidote.â€ù

Unfortunately, the movie covers almost three decades choppily. But Mr. Camarago and Mr. Miguel convey the stubborn commitment that made the brothers so revered by the tribes. The native actors add authenticity to the production, which uses the TupÃ_ language and films in the park. In all, â€œXinguâ€ù is a fitting tribute to the Villas BÃ´as vision.

Mr. Perryâ€™s moms are first thrown together when their children get in trouble at school. The five women are a spectrum of case studies in single motherhood, lightly dosed with comedy and realized with varying degrees of vividness: the abrasive publishing agent, Jan (Wendi McLendon-Covey); the overprotective waitress, Lytia (Cocoa Brown), hardened by two family casualties of urban strife; the feckless, fresh and divorced Hillary (Amy Smart), also Janâ€™s pal; and Lytiaâ€™s friend Esperanza (Zulay Hanao), who hides her hot boyfriend from her daughter and manipulative ex-husband. Thereâ€™s even a print journalist, May (an underenthused Nia Long).

The group resolves to meet for regular vent sessions, with wine washing away initial class tensions. As Lytia, the mostly deft Ms. Brown is tasked with the hard looks and the tough parenting Mr. Perry admires, while also fending off a goofy suitor (Terry Crews). Ms. McLendon-Covey embraces Mr. Perryâ€™s improvisatory style in expressing Janâ€™s snobbish insensitivity, but she throws some scenes a little out of whack. Ms. Hanao is warm and appealing, while Ms. Smart doesnâ€™t quite find her footing, though, admittedly, her character is supposed to be flailing.

The mothers eventually hit upon a babysitting arrangement that allows big nights out while one of them looks after the kids, who are clever and misunderstood. Whatever class anxieties and double binds Mr. Perry sets up lose their mild bite as the film concocts a last-minute conflict and then melts away. The movie arrives having already succeeded in one respect â€” Oprah Winfreyâ€™s OWN channel announced plans to adapt it into a television series back in January â€” but the complacency of the filmmaking is all too apparent.
â€œTyler Perryâ€™s The Single Moms Clubâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Family woes and playfully blunt overtures.

A movie-length act of affirmation, â€œTyler Perryâ€™s The Single Moms Clubâ€ù saunters through the struggles, hopes, and reconciliations among five mothers making do. Mr. Perryâ€™s latest film touches upon some recognizable and realistic challenges with efficient compassion, but thereâ€™s probably more dramatic tension in a car pool than in this filmâ€™s collection of predicaments.

No actor can truly hit her stride when periodically charged with delivering announcements that characters should stick together, press on and put themselves out there. The filmâ€™s chief themes are at one point literally flashed in writing on the screen, when May is inspired to work on a book about the club. Mr. Perryâ€™s usual alter ego, Madea, may not be present to give free-style sermons, but the actor-writer-director plays his customary substitute role as a decent and flirtily frank gentleman.

Mr. Khurrana plays Mohit Chaddha, a recently promoted airline marketing whiz who lives the high life in Delhi with Mayera (Ms. Kapoor). Just days after he has proposed to her, a faltering economy forces him out of his job. As if that threat to his self-esteem werenâ€™t enough, he must ask Mayeraâ€™s gruff father, V. K. Sehgal (the veteran actor and director Rishi Kapoor, no relation to Ms. Kapoor), for her hand. And V. K. has some stringent (and tedious) demands.

The wages of love â€” that is, the salaries of people in love â€” is the most interesting plot hinge in Nupur Asthanaâ€™s Bollywood romantic comedy â€œBewakoofiyaanâ€ù (â€œFoolishnessâ€ù in Hindi). This tale of a yuppie couple (played by Ayushmann Khurrana and Sonam Kapoor) flirts with intriguing notions of recessionary struggle, though strained, contrived humor bogs it down.

Mr. Khurrana acquits himself, parading his enviable six-pack abs in a poolside production number and holding his own opposite Mr. Kapoorâ€™s barrel-chested bluster. But the more interesting portrait is Ms. Kapoorâ€™s poised Mayera. Slightly wealthier at the outset than Mohit, she demonstrates a faith in love that he lacks and saves the day. And when Ms. Kapoor smiles, she displays a dazzling goofiness ideal for, say, a screwball comedy. She may be eclipsed by Mr. Khurrana in screen time, but she is the one to watch.

A civil servant nearing retirement, V. K. puts his prospective son-in-law through countless arch comic paces, conducting background checks and challenging him to squash matches that Mohit must let him win. After humiliating rejections at job interviews and the A.T.M. and with his credit card, Mohit is reduced to working as a barista, while his friends at his former office pretend he is still employed there during visits from a snooping V. K.

Along the way, Mr. Panh takes stock of the Khmer Rouge; its leader, Pol Pot (1925-1998); and the geopolitical events preceding their years of terror, but his approach is at once more expansive and specific. Culturally authorized history invariably belongs to vanquished leaders as well as to their victorious counterparts, which itself becomes a triumph, as endless books and movies about Hitler suggest. In â€œThe Missing Picture,â€ù Mr. Panh rights that imbalance by focusing on the ordinary people, like his relatives, who lived and died under the Khmer Rouge (Khmer is the name of a Cambodian aboriginal people and the countryâ€™s largest ethnic group), rather than on the perpetrators who tortured, starved and slaughtered so many. Mr. Panh shows Pol Pot, who eerily smiles in propaganda clips, but thereâ€™s no doubt to whom this movie belongs.

The audacity of â€œThe Missing Pictureâ€ù â€” a brilliant documentary about a child who held on to life in Cambodiaâ€™s killing fields â€” is equaled only by its soulfulness. On April 17, 1975, the day the Khmer Rouge seized the capital, Phnom Penh, the 13-year-old Rithy Panh, his family and millions more were driven from that city and other towns and villages and straight into hell. Four years later, many of his relatives, including his father, mother, sisters and a niece and nephew were dead; decades later, Mr. Panh, now a filmmaker, has told his story in a movie in which the act of remembrance serves as a form of resistance.

â€œThe Missing Pictureâ€ù is narrated with restrained musicality in French (by Randal Douc), a language that Mr. Panh learned after he emigrated to France. (An equally affecting English-language version was shown at the New York Film Festival last year.) The French narration, Mr. Panh has said, is in tribute to his father, a former Cambodian government worker who loved French poetry. The first clay figurine you see emerges in the rough hands of a man who turns this little lump into a totem, a memory, a father. (The figurines were created by Sarith Mang.) Itâ€™s an indescribably touching transformation, as is the narration that echoes another, more familiar story of creation: â€œWith clay and water, with the dead, with rice fields, with living hands, a man is made.â€ù

In time, the clay figurines begin to change â€” their rib cages jut out, their faces sink in â€” as does your relationship to them. First, they become characters, and then, with alchemical mystery and deep feeling, they turn into people. The transformation of clay figurines into rounded characters you come to care about greatly may not be especially surprising, given that such transporting transmutations are as old as cinema. Yet what is startling is the depth of emotion that Mr. Panh solicits from you as he fills in the missing picture of this lost world and â€” with the little clay boy in the colorful shirt, the little clay woman dying in her bed and the little clay father that he yearns to hold close â€” reclaims the very human individuality that the Khmer Rouge sought to obliterate.

â€œMemory must remain a reference point,â€ù Mr. Panh asserts in his 2012 memoir, written with Christophe Bataille, â€œThe Elimination: A Survivor of the Khmer Rouge Confronts His Past and the Commandant of the Killing Fields.â€ù â€œWhat Iâ€™m looking for is comprehension,â€ù Mr. Panh continues, â€œI want to understand the nature of the crime, not to establish a cult of memory.â€ù Itâ€™s an edict that feels like a moral imperative in â€œThe Missing Picture.â€ù The movie, which turns historical reclamation into something of an exorcism, traces Mr. Panh and his familyâ€™s ordeal both through familiar documentary devices â€” including archival news footage, old photographs and haunting snippets of song â€” and, more radically, through carved and painted clay figurines that serve as human stand-ins.

Despite the peasant roots of his father, the family wasnâ€™t spared the Khmer Rougeâ€™s violence, and soon after leaving Phnom Penh, it was swept up and away in the terror, subjected to ideological â€œre-educationâ€ù and renunciation, as well as to crushingly brutal forced labor, disease and starvation. The figurines in the movieâ€™s diorama-like sets â€” including the one in the colorful shirt representing the young Mr. Panh â€” initially help keep what happens on screen at somewhat of an intellectual remove. Thereâ€™s a distinctly Brechtian quality to how the figurines are deployed that initially recalls Todd Haynesâ€™s â€œSuperstar: The Karen Carpenter Story,â€ù a 1980s film in which Barbie dolls are used to narrate the singerâ€™s death, The figurines in â€œThe Missing Pictureâ€ù are more sober and nakedly sincere, more touching and horrifying.

Written by Mr. Panh and Mr. Bataille, it opens with a striking series of images of badly discolored and misshapen strips of celluloid and corroded, dusty film cans. These, too, were victims of Pol Potâ€™s ideologically grim reign, which sought to â€œpurifyâ€ù Cambodia by stripping it of any perceived Western influence and bourgeois taint and by turning the population into revolutionary peasants. Cambodians were divided into â€œold peopleâ€ù (or â€œbase peopleâ€ù), who were from rural areas and often illiterate, and â€œnew people,â€ù who included intellectuals, Buddhist monks, city dwellers and even those who spoke French, the language of the countryâ€™s past colonial master. Wearing eyeglasses could be a death sentence; in his memoir, Mr. Panh recalls how his mother asked his father to throw away his neckties.

â€œBirds are my muses, and I strive to be a true watcher,â€ù he says, referring to people who seek a transcendent connection between human and bird souls. Mr. Kingsley, with his sharp features and penetrating gaze, has a distinctively avian demeanor, and his character reinforces the impression that some people obsessed with winged creatures display birdlike characteristics. Lawrence is no saintly sage.

How do you survive the humiliation and embarrassment of being 15 and desperate to be a grown-up? Through patience and the instinctive realization that youâ€™ve reached an awkward transition and that the worst will soon be behind you.

This gentle comedy, the first feature directed by Rob Meyer, is an eye opener for anyone who takes the everyday natural world for granted. Before the end of this smart, likable coming-of-age movie, the members of a high schoolâ€™s Young Birder Society go on an expedition in search of the Labrador duck, a supposedly extinct species. â€œThatâ€™s the great thing about this field,â€ù Lawrence Konrad (Ben Kingsley), a bird-watching fanatic, declares to a group of adolescent followers in â€œA Birderâ€™s Guide to Everything.â€ù â€œIt doesnâ€™t matter if youâ€™re a high school kid on your bike, or if youâ€™re an egghead like me with a boatload of degrees. Anybody can be a birder.â€ù

Ms. Lee could have delved more deeply into Ms. Boggsâ€™s thoughts, and slips into glib autopilot by using archival footage with sound effects or repeating ideas of personal transformation. But in sharing her subjectâ€™s life achievements, she raises meaningful questions and keeps them profitably open.

Ms. Boggsâ€™s path helps trace the vicissitudes of leftist activism after the 1960s, from a time of violent resistance to a seemingly insular period, when she conducted discussion groups in Maine. Ms. Mock shows the ways the Senate proceedings quickly collapsed amid racial unease after Mr. Thomas declared that his confirmation was imperiled as a result of a â€œhigh-tech lynching.â€ù He was referring to himself and not to Ms. Hill.

In the second half of the film, Ms. Mock takes Ms. Hill away from that famous image of her testifying before a panel of white men and places her in a context of power as she speaks in front of rooms full of women (like the Brooklyn-based group Girls for Gender Equity). By showing this evolution, Ms. Mock demonstrates that harassment holds its power mainly in isolation.

With the new documentary â€œAnita,â€ù the Oscar-winning director Freida Mock (â€œMaya Lin: A Strong Clear Visionâ€ù) brings a fresh perspective to a somber and awkward chapter of modern American politics: the Senate hearings to confirm Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court amid accusations of sexual harassment by Anita Hill.

â€œAnitaâ€ù is an important historical document about an event that prompted a larger cultural conversation about sexual harassment. But, perhaps more important, it conveys Ms. Hillâ€™s journey from an accuser alone to an activist who shares with, and listens to, others. (She is now 57 and a professor at Brandeis University.)

â€œPeople think, when they think of those hearings, â€˜He had a race, and she had a gender,â€™Â â€ù Ms. Hill tells a group at Spelman College in the film. She then laughs uneasily at the absurdity before continuing: â€œBut it was really the combination. And it changed the dynamics.â€ù
â€œSexual harassment is just part of a larger problem of gender inequality,â€ù she says. â€œAnd I didnâ€™t realize that until I started hearing from people.â€ù

In the first half of this marvelously structured film, Ms. Mock deftly segues from the hearings to present-day interviews with people who were in that room in 1991, including Ms. Hill, her lawyer and her friends. (Among those interviewed are Jill Abramson, the executive editor of The New York Times, who covered the trial for The Wall Street Journal and wrote, with Jane Mayer, the 1994 book â€œStrange Justice: The Selling of Clarence Thomas.â€ù)

Our pusillanimous centerpiece is Samantha (an overacting Julianne Michelle), who has returned to her small-town home to investigate the death of her mother 14 years earlier. Still, Mr. Canetâ€™s greater focus on the female characters forces you to realize the extent to which the modern gangster movie is a primal macho bonding ritual in which the pain of servile women kowtowing to foulmouthed outlaws is collateral damage.

Hollywood gangster movies, especially those directed by Martin Scorsese and Francis Ford Coppola, have conditioned us to expect every film in the genre to follow particular guidelines or risk feeling inauthentic. If itâ€™s unfair to expect a reputable European director to follow that template, so be it. But by now, those expectations have been programmed into us. Most of the characters are Italian-American, although their ethnicity is barely noted, except for Frank, whose married African-American girlfriend, Vanessa (Zoe Saldana), accuses him of being ashamed of her because she is black. Vanessaâ€™s husband, Scarfo (Matthias Schoenaerts, providing the movieâ€™s scariest performance), is jailed after Frank arrests him on a weapons charge.

â€œBlood Tiesâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violence, strong language, some sexual content and drug taking.

Trying to go straight, Chris takes a job at a local garage while unsuccessfully working to resuscitate his relationship with his bitter, drug-addicted ex-wife, Monica (Marion Cotillard), who turned to prostitution to support their two children while he was in prison. So Chris initiates a relationship with Natalie (Mila Kunis), a clerk from the garage, and eventually proposes to her. After quitting the dead-end garage job, he tries to start a snack stand in Prospect Park with a friend. But his prison record gets in the way.

â€œBlood Ties,â€ù a remake of the 2008 French film â€œLes Liens du Sangâ€ù (â€œRivalsâ€ù), directed by Jacques Maillot, is set in Brooklyn in 1974. McCanick (David Morse) learns as the story opens that Simon (Mr. Monteith), a reedy street hustler whom he put in prison some years earlier under dubious circumstances, has been released. Josh C. Waller, the director, and Daniel Noah, the screenwriter, give us skimpy flashbacks showing the connection between the two, but theyâ€™re too thinly developed to be intriguing. Itâ€™s all rendered in cop movie clichÃ©s: the shootout in the stairway, the chase that ends with a subway door closing just in time, and so on. The big revelation, when it finally comes, isnâ€™t so big and leads to a denouement that doesnâ€™t make much sense.

The full title of the new documentary by Maria Iliou, â€œFrom Both Sides of the Aegean: Expulsion and Exchange of Populations, Turkey-Greece: 1922-1924,â€ù is quite a mouthful. The film focuses on ethnic cleansing in the Ottoman Empire, beginning in the 19th century, specifically resulting in a compulsory â€œexchange of populationsâ€ù in the mid-1920s, in which Greek Orthodox Christians were forced out of Turkey and Muslims from Greece. â€œDivergentâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). The old dystopian woes and violence.

You have to take his word for it. Itâ€™s hard not to root for Ms. Woodley, who has been coming on strong in recent indie titles like â€œThe Descendantsâ€ù and â€œThe Spectacular Now,â€ù but she seems palpably uncomfortable here. Thereâ€™s a tentative, awkward quality to her physical performance that at times registers as a lack of confidence and that, as the story progresses, is badly at odds with her characterâ€™s intensifying ferocity. That hardly seems like Ms. Woodleyâ€™s fault, given that sheâ€™s ill-served by the production on so many levels, from the fight choreography to the dialogue and those eyelashes. But itâ€™s finally galling because women will never break out of the representational ghetto theyâ€™ve been relegated to if you watch a movie like this one and think that the heroine, metaphorically and otherwise, throws like a girl.

To do so, though, theyâ€™re going to need directors who can handle the demands of an industrial production like this and a script that obscures rather than emphasizes the weakness of the source material. A good action choreographer will be crucial, as will decent hair and makeup.
Women warriors are on the rise again in American movies, and so, too, are hopes that theyâ€™ll be able to strike where it counts: in the industryâ€™s executive suites.

That the length of Shailene Woodleyâ€™s eyelashes changes throughout â€œDivergentâ€ù may have been amusingly distracting for a while (maybe theyâ€™re mood lashes, a friend quipped), but such shoddiness also underscores the contempt that movie companies have for the medium and the audience.

So, yea for â€œDivergent,â€ù a dumb movie that I hope makes major bank if only as a reminder of the obvious: Women can drive big and little movies, including the pricey franchises that fire up the box office and the culture.

There is a crucial difference: While Katniss Everdeen doesnâ€™t make much room for romance in â€œThe Hunger Gamesâ€ù (she has a revolution to lead), Tris Prior spends a whole lot of time wondering why her instructor pays attention to her. Heâ€™s a guy, as if you didnâ€™t know, because while â€œDivergentâ€ù celebrates individuality and breaking out of the little boxes that its authoritarian leaders (i.e., adults) insist on putting teenagers in, the story sticks to the familiar gendered template. Girl warrior meets boy warrior and, in between punches, kicks and bullets, they hold hands. One of the few real surprises in the â€œDivergentâ€ù novel is that itâ€™s nearly as chaste as the â€œTwilightâ€ù series, although Ms. Woodley and her romantic foil, Four (Theo James), do open wide during several kisses.

Veronica Roth, who wrote the book â€œDivergentâ€ù and its two hot-selling follow-ups, tends to avoid mentioning â€œThe Hunger Games,â€ù but the similarities between these young-adult juggernauts are conspicuous in the extreme. â€œThe Hunger Gamesâ€ù is a dystopian tale set in a postwar North America divided into 13 districts; â€œDivergentâ€ù is a dystopian tale set in postwar Chicago divided into five factions. Each series pivots on a gutsy teenage heroine who fights to the death like a classic male hero. Each year, the young characters in the books undergo a weird ritual: In â€œThe Hunger Games,â€ù wee ones are sent into mortal combat; the initiation ritual in â€œDivergent,â€ù much like the book itself, is rather more anticlimactic, because teenagers just choose which faction to grow old in.

The story, adapted by Evan Daugherty and Vanessa Taylor, opens with Tris living with her family in Abnegation, a faction whose inhabitants have embraced selflessness to the point of pride and who wear drab, flowing clothes that suggest that Eileen Fisher managed to survive Armageddon. Tris, however, yearns to run wild with Dauntless, a faction that puts a premium on courage, fearlessness, piercings, tattoos and hair gel. Each faction â€” the others are Amity, Candor and Erudite â€” lives according to restricted values in order to keep the peace and considers an outlier like Tris, called Divergent, as a threat. It doesnâ€™t make any sense, but Ms. Rothâ€™s prose style is good enough and Tris appealing enough that, at least in the book, itâ€™s easy to breeze past the plot holes.

Itâ€™s harder to ignore those flaws in the movie, partly because the director, Neil Burger (â€œLimitlessâ€ù), gives you little to hang onto â€” beauty, thrills, a visual style. The script, or whatâ€™s left of it, doesnâ€™t help, because someone (itâ€™s impossible to know who merits most of the blame in a big enterprise like this) has made the familiar blunder of thinking that the most important thing in adapting a book to the screen is the stuff that happens rather than to whom it happens. That the Dauntless inhabitants like to jump on and off moving trains or clamber up buildings like monkeys isnâ€™t interesting or novel. What matters is how thrillingly free and alive Tris feels when she hurtles across an abyss or zip-lines over the ruined city. â€œFear doesnâ€™t shut you down,â€ù Four tells Tris, â€œit wakes you up.â€ù

They make a fine duo. Theyâ€™re easy on the eyes, for one, and Ms. Woodley has a gift for conveying a sense of genuine, deep-tissue sincerity, while Mr. James, whose slashing cheekbones look as if they could do some serious damage, is good at keeping a straight face. (Heâ€™s had practice: Until now, he was best known for croaking in Lady Maryâ€™s bed in â€œDownton Abbey.â€ù) The characters trade many moony looks as well as spit, but their cute, farcically overdetermined match â€” he thrusts with penetrating stares, while she parries by retreating and looking at her feet or a wall â€” grows wearisome when it becomes clear that thereâ€™s not much else going on. Lots of things happen, of course, as per the dystopian rule book, but for all the jumping and scaling of heights, the movie remains grounded.
Some of this faith can be traced, irrationally or exuberantly, to â€œThe Hunger Games.â€ù

Its second installment, â€œCatching Fire,â€ù wasnâ€™t only the highest grossing movie of 2013, it also pulled in a lot of guys, and not just, you know, women, that 52 percent of North American moviegoers who are deemed a limited demographic, a niche and a seemingly unsolvable problem. You may complain that â€œJust a Sighâ€ù is too episodic to cohere and that Alixâ€™s eccentricities are plot mechanisms. But to me, this fateful day-in-the-life feels believable.
