â€œJust a Sigh,â€ù the fifth feature directed by JÃ©rÃ´me Bonnell (â€œThe Queen of Clubsâ€ù), suggests a contemporary Gallic â€œBrief Encounter.â€ù The movie is beautifully acted, and the chemistry between Ms. Devos, who is 49 (her character is 43), and Mr. Byrne, 63, is heated in a sadder-but-wiser, grown-up way. Ms. Devos, a mainstay of French cinema, suggests a younger Catherine Deneuve, with her lustrous hair framing a face that expresses determination and dignified willfulness.

Douglas, with his mixture of fragility and toughness and his sad blue eyes on the verge of tearing up, is almost identical to Dr. Paul Weston, the psychotherapist Mr. Byrne played for three seasons on the brilliant, sorely missed HBO series â€œIn Treatment.â€ù Douglas, a British professor of literature with several children who he says resent him, exudes the embattled defeat of someone who knows too much about human weakness but still holds out hope for love. In his sex scenes with Alix, he expresses a complicated mixture of tenderness, vulnerability and wariness. When he gently accuses her of stalking him, she replies: â€œI didnâ€™t follow you. I went and found you; itâ€™s very different.â€ù

Trippy sensibility or no, Mr. Jodorowsky was an early convert to the genius of the Swiss surrealist H. R. Giger and the French graphic artist Jean Giraud, known as Moebius, whose extensive designs and storyboards â€” some gently animated here by Syd Garon â€” are a revelation. And when we see the DNA of those illustrations metastasize (like their creators) to blockbusters like the â€œAlienâ€ù franchise and â€œThe Fifth Element,â€ù the sequence evokes a surprising degree of what-might-have-been nostalgia.

Seeing no need to read Mr. Herbertâ€™s novel before assembling his dream team, he tempted the writer Dan Oâ€™Bannon (who died in 2009) with â€œspecial marijuanaâ€ù and seduced Salvador DalÃ_ into accepting a role by promising one to the artistâ€™s muse, Amanda Lear (still fit and fabulous and of indeterminate age).

A making-of special about a film that was never made, â€œJodorowskyâ€™s Duneâ€ù details the mid-1970s efforts of the Chilean director Alejandro Jodorowsky to translate Frank Herbertâ€™s extravagant science fiction novel â€œDuneâ€ù to the big screen.

â€œBigâ€ù being the operative word. â€œFor me, â€˜Duneâ€™ will be the coming of a god,â€ù recalls Mr. Jodorowsky, the very picture of a man who doesnâ€™t easily adopt the mantle of failed midwife. Capitalizing on his subjectâ€™s mobile face, authoritative voice and glorious ego, Frank Pavich directs by ceding the stage to their owner, a handsome devil of 85 who remains convinced of the would-have-been magnificence of his forcibly abandoned project.
â€œI was raping Frank Herbert, you know, raping, like this,â€ù Mr. Jodorowsky says, gesticulating. â€œBut with love, with love.â€ù I canâ€™t be the only one who would have paid to see that.

Cheerfully partial and unapologetically deferential to its subjectâ€™s operatic self-promotion, â€œJodorowskyâ€™s Duneâ€ù makes you wish that he had scraped together the final $5 million needed, we are told, to realize his dream. The director Nicolas Winding Refn suggests that Hollywood was scared of Jodo, as Mr. Jodorowsky is known to his friends, but the instigator of this whole shebang is unrepentant.
â€œJodorowskyâ€™s Duneâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Drugs are mentioned, and a gargantuan ego is exposed.

Yet one of this filmâ€™s many delights is its surprising lack of bitterness. (Perhaps because Mr. Jodorowsky, when he finally got around to seeing David Lynchâ€™s 1984 adaptation, was relieved to pronounce it â€œawful.â€ù) Widely credited with creating the original midnight movie in the bizarre â€œEl Topoâ€ù (1971), heâ€™s a natural raconteur who may liken himself to a prophet but is no slouch at identifying offbeat talent.

â€œYou canâ€™t have a masterpiece without madness,â€ù the producer Michel Seydoux â€” one among many like-minded interviewees â€” declares, an opinion supported by a surreal tour of Mr. Jodorowskyâ€™s back catalog. Thereâ€™s nothing loony, however, about recognizing the box office wisdom of roping in Orson Welles, Mick Jagger and Pink Floyd, especially if one of your stated goals is to produce the cinematic equivalent of a hit of LSD.

That running gag is among the funniest things in this film, which makes you wonder about the movieâ€™s target audience. Itâ€™s a grown-up joke, and there are many others lurking in the rather complicated globe-hopping plot. Adults will find more to amuse them than was offered in â€œThe Muppets,â€ù but younger children might be left behind.

Besides Mr. Gervais, the film features Ty Burrell, of â€œModern Family,â€ù as an Interpol agent (and the focal point of most of those Europe-bashing jokes) and Tina Fey as a gulag guard. Ms. Feyâ€™s talents are wasted, since she is chained to a stereotypical Russian character and accent, and she doesnâ€™t seem to be enjoying herself nearly as much as an A-list star in a Muppet movie ought to.
â€œMuppets Most Wantedâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for some mild cartoon violence.

The film, a music-filled follow-up to the 2011 hit â€œThe Muppets,â€ù lands poor Kermit in a gulag in Siberia, which is depicted just as unflatteringly as gulags in Siberia always are. Vladimir V. Putin is unlikely to be amused. But the real concern, in terms of Americaâ€™s international relations, is its sly skewering of our European allies, whose work habits, vacation-taking and such are mocked relentlessly.

In the story, the gang, drunk on the success of the 2011 movie, signs on for a world tour with a shifty promoter named Dominic Badguy (Ricky Gervais). Dominic is in cahoots with Constantine, a criminal frog who bears a striking resemblance to Kermit. The two work a mistaken-identity trick that lands Kermit in the gulag and allows Constantine to take his place on the Muppet world tour. The Muppet stage shows in various European cities become a tool in a complex scheme by Dominic and Constantine to steal the crown jewels in Britain.

The whole film seems to have a vague heaviness to it. The best Muppet movies have been great because they had charm. Thereâ€™s no charm here, really; just self-referential jokes, decent but not memorable songs, and lots and lots of cameos (again, for the adults; not many children are going to be impressed by the presence of Stanley Tucci or Frank Langella).

The United States government today called on Walt Disney Pictures to delay or cancel the release of â€œMuppets Most Wantedâ€ù on national security grounds. Or at least, it should have. Not only might this movie annoy Russia, with whom the American government is already nose-to-nose over Crimea, but it could also cause any European allies being courted by President Obama to unfriend him and the rest of the country.

It all adds up to an eventful entry in the Muppet film library but not a classic one. There is, however, one noteworthy moment: In a fantasy sequence, we get a glimpse of what babies made by Kermit and Miss Piggy might look like, something explored only rarely in the past. The movieâ€™s elaborate plot might not be the only thing parents find themselves explaining to youngsters after the ending credits.

Mr. LaBeouf shows up fairly early as JerÃ´me, anxiously working a sleazy mien and an unconvincing British accent as Joeâ€™s first conquest. As she explains to Seligman, she chose JerÃ´me to relieve her of her virginity. He does so with comic briskness in a scene that almost makes you feel sorry for Mr. LaBeouf, and this pity may be the point. Mr. von Trier is a brilliant, unorthodox director of actors who plays with performance the way other filmmakers play with light. The acting in his work is often unpredictable, almost fluid, and can change moment to moment, scene to scene, creating rippling shifts in the air. One minute, his actors are dragging you deep into the story with raw emotion; the next, theyâ€™re pushing you out of the movie with brittle, self-conscious artificiality.

Attentive filmgoers who stuck it through Lars von Trierâ€™s 2009 movie â€œAntichristâ€ù â€” a deranged heave with a dead child, talking fox (â€œchaos reignsâ€ù) and his-and-her mangled genitalia â€” might have noticed a strange closing credit for â€œresearcher on misogyny.â€ù It seemed like a joke, especially given that the movie pivots on a crazy woman (Charlotte Gainsbourg) who, consumed by grief, and having made the extremely bad call to undergo treatment by her therapist husband, mutilates them both. Yet several other credits, including researchers on â€œanxiety,â€ù â€œtheologyâ€ù and â€œmythology and evil,â€ù suggested that Mr. von Trier wasnâ€™t kidding even if, oh, maybe he was.

Thatâ€™s true of Joe (Ms. Gainsbourg, affectless and affecting), who enters â€œVolume Iâ€ù bloodied and supine in an alley. Sheâ€™s a mess, a spectacle as well as a question mark, and she has a story to tell, although one, as the title indicates, that wonâ€™t be completed here. (â€œVolume IIâ€ù is available on video on demand and opens in theaters on April 4.) Because Joeâ€™s story has been divided, this isnâ€™t a review of the second part (weâ€™ll take it on when it opens), but I will say that the separation feels like a mistake. If Mr. von Trier is going to ask viewers to watch a movie with explicit sex, if one in which the lower half of pornographic actorsâ€™ bodies has been digitally fused with the top half of the movieâ€™s stars, then he should really bring it all on. Cinematic interruptus is a drag.

The clock turns back soon after the movie opens, and a stranger, Seligman (Stellan Skarsgard), guides Joe out of the alley and to his modest apartment, where he tends to her. There, cozily tucked under some covers, she begins relating her story from childhood to an early sexual encounter (enter Shia LaBeouf) and the first stirrings of her self-described nymphomania. Soon, in between pit stops in the present, the story jumps, and sheâ€™s a young woman (Stacy Martin) seducing men for sport alongside a girlfriend, B (Sophie Kennedy Clark). (A model turned actress with a whippetlike figure, Ms. Martin could easily pass for a teenager, which may be a reason she was cast.) A rapt, serious listener, Seligman likes to relate Joeâ€™s exploits to fly fishing. A nymph, among other definitions, is the immature form of some insects.

Then â€œNymphomaniac: Volume Iâ€ù bluntly ends, and the credits roll next with some teasing clips from â€œVolume IIâ€ù that imply Joeâ€™s tale is about to turn ugly or silly, both being possible with Mr. von Trier. His is a cinema of shocks, characterized by sometimes elegant and abrupt changes in mood and tone, and violently deployed gags, sharp narrative turns, indelible beauty â€” here, Iâ€™m thinking of any given shot in â€œMelancholiaâ€ù â€” and more ordinary jolts, like the shot of coitus that helps set â€œAntichristâ€ù on its outlandish way. Viewer mileage will vary with that image, but, as with this demi-movie, youâ€™re unlikely to turn away. The problem with aesthetic shocks is that their power can drain off and their original effects become harder to replicate, so weâ€™ll just have to see what happens next.

Mr. von Trierâ€™s use of actors like Mr. LaBeouf, best known for Michael Bayâ€™s â€œTransformersâ€ù franchise, and Christian Slater, who delivers a lovely performance as Joeâ€™s (unnamed) father, may appear like stunt casting. And certainly, there may be some commercial considerations involved, too. Yet the sincere emotion that Mr. Slater brings to his role is as crucial to the mix as Kiefer Sutherlandâ€™s turn was in â€œMelancholia.â€ù And the viscerally uneasy Mr. LaBeouf and his baggage make him a perfect, almost inevitable fit for JerÃ´me, an unlikely seducer who serves as a suggestively meaningful counterpoint to Joeâ€™s father. Later, Joe will reunite with JerÃ´me; her father will fall ill; she will take numerous lovers and be condemned by an enraged wife, Mrs. H (a sensational Uma Thurman).

Given his talent for provocation, for tweaking critics and blurting out idiocies â€” including his unpersuasive assertion that he was a Nazi, during a news conference at the 2011 Cannes Film Festival â€” it would be easy to dismiss his latest, â€œNymphomaniac: Volume I,â€ù sight unseen. The title is preposterous, a huckster gimmick; it may also be a dig at those who, I think wrongly, label him a misogynist because of the abuse he rains down on his female characters. Itâ€™s a charge thatâ€™s dogged him since â€œBreaking the Waves,â€ù his sometimes brutal, sometimes sublime 1996 film about a woman who endures a crucible of suffering (her paralyzed husband asks her to have sex with other men) before dying. Women suffer in Mr. von Trierâ€™s films, yet they also dominate, shape and haunt his work.

Rounding up a familiar chorus of ugly-mug contest contenders, Mr. De Felitta stages a series of stickups that, while undeniably entertaining, never feel remotely perilous. Armed with an Uzi that Rosie has to load for him (â€œYouâ€™re better with mechanics than me!â€ù), Tommy divests doughy mobsters of their wallets and jewelry, nervously spraying bullets from a weapon he canâ€™t control. Initially amused, then irritated, his well-connected victims soon lose patience, especially when a critical list of names becomes part of Tommyâ€™s haul.

Like the crazy-in-love couples of â€œSid and Nancyâ€ù (1986) and â€œTrue Romanceâ€ù (1993), Tommy and Rosie Uva (Michael Pitt and Nina Arianda) are blessed with more bravado than brains. Incompetent small-time crooks and enthusiastic drug users â€” when we meet them, theyâ€™re botching a robbery that will land Tommy behind bars for 18 months â€” the pair eventually find work at a debt-collection agency. Rosie is into it, embracing the straight and narrow with the newfound energy of the reformed addict.

Bright and fleet, â€œRob the Mobâ€ù is a firm step up from the undiluted corn of Mr. De Felittaâ€™s 2010 feature, â€œCity Island.â€ù This time he has delegated the script to Jonathan Fernandez, who writes tight scenes that donâ€™t peter out and dialogue that gives Tommy and Rosieâ€™s dumb-and-dumber partnership a chipper charm. Vividly painting Queens in the early 1990s as a landscape of crack and graffiti, the filmmakers go on to smother any menace with a swoony-upbeat soundtrack and an â€œoh, those kooky kidsâ€ù tone.

Fighting this, the wonderful Cathy Moriarty, in a painfully brief cameo as Tommyâ€™s mother, is so wounded that she almost cracks the filmâ€™s veneer of indifference â€” a pose embodied by Andy Garcia as a wearily aristocratic don who would rather cook than kill. Tutoring a young family member and raving about his rice balls, his character comes dangerously close to glorifying the goombah lifestyle: Thereâ€™s no hint of the vile beneath the veal parmigiana. Similarly, thereâ€™s nothing of the tabloid vulture in Ray Romanoâ€™s kindly news reporter, although itâ€™s nice to see him continue an impressive career reinvention â€” currently rocking a strong recurring role in the popular NBC soap â€œParenthoodâ€ù â€” as a dramatic actor.
â€œRob the Mobâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Foul language, mishandled weapons and world-class idiocy.

Tommy, however, is fed up, chafing at their lack of cash and anxious to make a score. So when he begins visiting the trial of the crime boss John Gotti and hears a mobster testify that Mafia social clubs have a strict no-guns policy, he decides that robbing these wiseguy hangouts will be a breeze.
Real-life tragedy receives a comic-caper makeover in â€œRob the Mob,â€ù Raymond De Felittaâ€™s breezy retelling of one of New York Cityâ€™s more unusual crime sprees.

The movieâ€™s biggest problem, though, is a central couple whose backgrounds are so vague that itâ€™s difficult to care what happens to them. Despite this, Mr. Pitt is a credible lunkhead, and Ms. Arianda is a delight, dressing Rosieâ€™s filthy mouth in the sweetest of smiles. If you were Tommy, youâ€™d want to give her everything, too.

The young woman, Abby (Taylor Schilling of â€œOrange Is the New Blackâ€ù), has been living in an out-of-the-way cottage with Dermot (Aidan Quinn), a mildly rugged exile from academia who is nicknamed â€œthe Professor.â€ù When a pregnancy test comes up positive, she seeks refuge with her father back home in Montreal, where she worries about becoming like her mother. Back in Ireland, the story toggles diligently among Dermot and thematically relevant characters: a nosy teenager searching for purpose and a single neighbor who gives birth at her motherâ€™s wake.

An expatriate in rural Ireland gets restless in her relationship with an older man and questions her commitment in the light drama â€œStay.â€ù Because of the lukewarm scenarios and signpost-filled screenwriting, audiences may well follow suit with their own antsiness.

The movie, admirably shot on location, has a cast that is nonetheless directed without much verve by Wiebke von Carolsfeld. The film was adapted from a novel by Aislinn Hunter, but the charactersâ€™ inner lives remain elusive. Perhaps a sharper focus on Ms. Schilling, who almost seems more expressive in solitude, might have yielded greater depth to the storyâ€™s secrets of the heart.

Fires burn, simmer and die, only to rekindle, in â€œThe French Minister,â€ù a comedy of manners and errors. Itâ€™s based on â€œQuai dâ€™Orsay,â€ù a graphic novel that takes its title from the colloquial name for the French Foreign Ministry and its 19th-century wedding cake building. (The rather more blunt title of the bookâ€™s English-language version, â€œWeapons of Mass Diplomacy,â€ù openly telegraphs its comic doings.) Illustrated by Christophe Blain, whose sharp caricatures and comic-book flourishes have been nicely translated to the screen, â€œQuai dâ€™Orsayâ€ù was written by Abel Lanzac, a pseudonym for Antonin Baudry, a diplomat who based it on his experiences working for Dominique de Villepin, the foreign minister during the lead-up to the war in Iraq.

Mr. Tavernierâ€™s filmmaking here is loose, almost casual, and you may not always notice what heâ€™s doing with the camera as he frames the ministryâ€™s choreographed chaos with its whirling people and parts. Itâ€™s telling, though, that when Arthur first comes to the ministry for his job interview, haplessly dressed down in beige pants and muddied shoes, heâ€™s led through the buildingâ€™s long, gleaming halls by an aide formally dressed in black tails, like an emissary from a past as disdained as it is fetishized. After he finally reaches the ministerâ€™s enormous chambers, Mr. Tavernier pulls the camera back to show Arthur slumped in a chair. Dwarfed by the vaulted ceilings and luxuriously appointed walls, he looks very small in a room and a world that are as empty as they are pompous.

The names of real people and countries were changed for the book, and Mr. Tavernier, who shares the screenwriting credit with Mr. Baudry and Mr. Blain, has done some additional tweaking. What remains are the general themes, the fighting and squabbling, the gassy proclamations and the slamming doors, as well as the dizzying, unsurprising observation that citadels of power are in the hands of the mad, the craven and the stupid, or maybe just the weary and cynical. Soon after Arthur meets some of his colleagues, including Alexandreâ€™s main fixer, the leonine Claude Maupas (the great Niels Arestrup, commanding his every scene), another worker advises the newbie: â€œIf anybody mentions NATO, say: NATO, No Action Talk Only. Insider speak. Or NATO-rious, for useless. Itâ€™s a running gag.â€ù

Embodied chaos, Alexandre is the hub of â€œThe French Ministerâ€ù and the world he inhabits. Played with sharply clipped gestures and precise comic timing by Thierry Lhermitte, whose torqued physicality here has an almost extracinematic quality â€” he seems to be sending waves of energy off the screen â€” Alexandre is a man of many words, some strange, others confusing, many borrowed. When he summons Arthur Vlaminck (RaphaÃ«l Personnaz), a graduate of the vaguely Kafka-sounding National School of Administration (a real institution), Alexandre soon seems to be swooping in for the kill. In truth, heâ€™s offering Arthur a job. â€œOurs is a tiny ship,â€ù Alexander declares â€” he isnâ€™t one for simply saying: He proclaims, declaims and vows. â€œNot a ship, even. More a dingy, a canoe.â€ù

Whoosh. When the title character slams a door in Bertrand Tavernierâ€™s dry, sly comedy â€œThe French Minister,â€ù the walls shudder, and papers and people go flying. A man on the furious move, Alexandre Taillard de Worms isnâ€™t only the French minister of foreign affairs, with a name thatâ€™s a meaningful mouthful, but heâ€™s also a force of nature or maybe of bureaucracy. Sleek, coifed and buffed, with tailored suits and brilliantly shined shoes, he looks like one of the more sober masters of the universe, even if his violent gestures and the wreckage he leaves in his wake make him a closer kin to that old cartoon menace, the Tasmanian Devil, than to one of the boldface names running La France.

Itâ€™s actually more of a raft, Alexandre continues, but thereâ€™s room for Arthur, whoâ€™s hired to be in charge of â€œwords.â€ù Although Arthur is initially bewildered by the exact parameters of his new position, he has been engaged to write and rewrite Alexandreâ€™s speeches. This proves no easy task, because Alexandre emits large, near-impenetrable clouds of clichÃ©s, bulging masses of politician-speak that can build into disquieting Orwellian fogs and that serve as both a weapon and protective shield. Itâ€™s hard to make sense of Alexandre, an enigma given to quoting Heraclitus, who had a line that fits the movie nicely: â€œThis world order, the same of all, no god nor man did create, but it ever was and is and will be: ever-living fire, kindling in measures and being quenched in measures.â€ù

The fearless streak displayed by the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble deserves its equivalent in a bolder movie technique. But Mr. Atlas delivers a rousing finale with a shiver-inducing studio session involving father and sons thatâ€™s at once a glimpse at deeply felt family dynamics and a moving bridge across generations.

Probably the biggest influence on the group in â€œBrothers Hypnoticâ€ù comes from very close to home. In Reuben Atlasâ€™s relaxed documentary about the Hypnotic Brass Ensemble, the bandâ€™s proudly independent musicians still grapple with the ideals of the Chicago trumpeter Kelan Phil Cohran, father to seven of the groupâ€™s eight members, their teacher in their formative years and an advocate of black consciousness for alternatives to the establishment.

One telling juxtaposition encapsulates the bandâ€™s evolving identity: A police officer scolds the musicians about performing in the street and says that he could seize their instruments, and in the next shot, the ensemble is loosening up for a gig at Jazz at Lincoln Center with Mos Def.

Yet the playersâ€™ upbringing â€” which involved early-morning lessons with â€œPops,â€ù and the presence of two of the three mothers with whom he had children â€” exerts a fascination. So does their organic flow as a brotherly ensemble, whether performing or not, though itâ€™s a tough challenge to individuate all the members (who were in their 20s and 30s during filming).

The style of the documentary falls into some commonplace rhythms: the bandâ€™s concerns about keeping it real, spotlighted brushes with stardom and the kind of visual filler that might round out any tour chronicle. These dull the impact of some moving introspective interludes and well-observed moments.

Mr. Atlas tracks the ensemble as it performs on New York streets, and selects gigs and recording engagements in an industry the membersâ€™ father, now in his 80s, often scorned. The groupâ€™s fusion of funk, jazz and hip-hop is a propulsive pleasure, and â€” as is the case with many music documentaries â€” we could do with seeing and hearing even more of it.

â€œSabotageâ€ù isnâ€™t any good, even if its jagged, jolting visual excesses and frenzied energy keep you awake, gasping and guffawing by turns. It does have one genuine surprise: the dependably watchable Olivia Williams, who shows up as Caroline, a detective who wears suits and no visible makeup and holds her ground amid the carnage and chaos as the movieâ€™s only believably human being. In this respect, she evokes those heroines called Final Girls in many horror flicks, the ones that screened in the old Times Square, where films would be turned into a communal experience thatâ€™s difficult to replicate with video on demand. This is a movie that demands audience participation, shared cries of derision, bursts of laughter and warnings shouted out to the characters, like, â€œGet out now!â€ù

Itâ€™s doubtful that the director, David Ayer (â€œEnd of Watchâ€ù), who shares script credit with Skip Woods, intentionally embraced self-parody, but it certainly sneaked up on him. The narrative pieces he and Mr. Woods toss out â€” a dead wife, stolen loot, a D.E.A. investigation, a drug cartel â€” are hackneyed in the extreme. More memorable and strange is how Mr. Ayer lingers over the movieâ€™s near-vivisectionist moments. In one nocturnal sequence after a train wreck (he likes shooting in the murk), Breacher wanders about, looking at a body thatâ€™s been reduced to bloody chunks. Later, he finds an eviscerated corpse pinned to a ceiling, its guts dangling like sausages in a butcher shop window. These images have an undeniable bluntness, but then so does a poke in the eye.

He enters looking down, heavy head bowed, which proves a foreshadowing of the bummer times to come. Shrouded in muddy darkness, his character, John Wharton, known as Breacher (the name evokes Jack Reacher, Lee Childâ€™s best-selling macho man), is watching a snuff video in which a woman is being tortured to death; this feels like some kind of warning to the audience. Breacher is big and heâ€™s bad, although he may be good. It hardly matters, and neither does the story, which turns on the slam-bam exploits of Breacherâ€™s crew, which calls itself a family (so did Charles Mansonâ€™s brood) and is being picked off, one by one, with flamboyant goriness for a kind of Agatha Christie meets Eli Roth mash-up.
â€œSabotageâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Guts but no glory.

Lovers of camp and cannabis are the most plausible audience for â€œSabotage,â€ù given the giggle-to-bullet ratio in this extravagantly silly movie about a gang of marauding Drug Enforcement Administration undercover thugs. Scholars of Arnold Schwarzenegger, its big-ticket attraction, may also want to check in, just to see what the governator has been up to in his postpolitical golden years. Let me spare you the change and the suspense: He can still bench-press serious weight, as a narratively superfluous visit to a gym makes clear, and heâ€™s still not an actor, as is evident by the confusingly indistinguishable grimaces, smiles and vacant looks that heâ€™s put into rotation here.

The story gets going with noses nestled deep in bosoms and drifts of cocaine and quickly morphs into a visual free-for-all with bodies and bullets flying amid so much yowling that itâ€™s a surprise that Joe Manganiello, who plays an upstanding wolf-dude on the HBO show â€œTrue Blood,â€ù doesnâ€™t sprout fur and fangs here. He plays one of Breacherâ€™s minions, alongside some other fine B-listers â€” Mireille Enos, Sam Worthington, Josh Holloway and Terrence Howard â€” who all should have a heart-to-heart with their representation. The paychecks might have been nice, and Ms. Enos, for one, might have dug playing a crazy mama with a machine gun. These are amusingly hyperbolic performances until, like the rest of this movie, they grow tedious and dispiriting. Slumming is a risky career move.

The warning notes in the tense marital drama â€œBreathe Inâ€ù are sounded during a casual conversation at a suburban outdoor gathering whose hostess breezily remarks that she has been to six divorce parties in the past few months.

What distinguishes â€œBreathe Inâ€ù from countless similar movies about marital discontent and disruption is the restraint with which the story is handled, the subtlety of its performances and its almost perverse refusal to turn into a prurient, heavy-breathing examination of adultery and its consequences. It offers few vicarious thrills. The would-be lovers in â€œBreathe Inâ€ù exchange longing glances but no ravenous kisses.

The moment Sophie sets her eyes on Keith, she makes awkward small talk while gazing at him with a fixed intensity, her lips slightly parted, as she patiently waits for him to notice her. She may not fit the clichÃ© of an aggressive temptress, but her earnest, unsmiling presence is unsettling. Keith begins paying attention after coaxing her into playing the piano at one of his classes, where she astonishes with a fiery performance of a Chopin piece. Even then, his interest is more academic than amorous. Eventually, the jittery, self-centered Keith, aware of their 30-year age difference, begins sneaking piercing sidelong glances at Sophie.

Barely taking note is Megan (Amy Ryan), a chatty middle-aged homemaker whose principal hobby is collecting cookie jars. Her dour husband, Keith (Guy Pearce), is a cellist, a high school music teacher and an alumnus of a New York rock band. They have a high-strung daughter, Lauren (Mackenzie Davis), a champion swimmer soon to leave home for college. Also at the party is their houseguest, Sophie (Felicity Jones), a beautiful, poised 18-year-old exchange student and piano prodigy from England, staying with them for a semester. The movie offers so little information about her background that she remains a mystery.

Megan and Keith, who live 90 minutes from New York, used to be city dwellers but were driven out by high real estate prices. Keith occasionally subs as a cellist in a metropolitan orchestra and dreams of winning a chair with the ensemble and returning to the city, but Megan balks at the idea.
â€œBreathe Inâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for some strong language.

â€œBreathe Inâ€ù reunites Ms. Jones with the director Drake Doremus and his co-screenwriter, Ben York Jones; their film â€œLike Crazyâ€ù was a small prestige hit in 2011. Their new movie is a partly successful attempt to infuse depth to a story so familiar that it almost doesnâ€™t bear repeating: A comfortably lived-in marriage in which the husband is quietly suffering through a midlife crisis is threatened by a glamorous interloper who stirs up his deepest longings.

â€œBreathe Inâ€ù is a good enough movie that you wish the screenplay had further fleshed out its characters and relationships and emerged as more than a skillful sketch. A superior score by Dustin Oâ€™Halloran bridges the gap between classical and standard film music to sustain a mood of anxious longing.

From the beginning, Sophie and Lauren have a wary, competitive relationship. It flares into hostility when Laurenâ€™s handsome, arrogant ex-boyfriend, Aaron (Matthew Daddario), puts the moves on Sophie. Luring her to a nightclub under the pretense that they are meeting friends, he pounces on her when they return, and she narrowly escapes being raped.

The film, which he directed with Charlie Siskel, is absorbing, touching and satisfyingly enjoyable because Maier was a fascinating, poignant and somewhat enigmatic woman. As the title suggests, the filmmakers take up Mr. Maloofâ€™s search for his mystery woman (complete with an unnecessary show-and-tell shot of someone typing her name into Google), framing her as a riddle to be solved. With Mr. Maloof playing M.C. and sleuth, he and Mr. Siskel follow much the same arc that runs through the better news accounts about Maier. Itâ€™s a breezy, perhaps overly tidy narrative ornamented with her work and packed with interviews with some of her old charges and their parents. Some of the darker reminiscences are in sharp contrast to the movieâ€™s upbeat tone and relentlessly jaunty music.

By the next month, the British newspaper The Independent had churned out an article on Maier with the waggish, heat-seeking, imprecise headline â€œLittle Miss Big Shot: Fifties America Exposed â€” by a French Nanny.â€ù (She had a French connection, but thereâ€™s more to her than her accent suggests.) More news articles followed, and by January 2011, the Chicago Cultural Center had mounted an exhibition titled â€œFinding Vivian Maier: Chicago Street Photographer.â€ù The industrious Mr. Maloof, meanwhile, scanned more of her work, bought more of her negatives and started telling his tale and hers, or as much as he knew. Given that this is also a social-media story â€” Mr. Maloof discovered her, but the Internet made her a star â€” the Kickstarter campaign to bankroll this documentary was inevitable.

An exciting electric current of discovery runs through â€œFinding Vivian Maier,â€ù a documentary about a street photographer who never exhibited her work. She scarcely shared it even with those who knew her. Then again, many of her acquaintances when she was taking some of her remarkable images, particularly in and around Chicago in the 1950s and â€™60s, were the children she cared for while working as a nanny. Later in her life, some of those children took care of her in turn, first by moving her into an apartment and then the nursing home where she died in 2009. What rotten timing: She was on the verge of being discovered, first as a curiosity and then as a social-media sensation and a mystery.

So, itâ€™s a solid if finally thin introduction to Maier. Itâ€™s also, to state the obvious, a feature-length advertisement for Mr. Maloofâ€™s commercial venture as the principal owner of her work; his name is on the stamp that authenticates the photographs. Vivian Maier is a find but sheâ€™s also now a business, and the documentary would be stronger if it had dug into the complexities of what it means when one person assumes ownership of anotherâ€™s art. There are times when Mr. Maloof â€” particularly when heâ€™s defensively speaking about the workâ€™s artistic merit â€” feels as if he were delivering a sales pitch. He and the movie are on better ground when they let the likes of Mary Ellen Mark testify to its quality.

Itâ€™s no surprise that Maier is now the subject of a documentary, given the quality of her work, the nominal exoticism of her life and the secrets that still drift around her. Sheâ€™s a terrific story â€” part Mary Poppins, part Weegee â€” who was at once emancipated and in service. She was introduced to the world, as it were, by John Maloof, one of this movieâ€™s directors, who bought a box of her negatives at a Chicago auction in 2007 for about $400. The auction house, he explains, told him the work was by Maier, but he found nothing about her on Google. He had purchased the negatives for a book he was working on, but after deciding that they were of no use, he stashed the box away.

The documentary nods in the direction of some rich issues, including who gets to sanctify work as art, and why. Itâ€™s a thread that has additional resonance, given that everyoneâ€™s a critic on the Internet, which is where Maierâ€™s work was not just first publicly seen but also anointed. Thereâ€™s another undercurrent here about her status as an artist (partly because she didnâ€™t formally study art) and even questions about photographyâ€™s status as an art (a hoary theme that emerges because she didnâ€™t print all of her own work). Time and professional pronouncements will decide if she was an outsider artist or just an unorthodox one who, as a single 20th-century woman, found freedom, her voice and her own private bohemia while under cover of other peopleâ€™s bourgeois domesticity.

And then he took it out again, scanned some images and put them up on Flickr. â€œI have a ton of her work (about 30-40,000 negatives), which ranges in dates from the 1950s-1970s,â€ù he wrote there in October 2009. â€œIs this type of work worthy of exhibitions, a book? Or do bodies of work like this come up often? Any direction would be great.â€ù

For the boysâ€™ father, Jesus (Manny Perez), it seemed like the right thing to do. Two seemingly well-informed Army officers sat right in the family living room and told them that Betoâ€™s enlisting would end their immigration problems. With a son in American uniform, Jesusâ€™ family members, who arrived in Los Angeles from El Salvador, will be able to get the proper papers.

A 14-year-old Latino boy falls in love with an African-American girl, and the neighborhood Latino gang does not approve, in â€œGreencard Warriors.â€ù The girl is played by Paige Hurd, and Vivica A. Fox does a star turn as her mother. The boy, Angel (Angel Amaral), is vulnerable because his protective older brother, Beto (Mario Ardila Jr.), has just been sent to Iraq.

â€œGreencard Warriors,â€ù filmed in Los Angeles, was written and directed by Miriam Kruishoop, a Dutch filmmaker whose firsthand knowledge of Southern California gang culture and the plight of Latino immigrants in the United States is somewhat limited. At first, there is something a little too straightforward about the characters and their dialogue. But gradually, a group of strong, sure performances and the scriptâ€™s twists â€” Betoâ€™s fate is only the beginning of the problems â€” take hold, and we are fully involved. Ms. Kruishoopâ€™s direction and Helle Jensenâ€™s cinematography, on dark streets and in small rooms, create an all too foreboding sense of danger.

And if you read between the lines of Mr. Lunaâ€™s earnest, clumsy film, you find not just a history lesson but an argument. The success of the farm workers depended on the strength of labor unions, both in the United States and overseas, and the existence of political parties able to draw on that power. What the film struggles to depict, committed as it is to the conventions of hagiography, is the long and complex work of organizing people to defend their own interests. You are invited to admire what Cesar Chavez did, but it may be more vital to understand how he did it.

We also venture into the household of one of Chavezâ€™s main antagonists, a landowner named Bogdonovich, played with sly, dry understatement by John Malkovich. He is determined to break the incipient union, and the fight between the two men and their organizations becomes a national political issue. Senator Robert F. Kennedy (Jack Holmes) takes the side of the workers, while the interests of the growers are publicly defended by Ronald Reagan, shown in an archival video clip describing the grape boycott as immoral, and Richard Nixon. Parts of â€œCesar Chavezâ€ù are as rousing as an old folk song, with chants of â€œÂ¡Huelga!â€ù and â€œÂ¡SÃ_, se puede!â€ù ringing through the theater. Although it ends, as such works usually do, on a note of triumph, the film, whose screenplay is by Keir Pearson and Timothy J. Sexton, does not present history as a closed book. Movies about men and women who fought for social change â€” â€œMandela: Long Walk to Freedomâ€ù is a recent example â€” treat them less as the radicals they were than as embodiments of hope, reconciliation and consensus.
â€œCesar Chavezâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Strong language and scenes of bloody class struggle.

â€œCesar Chavez,â€ù directed by Diego Luna, is a well-cast, well-intentioned movie that falls into the trap that often awaits film biographies of brave and widely admired individuals. The movie is so intent on reminding viewers of its subjectâ€™s heroism that it struggles to make him an interesting, three-dimensional person, and it tells his story as a series of dramatic bullet points, punctuated by black-and-white footage, some real, some simulated, of historical events.

In spite of these shortcomings, Mr. Lunaâ€™s reconstruction of the emergence of the United Farm Workers organization in the 1960s unfolds with unusual urgency and timeliness. After a rushed beginning â€” in which we see Chavez (Michael PeÃ±a) arguing in a Los Angeles office and moving his family to Delano, a central California town, before we fully grasp his motives â€” we settle in for a long, sometimes violent struggle between the workers and the growers. Attempted strikes are met with intimidation and brutality, from the local sheriff and hired goons, and Chavez and his allies (notably Dolores Huerta, played by Rosario Dawson) come up with new tactics, including a public fast, a march from Delano to Sacramento and a consumer boycott of grapes.

Though Cesar Chavez, who died in 1993, has been honored and celebrated, the problems he addressed have hardly faded away. The rights of immigrants and the wages and working conditions of those who pick, process and transport food are still live and contentious political issues.

As is customary in movies like this, we see the toll that the heroâ€™s commitment takes on his family life. His wife, Helen (America Ferrera), is a steadfast ally, but there is tension between Chavez and his oldest son, Fernando (the only one of the coupleâ€™s eight children with more than an incidental presence on screen). Fernando (Eli Vargas) endures racist bullying at school and suffers from his fatherâ€™s frequent absences. Their scenes together are more functional than heartfelt, fulfilling the requirement of allowing the audience a glimpse at the private life of a public figure.

Daniel Patrick Carboneâ€™s haunting debut feature, â€œHide Your Smiling Faces,â€ù evokes a semi-rural 1950s America in which packs of neighborhood boys pass the time riding bikes, exploring the woods and engaging in ritualistic roughhouse games. The mood of the film, shot in areas of Sussex County, N.J., suggests a darker reflection of the same vision of boyhood adventure depicted in Terrence Malickâ€™s â€œThe Tree of Life.â€ù Although the time feels like the 1950s, the appearance of a portable DVD player signals that it is set more or less in the present.

The subject of death comes up frequently in the boysâ€™ idle conversations, and at times the dialogue sounds a little ham-handed. But it is the vision of the natural world in which the brothers cavort that lends â€œHide Your Smiling Facesâ€ù much of its gravity. The opening image of a snake with a fish in its mouth begins a procession that includes a dead bird and the discovery of a dead raccoon, which Eric sets on fire.

As the local boys (there are no girls) explore the natural world in summer, this gorgeously photographed movie bombards you with imagined scents of ripeness and decay. The sounds of nature, combined with a spare and vaguely ominous electronic soundtrack, add enough atmosphere to augment an acute awareness of the great outdoors as a wild kingdom fraught with peril.

While wandering through the woods late in the movie, Eric encounters a brown bear. He pets the creature before both go their separate ways. By the end of â€œHide Your Smiling Faces,â€ù these boys of summer have blended so thoroughly with their environment that they seem inseparable from the rest of the wildlife.

The main event of the summer is the death of a playmate, Ian (Ivan Tomic), a boy Tommyâ€™s age whose body is found at the foot of a bridge. Did he jump, or did he fall? The movie doesnâ€™t say. But in an early scene, Ian proudly brings his fatherâ€™s loaded gun out of a barn to show Eric and Tommy, and the boys struggle for it. Before the gun can discharge, Ianâ€™s father (Colm Oâ€™Leary) furiously rushes out of the house and scolds Ian, who runs into the woods while the brothers scatter. That gun (or another like it) reappears several more times. Whenever it does, you worry that someone will be shot.

Because the boys are left to their own devices during the day, and the adults remain in the background except at mealtimes, â€œHide Your Smiling Facesâ€ù conveys life as the boys experience it: a pungent mixture of boredom, curiosity, fear and mischievousness, along with an anxious sense of being trapped.

What little story exists focuses on Eric (Nathan Varnson), who is 14, and his 9-year-old sibling, Tommy (Ryan Jones), whom he bullies the way older brothers often do. In one of many challenges, Eric forces Tommy to learn to swim by carrying him into deep water and letting go, while Tommy howls with fear. Eric, driven by an inchoate rage and frustration he can barely express, is a little scary, because you sense that his impulse toward cruelty could tip over the line at any second. Their intimacy at certain moments feels almost stifling, as if they were physically conjoined.

Displaying an adroit way with language that lifts the filmâ€™s saggier, more formless moments, Mr. Fisher is an astute and pitiless observer of our less noble instincts. (A scene where Ethan explains why he doesnâ€™t want his shiksa girlfriend to become Jewish â€” â€œThen sheâ€™ll be enthusiasticâ€ù â€” nails exactly whatâ€™s annoying about the freshly converted.) But Ethanâ€™s search for the perfect partner leaves a bitter, almost misogynistic aftertaste: He responds to women on a cruelly judgmental spectrum from mild annoyance to outright disgust. As a result, his sole romantic gesture leaves you wishing that the object of his belated affection would run for the hills.
Sharp yet overdetermined, â€œBlumenthalâ€ù doesnâ€™t breathe naturally â€” itâ€™s a comedy in a box. Just not a box that everyone will want to open.

No one cares. Not his brother, Saul (Mark Blum), an English professor whose extreme constipation is a too obvious metaphor for his inability to let go of old grudges. Not Saulâ€™s wife, Cheryl (the marvelous Laila Robins), a sexually frustrated actress seeking consolation in the arms of a dog walker with much-in-demand supplemental services. And certainly not Saulâ€™s ultraneurotic son, Ethan (played by the filmâ€™s writer and director, Seth Fisher), who hawks medicine for womenâ€™s bodies while knowing nothing about their minds.

â€œBlumenthal,â€ù a chilly Jewish comedy that wraps old jokes in a distinctively young voice, has a brisk cleverness that can cause you to overlook its more unpalatable characteristics. Before those take hold, though, there is much to enjoy in this prickly observation of the familial fallout when Harold Blumenthal (Brian Cox), a bloviating playwright, dies while relishing one of his own jokes.

The couple issue one dare after another to the two friends â€” punch a bouncer; spank a stripper â€” and pay off in wads of cash, the amounts increasing with the riskiness or distastefulness of the dare. Soon the lure of money has turned Craig and Vince against each other as they vie for the cash, and the dares become darker and bloodier.
The actors play â€œCheap Thrillsâ€ù straight, but you should watch it as a twisted comedy. Those who do will be rewarded, especially by the filmâ€™s outlandish final image.

Mr. Koechner is terrific as the main instigator, and Mr. Healy does a pretty good job of transforming from wimpy family man to cutthroat competitor. E. L. Katz, the director, making his feature debut, has the courage to have everyone play it completely seriously. This is dark comedy indeed, and if viewed as such, it works deliciously. And hey, if you like, you can consider it some kind of allegory for a society in which the rich are very rich, and the poor are mere playthings.

Craig (Pat Healy) is in the midst of a bad day, having been fired and received an eviction notice hours apart, and heâ€™s wondering how he will support his wife and newborn son. In a bar, he encounters an old friend, Vince (Ethan Embry), and the two of them fall in with a couple (David Koechner and Sara Paxton) with odd tastes and an apparently limitless amount of money.

But rather than distressed retro photography, or Guy Maddin mash-up fantasias, the movieâ€™s often deadpan episodes feel like something out of one-act theater: two soldiers in a forest; a playfully tense card game; a postcoital bedside monologue. A jack-of-all-trades kid named Butler (Rayvin Disla) is the closest there is to a lead character, a beacon in the wilderness.

The archaic clothing, deliberate speech rhythms, contemplative amputees, folk songs and other old-timey accouterments give the story some general bearings. (The movieâ€™s title recalls a â€œfuneral sermonâ€ù in verse by James Weldon Johnson.)

Several years in the making and seemingly unfolding some hundred years in the past, Aaron Schimbergâ€™s black-and-white pastiche, â€œGo Down Death,â€ù is a curious foray into lo-fi anachronism. Shot on 16-millimeter film, this staccato ensemble of vignettes shuffles among the fatalistic inhabitants of a run-down hamlet who have little to cling to but crackerjack philosophizing.
