Its off-kilter use of the past feels a bit mannered (and dated to an earlier decade of design and music revival). But the nostalgia is sharpened to a point with an abrupt final jump to a chattery present-day Brooklyn dinner party.

What itâ€™s not is entertaining or even mildly diverting. Teaming up with a sympathetic court-appointed shrink (a wooden Keith McGill), Jennifer â€” who turns out to be a surprisingly effective sleuth for a nut case â€” stages a breakout and fights off her attraction to powerful men. But even if we can get past unlikely details (like a mental institution that allows patients to play with scissors), the drab locations and dull performances suck the air out of a story (by Mr. Irving and Rick Santos) thatâ€™s every bit as troubled as its unappealing heroine.

Unfolding from the viewpoint of Jennifer (Emily Fradenburgh), a batty erotomaniac, Xackery Irvingâ€™s â€œNothing Without Youâ€ù might have had a fighting chance as a skewed study of a sick psyche. But by embedding Jenniferâ€™s mental issues in a murder mystery of unmitigated tedium, this low-budget drama essentially cuts its own throat.

For the first 15 minutes, however, interest is piqued as Jennifer, holed up in the attic of a married city councilman (Joshua Loren), peeps down on his master bedroom. Emerging only to sniff his sheets, read his diary and steal his wifeâ€™s dry cleaning, sheâ€™s a ghostly stalker whose internal monologue, paired with Mr. Irvingâ€™s off-kilter staging, lends the film an unsettling tone. This soon dissipates when she witnesses a gruesome murder and becomes the prime suspect; from this point on, Jenniferâ€™s journey to clear her name â€” given her few wits and immediate confinement in a psychiatric institution â€” could generously be described as uphill.

Amy (Krysten Ritter) has taken over the raising of her two younger siblings after their parents apparently abandoned the three of them, though the details of this life-changing event are never given. She meets the just-passing-through Sam (Brian Geraghty) in a bar, the two tumble into bed, and the rest of the film is a fragmentary, unconvincing effort to trace the emergence of a familial bond. Itâ€™s complicated, because Amyâ€™s brother and sister (Logan Huffman and Madeleine Martin) have significant problems, either emotional or physical, which are also not detailed. Jessica Goldberg, who wrote and directed the film, prefers showcasing the somewhat treacly soundtrack to fleshing out back stories.

â€œRefuge,â€ù like a lot of movies these days about young people searching for meaningful relationships, is the old Disney fantasy reimagined for the hookup age. That leaves it feeling just as unsatisfying and unrealistic as a happily-ever-after story about a damsel and a prince she has barely met.

It would be wonderful if true love depended only on a properly fitting glass slipper, and it would be equally wonderful if a difficult domestic situation like Amyâ€™s could be conquered by the flimsy definition of love depicted here â€” Sam doesnâ€™t even know her last name until halfway through the film, and when either asks about anything deeper than whatâ€™s for dinner, the other changes the subject. The film presumably is trying to end with the promise of a brighter future for all involved, but reality isnâ€™t nearly that simple.

The Welsh-born Mr. Evans and his skilled crew of combat specialists sustain the movieâ€™s extended warfare with discipline, the alert camerawork staving off the numbness induced by the preceding film. And it all ends with a hard-earned, satisfying signoff that recognizes the limits to the punishment the body can take.

After opening long shots of a rural execution, the fights get bloodier and more brutal, the sadism more overt, and itâ€™s as if we got closer to the violence. But within the daisy-chaining brawls that ensue, thereâ€™s also something oddly grounded, even meditative: yeomanâ€™s work by a decent, deadly hero.

When a prison yard becomes a sloppy battlefield in â€œThe Raid 2,â€ù the mud-covered combatants turn gray, reduced to their essence: bodies smashing together in the muck. The pleasant surprise of Gareth Evansâ€™s sturdy sequel to â€œThe Raid: Redemptionâ€ù is that neither its undercover drama nor its two-and-a-half-hour length bog down the bracing, and numerous, fight fests.

Iko Uwais returns as Rama, a Jakarta cop who infiltrates a crime syndicate by aiding the bossâ€™s son, Uco (Arifin Putra). Pride and greed push Uco into cooking up turf intrigue with the help of a leather-gloved rival boss, Bejo (Alex Abbad). The story delivers diverse settings (and opponents) for the clobbering-kicking-lunging-shooting melees: in a dated big-box club, at a pornography operation, in a car and between speeding cars. Rama soldiers on through all of it, making clandestine phone calls to his wife.
â€œThe Raid 2â€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for bloody violence, sexuality and strong language.

Amir Ramses, the 34-year-old director of â€œJews of Egypt,â€ù says in publicity notes for his documentary that â€œthe contradiction between modern intolerant Egypt and cosmopolitan Egypt in the first half of the 20th centuryâ€ù led him to focus on the period from 1949 to 1956, when many Egyptian Jews left or were forced out of the country. The film consists of archival footage and interviews, primarily with people who remember those turbulent years.

Documentaries like these can resemble a moving-picture photo album: a collection of images that simply preserve memories of a time and place. And, unfortunately, this film tends to follow that format, taking the concept even further by freeze-framing interviewees at emotional moments, which yields a cheap, sentimental effect. As the film evolves, though, Mr. Ramses shows a talent for storytelling. It turns out that one unassuming subject was a leftist spy, and another witness was long unaware that he was the son of another subject. The movie is rich in romanticism and complex political relationships.

The radical left-wing leader Henri Curiel (who was born in Egypt and later based in Paris) is a crucial figure in these scenes of intrigue. Speculation is presented about his assassination in 1978, yet no solution is offered. In this and other instances, Mr. Ramsesâ€™s admirable eagerness to tell a good tale seems to have favored excitement over facts.

Placed side by side, Tom and Matt Berninger are as aesthetically harmonious as marshmallow and beef jerky. But physical difference is only the tip of a fond estrangement that began during their childhood in Cincinnati and widened as Matt, the elder by almost a decade, gained recognition as the lead vocalist for the National. Seeing an opportunity to close that gap, Tom â€” whose main creative output had been microbudgeted horror movies â€” accepted Mattâ€™s offer of a grunt job on the bandâ€™s 2010-11 European tour, toting a camera and a vague plan to make a documentary. What could go wrong?

Pierced with touching moments of seemingly stumbled-upon clarity, â€œStrangersâ€ù is a shaggy ode to sibling reconnection. As Matt roams an auditorium during one of his midsong walkabouts, Tom scurries behind with the microphone cable before boosting his brother back onstage. The sequence is wordless, but its metaphorical impact is deafening.

A tale of two brothers, one band and a boatload of psychological baggage, â€œMistaken for Strangersâ€ù is, like its maker, scruffy, undisciplined and eager to be loved. The big surprise is how easy it is to comply.

Quite a lot, as it happens. Despite intermittent blasts from the bandâ€™s anguished, cerebral performances, â€œMistaken for Strangersâ€ù isnâ€™t about the music (which Tom, in any case, doesnâ€™t really cotton to). The gold here lies offstage, in Tomâ€™s left-field interviews with bemused band members (do they take wallets onstage, he wonders?) and in barbed confrontations with the highly organized road crew members who resent his laissez-faire work ethic. Chided by Matt for drinking too much (â€œYouâ€™ve got the allergyâ€ù) and disillusioned by the bandâ€™s aversion to drugs and partying, he visibly wilts; we can sense him recalibrating his notion of perhaps more than just the rock star lifestyle.

But even though the scale of this film â€” the size of its budget and the breadth of its themes â€” is larger than anything this director has attempted before, â€œNoahâ€ù is less an epic than a horror movie. There are some big, noisy battle scenes and some whiz-bang computer-generated images, but the dominant moods are claustrophobia and incipient panic. The most potent special effects are Mr. Croweâ€™s eyes and the swelling, discordant strains of Clint Mansellâ€™s score. Once the waters have covered the earth and the ark is afloat, a clammy fear sets in, for both the audience and the members of Noahâ€™s family: Weâ€™re stuck on a boat full of snakes, rats and insects, and Dadâ€™s gone crazy.

Through five features, from â€œPiâ€ù to â€œBlack Swan,â€ù Mr. Aronofsky has refined his taste for extremity and his mastery of a queasy, feverish camera style. He specializes in intimate portraits of people whose sense of reality is coming undone, and Noah, played with rabid gloominess by Russell Crowe, is no exception. The difference between him and Mr. Aronofskyâ€™s earlier protagonists is that Noahâ€™s mental equilibrium is bound up with the fate of humanity, and that his actions may have a lesson to teach us.

â€œNoahâ€ù is occasionally clumsy, ridiculous and unconvincing, but it is almost never dull, and very little of it has the careful, by-the-numbers quality that characterizes big-studio action-fantasy entertainment. The riskiest thing about this movie is its sincerity: Mr. Aronofsky, while not exactly pious, takes the narrative and its implications seriously. He tries not only to explore what the story of the flood might mean in the present age of environmental anxiety and apocalyptic religion, but also, more radically, to imagine what it might have felt like to live in a newly created, already-ruined world, and to scan the skies for clues about what its creator might be thinking.

The earlier chapters of Genesis (the snake, the forbidden fruit) are rendered as brightly hued hallucinations, but the post-Edenic world is a blasted, desolate, shadeless landscape from which Mr. Aronofsky and his cinematographer, Matthew Libatique, have drained every warm and living color. (That is, until the CGI trees sprout from a magic seed to supply building materials for the ark.)

Mr. Hopkins is gleefully hammy as Methuselah, Noahâ€™s grandfather and the filmâ€™s resident wise wizard. Ms. Watson is Ila, a character invented as the love interest for Noahâ€™s eldest son, Shem (the blankly pretty Douglas Booth), and as a partial answer to the â€œbe fruitful and multiplyâ€ù imperative. Ilaâ€™s presence quickens the ethical dilemma that supplies the filmâ€™s dramatic pulse, as Noah is forced to choose between obedience and love, with potentially suicidal results either way.

â€œNoahâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). â€œAnd every living substance was destroyed which was upon the face of the ground, both man, and cattle, and the creeping things, and the fowl of the heaven; and they were destroyed from the earth: and only Noah remained alive, and they that were with him in the ark.â€ù

But Tubal-Cain is also something of a humanist, or at least a proponent of the idea that humanity, for all its cravenness and corruption, might be worth saving. He has a sly, passionate energy that the terrified, humorless Noah completely lacks, and he tempts Noahâ€™s middle son, Ham (Logan Lerman), to betray his father. Tubal-Cain may be a brute and a deceiver, but his nemesis is, at least potentially, a genocidal lunatic. The way Noah sees it, he has been chosen not to save mankind but to ensure its annihilation.

Noahâ€™s instability â€” he walks up to the boundary that separates faith from fanaticism, and then leaps across it â€” is not, strictly speaking, in the source material, and I will hardly be the first or last to note that Mr. Aronofsky, who wrote the screenplay with Ari Handel, has taken some liberties with the text. For example, while the Bible does note that â€œthere were giants in those days,â€ù it does not specify that they were six-armed stone colossi with the voices of Nick Nolte and Frank Langella. These figures, known as watchers, are cousins of Peter Jacksonâ€™s Ents and Michael Bayâ€™s Transformers, and part of a vividly, if not always coherently imagined, pre-diluvian reality.

Many versions of the tale â€” including that Sunday-school and summer camp song that has been stuck in my head for decades â€” emphasize the happy outcome: the rainbow, the dove, the cute paired-off beasts, the repopulation of the flood-cleansed earth. But Darren Aronofsky, in his ambitious fusion of Old Testament awe with modern blockbuster spectacle, dwells on the dark and troubling implications of Noahâ€™s experience. â€œNoah,â€ù Mr. Aronofskyâ€™s earnest, uneven, intermittently powerful film, is both a psychological case study and a parable of hubris and humility. At its best, it shares some its namesakeâ€™s ferocious conviction, and not a little of his madness.

Mr. Crowe has no problem playing this kind of monster. He specializes in portraying righteousness pushed to the point of murderous, monomaniacal rage. He also benefits from the presence of gentler, more emotionally flexible performers, and here he has, in addition to Ms. Connelly (in a variation on her role as the capable, patient wife in â€œA Beautiful Mindâ€ù), Emma Watson and Anthony Hopkins.

Noah, one of the last descendants of the peaceful line of Seth, is a vegetarian and a nomad, camping out on the brown hillsides with his wife (Jennifer Connelly) and their children. The family is occasionally harassed by marauders from the line of Cain, a clan that has blighted the planet with greed and industry, killing off animals and strip-mining precious minerals. Their leader is a shaggy, bellowing warlord named Tubal-Cain (Ray Winstone), conveniently the object of Noahâ€™s justified vengeance as well as of fully merited divine judgment.

The information supplied about Noah in the Book of Genesis is scant â€” barely enough for a Hollywood pitch meeting, much less a feature film â€” but his story is among the strangest and scariest in the Hebrew Bible. At its center is what appears to be an unnerving example of divine self-doubt. Disgusted with his creation, God decides to wipe the slate clean and start again, only to relent and allow Noah, a 500-something-year-old father of three, to save his family and a boatload of animals.

Unlike Robert S. McNamara, another former defense secretary who sat for a portrait in front of Mr. Morrisâ€™s camera (in â€œThe Fog of Warâ€ù), Mr. Rumsfeld is untroubled by second thoughts or pangs of conscience. At times, the discrepancy between his view of himself and the historical record is almost comical, as when he waves off the suggestion that he was a ruthlessly Machiavellian player in the internecine Republican struggles of the 1970s. He portrays himself both as selflessly loyal and as ferociously independent, and when asked whether he sees himself as the master or the pawn of events answers both and neither. When Mr. Morris wonders if it might have been better to stay out of Iraq â€” a view now widely held among Americans of both political parties â€” Mr. Rumsfeld takes refuge in the unknowable. â€œTime will tell,â€ù he says.

While it is unlikely that Mr. Rumsfeld would describe himself as a postmodernist, he does seem to be invested in the obscurity of truth and the indeterminacy of meaning, and to believe that what we know is constructed by language rather than reflected in it. An important figure in a political faction famously committed to creating its own reality, he patiently explains the role that â€œimaginationâ€ù plays in world affairs. Mr. Morris, an ardent old-school positivist, suggests the word â€œintelligenceâ€ù as a substitute.

In 2003 the journalist Hart Seely published â€œPieces of Intelligence: The Existential Poetry of Donald H. Rumsfeld,â€ù a book that arranged some of the public pronouncements of that secretary of defense into spiky, evocative morsels of free verse. Mr. Rumsfeld may have been an accidental poet, but â€œThe Unknown Known,â€ù Errol Morrisâ€™s new documentary about him, nonetheless makes an implicit argument for his literary distinction. Not only does Mr. Rumsfeld revel in his status as the proud and prolific author â€” via his beloved Dictaphone â€” of memos known at the Pentagon as â€œsnowflakes,â€ù but he also shows himself to be a man fascinated by language and delighted by his ability to use it.

In his writings on photography, on the historian of science Thomas Kuhn and on the Jeffrey MacDonald murder case (some of them first published in the online opinion section of The New York Times), Mr. Morris insists that the truth, though it may be obscured by circumstance and clouded by human error, exists and can be known. His films can be dizzyingly discursive, but they are also motivated by a doggedly empirical impulse. The unreliability of human beings â€” our propensity to lie, to spin, to delude ourselves and one another â€” is for him an ethical problem rather than a metaphysical puzzle.

Though Mr. Morrisâ€™s filmmaking technique is supple and sophisticated â€” â€œThe Unknown Knownâ€ù weaves its central interview through archival footage, poetic images of snow globes and seascapes and discreet re-enactments, using Danny Elfmanâ€™s spooky score as connective tissue â€” he has a fairly straightforward interviewing method. He gives his interlocutors plenty of rope. But rather than hang himself, Mr. Rumsfeld tries to fashion a ladder and escape through the window.

Mr. Rumsfeld presents himself as a man without secrets or ulterior motives, as legible as one of his snowflakes, untroubled by doubt and continually surprised by circumstance, shrewd and guileless, modest and vain. He explains himself clearly and remains impossible to read.

Clips from press briefings during the Iraq war illustrate his penchant for using semantics as a weapon, one he wields with undiminished glee against Mr. Morris. When the filmmaker presses him on the â€œtorture memosâ€ù authorizing harsh treatment of suspected terrorists, Mr. Rumsfeld rephrases the question in such a way as to minimize any moral stigma and also any hint of his own responsibility. â€œLittle different cast I just put on it than the one you did,â€ù he says, breaking into a smile and raising a finger of triumph. â€œIâ€™ll chalk that one up.â€ù

â€œThe Unknown Knownâ€ù may or may not influence the judgment of history. Your sense of who â€œwinsâ€ù â€” the filmmaker or his subject â€” is likely to reflect your opinion going in. The film is a cat-and-mouse game in which each player thinks heâ€™s the cat, making it both thrilling and disconcerting to watch. It is also a nature documentary about behavior at the very top of the imperial food chain and a detective story about the search for a mystery that is hidden in plain sight.

With Mr. Morrisâ€™s off-camera encouragement, Mr. Rumsfeld, voluble and energetic in his early 80s, reads aloud from a dozen or so of his most memorable snowflakes. (He guesses that he composed around 20,000 during his six-year tenure in the administration of George W. Bush and possibly a million in the course of his career in politics and business.) The headings of several of the memos are â€œDefinitionsâ€ù and â€œTerminology,â€ù and their author seems to have been fond of sharing passages from various dictionaries with staff members.
â€œThe Unknown Knownâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Thousands of deaths, bloodlessly discussed.

And â€œThe Unknown Known,â€ù which draws its title from one of Mr. Rumsfeldâ€™s most famous rhetorical flights, is very much a battle of wits and words. Yes, it is a probing and unsettling inquiry into the recent political and military history of the United States, but it is also a bracing and invigorating philosophical skirmish. The tension between those two registers â€” between hard facts about state violence and devilish abstractions about causes and consequences â€” is what gives the film some of its energy and suspense. It is clear enough that an ideological chasm separates the unseen interviewer from his crisply dressed subject, but the real drama between them arises from a clash of epistemologies.

Come for the performance; stay for the performance. Because, to answer Peggy Leeâ€™s lingering question, thatâ€™s all there is. Well, almost: There are also bright eye-popping colors, amusing lines and many clever production-design touches, like the large photographs of monkeys by Jill Greenberg that expressively loom on the walls while Dom unleashes one of his humorous, increasingly grinding rants. Monkey see; monkey yammer. By this point, Dom has hooked up with his best and apparently only friend, Dickie (the invaluable Richard E. Grant), and together theyâ€™ve gone to France to meet Mr. Fontaine (Demian Bichir, nicely restrained), the big boss for whom Dom took the fall and who now, all these years later, is ready to pay for services rendered.

â€œDom Hemingwayâ€ù is a bright, shiny bauble with next to no lasting power. The movie is fabulously kitted out with tasty people, cool costumes, artful scoops of pomaded hair and the kind of eyeglasses that somehow make the characters look stupider. (British screen eyewear, from Harry Palmerâ€™s frames to George Smileyâ€™s, constitutes an entire field of cinematic signification.) But the movie is all setup and badly served by a sentimentalism thatâ€™s tipped as soon as Dom mentions his daughter, Evelyn (Emilia Clarke, Daenerys Targaryen on â€œGame of Thronesâ€ù), and the score starts gently weeping. Mr. Shepard has a great eye, but as in his earlier film â€œThe Matadorâ€ù â€” which features the unforgettable sight of Pierce Brosnan promenading in boots and tight black trunks â€” thereâ€™s only so much chest hair can do.

The writer and director Richard Shepard makes the most of this French sojourn (with its presumptive tax incentives) and its visual pleasures, which Dom greedily takes in, from Mr. Fontaineâ€™s prettily situated villa to Mr. Fontaineâ€™s prettily styled ornament, Paolina (Madalina Ghenea). There, in between Domâ€™s tirades and Mr. Fontaineâ€™s murmured assurances (and threats), bottles are uncorked, bras unfastened, appetites indulged. For some reason, Dom takes a stroll in the nude in an olive grove, allowing you to contemplate Mr. Lawâ€™s backside and Mr. Grantâ€™s ability to keep a straight face. The two are deftly funny together, even if nothing they say sticks. In another scene, Mr. Shepard stages a nighttime car crash that unfolds in eye-catching slow motion, bodies and booze bottles floating.
â€œDom Hemingwayâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Guns, gangsters and lovingly delivered obscenities.

There is, perhaps, only so much to say about a movie that opens with a man delivering a soliloquy about his penis. When you first see the title character of â€œDom Hemingway,â€ù a violent British comedy about a gangster who talks the hard-boiled talk with verve and gutter lyricism, heâ€™s speaking and staring into the camera. His arms are stretched out to the side, Christlike, and while the camera doesnâ€™t show the full monty, the shot is wide enough for you to see that Jude Law has packed on a few pounds to play this flamboyant tough guy and hasnâ€™t taken a Gillette to his chest.

Domâ€™s words burble and gurgle musically with increased dramatic heat until you finally get enough of the big picture so that itâ€™s clear he isnâ€™t actually alone. Heâ€™s in prison, to begin with, and as he says, 12 years is a long time. He doesnâ€™t stay there and is soon strolling into the story a free man, dandified in a double-breasted blue suit, violet shirt and the short, pointy boots of mods if not rockers. Mr. Law wears this look well, and with enthusiasm. Thereâ€™s a lot going on in his face, with its riptides of extreme emotion and artfully manicured mutton chops, but much of the performanceâ€™s comedy and energy comes from the thrusting, centrifugal physicality that telegraphs Domâ€™s primitivism and will to dominate.

A tough, tender little movie, â€œThe Retrievalâ€ù tells a story of divided souls wandering a divided land. It takes place in 1864, the year before the Civil War ended, and opens in the dead of night. As cannons boom in the distance, a 13-year-old black boy, a seeming runaway, takes refuge in a barn guarded by a white woman with a long gun. Shortly after the boy settles in next to a few black fugitives â€” one silently hands him food â€” he slips out to alert his employers, white bounty hunters who quickly torch the barn and capture the fugitives, who fetch as much as $600 a head.

Like many other fictional American travelers, the aptly named Will is on a journey of discovery even if his road necessarily winds more inwardly than past the horizon. Despite some talk of the West, he and his fellow travelers are restricted by their existential realities as mid-19th-century black Americans. These constraints may be finally more a function of the productionâ€™s limited budget than of history, but they dovetail with the storyâ€™s human scale. At one point, Will, Marcus and Nate are swept up in a battle between Union and Confederate soldiers. Itâ€™s a ragged skirmish, thinly manned and awkwardly staged. Yet by then the movie, unlike some other Civil War tales, has made the point that while Will and the others may not be conscripts, this is very much their fight.
â€œThe Retrievalâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). War violence.

Mr. Eskaâ€™s choices are thoughtful if sometimes studied: the movie is well cast with solid performers, and if the handsome digital images look overly sharp, as if outlined in razor, he consistently makes the most of his limited resources. Mr. John, Mr. Oberst and Mr. Scott have faces that you want to spend time searching, and the cinematographer, Yasu Tanida, knows how to shoot African-Americans; here, they donâ€™t ebb into shadow because the scenes were lighted for their white co-stars. This is also a movie made for the big screen: there are plenty of TV-ready medium and head-and-shoulder close-ups, but Mr. Eska uses tight ones sparingly and has a feel for landscape, often showing the characters framed against the trees, pale sky and pooling night, as if to emphasize the world in which they exist.

A few times, as in a scene in which Will walks around with an animal skull in front of his face, obscuring himself with the bony mask, the movie slips into strained poetry. The image is visually arresting, including chromatically, as black shifts against white with a spooky, morbid loveliness that draws you in. It also conveys a sense of playfulness that underscores that Will, despite his protests, is still a child. Yet when the camera continues to trail after Will, it feels as if Mr. Eska were moving away from a concretely, resonantly human moment â€” and a boy fooling with a weird talisman of death â€” and into that Terrence Malick realm where light and the mystery of being converge at the back of a characterâ€™s head. Mr. Eska is on firmer ground when his movie and people are too.

Money changes hands throughout â€œThe Retrieval,â€ù passed from man to man in bloody communion. The boy, Will (Ashton Sanders), carries around a coin given to him by his long-gone father. With no family or home, he clings to it and to a man he calls uncle, Marcus (Keston John), a black mercenary with fast, cruel hands. Itâ€™s unclear how they ended up working for the bounty hunters, who are led by the foreboding Burrell (Bill Oberst Jr.). After the gang captures the fugitives, Burrell pays Marcus, who then tosses Will some coins. Thereâ€™s pathos in how Will scrambles for his meager pay and also in his reluctance to feed the fugitives, whining that it isnâ€™t his turn.

Written, directed and edited by Chris Eska, â€œThe Retrievalâ€ù is modest in means and narrative scope. Its heft comes from the moral awakening at its center, which involves the humanization of a black adolescent who, however nominally free, is captive to a system that reduces human relationships to financial transactions. The story follows Will and Marcus as they, under orders from Burrell, go north to bring back a black man, Nate (Tishuan Scott). Will and Marcus find Nate digging graves for the Union and persuade him to return south to visit his brother, whom they say is dying. Initially reluctant or just wary, Nate at last agrees, and together they head off into a wintry landscape wreathed in a spectral blue light and speckled with leafless trees and corpses.

A young actor named Reid Ewing, who might be familiar from â€œModern Family,â€ù spends much of the movie running around naked in service to jokes that arenâ€™t funny, and Michael McKean was somehow talked into a degrading small role. Worst of all, the 10 rules of the title are nothing you couldnâ€™t have figured out on your own. The movie doesnâ€™t work even as an instructional video.
â€œ10 Rules for Sleeping Aroundâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for flashes of nudity and general randiness.

One couple (Virginia Williams and Jesse Bradford), who profess to have an open relationship that allows for fooling around, try to encourage a more restrained couple (Tammin Sursok and Chris Marquette) to let their libidos loose. The plot grows almost indecipherable as things converge on a beach house, a big party and an important book author.

Which brings us to â€œ10 Rules for Sleeping Around,â€ù written and directed by Leslie Greif. There is quite a lot of talk about sex, none of it amusing, but thereâ€™s little sex or sexiness. Unless you find overacting sexy.
A sex comedy can sometimes get by, even if it is deficient in one of the two things that term promises. But a sex comedy that is short on both sex and comedy is unlikely to please anyone.

This remarkably terse movie doesnâ€™t waste a word or an image. It refuses to linger over each little crisis its characters endure. And its detachment lends a perspective that widens the filmâ€™s vision of people reacting to events beyond their control. This family and Singapore belong to a complex, tightly knit social organism in which, consciously or not, every part is sensitive to every other.

The mild-mannered Teck (Chen Tianwen), who works in sales, and his pregnant wife, Hwee Leng (Yeo Yann Yann), a secretary, toil long, stressful hours in their drive toward upward mobility. A thorn in their side is their neglected 10-year-old son, Jiale (Koh Jia Ler), a troublemaker at his elementary school, where officials â€” driven to their witsâ€™ end by his behavior â€” summon Hwee Leng from her workplace when he misbehaves. When Jiale punches another boy, he is threatened with expulsion.

Hwee Leng, the hardest character to like, is suspicious and demanding; she talks down to Teresa, issues curt orders and never expresses even a hint of gratitude. She may behave monstrously, but you come to understand why and to grudgingly admire her tenacity. You also notice that her bark is much worse than her bite, and that behind her severity is a reservoir of love.

The bad economic news breaks just as Hwee Leng hires Teresa (Angeli Bayani), a 28-year-old Filipino with a child back in the Philippines, as a housekeeper. One of her duties is to watch over Jiale, who refuses to obey her. In one incident, the boy flees on his bike and breaks his arm when he is struck by a car.

The economic woes that weighed heavily 17 years ago in Singapore arenâ€™t all that different from American workplace anxiety during and after the 2007-8 financial crisis. Fueling the family membersâ€™ tension is the unvoiced fear that just one slip on the ladder could cost them everything. They are a mirror of society, clutching at a dream that may suddenly be out of reach.

â€œIlo Iloâ€ù increasingly focuses on the relationship of Jiale and Teresa, who is as financially insecure as her employers and supplements what she makes as a housekeeper with a hairdressing sideline. Teresa is so servile that she never loses her temper with either Hwee Leng or Jiale, no matter how provoked. As a bond slowly develops between Teresa and the boy, he begins to express his affection in small, subtle ways, and Hwee Leng becomes resentful. â€œIlo Iloâ€ù could have sentimentalized this relationship, but it doesnâ€™t. And by the end of a movie that could have been a tear-jerker, you empathize with everybody equally.

â€œIlo Ilo,â€ù Anthony Chenâ€™s small, wonderful first feature film, is an acutely perceptive examination of middle-class life in Singapore during a 1997 financial crisis that sent tremors of panic through Asiaâ€™s developing countries. Its semi-autobiographical story focuses on a family of three, with a baby on the way, suddenly facing uncertainty.

In her severity, Hwee Leng might be described as a tiger mother. She yells at Jiale, who responds to her tirades with a blank stare. She imperiously bosses around her husband, who is too ashamed to tell her when he is laid off from his job selling shatter-resistant glass. On top of that, he has secretly lost a bundle gambling on the stock market, and his belated confession of recklessness briefly drives her out of the house.

Teck is a passive-aggressive, grown-up version of his son. He defies Hwee Leng by smoking cigarettes in the hallway outside their apartment. At a family birthday party, where she allows him one drink, he gets drunk and is found collapsed in a bathroom. A minor crisis erupts when a cigarette that Jiale tried smoking is found in a toilet, and Teck is scolded.

There is still plenty of idiocy on the airwaves and on cable, in Britain and everywhere else, but the kind of chipper, infuriatingly inoffensive prattle that Alan Partridge was invented to lampoon is no longer as prevalent as it used to be. Compared with the coarseness and hostility that dominate daytime radio and cable news, his blithe stupidity seems almost innocent. Like his trans-Atlantic counterpart Ron Burgundy, Alan risks becoming lovable.
â€œAlan Partridgeâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Mr. Coogan appears briefly â€” though perhaps not briefly enough â€” without pants.

And also a hint of nostalgia. Alan, who gives his age as 55, is not quite the brash, chirpy young wally you can find in video clips on the Internet. He still has a terrible haircut and an abrasive manner, but he shows noticeable signs of fatigue. It is not that Mr. Coogan has aged, just that the world of media fatuity that Alan represents has evolved away from this kind of satire.

Partridge, cooked up by Mr. Coogan and Armando Iannucci almost 20 years ago, began as a BBC sports announcer and failed upward, hosting a talk show called â€œKnowing Me Knowing Youâ€ù before ascending to â€œIâ€™m Alan Partridge,â€ù a series similar to â€œThe Larry Sanders Show.â€ù In it and in â€œAlan Partridge,â€ù the new feature film directed by Declan Lowney, he has been exiled to radio, hosting a stretch of daytime music and gabbing at a station in Norwich. That somewhat pathetic job is now threatened by new owners, who want to refresh the format to make it more youthful and digital-friendly.

Alan, whose salient traits are cowardice, disloyalty and a complete inability to keep his mouth shut, becomes the crucial player in a hostage drama. The situation provides opportunities for him to spout articulate nonsense, lose his pants and endanger nearly everyone else. Not that there is any real danger â€” just an atmosphere of cheeky mayhem.

Can unpleasantness be its own kind of charm? The British comedian and actor Steve Coogan has built a career around the answer â€œwell yes, sort of.â€ù American audiences that know him for his uncharacteristically sweet turn in â€œPhilomenaâ€ù or his role as the miniature Roman soldier in â€œNight at the Museumâ€ù movies may have a distorted view of his talents. As a character named â€œSteve Cooganâ€ù (in â€œThe Tripâ€ù and elsewhere), he has satirized the fragile vanity of the semicelebrity class. But his greatest creation may be a broadcaster named Alan Partridge, a man whose Wikipedia entry helpfully describes him as â€œan insecure, superficial and narcissistic â€˜wally.â€™Â â€ù

Or something. The plot of â€œAlan Partridgeâ€ù (also known as â€œAlan Partridge: Alpha Papaâ€ù) is designed not for coherence but to maximize the chances for Mr. Coogan to riff in character and to bring his alter ego to the very edge of either improbable likability or utter awfulness. Itâ€™s an act that requires agility and energy, both of which Mr. Coogan possesses in exhausting abundance, as well as an obliging cast of supporting performers. In addition to Felicity Montagu as Alanâ€™s long-suffering assistant, Lynn, Mr. Coogan is served by Tim Key as Alanâ€™s diffident on-air sidekick, Monica Dolan as his office crush and Colm Meaney as an irascible fellow disc jockey whose firing sets off a chain of absurd and alarming events.

Mr. Coogan fights hard against that outcome, even as the three-act structure of the feature film drags â€œAlan Partridgeâ€ù toward sentimentality. He manages, just barely, to keep the project from going soft, and to keep us perched between finding Alan Partridge unbearable and admitting that we kind of enjoy his company.
As on the nose as its title, Matty Beckermanâ€™s â€œAlien Abductionâ€ù repackages ancient legend for modern audiences in a found-footage story of streamlined efficiency.

But while the whole lacks novelty (even the aliens are standard-issue), Luke Geissbuhlerâ€™s low-angle photography lingers intuitively on sights that a young boy would want to investigate. And when Rileyâ€™s mother is sucked into the night sky, the ghastly popping of her spine proves that, when it comes to effects, cheap as chips is sometimes more than good enough.

Drawing inspiration from reported sightings of ghostly lights in the Brown Mountain region of North Carolina, Mr. Beckerman places a camcorder in the hands of Riley Morris (Riley Polanski), an autistic 11-year-old camping in the area with his family. Presenting the camera as Rileyâ€™s blankie â€” a soothing device for negotiating a scary world â€” proves to be a nifty way of explaining its continued use, especially when dead crows rain from the heavens, and a tunnel filled with abandoned cars turns into a terrifying battleground.

Essentially a chase movie with extraterrestrial pursuers (and a little treat after the end credits), this debut feature makes no pretense of subtlety. Swift and single-minded, the action â€” alternating breathless respites with bursts of hysterical motion â€” flows through a cabin in the woods, as we lose family members and gain a monosyllabic mountain man. The lighting dims, the actors do what little is asked of them, and the sound design swells to a satisfying medley of cracks and screams and animalistic roars.

â€œDo you have, like, an attractive expression?â€ù his camerawoman, Lou McLoughlan, suggests, watching him practice different looks in the bathroom mirror. Her amusingly direct comments, along with Cat Bruceâ€™s adorable cartoons and the knowing advice of Mr. Harrisâ€™s friend Ben (whose own mop is a marvel of carefully controlled anarchy), inject a lightness that elbows aside the psychological hurt. By the time we visit a ginger festival in the Netherlands, where tresses from russet to strawberry blaze with pride, the tone is positively buoyant.

Sweet, funny and ultimately rather touching, this rudimentary record of Mr. Harrisâ€™s quest to overcome the romantic barrier of his carrot top walks a wavery line between dating odyssey and meditation on the scars of the schoolyard. Bullied mercilessly during his Kentucky childhood, he later decided as a film student in Edinburgh â€” chosen, perhaps, for its high concentration of redheads â€” to turn the camera on his own pain.

The result is as messy and awkward as you might expect. But as Mr. Harris trawls a special website for lovelorn gingers and accosts passers-by to chat about hair color â€” and get a phone number or two â€” his candor and vulnerability are enormously endearing.

For most of â€œBeing Ginger,â€ù its flame-haired maker and subject, Scott P. Harris, thinks heâ€™s looking for a woman who will love him. What heâ€™s really searching for, however, is a way to love himself.
Yet Mr. Harris may still have a way to go; as any woman will tell you, a man with no confidence can be a much bigger turnoff than one with locks that seem lit from within.

â€œFlex Is Kings,â€ùa documentary about a street dancing style â€” from East New York, Brooklyn â€” reminiscent of vogueing, break dancing, and miming, concentrates on two performers. One is Flizzo, who says in the film that his grandmother described these dancers as looking as if they were having strokes.

Flizzo is gregarious, stout and feeling the financial pressure of a new baby as he prepares for Battlefest, a competition for flex dancing organized without much funding by devotees to the movement. The other main subject is Jay Donn, a mask-wearing performer who is cast as the lead in a Carroll Gardens dance companyâ€™s rendition of â€œPinocchio.â€ù The group, Company XIV, ends up debuting the show at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe.

Directed by Michael Beach Nichols and Deidre Schoo (a photographer and regular contributor to The New York Times), the film creates narrative tension between the improvised street style and the more formal modern performance. Because of the rote and typical way of organizing a dance movie around a contest, the pace and interest lag even though the images and characters are fascinating. Yet the film is worth watching because of the strong cinematography and the glimpses of strange beauty in the dance moves.
â€œFrankie & Aliceâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), mostly for a smattering of harsh language.

Ms. Berry plays Frankie, a go-go dancer who struggles to understand her bursts of odd behavior and frequent blackouts. Stellan Skarsgard is the psychotherapist who begins to suspect dissociative identity disorder and documents the personalities inhabiting Frankie. Yes, this is a serious condition, and yes, Ms. Berry does as well as anyone could with the formulaic script. Yet when she abruptly switches to the voice of a young child or of a white Southern racist â€” two of the alternate personalities â€” itâ€™s hard not to flash back to some humorous working of the same territory. (Think of Toni Collette in the Showtime series â€œUnited States of Tara.â€ù) It may be that this genre has been forever ruined, or just that it requires a more subtle hand than the one exhibited by Geoffrey Sax, the director here.

Multiple-personality roles are always difficult to sell to an audience because they have been parodied so often, a problem Halle Berry never quite banishes in â€œFrankie & Alice,â€ù an earnest drama said to be based on a true story.

And perhaps that has contributed to this filmâ€™s odd history. It was shot back in the last decade and then given a very limited awards-season release in late 2010. (Ms. Berry was nominated for a Golden Globe.) Then it disappeared, until now. In any case, Ms. Berry does a decent job with the role, and the film treats its subject matter respectfully, but the overall package doesnâ€™t rise above ordinariness.

â€œThe Galapagos Affairâ€ù would be a much stronger film were it not padded with the dull reminiscences and speculation of the settlersâ€™ descendants. It is profusely illustrated with photographs and vintage home movies, and augmented by excerpts from diaries and journals read by actors assuming the voices of Ritter (Thomas Kretschmann), Strauch (Cate Blanchett), Heinz (Sebastian Koch), Margret (Diane Kruger) and the Baroness (Connie Nielsen). The weirdest scene is a one-reel home movie of the Baroness and Robert preening before the camera.

The settlers may have hoped to forsake the outside world, but the European newspapers and magazines of the day kept tabs on them as best they could and published mostly fanciful stories. The film reconstructs a social history of Floreana from the arrival of Ritter and Strauch until 1934, when this island of fractious pioneers disintegrated after a drought and two possible murders.

â€œThe Galapagos Affair: Satan Came to Edenâ€ù is a darkly amusing historical documentary about the fruitless search for paradise on Earth by vainglorious, world-weary dreamers who set themselves above, and apart from, the rest of humanity. The heart of the film â€” directed by Dayna Goldfine and Dan Geller (â€œBallets Russesâ€ù), who wrote the screenplay with Celeste Schaefer Snyder â€” is a hybrid of juicy period soap opera and â€œSurvivor.â€ù

At the start of the movie, we learn of the Curse of the Giant Tortoise, a creature that, local legend had it, could read the dirty secrets in the minds of visitors to the islands. In a shot of a tortoiseâ€™s scaly face, it appears to wear a knowing smirk.

Paradise, as shown in the film, looks far from hospitable, and the couple toiled ceaselessly just to survive. Ritter, a vegetarian and ardent devotee of Friedrich Nietzscheâ€™s Superman philosophy, is remembered as a crackpot genius manquÃ© who discovered he had little time left over to concentrate on the major philosophical works he planned to write.

The lessons, although obvious, bear repeating. Wherever you go, you canâ€™t get away from yourself. Once your private space is breached, the usual power struggles inevitably come into play. Even in paradise, you canâ€™t escape your humanity.

The movie focuses on the eccentrics who, beginning in 1929, settled on Floreana, a small, uninhabited island in the remote GalÃ¡pagos archipelago, 575 miles west of Ecuador in the southern Pacific. Its original Adam and Eve â€” Friedrich Ritter, a German physician, and his younger lover, Dore Strauch, who were both married to others â€” abandoned their mates to put down roots in this supposed Eden. So what if Dore was weakened by multiple sclerosis and had limited stamina? They were determined to go it alone.

Next came Eloise von Wagner Bosquet, an imperious, self-described baroness who was accompanied by two younger gigolos, Robert and Rudolf, whom she introduced as the architect and engineer of a grand hotel she hoped to build. A toothy, bright-eyed diva with an avid gleam in her eye, she never went anywhere without her most cherished possession, a copy of Oscar Wildeâ€™s â€œThe Picture of Dorian Gray.â€ù Shortly after her arrival, she unilaterally proclaimed herself the islandâ€™s â€œempress.â€ù

An autocratic taskmaster and full-scale misanthrope, Ritter was nobodyâ€™s idea of a friendly neighbor. And when another German couple â€” Heinz and Margret Wittmer, inspired by his example â€” arrived on the island, he shunned them as best he could. The mystery at the movieâ€™s heart revolves around the disappearance of the Baroness shortly after she announced she would resettle on Tahiti with Robert. As these overwritten characters cope and make fresh romantic missteps, the movie cruises obliviously along, littered with glib dialogue and howler developments. A pair of rogue National Guardsmen appear and turn out to be bullies, adding an edge of life-or-death menace, and thereâ€™s a glimmer of interest in this generationâ€™s living up to past ideals (reminiscent of baby boomer dilemmas). But for all the outside threats and watchable cast members, the story falls apart from within.

The occasion for disaster is a global cellphone virus, followed by street violence and an inexplicably immediate breakdown in the social order. But the opening voice-over sets a semi-casual tone: After quoting from â€œWalden,â€ù James (Adrian Grenier) explains that he and his weed-loving wife, Lily (Kerry BishÃ©), had already sold a company and moved off the grid before everything went kaput.

If its premise didnâ€™t involve the collapse of civilization, â€œGoodbye Worldâ€ù could be a pilot episode for a TV drama about attractive, self-absorbed professionals in their 30s. Prettily shot in Mendocino, Calif., Denis Hennellyâ€™s glide of a movie coops up old friends in a secluded country house and watches them natter about love and money while the world burns.

The global meltdown occurs during a visit by Jamesâ€™s former business partner, Nick (Ben McKenzie), and his libertarian wife, Becky (Caroline Dhavernas). Late additions to the retreat include a lecture circuit radical, Benji (Mark Webber); a suicidal hacker, Lev (Kid Cudi); and a disgraced former government security employee, Laura (Gaby Hoffmann).

â€œThe Winter Soldierâ€ù becomes progressively less enjoyable once the plot thickens and a menace looms, as Fury moves one chess piece, while Pierce moves another. Captain America doesnâ€™t move much, beyond cars and debris. However appealing, Mr. Evans remains a recessive screen presence, and while it may be a relief that Captain America isnâ€™t angst-ridden, heâ€™s blandly well adjusted for a guy who, in his last movie, emerged from a decades-long deep freeze. Comic-book movie directors have to sell the prepackaged goods while trying to capture â€” and maybe redefine, as Christopher Nolan did with Batman â€” a superheroâ€™s essence. And they have to do so without boring everyone who could not care less why a crusader went dark as night or that he died only to be reborn. But what if heâ€™s kind of dull?

As with every new chapter in such series, introductions must be made in â€œThe Winter Soldierâ€ù so that nonenthusiasts can meet the team members and grasp their place in this cosmos. Here, these include Bucky Barnes (a good Sebastian Stan), Natasha Romanoff a.k.a. Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson) and Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson), who run S.H.I.E.L.D., the spy agency that here gives the movie its topical gloss. Kevin Feige, who runs Marvel Studios, has said that the Russos were hired as directors â€œbecause they loved our explanation that we really want to make a â€™70s political thriller masquerading as a big superhero movie.â€ù Thatâ€™s the idea anyway, which explains why Robert Redford, the star of â€™70 paranoid classics like â€œThree Days of the Condor,â€ù plays Alexander Pierce, a S.H.I.E.L.D. official.

Itâ€™s fun until it goes kablooey, when the directors, the brothers Anthony and Joe Russo, are first warming up this sequel and scratching their initials next to the Marvel logo. The ticklish, loose opener finds Steve Rogers (Mr. Evans), Captain Americaâ€™s Everyman alter ego, running laps around the Lincoln Memorial Reflecting Pool. Heâ€™s making such a good cartoonish time â€” heâ€™s super in and out of costume â€” that he keeps lapping another runner while yelling, â€œOn your left!â€ù The laggard is Sam Wilson (the unfailingly charming Anthony Mackie), who becomes a down-to-earth friend and high-flying ally. (Itâ€™s nice to see talented American actors get some of the rewarding franchise action enjoyed by their British counterparts with Harry Potter.)

Heresy! Yet one of the problems with Captain America, who was introduced in 1941, is that he didnâ€™t cross over into the mainstream until three years ago with â€œCaptain America: The First Avenger.â€ù Directed by Joe Johnston, who wisely kept the irony in check, â€œThe First Avengerâ€ù hit the origin-story marks by tracing the metamorphosis of a 90-pound weakling into a World War II hero while showing that Mr. Evans could wear the suit and throw a punch. It was amusing, old-fashioned and ponderous, just like its protagonist. The sequel, which was also written by Christopher Markus and Stephen McFeely, suffers from some routine blockbuster sins, including an excess of plot. But it, too, doesnâ€™t make the case on screen for why Captain America should have been taken out of mothballs.
â€œCaptain America: The Winter Soldierâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Comic-book movie mayhem.
Itâ€™s a bird, itâ€™s a plane â€” oh, wait, itâ€™s Captain America.

Given how little creative wiggle room there is in properties like â€œThe Winter Soldier,â€ù itâ€™s a minor triumph that the Russos imprint any personality on the movie, which is less a stand-alone work than a part of an ever-expanding multimedia enterprise. The directors make their presence felt largely in the first half when theyâ€™re emphasizing Steveâ€™s humanity, whether heâ€™s in costume or not. Thatâ€™s partly the point of his introductory race around the reflecting pool: He runs like the wind, but he also makes you laugh. This emphasis on the human also spills over into some exciting, smartly staged and shot action sequences, including choreographed fights in which the entire bodies of the performers remain visible in the frame and arenâ€™t dissected by the camera and editing.

Despite Mr. Evansâ€™s stated  lack of passion for playing super-characters like this one and despite the genreâ€™s creeping exhaustion, Captain America seems likely to keep running and jumping. Unlike the James Bond movies, which have dribbled out fairly slowly or a series like Harry Potter, which has a finite number of exploitable titles, there appears to be no end in sight when it comes to superhero movies. Warner Bros. has introduced Batman twice in separate franchise cycles and Sony has done the same, at a faster clip, with Spider-Man. In other words, superhero stories have become, or at least some would claim, the Hollywood equivalent of, say, Shakespeare: a well that they return to again and again to reboot, remake, redesign and resell until death (ours, the artâ€™s, the planetâ€™s) do us part.

The costume looks different, of course, as does the looker (Chris Evans) squeezed into the form-fitting corporate brand. But, gee, it can be hard keeping track of all the men flying and fighting in the superhero cinematic universe. Next up is yet another Spider-Man movie, and then come the X-Men, and then the Guardians of the Galaxy, and then (again) the Avengers, whose numbers include Captain America. So, heâ€™ll be back. Meanwhile, he has another movie to call his own, â€œCaptain America: The Winter Soldier,â€ù one that, like many others of its type, gets off to a kinetic start only to lose steam before blowing everything up.

The Russos have directed a few other movies, including â€œWelcome to Collinwoodâ€ù (2002), a redo of the 1958 Italian satire â€œBig Deal on Madonna Streetâ€ù that was produced by Steven Soderbergh and George Clooney. That movie didnâ€™t go anywhere, but, having been put on the industry map with that kind of patronage, itâ€™s no surprise that the brothers went on to have a busy decade in television, working as directors and sometimes executive producers for the smart sitcom likes of â€œArrested Developmentâ€ù and â€œCommunity.â€ù In between, they also directed another movie, â€œYou, Me and Dupree.â€ù It was a dud, but it didnâ€™t matter. In the magical world of big-screen entertainment, some guys get all the breaks and also the keys to the studio gate, meaning a franchise like this.

This is less a matter of judgment than of Mr. von Trierâ€™s intentions. There are gloom and violence in Volume I â€” the illness of a beloved father, cuts and bruises on the face of the main character, a woman named Joe â€” but there is also a fair amount of queasy, nasty comedy. Also, some pseudo-hard-core sex, as the director, deftly manipulating the audienceâ€™s prurience (or our squeamishness, which amounts to the same thing), evokes both the intensity and the absurdity of Joeâ€™s erotic pursuits. Played, as a young woman, by Stacy Martin in flashbacks that are narrated by her older self (Charlotte Gainsbourg), Joe is a reckless, mostly fearless adventurer, exploring her desire and her sexual power.

The notion that unleashed female sexuality constitutes a threat to the order of things is one that can have both feminist and misogynist possibilities. Mr. von Trier plays with both, but his inquiries are blocked by his dogmatic ideas about human nature, which he views as fundamentally predatory and destructive. To believe otherwise is to be a monster or a fool, and to insist on the baseness of the species is a mark of intellectual and artistic honesty.

To keep our interest, Mr. von Trier falls back on some old tricks. He is a master of intimate dread, at moving his camera past the comfort zone into psychic and visual territory fraught with danger and shame. The scenes between Joe and a man she calls K (Jamie Bell), who tends to her needs with the help of rope, duct tape and a riding crop but refuses more conventional sexual relations, show an intriguing, unnerving blend of tenderness and cruelty. But at other moments, you are mostly aware of the effort being made to freak you out. A sequence that echoes the beginning of â€œAntichristâ€ù â€” in which a young child is lethally endangered by parental neglect â€” feels crude and unimaginative the second time around.

The problem with â€œNymphomaniac: Volume IIâ€ù lies not in its display of erect penises and reddened buttocks, but rather in its dull narrative and overworked ideas. We learn a bit more about Seligman, whose erudition is a precise match for Joeâ€™s promiscuity: He can supply a classical or philosophical footnote to any kink in the book. A lot happens to Joe (who is now played by Ms. Gainsbourg in both the flashbacks and the framing narrative). She becomes a mother, drifts into therapy, finds a new career as a debt collector and acquires a pretty young protÃ©gÃ©e (Mia Goth). But as the movie chronicles these developments, it wanders and slackens.

Eventually, though, there is something of a payoff. We learn how Joe suffered the beating that brought her to Seligmanâ€™s attention, and we are also allowed to glimpse the possible moral of her story. Her nymphomania â€” she defiantly refuses to call it sex addiction, the preferred term in her therapy group â€” is a challenge to the sentimentality and hypocrisy of what she and Seligman like to call â€œsociety.â€ù

Lars von Trierâ€™s latest movie, â€œNymphomaniac,â€ù is being released in two sections and two formats. As of Friday, both â€œvolumesâ€ù can be seen in theaters or, for the lazy or easily embarrassed, on various on-demand platforms. The division is a little awkward, but it makes a certain thematic sense. â€œVolume I,â€ù which was reviewed here two weeks ago, is (relatively speaking) the fun part.

But even to claim as much is to risk falling into bourgeois ideology, and Mr. von Trier has one last trick up his sleeve to prevent that from happening. The end of â€œNymphomaniacâ€ù seems to drift toward tenderness and empathy, a destination that may provoke some incredulity. Lars, you old softy, are you joking? Donâ€™t worry: He is.

We knew from the outset that things would go wrong. Joe is telling her story to Seligman (Stellan Skarsgard), a bookish, middle-aged fellow who found her beaten in an alley. And, at the start of Volume II, she warns that the tale is about to take a dark turn. The scholarly Seligman associates this shift in tone with the schism that split the Christian church into Eastern and Western branches. Having dabbled in the sunlight of Constantinople, we are now steering toward the guilty shadows of Rome. (Any theological quibbles with this metaphor should be taken up with the filmmaker.)

When Joe, who lives with a nice-enough fellow named JerÃ´me (Shia LaBeouf, doing his best), loses her ability to reach orgasm, her sex life turns desperate and kinky, and Mr. von Trierâ€™s Puritanism peeks out from behind the facade of provocation. Joeâ€™s forays into interracial group sex and sadomasochism are conveyed with a judgmental leer directed less at her than at the viewers, who will show themselves to be either perverts or prudes.

In an early scene on a beach, she observes the attempted rescue of a swimmer buffeted in heavy surf as a baby at the far end of the sand cries. When the rescuer emerges from the water and collapses, she approaches him and beats him to death with a rock as the baby continues to wail. She seems utterly indifferent. One hitchhiker has a disfigured face like that of the Elephant Man, but she seems not to notice and tells him he has beautiful hands.

In Michel Faberâ€™s satirical novel, from which the film was adapted by Mr. Glazer (â€œSexy Beast,â€ù â€œBirthâ€ù) and Walter Campbell, her character, unidentified in the film, is named Isserley. That eye belongs to Ms. Johansson, whose character later appears as the driver of a white van that makes its way through the crowded streets of Glasgow. Late in the movie, Ms. Johanssonâ€™s character appears to become more human and vulnerable after a sexual interlude with a man she picks up. A connection has been made. Ms. Johanssonâ€™s luscious, cherry-red lips, onto which she is shown daubing deeper shades of crimson, seem to have an extra cushion of softness. But instead of a seemingly empathetic cyberfriend, she turns out to be a heartless humanoid temptress from outer space.

â€œUnder the Skinâ€ù was filmed in tones of darkness. Ms. Johanssonâ€™s expressionless character is frequently seen in shadow, out of which she emerges like a film-noir vamp. The van was equipped with tiny surveillance cameras to capture her interactions with the victims, real-life hitchhikers unaware that they were being filmed. â€œUnder the Skinâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for graphic nudity, some sexual content, mild violence and strong language.

In the movieâ€™s striking opening sequence, this otherworldly siren first appears as a speck of light that expands into a disc, which forms into an unblinking eye. Scarlett Johansson as an extraterrestrial femme fatale cruising the streets of Glasgow in Jonathan Glazerâ€™s cerebral sci-fi horror fantasy â€œUnder the Skinâ€ù is an indelible personification of predatory allure. â€œIn the Bloodâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for violence, strong language and crimes against a promising action star.

She plays Ava, who was raised to be a fighting machine by her drug lord father (Mr. Lang). Free Gina Carano! This former mixed-martial artist has plummeted from the heights and all-star cast of â€œHaywireâ€ù â€” Steven Soderberghâ€™s delightful 2012 revenge thriller â€” and now, after a supporting role in â€œFast & Furious 6,â€ù appears trapped in B-film depths. What those might be is not this filmâ€™s primary concern. Always arresting and sometimes troubling, â€œWatermarkâ€ù â€” aside from the odd comment here and there â€” neither lectures nor argues. Moving serenely from inscrutable tight shots to wide-scale aerial vistas, the film can be frustratingly oblique: Thereâ€™s nothing bewildering in the millions of Hindus enjoying a ritual bath in the Ganges, but what about those copper-colored containers dangling in the bowels of a colossal Chinese dam? Whatever theyâ€™re up to â€” like the destination of the foaming sludge exiting a leather-tanning operation in Bangladesh â€” we may never know; it just feels like no good.

A gargantuan wall of roiling, nicotine-brown water gives way to a parched riverbed where bleached branches decorate the baked earth like skulls. The images, captured in ultrahigh definition by Nicholas de Pencier, are primal and striking, presented initially without identification or narration. In a general sense, we know what weâ€™re looking at, but the specifics remain stubbornly veiled.

So goes much of â€œWatermark,â€ù Jennifer Baichwal and Edward Burtynskyâ€™s second investigation (after â€œManufactured Landscapesâ€ù in 2007) into the impact of human beings on the natural world. Driven by the question â€œHow does water shape us, and then how do we shape water?,â€ù Ms. Baichwal and Mr. Burtynsky, a photographer noted for his large-scale industrial panoramas, travel across 10 countries and countless human activities, seeking an answer. From the denatured Colorado River delta to abalone fisheries along Chinaâ€™s Fujian coast, the filmmakers find a species in thrall to H2O and largely heedless of the consequences of its unnatural manipulation.

Pierre Dulaine, a teacherÂ andÂ former champion in ballroom dancing, is the founder of Dancing Classrooms, a nonprofit organization behind the events in Marilyn Agreloâ€™s 2005 documentary, â€œMad Hot Ballroom.â€ù That film concerned Dancing Classroomsâ€™ work with New York students; in Hilla Medaliaâ€™sÂ charming â€œDancing in Jaffa,â€ùÂ Mr. Dulaine heads to Israel to try to instill mutual respect in 10- and 11-year-old Jewish and Palestinian Israelis through a 10-week course in the movements (and courtesies) of Latin dance.

Predictably, the film culminates in a dance competition, irresistible to behold and leading to an ending just about too pat to believe. The filmâ€™s comforting denouement almost disperses any worries about what a fraught society these preteenagers stand to inherit.

Mr. Dulaine, a Jaffa native born to an Irish father and a Palestinian mother (the family left Israel in 1948), instructs at five schools, some mainly Palestinian, some mainly Jewish, one a blend of both. Though he admits to a particular concern for his Palestinian students (â€œI would like to give them a chance to better themselvesâ€ù), he is equally firm yet considerate with all his charges. As if acrimonious protests on Israelâ€™s Independence Day didnâ€™t add enough tension to the lives of these young people, there are budding hormones to contend with. But Noor evolves from â€œa closed flowerâ€ù (in a teacherâ€™s words) to a confident girl, and Alaa and Lois strike a friendship.

Thatâ€™s the sort of thing that happens periodically in films from FranÃ§ois Truffaut or Arnaud Desplechin, but not for the entirety of the running time. Asha, a bubbly Indian student at a Prague film school, reaches out to Hank, a filmmaker whoâ€™s a lonely Southerner newly arrived in New York, after seeing his documentary. Their exchanges soon shift from fan mail to pen pal confidences to something like a progression of dates. Throughout, the director, James E. Duff, and his writing partner, Julia Morrison, mostly show each of them head-on, as on a webcam, with occasional tourist bureau sightseeing jaunts.

Cutesy pop music montages occasionally ruin the moment (even if they are supposed to be the work of Hank or Asha). Though ultimately more disappointing than any correspondence might be, this is a movie by people who honor the pleasures of waiting, wondering and longing in an instantaneous world.

A rare sustained epistolary romance, â€œHank and Ashaâ€ù runs on video recordings instead of pen and paper. Though not very ambitious, this winsome, whisper-thin tale shimmers along with the charming urge to connect and reveal yourself that links its two correspondents.

When Johanna takes up her new position, keeping house for Mr. McCauley (Nick Nolte), a rich, elderly man, and looking after his teenage granddaughter, Sabitha (Hailee Steinfeld), she seems like a creature from another time, a Victorian servant out of Charles Dickens or Charlotte BrontÃ«. The film, transplanted to Iowa (and filmed mostly in Louisiana), has a slightly out-of-time feeling. In spite of some updating â€” email has replaced typewritten letters in one crucial plot turn, and a neâ€™er-do-well has been turned into a drug addict â€” â€œHateship Loveshipâ€ù unfolds in a fuzzily imagined small-town world, where painful secrets and buried hurts do battle with kindness and redemption.

The filmmaking feels indecisive: Scenes trail off; emotions are blurred; the narrative organization seems slack and haphazard. But the cast members â€” Christine Lahti and Jennifer Jason Leigh in important small parts, along with everyone else Iâ€™ve mentioned â€” bring enormous credibility to their roles, and Ms. Johnson has clearly directed them with tact and generosity. She has also held onto the most important aspects of Johannaâ€™s temperament, which reveal themselves slowly and slyly as she makes her way in the world: her passion, her stubbornness and her wit.

The social specificity that forms the hard backbone of Ms. Munroâ€™s studies of men and women in various states of distress has been stripped away on the journey from page to screen, and Ms. Johnson and the screenwriter, Mark Jude Poirier, have transformed a taciturn masterpiece into an absorbing, messy, modest story of damaged relationships. Sabitha, whose mother died in an accident, is a suspicious, sullen girl, encouraged by her friend Edith (Sami Gayle) to play a cruel prank on Johanna. The result is that Johanna falls in love with Sabithaâ€™s father, Ken (Guy Pearce), an ex-convict who lives in an abandoned Chicago motel that he vaguely intends to fix up.
â€œHateship Loveshipâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex and drug use.

In the first moments of our acquaintance with Johanna Parry â€” before the opening titles of â€œHateship Loveshipâ€ù appear on screen, and before the first notes of music have sounded â€” we know some important things about her. We note her kindness as she grants an old womanâ€™s dying wish, and also her practicality and physical strength. Other people will perceive Johanna as drab, passive and unworldly, a person to be quietly mocked or carelessly ignored, but the first shots of Liza Johnsonâ€™s new film, adapted from a story by the Canadian Nobel laureate Alice Munro, provide important evidence to the contrary.

There is also the fact that Johanna is played by Kristen Wiig, a quick-thinking, fearless and unpredictable comic actress taking the lead role in a movie that carefully rations its humor. Even when her characters are dim, daffy or prone to bad judgment (letâ€™s say in â€œAnchorman 2â€ù or â€œBridesmaidsâ€ù), they are always capable of showing self-awareness or taking initiative. Knowing this about Ms. Wiig may color our expectations of Johanna, or at least inform our sense of her strangeness. (â€œHateship Loveshipâ€ù also invites comparison with â€œEverything Must Go,â€ù another low-key short-story adaptation starring a former â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ù cast member; what Will Ferrell did for Raymond Carver in that film, Ms. Wiig does for Ms. Munro in this one.)

At a media ethics talk excerpted toward the end of â€œA Fragile Trust,â€ù an audience member asks the speaker, Jayson Blair, why anyone should ever believe him. That question isnâ€™t satisfactorily addressed in Samantha Grantâ€™s documentary, a decade-later excavation of the scandal involving Mr. Blair at The New York Times. Itâ€™s not as if this superficial accounting of his offenses offered evidence of renewed credibility.
