The most haunted interviewee is Howell Raines, who resigned as executive editor after the revelations. Mr. Raines says that itâ€™s too late to place blame for his failure to heed a colleagueâ€™s warning memo (â€œit simply never reached my deskâ€ù) and suggests that he might have lightened his leadership touch had he remained.

Lightness of touch is missing from the film, which features animated graphics and an ominous score. This style is familiar from Errol Morrisâ€™s documentaries, but â€œA Fragile Trustâ€ù is far less successful at conjuring ambiguity or mystery.

Mr. Blairâ€™s fabrication and plagiarism became the subject of an unprecedented â€œCorrecting the Recordâ€ù article in May 2003; Ms. Grant recounts some of the same material. But the hypothetical draw is Mr. Blair himself. Reflective in tone, he says â€œthere isnâ€™t a simple one answerâ€ù to why he began to fake his reporting, citing substance abuse, bipolar disorder and the competitive nature of deadline journalism.
â€œCuban Furyâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strong language and sexual references.

Comedy, romantic and otherwise, has shuttled back and forth across the Atlantic over the years, picking up a band of horny buddies here, some mumbling self-deprecation there. â€œCuban Furyâ€ù (which has both) stars the British comic Nick Frost as Bruce, a former child salsa-dancing champ. But despite the overblown title, the movie is milder than a Will Ferrell drag vehicle and more of an ordinary shy-guy-makes-good yarn punched up with some recurring bits.

Not that some of this isnâ€™t amusing, but you feel the considerable improvisational skills of the cast going to waste. Mr. Frost, except perhaps when whaling on Mr. Oâ€™Dowd in a dance-off, canâ€™t have too much fun with this character, and heâ€™s missing the sort of gleeful bonhomie he shares with his frequent co-conspirator Simon Pegg (who makes a drive-by cameo). And though the movie is laced with salsa by Tito Puente and shot in wide screen, itâ€™s hard to be very passionate about it.

A sequined dervish as a child, Bruce is now a doughy, successful engineer with a crush on his officeâ€™s new American boss, Julia (Rashida Jones). When he returns to dancing, in part to woo her, â€œCuban Furyâ€ù proves fairly restrained at treating him like a dancing bear. But thereâ€™s plenty of razzing by a sleazy colleague (Chris Oâ€™Dowd), and joshing from pals and a helpful diva (Kayvan Novak). Bruceâ€™s sister (Olivia Colman) gives him pep talks, which are some of the worst examples of weak-tea filler by the screenwriter, Jon Brown.

Based on the director Mike Flanaganâ€™s own 2006 short, â€œOculusâ€ù sticks to a modest scale. Released from a mental hospital on his 21st birthday, Tim (Brenton Thwaites) reunites with his sister, Kaylie (Karen Gillan, right). Sheâ€™s concocted a plan to prove that their fatherâ€™s homicidal rage wasnâ€™t free will, and that their parentsâ€™ madness was caused by the Lasser Glass, supposedly the source of at least 45 deaths over four centuries.
â€œOculusâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Masticated light bulb, Mom on a dog chain.

Correlation, not causation, Tim scoffs. Kaylie, on the other hand, seeks to record evidence of a supernatural presence, training three cameras on the mirror and using alarm clocks and timed phone calls to interrupt the hallucinations it induces. The mirror soon resumes its repertoire, wilting nearby plants and convincing Kaylie that a light bulb is an apple.

That photography can create illusions is, of course, a fundamental premise of cinema. â€œOculusâ€ù plays on that notion, confounding distinctions among reality, fantasy and dream sequences. Doubling as editor, Mr. Flanagan crosscuts between flashbacks and the present, sometimes even uniting the two story lines in the same shot. The elegant use of wide screen canâ€™t totally obscure stiff acting, and the rug pulling finally seems arbitrary. When nothing can be trusted, the mirage of suspense disappears.

Donâ€™t try to outwit a haunted mirror: It can see you. Thatâ€™s the moral of â€œOculus,â€ù a derivative but efficient chiller that cribs from â€œSolaris,â€ù â€œThe Shiningâ€ù and â€œThe Amityville Horrorâ€ù yet also shows glimmers of imagination.

Thatâ€™s a lot for one man to handle, but Sonny has some personal baggage to go with his professional burdens. In other words, this man-crowded movie also has a few women in it. Sonnyâ€™s office romance â€” with Ali (Jennifer Garner), a younger executive in charge of the teamâ€™s salary-cap compliance â€” has taken a turn toward unexpected parenthood. Sonny has plenty of guilt about his own father, a beloved Cleveland coach and local hero whom he fired and who has just died. On the most stressful day of the off season, Sonnyâ€™s mother (Ellen Burstyn) and former wife (Rosanna Arquette) show up in his office with emotional demands and an urn full of ashes.

Sonny has to pick the right college players to help lift his team, the Cleveland Browns, out of the doldrums. Will he choose the seemingly flawless, Heisman Trophy-winning quarterback (Josh Pence), the good-hearted linebacker (Chadwick Boseman) or the talented but possibly troubled running back (Arian Foster)? The answer is telegraphed early, but the fun lies in watching Sonny hustle, bluster and beg his way toward a conclusion that is both predictable and exciting. In addition to rival general managers, he must contend with the Brownsâ€™ imperious owner (Frank Langella) and their pugnacious coach (Denis Leary). There are also a geeky intern (Griffin Newman), an angry quarterback (Tom Welling) and an office suite full of ex- and would-be jocks.

For his part, the director, Ivan Reitman, does an efficient job disguising this marshmallowy melodrama of masculinity in crisis as a tough sports movie. â€œDraft Day,â€ù with a ticking-clock plot and a testosterone-saturated setting, trots along briskly, even though most of the action consists of rushed cellphone negotiations. A sinuous split-screen technique cleverly adds momentum to a series of static conversations, though it is finally Mr. Costnerâ€™s charisma that weaves it all together.

Mr. Costner handles it all with his usual gruff grace, allowing you to entertain the possibility that he might be a jerk or a loser just long enough to be gratified when he turns out to be a great guy in every way. He has a knack for making born winners look like underdogs, and for making you root for him at his most brazenly manipulative. I donâ€™t really buy â€œDraft Dayâ€ù â€” itâ€™s a shallow and evasive movie, built more around corporate wish fulfillment than around reality â€” but I have to say that it sells itself beautifully.

Kevin Costner is one of the great salesmen in American movies, a natural-born closer. Heâ€™ll look you in the eye, start in with the pitch, and the next thing you know, you almost believe that Donald Sutherland and Lyndon Johnson killed Kennedy; that if you build a ballpark in the middle of a cornfield, â€œthey will comeâ€ù; and that â€œDances With Wolvesâ€ù is a better picture than â€œGoodfellas.â€ù Something about him â€” the baby blues, the slightly weak chin, the aw-shucks manner, at once aggressive and self-effacing â€” makes him hard to resist, even when you know youâ€™re being conned. Thatâ€™s part of the appeal.

Lately, Mr. Costner hasnâ€™t been around much, and his newest film projects, â€œ3 Days to Killâ€ù and now â€œDraft Day,â€ù are not exactly what youâ€™d call the Glengarry leads. But every salesmanâ€™s real product is himself, and in â€œDraft Day,â€ù especially, playing the beleaguered general manager of a professional football team, Mr. Costner revels in his undiminished powers of persuasion. His face is softer than it used to be, and his body is a little thicker and slower-moving, but his voice is still a marvel. There is no real difference between what this movie is about and what it displays: an aging professional doing his job. Like his character, Sonny Weaver Jr., Mr. Costner is very good at his, though sometimes apt to be underestimated.
â€œDraft Dayâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Some rough language.

â€œDraft Day,â€ù made with what appears to be the very enthusiastic â€” not to say domineering â€” cooperation of the N.F.L., is less a football movie than a promotional film. You will see sweeping aerial shots of skylines and stadiums in franchise cities. You will see the leagueâ€™s commissioner, Roger Goodell, and a bunch of players and executives, past and present, gamely portraying themselves. You will not hear anything about concussions or sexual assault or the exploitation of college athletes, though you may notice that this is a story of (mostly) white men buying and selling the labor of (mostly) African-Americans. But the spectacle of guys in suits making deals is nonetheless pretty entertaining, and while this film doesnâ€™t have the fussy authenticity of â€œMoneyball,â€ù it does offer a reasonably clear and convincing glimpse of the business of big-time sports.

Mr. Reitman, like his star a onetime powerhouse who could use a comeback, finds the mix of slick, antic comedy and reassuring sensitivity that made him one of the top Hollywood hacks of the 1980s and â€™90s. I donâ€™t mean this as an insult. â€œGhostbustersâ€ù is a wonderful movie, and â€œDaveâ€ù is delightful, but even those high-concept Arnold Schwarzenegger farces (â€œTwins,â€ù â€œKindergarten Cop,â€ù â€œJuniorâ€ù) are more fun than they have any right to be. Really!

From the start, â€œJoeâ€ù reads as a quasi-biblical parable in which Joeâ€™s good and bad instincts are at war. It leads to a grisly but ultimately anticlimactic showdown in which Joe goes after Willie and Wade, who have joined forces in a kidnapping scheme.

In a scene that illustrates the movieâ€™s bestial view of humanity, Joe brings his beloved brown-and-white bulldog to a brothel, where he leaves the animal to fight with another unleashed dog while he enjoys a quickie with a prostitute.

Mr. Cage gives his most committed performance in years as this divided soul, but it still looks like acting when compared with Mr. Poulterâ€™s embodiment of pure evil. No glib psychological explanation is offered to explain Wade, a predator whose hatred of the world leaks out of his eyes like a toxin that canâ€™t be contained in his wiry body. Like snakes, some men are born venomous.

This is a society in which women shrink into the background, and the men seem to subsist on cigarettes and cheap liquor, which they swill from the bottle and use to fuel a rage that makes them feel alive. Itâ€™s all they can do not to kill one another.

At the heart of the movie stands its conflicted title character, Joe (Nicolas Cage), the good-bad supervisor of the tree poisoners. A hothead who has served time in a penitentiary, Joe is watched wherever he goes by the police, who try to goad him into lashing out. Also hounding Joe is Willie (Ronnie Gene Blevins), a snarling scar-faced sociopath who has been stalking him with a gun since they tangled in a bar.

The local color is so pungent that it overwhelms the too-sentimental story of Joeâ€™s redemptive mentoring of an ingenuous, hardy 15-year-old boy, Gary (Tye Sheridan, seen in â€œThe Tree of Lifeâ€ù and â€œMudâ€ù), who approaches Joe in the pine lands looking for work. As the days pass, Joe warms to Gary and becomes a surrogate father to someone who needs all the paternal encouragement he can get.

Garyâ€™s real father, Wade (Gary Poulter, a nonprofessional actor who died after â€œJoeâ€ù was completed), is a violent drunk and scraggly parasite with a cowering wife and an abused daughter too traumatized to speak. Once Gary starts working for Joe, Wade begins stealing his cash and beating him up. Wade is a wild creature not unlike the poisonous snake Joe catches early in the movie.

Dogs are everywhere, barking, snarling, snapping and straining at their leashes whenever a stranger approaches a house. In one of the more disturbing, if unsubtle, comparisons the movie makes, â€œJoeâ€ù wonders: Which are more feral, the dogs or their human keepers? Throughout the film, the dog-eat-dog metaphor is worked nearly to death.

Watching these early scenes in the movie, whose screenplay was adapted by Gary Hawkins from a 1990 novel by Larry Brown, I had the sensation of being thrust into a primitive, half-forgotten world, somewhere out of time. Brought to scorching life by Mr. Greenâ€™s longtime cinematographer Tim Orr, it registers as simultaneously ordinary and mythic, the wild, scruffy landscape evoking the tragic weight of American history. These ignorant, desperate rural poor people are so cut off from modern civilization, they seem hardly aware of the outside world.
â€œJoeâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for extreme violence and strong sexual content and language.

The most indelible scenes in David Gordon Greenâ€™s â€œJoe,â€ù filmed in the backwoods of Texas, have the fierce clarity of illuminations glimpsed in a lightning flash. In one lingering afterimage, a team of mostly African-American laborers, toiling in a desiccated pine forest, methodically poison sickly trees with â€œjuice hatchetsâ€ù (small axes that squirt deadly herbicide) to kill them off and make room for the planting of hardier species. These woodsmen, played by nonprofessionals, share an easy, rough-hewn camaraderie. They are the least tormented characters in â€œJoe,â€ù a punishing exercise in Southern miserablism.

Marshaling every trick in the olden-times playbook, the writer and director, Terry Green, constructs a sepia-toned account of Reds-under-the-bed hysteria and leftist defiance. Holding our hands through spotty news footage and starchy performances, the estimable David Strathairn plays Flynn, a left-leaning government agent charged with investigating a series of bombings aimed at prominent politicians and business leaders.
â€œNo God, No Masterâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Stuffy exposition and unflattering headgear.

A stodgy banquet of idealistic speeches and weeping violins, â€œNo God, No Masterâ€ù presents a fascinating period in modern American history â€” the infamous 1919-20 raids on anarchist suspects by Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer â€” with more earnestness than artistry.

Dignified to a fault and crammed with historical worthies (like a pre-deportation Emma Goldman), this dry tour of union hall strife and kitchen table sentiment wears its sympathies proudly. (How can you hate a kitten-cuddling anarchist?) Soldiering on, Mr. Strathairn (who burned through a similar character in John Saylesâ€™s magnificent 1987 labor tragedy, â€œMatewanâ€ù) seems to realize that his talents alone canâ€™t rescue a film that probably should have been called â€œNo Ambien? No Problem!â€ù

â€œFreedom isnâ€™t a right; itâ€™s a commodity,â€ù Palmer (Ray Wise) tells Flynn, waving him off to harass the poor but proud immigrants and downtrodden laborers who Palmer believes are fomenting the violence. The assignment yields about as many thrills as Flynnâ€™s chaste pursuit of his dead partnerâ€™s widow â€” an endeavor that barely permits him to remove his hat â€” though it does afford plenty of opportunities to extol workersâ€™ dignity and denounce their mustache-twirling overlords.

It is part of the conceit of â€œOnly Lovers Left Alive,â€ù Jim Jarmuschâ€™s latest slow-burn celebration of art, style and aimless conversation, that old Kit Marlowe (a marvelously grizzled John Hurt), one of the original literary outlaws, is alive and well, if a bit weary. Dwelling in a city associated with latter-day writer-renegades like William S. Burroughs and Paul Bowles, Marlowe is Eveâ€™s confidant and mentor. He also supplies her with human blood, since both of them (and Adam too) are vampires.

I can certainly sympathize, but Iâ€™m also a bit unnerved to see one of the avant-garde heroes of my own vampire youth turn conservative. In many ways, â€œOnly Lovers Left Aliveâ€ù is among Mr. Jarmuschâ€™s most voluptuous movies â€” full of rare and gorgeous images and sounds, heavy with wistful sighs and sprinkled with wry, knowing jokes â€” but it is also thin and pale, and perhaps too afraid of daylight for its own good.
â€œOnly Lovers Left Aliveâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex, blood, rock â€™nâ€™ roll.

While it is not specified that all of these artists were vampires, it is clear that Adam, Eve and their dwindling ilk are especially sensitive to certain forms of beauty. They are muses and ideal critics. (They also have a lot of time to read and listen to music while the rest of us sleep.) Part of the pathos of their situation is that the ordinary humans Adam and Eve derisively call zombies have lost or squandered the ability to appreciate art. When Eve visits Detroit, Adam shows her the Michigan Theater, a once-grand, now-decrepit movie palace and a symbol of his own malaise. His depression, triggered by the zombies and their vulgar ways, has brought him to the edge of suicide. Eve has come to cheer him up.

Adam and Eve are not the type to go out and bite necks: They purchase their nutrition from medical professionals (including one played by Jeffrey Wright) and drink it from long-stemmed, shapely goblets. But the film does not hesitate to make another familiar metaphorical link â€” one between vampirism and addiction. After these vampires taste blood, their heads roll back and the room starts to spin. And when supplies dwindle, things grow desperate in a hurry. It is also clear that not everyone manages the habit as well as Adam and Eve, as demonstrated when Eveâ€™s wild sister, Ava (Mia Wasikowska), shows up for a visit.

When you live for hundreds of years without the inevitability of a natural end, there is no reason to hurry, and Mr. Jarmusch is a practiced hand at slow filmmaking. What sustains â€œOnly Lovers Left Aliveâ€ù is less a story than a sensibility, an attitude of nostalgic and somewhat cranky connoisseurship. Plots are for squares, which is not to say that nothing happens.

There is something a bit musty about a romanticism that equates creativity with chemical dependency, and also something a little threadbare about the countercultural mystique that Adam and Eve embody. They are undoubtedly seductive, and anyone who shares their musical, literary and cinematic interests will luxuriate in their company. But this elegy for the tradition of the cool has a defensive, even reactionary undercurrent. At bottom, itâ€™s a generational protest against the zombie kids and their enablers, digitally distracted creatures who donâ€™t appreciate the tactile, sensual glories of the old things.

With their finely chiseled clavicles and cheekbones, their nocturnal habits and exquisite taste, Adam and Eve are about the coolest couple you could imagine. (They are played by Tom Hiddleston and Tilda Swinton, which definitely helps.) Adam lives in a vast apartment in the picturesque ruins of Detroit, surrounded by vinyl records and vintage guitars acquired by an eager young gofer named Ian (Anton Yelchin). Eve haunts the alleys of Tangier, speed-reading old books in every known language and lingering in an all-night cafe with Christopher Marlowe, who still regrets, five centuries after the fact, not receiving proper credit for Shakespeareâ€™s plays.

Yes, another vampire movie. But Mr. Jarmusch is not Stephenie Meyer, Ms. Swinton is not Kristen Stewart, and, despite its title, â€œOnly Lovers Left Aliveâ€ù is less about sex than about art. Vampirism, in other words, serves in this film as a metaphor not for insatiable desire (as it has, to different effect, in the â€œTwilightâ€ù movies and the HBO series â€œTrue Bloodâ€ù), but for passionate creativity. Mr. Jarmusch imagines the tribe of the blood-consuming undead as a kind of aesthetic aristocracy, counting in their ranks most of the worldâ€™s geniuses of painting, fiction, cinema and music. Byron and Shelley are name-checked, a careful selection of books (including â€œDon Quixoteâ€ù and â€œInfinite Jestâ€ù) are packed into Eveâ€™s suitcases, and Adamâ€™s walls are hung with portraits of Buster Keaton, Mark Twain, Robert Johnson and others.

Several times, â€œPerfect Sistersâ€ù shifts its tone so jarringly that youâ€™re left scratching your head. But eventually you realize that Stan Brooks, the director, might be making a point with the incongruity. If so, kudos to him for trying something different in a movie that otherwise could have seemed like an extended episode of any of the scheming-teenager shows that are all over television.

Once in a while, as this serious drama is percolating along, Mr. Brooks detours into comedy, as with a series of vignettes in which the girls fantasize about possible methods of matricide. Itâ€™s odd at first, but, by the filmâ€™s end, it feels fitting somehow, a signal that these teenagers donâ€™t really understand the consequences of their actions. Ms. Breslin and especially Ms. Henley are quite good, elevating a film that seems like an oft-told tale.

The film, based on a Canadian case, gives us Sandra (Abigail Breslin) and Beth (Georgie Henley), teenage sisters whose neglectful mother (Mira Sorvino) drinks too much and brings home abusive boyfriends. Adults whom they turn to for help donâ€™t intervene, so the sisters slowly convince themselves that the best way to end their living nightmare is to kill Mom.

Rejoining Blu and Jewel (still voiced by Jesse Eisenberg and Anne Hathaway), the mated pair of blue macaws from the previous feature, we follow them from domestic bliss in Rio to the lush perils of the Amazon rain forest. Though delivered by a mostly unremarkable chorus of sidekicks, the humor refuses the crutch of vulgarity in service to an insipid, eco-friendly plot and a bland, family-centered message about finding your tribe and protecting your turf. The colors are insane, the 3-D animation is impressive, and the additions of Bruno Mars (as Bluâ€™s romantic rival) and Kristin Chenoweth (as a love-struck frog) expand the Latin-flavored musical palette to include pop crooning and Broadway belting.

In 2009 â€” something of a golden year in American animation â€” Shane Ackerâ€™s wondrous â€œ9,â€ù Henry Selickâ€™s inspired â€œCoralineâ€ù and Wes Andersonâ€™s accurately named â€œFantastic Mr. Foxâ€ù all provided calm, meditative space for experiencing the marvel and mystery of their beautifully realized worlds. That space is crucial; like the Japanese genius Hayao Miyazaki, these filmmakers understand that nonstop agitation gets wearisome and that even tots need time to think.

Ms. Chenoweth is the filmâ€™s secret weapon, her characterâ€™s interspecies crush on an addled cockatoo (the perfect Jemaine Clement) yielding Christine-and-the-Phantom moments of forbidden-love lunacy. But these pops of avant-garde flavor â€” suggesting that at least one of the filmâ€™s four credited writers might be a keeper â€” are smothered by the retro rhythms of comic formula and the relentless beats of choreographed stimulation that characterize too many American-made childrenâ€™s movies.

The Brazilian Ministry of Tourism, at least, should be pleased. With one eye on the soccer and the other on the 2016 Summer Olympics, Rio de Janeiroâ€™s image watchdogs must welcome a counterweight to the slum-centered aesthetic of movies like â€œElite Squadâ€ù and â€œCity of God.â€ù And while the â€œRioâ€ù doubleheader may not deflect the professed concern over visitor safety that has prompted officials to begin clearing out those slums, the franchise is a gift of samba-and-Carnival cheer that Mr. Saldanha lards with all the fondness of a native son.

The cinematic equivalent of attack by kaleidoscope, â€œRio 2â€ù sucks you in and whirls you around before spitting you out, exhausted. A tropical tornado of cadmium and cobalt, magenta and marigold, Carlos Saldanhaâ€™s frantic follow-up to his well-received 2011 animated feature, â€œRio,â€ù ups the ante on sound and movement but pays scant attention to story. Prioritizing a sellable soundtrack â€” and a veiled plug for this yearâ€™s World Cup soccer tournament â€” over an original and engaging narrative might not have been the intent, but it sure feels that way.

The specter of Auschwitz hovers over the film. The subject comes up early â€” in a fight between Jean-Marie and his father, who canâ€™t reconcile himself to his sonâ€™s faith â€” and returns again and again. Jean-Marie visits the camp but finds he can recite neither the Lordâ€™s Prayer nor Kaddish, the Jewish prayer for the dead, for his mother.

Later, when Carmelite nuns establish a convent at Auschwitz, it becomes a problem between Jean-Marie and the man who has been his ally and patron, a folksy John Paul II (AurÃ©lien Recoing), who scoots down the Vaticanâ€™s halls in white sneakers. (â€œThey give me wings.â€ù)

The title of Ilan Duran Cohenâ€™s film â€œThe Jewish Cardinalâ€ù may sound like a punch line. But it accurately describes a real man, Jean-Marie Lustiger, the Paris-born son of Jewish immigrants from Poland, who at 13, bar mitzvah age, converted to Catholicism in the fraught year of 1940.

The movie picks up the story of Jean-Marie (Laurent Lucas) in 1979, when heâ€™s made archbishop of OrlÃ©ans. Though the movie doesnâ€™t play like a standard biopic, it does sometimes feel as if it were checking off points on a timeline.

The movie also keeps a steady focus on the strange way Jean-Marie insists on being both Jew and Catholic, and sometimes a bridge between the two. And it holds your interest, even if Jean-Marie remains what he must be to Mr. Cohen: an enticing puzzlement, his faith a mystery.

Mr. Cohen, who wrote the screenplay with Chantal Derudder, seems fascinated by the central contradiction in Lustigerâ€™s life and the schism in his soul. Lustiger, whose mother died in Auschwitz, never stopped considering himself Jewish, even after becoming an archbishop and then a cardinal. (He died in 2007.)

The title recalls a promotional moniker of Harry Houdini, apparently with a sense of irony, given Armandâ€™s air of haplessness. Yet the omnipresent police chief (at one point a helicopter hovers into view above the couple) is a joke with a slight edge, suggesting a check on private desires, as if Armand is damned, no matter what he does. Above all, the film makes us interested in what Mr. Guiraudie will come up with next.

Even before they become fugitives, Armand finds himself ambushed by a droll police chief (FranÃ§ois Clavier) who keeps materializing. He also crosses paths with a scrappy codger (Jean Toscan), who is said to be prodigiously well endowed, during a pit stop at an amusingly lazy country restaurant â€” one of Mr. Guiraudieâ€™s affectionate provincial details. Everyone is ordinary, except for all the sneaking into the forest for alfresco sex.

Thatâ€™s one common point with the Hitchcockian â€œStranger by the Lake.â€ù The sex, though less explicit, is accepted as a natural urge that kicks up chaos. â€œThe King of Escapeâ€ù is more loosely put together than â€œStranger,â€ù and, considering what happens, itâ€™s relatively underplayed. But Mr. Guiraudie also makes room for, say, a delightfully gratuitous wide-screen tracking shot when Curly chases Armand with intriguing flourishes on the score.

It all begins, as far too few comedies do, with a diffident gay tractor salesman helping a client choose a color. The pudgy salesman, Armand (Ludovic Berthillot), is a nice guy but a bit passive, and so itâ€™s a surprise when he saves a lusty teenage girl named Curly (Hafsia Herzi of â€œThe Secret of the Grainâ€ù) from would-be rapists. (Of course, he does so by taking them to an A.T.M. and paying them off.) Whatâ€™s even more surprising is the helplessly torrid affair that erupts between Armand and Curly, which eventually impels them to go on the run from her father and the authorities.

Before Alain Guiraudie made his justly lauded â€œStranger by the Lake,â€ù he directed â€œThe King of Escape,â€ù a fresh, antic comedy thatâ€™s powered just as much by libido. In this case, sex is comedy, and Mr. Guiraudie makes the most of the anarchic freedoms of the genre. Originally shown at Cannes in 2009, â€œThe King of Escapeâ€ù matter-of-factly sketches out a randy patch of the French countryside, where cruising thrives among butch, gray-haired rustics and where aphrodisiac roots grow in the woods.

The movie alludes to two inspirations: â€œBrief Encounterâ€ù (its underdeveloped love story) and â€œThe Bridge on the River Kwaiâ€ù (its tale of forced labor by Allied prisoners of war). If â€œThe Railway Man,â€ù like many films about combat, is reflexively antiwar, it unabashedly celebrates the nobility and courage of British soldiers. Thatâ€™s the way it is with all but the most nihilistic movies contemplating the horrors of war.

The moral crux of the movie revolves around the news four decades later that Nagase (portrayed as an older man by Hiroyuki Sanada) is working as a tour guide in a Japanese war museum. With the idea of killing him, Lomax visits the museum and reveals his identity and undertakes his own interrogation.

Mr. Firth gives a reserved, compelling performance of a tormented man whose experience as a prisoner helping the enemy build a railroad hasnâ€™t dampened his boyish enthusiasm for trains. But behind Lomaxâ€™s stiff-upper-lip facade are wartime memories he is too frightened to confront.

â€œThe Railway Manâ€ù begins awkwardly with the dying Lomax mumbling a fragment of a poem that never amounts to much. From this deathbed scene, the film dips back to 1980 and a British veteranâ€™s club where Lomax regales his friends with his story of recently meeting Patti (Nicole Kidman), a nurse who was sitting opposite him in a train compartment. They soon marry.

In the early scenes, Mr. Firthâ€™s eyes convey a profound hurt barely camouflaged by a sardonic joviality. Later in the film, they signal a cold, murderous hatred, and even later, something more complex. His performance is all the more convincing for its understatement. That modesty prevents â€œThe Railway Manâ€ù from turning mawkishly sentimental once Lomax embraces the concept of forgiveness, and you can believe itâ€™s possible.

In protracted flashbacks, Lomax, while helping construct the Burma Railway under slave-labor conditions, secretly assembles a crude radio through which the prisoners receive morale-boosting news. When the radio is discovered, Lomax bravely takes the blame. But his nightmare at the hands of Nagase (Tanroh Ishida), a sadistic Japanese interrogator, begins. At first, he is subjected to furious beatings. Later, he endures a precursor of waterboarding that involves a hose attached to his mouth. Somehow he survives, although these gruesome scenes make you wonder how that was possible.

What place is there nowadays for a solid, old-fashioned movie about war, remembrance and reconciliation? That question occurred to me while watching â€œThe Railway Man,â€ù an unabashedly stodgy, high-minded film in the David Lean tradition (without the grandeur), starring Colin Firth as Eric Lomax, a British Army officer who served and suffered during World War II.

The film, directed by Jonathan Teplitzky (â€œBurning Manâ€ù) from a screen adaptation of Lomaxâ€™s 1995 memoir, tells the true story of his brutal treatment by the Japanese after his capture in Singapore in 1942 and his determination to come to terms with it decades later. (Lomax was 93 when he died in 2012.)

The early scenes are a confusing hodgepodge that jumps around in time. Only after Patti discovers that her husband suffers from terrifying nightmares does the story take shape. When Patti pressures his friend and former army buddy Finlay (Stellan Skarsgard) for an explanation, he breaks the veteransâ€™ code of silence and reluctantly informs her of their wartime experiences.
â€œThe Railway Manâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has intense scenes of torture.

The role of Lomax is divided between Mr. Firth, who plays him as a mature veteran in the 1980s, afflicted with severe, untreated post-traumatic stress disorder, and Jeremy Irvine (â€œWar Horseâ€ù) as his younger self, a fresh-faced soldier who stands up to the enemy and is put through hell. Their physical resemblance is just enough that you buy it.

Although Ms. Kidman is radiant, her character is just a catalyst for Lomaxâ€™s recovery and redemption. Besides being an empathetic helpmate and angel of compassion who gently coaxes him to confront his demons, she barely exists.

During college at Yale, he discovered a strong interest in contemplation of the Gospels, as opposed to what he described as the bourgeois Christian faith he commonly saw practiced. Later, in the late 1960s and early 1970s, he developed an interest in Eastern religions and found connections between contemplation and meditation.

At one point, Father Keating, now 91, quotes the saint John of the Cross: â€œThe eternal father spoke only one word and he spoke it in an eternal silence. And that isnâ€™t silent; we hear it.â€ù Itâ€™s a fascinating concept. If only it had been observed in this film, so packed with dialogue and weak on images that it could have been a radio show as easily as a movie.

â€œThomas Keating: A Rising Tide of Silenceâ€ù is a loving portrait of the titular Trappist monk and author, directed by Peter C. Jones, his nephew. The film covers Father Keatingâ€™s early days in an affluent family in New York City and on Long Island, then progresses through his passionate embracing of the monastic life.
â€œHeâ€™s had a tremendous influence, maybe more than any other Christian, on world religious dialogue,â€ù his friend and former colleague John Osborne says in a voice-over testimonial.

The film is a staid and reverent collection of interviews and archival speeches, enlivened mostly by Father Keatingâ€™s wisdom and his animated, almost twinkly speaking voice. Though the film proposes to be about silence, it is packed with incessant talking heads, voice-over narration and music.

The movie, written and directed by Eric Stacey, explores the case of Philip Marshall, who was found dead early last year at his home in California, along with his two teenage children. The authorities determined that Mr. Marshall had shot his children and then himself, but since he had written â€œThe Big Bamboozle: 9/11 and the War on Terrorâ€ù and was at work on another Sept. 11 conspiracy book, suspicions arose in certain quarters.

Randall Paul portrays the main character, who for the film is renamed Marshall Philips. Dennis Fitzpatrick is the investigative journalist who is suspicious of official explanations (Wayne Madsen, also renamed). The film is subtitled â€œAn Airline Captainâ€™s Storyâ€ù because Mr. Marshall was once a pilot, an experience that made him skeptical of the accepted version of the Sept. 11 attacks.

Mr. Stacey weaves voice recordings of Mr. Marshall and others into his dramatization, but the acting is so clumsy and the shoestring-budget filmmaking so dreadful that the movie never establishes the credibility that this sort of alternate narrative needs.
â€œUnthinkableâ€ù is unwatchable, which is too bad, because there are certainly enough oddities in the incident it tries to dramatize to have made for a decent conspiracy theory film.

Their leader is Alan Mooney (Dylan Walsh), a frustrated eye doctor filled with terrible ideas for novels. â€œI think I know what my mission is,â€ù says the labor leader Cesar Chavez in â€œCesarâ€™s Last Fast.â€ù â€œRighting the wrongs that were committed against workers for 100 years.â€ù Chavez  (1927-1993), a founder of what became the United Farm Workers union, faced brutal odds, as this compelling documentary demonstrates.

In â€œHome, James,â€ù James is a photographer who makes most of his money as a driver for hire who transports the dissolute late-night souls of Tulsa, Okla., when theyâ€™ve had one or three too many. Thatâ€™s how he first meets Cooper, a hard-drinking rich girl.

â€œThe Final Memberâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Genitalia in jars, in tricolor and in your face.

Because he and Ms. Spray donâ€™t try to control your viewing experience or steer your gaze â€” there are no cutaways to trembling lips or close-ups of fluttering eyes â€” itâ€™s hard even to guess what that womanâ€™s face expresses. Located in the Gorkha district near the center of Nepal and close to the Chinese border, Manakamana is a temple of the Hindu goddess Durga, believed to have the power to fulfill wishes. Thereâ€™s little available online in English about the temple other than the vaguely touristic, which ranges from the yawningly obvious (itâ€™s a sacred site) to the hair-raising (itâ€™s also a gory locale because of the animal sacrifices at the temple). Somewhat surprisingly, thereâ€™s also next to no information about it in â€œManakamana,â€ù which consists of 11 uncut shots â€” each 10 to 11 minutes long, or a 400-foot roll of 16-millimeter film â€” most taken in a closed cable car. â€œManakamanaâ€ù was directed by Stephanie Spray and Pacho Velez, and produced by Lucien Castaing-Taylor and VÃ©rÃ©na Paravel, who directed â€œLeviathan,â€ù an unflinching, at times nauseating, immersion in the carnage aboard an industrial fishing vessel. Mr. Castaing-Taylor also created, with Ilisa Barbash, â€œSweetgrass,â€ù a considerably less brutal, less brutalizing look at Montana sheepherders and their baaing charges. (All three movies were developed with the Sensory Ethnography Lab at Harvard University.) The intersection of humans and animals in these particular films is striking, sometimes difficult to watch and meaningful simply because it is so foregrounded: raw, meet the cooked. The animal slaughter in â€œManakamanaâ€ù takes place off screen; itâ€™s evoked rather than shown, as in the shot of a cable car crammed with piteously bleating goats, yet it resonates throughout.

All the shots begin and end with passengers clambering on and off a car in the near dark as the camera stays securely inside, the tripod fixed to a wooden base that the filmmakers had built. For about half the trips, the cars hypnotically move up and over the undulating forested mountain; for the other half, they move down. The men, women and children in the cars wear some traditional garments, although three longhaired male beauties pop up in T-shirts, the universal uniform of youth. Some passengers chat, others laugh, while still others sit in silence framed by the large window that turns the brilliant emerald landscape â€” dotted by passers-by and grazing cows â€” into a film within a film. At one point, a mewling kitten rides along; later, so does a doomed chicken.

This circumscribed approach in â€œManakamanaâ€ù and some of the other Sensory Lab titles may partly be a response to how nonfiction cinemaâ€™s already problematic hold on the truth has been further loosened by digital technologies. Part of the enduring appeal of documentary has always been its claim on the real and the assurance that the results bear a strong relationship to the world as it exists. Itâ€™s never been that simple, of course, no matter how shaky the camera and pared down the style, and digital technologies have only complicated the picture as has fiction filmâ€™s absorption of documentary conventions. By focusing on such a narrow slice of Nepali life, Ms. Spray and Mr. Velez have ceded any totalizing claim on the truth and instead settled for a perfect incompleteness.

One of the most bracing features of â€œManakamanaâ€ù is how little overt information it offers about the people in front of the camera, in pointed contrast to the overexplaining that takes place in many contemporary documentaries. The film doesnâ€™t have a voice-over; it doesnâ€™t expound on the history of Manakamana or Nepal. Everyone who rides the cable car is listed in the final credits, but no one is identified while on screen. The faces in â€œManakamana,â€ù a transporting ethnographic film set in a green sliver of Nepal, stare into the camera, out into space and, perhaps, into the great beyond. The faces are sometimes creased and weathered, sometimes smooth as pebbles. A few look etched with worry, as if they were weighed down by a heavy burden, although they may also be seized with fear. Thatâ€™s because for 10 or so minutes at a time, these faces are floating hundreds of feet above a lush Nepali forest in a cable car that takes pilgrims to and from the temple that gives this film its rhythmic title.

The title character in â€œFading Gigolo,â€ù a low-key, low-energy comedy about New York haves and have-nots, is Fioravante, a melancholic bookstore employee played by the filmâ€™s director, John Turturro. When you first meet Fioravante, heâ€™s packing up boxes, on the verge of becoming an ex-bookstore employee. â€œFading Gigoloâ€ù is rated R. (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian.) Under-the-sheet romping.

It gets better gradually, largely because of the appealing performers, including the amusingly frenetic Mr. Allen, who enlivens his every scene, and Liev Schreiber, who plays a hunky Hasidic neighborhood cop, Dovi, who has his eye on a rabbiâ€™s fetching widow, Avigal (Vanessa Paradis). Avigal comes into the picture, and soon into Fioravanteâ€™s life, with the strained romanticism that defines Mr. Turturroâ€™s approach: Murray meets Avigal when he takes his live-in black partnerâ€™s children to her to be deloused. Before you know it, all the children â€” African-American and Hasidic â€” are playing ball with Murray, and Fioravante is meeting the nominally repressed, hot Yiddishe momme. The influence of Spike Lee, with whom Mr. Turturro has worked repeatedly, shows up early in â€œFading Gigolo,â€ù notably in the way streets transform into stages on which the diverse characters act out their comedies and dramas. This idea works better in the more intimate scenes, say, of just two people walking and talking, rather than in the busier, more populated scenes that reach for the panoramic.

Mr. Turturroâ€™s penchant for layering his scenes in music also suggests Mr. Leeâ€™s influence. Yet while Mr. Lee uses music for heightened emotion, ironic counterpoint and political commentary, Mr. Turturroâ€™s musical choices in â€œFading Gigoloâ€ù tend to feel, like so much here, generically applied instead of meaningfully coaxed from some essential, lived-in truth.

Murray doesnâ€™t actually say those words, or not that I remember, and neither does anyone throw around any of the other, cruder descriptors that often come into play when someone has sex for money. Sizing up Fioravante like a prime cut, Murray decides that his friend is the prostitute for the job. Fioravante shrugs off the idea, only to succumb, because, well, that is how heâ€™s written. These visual echoes donâ€™t hurt â€œTranscendence,â€ù and they soon recede amid the escalating narrative noise. Mr. Pfister handles the predictable third-act action booms adequately â€” it must be contractual that every director who makes a thriller these days must blow his sets to smithereens â€” but heâ€™s better when the story scales down.

His image pops up on screen, like some holographic specter, a kind of rebirth that thrills Evelyn and freaks out most everyone else, including, naturally enough, the extremists. Implausibly led by a scowling half-pint, Bree (Kate Mara), they try to stop Will and Evelyn, in a chase that also pulls in other scientists and government agents played by the likes of Morgan Freeman and Cillian Murphy.

However predictable and ridiculous, the film raises the question of what â€” as the machines rise â€” makes us human and why, which certainly gives you more to chew on at the multiplex than is customary these days. In â€œFrankenstein,â€ù the monster tells his creator, â€œI ought to be thy Adam, but I am rather the fallen angel.â€ù This is the warning that pulses through many dystopian fictions and which here finds another beat.

The twist in â€œTranscendenceâ€ù is that the scientist becomes the monster of his own creation or so it seems. Shortly after the film opens, Will is shot by an extremist during a series of coordinated attacks on high-tech targets. He survives the initial assault only to succumb to the radiation that laced the bullet.

When Evelyn appears in that white hallway, Mr. Pfister is showing off the production design, but heâ€™s also bringing you close to a woman who, as Willâ€™s power expands, is becoming progressively more isolated. One of those actresses who always seem smart even in dumb roles, Ms. Hall is very sympathetic as a woman in love and then in fear who, scene by scene and with palpable tenderness, takes over the film as Will gobbles up the world.

To an extent, â€œTranscendenceâ€ù can be filed alongside other movies about fanaticism that have emerged since Sept. 11. Yet, for all its topical gloss and technobabble, it also draws from older, familiar preoccupations about the nature of being, which, along with Mr. Pfisterâ€™s eye and largely smooth handling of his actors, accounts for its modest pleasures.

Mr. Pfister, shooting on film and working with the cinematographer Jess Hall, gives â€œTranscendenceâ€ù the dark, gleaming surfaces that gloss up a lot of contemporary thrillers and which canâ€™t help evoking Christopher Nolanâ€™s work. Mr. Pfister has been the director of photography on most of Mr. Nolanâ€™s films, including the â€œDark Knightâ€ù trilogy, and Mr. Nolan has given â€œTranscendenceâ€ù his blessing by signing on as an executive producer. So itâ€™s no surprise that the depthless blacks and glowing whites in â€œTranscendenceâ€ù and Mr. Pfisterâ€™s use of negative space suggest Mr. Nolanâ€™s influence, notably in the high-tech complex where Evelyn and Will set up a compound. When Evelyn walks down one of its luminous white halls, she looks as if sheâ€™s headed right for one of Bruce Wayneâ€™s lairs.

Johnny Depp, whoâ€™s built a brilliant career despite many of his lamentable film choices, may not be the first actor you think of to play a genius â€” much less humanityâ€™s destroyer or savior. But heâ€™s weirdly perfect in â€œTranscendence,â€ù an inelegant, no doubt implausible (maybe not) science-fiction film about a futurist whose consciousness is uploaded onto the Internet. There, he (or a mysterious vestige of his being) expands like the universe, growing larger and mutating into a being who is godlike and yet far from divine, sort of like a star at the apex of his popularity.

As he lies dying, Evelyn, in one of those eureka moments that implies her brain is as infinite as her husbandâ€™s, initially uploads Willâ€™s consciousness into PINN, a clever bit of business she manages with their friend Max Waters (a solid Paul Bettany), a neurobiologist. One minute Will looks like a tortured lab monkey; the next, heâ€™s the ghost in everybodyâ€™s machine. Well, it sounds plausible or at least Mr. Pfister moves fast enough that you donâ€™t have time to puzzle over niceties like logic.

Once Willâ€™s consciousness is uploaded, his voice supplants PINNâ€™s. In its initial poetic fragmentation, the voice emanating from Evelynâ€™s reconfigured supercomputer sounds amusingly like Marlon Brandoâ€™s tape-recorded ramblings as Colonel Kurtz in â€œApocalypse Now.â€ù (Mr. Depp and Brando were friends.) After some throat clearing, though, Will starts to sound like himself and the movie gets its crazy on.

Directed by Wally Pfister, a cinematographer making his feature directing debut, â€œTranscendenceâ€ù is a dark, lurchingly entertaining pastiche of age-old worries, future-shock jolts, hot-button topics and old-fashioned genre thrills. It was written by Jack Paglen, who, while researching, probably thumbed through Mary Shelleyâ€™s â€œFrankenstein; or, the Modern Prometheus,â€ù along with some Isaac Asimov and William Gibson. The scientist here is Will Caster (Mr. Depp), whose work in artificial intelligence has landed him on the cover of Wired magazine. (Even in a brave new world, old media remains useful shorthand.) With his wife, Evelyn (Rebecca Hall), a computer scientist, Will has created PINN, one of those supermachines with sleek surfaces, blinking lights and pulsating menace.

Like some other notable machine-based intelligences â€” including the shipâ€™s computer in the original â€œStar Trek,â€ù CORA in the television series â€œBattlestar Galacticaâ€ù and Samantha in Spike Jonzeâ€™s recent film â€œHerâ€ù â€” PINN has a female voice. It may be that the enduringly creepy legacy of HAL 9000, the mutinous computer from â€œ2001: A Space Odyssey,â€ù has made it tougher for male voices to fill in these disembodied characters. Whatever the case, while artificial intelligences with any kind of human voice seem at once familiar and uncanny, further blurring the line between makers and their machines, those with female voices also suggest another creation story, that of Adam (the origin) and Eve (the product). â€œTranscendenceâ€ù plays with this idea, and itâ€™s not for nothing that its heroine is named Evelyn.
â€œTranscendenceâ€ù is rated PG-13. (Parents strongly cautioned.) Dystopian violence.

Although the filmâ€™s subtitle is â€œThe Passion, Pitfalls & Power of Womenâ€™s Professional Cycling,â€ù the closest Ms. Bertine, a former ESPN columnist, comes to conveying that passion is near the end, when little girls just beginning to race talk about their love for the sport. Itâ€™s more like a political campaign ad disguised as a public service announcement, and the message is: Get rid of the U.C.I.â€™s current leaders. Thatâ€™s the Union Cycliste Internationale, the organization that its detractors canâ€™t just walk away from, because it has the power to award Olympic qualification points.

Menâ€™s cycling offers ridiculously higher prize money and gets a lot more attention than womenâ€™s. A number of women say they could die happy if they just had the chance to do the Tour de France. But the message is repeated ad infinitum; this documentary is painfully long for a project of this kind.

The youthful cast is pretty good and receives a delightful boost from two veteran actors, Ron Perlman as a kingpin who bankrolls the boys, and John C. McGinley as the grower whose product they import. The filmâ€™s main distraction, oddly, is the voice-over through which Nate annotates the action. A voice-over is standard procedure for the wistful-look-back genre, but here itâ€™s forced and unfunny. This wild story sells itself, no narration needed.

Selling or using marijuana remains illegal in plenty of states, but on screen, the underground marijuana business is already being treated with a â€œHappy Daysâ€ù glow of nostalgia. Jonathan Daniel Brown plays Nate, a schlubby Idaho lad who organizes his pals into a squadron that brings high-grade marijuana down from Canada, hauling it through the unguarded woods while wearing ridiculous camouflage gear. Although the story is not without its serious aspects, including a homicide, John Stockwell, the director, keeps things carefree as he explores the rise and eventual fall of the smuggling crew, a rags-to-riches-to- ruin saga that leaves most other teenage fantasies looking pretty anemic.
Nobody wants Donny and Aya to hook up. But â€” but â€” thereâ€™s dancing to do!

O.K., itâ€™s not Montagues and Capulets, itâ€™s rival Brooklyn dance clubs: the gritty, underground Static and the more upper-crust Oto. The star-crossed lovers are Donny (Derek Hough), a street dancer and parolee from New Orleans, and Aya (the South Korean pop star BoA), a Korean dancer-drummer raised in Japan. Staticâ€™s owner is Donnyâ€™s foster brother, Nick (Wesley Jonathan), who had a falling-out with his partner, Kaz (Will Yun Lee of â€œHawaii Five-Oâ€ù), Ayaâ€™s overprotective brother. Kaz went to work at Oto, which is owned by the Wall Street knave Michael (Jefferson Brown), who has designs on Aya and wants her at his beck and call.
On the floor, however, their chemistry ignites. And when Aya expresses her gratitude that Donny doesnâ€™t try to control her, the movieâ€™s heart is in the right place. Tragedy? Not at all.

Duane Adler, the writer of â€œStep Upâ€ù and â€œSave the Last Dance,â€ù capably directs â€œMake Your Move,â€ù a soapy, flashy confection that juxtaposes Mr. Houghâ€™s tap dancing with the Japanese drumming style Taiko, tossed with liberal helpings of contemporary hip-hop moves. â€œMake Your Moveâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Language, drug and sexual references, brief violence and prurient tap dancing.

Employing scaled-down sets and low-budget audacity, Mr. Parker, an intelligent and boundary-testing filmmaker, proves less concerned with logic than with how far he can push his characters. His cast is more than game, with Kristina Klebe, playing Estherâ€™s hard-case lover, providing a volatile counterpoint to Ms. Havinsâ€™s deceptively sweet schemer. Even the indie-film hyphenate Joe Swanberg, as Melanieâ€™s buffeted husband, is uncharacteristically credible.

But when almost everyone on screen is nursing a pathology, interest in their fates is far from guaranteed. Accordingly, Mr. Parker (who wrote the screenplay with Kevin Donner) provides a succession of startling twists that hold our attention â€” all the more necessary when one of your lead characters is borderline catatonic. That would be Esther (Alexia Rasmussen), a drippy mother-to-be who suffers a violent attack, loses her baby and lackadaisically visits a support group. There, she meets Melanie (Alexa Havins), whose apparent pain over a kidnapped toddler ensures an instant bond.

Playing with extremes of love and jealousy â€” as he did in his wickedly effective 2011 feature, â€œScaleneâ€ù â€” Mr. Parker brings his thriller format to within an inch of horror-comedy. Not many viewers will be laughing.

A bizarre puzzle box of twisted passions and psychological sickness, Zack Parkerâ€™s â€œProxyâ€ù presents us almost immediately with a scene of such repulsive brutality that the film seems to be daring us to keep watching. If you accept, youâ€™ll find yourself wading waist-deep into the swampy center of an original if overlong story about manufactured grief and disturbingly bad mothering.
â€œSmall Timeâ€ù adds up to a refreshingly unpretentious, warmhearted made-for-television movie that thinks better of humanity than most movies nowadays.
â€œSmall Timeâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for sexual references.

Although what follows is exactly that, itâ€™s not bad. â€œSmall Timeâ€ù is agreeably sentimental meat-and-potatoes fare with strong dashes of humor, executed with a sincerity thatâ€™s hard to resist. The voice-over belongs to Freddy (Devon Bostick), the brash 18-year-old son of Al Klein (Christopher Meloni), who, with his friend Ash (Dean Norris), owns Diamond Motors, a used-car dealership in Covina, Calif.

The time is the indeterminate recent past, before smartphones and when soul music was popular. And Al, a straight-talking salt-of-the-earth type, is still hurting after a divorce from his beautiful upwardly mobile wife, Barbara (Bridget Moynahan). Barbara dumped him to marry Chick (Xander Berkeley), a rich venture capitalist for whom she worked while Al was struggling to build his business.

At first, â€œSmall Timeâ€ù seems as if itâ€™s going to be a polemic about class warfare that pits the hearty working class against the chilly, indifferent rich. But it proves to be an evenhanded serious comedy reflective of a more optimistic era. (Its first draft was written in 1976.) Mr. Meloniâ€™s Al, the good dad incarnate, is a less hotheaded version of Elliot Stabler, his character on â€œLaw & Order: SVU.â€ù Mr. Norrisâ€™s Ash exhibits the same gruff heartiness as Hank, his character on â€œBreaking Bad.â€ù Barbara softens, and Chick, although reserved, is far from icy. Mr. Bostickâ€™s Freddy, for all his upstart behavior, is a good boy at heart.

In the deadly voice-over that begins Joel Surnowâ€™s â€œSmall Time,â€ù a man declares: â€œThis is the story about my father and the summer we spent together many years ago. It was the summer that changed my life.â€ù

Freddy moves in with Al, and, in the movieâ€™s funniest scenes, he learns the ropes about car salesmanship. He proves to be an adept, funny fast talker and soon starts behaving like an obnoxious big shot. Al reluctantly takes action.
Please, no, I groaned. I donâ€™t know if I can stand under another male weepie about fathers and sons and a boyâ€™s coming-of-age.

Relative peace prevails, until Freddy suddenly announces that he would rather work for Diamond Motors selling cars than go to college, and that he wants to live with Al in a house Chick describes as â€œa shoe box in the valley.â€ù Barbara, beside herself, warns Al, â€œIf he ends up like you, Iâ€™ll hang myself.â€ù

â€œTasting Menuâ€ù cites as inspirations the 2011 closing of El Bulli, the acclaimed Catalan restaurant that showcased its visionary chef, Ferran AdriÃ , as well as culinary cinema like â€œBig Nightâ€ù and â€œBabetteâ€™s Feast.â€ù Unfortunately, Roger Gualâ€™s half-baked film hopes to split the difference between romantic comedy and foodie delight but fails at both.

Given its premise, itâ€™s surprising that â€œTasting Menuâ€ù does not focus on food more, either in its cooking or its pleasures. Aside from brief glimpses of vegetables being chopped and plates being prepared, it spends almost no time in the kitchen. Even when these one-of-a-kind dishes are consumed, the diners do little more than smile before diving back into the tedium of their supposed problems. A confection need not be filling. But it ought to be properly seasoned. Send it back.
Those lucky few include a garden-variety lineup of characters.

In the script, which Mr. Gual wrote with Javier Calvo, the best restaurant in Spain is shutting down because of the desire by the chef, Mar Vidal (Vicenta Nâ€™dongo), to go out on top. For the final night, 30 diners will enjoy a menu of 40 dishes, as well as the Costa Brava beachfront.

Marc (Jan Cornet) and Rachel (Claudia Bassols), a young divorcing couple, are reuniting for a reservation made more than a year earlier; the Countess (Fionnula Flanagan) brings the ashes of her dearly departed husband for a last supper; Japanese investors consider whether to back whatever the chef and her ambitious partner, Max (Andrew Tarbet), want to do next.

As the fourth anniversary of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill approaches, on April 20, arguments will rage about who should have done what and when. The advocacy documentary â€œVanishing Pearls,â€ù which opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles and will have one-night engagements in cities across the country over the next three months, makes an impassioned case that the spillâ€™s effects still linger.

Nailah Jeffersonâ€™s film zeros in on the small Gulf community of Pointe Ã  la Hache, La., about an hour from New Orleans, where the oyster industry has been devastated, leaving out-of-work fishermen and their families. The movie charges that legal settlements were slowly and ineffectively distributed. (Wes Tunnell, the marine biologist who provided the victimâ€™s compensation fund with projections on how quickly the Gulf might rebound, expresses reservations about how his report was used.) More than one person compares fighting BP, which leased the runaway well, to fighting God.

Donâ€™t expect much in the way of balance â€” the claims administrator Kenneth Feinberg plays defense in an interview â€” or anything other than the standard info-doc presentation (talking heads, news clips). â€œVanishing Pearlsâ€ù is most illuminating when offering a historical perspective. The Pointe Ã  la Hache fishing industry descended from a sharecropping model, with money flowing upward; the areaâ€™s African-American residents have a long tradition of fighting back (racism-driven) attempts to prevent their boats from operating independently in public waters. As its conscience, the movie selects Byron Encalade, a third-generation oysterman and president of the Louisiana Oystermen Association, who argues that itâ€™s heritage, not just income, thatâ€™s being lost.

Nathan Silverâ€™s â€œSoft in the Headâ€ù opens in medias res, as Natalia (Sheila EtxeberrÃ_a) explains to her abusive boyfriend (Nick Korbee) that sheâ€™s having a holiday dinner with her friend Hannahâ€™s family. When this scene turns into a violent breakup, Mr. Silver disorientingly cuts to the opening titles, shown over an Orthodox Jewish candle-lighting ceremony. A sense of worlds colliding seems fundamental to the film.
From a formal standpoint, though, the movie impresses, maintaining a sense of anxiety through tight shots and a sound design that favors overlapping voices and constant clatter.

For most of the movie â€” set on the sort of gritty New York streets rarely seen on screen anymore â€” Natalia, an alcoholic, bounces between these two surrogate families, drinking, acting out, cruelly flirting with Hannahâ€™s brother (Carl Kranz), who is socially stunted. Divided into chapters, â€œSoft in the Headâ€ù builds â€” a tad moralistically â€” to a finale in which the protagonist is confronted with the selfishness of her self-destruction.

In making â€œSoft in the Head,â€ù his third feature, Mr. Silver has cited Dostoyevskyâ€™s â€œThe Idiotâ€ù as an inspiration, yet improvisations have yielded a peculiar, ultra-personal work in which itâ€™s difficult to predict what will happen. From a dramatic standpoint, the movie can be unconvincing. Some half-muttered dialogue evokes John Cassavetes at his most indulgent; Ms. EtxeberrÃ_aâ€™s performance is both bravely off-putting and irritatingly mannered.

At the dinner, Hannah (Melanie J. Scheiner) is reminded why the volatile Natalia is no oneâ€™s idea of a polite guest. Ushered out, she finds refuge in a shelter run by the wise, patient Maury (Ed Ryan).

Malcolm (Mr. Wayans) is moving into a home with his new girlfriend, Megan (Jaime Pressly), since his amour from â€œA Haunted House,â€ù the demonically possessed Kisha (Essence Atkins, briefly seen here), has died in a car wreck. Megan has a young son, the innocent-looking but foulmouthed Wyatt (Steele Stebbins), and a sexually active teenage daughter, Becky (Ashley Rickards). Of course, the house has other residents â€” Tony, Wyattâ€™s unseen ghostly playmate (Ã  la â€œParanormal Activity 3â€ù), and Abigail, a sinister-looking doll (Ã  la Annabelle in â€œThe Conjuringâ€ù) â€” and countless surveillance cameras. Eventually, Malcolm enlists his neighbor (the stand-up comic Gabriel Iglesias); married, bickering exorcists (Missi Pyle and Hayes MacArthur); and his friend Father Williams (Cedric the Entertainer, back from the last installment) to help curtail the annoying visitations.

Run in fright. Marlon Wayansâ€™s comedy â€œA Haunted Houseâ€ù unaccountably made $40 million at the domestic box office, so we have â€œA Haunted House 2,â€ù which, like its predecessor, pays parodic tribute to horror films including â€œDark Skiesâ€ù and the â€œLast Exorcismâ€ù movies, among countless others. Already the franchise displays a sputtering exhaustion.
â€œA Haunted House 2â€ù is rated R. (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian.) Nudity, drug use and simulated doll fornication.
The tone grows ever more shrill and desperate. â€œIâ€™ve had enough of this haunted house craziness!â€ù Megan says at one point. Havenâ€™t we all.

But this is Mr. Wayansâ€™s show, and his perspiring physicality, wide-eyed mugging and relentless pop culture references grow exasperating. One especially tiring device, more indicative of a meager budget than of humorous ingenuity, is his attacking inanimate objects: taking a rifle to a corrugated cardboard box; endlessly tussling in the kitchen with a prop chicken; burning and punching out Abigail, with which he has had simulated sex. (He leaves the doll with bruised and swollen eyes.)

Thatâ€™s because when they meet at their offspringâ€™s graduation, itâ€™s hate at first sight. The sotto voce insults fly: Punjabis have money but no culture; Tamils are too dark-skinned. These twains cannot meet.

Still, on screen, Krish and Ananya remain a generic He and She of young, ascendant India: good-looking, well educated, open-minded. Heâ€™s a bit broody; sheâ€™s a bit spunky. They could be any Bollywood hero and heroine, except theyâ€™re stuck in a movie that needs them to be more. And while Mr. Kapoor and Ms. Bhatt (who was very good in the very odd â€œHighwayâ€ù) give credible performances, they canâ€™t fill in the blanks.

â€œ2 Statesâ€ù is based on a novel by Chetan Bhagat, so itâ€™s not surprising that the film has a novelistic texture and pace. But the screen demands more narrative economy than the script can muster, and that texture doesnâ€™t carry over to the characters, though there are hints of their origins in another kind of storytelling.

Like â€œKai Po Che,â€ù another movie adapted from a novel by Mr. Bhagat, â€œ2 Statesâ€ù is an effort to go beyond formula while also embracing formulaic elements, including some nice song-and-dance sequences. The mix isnâ€™t right yet. But that ambition provides its own tensions and energies, which help â€œ2 Statesâ€ù from feeling becalmed.

Krish (Arjun Kapoor) and Ananya (Alia Bhatt) meet on neutral ground: the photogenic campus of the Indian Institute of Management in Ahmedabad. (It was designed by Louis I. Kahn.) We follow their romantic arc â€” they fall in love, become engaged, secure great jobs â€” but thatâ€™s just Act I. Krish and Ananya still have to woo each otherâ€™s parents.

Love is a communal thing in Abhishek Varmanâ€™s â€œ2 States,â€ù a Bollywood romantic comedy about a southern girl (sheâ€™s Tamilian) and a northern boy (Punjabi) who have to overcome their parentsâ€™ bickering and prejudices to find a happy ending.

Each of them has to keep secrets: Anna, selling art objects to maintain appearances; Fai, hiding his wife behind closed doors because of the Chinese governmentâ€™s one-child limit. Their stories follow a gradual decline, methodically switching between Anna and Fai as they face their respective countdowns to bankruptcy and birth. Weâ€™re left to watch the characters cope at a somewhat cool distance, though that perspective is redeemed by an intimate sense of their environments and the subtle gestures by which they try to maintain their dignity or otherwise shield themselves. (In one memorable moment, when Anna is overwhelmed by her problems, sheâ€™s voluptuously photographed wrapped in blankets and darkness.)

â€œBends,â€ù Flora Lauâ€™s restrained debut feature, seesaws between the painful limbos of an upper-class Hong Kong housewife and her driver, who lives on the mainland. Shot in sleek tones by Christopher Doyle, the film melds class-conscious melodrama with malleable mood piece, but keeps threatening to fade from understatement into stasis.

Anna (Carina Lau, who is not related to the director) lives in an apartment with expansive views, and sheâ€™s never less than smartly turned out. Then her husband absconds, leaving behind canceled credit cards that reveal some financial catastrophe. Her dutiful driver, Fai (Chen Kun), meanwhile, is preoccupied with finding a hospital bed for his pregnant wife, who is about to deliver their second child.

Perhaps unavoidably, at a time of continued economic upheaval in the region, the film also serves as another cinematic dispatch reflecting the toll taken by the underlying political order. (The original Chinese title has to do with crossing the border.) Anna and Fai arenâ€™t reduced to mere illustrations of the phenomenon, but the director, who also wrote the story, doesnâ€™t nurture the dramatic life of her characters sufficiently for them to stand alone.
â€œWhen I see men treat each other as they do, I see nothing but base flattery, injustice, treachery, selfishness and deceit.â€ù

The veiled competition intensifies once Francesca (Maya Sansa), an attractive, bad-tempered real estate agent, enters the picture. The movie pays deliberate tribute to â€œJules and Jim,â€ù as both men cagily vie for her attention.

Their conversations take place on the Ã_le de RÃ©, an island off the west coast of France, where Serge, a retired actor of considerable renown, lives a reclusive existence in a dingy cottage whose leaky sewage system he refuses to repair out of general ill will. Their discussions begin when Gauthier Valence (Lambert Wilson), a handsome actor of late middle age who plays a surgeon on a popular nighttime soap opera, visits Serge to propose the revival. A scene from that tacky soap, for which Valence is highly paid, suggests that they come from not only different show business worlds but also different planets.

Gauthier is a latter-day dandy on the verge of going to seed; his overly styled hair suggests the coif on a Las Vegas crooner. But he is not nearly as nice as he pretends to be. And in one scene, he punches a persistent fan for no particular reason.

Although Francesca, who is going through a divorce, lightens up as the story goes along, she is as bitter, in her way, as Serge is in his. Early in the film, she blithely announces that theyâ€™re all going to die, their flesh will go flabby, theyâ€™ll rot in the grave, and everything will end up as dust.

As two actors of opposite temperaments discuss a possible collaboration on a new production of the play, their arguments about interpretation become part of a sneaky power game in which each tries to get the better of the other. Because both want to portray the title character, Alceste, they agree to take turns if Serge Tanneur (Fabrice Luchini), the older of the two, finally says yes to the project.

As they try out various line readings, they never proceed beyond the first scene of Act I, in which the bitter, uncompromisingly moralistic Alceste debates social ethics with Philinte, who preaches civility and discretion in the interests of peaceful coexistence. Many of the actorsâ€™ dialogues take place as they bicycle side by side on the picturesque island, where Gauthier is contemplating buying a house.

â€œBicycling With MoliÃ¨reâ€ù reunites Mr. Le Guay and Mr. Luchini, whose last film together was the frothy boulevard comedy â€œThe Women on the 6th Floor.â€ù The new movie has a little more weight. The screenplay ultimately bears out Alcesteâ€™s observations about treachery, selfishness and deceit, but with such charm and zest that their sting tickles more than it hurts.

The screenplay is far from seamless. Its slapstick moments â€” two involving cyclists who are run off the road, and another in a hot tub that acts like a boiling caldron â€” donâ€™t quite land. A subplot, in which a beautiful aspiring actress slumming in pornography reads MoliÃ¨re for them, goes nowhere. But those are small complaints.

Those words are heard more than once in â€œBicycling With MoliÃ¨re,â€ù the French director Philippe Le Guayâ€™s witty contemporary deconstruction of MoliÃ¨reâ€™s 17th-century comedy â€œThe Misanthrope.â€ù

Initially, they seem to be perfectly typecast for the roles of Alceste and Philinte. Mr. Luchiniâ€™s scruffy, unshaven Serge surveys the world with the contemptuous glare of a know-it-all poised to pounce on an adversary. What appears at first to be a smile on his face is a really a baring of teeth. Serge takes an unseemly relish in voicing Alcesteâ€™s views of how awful human beings really are. And Mr. Luchini, a MoliÃ¨re aficionado, gives one of his sharpest screen performances ever.

Jaiyah Saelua, a player who belongs to American Samoaâ€™s third gender, faâ€™afafine (way of the woman), looks beautiful when â€œherâ€ù hair and makeup are done for an evening but throws â€œhisâ€ù body in front of opponents like a suicidal gladiator. A former player, now in the military, takes his annual leave to return and participate. A Californian of American Samoan descent joins the team to honor his grandparents.
In some ways, this is just another underdogs-go-for-it sports movie. In others, it is as sensitive and observant as an Edith Wharton novel.

But the guys on the team are embarrassed by all the negative attention (a 31-0 defeat in Australia in 2001 still haunts them), and in â€œNext Goal Wins,â€ù Mike Brett and Steve Jamisonâ€™s splendid celebration-of-humanity documentary, they give it their all.

Their savior is Thomas Rongen, a wiry, silver-haired Dutchman who had moved to America to play and coach and who answers a help-wanted ad placed by the United States Soccer Federation. Mr. Rongen, whose daughter died in a car accident at 18, now dedicates to her everything he does.
The film is a portrait of a culture that values the joys of camaraderie over other factors, which sounds like a good reason to price flights to Pago Pago.

That American Samoa has a soccer team, much less one that aspires to compete in world championships, is fairly momentous. In terms of population, itâ€™s something like Pontiac, Mich., or Lynchburg, Va., putting together a local group and sending it to the Olympics. So the nickname â€œworst soccer team in the worldâ€ù doesnâ€™t seem that shameful.

Thereâ€™s a conspicuous void when it comes to the screenplay, which puts Nicolai and Elise through their paces (she has tuberculosis; he is tragically persistent) without defining their characters with much insight or depth. Weâ€™re constantly told of all the obstacles to their romance, but more is said through the fall of shadows on Elise in repose than through the spotty dialogue.

Through flashback, this awkwardly titled film from Jos Stelling recounts the rather prolonged, doomed romance between Nicolai (Leonid Bichevin) and Elise (Sylvia Hoeks), as he courts his way past the oversight of the thuggish prince (Dieter Hallervorden). The ache of the story is largely sustained through an air of enchantment, partly cast by Goert Giltayâ€™s cinematography and Andrea Scheinâ€™s sumptuous costume design, with Eliseâ€™s fellow courtesan, Nina (a mischievous Renata Litvinova), adding spice with her frank perspective. (Ms. Hoeks was a similarly cloistered object of obsession in Giuseppe Tornatoreâ€™s â€œThe Best Offer.â€ù)

â€œThe Girl and Deathâ€ù is primarily set in that most durable of mysterious settings: a secluded, well-appointed hotel from another era. This particular establishment, tucked outside Leipzig, in post-World War II Germany, has its dotard guests and their routines, its officious and stiffly uniformed staff, and its intimations of secrets and riches. Most important, as discovered by a young visiting Russian doctor, Nicolai, it hosts Elise, the lovely kept mistress of a wealthy prince.
The movie proves to be a fragile conceit. Itâ€™s as likely to fall apart and cause frustration as it is to induce a reverie.
â€œWalking With the Enemyâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Holocaust- and war-related violence.

In the movieâ€™s fictionalized retelling, the hero, Elek (Jonas Armstrong), bolts from a bombed labor camp. His family deported, he finds refuge in Budapest, falling in with a resistance based around the cityâ€™s Glass House, which prints Swiss papers to aid escape.

â€œWalking With the Enemyâ€ù is based on the real-life deeds of Pinchas Rosenbaum, a Hungarian rabbiâ€™s son who was able to save Jews from the Nazis and their collaborators by disguising himself in enemy garb.

Visually, â€œWalking With the Enemyâ€ù resembles a TV mini-series, a sense enhanced by the director Mark Schmidtâ€™s habit of cutting away from bloodshed. Constant title cards introducing historical figures suggest the work of a completist rather than a filmmaker who has focused the material. (The opening credits twice note that the movie was inspired by a true story.)

â€œWalking With the Enemyâ€ù conveys a palpable sense of how the Nazis were able to rule by fear. Simply dressing up as a German officer and shouting orders, Elek is able to free an imprisoned comrade and redirect death-camp-bound Jews. Via a love interest (Hannah Tointon), the movie shows once again that the imperatives of melodrama â€” which dictate that preferred characters survive â€” and the indifferent slaughter of the Holocaust make for an uneasy mix.

Indeed, a parallel plotline featuring Ben Kingsley as Miklos Horthy â€” who led Hungary as regent and attempted to broker a late surrender to the Soviet Union in defiance of an official alliance with the Nazis â€” would have made a compelling procedural in its own right.

A biting, sometimes droll look at the allure of humiliation, â€œApeâ€ù appears simple, but its underlying machinery is joltingly clever. Working with a tiny crew, the writer and director, Joel Potrykus (a former stand-up who also photographed and edited), proves a maestro of despair and discomfort. In the publicity notes, he describes his film as â€œa rage fantasy with bad jokes,â€ù neglecting to mention how sneakily he implicates the viewer in Trevorâ€™s fury. When Trevor attacks a heckler with a microphone stand, youâ€™ll feel every bit as triumphant as he does.

As insults accumulate â€” a fellow comic steals Trevorâ€™s material; his indifferent boss cancels his set â€” and the pyromania grows more pronounced, the movieâ€™s ultrarealistic style contrasts pointedly with its swelling symbolism. The look is cheap, and the hand-held camera movements are awkward, but Mr. Burge makes Trevor such a weirdly magnetic loser that weâ€™re willing to give him and the film time to find their groove.

Pain is everywhere in â€œApe,â€ù but it starts with the light. From the bright stab of morning after a rough night to the merciless glare of the spotlight in a pitch-black comedy club, this knife-edged portrait of a struggling stand-up uses agony like a silent soundtrack.

Sticking like glue to Trevor (an exquisitely tortured Joshua Burge), the camera wincingly observes his disastrous stage act and lurks behind as he wanders through his day. Alone in a shabby apartment, where posters of Steve Martin grimace from the walls, Trevor practices his delivery in mirrors and absent-mindedly lights scraps of paper on fire. Outside, as he wanders the daytime streets of an unidentified city, a growing aura of threat accompanies his increasingly odd encounters.

Worryingly emblematic of the Everyman assassin who feels entitled to brandish a gun for whatever misguided reason, Dwight makes for a bungling action hero and a polarizing moral center. â€œBlue Ruinâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Wounds inflicted by knife, gun, arrow and garden implement.

Pretty soon, however, heâ€™ll be leaving more than one. â€œThere were some men there,â€ù the small boy with the large brown eyes tells us. â€œYou would go and give them your body.â€ù Others around him nod in agreement â€” and corroborate in more explicit language â€” but â€œDesert Riders,â€ù a deeply troubling account of child camel jockeys in the United Arab Emirates, is not primarily concerned with sexual abuse.
