Thatâ€™s one of the reasons this 78-minute film feels almost twice as long. With one foot among the gleaming skyscrapers of Dubai and the other in the destitute villages of Pakistan, Bangladesh and Sudan, the director, Vic Sarin, unearths tales of children whisked from their parents â€” often by relatives â€” and sold to Arabian camel farms. There, they endure punishing work, appalling injuries and virtual starvation in service to a sport that has become enormously lucrative.

It is tempting to regard Mr. Steadman, with his calm demeanor, mellow voice and lack of interest in drugs, as the sensible Sancho Panza to Thompsonâ€™s gonzo Quixote. But Jann S. Wenner, the publisher of Rolling Stone and as such their frequent underwriter, insists that the artist was the wilder of the two, and his work supports that thesis. Much of â€œFor No Good Reasonâ€ù consists of an extended visit to Mr. Steadmanâ€™s home in England, where he allows us a glimpse of his working methods, and explains himself, in a warm, tobacco-cured voice, to the audience.

And to Johnny Depp, who in the film is both an audience surrogate and something of a distraction. Mr. Depp, who has played Thompson on screen twice (in Terry Gilliamâ€™s â€œFear and Loathing in Las Vegasâ€ù and Bruce Robinsonâ€™s â€œThe Rum Diaryâ€ù), has become an unofficial custodian of the writerâ€™s legacy. As such, his interest in Mr. Steadman is obviously sincere, but his presence exposes a serious weakness in Mr. Paulâ€™s film, which does not seem to trust its subject or his work to be sufficiently interesting to hold the audienceâ€™s attention.

But there is enough of the man and artist here to rekindle interest and appreciation in his often disturbing pictures and an understanding of what motivated them. He is a satirist of Swiftian ferocity, in a graphic tradition that includes the 20th-century German artists George Grosz and Otto Dix. He is intent above all at exposing the ugly face of authority and the harrowing facts of poverty and humiliation. His drawings of hungry children and homeless men mingle with caricatures of popes, plutocrats and presidents into an angry tableau of violence and injustice.

In 1969, Ralph Steadman, a British cartoonist and illustrator, was invited by the editors of Scanlanâ€™s Monthly to attend the Kentucky Derby in the company of Hunter S. Thompson, who was writing an article about the race. This assignment marked the beginning of a long, fruitful and frequently volatile collaboration. Nine years after Thompsonâ€™s death, it is nearly impossible to think of his prose without conjuring visions of Mr. Steadmanâ€™s drawings â€” nightmarishly funny compositions in which spidery lines intersect with clouds of spilled and sprayed ink.

Thompson casts a long shadow over â€œFor No Good Reason,â€ù Charlie Paulâ€™s admiring documentary about Mr. Steadman. Thompson, the demigod of the New Journalism, appears in archival footage, some from older documentaries, cigarette holder clamped between his teeth, never far from a glass of whiskey or a dose of something crazier. The reminiscences of their adventures together are pretty crazy, too. A principle of Mr. Thompsonâ€™s style of journalism was to make himself part of the story, and whether they were covering the Honolulu marathon, the Americaâ€™s Cup or the Ali-Foreman Rumble in the Jungle, he and Mr. Steadman became vivid characters in a pageant made surreal by their participation.

This is evident not only in the repeated reaction shots that show Mr. Depp nodding sagely or gazing admiringly at Mr. Steadmanâ€™s drawings, but also, more egregiously, in the irrelevant pop songs plastered over images that would benefit from silent contemplation. And though it is padded to feature length with tangential interviews (for instance, with Mr. Gilliam and Richard E. Grant, star of â€œWithnail and I,â€ù for which Mr. Steadman drew a poster), â€œFor No Good Reasonâ€ù is less revealing than a standard hourlong television tribute might have been. We learn almost nothing about Mr. Steadmanâ€™s life, and too little about the non-Thompson-related aspects of his oeuvre.

Suspicion of power was something he and Thompson shared â€” their savage depictions of President Richard M. Nixon will live forever â€” but there is a formal discipline and thematic coherence to Mr. Steadmanâ€™s images that his friendâ€™s writing sometimes lacked. Mr. Steadman has frequently aimed to shock, and almost always with good reason.
â€œFor No Good Reasonâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Disturbing images and naughty tales.

The affair begins at a senior center in the picturesque seaside town where Caroline and Philippe have been living comfortably. Mr. Lafitte regards her with an undisguised lust not seen in a movie since Olivier Martinez scrutinized Diane Lane in â€œUnfaithful.â€ù But Caroline never completely melts. The redoubtable French star Fanny Ardant plays Caroline, a comfortably married, recently retired 60-year-old dentist who suddenly finds herself at loose ends. When she has a guilt-free affair with a handsome womanizer (Laurent Lafitte) who is single and 20 years younger, the earth may tremble a little, but it doesnâ€™t open up and consume them in hellfire.

Throw in rape, erotic asphyxiation and a violent beating, and itâ€™s clear the director John Nizzariâ€™s Bronx tale has more than its share of macho posturing. Yet amid the overheated, sometimes amateurish histrionics â€” Mr. Nizzari shoots a lengthy father-son blowout in a single, theatrical take â€” â€œGrand Slammedâ€ù contains inklings of a serious point about immobility in America.

Howie (Ben Mac Brown), a lawyer friend who was also in the car, promises to fix Mikeyâ€™s legal situation, but his obvious designs on Mikeyâ€™s actress girlfriend, Mimi (Natasa Warasch, who helped write and produce), make him difficult to trust. And not even a boozy weekend â€” including a laced drink â€” in the Hamptons can faze Mikey before his coming Phillies tryout, an audition for which his construction worker father (Paul Calderon) has impossibly high hopes.

Howie, the only character who seems to have a shot at escaping the neighborhood, is also a pathological liar, sowing discord among the others and plying a friend (Walter Masterson) with drugs. The Shakespearean plot devices donâ€™t mesh with the documentarylike, realistic portrait of the Bronx. To say that Mikey (Alexander Emmet), the embattled protagonist of â€œGrand Slammed,â€ù has hit a rough patch understates the matter gravely. An aspiring pitcher, he blows his chance in front of a talent scout, leaving blood spattered on home plate from a wild pitch. That evening, he serves as a getaway driver when his buddy Pete (Dimitri Meskouris) hops out of the car for an unexpected gangland shooting.

Cleverly placing question marks on several characters â€” is the attractive young woman (Kara Tointon) a little too friendly? Does the older gent with the omnipresent briefcase (David Schofield) seem overly authoritarian? â€” Mr. Nooshin stirs a mystery thatâ€™s light on special effects and bravely uncomplicated. He may not have much money, but his feel for age and class dynamics is sure, and his actors respond. The result is a quintessentially English action movie: No sex, lots of talking and not a six-pack in sight.

Minimally plotted and modestly executed, this first feature by Omid Nooshin has a comforting, old-fashioned commitment to character building that â€” coupled with railway carriage claustrophobia and the general unloveliness of the surroundings â€” makes the first 30 minutes a little sleepy. (Much like the passengers.) â€œLast Passengerâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Offensive language and even more offensive dÃ©cor.

Like a hard-up version of a 1970s disaster movie, â€œLast Passengerâ€ù drops a disparate group of people in the path of a calamity, then watches as they wriggle to escape. But instead of being on a sinking ship or in a blazing tower block, these unfortunates are trapped on a late-night commuter train that has just left London. And if thatâ€™s not terrifying enough, theyâ€™re headed for the snooty borough of Tunbridge Wells.

One of those road movies in which the journey turns out to be far more interesting than the destination, â€œLockeâ€ù is about a man on the move â€” and on the phone. For nearly the entirety of its fast-moving running time, you effectively play passenger as Ivan drives on a freeway toward a terminus revealed gradually through a succession of phone conversations with various alternately loquacious and tight-lipped relatives, freaked-out co-workers and assorted others, including a panicked mysterious woman. One minute Locke is gently cooing to his increasingly anxious wife, Katrina (voiced by Ruth Wilson), who expected him home after he knocked off; the next, heâ€™s coaxing a co-worker, Donal (Andrew Scott), to take his place during a complex concrete pour at the building site.

In â€œLocke,â€ù he looks like heâ€™s hiding behind a beard to play Ivan Locke, a foreman whoâ€™s first seen leaving a large construction site at night. The director Steven Knight, working from his own script, opens with an establishing shot of the enormous site, a pointed work in progress, and then cuts to a man who approaches an S.U.V. and, after removing his boots, settles in and starts the car. By the time Mr. Knight reveals Ivanâ€™s face, a teasing two minutes have elapsed, enough for the carâ€™s Bluetooth to have fired up and for you to register that the driver is probably in Britain (the wheel is on the right) and makes pretty good money (heâ€™s driving a BMW).
â€œLockeâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Some bad driving and words.

A truism about cinema and television, two tributaries that increasingly flow into one image stream, is that together they have turned the human face into our favorite destination spot. The ubiquity of close-ups, particularly in broadcast television, with its parade of bobbling heads and babbling mouths, could have drained movie faces of their power. Yet we canâ€™t seem to get enough of other peopleâ€™s faces, whether theyâ€™re as frozen as masks or changeable as churning water. We trace stories across these familiar landscapes, becoming geographers of emotion.

Some faces suggest innate vulnerability from forehead to chin. While there are memorable movie faces that seem like jumbles of warring emotions, faces like Mr. Hardyâ€™s appear to express a coherent story, from their sensuous mouth to their searching eyes. Robert Mitchum had sleepy bedroom-ready eyes and thin lips that could, especially as a cigarette dangled from them, suggest infinite possibilities once inside that bedroom. Mr. Hardy has been rightly celebrated as a gifted chameleon because of the shape-shifting talents he demonstrates by dramatically bulking up for some roles and whittling down for others. But itâ€™s how he uses his eyes â€” heâ€™s a master of the averted gaze â€” in consort with his plush, pouty mouth that make him more than just another pretty face.

Initially, it seems almost perverse that Mr. Hardy is bearded in â€œLocke,â€ù if only because it suggests that all that fuzz might get in the way of his expressiveness. Although his mouth is partly obscured and its natural red color tempered by some of the directing choices, including the dusky digital cinematography (the interior of the car is often washed in yellow, presumably from the streetlights), Mr. Hardyâ€™s deliberate, largely hushed delivery and the Welsh accent heâ€™s affected draw attention to his mouth â€” to how he talks, not just what he says. Mr. Knight keeps a fairly steady distance from Ivan â€” underscoring certain tense passages with tighter close-ups â€” but moment by moment, with a twitch, a shudder, a look, itâ€™s Mr. Hardy who movingly draws you in, turning a strangerâ€™s face into a life.

It sounds deadlier and much drier than it plays on screen, particularly given that â€œLockeâ€ù is one of those man-in-a-can movies in which a character spends most of the story immobilized in a tightly circumscribed space. Most man-in-a-can titles wear out their welcome quickly, including â€œPhone Booth,â€ù about a man trapped in you know what, and â€œBuried,â€ù about a far less lucky guy buried alive in a coffin; in â€œGravity,â€ù Sandra Bullock switched cans often enough that the movie never felt oppressive. Here, Mr. Knight helps keep claustrophobia at bay with copious cutaways and point-of-view shots of the darkly shimmering night. (Best known for his scripts for â€œDirty Pretty Thingsâ€ù and â€œEastern Promises,â€ù Mr. Knight also directed â€œRedemption,â€ù one of Jason Stathamâ€™s more ambitious vehicles.)

A movie about a man in lockdown â€” emotionally, psychologically, existentially â€” â€œLockeâ€ù asks you to spend 85 minutes in intimate quarters with Tom Hardy, whoâ€™s mostly seen in medium close-up behind a steering wheel. In recent years, moviegoers have had ample opportunities to explore his beautiful mug in films like â€œTinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy,â€ù in which he wore a bleach job and wounded mien as a British spy who, while doing his dirty work as a so-called scalp hunter falls tragically in love. It was ideal casting because part of what makes Mr. Hardy pop, even in a relatively modest role, is how his somewhat blunt, swaggering, at times inflated physicality â€” in general, he registers as being bigger than he is â€” works in expressive counterpoint to his soft, yielding face.

We follow her through four seasons, each one introduced by a FranÃ§oise Hardy song, but pop-music romance is not really Isabelleâ€™s thing. Ms. Vacthâ€™s face sometimes suggests a very young Julia Roberts, though the portrayal of sex work in â€œYoung & Beautifulâ€ù has more in common with â€œBelle de Jourâ€ù than with â€œPretty Woman.â€ù Or it would, if Mr. Ozon, who wrote and directed, had figured out where he wanted to go with his premise. Isabelle (Marine Vacth), the girl on the beach, is about to turn 17. On vacation with her mother, stepfather and nosy little brother, she loses her virginity to a German guy named Felix. She seems a little bored by him and by the experience, as she does by most things, concealing her emotions behind a mask of sullen affectlessness.

â€œYoung & Beautiful,â€ù the latest movie from the French director FranÃ§ois Ozon, begins with a shot, through binoculars, of a young woman sunbathing topless on a beach. Voyeurism is clearly on the agenda, and Mr. Ozon seems to be teasing out some of its creepy implications when he reveals that the binoculars belong to the sunbatherâ€™s younger brother. She is visibly nervous at first, unconvincingly lying about her age and looking awkward in high heels and one of her motherâ€™s silk blouses. But after a while she approaches her work with confidence and sang-froid, though not exactly with delight.

There is something artificial about this quasi-objective matter-of-factness, and about the filmâ€™s emotional inertness. Though it shares with Lars von Trierâ€™s â€œNymphomaniac: Volume 1â€ù an interest in the erotic power of young women and the pathetic predictability of male appetites, it offers very little in the way of insight or provocation. And as a coming-of-age story, â€œYoung & Beautifulâ€ù has neither the feverish empathy of Abdellatif Kechicheâ€™s â€œBlue Is the Warmest Colorâ€ù or the passionate clarity of Mia Hansen-Loveâ€™s â€œGoodbye First Love.â€ù

Seth (Alex Karpovsky of HBOâ€™s â€œGirlsâ€ù) and Stanley (Stephen Gurewitz, who wrote and directed) are brothers who go on a fishing trip with their father, Marvin (Marvin Gurewitz, the directorâ€™s actual father), though the three of them do not seem to enjoy one anotherâ€™s company. â€œMarvin, Seth and Stanleyâ€ù aims to be a deadpan travels-with-my-wacky-dad story, but the father in it is almost an afterthought. It still has sublime moments, but it leaves you wanting more of them.

The movie bites off more plot than it can comfortably chew, making a crucial final twist more ridiculous than revelatory. But narrative coherence is irrelevant here. Mr. Delamarre is not an action virtuoso, but his visual style, heavily indebted to the Grand Theft Auto video games, is appropriately rough and kinetic. Mr. Walker, the anchor of the â€œFast and Furiousâ€ù franchise and who died in a car accident in November, demonstrates why he will be missed. As is not uncommon with movies of this kind, a certain amount of the dialogue in â€œBrick Mansionsâ€ù consists of excited elaborations of the obvious, perhaps for the benefit of viewers who missed something while texting or dozing. During a foot chase, when the pursued parties have succeeded in locking a door from the outside, one of the pursuers remarks, â€œThey locked the door from the outside!â€ù In the midst of a later chase (there are a lot of them), when the guys who locked that door are hiding on an abandoned school bus, someone shouts, â€œTheyâ€™re on the bus!â€ù And when it is revealed that one of the chief villains is in possession of a military-grade rocket, the strangeness of this fact does not go unnoticed: â€œOnly a crazy person would have a rocket!â€ù

But enough about that. Itâ€™s 2018, and Detroit is under martial law, Brick Mansions is sealed behind checkpoints and security walls, and the mayor and his cronies have cooked up a shady redevelopment scheme. Standing in the way of their plans is Tremaine Alexander (RZA, still best known as one of the masterminds of the Wu-Tang Clan), a narcotics kingpin with an army of hooligans and a serious interest in cooking. Lino and the rugged undercover cop Damien Collier (Paul Walker) are dispatched to take care of Tremaine, who killed Damienâ€™s father and has taken Linoâ€™s former girlfriend, Lola (Catalina Denis), as a hostage.

This movie, a remake of the 2004 French franchise-starter â€œDistrict B13,â€ù can be enjoyably crazy in its hectic, cartoonish way. The rocket, with a neutron bomb strapped to it, is aimed at downtown Detroit, where it threatens to kill three million people. This is a generous estimate for a city that has notoriously suffered a drastic population loss in recent decades, and also a clue that the Detroit of â€œBrick Mansionsâ€ù is more idea than place â€” a convenient shorthand for urban decay.

Thatâ€™s too bad. In the first â€œDistrict B13â€ù film, the rough high-rise housing projects outside Paris â€” the â€œBâ€ù is for banlieue, French for suburb â€” provided a geographically and socially specific dystopian setting for all the running and jumping and fighting. While no one would want â€œBrick Mansions,â€ù directed by Camille Delamarre under the aegis of the genre auteur Luc Besson, to be a work of realism, it does set up topical expectations that it doesnâ€™t quite satisfy. â€œBrick Mansionsâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Violence without blood, sexual titillation without skin and carefully rationed profanity.

The film records a trip to Africa by a young American woman, Kristen Kenney, and her friend Venance Ndibalema, a Tanzanian man who has been studying in the United States for eight years. For him, it is a return to his homeland and a chance to revisit his childhood and the memories of his mother, who died when he was just a boy. For her, it is a chance to demonstrate her self-absorption and cluelessness about the rest of the world, repeatedly.

The filmmaker, Sylvia Caminer, is trying to work the contrast, but Ms. Kenney is so uninformed and shallow that it defies credulity. â€œI havenâ€™t had to overcome anything, compared to these people,â€ù she says at one point, as if thinking the thought for the first time.
The documentary â€œTanzania: A Journey Withinâ€ù is two travel diaries woven together. One is somber and moving. The other is distractingly annoying.

Even the most inattentive young American knows that there are poor people in the world and that life is much harder in most places than it is in the United States. Ms. Kenney seems like a caricature, which inadvertently undercuts the very powerful story her traveling companion has to tell. When it finally emerges, the film finds its purpose.

If some of the facts that mingle seamlessly with the fiction in â€œThe German Doctorâ€ù are familiar, itâ€™s no wonder. The story of Josef Mengele, the Nazi doctor known as the Angel of Death, has been told so often and in such attenuated and mythologizing fashion that it has become part of our collective pop consciousness. Most famously, thereâ€™s â€œThe Boys From Brazil,â€ù the 1976 Ira Levin novel about old Nazis conspiring in South America that was turned into a 1978 thriller with Gregory Peck (!) as Mengele, and Laurence Olivier as a Nazi hunter. Olivier was on the other side in John Schlesingerâ€™s 1976 film version of â€œMarathon Man,â€ù playing a former Auschwitz dentist, called the White Angel, whose way with a drill set back dentistry about as much as â€œPsychoâ€ù did showering.

Like some extraterrestrial being who takes human form, Helmut is at once utterly familiar and utterly alien. Ms. Puenzo doesnâ€™t throw him on the couch: She advances no theories about what makes him who he is, nor does she meditate on questions of evil, justice and vengeance. Although Helmut expresses some of his ugly ideas to Lilith, talking about purity, his worldview and its evil surface somewhat obliquely, in the precise line drawings of human bodies that fill his notebook and in the anxious smiles of others. Mostly, the evil is in his predatory gazing at Lilith, a girl who at one point follows him into the woods like a fairy tale babe, and in the jagged, meaningful tension that emerges from the storyâ€™s beautiful natural setting and the ghastly, unnatural rot of its people.
â€œThe German Doctorâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Nazis and some gun play.

It takes a while before the name Mengele materializes. But the clues are there from the start, beginning with his interest in the girl, Lilith (Florencia Bado), an undersized child whom he befriends and through whose eyes swaths of the story unfold. A classically naÃ¯ve character, Lilith becomes the bridge between Helmut (who, of course, knows the truth); the audience (who can guess); and her parents (whose suspicions and willful ignorance mirror that of the larger world). Because, while Lilithâ€™s father, Enzo (Diego Peretti), looks askance at Helmut, her mother, Eva (Natalia Oreiro), is more accepting, having been raised in the German immigrant hamlet nestled in the foothills of the Andes that â€” edged by snowcapped mountains â€” does much to give this film its subtle, atmospheric chill.

The Argentine writer and director LucÃ_a Puenzo, shooting in wide screen, takes an effective, largely low-key approach to her fictionalization of Mengeleâ€™s time in South America. â€œThe Other Womanâ€ù settles into being a rip-off of the infinitely superior but still minor â€œFirst Wives Club,â€ù in which Bette Midler, Diane Keaton and Goldie Hawn formed a similar team of women dispensing payback to rats. Stack). The movie is directed by Nick Cassavetes, who proves to be much more comfortable playing in soapsuds (â€œThe Notebookâ€ù) than managing a comedy. As for Carlyâ€™s romantic future, never fear. When Kateâ€™s hunky unmarried brother, Phil (Taylor Kinney), appears early in the film, you know he is the designated prince in waiting. Eventually, Carly and Kate team up with Amber (Kate Upton), another of Markâ€™s extramarital playthings, who turn out to be numerous. The three begin plotting revenge. Amber is crassly shoehorned into the movie to provide jiggling eye candy for boys.

The vogue for both remaking films from the 1970s and â€™80s and imitating them, at times down to the last polyester thread (as in â€œThe Conjuringâ€ù), may be an expression of nostalgia, especially for directors born in those decades, or just another example of market-driven copies. Mr. Pogue doesnâ€™t push the God angle hard, even if he does hang a cross around the neck of the credulous lug, Brian (Sam Claflin), whom Coupland hires to film his work with Jane. After objections to Couplandâ€™s methods lead to his experimentâ€™s being shut down, he moves her and a team, including Brian and two students, Krissi (Erin Richards) and Harry (Rory Fleck-Byrne), off campus and into a dilapidated, isolated house with poor lighting and creaky floorboards. The title of â€œThe Quiet Ones,â€ù the latest horror movie about supernatural doings set in the 1970s, is explained fairly late. By then its director, John Pogue, has made a modest racket with the usual bumps in the night, some cackling and screaming, a bit of door slamming and table knocking. An Oxford University lecturer, Coupland believes that the supernatural occurrences in Janeâ€™s bleak, lonely life have been created by her mind and is using every bad idea he has â€” including curing her through sleep deprivation â€” to prove it.

There are nice touches, like the short scene at Oxford in which an angry Coupland, striding across a green lawn with his black gown flapping, evokes a malevolent raven. Yet many of the movieâ€™s more nominally horrific elements are too familiar, including the spooky boy with the dead eyes who appears in the digitally produced black-and-white eight-millimeter film that â€” like Brianâ€™s similarly faked 16-millimeter footage â€” is woven into the main narrative. Mr. Pogue switches between these counterfeited formats well enough, if mechanically, and they add little to the storyâ€™s meaning or the movieâ€™s visual texture. Mostly, they suggest that film stock itself, which has been almost entirely displaced by digital, has already become a ghost haunting the cinema. The horror, the horror.

â€œWe Could Be Kingâ€ù tracks the efforts to combine the schoolsâ€™ football teams, in spite of the lack of funds. Last year, the School District of Philadelphia, facing a shortfall of more than $300 million, instituted a â€œdoomsdayâ€ù budget that ultimately closed 24 schools. Those included the 99-year-old Germantown High School, whose students would attend Martin Luther King High, its former bitter rival.

Having a recognizable face does have the effect of, somewhat awkwardly, underlining the crushing anonymity of the journeyâ€™s many casualties. Itâ€™s hard to tell how much this was intended by the filmmakers. (The movie was written by Mark Monroe and directed by Marc Silver.) In any case, it also amounts to a gruesome body swap: Mr. GarcÃ_a Bernalâ€™s pristine traveler following the route of the sneaker-wearing corpse shown at the beginning, bloated and digitally blurred.

Thatâ€™s not to shortchange how â€œWho Is Dayani Cristal?â€ù skillfully operates in more than one tense through its three angles, and itâ€™s certainly not the first film on the subject to experiment with approaches. (Chantal Akermanâ€™s â€œFrom the Other Sideâ€ù comes to mind.) But itâ€™s also a movie whose techniques present problems not containable by the noble intentions of its makers.

The third perspective comes out of an honorable attempt to trace the manâ€™s steps. These are the movements of many migrants â€” by bus, by train top and by foot. In this case, theyâ€™re taken by Mr. GarcÃ_a Bernal. Clad in a baseball cap, he strikes up conversations with people who are actually making the journey. (The movieâ€™s cinematography award at the Sundance Film Festival comes to feel a little macabre.)

Our main â€œcharacterâ€ù starts as an unknown: The question of the title comes from a tattoo found on a dead body, vividly shown the way it was found in a desert. Colin Firth stars as a fussy, feckless art buyer, Harry Deane, fed up with his boorish media-baron boss, Lionel Shahbandar (Alan Rickman). Puznowski (Cameron Diaz), to sell a counterfeit Monet to Shahbandar. Though troupers as ever, Mr. Firth and Ms. Diaz donâ€™t gel and donâ€™t really embellish their broad characters. The farce of Deaneâ€™s deception never gets its class-comedy glide on. But rather than a shameful mess or even an auteurist curiosity, â€œGambitâ€ù can be almost serenely boring.

Expertly gliding his camera around people who love to talk and a filmmaker who loves to let them, the director of photography, Hanania Baer, works to achieve coherence. No one cares that Mr. Baer is wasting his time.

As cavalier with structure as ever, Mr. Jaglom surrounds himself with familiars who embrace his cheery, disorderly style. (His films feel like gatherings of old friends because they are.) Mouths run and sentences are stepped on; love blossoms and employees rebel. Direct-to-camera interviews for Moxieâ€™s documentary (starring the wonderful Frances Fisher as her wildly hormonal mother) are candid and funny, and Ms. Frederickâ€™s gift for juggling farce, fantasy and raw emotion remains impressive â€” even if her flame is too often muted by a distractingly ugly black beanie.

Most male directors would think twice before wading into a comedy about menopause, but not Henry Jaglom. For his 19th film, â€œThe M Word,â€ù this warmly humane and unfailingly indulgent observer of women and their distractions â€” as celebrated in â€œBabyfeverâ€ù (1994) and â€œGoing Shoppingâ€ù (2005) â€” proves as comfortable with hot flashes as with cooling desire.

But the battle between women and their hormones is only one skirmish in a plot powered by the standoff between money â€” the other â€œMâ€ù word â€” and creativity. In one corner are the employees of a limping television station in Los Angeles; in the other are the New York suits (led by Michael Imperioli) charged with balancing the books. The creatives, however, have a secret weapon: The appropriately named Moxie (Mr. Jaglomâ€™s frequent leading lady, Tanna Frederick), the star of a childrenâ€™s show and the would-be director of a documentary about the change of life.
â€œThe M Wordâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Middle-aged moaning and a menstruation song.

Ms. RodrÃ_guez offers an agonized account, tempered with a palpable affection for Nicaragua. (Of Spanish-Nicaraguan descent, she spent half of her early life there.) While she savors the memory of the idealism following the revolutionariesâ€™ triumph, she mourns later land grabs by Sandinista National Liberation Front leaders, illustrated with tableaus of rotting buildings that convey the partyâ€™s abandoned aspirations. Nicaraguaâ€™s old financial elite, Ms. RodrÃ_guez suggests, retreats in times of tumult, to reappear years later â€” here at a horse show, smug and overfed.

What persists is an underserved lower class, pervasive sexism and a stagnation symbolized by the polluted Lake Managua. Images caught by the cinematographers, Carlos F. Rossini and Leoncio VillarÃ_as â€” a scrawny street cat, a dormant volcano, bicyclists in a sunset silhouette â€” offer a gentle counterpoint to mounting street tension between political parties. â€œWe walk in endless circles,â€ù Ms. RodrÃ_guez narrates. â€œEven if we think we are moving forward, we are just turning back to the same place.â€ù The promise of Nicaraguaâ€™s society may be dim, but Ms. RodrÃ_guezâ€™s concern burns brightly.

In the poetic documentary â€œPalabras MÃ¡gicas (Para Romper un Encantamiento)â€ù â€” â€œMagic Words (Breaking a Spell)â€ù â€” the director Mercedes Moncada RodrÃ_guez meditates on the fraught history of Nicaragua, starting with the years preceding the Sandinista overthrow of the Somoza dictatorship in 1979. Ms. RodrÃ_guez, a sociologist turned filmmaker, has examined the countryâ€™s history before: Her 2005 documentary, â€œEl Inmortalâ€ù (â€œThe Immortalâ€ù), examined the scars left on a family whose members fought on opposing sides in the Contra war in the 1980s. Her new film, presented as part of the Museum of Modern Artâ€™s series â€œIberoamÃ©rican Images: The State of the Art,â€ù covers decades, juxtaposing period footage with the directorâ€™s reflective narration and gorgeous images.

In a filmmakerâ€™s statement, Mr. Gaglia cites his past as a victim of institutional abuse, expressing a wish that the movie will start conversations on the subject. Thatâ€™s certainly valid, but the message gets lost in translation.

The protagonist of â€œAltered States of Plaineâ€ù suffers from an affliction that causes him to teleport to unexpected places. The condition also apparently affects the movie, which has somehow appeared in a commercial theater, despite betraying few signs of visual, aural or narrative control.

Because Emanuel remains conscious, there arenâ€™t many geographic leaps, but a sense of spatial dislocation nonetheless becomes familiar, thanks to a cinematographer who canâ€™t keep his finger off the zoom function. Muddy sound contributes to the atmosphere of confusion, while the script (credited to the director, Nick Gaglia, along with Mr. Gallagher and Ms. Donohue) goes nowhere, eventually stranding Emanuel in a hospital.

Soon after Emanuel rescues a prostitute, Violet (Kether Donohue), from a violent john, the two set out for Maryland, where a professor (Jason Grant) may hold the secret to the illness. Emanuel mainlines crushed caffeine pills to stay awake; heâ€™s mistaken for â€” and functions metaphorically as â€” a drug addict, though Violetâ€™s family hardly notices when the pair stop by for dinner.

We first see Emanuel Plaine (George Gallagher) naked on a New York subway; whenever he falls asleep, thereâ€™s the danger heâ€™ll wake up somewhere else. Apart from the heroâ€™s habit of turning up in random locations au naturel, thereâ€™s no connection to Ken Russellâ€™s â€œAltered Statesâ€ù (1980) or the Paddy Chayefsky novel.

It seems axiomatic that the superhero costume is more important than the actor filling it, and thatâ€™s true to an extent, although perhaps only for comic-book die-hards and movie executives. For the rest of us, talent matters, as demonstrated by the chasm separating the â€œDark Knightâ€ù films and failed adaptations like â€œGreen Lantern.â€ù Kirsten Dunstâ€™s wistful turn as Mary Jane in Mr. Raimiâ€™s trilogy did much to humanize the series, and helped put a personal touch on an industrial product. As Gwen, Peterâ€™s other historically romantic foil, Ms. Stone performs much the same duty in Mr. Webbâ€™s movies, as she effortlessly charms Peter (and you) and brings him to tears. In the comic book, both women have played a part in Peterâ€™s life, but apparently thatâ€™s more than the franchiseâ€™s male screenwriters and directors could handle. So, with Mary Jane nowhere in sight, itâ€™s just Gwen and Peter, dewy lovers discovering each other between spasms of mostly bloodless violence. Mr. Webb has some fun with the image of Spider-Man swinging through the urban canyons, and there are moments â€” as when the image freezes on the tucked, airborne Spider-Man, ready to spring into action like an Olympian â€” in which the movie taps into the giddy freedom and near-unboundedness that the characterâ€™s physical transformation has brought him. Special effects have become so persuasive that it now looks as if there were a real person flying through the air, rather than computer-generated pixels. That said, somebody needs to work on that sticky pale fluid that shoots from Spideyâ€™s wrists and that at times looks distinctly X-rated.

Itâ€™s an amusing moment but disappointing. Gwen deserves better: Sheâ€™s too appealing and crucial to the series to be the subject of mockery, including her boyfriendâ€™s. It isnâ€™t necessarily Mr. Webbâ€™s fault, but the scene serves as a brief, irksome reminder that most women in the big comic-book movies continue to be consigned to supporting roles, and especially antediluvian ones, good for ogling and saving and not much more. Gwen is actually more interesting. Thatâ€™s because, unlike some other superhero stories in which godlike heroes live and love among ordinary folk, Peter remains a strongly human presence. As a superhero, he carries impossible weight on his slim shoulders, but itâ€™s life itself that presses down on him with its burdening guilt, regret and sorrow.

The last time Spider-Man swung into sight, it was to fight a lizard man in a lab coat and cozy up to a living doll. The lizard landed in the clink, but the doll, Gwen Stacy, is back for the good of Spider-Man (Andrew Garfield) and the franchise. As played by Emma Stone, who has the zing of a screwball heroine and the depthless eyes of an anime character, Gwen brightens â€œThe Amazing Spider-Man 2,â€ù a sequel that, until a late, lamentably foolish turn, balances blockbuster bombast with human-scale drama, child-friendly comedy and gushers of tears.

This may be the wettest superhero since Aquaman splashed through the HBO show â€œEntourage.â€ù Then again, Spider-Man, a.k.a. Peter Parker, created at Marvel by Stan Lee and Steve Ditko in 1962, has always been an emotional guy, having entered comic-book legend as a bespectacled high school bookworm who was orphaned, shunned and generally misunderstood: He wasnâ€™t an extraterrestrial, just an above-average, alienated adolescent. When, in an early issue, Peter tries to persuade some kids to visit a science exhibit with him (they laugh and leave), the text spells out his problem and his appeal: â€œFor some, being a teenager has many heartbreaking moments!â€ù And while a radioactive spider bite scrambled his genetic makeup, his juvenile sensitivities remained.

Mr. Webbâ€™s directorial signature is most evident in Peterâ€™s intimate scenes with Gwen, Harry and Aunt May (Sally Field), which have a natural intimacy that can make this superhero movie feel unusually grounded in real life. These scenes warm up the movie, but they take a toll, because, like innumerable other male heroes, super and not, Peter has difficulty straddling the domestic sphere and the world beyond. In some action movies, that can be a source of humor, if often at the expense of the little lady impatiently tapping her foot while her guy saves the world. Such is the case in a scene in which Peter answers a call from Gwen while in the midst of a melee.

That world, according to the screenwriters Alex Kurtzman, Roberto Orci and Jeff Pinkner, who share story credit with James Vanderbilt, has an almost rhythmic predictability: Spider-Man fights a villain; Peter hangs with family and friends; repeat. Fans will note canonical details, like the Ravencroft Institute for the Criminally Insane, while civilians may find themselves comparing Dane DeHaan, who plays Harry Osborn, Peterâ€™s friendly nemesis, with James Franco, who had the role in Mr. Raimiâ€™s trilogy. Mr. Franco was then a near-ringer for James Dean, which dovetailed with Mr. Raimiâ€™s nods to â€œRebel Without a Causeâ€ù; in this movie, Harry registers as more of a neurasthenic dandy with a dreamy, disquieting otherworldliness that can bring to mind the young David Bowie.

Thatâ€™s part of what keeps â€œThe Amazing Spider-Man 2â€ù moving nicely, at least until a late, badly handled turn for the grim. This blunt, uncharacteristically violent development is true to the source material, but itâ€™s a bummer and a blown opportunity, both narratively and in terms of how the male and female characters work. Filmmakers who adapt beloved texts are invariably criticized, no matter what they do, and thatâ€™s particularly true of superhero movies, because the fans exert such claims on the material. Thereâ€™s something amusing about the corporate owner of a superhero brand being held near-hostage by the love of the comic-book true believer, yet itâ€™s hard not to think that this fanatical love can be as creatively inhibiting as the company bottom line.
â€œThe Amazing Spider-Man 2â€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). The movie has the usual largely bloodless violence and includes a death that may be too intense for some younger viewers.

Visionary filmmakers like Christopher Nolan take their movies where they want, and if the results are strong enough, please buffs and agnostics. Mr. Webb seems to have been hired mostly to keep Sonyâ€™s Spider machine going, a tricky task, given that the character doesnâ€™t have the mythic grandeur and gravity that make Batman and Superman seem endlessly exploitable. Peter is a superhero, but heâ€™s also another mopey teenager. Rhys Ifans, who appeared in â€œThe Amazing Spider-Man,â€ù has compared Spidey to another grade-A moper, Hamlet. It goes without saying that â€œHamletâ€ù isnâ€™t only a character; itâ€™s also a bulletproof literary classic with a lot of good lines. It also goes without saying that while some superheroes are born great, others need to have greatness thrust upon them.

Once he comes down to earth, though, the movie does, too, with scenes of heavy destruction that quickly grow monotonous. Many of these involve Oscorp, the evil corporation that symbolizes dehumanizing capitalism (kidding!) and that breeds yet another unhappy employee turned monster turned Spider-Man foe, Max Dillon, a.k.a. Electro (Jamie Foxx). Their first big blowout, in the actual Times Square, arrives like clockwork at the one-hour mark, and, despite some pretty streaks of electric blue and the locationâ€™s texture, is as overly long and busy as most blockbuster battles. Mr. Webb slows down the action here, too, which makes details and gestures pop; itâ€™s a nifty effect, familiar from â€œThe Matrixâ€ù and commercial advertising, and it suggests how Spider-Man sees the world.

Mr. Garfield, whoâ€™s making a career out of playing delicate flowers, fits the role, suit and moist sniffling fine. Heâ€™s a stronger, more restrained actor, as well as a better crier, than Tobey Maguire, who had the role in the three films directed by Sam Raimi (the first one hit in 2002), before the â€œamazingâ€ù sobriquet was tagged on. Resurrected just five years after Mr. Raimiâ€™s final installment, the reborn franchise did the job, â€œwonâ€ù the opening weekend, placated the fans. Directed by Marc Webb, whose one other feature was â€œ(500) Days of Summer,â€ù a romance with a sting, â€œThe Amazing Spider-Manâ€ù did well enough to effectively guarantee that Sony Pictures Entertainment, which has the property, will continue to pump this well until itâ€™s dry. And, indeed, two more sequels have been announced.

According to the singer-songwriter Bill Callahan, performing in front of an audience is â€œthe realest me that there is.â€ù Taking him at his word, the director Hanly Banks makes his live shows the meat of â€œApocalypse: A Bill Callahan Tour Film,â€ù allowing her introspective subject to reveal as much, or as little, as he pleases.

Captured during a 2011 tour to New York from California (Ms. Banks shared cinematography duties with Smokey Nelson), â€œApocalypseâ€ù periodically glances away from stripped-down stage performances to peer at rolling tarmac and grazing cattle. Behind the microphone, however, Mr. Callahanâ€™s thick, peaty baritone â€” accompanied by Matt Kinseyâ€™s clean guitar riffs and Neal Morganâ€™s precise drumbeats â€” needs no visual embellishment. And though this dark troubadour in summery seersucker may drop the odd cryptic comment (â€œSymbols are everything, and thatâ€™s all we haveâ€ù), there are no dredged-up traumas or midnight confessions. Just a tantalizing glimpse of a determinedly outsider talent.

No one familiar with Mr. Callahanâ€™s close-to-the-vest persona will be shocked to learn that, in the revelation department, pickings are slim. (He used to perform under the band name Smog, which perfectly suited his pea-soup voice and sometimes impenetrable lyrics.) Rather than divulge personal tidbits, heâ€™s more comfortable expressing himself in songs that play as a conversation with the America he loves and the people he passes. Movement moves him â€” one song rides the familiar rhythm of a chugging train â€” but you canâ€™t dance to his music or sing it in the bathtub. Deep and cloudy, these are songs you sway to, float on and, if youâ€™re feeling especially broody, drown in.

But the organ hasnâ€™t really disappeared; it has become a person (played by the comedian Nick Thune, whose resulting film credit is â€œRichâ€™s Penisâ€ù). This newcomerâ€™s bad behavior teaches Rich the obvious lesson. Here the film loses its wit and becomes predictable, but it finishes strong, with a funny climactic battle ripped straight from todayâ€™s pharmacy counters.

The movie, directed by Huck Botko and written by Jeff Tetreault, is funny early, as Rich, a chick magnet who keeps sabotaging good relationships by not being able to say no to the many offers he gets, blames his organ for his naughty ways and wishes he could be rid of it. His wish is granted: He wakes up one day to find himself without a penis, leading to some of the movieâ€™s best humor.
A manâ€™s worst nightmare isnâ€™t that an ex posts an Internet rant about him or that beer is found to cause impotence. Itâ€™s that his penis takes human form. Oh, the stories it could tell.

â€œYouâ€™ll be like Carrot Top,â€ù a friend says, speculating on Richâ€™s coming infamy as the Man With No Penis. â€œEveryone will want a picture with you, but no one will want to have sex with you.â€ù
Most men wonâ€™t realize that this is their worst nightmare unless they see â€œBad Johnson,â€ù a sometimes amusing sex farce in which that happens to Rich (Cam Gigandet).

Written by Misan Sagay, â€œBelleâ€ù tracks its heroineâ€™s dawning awareness of both her own social, political and legal position and that of the black slaves who, initially, exist for her only as abstractions. Her education comes through her uncle, the Lord Chief Justice, who has to decide on a horribly real case involving the Zong slave ship, as well as from an amusingly dashing suitor, John Davinier (Sam Reid). The movie plays with the historical record for dramatic effect, as is often the case when the past is disinterred for entertainment, and its realism at times groans under the weight of too many passionate speeches. Yet the weave of the personal and the political finally proves as irresistible as it is moving, partly because it has been drawn from extraordinary life.

You meet her as a child, just as sheâ€™s being taken by her father, a navy captain, Sir John Lindsay (Matthew Goode), from some shadowy mystery hovel to a large country manor. There, in an elegantly appointed room, the kind that announces the refinement of its inhabitants and whispers their entitlement, Sir John formally claims the child as his own and promptly hands her over to his uncle, Lord Mansfield (Tom Wilkinson, very good), and Lady Mansfield (a dry, funny Emily Watson). The Lord and Lady keep their lips, necks and manners stiff, but take the girl in and raise her as their own â€” or almost. Soon sheâ€™s laughing in the garden, and then sheâ€™s a genteel beauty (a fine Gugu Mbatha-Raw) facing life as a black woman in a slave-trading country.

No bodices seem to have been harmed, much less ripped, during the making of â€œBelle,â€ù a period film at once sweeping and intimate, about an 18th-century Englishwoman who transcends her historical moment. Even so, peekaboo bosoms tremble throughout the movie amid the rustle of luxurious gowns and the gasps of polite company as conventions are crushed underfoot. Melodramatic and grounded in history, â€œBelleâ€ù is enough of an old-fashioned entertainment that it could have been made in classic Hollywood. Well, except for one little thing that would have probably given old studio suits apoplexy: The movieâ€™s prettily flouncing title character is biracial.

An unusual painting of her and Elizabeth that shows the women smiling side by side on a terrace â€” both in silk gowns and pearls, and staring directly at us â€” suggests that there was far more to Dido than Hutchinsonâ€™s shabby account. The double portrait, often attributed to Johann Zoffany, now hangs in Scone Palace in Scotland but was painted at Kenwood House in Hampstead, England, where Dido lived for the first 30 or so years of her life. Itâ€™s an exciting image because she wasnâ€™t painted in a traditional subservient pose but instead assumes an almost â€” if not quite â€” equal place with her cousin on the canvas. While Elizabeth stands as still as a vase, the somewhat exoticized Dido (she wears a turban) seems to have been, evocatively, captured in midflight.

Sheâ€™s based on Dido Elizabeth Belle (1761-1804), the daughter of an African woman, Maria Bell, who was probably enslaved and maybe captured off a ship by Sir John. The details of their association and Bellâ€™s life are murky, but when Dido was young, Sir John took her to Lord Mansfield, who raised her alongside another grandniece, Elizabeth Murray (played by a strong Sarah Gadon). In one account, Thomas Hutchinson, a governor of Massachusetts, described visiting the family: â€œa Black came in after dinner and sat with the ladiesâ€ù and later walked arm in arm with one. â€œShe had a very high cap, and her wool was much frizzled in her neck,â€ù Hutchinson wrote, â€œbut not enough to answer the large curls in fashion. She is neither handsome nor genteel â€” pert enough.â€ù

The vivaciousness of Didoâ€™s image doesnâ€™t always come through in the movie portrait, which the director, Amma Asante, has created in the Merchant-Ivory school of serious, tasteful entertainments. Itâ€™s easy to mock such films, with their pretty manners and people, but, at their best, they open a door onto an old world that is sometimes more fragile, brittle, imperiled and considerably more complex than its sumptuous trappings at first suggest. Likewise here, Dido and her cousin, both cosseted and corseted, exist in near-pastoral harmony, yet their lives are nowhere as carefree as they seem. Elizabeth has a complicated history and needs, much like a Jane Austen heroine, to marry to ensure her future. And while Dido may be one of the family, sheâ€™s also sometimes kept segregated.
â€œBelleâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Squeaky clean.

Because Casper and Dominicâ€™s relationship is the center of the movie, other key characters remain underdeveloped. Casper works for his father, Clayton (Aidan Gillen from â€œGame of Thronesâ€ù), a small-time crook who smuggles in Canadian pharmaceuticals that make their way down the Interstate 95 corridor. The operation is a family affair that involves Claytonâ€™s jittery brother, Badger (Timm Sharp), who is arrested by state drug enforcement agents and pressured to gather evidence against Clayton.

These scenes have explosive dramatic potential, but they arenâ€™t sufficiently developed to convey the sense of tragic inevitability that underlies the story. The characters arenâ€™t properly introduced, and as the increasingly choppy film zigzags among several subplots, you long for a dramatic grounding wire as compelling as Melissa Leo in â€œFrozen River,â€ù an equally bleak film set in similar border territory.

Dominic, explaining his loyalty to his volatile buddy, declares, â€œWhen Iâ€™m with Casper, I know something crazy is going to happen.â€ù And in a place where they are first seen idly throwing stones at a rusted water tower, shooting potatoes out of a cannon and going on a â€œmoose safari,â€ù crazy is better than nothing.

This is the world of â€œBeneath the Harvest Sky,â€ù the dour first feature film directed by Aron Gaudet and Gita Pullapilly. For teenagers unlucky enough to grow up there, the desire to leave is a driving force. But Boston, the nearest big city, over 400 miles away, might as well be on another planet.

Dominic shyly pursues a romance with Emma (Sarah Sutherland), with whom he works in the potato fields. Planning to go to college and knowing that she may not return, Emma disappoints him by characterizing their bond as a â€œharvestâ€ù friendship.

Geography is destiny. Even in the land of opportunity, the place you are born and brought up has a lot to do with determining your future. And if that place is Van Buren, Me., a dingy, fading agricultural town on the Canadian border, there is not much of a future to look forward to.

Filmed in a quasidocumentary style using hand-held cameras, extreme close-ups and a muddy palette, this slice of regional life aspires to be a northern New England answer to â€œThe Last Picture Show.â€ù Its protagonists â€” the cocky, hotheaded Casper (Emory Cohen) and the even-tempered Dominic (Callan McAuliffe), both 17 and best friends since childhood â€” face three choices: accept a lifetime of grueling, low-wage farm work harvesting blue potatoes; run drugs back and forth across the Canadian border; or flee.

â€œBeneath the Harvest Skyâ€ù reaches a dramatic climax that is so rushed and confusing, you are left scratching your head. But for all its missteps, the film feels authentic. Through thick and thin, it stubbornly maintains a thorny integrity.

The boys are pooling their meager resources to buy a used red sports car to drive to Boston with no particular goal beyond getting out of Van Buren and going to Red Sox games. But Casperâ€™s fantasies of escape are dashed when his 15-year-old girlfriend, Tasha (Zoe Levin), announces she is pregnant. A hormonal firecracker who is Cain to Dominicâ€™s Abel, Casper reacts to the news with a stunned, sullen silence.

The movie makes clear how rapid advances in computer technology helped Ms. King prove the link between genetic mutations and the increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers. Because the screenplay offers more scientific data than the average viewer can probably take in, the documentary and dramatic aspects often get in each otherâ€™s way, and the movie barely begins to integrate the two.

These two heroines could hardly be more dissimilar. Ms. Mortonâ€™s Annie is a soft, resilient woman who endures enormous suffering with a stoic resignation, although she begins to crack during the agonies of chemotherapy. With the exception of one doctor, the medical experts she consults treat her condescendingly.

Ms. Mortonâ€™s quiet, strong performance gives â€œDecoding Annie Parkerâ€ù much of its human dimension. Annie is only 14 when her mother collapses and dies. At 19, she marries Paul (Aaron Paul), who works as a pool cleaner in Toronto while futilely pursuing a career as a rock musician. At a certain point, he goes around wearing eye makeup. After Annie falls ill, Paul begins an affair with her best friend, Louise (Alice Eve). The movie could easily have depicted him as rat but instead portrays him as a confused, overgrown boy not unlike Jesse Pinkman, Mr. Paulâ€™s character on â€œBreaking Bad.â€ù

Ms. King is a taut, unsmiling crusader waging a war not only against breast cancer but also against the smug, dismissive, mostly male medical establishment that leaves her research perpetually underfunded. Crisp, bordering on icy, she is portrayed by Ms. Hunt with the simmering anger of someone so consumed by her quest that she has no room in her life for anything else.

â€œDecoding Annie Parkerâ€ù is considerably better than the kind of disease-of-the-week fare that used to be a television clichÃ©. In todayâ€™s colder emotional climate, the mystique of medical technology is supplanting weepy spirituality as the default mode of movies about serious illness. Tears are shed in â€œDecoding Annie Parker,â€ù but they arenâ€™t accompanied by the kind of sad, misty soundtrack music that can leave you feeling used and abused. Instead of jerking tears, the movie edifies.

â€œDecoding Annie Parker,â€ù Steven Bernsteinâ€™s useful, high-minded docudrama about breast cancer, is a gawky mixture of medical tutorial and personal history. Ms. Parker, played by Samantha Morton with an air of crumpled dolefulness that masks a core of ferocious determination, is a Canadian living in Toronto whose mother and sister succumb to breast cancer, which she eventually develops herself. It was the first of her three bouts with cancer, all of which she survived.
â€œDecoding Annie Parkerâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strong language and some sexual content.

In its saddest scene, this kindhearted film gives Paul his say after Annie finds the courage to voice her disappointment that their once torrid physical relationship has gone dry. When Paul confesses his revulsion toward Annieâ€™s mastectomy scar, their relationship reaches a hopeless impasse.

The screenplay parallels her dogged search for a connection between the deaths in her family with the uphill battle of the renowned geneticist Mary-Claire King (Helen Hunt) to prove the existence of a genetic predisposition to cancer. Annie sends many letters of inquiry to Ms. King, then based at the University of California, Berkeley, but they go unanswered. When the women finally meet at the end of the movie, Ms. King is brusquely welcoming.

In earlier films, she has cast Isabelle Huppert and Nathalie Baye as her mother (in â€œEntre Nousâ€ù and â€œCâ€™est la Vieâ€ù). In â€œFor a Woman,â€ù the blond, open-faced MÃ©lanie Thierry â€” an actress less intensely present than Ms. Huppert and Ms. Baye â€” steps into the role. Not surprisingly, the focus shifts from the mother to the father (a nuanced BenoÃ®t Magimel here; Guy Marchand and Richard Berry previously).

â€œFor a Womanâ€ù (the title refers to a perfume) moves between two periods. In 1947, the parents, Michel and Lena (he saved her from a concentration camp), are starting to build new lives; in the 1980s, the Ms. Kurys stand-in, Anne (Sylvie Testud), and her sister (Julie Ferrier) cope with a dying father.

Ms. Kurys tells this part of the story assuredly and unhurriedly. The 1980s sequences, with their tears and epiphanies, are less vivid and less convincing. An inviting sense of mystery hangs over the events of 1947, Ms. Kurysâ€™s origin story. There are some things, she seems to say, that we never fully understand, including the people we are closest to.

The past seems to haunt the writer-director Diane Kurys â€” and to tempt her to reimagine events, testing out versions of her parents and stretching their emotional contours by placing them in different dramatic situations.

The real drama is in 1947. Michelâ€™s long-lost brother, Jean (an excellent Nicolas Duvauchelle, the broody ThÃ©o on the noirish French TV series â€œBraquoâ€ù), shows up, challenging Michel on two fronts: the political (Michel is a Communist) and the domestic (Lena is attracted to Jean, and he to her).

After years of working as a reporter in the United States, Jose Antonio Vargas performed the journalistic equivalent of a scientific experiment on himself. He publicly revealed his status as an illegal immigrant through an article in The New York Times Magazine in 2011. In the film â€œDocumented,â€ù which is part get-out-the-message tour, part personal reckoning, Mr. Vargas argues on behalf of liberalizing immigration policy and confronts others â€” and himself â€” about his predicament.

Mr. Vargas, 33, was slipped into the United States from the Philippines as a child, to California, where his grandparents had already settled. He flourished, a magnet for mentors and proxy moms, but grew distant from his actual mother back home and uncomfortable with the deception. His film amounts to a series of attempts at connecting, whether with a classroom full of high school students, white-haired Mitt Romney supporters at a rally or (in one bridge-building moment) a possibly intoxicated housing contractor complaining about immigrant â€œhordes.â€ù (As a result of his article, Mr. Vargas loses his driverâ€™s license, but he remains in the United States and seems to travel freely.)

Thereâ€™s a late, welcome shift in point of view to his mother. A Skype call yields, within seconds, a heartwarming bit of why-are-you-up-so-late mothering. But until then, the string of lectures and encounters and the considerable drama of his situation donâ€™t always translate to the screen, and Mr. Vargasâ€™s apt formulations come to sound like sound bites. His strategy is political â€” in a meaningful way â€” but not cinematic.

A Los Angeles parking meter attendant, Michael Harris (the motor-mouthed Ryan Hansen) lives to issue tickets. Michael speaks in messaging abbreviations (he actually says â€œbee-tee-dubsâ€ù) and takes unseemly glee in using Facebook to make fun of the ostensible losers he fines.

Challenged, in one day, with being fired from his job and rejected by his nominal friend Joel (Zach McGowan), Michael decides to announce his death online, strong-arming a former co-worker, Emile (James Immekus), into the scheme.

Movies have struggled to make social media cinematic, but judging from â€œFriended to Death,â€ù the revolution can wait. The feature debut of the director Sarah Smick, this bubble gum comedy gambles on a noxious protagonist â€” and fails to find much humor in him.

By populating the scenario with man-children, Ms. Smick (who wrote the screenplay with Ian Michaels) has guaranteed her own performance â€” as a towing victim who stalks Michael â€” a spot as the filmâ€™s relative beacon of sanity. Constant close-ups give the sense that the movie itself is violating viewersâ€™ personal space, while an earnest moral suggests that online communication canâ€™t substitute for face-to-face interaction: a topic â€œFriended to Deathâ€ù doesnâ€™t seem to know much about.

Suddenly, the virtual world takes a shine to him. â€œPeople are devastated â€” itâ€™s like 9/11,â€ù Michael crows, in one instance of the movieâ€™s mistaking his outrageousness for humor. Thereâ€™s a peculiar vagueness about whether these characters are adults or severely arrested adolescents. Emile nervously jokes that Michael and Joel might not just be â€œbestiesâ€ù but â€œÂ â€˜Brokebackâ€™ besties.â€ù
â€œFriended to Deathâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Bad behavior online and off.

Mr. Pawlikowskiâ€™s style of shooting might be described as sympathetically objective. His camera maintains its distance, and he never presumes access to the inner lives of his characters. He keeps them low in the frame, with unusually ample space above their heads, creating a kind of cathedral effect. Ida and Wanda can seem small and alone, lost in a vast and empty universe. But their surroundings often achieve a quiet grandeur, an intimation of divine presence.

But the accomplishment is hardly his alone: â€œIdaâ€ù belongs equally â€” and on the screen, pre-eminently â€” to the two Agatas. Ms. Kulesza is a poised and disciplined professional, able to show us both Wandaâ€™s ruthless self-control and its limits. Ms. Trzebuchowska, a student with little previous acting experience, is a natural screen presence and also an enigmatic one. Ida starts out, for the audience and perhaps herself, as an empty vessel, with little knowledge or experience of the world. To watch her respond to it is to perceive the activation of intelligence and the awakening of wisdom. I canâ€™t imagine anything more thrilling.

This is almost literally true, thanks to Lukasz Zal and Ryszard Lenczewskiâ€™s beautifully misty, piercingly sharp monochrome cinematography. The look of â€œIdaâ€ù â€” images captured by a mostly stationary camera in the boxy frame associated with old movies â€” serves an obvious period function. What you are watching could virtually have been made in 1962. (The Polish countryside seems to have cooperated by not changing too much in the decades since.) Until the very end, the audience never hears music unless the people on screen hear it, too, and many of the scenes â€” at once austere and charged with an intensity that verges on the metaphysical â€” owe an evident debt to â€™60s cinema heroes like Ingmar Bergman and Robert Bresson.

Ida (Agata Trzebuchowska) is a young novice a few days from taking her vows in the convent that has been her only home since infancy when she learns of the existence of a previously unknown aunt named Wanda (Agata Kulesza). If this were actually a fairy tale, Wanda might be both fairy godmother and wicked witch. A former state prosecutor, she boasts grimly of her role in the political show trials of the early 1950s, when Polandâ€™s Communist government used judicial terror (among other methods) to consolidate its power and eliminate its enemies.

Ida and Wanda set out to discover what happened to Idaâ€™s parents, a quest that turns â€œIdaâ€ù into both a road movie and a detective story. They encounter priests and peasants, provincial officials and a saxophonist (Dawid Ogrodnik) whose advanced musical taste (as well as his attraction to Ida, in spite of her habit) provides a hint of youthful â€™60s spirit amid the gloom and bad memories.

There is an implicit argument here between faith and materialism, one that is resolved with wit, conviction and generosity of spirit. Mr. Pawlikowski has made one of the finest European films (and one of most insightful films about Europe, past and present) in recent memory.

Though it takes place in Poland in 1962 â€” a weary, disenchanted country grinding along under gray, post-Stalinist skies â€” Pawel Pawlikowskiâ€™s â€œIdaâ€ù has some of the structure and feeling of an ancient folk tale. It concerns an orphan who must make her way through a haunted, threatening landscape, protected only by her own good sense and a powerful, not entirely trustworthy companion.

But â€œIdaâ€ù is hardly an exercise in antiquarian pastiche. It is rather an excavation of truths that remain, 70 years after the Holocaust and a quarter-century after the collapse of Communism, only partially disinterred. And it is, above all, about the spiritual and moral condition of the women, who, between them, occupy nearly every second of this film.
â€œIdaâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Â Implied sex, death and dictatorship. Heavy smoking.

Mr. Pawlikowski, who started out making documentaries and whose previous fictional features include â€œLast Resort,â€ù â€œMy Summer of Loveâ€ù and â€œThe Woman in the Fifth,â€ù can be a wonderfully lucid storyteller. â€œIdaâ€ù is as compact and precise as a novella, a sequence of short, emphatic scenes that reveal the essence of the characters without simplifying them. Having set up an obvious contrast between Wanda and Ida â€” atheist and believer; woman of the world and sheltered child; sensualist and saint â€” the film proceeds to complicate each womanâ€™s idea of herself and the other. Their black-and-white conceptions of the world turn grayer by the hour.

A decade later, she is still part of the political elite, though whatever zealotry she might once have had has long since been replaced by cynicism. Chain-smoking and drinking heavily, pursuing one-night stands more out of habit than desire, she is in every way the opposite of her unworldly, pious niece. But Wanda does see a family resemblance and also has a startling piece of news, delivered with a wry, bitter smile as Ida, with her coif and crucifix, sits at the kitchen table: â€œYouâ€™re Jewish.â€ù

This is not a joke â€” and there is nothing funny about the wartime fate of Polandâ€™s Jews, including Idaâ€™s parents â€” but â€œIdaâ€ù and its characters are alert to the absurdities of Polish history, as well as its abundant horrors. Mr. Pawlikowski, a Polish-born writer and director who has spent most of his career in England, has reached into his countryâ€™s past and grabbed hold of a handful of nettles. â€œIdaâ€ù is a breathtakingly concise film â€” just 80 minutes long â€” with a clear, simple narrative line. But within its relatively brief duration and its narrow black-and-white frames, the movie somehow contains a cosmos of guilt, violence and pain. Its intimate drama unfolds at the crossroads where the Catholic, Jewish and Communist strains of Polandâ€™s endlessly and bitterly contested national identity intersect.

Sometimes genre-based filmmakers donâ€™t know how to make their material fun without making fun of their material, but thatâ€™s not a failing of Mr. Krenâ€™s. He lines up his characters â€” a hapless group led by a grumpy technician, Janek (Gerhard Liebmann), and joined by a government minister (Mr. Krenâ€™s mother, Brigitte Kren) making a publicity visit â€” then happily unleashes the monsters. Claustrophobic suspense arises from whirling attacks in rocky valleys and within cabins. Thereâ€™s creepy-crawly horror, a dog that emerges as the emotional (and biological) center of the story and some nasty bites (the kind that only get unimaginably worse after scratching).

As the threat of a Pandoraâ€™s box of crossbreed mayhem develops, it ceases to matter that we donâ€™t always get a good look at these attackers, or that Mr. Kren is rather free with the sonic mood setting. Itâ€™s all part of the enthusiastic craft of setting critters loose, on a budget but without mercy.

For anyone who still associates Austrian cinema with Michael Hanekeâ€™s dour, stringent visions, â€œBlood Glacier,â€ù from the Vienna-born filmmaker Marvin Kren, presents a rousing alternative, complete with giant flying insects. In Mr. Krenâ€™s enjoyably committed and splattery creature feature, scientists and visitors at an Alpine weather station fend off mutant beasts that materialize after the discovery of a sprawling, rust-colored hunk of ice.

Born Bruce Campbell in Philadelphia, the musician clashed with his divorced parents, who were in denial about his sexuality, and went AWOL from military service. As Jobriath Salisbury, he was a member of the Los Angeles cast of â€œHairâ€ù and of a band called Pidgeon that showcased his mix of flowery folk and orchestral studio pop. After his David Bowie/Ziggy Stardust turn flamed out, he re-emerged as a New York cabaret act, first as Cole Berlin, then as Bryce Campbell, and died in 1983, an early AIDS casualty.

If Jobriath, a would-be star of glam-rock during the genreâ€™s 1970s heyday, is recalled at all, itâ€™s because of his monster billboard, which loomed over Times Square despite a debut album that failed to sell.
â€œTake it over the top,â€ù Mr. Brandt says, â€œThatâ€™s my job.â€ù

The premise of Kieran Turnerâ€™s â€œJobriath A.D.â€ù is that a monumental talent died a victim of criminally negligent management that hyped him as the first openly gay rocker without promoting his music. The film makes something of the same error: Describing a personal story of considerable sympathy, it does not play full Jobriath tracks, just clips.

Itâ€™s cruel but must be said: Presented in hushed, reverent tones, â€œJobriath A.D.â€ù often comes across as mockumentary material; each ghastly career move is followed by another. Hampered by limited video of Jobriath, the film lacks a sense of him or his music. Its chief contribution is to let Jobriathâ€™s manager, Jerry Brandt, discuss his stupefyingly dumb marketing while evading responsibility. Everything he did, he stresses, Jobriath wanted.

When last we saw Kham, a Thai martial arts expert and fierce defender of his jungle domain, he was battling to retrieve his sacred baby elephant, Khon, which had been kidnapped and taken to Australia in â€œThe Protectorâ€ù (2006).
Again with the elephant?

That worked out well enough. So when the director, Prachya Pinkaew, and his favorite elbows-of-fury actor, Tony Jaa, were finished with their â€œOng Bakâ€ù trilogy, they brought the whole gang back in â€œThe Protector 2.â€ù That includes Kham (Mr. Jaa); his friend Mark, the Interpol agent (Mum Jokmok); and Khon, who is kidnapped once more.

With jokes and computer-generated spectacles diluting the action, this is not one for fight-film purists. The movieâ€™s true hero, of course, is Panna Rittikrai, the renowned martial arts choreographer who comes up with many impressive set pieces here, including Khamâ€™s face-off with hordes of motorcycle-riding assassins on the rooftops of Bangkok. Next time, maybe theyâ€™ll get Khon up there, too.
â€œThe Protector 2â€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for excessive stylized violence and about every 10th word RZA utters.

This time, Khon has been stolen ostensibly for an elephant camp but, it turns out, for a far darker purpose. As Kham hunts for Khon, he gets mixed up with a murder, twin female martial artists who think he did it, and LC, a crime lord who ranks and collects fighters. (LC is played by RZA of the Wu-Tang Clan; he portrays a similar character â€” minus the blind Thai translator â€” in â€œBrick Mansions.â€ù) Since Kham combines the best of the Muay Thai discipline with elements of parkour, he is branded No. 1. Literally.

â€œNOWâ€ù is ostensibly about the last production of the Bridge Project, an ambitious collaboration of British and American actors that took its work to stages around the world. The effort concluded with â€œRichard III.â€ù (It played in 2012 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where I saw it.) Fans of â€œHouse of Cardsâ€ù on Netflix will see, as Mr. Spacey acknowledges, the shadings of Frank Underwood in his King Richard.

In interviews, Mr. Spacey is generous in his comments, and his journeyman co-stars are generous about him. Still, he remains an enigma. Most absorbing are the electric moments when the camera captures him about to go onstage, sweating, concentrated, in heaven.

What â€œNOWâ€ù does well is explain why these actors love the place- and time-bound quality of live theater, most evident in the troupeâ€™s stop at the ancient Greek theater of Epidaurus. They share a convincing respect for the rituals and bonds this project has let them form; â€œNOW,â€ù in the end, celebrates a warm and particular type of family values.

The first image that appears in â€œNOW: In the Wings on a World Stageâ€ù is the â€œSpacey Presentsâ€ù logo. Thatâ€™s Kevin Spacey, the benefactor and, more or less, the focus of this entertaining documentary â€” entertaining for a select audience, which pretty much means fans of theater or Mr. Spacey, or both. Iâ€™m both. Your results may differ.

But the documentary aims to honor the Bridge Project, and that goal is shortchanged. Too little is said about the international nature of the collaboration of British and Americans, or about the varying audiences around the world. And while the cast members are nicely photographed on their travelogue adventures in Qatar and China, those moments arenâ€™t particularly unguarded.

But Mr. Mann also speaks movingly of having to be a student of sorts himself, well into his career: He was with the quartet for so long that other players cycled in and out, bringing fresh perspectives to which he had to adjust.

Mr. Mann, now in his 90s, was a founder of the Juilliard Quartet in 1946 and played with the group for 51 years, retiring in 1997. He recalls one particular music lesson from his childhood in Oregon that opened his eyes.
â€œUp to then, I was going to be a forest ranger, hopefully in a national park,â€ù he says. â€œThat was my dream. But that day, I thought, â€˜You know, music is very interesting.â€™Â â€ù

Allan Miller wisely keeps the hagiography to a minimum in â€œSpeak the Music,â€ù his documentary about Robert Mann, the longtime violinist for the Juilliard String Quartet. Though colleagues and former students chime in, Mr. Miller lets Mr. Mann and his violin do most of the talking, drawing on assorted interviews and vintage performance clips that convey both the skill and the enthusiasm underpinning his subjectâ€™s long career.

He learned not only to play extremely well but also to study the music and the composer to find the meaning and intent beneath the notes. The film is subtitled â€œRobert Mann and the Mysteries of Chamber Music,â€ù and it includes scenes of him teaching and coaching young players, trying to convey nuances that, frankly, might be accessible only to viewers who are musicians, too.

The cast does a fine collective job, and Mr. Brillâ€™s script flirts with clever charm here and there. But the whole film is a missed opportunity because the situations repeatedly defy credibility, and the humor never says anything remotely fresh about human nature or the world we live in.

After Meghanâ€™s night with the gorgeous bartender-author, Gordon (Mr. Marsden), she learns that she still has a shot at the job and sneaks out before dawn to go home and prepare. But her car is towed before her very eyes with her purse inside. And sheâ€™s just left her smartphone at Gordonâ€™s place. (She canâ€™t remember the apartment number.) This being the kind of neighborhood a bartender-author could afford to live in, she soon encounters crack dealers, a hairy taxi driver willing to accept a lap dance instead of the fare and a pair of cops who assume that she is a hooker and are too busy preaching at her to listen to her story.
