â€œWalk of Shameâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Enough four-letter words to sink a ship, gun violence, alcohol abuse, drug references and sexual situations.

Meghanâ€™s out-of-character behavior, drinking to extreme excess with her best friends, is explained by the double blow that day of being left by her fiancÃ© and learning she has lost the job (she thinks). Meghanâ€™s first real mistake that evening is agreeing to wear the yellow micro-mini- dress that belongs to her friend Denise (Sarah Wright Olsen), who defines the term dim bulb.

The filmâ€™s comic premise has worked before, in â€œThe Out-of-Towners.â€ù A respectable, sheltered middle-class American has a big job interview, but everything goes wrong. He ends up in a big city with no money, ID, food or transportation, and people treat him and his wife like pariahs. In this new comedy, written and directed by Steven Brill, the respectable American is Meghan (Elizabeth Banks), a Los Angeles television newswoman and self-described â€œgood girlâ€ù being considered for a network job.

Spanning ethnicities and incomes â€” without drawing conclusions based on either â€” Ms. Ben-Ari simply observes the nursing journeys of five new mothers in New York City. All are candid, hopeful and a little hesitant, bravely allowing the camera access to intimate moments and difficult decisions. Variously confronting sexual and financial worries, lack of maternity leave and performance anxiety, the women transform a seemingly simple act of mothering into a complex diary of daily challenges.

â€œHeâ€™s looking for something to latch on to,â€ù one awed father says as his newborn son gapes at the world. If little Matteo is anything like most of his peers, thatâ€™s probably going to be a lifelong quest.

Whether spraying or leaking, massaged by hand or pumped by machine, the breasts of the young mothers in â€œBreastmilkâ€ù are arguably more active than the infants they nourish. Cheerfully exposed or decorously veiled, the functioning of these workhorses may be life-sustaining, but, as Dana Ben-Ariâ€™s admirably agenda-free documentary reveals, it can also be shockingly stressful.
Touching segments with two resourceful same-sex couples widen the filmâ€™s perspective, as do the fathers who hover benignly on the margins.

Empathetic and nosy, Ms. Ben-Ari is no unequivocal cheerleader for breast over bottle: If anything, her subjectsâ€™ time-consuming struggles and evident exhaustion could put a damper on the natural-feeding plans of the most sanguine new parent. Yet the film isnâ€™t a downer. The lighting is soft, the close-ups are kind, the tone is peaceful, and occasional professionals â€” like Patrece Griffith-Murray, a community health worker and mistress of the salty, sensible comment â€” inject humor and calm nerves.

Ms. Halpern (who has made fiction films, including â€œYour Name Here,â€ù featuring Mr. Foulkes) and Mr. Quilty face a common pitfall: a reluctance to rein in a personality. Maybe it arises from a belief in the authenticity of an unmediated voice, or maybe just from growing accustomed to his routine. But Mr. Foulkes overwhelms this documentary, which buys into his one-man band a little too much.

His self-edits demystify the sanctity of completed artwork and serve to produce a mix of hope and terror among any chronic procrastinators in the audience. Itâ€™s part of a glimpse of creative excess matched by cutaways and clips of Mr. Foulkesâ€™s songs, and his hopefully cathartic stream of musings, regrets and complaints.

In more ways than one, Tamar Halpern and Chris Quiltyâ€™s documentary â€œLlyn Foulkes One Man Bandâ€ù is about not knowing when to stop. The filmmakers are blessed and cursed with a subject who seems to lack the usual filters. We in turn witness Mr. Foulkes in action, at length â€” revamping his works, railing against the art world and speaking his neurotic mind.

Perhaps too obediently, Ms. Halpern and Mr. Quilty adopt the not uncommon narrative of a comeback, building up to a New York exhibition and coming down with Mr. Foulkesâ€™s ensuing recovery period. (The film covers seven years in all and includes Dennis Hopper among its interviewees.) The idea of a work in progress is vigorously exercised before our eyes: Mr. Foulkes adjusts elements of his textured, wall-size piece â€œThe Lost Frontierâ€ù and saws off an offending portion of his painting â€œThe Awakening,â€ù influenced by a past marriage.

Now 79, he belongs to the constellation of West Coast artists in the 1950s and â€™60s widely associated with Pop. Thatâ€™s only part of a career featuring junk assemblage, geological portraiture and a sideline in music with a homemade Seussian contraption of horns and drums. He comes across as a mostly lovable, cranky and brilliant outsider who nurses a gallery-size chip on his shoulder about not getting his due.

The on-camera absence of its subject and its overall indifference to matters of biography make â€œSol LeWittâ€ù a welcome departure from most documentaries about artists, as well as a fitting and serious tribute to his art. It is odd that people devoted to the remaking of forms and the renewal of imagination are usually subjected to the most conventional and literal-minded cinematic treatment. Mr. Teerink defies the formula, declining to speculate on the psychological or personal sources of LeWittâ€™s art and focusing instead on the philosophy behind it.

The result is both an accessible introduction and a piece of advanced criticism. â€œSol LeWittâ€ù will help you understand the art it depicts and allow you to appreciate those aspects of it that surpass understanding. You also appreciate the labor and time that goes into turning LeWittâ€™s instructions into visual facts:

Mr. Teerinkâ€™s film is attuned to the intellectual implications of LeWittâ€™s work and to the aesthetic effects of its realization. We spend a gratifying amount of the filmâ€™s compact running time looking at witty, building-block structures in the middle of urban parks and plazas; at rooms in the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art that buzz with undulating bands of color; at walls in private houses covered in faint pencil markings.

â€œWall Drawing 801: Spiralâ€ù involves scaffolding, several layers of paint, masking tape and the meticulous care of a large crew of artisans and students. The installation of the Mass MoCA retrospective, which fills cavernous spaces in an old textile mill (and is to remain up until 2033), was an even bigger project.

LeWitt, who died in 2007, believed that an artistâ€™s work was primarily done not with the hands, but with the mind. â€œThe idea becomes a machine that makes the art,â€ù he wrote in his manifesto-ish â€œParagraphs on Conceptual Art,â€ù and a large part of his oeuvre consists of instructions, at once precise and enigmatic, for making sculptures, paintings and drawings that are geometrically complex and visually powerful in ways that surpass understanding.

But there is also something refreshingly democratic about LeWittâ€™s aesthetic, which was partly meant to subvert the commodification of art by making the work a series of ideas that anyone could, in principle, carry out. And there is something beautiful about the way he disappeared into it, even as he was making what proved to be an indelible mark on the world.

The central action in â€œSol LeWitt,â€ù Chris Teerinkâ€™s eye-catching and informative new documentary about that great American conceptual artist, is the execution of one of his pieces â€” â€œWall Drawing 801: Spiralâ€ù â€” on the interior wall of a vast, bell-shaped room at a Dutch museum.

What we do not see much of is LeWitt himself, who was averse to publicity and resisted the celebrity status many of his colleagues were more than happy to cultivate. He is present in a few old photographs, some audio snippets from an interview and the recollections of friends. These include fellow artists, gallerists and museum curators and LeWittâ€™s neighbors in Spoleto, Italy, where he and his family lived in the 1980s.

â€œNeighborsâ€ù is not a great film and does not really aspire to be. It is more a status report on mainstream American movie comedy, operating in a sweet spot between the friendly and the nasty, and not straining to be daring, obnoxious or even especially original. It knows how to have fun. How very grown-up.

Soon enough, the Greeks and their neighbors are at war, and â€œNeighborsâ€ù ascends to an impressively high level of farcical anarchy. Mr. Stoller, whose previous films as a director are â€œForgetting Sarah Marshall,â€ù â€œGet Him to the Greekâ€ù and â€œThe Five-Year Engagement,â€ù is good at keeping the momentum going while also finding time for offbeat grace notes and occasional bursts of emotional candor. Mac and Kellyâ€™s fights account for some of those, but so do Teddy and Pete as their ideas of collegiate life and its aftermath start to diverge.

As is customary for projects like this, a flash mob of very funny secondary performers has been assembled, both to exercise their skills and to elicit chuckles of recognition from clued-in (which is to say couch-bound) members of the audience. Andy Samberg and the guys from â€œWorkaholicsâ€ù show up in blink-and-you-miss-it cameos, while Christopher Mintz-Plasse pursues the further adventures of McLovin. Ike Barinholtz and Carla Gallo are amusing as the wacky friends on hand to make Mac and Kelly seem conventional. Hannibal Buress ambles by to steal a scene or two as a police officer. Lisa Kudrow does the same as a college dean, and Jerrod Carmichael wins the prize for funniest and most counter-stereotypical fraternity brother.

At an especially stressful moment in their domestic life â€” they are in the midst of an escalating battle with the fraternity next door, about which more shortly â€” Mac and Kelly, a married couple with a cute (and notably quiet) baby daughter, have a fight. At issue is who has the right to be irresponsible. Although they have a kid, a mortgage and other trappings of grown-up life, neither is entirely willing to give up the wild, impulsive behavior associated with youth. Mac (Seth Rogen) thinks his gender (and perhaps also his body type) entitles him to be the self-indulgent one. â€œWe canâ€™t both be Kevin James,â€ù he says. And of course, he points out, Kelly (Rose Byrne) is a wife and mother, a bit of biological typecasting she furiously resents, and one that â€œNeighborsâ€ù rejects.

But it canâ€™t all be jokes and joints and coitus interruptus. Comedy thrives on conflict, which arrives in the form of that fraternity. The house next door to Kelly and Macâ€™s is (somewhat improbably, but whatever) purchased by the local collegeâ€™s chapter of Delta Psi Beta, whose members make the couple feel old and also keep them awake at night with loud music and nonstop debauchery. The president is an abdominally gifted young scholar named Teddy (Mr. Efron), who is determined to make party history, assisted by his best bro, Pete (Dave Franco), and the rest of their brothers. Kelly and Mac try to befriend these dudes, but despite certain shared interests, relations sour quickly.

This argument is a minor episode in a film (directed by Nicholas Stoller from a script by Andrew Jay Cohen and Brendan Oâ€™Brien) that has a lot of other things on its mind: marijuana, sex toys, Zac Efronâ€™s muscles and enough pop-culture flotsam to dominate a yearâ€™s worth of pub trivia nights. The usual stuff. But the scene nonetheless marks a significant point in the evolution of what French critics (who take such matters very seriously) have called â€œle nouvel Ã¢ge dâ€™or de la comÃ©die amÃ©ricaine.â€ù The central problem in American film comedy for the past 15 years or so â€” letâ€™s say from middle-period Sandler through prime Apatow and late â€œHangoverâ€ù â€” has been maturity, or, more precisely, its avoidance. In the old days, adulthood was a fact. Now itâ€™s a vague, unproven theory. Adolescence used to represent constraint and frustration, to be left behind as quickly as possible. For the heroes of the New American Comedy, it represents a blissful state of hedonistic freedom, to be held onto for as long as possible.
â€œNeighborsâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Hire a sitter.

â€œNeighborsâ€ù does something a little different. It fuses romantic traditionalism with new-school naughtiness and imagines marriage not as a prison but as a shared playground. Not that parenthood is all fun and games for Kelly and Mac. She is bored staying home with their daughter, and he is bored at work, a situation that both upholds and subverts the Ozzie and Harriet stereotype. Heâ€™s hardly a professional go-getter. The movie doesnâ€™t even bother to specify what he does for a living. What does anyone do? He wears a tie and sits in a cubicle. At home, thereâ€™s sex (when the baby doesnâ€™t interrupt), weed (though not so much for Kelly while sheâ€™s nursing) and fast-moving, highly referential comic banter.

How to stay a child when the world expects otherwise â€” and how to make the world love you anyway â€” has usually been, in these movies, a male predicament. Women have been sirens or mommies, on hand to inflame the boysâ€™ desires or soothe their fears. This has begun to change recently, although mainly on television, where shows like â€œGirlsâ€ù and â€œBroad Cityâ€ù have extended the privileges of arrested development on a more or less equal-opportunity basis.

I donâ€™t want to create the wrong impression. The insightful glimmers matter to the filmâ€™s credibility, but they also provide a scaffolding of sincerity for the abundant drug-, sex- and body-based humor. The best gags involve human lactation and automobile air bags (not at the same time). Nobody really gets hurt.

The innovative fictional narrative, woven throughout, demonstrates that many of these young actors have learned their lessons well. The nonfiction segments mix information and interviews with observation to illustrate the uphill battle faced by many Cambodian children, particularly those without parents.

Thatâ€™s the fictional part, in which the filmâ€™s real-life orphans play warriors of the spirit on a mythic journey in the natural world. That this fiction skillfully incorporates elements of the actor-orphansâ€™ challenging histories makes for a layered viewing experience.

Earlier, and later, we meet these orphans, who live at the National Action Culture Organization group home in Phnom Penh. It helps children with difficult backgrounds, using the performing arts, particularly theater and dance. The aim is for the children to develop real expertise, not just kill time.

However dry (thanks to the caretaker Peng Phan for smiles that leaven that tone), â€œStill I Strive,â€ù by the filmmakers Adam Pfleghaar and A. Todd Smith, is a remarkable find, a tale of uplift in a too-little-seen environment.

For everyone who â€œplayed pretendâ€ù as a youth, who concocted elaborate stories of homemaking, piracy or other adventure without needing the rules of basketball or Capture the Flag, something about the Cambodian documentary â€œStill I Striveâ€ù may touch you.

The hybrid â€œStill I Striveâ€ù could offer a worthy experience for empathetic children, with the caveat that audiences should be patient; the filmâ€™s dual elements may confuse youngsters, and its somber tone may put off some. And itâ€™s a little slow, and itâ€™s in Khmer.

No one is a villain in this aggressively feel-good movie. On the evening Ramsey appears, Carl is pressured by the restaurantâ€™s owner (Mr. Hoffman) not to follow his instincts and experiment but to serve the same-old, same-old dishes; he is predictably pilloried on Ramseyâ€™s blog. Making matters infinitely worse, Carl, who is naÃ¯ve about social media, is brought up short when his venomous response to the review goes viral and is followed by an angry face-to-face encounter with Ramsey that is captured on dinersâ€™ smartphones.
â€œChefâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for some strong language and sexual references.
Food trucks, Twitter wars and salsa music: â€œChefâ€ù has its pinkie on the pulse of the moment.

The melting pot in â€œChefâ€ù is not theoretical. Carlâ€™s ex-wife, Inez (Sofia Vergara), who encourages him to start over with a food truck, is a Latina. Both Los Angeles and Miami are buzzing, multicultural hubs in which Carlâ€™s unfamiliarity with Spanish is a disadvantage. And Carl is so likable that his Hispanic line cook (John Leguizamo) follows him to Miami and acts as a middleman and interpreter for day laborers who had ignored him when he asked them for help setting up the truck.

The major complaint of the critic, Ramsey Michel (Oliver Platt), with whom Carl fights a losing war of words on Twitter, is that Carl is stuck in a rut that has robbed his cuisine of its soul. But as played by Mr. Platt, Ramsey is not the poisonous Addison DeWitt of the food world but a mild-mannered epicurean with a sharp literary tongue.

In this shallow but enjoyable all-American morality play, Carl falls but rises, chastened, to pursue happiness and fulfillment operating a food truck whose specialty is Cuban sandwiches. Those sandwiches, the movie tells us none too convincingly, are far tastier and more wholesome than the carefully arranged, high-priced elaborate dishes Carl created in his heyday.

Food, glorious food! Whatever else it does or doesnâ€™t do, â€œChef,â€ùJon Favreauâ€™s good-natured culinary comedy, works as an appetite stimulant. And where thereâ€™s delicious food â€” plenty is shown being prepared, served and devoured â€” thereâ€™s life.

Whatever the reasons for Mr. Favreauâ€™s retreat from the tent, he makes an agreeably blustery tour guide in a road movie that begins in Los Angeles, relocates to Miami, then returns to the West Coast by way of tasty stopovers in New Orleans and Austin, Tex. Through it all, Mr. Favreauâ€™s gruff, roly-poly character, Carl Casper, a high-end Los Angeles chef whose ascent to gastronomic stardom is abruptly ended by a snooty restaurant critic, never loses his enthusiasm for cooking, eating and living.

â€œChefâ€ù arrives at an opportune moment for a hearty celebration of the putatively redemptive joys of downward mobility. The movie exalts the superiority of inexpensive real food, served on the street, for real people in the American melting pot. Only when Carl forsakes his lofty ambitions does he begin to cook food he â€œbelieves in.â€ù

If â€œChef,â€ù in its second half, is little more than a glorified travelogue, it is buoyed by a terrific soundtrack that mixes salsa, soul music and country blues with Caribbean styles. That said, the movieâ€™s exploration of multiculturalism isnâ€™t any deeper than that of an average episode of â€œModern Family.â€ù

The movie, which Mr. Favreau wrote and directed, is a self-conscious return to the small-scale indie values of his early films, like â€œSwingersâ€ù and â€œMade,â€ù although it is stuffed with stars, including Robert Downey Jr., Scarlett Johansson and Dustin Hoffman in cameo roles. This back-to-my roots fable can even be read as Mr. Favreauâ€™s apologia after his 2011 tent-pole flop, â€œCowboys & Aliens.â€ù

A sentimental subplot involves Carlâ€™s relationship with his partly estranged 10-year-old son, Percy (Emjay Anthony), who becomes his social media tutor. Once Carl has time to spend with the boy, â€œChefâ€ù tells a standard father-son bonding story in which a devoted dad passes on his wisdom. â€œChefâ€ù believes in work, and as father and son scour and spruce up a battered taco truck that Inezâ€™s wealthy first husband (Mr. Downey) gives Carl, the film earns points by eschewing magical thinking and showing the intensive labor behind the rattletrapâ€™s transformation into a jazzy-looking mobile kitchen.

The filmmakers, Ben Knight and Travis Rummel, have obviously dug into the history of their subject, but they blow through a pocket chronology of dams in America with unsettling speed. Their case leans somewhat heavily on the plight of salmon, and the oddly casual voice-over is misjudged. Among the raft of interviewees, the straight-shooting singer Katie Lee and a graffiti-tagging activist shake the film out of its dutiful tracks. But you feel that the filmmakers wouldnâ€™t mind just profiling those two, or one ardent naturalist who spends his monastic days taking notes on a salmon community.

A stirring argument against dams can be made by the outdoors itself: the rivers, trees, wildlife and vibrant contours of an organically forged landscape. â€œDamNationâ€ù begins with such images of nature, often artfully framed, and returns to them as well as to some beautifully fine-grained archival photography. But this documentary (which was funded by the outdoor apparel company Patagonia) also lumps together its grievances and interviews in a way that feels scattered and geared toward those inclined to agree.

If the film is less persuasive for its lack of balance, itâ€™s at least heartening to learn that undesirable dams can be destroyed and their rivers restored to their old ways and means. For vivid proof, â€œDamNationâ€ù shows time-lapse sequences of dam demolition and its aftermath that are almost spiritually rejuvenating: a fresh chapter in natureâ€™s story.

Had â€œDevilâ€™s Knotâ€ù dared to spin out a bizarre conspiracy theory, the way Oliver Stoneâ€™s â€œJFKâ€ù did, it probably would have been more compelling than this workmanlike recapitulation of the so-called West Memphis Three case. Because the movie, based on a book by Mara Leveritt, stays within the facts, its reticence reinforces the notion that truth is stranger than fiction. The real-life characters, as shown in the documentaries, are far more colorful and quirky than they appear in these well-acted but comparatively safe performances.

The question is why. Why would the gifted Canadian filmmaker Atom Egoyan choose to make â€œDevilâ€™s Knot,â€ù a feature film about a notorious unsolved 1993 murder case that has been exhaustively investigated in several well-regarded documentaries?

Perhaps Mr. Egoyan, being Canadian, did not realize the degree to which Americans are experiencing West Memphis Three fatigue. How very different â€œDevilâ€™s Knotâ€ù might have been if Mr. Egoyan had not felt obliged to be true to the facts.

Mr. Egoyanâ€™s film, which ends in 1994, concentrates on the characters played by its biggest stars, Reese Witherspoon and Colin Firth. Ms. Witherspoon gives a flashy, live-wire portrayal of Pam Hobbs, the mother of one of the victims, Steve Branch. Mr. Firth, gravely miscast, plays Ron Lax, a private investigator from Memphis who donated his services to the defense team. With an understated Southern accent and exuding obvious discomfort in the role, he projects the polite aloofness of an amusement park tour guide slightly embarrassed to be stuck in such a tacky job.

Alessandro Nivola as Pamâ€™s volatile husband, Terry, who Ms. Bergâ€™s film suggests may be the true culprit, creates an ominous portrait of a suspicious, taciturn man with shifty, deep-set eyes and a streak of violence just under the surface. Mr. Hamrick portrays Mr. Echols, the only one of the West Memphis Three to receive the death penalty, as a pathetically defiant lost boy who foolishly flaunts his interest in witchcraft and claims to have consumed blood.

Ms. Bergâ€™s film followed the case through to its conclusion in 2011, when the defendants were finally released from prison. Under what is known legally as an Alford plea, they formally accepted guilt without admitting they had committed the murders and were set free.

The real people can be seen in Joe Berlinger and Bruce Sinofskyâ€™s â€œParadise Lostâ€ù trilogy (1996, 2000, 2011) and Amy Bergâ€™s â€œWest of Memphisâ€ù (2012), which chronicled the wrongful convictions of three teenagers in the brutal killings of three 8-year-old boys in the woods of West Memphis, Ark. In â€œDevilâ€™s Knot,â€ù those teenagers â€” Damien Echols (James Hamrick), Jason Baldwin (Seth Meriwether) and Jessie Misskelley Jr. (Kris Higgins) â€” emerge as shellshocked victims of mass hysteria railroaded by a prosecution that made a mockery of justice.

â€œDevilâ€™s Knotâ€ù is very good at local color embellished with subtle horror movie touches and a Southern Gothic ambience, as when a corpse slowly rises to the surface of muddy water during a dragnet search for bodies. Surveying a closely packed trailer park, it conveys all you need to know about the living standards in the poorer sections of town. A mob protest outside the courthouse conjures the witch hunt surrounding a case in which these alienated teenagers were denounced as Satanists by fearful Christians. The movie even has a brief fantasy sequence of a satanic ritual in which figures dressed in black dance around a fire.

In the opening images of â€œDevilâ€™s Knot,â€ù the camera sets a menacing, Hitchcockian mood by stealthily creeping into the woods where the murders took place. But the movie settles into being a police procedural with the tone of a superior episode of â€œLaw & Order: SVU.â€ù

A glance at the publicity notes, however, will tell you that this one-sided puff piece was â€œmade with the generous support of the U.S. Farmers and Ranchers Alliance,â€ù a trade association formed in response to films like â€œFood, Inc.â€ù Smooth and folksy, it traffics in broad, unchallenged claims that serve a single purpose: to persuade us that the only thing wrong with todayâ€™s farming methods is our misinformed perception of them.

Personable and hardworking, Mr. Mollâ€™s subjects face the camera to bemoan fluctuating market prices and risky weather (but not climate change). The utility of sentiment is not overlooked, as one prepares for the birth of twins, and another mourns the loss of a patriarch. Audiences, however, will mostly be mourning the lack of an alternative viewpoint.

Whipping up a down-home blend of horses, hills and communal meals, the director, James Moll, follows five men and one woman (an enterprising pistol who deserves her own movie) as they operate family-run enterprises. We learn that genetically modified organisms reduce the need for pesticides â€” which, one assures us, never reach the consumer â€” and that feeding growth hormones to chickens is a fiction. Counterclaims are absent (the filmâ€™s organic farmers are too polite to heave dirt on anotherâ€™s methods), as is any discussion of corporate seed patents or government subsidies.

â€œBad behavior is pretty rare in our industry,â€ù one of the six young farmers profiled in â€œFarmlandâ€ù tells us. Though he doesnâ€™t elaborate, his commentâ€™s lack of detail and depth is typical of a film that plays more like a feature-length advertisement than like a documentary. You keep expecting the camera to zoom in on a packet of bacon or a box of cereal.

If you are interested in learning the latest on fighting whatâ€™s called the obesity epidemic, you may want to avoid the Centers for Disease Control and Preventionâ€™s website. There, in a section about balancing calories (â€œHealthy Weight â€” itâ€™s not a diet, itâ€™s a lifestyle!â€ù), amid tips on reducing and exercising, you can read that â€œa calorie is a calorie regardless of its source.â€ù The page also features a graphic of a scale with the words â€œcalories inâ€ù and â€œcalories out,â€ù as if all calories were equal. The American Beverage Association, as it happens, pretty much says the same thing on its website: â€œQuite simply, overweight and obesity are a result of an imbalance between calories consumed and calories burned.â€ù

Itâ€™s almost paradoxical that â€œFed Upâ€ù is opening in cinemas given that junk food and movies go together like Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. (Do Goobers taste good with outrage?) Yet many of the familiar movie-theater concession offerings now also line the shelves of electronic stores and other nonfood shops. This may seem like one of those ineluctable mysteries of modern life â€” the old pharmacy soda fountain has given way to drugstores with aisles of processed food â€” but itâ€™s the sort of development that â€œFed Upâ€ù helps to demystify.

The rest of it is just fine. With Ms. Couric as its guide, â€œFed Upâ€ù introduces you to a mystery, namely the puzzle of rising obesity rates. From there, it moves into investigative mode, which is where it becomes more complex and transparently political, as the filmmakers explore whoâ€™s killing our health. The villains it nails include entities described in the movie as Big Sugar and such, which are sharply cut down to size by the likes of Robert H. Lustig, a neuroendocrinologist, author and YouTube star whose 2009 lecture, â€œSugar: The Bitter Truth,â€ù went viral. Finally, there are answers, surprising and not, which can be reduced to the ugly truth that it isnâ€™t always in the best interests of both big business and the government to keep people healthy.

Are such initiatives enough? In a 2007 article, â€œThe U.S. Obesity â€˜Epidemicâ€™: Metaphor, Method, or Madness?,â€ù Gordon R. Mitchell and Kathleen M. McTigue suggest that obesity should be reframed as a literal epidemic. The use of the word â€œepidemicâ€ù with obesity proved controversial, partly because of confusion over whether the word was meant literally or metaphorically. Itâ€™s a lack of clarity that, as â€œFed Upâ€ù shows, has played out in competing narratives about obesity. To rectify this, the article suggests that recasting obesity as a literal epidemic meriting the implementation of the â€œEpidemic Investigation protocolâ€ù could have the â€œpotential both to restructure the public health response to obesity and reframe public argument on the issue.â€ù What would happen, say, if obesity were fought like polio?

Recent research, by contrast, indicates that calories in fruit are not the same as those in soda, a conclusion that is part of the big picture in â€œFed Up,â€ù a very good advocacy documentary directed by Stephanie Soechtig and narrated by Katie Couric. (Ms. Couric is also an executive producer.) A whirlwind of talking heads, found footage, scary statistics and cartoonish graphics, the movie is a fast, coolly incensed investigation into why people are getting fatter. It also includes some touching video self-portraits by some young people who belong to the almost 17 percent of children and adolescents, 2 to 19, who are considered obese. The kids in the movie are charming and heartbreaking, but the documentary doesnâ€™t need their pain to make its points, and their participation can feel borderline exploitative.

â€œFed Upâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). This is a ridiculous rating, one that was partly given to the movie because it contains images of cigarette smoking that are used to compare Big Tobacco with Big Food.

No doubt, thereâ€™s a lot here that will be familiar to people who recognize the name Michael Pollan, whoâ€™s on hand to dispense wisdom. But even viewers who like to think that theyâ€™re well informed may be surprised by the movieâ€™s (relatively mild) criticisms of Democratic administrations and the (not new) assertion that Michelle Obamaâ€™s Letâ€™s Move! program has been co-opted by food companies. (She may be listening: In March, she delivered a speech urging Americans to get home cooking again.)

â€œFed Upâ€ù doesnâ€™t go that far. Itâ€™s a call to action that pinpoints the problems, identifies the players and stresses that obese people arenâ€™t to blame (â€œitâ€™s not their faultâ€ù), even as, somewhat contradictorily, it encourages greater self-control. The movie says a lot and unsurprisingly leaves out much, including whether the fat-acceptance movement can jibe with anti-obesity efforts like this one. From its use of images of anonymous obese bodies â€” a familiar, dehumanizing TV news strategy in which people are shown only from the neck down â€” itâ€™s clear that even the well-intentioned can struggle with this subject. The anonymity of such shame shots, as I think of them, conveys the message that the identities of obese people need to be protected, as if they were alleged criminals. Theyâ€™re not.

Leon was the stepson of Mickey (Mr. Hoffman), the hard-drinking owner of a meat truck whose wife, Jeanie (Christina Hendricks), is devastated by the death. Mickey, who plays the horses, gambles away the money he borrows for Leonâ€™s burial and stores the body in his truck after he stumbles over it in the alley where the funeral director has thrown it. Then the truck is stolen.

The dead man in â€œGodâ€™s Pocket,â€ù Leon (Caleb Landry Jones), was a sociopathic punk who is clobbered over the head with a lead pipe after taunting an African-American day laborer with racial epithets at a construction site. Describing the residents of the rough, seedy South Philadelphia neighborhood that gives the movie its name, this local celebrity, Richard (Richard Jenkins), muses out loud with barbed affection: â€œEveryone here has stolen something from someone else, or when they were kids, they set someoneâ€™s house on fire. They know who cheats at cards and who slaps their kids around. The one thing they canâ€™t forgive is not being from Godâ€™s Pocket.â€ù

With a screenplay adapted by John Slattery and Alex Metcalf from a 1983 novel by Pete Dexter, and a star-filled cast led by Philip Seymour Hoffman, â€œGodâ€™s Pocketâ€ù is the first feature film directed by Mr. Slattery, who plays Roger Sterling on â€œMad Men.â€ù From the outset, it is painfully clear that he stumbled into the wrong neighborhood.

As this strained, foul-mouthed exercise in gallows humor proceeds, â€œGodâ€™s Pocketâ€ù sustains a facade of meanspirited deadpan comedy. But there are no laughs, not even smirks to be had. â€œGodâ€™s Pocketâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has profanity, violence and sexual situations.

These misfires undermine the strength of solid performances by Hoffman, John Turturro and Domenick Lombardozzi, playing tough-guy losers in a movie that never jells into a coherent portrait of working class solidarity. Initially, â€œChapmanâ€ù engrosses as a noir procedural, illustrating how a stealthy locksmith might travel on the cheap. Rather than settle for a Ford Fiesta, Alex steals a sleeker car from a flirtatious rental agent (Christine Woods) whom he knows from high school. Employing lyrical imagery that owes much to the director Terrence Malick, Mr. Owensby offers a portrait of adolescence â€” meadow frolics, freshwater swims, treehouse getaways â€” that feels impossibly innocent.

Yet the more â€œChapmanâ€ù reveals, the less seems to be going on, and the more its quirkier developments â€” Alex loses his clothes and dons a bellhopâ€™s uniform â€” play like independent-film clichÃ©s. Mr. Owensby, who wrote the screenplay, cites a real-life inspiration for the material, but he takes shortcuts in the last act. Itâ€™s the cinematic equivalent of kicking in the door.

Paging Dr. Freud? Alex (Jesse Johnson), the haunted, aerosol-huffing antihero of â€œChapman,â€ù works as a locksmith. â€œEvery lock has a bypass, a cheat,â€ù he explains to an angry landlord before showing him a foolproof method: kicking in the door.

The filmâ€™s songs, imperfectly staged, feel pitched to younger tots, uneasily bridging Broadway and a childrenâ€™s television show. All in all, the beloved kingdom of Oz is not well served, though thereâ€™s just enough detectable affection to keep it from feeling like a pure cashing-in.

The maps included with many Oz books promised bookish completists that there was always another little corner of this flip-side world to explore. That sense of imagination is largely absent from â€œLegends of Oz: Dorothyâ€™s Return,â€ù a second-rate animated adaptation of a spinoff by Roger Stanton Baum, L. Frank Baumâ€™s great-grandson. China Country is one stop on a rescue mission undertaken by Dorothy (Lea Michele of â€œGleeâ€ù), here a blandly courageous kid whoâ€™s summoned to save Oz from an evil jester (Martin Short). â€œLegends of Ozâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for all the perils of a commute from Kansas.

The owlâ€™s argyle-pattern chest is a nice touch, as is the treeâ€™s textured grain. Anyway, Allyson decides that an evening out at a nice restaurant with her gal pals will cure all her discontent, and all â€” forgive me â€” hell breaks loose, with a hospital and a jail among the places the various participants end up. Allyson (Sarah Drew of â€œGreyâ€™s Anatomyâ€ù) is a young mother who appears, in the grand scheme of things, to have a pretty easy life but is thrown into hysterics by garden-variety mishaps. Her husband (Sean Astin) is that odious Hollywood caricature: the father who is terrified by the prospect of minding his own children for a few hours.

Seldom has wackiness been as tedious as it is in â€œMomsâ€™ Night Out,â€ù a Christian-themed film that is desperate to make adherents seem wild and crazy but mostly makes them seem incapable of raising children.

â€œMomsâ€™ Night Outâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested), presumably for cartoonish mayhem.

Most of the kids, including April (Emma Roberts, delicately touching) and Teddy (an equally affecting Jack Kilmer), arenâ€™t mired in any deep crisis, but rather floating on whatever current â€” home, sex, school â€” theyâ€™ve been pulled into. April plays soccer at school, babysits and, somewhat unusually for a movie about teenagers, cracks open schoolbooks. Sheâ€™s one of those nice girls whose virtue defines her, yet also weighs her down. She seems understandably bewildered by the nattering of a school counselor, Mrs. Ganem (an unrecognizable Talia Shire), who raises the subject of college â€” most of the movieâ€™s grownups are wildly unequal to the challenge of dealing with teenagers â€” yet, right from the start, it feels certain that this smart, tremulously impressionable 17-year-old will make it.

â€œPalo Altoâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). The movie features scenes of teenage smoking, drug taking and drinking, as well violence, including sexual violence.

The kids in Gia Coppolaâ€™s â€œPalo Altoâ€ù move as through a dream. Itâ€™s a drifty, appealing story, set in the Northern California city that gives the movie its title, about that twilight period between childhoodâ€™s end and the start of young adulthood. Here, under wavering palm trees, teenagers slip through homes and streets with the vagueness that comes with certain visions of adolescence. These arenâ€™t the tireless achievers cramming for tests, and preparing for college and the conformity to come. They are instead the anxious children who have â€” since the likes of Holden Caulfield and James Deanâ€™s rebel â€” defined American adolescence as a state of poetic confusion.

It doesnâ€™t take long to see that theyâ€™re interested in each other, but they have an entire movie and some drama to get through first. Somewhat surprisingly, not a whole lot of bad happens at home. Although their parents are as vaguely represented as those in a â€œPeanutsâ€ù comic, with the dads either absent or as good as gone, the mothers are present, and there are scenes in which both Aprilâ€™s dizzy mother, Jane (a funny Jacqui Getty, the directorâ€™s mother), and Teddyâ€™s, Sherry (Janet Jones Gretzky), tell their children that they love them. (The kids say it right back.) Both women come off as preoccupied with other matters, but from the affection that Ms. Coppola shows them, itâ€™s apparent that theyâ€™re guilty only of being distracted.

If you care about April and Teddy, itâ€™s because Ms. Coppola does, too. This is her feature directing debut â€” her grandfather is Francis Ford Coppola, and Sofia Coppola is her aunt â€” and she does a lot right here, including coaxing out sympathetic characters who, in other hands, could have been ciphers. Her quiet, attentive filmmaking goes a long way toward distinguishing the sometimes generic material, which she adapted from a collection of Mr. Francoâ€™s short stories, titled â€œPalo Altoâ€ù and partly inspired by his growing up there. Although it is set in the present, Ms. Coppola gives the story an out-of-time quality that dovetails with its out-of-place vibe. Thereâ€™s no trace of the software industry, for instance, despite its roots in the city and, palm trees aside, these children could be almost anywhere.

Teddy is another story, one that begins when the movie does. You first see him in a car parked in front of a wall, hanging with Fred (Nat Wolff, a jittery, effectively destabilizing presence), whoâ€™s behind the wheel. Itâ€™s night, and theyâ€™re smoking dope and talking, when suddenly Fred steps on the gas and drives right into the wall. They survive, but itâ€™s a worrisome omen, as is the relay of looks between April and her coach, Mr. B. (James Franco, nice and sleazy), in the scene that follows. Nothing if not schematic, the movie continues to shift between Teddyâ€™s world of big and little troubles and Aprilâ€™s, occasionally bringing them together as if by accident, as when they end up at the same underage bacchanal.

What tethers the movie and especially April and Teddy is how Ms. Coppola captures that exquisitely tender, moving moment between fragile, self-interested youth and tentatively more outwardly aware adulthood, a coming into consciousness that she expresses through their broken sentences, diverted glances and abrupt turns. (Nobody processes his or her feelings; they simply are.) Slowly, this incompleteness gives way to a sense of wholeness, if not closure; these stories, after all, are just beginning. And however familiar, they are ones that Ms. Coppola â€” working with her director of photography, Autumn Cheyenne Durald, and under the obvious influence of the cinematographer Harris Savides, who shot some of Gus Van Santâ€™s most beautiful films â€” pulls you into with color, light and feelings as lovely as caresses.
â€œThe Doubleâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Foul language and existential torment.

Mr. Eisenberg plays Simon with cringing, stammering authenticity, and he also plays James Simon, a man who is Simonâ€™s exact replica and his complete opposite. As is always the case in tales of doubling â€” from Dostoyevsky and Poe to JosÃ© Saramagoâ€™s â€œEnemy,â€ù recently filmed by Denis Villeneuve, with Jake Gyllenhaal in the lead roles â€” there is some ambiguity about Jamesâ€™s ontological status. Is he a person sent by a perverse universe to torment and humiliate Simon, or is he a projection of Simonâ€™s own desperate and disordered mind? For most of its running time, â€œThe Doubleâ€ù wears this puzzle lightly, concentrating, with a blend of sadistic glee and genuine empathy, on Simonâ€™s suffering at his doppelgÃ_ngerâ€™s hands.

In â€œThe Double,â€ù Richard Ayoadeâ€™s energetically stylized adaptation of a Dostoyevsky novella, Jesse Eisenberg plays Simon James, a man so unassuming that he barely exists. The security guard at his workplace demands his ID every morning, and a co-worker cheerfully describes poor Simon as â€œa bit of a nonperson, really.â€ù His boss (Wallace Shawn) has a vague idea of who he is, as does Hannah (Mia Wasikowska), a fellow employee as well as a neighbor. Simon is hopelessly in love with her, in a creepy way that is also kind of sweet.

It is not an unpleasant place to spend some time (except for them, of course), but â€œThe Double,â€ù shot and edited with an exuberant panache somewhat at odds with its dour setting and mood, is the kind of movie that may have been more satisfying to make than it is to watch. It never quite rises to the full potential of its theme or fully inhabits its intricately imagined space. Itâ€™s cool but not haunting â€” a brainteaser rather than a mindblower.

Mr. Ayoade, a British comedian, actor and video director whose previous feature was the coming-of-age story â€œSubmarine,â€ù places the Simon/James drama in a dark, dank steampunk world that seems at once Soviet, Dickensian and science-fictional. In movie terms, â€œThe Doubleâ€ù owes evident debts to Terry Gilliamâ€™s â€œBrazil,â€ùAndrew Niccolâ€™s â€œGattacaâ€ù and the handmade psychosocial dystopias of David Lynch. Simon and Hannah live in grim, high-rise apartment blocks. Their company (ruled by a distant, Big Brotherish figure known as the Colonel) is a maze of shadowy cubicles and retro-futuristic machines.

The plot moves swiftly and twistily along, and it is amusing to watch Mr. Eisenberg wear his persona like a reversible coat, switching from loser to charmer by adjusting his posture and the angle of his brows. James is as irresistible as Simon is forgettable. Their boss treats him as a surrogate son, the bossâ€™s daughter (Yasmin Paige) treats him as a mentor and boy toy, and he toys with the affections of a number of women, including Hannah. This drives Simon over the edge, and tips the movie into its breathless and somewhat muddled final act.

Trying to shed light on the darkness of human suffering, Michael Kingâ€™s â€œThe Rescuersâ€ù travels across Europe to chronicle the actions of those who saved Jews during World War II. While the documentary marshals an impressive array of survivors and visits several international locations, it grindingly adheres to an unwieldy tour-style presentation, with more than a few rough spots and, at times, an unpolished look.

The British historian Martin Gilbert is paired with the young Rwandan activist Stephanie Nyombayire to link genocide across the generations. They retrace stories of those called â€œrighteousâ€ù by Yad Vashem, the Holocaust memorial in Israel, for courageous acts of rescue. From a British princess to Japanese and Swiss diplomats, they took extraordinary action to counter the Nazi threat. Their deeds are explained here in terms of â€œthe mystery of goodness,â€ù but the assumptions behind that idea could use some more discussion.

The filmâ€™s series of stories feature Mr. Gilbertâ€™s learned asides and are punctuated by rather awkward chats and unnecessary re-enactments. Though released in a theater, this documentary looks better suited to television.

The film samples an assortment of out-of-the-mainstream varieties of Christianity, a wearying parade already familiar from reality television, newsmagazines and late-night monologues. Snake-handling church? Check. Ministry aimed at strippers? Check. Visit to the Creation Museum in Kentucky? Check.

If the intent is to look at people who spurn established denominations in favor of nontraditional versions, the selection seems chosen for its camera appeal rather than for its insight; only later in the film are a few serious thinkers heard from. And if the intent is to examine American Christianity as a whole, Mr. Garriga has omitted about 99 percent of it.

Finding a guy with a face tattoo who rambles on about Jesus and motorcycles is easy. Finding a means to convey on film the quiet ways that countless people apply their religious beliefs to day-to-day life takes more effort than went into â€œAmerican Jesus.â€ù

Itâ€™s not clear what Aram Garriga thinks he is accomplishing in his simplistic â€œAmerican Jesus,â€ù but heâ€™s not accomplishing much. Whatever hopes you might have had that this Spanish filmmaker would be able to do for American Christianity what another outsider, Alexis de Tocqueville, did for America as a whole are dashed as soon as the snake-handling minister shows up.

The boys of Sidi Moumen are the subjects of Nabil Ayouchâ€™s film â€œHorses of God,â€ù a compelling contemplation of the roots of Islamic terrorism in poverty and hopelessness. On May 16, 2003, 12 suicide bombers from Sidi Moumen, ages 16 to 23, attacked multiple targets in Casablanca, killing 45 people (including themselves) and wounding more than 100.

The movie, inspired by Mahi Binebineâ€™s novel â€œThe Stars of Sidi Moumen,â€ù is not about politics or religion but about poverty and a society steeped in a deadly machismo. In its demystification of these youthful slum dwellers, the film makes their embrace of terrorism frighteningly comprehensible. Because it follows its main characters over 10 years, from childhood into adulthood, it gives their fates a sense of tragic inevitability.

Suddenly, their lives have a noble purpose. They are expected to die for the glory of Allah, having embraced a cause larger than themselves. Unlike other movies about jihad, â€œHorses of God,â€ù doesnâ€™t concentrate on the terroristsâ€™ grandiose indoctrination and the rituals of their final meals, prayers and preparations, which can attach a perverse glamour to suicide. Even after Yachine is chosen to lead one operation â€” the bombing of an Italian restaurant â€” he is shown shaking with fear, and his eyes do not burn with heavenly fantasies.

The residents of Sidi Moumen, a sprawling shantytown on the outskirts of Casablanca, Morocco, live in tin-roofed shacks without electricity, running water or modern sewage disposal. The area sits atop a garbage dump where boys run wild in packs and engage in fierce soccer matches that often explode into violence. Aerial shots depict this slum as a fetid, desiccated wasteland, in which the pickings are thin, even for scavengers. To sell oranges in a market for a pittance, you must fight for space.

Women in this world are conspicuously absent, except for the boysâ€™ mother, who spends days watching soap operas. Yachine pines wistfully for an attractive neighborhood girl who notices him but is careful not to meet his longing looks for more than half a second. The absence of women gives this male society a fraught undertone of homoeroticism that is exacerbated by the beauty of the men, some of whom gaze at one another with desire. Anyone perceived as weaker or effeminate, like Yachineâ€™s best friend, Nabil (Hamza Souidek), is at risk of being raped. When Yachineâ€™s middle-aged boss at an auto repair shop makes a half-joking pass at him, he is savagely beaten to death, and there are no consequences.

When first seen, Yachine (Abdelhakim Rachid) and his older brother, Hamid (Abdelilah Rachid), are 10 and 13. The volatile Hamid becomes a local hero by tossing a rock at a police car and ends up in prison. When he returns, he is a changed man, having discovered Islamic fundamentalism, with its emphasis on austerity and self-discipline in the service of a greater cause. Yachine, who has always looked up to Hamid as the man of the house, is easily converted.

Without much ado, â€œHorses of Godâ€ù builds to a deliberately anticlimactic finale. The restaurant bombing is little more than a puff of smoke glimpsed from a distance. In addition to refusing to buy into the mystique of martyrdom, this hardheaded movie is smart enough to deny you the vicarious excitement of a good explosion. All you are left contemplating is the charactersâ€™ wasted lives.

Because we have seen these men as boys, their eagerness to join the cause comes across as not much different from joining a gang in high school and enduring its initiation. Itâ€™s an atavistic guy thing: Any danger involved is worth the thrill of belonging.

While traveling to Budapest, Vienna, Montreal, Ukraine, Romania and Germany, the film, the first feature by Aaron Yeger, presents a range of lucid commentators, some of whom touch upon distant Roma history. But the primary focus here is on the disenfranchisement and ruthless persecution the Roma have long suffered in Europe: in Romania in the mid-1400s, by the Habsburgs in 1500, by Henry VIII and again by the Habsburgs in 1721. (Joanna Goodey, a European Union official, cites a survey indicating that Roma are currently the most frequent victims of discrimination in the union.)

The darkest hour was the Holocaust, in which hundreds of thousands of Roma perished in concentration camps. Much of this movie is composed of survivors who give harrowing accounts of their experiences, and their warnings about rising ethnic hatred in Europe should not be ignored. But those seeking to learn in depth about, say, the dialects and traditions of the Roma should look elsewhere.

The subtitle to the documentary â€œA People Uncountedâ€ù â€” â€œThe Untold Story of the Romaâ€ù â€” might lead you to expect a historical overview of the people known as the Roma, or Gypsies. Itâ€™s a fascinating culture, which migrated to Europe from Northern India 1,000 years ago. The word â€œGypsy,â€ù derived from â€œEgyptian,â€ù is a misnomer; equally misleading is a stereotype of joyfully itinerant musicians, dancers and petty thieves that persists in opera, literature, pop hits and movies.
â€œA Short History of Decayâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian) for frank language.

Though heâ€™s played a committed writer on television (â€œOctober Roadâ€ù), Bryan Greenberg doesnâ€™t always come across as one in Michael Marenâ€™s â€œA Short History of Decay.â€ù That makes some sense, as Mr. Greenbergâ€™s 30-something character, Nathan, just switched from being a struggling novelist to being an inactive playwright. But the best parts of Mr. Marenâ€™s well-observed film arenâ€™t always to be found in its accessible setup.

Shortly before Nathanâ€™s girlfriendâ€™s new book comes out, she breaks up with him by announcing an affair with a literary agent. Still shocked, Nathan decamps from the writer-infested Brooklyn to visit his ailing, opinionated parents in Florida: Mom (Linda Lavin) is forgetful because of Alzheimerâ€™s, and Dad (Harris Yulin, an eloquent growler) is a stroke risk.

Amid all of this, the unassuming Nathan strikes up connections with two very different women (played by Kathleen Rose Perkins and Rebecca Dayan) and befriends a Sunday painter at the beach. While these loose ends might sound like scrambled bits out of an Eric Rohmer film, Mr. Marenâ€™s movie rather finds its groove in its humble domestic detail.

Despite Mr. Marenâ€™s own ample experience as a writer, the references to book culture donâ€™t feel vivid enough to act as more than scene-setting, and the filmâ€™s strength lies in the family relationships. Some of the smothering feels routine, but in that, thereâ€™s the shorthand language for caring. Even more effective is Nathanâ€™s rough-and-tumble rapport with his high-roller brother, Jack (Benjamin King), who suddenly flies in from Washington.

â€œFakeâ€ù is the name of Mr. Aiâ€™s studio, a translinguistic pun playing with the ideas of authenticity and artificiality that inform much contemporary art. The title of Mr. Johnsenâ€™s film also points to the spuriousness of the governmentâ€™s charges, but there is no doubt that Mr. Ai takes his situation seriously. And though his impish sense of humor is still intact, he also seems tired and melancholy. He has trouble sleeping, suffers from memory loss and worries that the harassment he has suffered is taking an irreversible toll on his health.

Under constant surveillance, he goes for walks with his young son, talks with lawyers and foreign journalists, and supervises the making of new work. Some of the film reflects directly on his confrontations with the authorities, notably a series of lifelike dioramas â€” called â€œS.A.C.R.E.D.â€ù and included in the Brooklyn show â€” depicting his detention.

Throughout â€œAi Weiwei: The Fake Case,â€ù Mr. Johnsenâ€™s camera never leaves Mr. Aiâ€™s side, giving the film an informal intimacy not unlike the mood in some of the artistâ€™s own videos. Critical and contextual perspectives will have to be sought elsewhere. Mr. Johnsen offers viewers the challenge and pleasure of an important artistâ€™s company, and a chance to appreciate anew his wisdom, his wit and his bravery.

The essential cinematic introduction to Mr. Ai remains Alison Klaymanâ€™s 2012 documentary, â€œAi Weiwei: Never Sorry.â€ù Mr. Johnsenâ€™s film is an interesting addendum and no doubt a harbinger of more sequels to come. It takes up the story in 2011, after Mr. Ai had been detained for nearly three months and found himself under virtual house arrest. Charged with tax violations and forbidden to leave the country or speak to the press, he spends his days in the Beijing complex that serves as his home, studio and quasi-corporate headquarters.

Part of the reason the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei â€” the subject of a current exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum and of the Danish filmmaker Andreas Johnsenâ€™s new documentary, â€œThe Fake Caseâ€ù â€” is such an intriguing figure is that his recent career feels like the latest battle in the very old war between the imagination and the state. Especially since 2008, when the aftermath of the Chengdu earthquake in Western China awakened his conscience and made him a determined critic of his government, Mr. Ai has taunted, mocked and passionately denounced the authoritarianism, corruption and incompetence that he sees around him. He has made more-or-less conventional works of art reflecting these concerns, and made deft use of social media and his own celebrity.

The European holdovers from the trilogyâ€™s earlier installments include Xavierâ€™s English wife, Wendy (Kelly Reilly), who was his roommate in â€œLâ€™Auberge Espagnoleâ€ù and a love interest in â€œRussian Dolls.â€ù In â€œChinese Puzzle,â€ù Wendy divorces Xavier to marry John (Peter Hermann), a wealthy American, and settle on Central Park South.

This is a frivolous, feel-good film whose cuteness factor is amplified by scenes in which the ghosts of Schopenhauer and Hegel pop in to offer enigmatic tidbits of observation of no particular depth and for no particular reason. When similar historical figures have dropped into a Woody Allen film, at least there is some connection to whatever is going on. Here, itâ€™s just a weightless comic conceit like the cutout figures who occasionally dance across the screen for no other purpose than to buoy an already giddy tone of insistent levity.
â€œChinese Puzzleâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has sexual situations, nudity and strong language.

Once you adjust to the fact that â€œChinese Puzzle,â€ù the trilogyâ€™s finale, doesnâ€™t have any more of an idea in its head than its upbeat forerunners, you can settle back and savor Mr. Klapischâ€™s valentine to New York and appreciate its rose-colored vision of the city as seen through European eyes.

Determined to stay in touch with his children, Xavier follows her to the United States and initially stays in the Brooklyn loft of another holdover, his Belgian friend Isabelle (CÃ©cile de France), a free-spirited lesbian, and her Chinese-American lover, Ju (Sandrine Holt). After a while, he moves into Juâ€™s shabby former apartment in Chinatown, which she had conveniently left unoccupied. He is persuaded, meanwhile, by Isabelle and Ju to donate his sperm for them to have a child. Itâ€™s all so easy.

To remain in New York without running afoul of the immigration authorities, Xavier, who arrives on a tourist visa, takes an off-the-books job as a bike messenger. One afternoon, while riding in a cab, he rescues its Chinese-American driver, who is nearly beaten to death in a skirmish with an irate trucker. As recompense, the grateful cabby fixes up Xavier with his bubbly niece for a hasty green-card marriage.

Although these shenanigans make little practical or even psychological sense, this warm-blooded paean to globalization is just enough in touch with reality to keep your eyes from rolling. For â€œChinese Puzzleâ€ù genuinely likes people. It overlooks the faults and misbehavior of its eccentric characters to express a lighthearted optimism that doesnâ€™t feel forced or manipulative. It is in love with life.

New York is a happy-go-lucky ethnic mosaic with a distinctively Asian flavor. Except for one minor characterâ€™s elegant Manhattan apartment, you donâ€™t sense the cityâ€™s extremes of luxury and misery or feel the tension between the haves and have-nots. The camera doesnâ€™t peer up at skyscrapers. There isnâ€™t the faintest suggestion of the security apparatus that lends life nowadays an undertone of paranoia. Except for one violent altercation, everyday New Yorkers are portrayed as relatively cheerful, good-natured people who pour down the streets in a joyous polyglot stream.

â€œThe next Proustâ€ù is the dubious marketing tag applied to Xavier Rousseau (Romain Duris), a flighty, footloose novelist, by his editor in â€œChinese Puzzle,â€ù the French filmmaker CÃ©dric Klapischâ€™s airborne romantic comedy. So what if there is nothing remotely Proustian about Xavier, the womanizing charmer with an idiot grin from two earlier films â€” â€œLâ€™Auberge Espagnoleâ€ù and â€œRussian Dollsâ€ù â€” also written and directed by Mr. Klapisch. Xavier, like the other returning characters from those movies, is about to turn 40. But in his carefree attitude, he might as well be 25.

Visitors from abroad pour into the city, and Xavierâ€™s apartment becomes a crowded international hotel. Martine (Audrey Tautou), his girlfriend from â€œLâ€™Auberge Espagnole,â€ù visits with her two children, and their dormant relationship is rekindled. The apartment also becomes a secret meeting place for Isabelle and a Belgian babysitter (Flore Bonaventura), with whom she initiates a hot affair. In a climactic scene that has the tone of a subdued bedroom farce, the out-of-town guests, nosy immigration officials and cheating lovers all collide.

Although Odenigbo is sarcastically called â€œthe revolutionary,â€ù the movieâ€™s writer and director, Biyi Bandele, seems less interested in the politics than in more familiar generational and romantic conflicts. Odenigboâ€™s provincial mother (Onyeka Onwenu) feels threatened by Olannaâ€™s education, calling her a witch. Olanna, teetering in her relationship with Odenigbo, selflessly decides to raise a child who is not her own.

Perhaps the greatest challenge faced by literary adaptations that juxtapose a small group of characters against a seismic backdrop â€” â€œDoctor Zhivago,â€ù say, or â€œThe Leopardâ€ù â€” is one of proportion. â€œHalf of a Yellow Sun,â€ù adapted from the 2006 novel by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, emerges on screen as a well-acted, finely wrought epic that nevertheless struggles to balance the requirements of melodrama with its drive to capture a historical moment. The movie could easily have been a mini-series, but at just under two hours, it plays like a highlight reel.

But by distilling the story, Mr. Bandele has created a mismatch between the movieâ€™s enormous scope and our ostensible identification point within it. The film comes across as less a portrait of complex intellectuals ideologically embroiled in a conflict than as a weepie about innocents adrift.

Odenigbo (Chiwetel Ejiofor) is a professor who speaks of how both race and nationality â€” unlike Nigeriaâ€™s economically fraught tribal divisions â€” are white manâ€™s constructs. He loves Olanna (Thandie Newton), a modern Nigerian who has lived abroad and, as the action begins, takes a job as a lecturer. Olannaâ€™s sister, Kainene (Anika Noni Rose), begins a fling that turns into a tumultuous relationship with an Englishman, Richard (Joseph Mawle), whose privileged perspective allows him to stand apart from the brewing strife.

Mr. Bandele accessibly (if somewhat disruptively) conveys the history via news clips, beginning with Elizabeth IIâ€™s arrival in a newly independent Nigeria, and illustrative maps. The faultless â€™60s art direction helps to bring the milieu to life, as do Mr. Ejioforâ€™s and Ms. Newtonâ€™s typically stormy performances.

While the novel unfolds from a variety of perspectives, the film opts for a more straightforward approach. Broadly, it concerns the experiences of an extended family in Nigeria throughout the 1960s, with a particular focus on their lives during the civil war of 1967 to 1970. At that time, the family resides in the secessionist Republic of Biafra, a flash point of the conflict.
â€œHalf of a Yellow Sunâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian). War violence, sex, nudity.

But eventually one instructor decides to make a YouTube video with his instructee, and soon thereâ€™s a contest to see which pair can come up with the best video. Some of the results are funny â€” here youâ€™ll learn that an iron is actually a cooking tool â€” while some are bittersweet. And as this is going on, a distressing side story involving Macaulee develops. The filmâ€™s director, Saffron Cassaday, is her older sister, and she does a commendable job of melding Macauleeâ€™s personal setback with the filmâ€™s overall theme.

It would be nice to hear more from the young mentors about what they learned, and more from the cyberseniors about how computer use might be made more elder-friendly. But in general, this is a sweet tale that will resonate with anyone who has tried to make a Skype call to a grandparent.

Early in the documentary â€œCyber-Seniors,â€ù you might find yourself saying, â€œUgh, are they really going to make me watch octogenarians poke fruitlessly at laptops for 75 minutes?â€ù But the film soon stops that torture and becomes a likable intergenerational tale with a bit of unexpected pathos.

It chronicles a program begun in Toronto by two high school sisters, Macaulee and Kascha Cassaday, in which students tried to help residents of a retirement community become more computer-literate. At first the film sounds like an advertisement for Facebook, with the teenagers introducing their gray-headed charges to it, generally at too fast a pace for an aging newcomer to absorb.
1 hour 38 minutes; not rated

Instead, a bit too true to a frugal indie philosophy, where winging it beats reshooting, the film gets more woolly and unfocused; many scenes feel improvised and only occasionally hit their marks. DON PEYOTE

The latest in the resurgent stoner-comedy genre, â€œDon Peyoteâ€ù stars Dan Fogler â€” like Seth Rogen, Jonah Hill and Zach Galifianakis before him â€” as a schlubby protagonist who knows his way around a morning bong hit.
Opens on Friday.
Directed by Dan Fogler and Michael Canzoniero

That character is Warren Allman, a graphic artist who, after a run-in with a street person spouting end-is-near babble, becomes a documentarian seeking answers to doomsday riddles. While his fiancÃ©e plans their wedding, Warren interviews experts on conspiracy theories, apocalyptic speculation, the Illuminati and assorted psychotropic pharmaceuticals and, big surprise, becomes ever more paranoid and hallucinatory. When he breaks out of a psych ward, the movie jumps its track completely, which is too bad: Mr. Fogler, who also wrote and directed the film with Michael Canzoniero, at first smartly organized it as a graphic novel, with chapters, sketched opening frames and a narrator.
Give â€œDon Peyoteâ€ù props for its title and nods for cameos by the likes of Josh Duhamel, Wallace Shawn, even Anne Hathaway as a leather-pantsed secret agent. You can stop there, though.
â€œGodzillaâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Whole cities are wiped out so that two enormous bugs can be prevented from having sex.

Godzilla shows up fairly late in the new movie that bears his name, and he also shows his age. Though this gigantic monster is, within the filmâ€™s own mythico-scientific terms, the long-slumbering reminder of a primordial, prehuman age, by the calendar of popular culture, heâ€™s a baby boomer. And now, roughly 60 years after he first appeared (as Gojira in the still unsurpassed, recently restored Japanese original), everybodyâ€™s favorite skyscraper stomper is exhibiting some familiar generational traits. He seems grumpy and underslept, as well as thicker around the jowls and midriff. And though he arrives dragging the usual heavy allegorical baggage, you can detect a trace of wistful worry in his rampages, as if he had begun to doubt his own relevance.

He also shoots radioactive beams out of his mouth and levels tall buildings with a flick of his tail. And this â€œGodzilla,â€ù though it surpasses Roland Emmerichâ€™s 1998 Hollywood version, remains safely within the bounds of the modern action movie spectacular. It is at once bloated and efficient, executed with tremendous discipline and intelligence and conceived with not too much of either.

The soul of â€œGodzilla,â€ù to the extent that it has one, dwells with the monsters. Not only with the great, angry lizard, but also with the pair of insectlike Mosura (evocative of Mothra, Godzillaâ€™s historic nemesis) that are causing most of the trouble. These sleek and scary creatures eat ICBMs like Tic Tacs and are preparing to meet up in San Francisco to spawn. Godzillaâ€™s job is to spoil the romance.

I know, I couldnâ€™t believe it either. Mr. Taylor-Johnson, who was the pretty-boy Vronsky in â€œAnna Kareninaâ€ù and the avenging nerd in the â€œKick-Assâ€ù movies, reports for duty as a muscly military guy whose family business is mixed up with Godzillaâ€™s. His name is Ford Brody, and his parents (Bryan Cranston and Juliette Binoche, a dream couple if ever there was one) were engineers at a Japanese nuclear plant where something went very wrong in 1999. Now, 15 years later, Fordâ€™s dad has become a wild-eyed truther, the walls of his tiny Tokyo apartment plastered with newspaper clippings and charts. Heâ€™s convinced that whatever happened at his former workplace was no natural disaster.

In the old days, after all, Godzilla really meant something. He was the supreme embodiment of atomic-age terrors, meting out punishment (and also offering redemption) for humankindâ€™s technological hubris. There is still plenty of that to contend with, but the focus of global anxiety has shifted from nuclear annihilation to climate change and related problems. â€œGodzilla,â€ù directed by Gareth Edwards from a screenplay by Max Borenstein, doesnâ€™t engage these matters directly, though it does contain some perfunctory scolding (â€œSuch arrogance,â€ù mutters a scientist played by Ken Watanabe) and a soothing fantasy in the midst of all the destruction. Weâ€™ve made a big mess of things with our missiles and our power plants, but Godzilla (again according to Mr. Watanabeâ€™s character) is natureâ€™s way of restoring balance.

What does happen is hardly surprising. A lot of people die, almost all of them anonymous citizens of unlucky metropolises. Most of those you expect to survive do so. You might not care about them quite as much as youâ€™re supposed to, since the characterizations are thin, and the talents of the actors mostly squandered. Still, one of the pleasures the movie offers is the thought that actors who have done splendid work elsewhere â€” Mr. Cranston and Ms. Binoche, and also Sally Hawkins as another scientist â€” are being paid well for shouting, grimacing and spouting expository claptrap.

Appreciation of a movie like this requires an almost morbid degree of connoisseurship, which may, in practice, be hard to distinguish from bored acquiescence. Evaluating its components is a little like scoring gymnastics or figure skating. You factor in degree of difficulty, technical accomplishment and various subjective responses, and it is always helpful to have points of comparison. How does the obliteration of, say, Honolulu stack up against the smashing of Chicago in that â€œTransformersâ€ù movie? Are the fights between Godzilla and the other Kaiju as cool as the Kaiju-Jaeger battles in â€œPacific Rimâ€ù? Does Elizabeth Olsen, as the worried wife and mom, have more to do than Mireille Enos did as the worried wife and mom in â€œWorld War Zâ€ù? Can Aaron Taylor-Johnsonâ€™s neck really be thicker than Channing Tatumâ€™s?

People are thus somewhat incidental to the story, and their feelings â€” mostly fear and determination â€” are less interesting than those of the ancient giants, who in their slimy, scaly, computer-generated movements and expressions register rage and anguish with an intensity beyond what the humans can muster. And in Godzillaâ€™s eyes you see something else, too: the desire, at long last, to be left alone.

We have suspected as much all along, but â€œGodzillaâ€ù is in no hurry to show us the monsters. Mr. Edwardsâ€™s first feature was the clever, low-budget â€œMonsters,â€ù and even with a lot of money at his disposal, he often prefers subtlety and indirection to obvious noise and spectacle. He seems more interested in showing the aftermath of a calamity than the event itself, and the vistas of trampled cityscapes are frequently more memorable and always more haunting than the chaotic scenes of smashing and flooding that clutter the filmâ€™s climax. Two sequences â€” one on a rainy San Francisco bridge, the other at a railroad trestle somewhere in Nevada â€” offer master classes in how to create suspense out of shadows, quiet and the sheer agony of waiting for something to happen.

But Mr. Hanna was confronted by overwhelming forces: family troubles, in the form of his brother Steve, who challenged his hold on the direction of the ranch, and mounting depression, which in 1998 led him to take his own life at 43. A panoply of speakers â€” including Mr. Schlosser (an executive producer of the film); Steve Hanna; Jay Frost, a half brother; and especially Mr. Hannaâ€™s wife, Ann, a pillar of tender, levelheaded resilience in the face of stark misfortune â€” flesh out the biographical arc of this innovator. Like many tragic visionaries, Kirk Hanna lives on through his ideas long after his death.

Faced with encroaching development in Colorado Springs, Mr. Hanna, a charismatic onetime president of the Colorado Cattlemenâ€™s Association, collaborated with environmentalists â€” previously sworn enemies of the ranching gentry â€” to defend his property, embracing the Nature Conservancy as a means of protecting the landâ€™s resources.

As Kirk Hanna did in life, Mitch Dickmanâ€™s documentary â€œHanna Ranchâ€ù wrestles with ecological concerns. But the biggest problems for Mr. Hanna were very, very human. This Colorado cattle rancher â€” a featured personality in Eric Schlosserâ€™s 2001 best seller â€œFast Food Nationâ€ù â€” was a forward-thinking cowboy who embraced Holistic Resource Management, a fruitful approach that, among other things, encourages herding methods less stressful to cattle and a more frequent rotation of livestock through pastures. Mr. Hanna used earth-friendly natural fertilizer; to attack weeds, he employed hungry goats.
â€œMillion Dollar Armâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for mild language and mildly suggestive content.

There are signs of a darker, more authentic sports movie half-hidden behind a jolly facade in scenes that feature Bill Paxton as a trainer; Alan Arkin as a world-weary retired baseball scout; and the football star Rey Maualuga as Popo, a spoiled, greedy gridiron celebrity JB used to represent and now wants back.

JB sells the idea to a wealthy Chinese-American entrepreneur who gives him a year to round up and train his discoveries. The first third of the movie follows him to India, where he scours the country in search of gifted athletes. After an unpromising start, the nationwide talent hunt yields two young men â€” Rinku (Suraj Sharma, from â€œLife of Piâ€ù) and Dinesh (Madhur Mittal, from â€œSlumdog Millionaireâ€ù) â€” who can hurl a baseball faster than 80 miles an hour. The other, more convincing aha moment arrives earlier in the movie, when an exhausted and discouraged JB idly flips the channel on his television back and forth between a cricket match in India and Susan Boyleâ€™s appearance on â€œBritainâ€™s Got Talent.â€ù In a flash, he conceives the idea of a reality television competition to find Indiaâ€™s best baseball pitchers and bring them to the United States. Because bowling in cricket is not unlike pitching in baseball, he reasons, there must be a huge reservoir of undiscovered talent in a country where cricket is the most popular sport. This watchable but rambling, flaccid movie, based on the true story of Mr. Bernsteinâ€™s 2007 journey to India in search of future baseball superstars, has little of the bite or tension of â€œJerry Maguire,â€ù whose obnoxious hotshot agent is a prototype for JB. Nor does â€œMillion Dollar Armâ€ù have the surreal exoticism and charm of its other obvious forerunner, â€œSlumdog Millionaire.â€ù This, after all, is a Disney family movie, and every conflict is softened by inspirational clichÃ©s.
â€œBaseball isnâ€™t just about business. You should have fun, too.â€ù

As portrayed here, JB is an imperious, unlikable go-getter and a callous womanizer whose face wears the self-absorbed frown of Mr. Hammâ€™s â€œMad Menâ€ù character, Don Draper, on a bad day. Now and then, however, the clouds part, and a look of boyish mischief lights up his expression. In these moments, Mr. Hammâ€™s manic side â€” charmingly visible in his â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ù guest appearances â€” comes into view.

Directed by Craig Gillespie (â€œLars and the Real Girlâ€ù) from a screenplay by Tom McCarthy (â€œThe Visitorâ€ù), it follows JBâ€™s attempt to salvage his failing career after leaving his agency to start his own operation with a partner (Aasif Mandvi of â€œThe Daily Show With Jon Stewartâ€ù) who is too distracted by family obligations to provide much input.

When that sentiment is voiced, none too convincingly, in â€œMillion Dollar Armâ€ù by JB Bernstein (Jon Hamm), a desperate, scrambling sports agent, it is presented as an aha moment of spiritual revelation. But it feels about as fresh and sincere as that shopworn grade-school bromide â€œItâ€™s not whether you win or lose but how you play the game.â€ù Nowadays, it seems, winning and raking in the dough are the only things that matter.
â€œItâ€™s just business,â€ù Popo explains to the crestfallen agent. The same might be said of â€œMillion Dollar Arm.â€ù

The movie barely distinguishes between these innocent man-children, who travel with their wacky pint-size interpreter, Amit (the Bollywood actor Pitobash), a chirping caricature worthy of â€œThe Three Stooges.â€ù In a silly protracted sequence â€” amid elbow-nudging and eye-rolling â€” the young men, with a lot of help from Brenda (Lake Bell), a smart, attractive medical student living in JBâ€™s guesthouse, prepare a romantic candlelit dinner for her and JB.

Directed by David Gaynes, â€œNext Year Jerusalemâ€ù captures experiences like ascending Masada, floating in the Dead Sea, praying at the Western Wall. Some of the travelers have been there before; some havenâ€™t. Not all are Jewish: Helen Downs, 91, a Roman Catholic resident who says sheâ€™d never been out of the United States, is profoundly moved by her dip into the Yardenit baptismal site on the Jordan River. These are not hardy folk â€” many are taxed by light walking or just long stretches in their wheelchairs â€” and officials speak candidly and gently of logistics, worst-case scenarios and their relief at avoiding serious complications.

Traditions may vary, but Passover Seders typically end with the wish that the participants might celebrate again â€œnext year in Jerusalem.â€ù For eight pilgrims from the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, Conn. â€” average age, 91 â€” next year was 2011, when they toured Israel, along with nursing aides, administrators and a film crew.

What elevates the film beyond a video scrapbook, though, are the glimpses of the routines and slow rhythms of the nursing home before and after this adventure, laced with unspoken insights into how to live when the world shrinks to a few rooms, a few activities and the people you share them with.
