Returning home, the travelers recognize their limits and are grateful to transcend them, however briefly. As Ms. Downs says on the bus headed to the airport, â€œBetter take it all in; who knows when weâ€™re coming back?â€ù

As Mr. Duvall paints his portrait of the none-too-cuddly Red in broad brush strokes, Mr. Irvine and the others have a hard time keeping up. Still, the director Emilio AragÃ_n wisely trains the camera on Mr. Duvall. â€œA Night in Old Mexicoâ€ù is his baby, and he rocks it.

Mr. Duvall has fun in â€œA Night in Old Mexicoâ€ù as Red Bovie, the latest in a series of ranchers heâ€™s played in recent years. Redâ€™s an ornery cuss whoâ€™s lost his South Texas spread to the banks. Just as heâ€™s about to end it all, thereâ€™s a knock on the barn door from Gally (Jeremy Irvine), a grandson heâ€™s never met. They have barely exchanged howdies when Red, who is being forced to leave his homestead, impulsively takes off in his Caddy for good times across the border, Gally reluctantly riding shotgun.

Robert Duvall won his Oscar for his finely calibrated portrayal of a recovering alcoholic country singer in â€œTender Mercies,â€ù and much of his best work is in service to nuanced roles. Yet his most memorable performances also include some where he goes big, as in, for example, the napalm-loving Lt. Col. Bill Kilgore in â€œApocalypse Now.â€ù When he has fun, he lets us in on it.

Written by Bill Wittliff, who first worked with Mr. Duvall on the â€œLonesome Doveâ€ù mini-series, the script is not shy about borrowing from other modern westerns. Arriving in a border town, Red and Gally dance and drink tequila, vie for a beautiful seÃ±orita and stumble onto a backpack filled with drug money that many professional killers want back. Red spends the rest of the movie trying to prove that, dammit, this is still country for one old man.

The camera lingers matter-of-factly, even affectionately, not only on fragile newborns but also on elderly bodiesâ€™ paper-thin skin, devastating wounds, a latex-gloved finger probing an abdominal port. Subtly, attention switches to the patientsâ€™ travails, but then thatâ€™s the whole idea. There are people too poor â€œto even dress their wounds,â€ù as Mr. Short observes. There is a dying woman serenaded by a dozen or so volunteers with the hymn â€œHow Great Thou Artâ€ù; an inmate who finds new purpose in life as a hospice volunteer; a man who lost two limbs, cherishing his nurseâ€™s visits because â€œBrian is an Army guy,â€ù too. Tears are almost inevitable.

It focuses on five nurses, each oneâ€™s mission seemingly more vital than the lastâ€™s. Naomi Cross is seen coaching an ovarian cancer survivor through a cesarean delivery of her first child. Jason Short navigates flooded roads to reach a dying Appalachian patient. Tonia Faust directs the hospice at a maximum-security prison. (Perhaps youâ€™ve heard of Angola?) Brian McMillion, a former medic, treats military veterans. Sister Stephen Bloesl runs a nursing home, often bringing residents comfort in the form of small farm animals they can hold and stroke.

Frankly, â€œThe American Nurseâ€ù sounded unpromising. When Carolyn Jones, the director, had breast cancer, she was so touched by the nursing care she received that she wanted to pay tribute to the profession. Sweet, understandable, admirable. But you sort of want to say, Why not just send them a card? Ms. Jones, however, has delivered a solid, worthwhile documentary. If the film is workmanlike at times, it is also elegantly cleareyed.

Lewisâ€™s estranged father, Stanley (Stuart Margolin), stops speaking; to look after him, the family joins his annual Lewis and Clark re-enactment hike. Stanleyâ€™s obsession with the American explorers has inspired both his sonâ€™s academic research and his hang-ups. (â€œRemember when you only used to let me eat what I killed?â€ù Lewis asks his dad.)

Mr. Dunne brings gravitas to a role that could easily have veered into caricature, while Ms. Martin (â€œAugust: Osage Countyâ€ù onstage) strikes a credible balance of prickliness and compassion. Writing and directing his first feature, the filmmaker Justin Schwarz avoids the usual sentimental traps, even delicately skirting Lewisâ€™s near-romance with a fellow hiker (Cara Buono). Mr. Schwarz falters with his ending, which feels overly tidy. Still, itâ€™s not the destination; itâ€™s the journey.

In a device that yields a few easy laughs, the re-enactors insist on period accuracy. (Zoeâ€™s pleas for vegan-friendly food receive a hostile reception.) But â€œThe Discoverersâ€ù counters its many contrivances with relaxed pacing and an evocative sense of the American woodlands by bonfire light.

On paper, â€œThe Discoverersâ€ù sounds like â€œNational Lampoonâ€™s Vacationâ€ù crossed with a self-help manual. Lewis (Griffin Dunne) is a struggling history professor in Chicago who, Ã  la Grady Tripp in â€œWonder Boys,â€ù is preparing to publish a nearly 7,000-page tome. In the sort of excursion that might generously be described as a getaway, he piles his teenage kids, Zoe (Madeleine Martin) and Jack (Devon Graye), into the car, bound for a conference in Portland, Ore. The road tripâ€™s destination suddenly changes when Lewisâ€™s mother takes a turn for the worse.

Still, Orlando is part of a vivid tableau of early-20th-century urban popular culture, a milieu that provides â€œThe Immigrantâ€ù with its setting and its inspiration. The tenor Enrico Caruso performs for the Ellis Island detainees before Orlandoâ€™s magic act, and the Banditâ€™s Roost, the Lower East Side nightclub where Brunoâ€™s â€œdovesâ€ù shed their clothes, is a hive of vaudevillian variety, home to strippers, comedians and musicians. It is hard to disentangle art from sleaze, much as, with Bruno, you canâ€™t quite separate the lost boy from the scoundrel.

At Ellis Island, Ewa and her sister, Magda (Angela Sarafyan), are separated by the authorities. Magda is quarantined, and Ewa, classified as a person of questionable morals and â€œliable to become a public charge,â€ù is prepared for deportation. She is rescued by Bruno Weiss (Joaquin Phoenix), a sharply dressed and well-connected representative of the Travelers Aid Society, whoâ€™s also a producer of burlesque shows and a pimp.
â€œThe Immigrantâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence, greed, nudity.

It does not take long for Ewa, who is desperate rather than naÃ¯ve, to figure out that her savior is also a predator. But Mr. Phoenix, who appeared in three of Mr. Grayâ€™s previous films (â€œThe Yards,â€ù â€œWe Own the Nightâ€ù and â€œTwo Loversâ€ù), is a notably complicated actor, and Bruno is by no means a simple villain. There are unmistakable gothic elements in Ewaâ€™s tale, which is to some extent a lurid fable of wronged innocence, irrational cruelty and wild coincidence set in a landscape of betrayal, brutality and corruption. But Mr. Grayâ€™s gentle, probing camera works its way under the skin and into the souls of the characters, who turn out to be as changeable and unpredictable as their circumstances.

In American popular culture, and in the private lore of millions of American families, the immigrant experience of the late-19th and early 20th centuries is often presented as a chronicle of struggle and triumph, a parable of dreams come true. In â€œThe Immigrant,â€ù James Gray (who directed the film and wrote it with Richard Menello) tries to push through this rosy nostalgia and recapture some of the terror and strangeness of the journey from the Old World to the New. The first shot is of the Statue of Liberty shrouded in harbor mist, and the film unfolds in the gap between the promise that lady embodies and the harsh realities a newcomer encounters once she gets off the boat.

It tells the story of a woman who is denied both the consolations of tribe and her own autonomy, and thus presents a kind of photographic negative of the American dream. It is not what your great-grandmother told her children, even though it may have been a story she knew very well.

All of which is part of the point Mr. Gray is making about America and equally about the art form to which he is so passionately attached. Crude manipulation sits side by side with exquisite subtlety; tawdriness is all mixed up with beauty, meanness with tenderness. Like his other movies, â€œThe Immigrantâ€ù is messy and glorious, a potboiler with the soul of a tragedy, a Dreiserian opera. (The lush musical score is by Chris Spelman).

Not everything in â€œThe Immigrantâ€ù works. Mr. Gray is more interested in mood and feeling than in the mechanics of plot, and some of the turns in the story stumble and creak â€” notably those involving Ewaâ€™s relationship with Orlando (Jeremy Renner), a stage magician who happens to be Brunoâ€™s cousin. He is, at least in Ewaâ€™s eyes, Brunoâ€™s antithesis, free-spirited and kindhearted, but he functions more as a structural convenience than a fully human presence. He arrives to propel the drama forward, but he also lowers the filmâ€™s feverish temperature.

Ewa suffers â€” she is forced into prostitution and rejected by relatives she thought would care for her â€” but she also schemes and steals. She is treated with not entirely undeserved suspicion by some of her new companions, notably Belva (the wonderful Dagmara Dominczyk), another of Brunoâ€™s charges.

The newcomer is Ewa Cybulska, a Polish Catholic who has crossed the ocean in 1921 with her sister, in flight from war and deprivation. She is played by Marion Cotillard (proving herself once again to be one of the subtlest and bravest screen actresses of the moment) with a luminous intensity â€” at once dignified and utterly vulnerable â€” that brings to mind the stars of silent film. And while â€œThe Immigrantâ€ù has dialogue (in several languages) and was shot in color (by the great cinematographer Darius Khondji with a soft-focus, gorgeously grainy palette), it feels almost like a lost artifact of the era it depicts. The film is earnestly and unabashedly melodramatic to an extent that may baffle audiences accustomed to clever, knowing historical fictions. But it also has a depth and purity of feeling that makes other movies feel timid and small by comparison.

Atsushi Funahashiâ€™s gloomy drama takes place in a depressed industry town in the aftermath of the 2011 earthquake and tsunami. But the hand of misfortune has yet one more blow in store, as Shiori, who works in a small factory, loses her husband, Kenji, to an accident. A pall is cast over life, felt in her stunned grief and in a dim workplace resembling a cluttered supply closet.

With that, â€œCold Bloomâ€ù enters the gradual thaw of grief and recovery, aggravated by the fact that Shiori (Asami Usuda) must still work alongside Takumi (Takahiro Miura), the young man who inadvertently caused Kenjiâ€™s death. Mr. Funahashi punctuates his traditional story of shame and forgiveness by repeatedly showing arguments and bullying at the factory over lost contracts and shorter hours. Shiori and Takumi remain tragically, inextricably linked, not least because Takumi insists upon somehow making amends.

The societal background is not incidental to Mr. Funahashi, who before this movie made the post-disaster documentary â€œNuclear Nation.â€ù Thereâ€™s a seed of optimism in the slow but sure progression of the story and its budding faith in traditional values (echoed in the prettily blossoming trees that the camera lingers over). Mr. Miura presents us with one dutiful young man, while Ms. Usuda throws herself with mixed success into her characterâ€™s fundamental confusion over the circumstances.

While a lot of this sounds noble on paper, â€œCold Bloom,â€ù in its tightly controlled moods, comes to feel like a smaller and more tentative film than it might have been, despite an admirably frank ending.

Those shivers owed much to the cinematographer Will Gibson, who died in 2007 and whose skills turned the outback into a hellish landscape of oppressive loneliness. His replacement, Toby Oliver, is no slouch; he just canâ€™t compete with a villain who has wandered too far from monster and too close to buffoon.

Even more inadvisable was the decision (whether made by Mr. McLean or his backers) to transform the mercurial psychopath Mick Taylor (a truly menacing John Jarratt) into a roguish cartoon. His once-terrifying bonhomie tamed, Mick has been reimagined as a chortling, xenophobic butcher who enjoys a singalong of â€œTie Me Kangaroo Down, Sportâ€ù and dismembers his victims with the help of Patsy Clineâ€™s â€œI Fall to Pieces.â€ù

This diminishment continues with a plot (by Mr. McLean and Aaron Sterns) that involves little more than Mickâ€™s terrorizing one innocent backpacker after another (though Ryan Corr is spunkily effective as a wily captive with above-average escape skills). Gone is the emphasis on Mickâ€™s creepy mining-camp lair; in its place is the open road, where Mr. McLean stages a series of slick car chases â€” and a nod to Steven Spielbergâ€™s â€œDuelâ€ù â€” with a brio that completely displaces the original filmâ€™s despairing chills.

With â€œWolf Creek 2,â€ù the director Greg McLean returns once more to remind us that the back of beyond â€” in this case, the Australian outback â€” is a perilous destination for unwary tourists. But those of us who championed its 2005 precursor, the artfully petrifying â€œWolf Creek,â€ù neither need nor want reminding. Like Neil Marshallâ€™s â€œThe Descent,â€ù another crazy-good frightener released in America the following year, â€œWolf Creekâ€ù deserved to stand alone, a uniquely moody and melancholy blood bath.

â€œWolfâ€ù follows Majid â€” a second-generation Dutchman of Moroccan descent recently released from prison and back living with his disapproving family â€” as he works in a warehouse and begins to make a career as a kickboxer in prize fights. His best friend, though, keeps involving him in robberies that grow bigger and bolder, and Majid eventually draws the interest of Hakan, a mob boss who sees potential in him.

Granted, the plot has a definite predictability. Still, the movieâ€™s grittiness â€” the director, Jim Taihuttu (â€œRabatâ€ù), shoots â€œWolfâ€ù in black and white â€” its intrigues, its graphic violence and Mr. Kenzariâ€™s performance make for a worthy addition to the annals of gangster films, Interpol edition.

As European criminal educations go, â€œWolfâ€ù isnâ€™t in the same league as â€œA Prophetâ€ù (2010), but it traffics in some of the same themes and gives similar consideration to the limited choices available to its protagonist. Convincingly played by Marwan Kenzari, Majid is a menace â€” powerfully built, he radiates a compressed, barely contained fury throughout â€” while stopping just short of sociopathy. He cares deeply for a dying older brother, is driven to despair by his fatherâ€™s rejection and spends much of the film torn between the straight life and the better money (and ego boost) that crime pays. Majid shows no remorse in using his brutal skills either in or out of the ring, but itâ€™s with something like regret that he submits to Hakan (a smooth Cahit Olmez), who makes demands he eventually finds hard to stomach.

Some 70,000 people live there as foreigners under an arrangement dating from 1948, and Mr. Fleifel spent summers there after moving with his family to Denmark. That gives him a privileged perspective shaded by some of the hand-wringing of an absentee. His video chronicles check in with personalities he knew and loved, from his pioneering grandfather to his best friend, whose complex political engagement seems superseded by doldrums.

Exiles at home, the generations of family depicted in the documentary â€œA World Not Oursâ€ù live in Lebanon without completely being part of it. This affecting, humor-tinged debut feature from Mahdi Fleifel goes back to the old neighborhood in southern Lebanon: the refugee camp Ain al-Helweh, a Palestinian pocket of hemmed-in buildings and stifled hopes.

Mr. Fleifel helps walk us through the history with an ingratiating voice-over that lightens the seemingly permanent clouds of a dire history. So does a spotlight on soccer fever and the jazz selections on the soundtrack, which at first seem a pandering attempt to ease audiences into the material. But these efforts do their duty without concealing the sense of toxic enforced stasis visible in so many of the lives portrayed by Mr. Fleifel.
â€œBlendedâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It will make your children stupid.

You see very little of that here. You see a lot of overdone reaction shots and strained attempts to generate credible emotions in a story that has no room for them. It has time for maudlin tributes to the virtues of parenthood, for moments of cherubic cuteness and adolescent awkwardness from the kids â€” blameless young actors whose rÃ©sumÃ©s will outgrow this embarrassment â€” and for one or two honest laughs, mostly courtesy of Kevin Nealon as a cradle-robbing fellow vacationer who speaks almost entirely in gerunds.

There are comedians who mine their own insecurities for material. Mr. Sandler, in his recent films, compensates for his by building monuments to his own ego. In â€œBlended,â€ù he once again proclaims himself both Ã_ber-doofus and ultimate mensch, disguising his tireless bullying in childish voices and the ironclad alibis of fatherhood and grief. His character, Jim, is a widower with three daughters who winds up sharing a deluxe South African vacation with Lauren (Drew Barrymore), who is divorced, and her two sons.

Because life is short and I have other things to be upset about, I will not dwell on the offensive aspects of â€œBlended,â€ù the new Adam Sandler comedy: its retrograde gender politics; its delight in the humiliation of children; its sentimental hypocrisy about male behavior; its quasi-zoological depiction of Africans as servile, dancing, drum-playing simpletons; its ... Iâ€™m sorry. Thatâ€™s just what I said I wouldnâ€™t do.

The politically correct scold in me â€” though I prefer the phrase â€œthinking human beingâ€ù â€” may object to all those lapses and more like them, but in my capacity as a film critic, I find myself more bothered by the sheer audience-insulting incompetence of the filmmaking and the writing. Duty compels me to identify Frank Coraci as the director and Ivan Menchell and Clare Sera as the authors of the script. I apologize to all of them for pointing this out, especially Mr. Coraci, who did much better work with Mr. Sandler in â€œThe Waterboy,â€ùâ€œThe Wedding Singerâ€ù and, dare I say, â€œClick.â€ù

The setup is that Lauren and Jim dislike each other after a blind date gone bad. The tragedy is that Ms. Barrymore, who has brought out the best in Mr. Sandler in their previous collaborations (â€œThe Wedding Singerâ€ù and â€œ50 First Datesâ€ù) is here sacrificed on the altar of his showboating narcissism. Women have generally served a decorative and defensive function in his movies â€” on hand to verify this eternal man-childâ€™s sometimes invisible charm and his ferociously insisted-upon heterosexuality â€” but she has been an exception, partly because sheâ€™s such a mischievous comic talent in her own right.

Most of â€œBlendedâ€ù has the look and pacing of a three-camera sitcom filmed by a bunch of eighth graders and conceived by their less bright classmates. Shots donâ€™t match. Jokes misfire. Gags that are visible from a mile away fail to deliver. Two rhinos are seen copulating by the side of a swimming pool, and someone has the wit to say, â€œThatâ€™s not something you see in New Jersey.â€ù Not funny on so many levels.

Mr. Owenâ€™s portrayal of the poet as a self-destructive, macho blowhard fighting a losing battle with the bottle is one of the more compelling portraits of an alcoholic to be encountered in a recent film. Jack, who will do anything not to lose his job, while refusing to toe the line, plays a game of chicken with himself in which the odds of a fatal misstep rise as his public demeanor becomes more disorderly. To buy some time, he commits a disgraceful act of literary theft that only exacerbates his self-loathing and his drinking.
â€œWords and Picturesâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It includes some nude sketches, strong language and sexual situations.

Surrounding and barely supporting these compelling performances is a rickety narrative structure with subplots that never quite transcend perfunctory conflict. One involves Jackâ€™s tense relationship with his college-age son. A more complicated and muddled subplot observes the cruel harassment of an Asian art student (Valerie Tian) by a boorish male classmate who mistakenly confuses his racial taunts with flirtation.

Which brings us to the dueling academics, Jack Marcus (Clive Owen) and Dina Delsanto (Juliette Binoche), who teach at the fictional Croyden prep school. Jack, a garrulous, combative and alcoholic poet who has lost his creative mojo, is on the verge of being fired. He is an outspoken champion of the written word and is fearless about voicing a special loathing for social mediaâ€™s reduction of literacy to tweets and text messages. His rants are witty and impassioned, and the examples he cites of world-changing literary passages convincingly bear out the truth of his conviction that much has been lost in the era of the instant message.

Because â€œWords and Picturesâ€ù is a comedy of ideas couched in the format of a Spencer Tracy-Katharine Hepburn movie, the temptation for some critics faced with a film that dares to be ostentatiously smart is to blast it to smithereens. Which more or less describes the critical reaction to the movie when it was shown last year at the Toronto Film Festival.

Dina, the schoolâ€™s new art instructor, is a painter and hard-nosed aesthetician who has rheumatoid arthritis. Their verbal skirmishes, enlivened by an undertone of sexual attraction, are reminiscent of the battles fought between Norman Mailer and Germaine Greer in the 1970s, although the issues are different. A question hovering throughout the movie: â€œWill they or wonâ€™t they?â€ù Or better yet: â€œWhen will they?â€ù

Jack and Dinaâ€™s jousting culminates with a debate in which arguments that bristled with acute perception in earlier scenes are rehashed in softer tones and lose their edge. Before it collapses into something warm and fuzzy and limp, â€œWords and Picturesâ€ù throws out ideas that are worth pondering.

â€œWords and Picturesâ€ù has a host of flaws, but the performances by Mr. Owen and Ms. Binoche have a crackling vitality, and the screenplayâ€™s strongest moments set off the kind of trains of thought that dedicated teachers hope to spur in their students. Cantankerous though these two teachers can be, you would be lucky to have them in your classroom.

After all, arenâ€™t we who write about movies infinitely more discriminating than the Philistines who make them? How dare the director Fred Schepisi and the screenwriter Gerald DiPego presume to invent a credible, stimulating dialogue, set in a high-toned northern New England prep school where the faculty members delight in playing intellectual mind games? What do they know? Itâ€™s all so â€œmiddlebrow,â€ù to use a popular critical buzzword that reeks of condescension.

Ms. Binoche, playing a female character who makes it a point not to be ingratiating, either to her students or to her fellow faculty members, walks a tightrope between dislikable arrogance and principled inflexibility. The screenplay is as attentive to her condition, whose symptoms fluctuate, as it is to Jackâ€™s drinking, and you admire the toughness required to carry out the physical labor of painting large-scale abstract canvases. The paintings are Ms. Binocheâ€™s, and theyâ€™re quite impressive.

When they meet again years later, Zak (Daniel Fraser) claims to haveÂ found a way to ease their disparities. Marie (Eleanor Wyld) is first intrigued to learn how he has accomplished this. Then, when they are able to touch and even kiss, she is won over, at last able to feel.

In this ambitious little British film, written and directed by Darren Paul Fisher, every individual emits a frequency that determines his or her luck, particularly in love. The higher the frequency, the better the luck â€” but also the lower the empathy.

Before summer tent poles are fully erected, and science fiction is dominated by spaceships, superheroes and special effects, â€œFrequenciesâ€ù arrives to remind us that all sci-fi truly requires is a slightly surreal twist on life.

Thatâ€™s only the first of the movieâ€™s many mysteries, which unfold as it pursues issues greater than one romance. Teeming with ideas, â€œFrequenciesâ€ù is just as interested in debating free will versus determinism, or investigating the science that might lie behind old superstitions. Flashbacks replay key scenes to reveal secrets hidden in plain view. While the detached, deadpan tone and occasionally stilted acting might leave some viewers flat, thereâ€™s no doubting the fierce intelligence behind this admirable puzzle box of a movie.

The story starts at a prep school, where testing identifies the studentsâ€™ frequencies at an early age. Marie, with a superhigh reading and an inability to feel, draws the unrequited desires of Zak and his superlow number. Because of the extreme difference in their frequencies, they cannot even speak together for more than a minute before the earth shudders, fires combust, or overhead planes drop luggage.

Vidalâ€™s first novel, â€œWilliwaw,â€ù was published when he was 19. â€œThe City and the Pillar,â€ù which dealt frankly with homosexuality when the subject was taboo, was a best seller. He later claimed that the literary and critical establishment, particularly The New York Times, had blacklisted him because of the book. He turned his energies to writing for the theater (â€œThe Best Manâ€ù) and the movies (â€œBen Hurâ€ù).

When Gore Vidal declared in an old television debate with William F. Buckley Jr. that 5 percent of Americans had 20 percent of the income and the bottom 20 percent had 5 percent, he was raising an alarm. That observation may be the most shocking moment in â€œGore Vidal: The United States of Amnesia,â€ù Nicholas Wrathallâ€™s admiring documentary portrait of Vidal, who died in 2012 at 86.

The film warmly acknowledges Vidalâ€™s relationship with Howard Auster, with whom he had a domestic partnership for 53 years, until Austerâ€™s death in 2003. The saddest moments show Vidalâ€™s departure from the gorgeous cliffside house they shared in Ravello, Italy.

Born into a well-connected political family, Vidal attended Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire, then joined the Army and plunged into a writing career. His grandfather, whom he idolized, was a blind senator from Oklahoma; his father, a director of air commerce for Franklin D. Roosevelt, taught him to fly at the age of 10.

The meat of the film consists of Vidalâ€™s gloomy thoughts on American history and politics and his conviction that the United States had metamorphosed from a republic into an empire in the thrall of imperialist grandiosity. His estimation of other politicians is devastating: John F. Kennedy was charming and an inspiring speaker but a poor leader who dragged us into Vietnam; Ronald Reagan was â€œthe best cue card reader they could findâ€ù; and George W. Bush was a â€œfool.â€ù About American involvement in the Middle East, he said: â€œWhat weâ€™ve done is unite the Muslim world. Weâ€™ve made a lot of trouble for ourselves. This is only the beginning, and we will wish we had not done it.â€ù

Intellectual celebrities nowadays eschew the lofty, disdainful tones affected by Vidal and Buckley, his conservative opponent, who died in 2008. Public discourse is louder, angrier and coarser. No liberal of comparable eloquence has taken Vidalâ€™s place in the public square, although Christopher Hitchens, who died in 2011, deemed himself Vidalâ€™s heir apparent, until the two men had a falling out.

Why shocking? It illustrates the astounding degree to which perceptions have changed over time. By the standards of today, when income inequality has widened exponentially and the middle class is shrinking, statistics that infuriated Vidal sound like the answer to a socialistâ€™s prayer.
Asked what he thought his legacy might be, Vidal replies in a tone of withering indifference, â€œI couldnâ€™t care less.â€ù

Heavily seasoned with epigrams worthy of Oscar Wilde, this entertaining documentary portrays Vidal as a pessimistic political prophet with streaks of paranoia and misanthropy, but a truth teller nonetheless. In carefully selected excerpts from interviews and conversations conducted during all phases of his career, he exudes a patrician hauteur fed by a reservoir of chilly rage. For this champion of democracy and freedom of speech was an aristocrat who blamed many of Americaâ€™s blunders on the short memory, or â€œamnesiaâ€ù span, of the body politic.

The film opens with an image of Vidal, cane at his side, sitting on the tomb in which he will be buried. What follows is a thorough, skillfully assembled chronology of the life and times of this all-around man of letters and public gadfly whose historical novels are widely regarded as his finest achievements.

â€œEnvy is the central fact of American lifeâ€ù is a typically acute remark from a man whose default attitude was a lofty contempt. It must be said that Vidal, an avid student of history, was better informed than most people and had a sweeping global perspective.

The documentary only glosses his private life, which is thoroughly dissected in Tim Teemanâ€™s recently published book, â€œIn Bed With Gore Vidal.â€ù Vidalâ€™s radical theories about sexuality, which earned him a fan letter from Dr. Alfred Kinsey, are mentioned briefly. The success of his comic transgender novel, â€œMyra Breckinridge,â€ù which landed him on the covers of Time, Newsweek, Look and Life magazines, is noted, but the bookâ€™s vision not analyzed.

The stolen-authorship premise is popular, used by Woody Allen in both â€œBullets Over Broadwayâ€ù and â€œYou Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger.â€ù The 2012 drama â€œThe Wordsâ€ù (starring Bradley Cooper) covers similar territory. But â€œLila, Lilaâ€ù fails to make witty use of the idea. The actors â€” the deft Mr. BrÃ_hl and the charming Ms. Herzsprung â€” add what levity they can.

After Marie submits the work to a publisher, the novel â€” which, from excerpts, sounds mawkish and trite â€” is hailed as â€œthe end of postmodernismâ€ù and â€œÂ â€˜Anna Kareninaâ€™ for the Internet generation.â€ù David must now contend with awkward reading appearances (heâ€™s unable to pronounce words he ostensibly wrote) and the perils of fame. And thatâ€™s before Jacky Stocker (Henry HÃ_bchen), a man who claims to be the real author, starts turning up, introducing himself to others as Davidâ€™s mentor and agent. As the basis for a bittersweet comedy, this material is right up there with â€œCape Fear.â€ù

A recent surge in cachet for Daniel BrÃ_hl â€” he played the methodical Formula One driver Niki Lauda in â€œRushâ€ù and the sniper turned movie star in â€œInglourious Basterdsâ€ù â€” hasnâ€™t quite blown the dust off â€œLila, Lila,â€ù a glossy trifle released in 2009 in Germany thatâ€™s belatedly opening in New York.

Mr. BrÃ_hl plays David Kern, a shy waiter who finds a manuscript in a night stand he has purchased from a flea market. Passing the book off as his own, David uses it to woo a literature student, Marie (Hannah Herzsprung), who seems interested exclusively in men of letters.

Inspired, offbeat casting drives the gory but not very suspenseful â€œCold in July,â€ù which stars Michael C. Hall, Sam Shepard and Don Johnson as three unlikely amigos banding against evil. The bad guys include the â€œDixie Mafia,â€ù the producers of snuff movies in which teenage girls are tortured and murdered; sinister, corrupt cops; and other monsters slithering through the hell of East Texas, often accompanied by thunder and lightning.

Richard is so reticent that he is embarrassed to find himself celebrated as a local hero. The police hastily identify the victim as Freddy Russell, a wanted felon and lowlife, and they warn Richard that Freddyâ€™s no-good father, Ben, a man just out of prison, could make trouble.

The film culminates with a protracted blood bath in a creepy mansion. The nervous Richard; the brooding, gun-crazy Ben; and the maniacally free-spirited Jim Bob might as well be colliding bumper cars at the wildest carnival this side of Houston.

The pulpy neo-noir â€œCold in Julyâ€ù should propel the filmmaking team of Jim Mickle and Nick Damici further up the blood-spattered, zombie-infested hierarchy of B-movie auteurs with Hollywood ambitions. Last year, they advanced a few feet with their remake of the 2011 Mexican cannibal fest, â€œWe Are What We Are,â€ù which followed two microbudget cult favorites: the post-apocalyptic â€œStake Landâ€ù (2011), and â€œMulberry St.â€ù (2007), a medical horror flick.

Sure enough, Ben (Mr. Shepard, at his most laconic and menacing) appears and begins stalking Richard. After one too many provocations, Ben is arrested and thrown in jail. But Richard, suspicious of the cut-and-dried handling of the case, begins sleuthing and is startled to witness the sheriff (Mr. Damici) and his deputies dragging Ben out of jail and tying him to a railroad track as a train approaches. Richard saves Benâ€™s life just in time, and an edgy rapport is established.

The movie, adapted from a novel by Joe R. Lansdale, is set in 1989, and Mr. Hall, amusingly done up with a mullet, plays Richard Dane, a prim, upright Texan with a picture-framing business, who lives with his dour wife (Vinessa Shaw) and a young son. His timid existence is uprooted when he shoots and accidentally kills an intruder in the middle of the night.

â€œCold in Julyâ€ù goes gleefully haywire with the arrival of Jim Bob (Mr. Johnson), a swaggering private eye and pig farmer who dresses like a cowboy and drives a fire-engine-red convertible. As the movieâ€™s resident live wire, Mr. Johnson, obviously having the time of his life, is a hoot, and the feisty camaraderie among these three men gives â€œCold in Julyâ€ù a euphoric goofiness.

The only hope is to send someone back in time to prevent the things from being invented, a journey that only Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) is strong enough to undertake. Assisted by Kitty Pryde (Ellen Page), he zips into the past and wakes up in a strange bed with a pretty companion beside him and Roberta Flack on the radio.

Wolverineâ€™s task is, in effect, to get the band back together, which means rousing proto-Professor X, Charles Xavier (James McAvoy), from a drug-addicted malaise; springing proto-Magneto, Erik Lehnsherr (Michael Fassbender), from lockdown (heâ€™s been blamed for the Kennedy assassination); and tracking down the elusive, shape-shifting, bright blue and super-angry Mystique (Jennifer Lawrence), also known as Raven. Crucial assistance is provided by the Beast (Nicholas Hoult) and a speedy teenager (Evan Peters) who will eventually become Quicksilver and who anchors a showstopping action sequence in the kitchen of the Pentagon.

And that, of course, is the big risk in a movie like this. So much has already been done, so much is supposedly demanded by fans, that any given installment in a multisequel enterprise can feel like the hysterical pursuit of diminishing returns. In the case of â€œDays of Future Past,â€ù the plot is as overelaborate and muddled as some of the effects. The clever historical revisionism of â€œX-Men: First Classâ€ù (a high point in the series, along with â€œX2: X-Men Unitedâ€ù) has given way to a more slapdash mix of period detail and clumsy anachronism.

Even compared with other self-serious superhero franchises â€” the brooding â€œDark Knightâ€ù saga, the agonized â€œAmazing Spider-Man,â€ù the hectic â€œAvengersâ€ù house party â€” the X-Men series wears its allegorical heart on its sleeve. In chronicling the adventures of a despised minority with extraordinary powers, the movies, like the Marvel comic books before them, poke around in some interesting social and political hot zones. The central conflict is the endless moral and political argument between Professor X and Magneto: in other words, between the accommodationist idea that the mutants should fight for the moral redemption of the humans, and the militant insistence that they should defend their own interests by any means necessary.
â€œX-Men: Days of Future Pastâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). High-impact, mostly bloodless violence and a few glimpses of mutant buttocks.

â€œX-Men: Days of Future Past,â€ù directed (like most of its predecessors) by Bryan Singer, situates this struggle in the 1970s, though how it arrives in that era is a bit complicated. The main action, which takes place around the Paris peace talks that ended the Vietnam War, is framed by an apocalyptic battle in the distant future. A bunch of familiar mutants, including Professor X and Magneto (played as older men by Patrick Stewart and Ian McKellen) are under siege by the Sentinels, fearsome, human-designed robots that descend from coffin-shaped airships and that seem to have neutralized any genetic advantage the mutants might have had.

But the psychology of anti-mutant prejudice has never really been Mr. Singerâ€™s main concern. The anger of the mutants remains the most interesting part of his â€œX-Menâ€ù movies, and the dramatic and emotional heart of the franchise. Each of the main mutants deals with it in a different way: Erik with icy, self-righteous fury; Charles with melancholy humanism; Mystique with an anarchistâ€™s drive to mess things up; Wolverine with world-weary stoicism. The actors tackle the roles without winking or condescension, and it is nice to see them together again, however distracting the circumstances. They will, of course, return, since in the superhero world, as in the real one, some problems can never really be solved, only put to rest in between episodes.

But, as usual, the characters â€” and the performers playing them â€” step unto the breach to provide just enough wit and feeling to make â€œDays of Future Pastâ€ù something other than a waste of a reasonable personâ€™s time. The film has found an excellent villain in the person of Peter Dinklage, playing a mutant-hating arms manufacturer with the excellent name of Bolivar Trask.

Not every moment is quite so inspired as that one, an intricate, freeze-frame slapstick ballet that fuses the pop playfulness of the old comics with the latest digital gimmickry. Far less effective, for example, is a climactic bit in which the enraged Erik, having donned a helmet that pays incidental homage to Professor Chaos of â€œSouth Park,â€ù levitates a sports stadium and plops it down on the White House lawn. This must have seemed like a good idea to someone, but, in practice, it seems, for both Magneto and Mr. Singer, like gratuitous, imagination-deficient grandstanding.

The logic of the story â€” a time-travel pretzel that strains after the brain-teasing power of an old â€œStar Trekâ€ù episode â€” requires too many variables. The frantic crosscutting of the culminating battles, which take place simultaneously and also a half-century apart, requires too much thought on the part of the audience because it has received too little on the part of the filmmakers.

From the director of â€œField of Dreamsâ€ù comes one of those movies about someone who learns he has a terminal diagnosis and desperately tries to take stock. In Phil Alden Robinsonâ€™s â€œThe Angriest Man in Brooklyn,â€ù Robin Williams plays an irascible New York lawyer who gains a sudden window of self-awareness when a doctor says he has 90 minutes left to live. The movie is predictably sentimental at its root, but itâ€™s also meant to be comedy, partly resting on Mr. Williamsâ€™s energetic but failed attempt to play a jerk.

At a doctorâ€™s appointment, Henry Altmann (Mr. Williams) needles Dr. Gill (Mila Kunis) until, in frustration, she blurts out a false diagnosis. Henry then does his hand-wringing shuffle across town, seeking out his wife (Melissa Leo) and his estranged dancer son (Hamish Linklater); meanwhile, the regretful Dr. Gill tries to track him down, having her own realizations. Henry also has some competition at anger management, as Mr. Robinson feebly sketches out a high-strung, traffic-addled city, complete with sassy street people.
â€œThe Angriest Man in Brooklynâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or guardian) for verbal abuse honed over many years, and a little sexual content.

An opening flashback suggests that Henry was not always the miserable human being we see before us, though thereâ€™s a running joke that everyoneâ€™s used to his apoplexy. Mr. Williams, however, has a well-established habit of taking such redemptive roles (with the odd, offbeat entry having some success, like â€œWorldâ€™s Greatest Dadâ€ù). His tirades and impatience here feel strained, though not so much that anyone could really get angry over them.

â€œStand Clear of the Closing Doorsâ€ù is all the more impressive for not overreacting to the catastrophe and making it the main event. It stays with its characters to a wonderfully witty and understated ending.

As the movie jumps back and forth between mother and son, Mariana becomes increasingly panicked, while Ricky gradually crumples into himself, growing hungrier, his only sustenance a bag of potato chips he buys with his last four quarters and a banana given to him by a homeless man. He also becomes dirtier. After a futile search for an unlocked bathroom, he urinates in his seat, and other passengers comment and begin to avoid him. It isnâ€™t clear how many days and nights he remains adrift.

The movie was three-quarters of the way toward completion when Hurricane Sandy hammered the Rockaways. Mr. Fleischnerâ€™s home was destroyed, and the subway closed for over a week. He had to rethink the ending.

Directed by Sam Fleischner from a screenplay by Rose Lichter-Marck and Micah Bloomberg, the film has such an infallible ear for subway sounds, ridersâ€™ remarks and panhandlersâ€™ spiels that it is next to impossible to distinguish overheard conversations by nonactors from scripted dialogue. It also finds an intense, gritty beauty in the patterns of tiles and pipes that Ricky studies fixedly as he rides from one end of the system to the other and back, stopping more than once at Times Square.

â€œStand Clear of the Closing Doors,â€ù a small miracle of a film, captures the grass-roots swirl of New York City with an extraordinary sensory attuning to urban life. Set largely inside the cityâ€™s subway system, it observes the world through the eyes of Ricky (Jesus Sanchez-Velez), a bright but easily distracted 13-year-old boy with midrange autism who gets lost underground. Mr. Sanchez-Velez, the untrained actor who plays him, has Aspergerâ€™s syndrome and is a hauntingly plaintive screen presence.

Mariana is an illegal Mexican immigrant who works as a part-time housekeeper. Ricky wanders off and disappears when Carla neglects her daily task of walking him home from school, to go shopping. Mariana is furious. Even in ordinary times, Ricky is a handful for whom school officials lack the resources to devote the attention he requires.

Throughout the movie, you are forcefully reminded that time spent on the subway may be the ultimate New York grounding experience. You feel the cityâ€™s collective pulse as the entire spectrum of humanity pours around you. The movie captures the complicated mixture of loneliness, exhilaration, fear and curiosity of subway travel, which even in the quietest of times can be a hallucinatory experience that seeps deep into your consciousness.

â€œStand Clear of the Closing Doorsâ€ù sharply distinguishes Rickyâ€™s dreaminess with Marianaâ€™s hard-edge desperation. The emergency forces Mariana out of her shell, and she befriends Carmen (Marsha Stephanie Blake), a saleswoman from a shoe store Ricky frequents who accompanies Mariana to a police station and helps her distribute fliers.

Ricky is an uncommonly imaginative artist with an entire notebook of drawings depicting dragons like the one on the strangerâ€™s jacket. A more ethereal beauty is glimpsed in the subway lights and in reflections on car windows as the trains swoosh by one another. Now and then, the film pauses to study a colored image as though gazing through half-closed eyes.

Entranced by a dragon decal on a strangerâ€™s jacket, Ricky follows him into the subway at Rockaway Beach, Queens, where he lives with his mother, Mariana (Andrea Suarez Paz), and 15-year-old sister, Carla (Azul Zorrilla). His father, Ricardo Sr., who is working upstate when Ricky disappears, is rarely at home but shows up late in the movie to help look for him.

Mr. Jodorowsky, whose noncinematic pursuits include the development of a therapeutic method called psychomagic, is a shamanistic presence in â€œThe Dance of Reality.â€ù He appears as the protector of his younger self and as a kind of tutelary deity, infusing the story of his own life with a potent and implicitly political lesson. â€œThe Dance of Realityâ€ù is the work of a highly disciplined anarchist, whose principal weapon against authority is his own imagination.

You do not have to be a devotee of this directorâ€™s earlier work to think so, since â€œThe Dance of Realityâ€ù serves both as a capstone and a calling card. Mr. Jodorowskyâ€™s reputation for extremity and surrealist inventiveness is upheld by grotesque, horrifying and comical images that seek out zones of maximum sexual, social and political sensitivity. A woman urinates on her semiconscious husband (in a scene that could not possibly have been simulated). Later, she dances naked with her young son after blackening his body with shoe polish. Her husband fights in the street with a group of shirtless, homeless men, most of them missing at least one limb. There are scenes of torture, sexual violence and almost unbearable embarrassment.

But the sensibility governing this film is as entirely and unmistakably Mr. Jodorowskyâ€™s as the experiences, dreamed and lived, that feed it. It is as much his fatherâ€™s tale as his own, and though it is unsparing in its depiction of Jaimeâ€™s cruelty, vanity and cowardice, it is also profoundly forgiving. And implicitly political in its fury, undimmed by the passage of years, at violence inflicted by the powerful on the weak. Jaime is a bully to his son, but circumstances conspire to teach him a lesson. After Jaime leaves home on an ill-fated mission to assassinate IbÃ¡Ã±ez, he suffers a series of physical and spiritual torments that both break and redeem him and that give the movie extraordinary moral force and emotional power.

The Chilean-born filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky has recently been the subject of a revelatory documentary â€” â€œJodorowskyâ€™s Dune,â€ù directed by Frank Pavich â€” about a movie he never made. There are a lot of those: Since his heyday in the early â€™70s as a midnight cult-film pioneer with â€œEl Topoâ€ù and â€œThe Holy Mountain,â€ù Mr. Jodorowskyâ€™s semimythic status as a cinematic wild man has outstripped his productivity as a director. So the arrival of a new feature â€” his first since 1990 â€” would be grounds for excitement even, if the movie in question, â€œThe Dance of Reality,â€ù were not something very close to a masterpiece.

The boyâ€™s mother, Sara (Pamela Flores), is not much easier to deal with. She withdraws her maternal love after Jaime forces the boy to cut off his flowing blond locks and confounds poor Alejandro by alternating chilly reserve with erotic provocation. She also sings all of her dialogue in a soaring soprano, as if her every utterance were an aria in her own private opera. (Ms. Flores, in addition to being a fearless screen actress, is also a professional opera singer.)

And yet, somehow, the mood is more tender than assaultive. Mr. Jodorowskyâ€™s dominant trait seems to be an exuberant sense of wonder rather than a desire to serve up gratuitous shocks. He shows up on screen early, a tall, charismatic, silver-bearded gentleman with a fondness for quasi-mystical aphorisms about money, desire and memory. You may roll your eyes at some of them, but those same eyes will be dazzled by bold colors and seduced by sweeping, sinuous camera movements. You will also be drawn into an eccentric and lovely coming-of-age story, an evocation of the lost landscapes and vividly recalled sensations of childhood that belongs in the company of films like Federico Felliniâ€™s â€œAmarcordâ€ù and John Boormanâ€™s â€œHope and Glory.â€ù

That is hardly the most peculiar thing in â€œThe Dance of Reality,â€ù but a simple catalog of oddities would misrepresent the beauty and coherence of the filmâ€™s conception, as well as spoiling some surprises. Its blend of visual elegance and perversity recalls the work of Luis BuÃ±uel, and also of Mr. Jodorowskyâ€™s countryman RaÃºl Ruiz. The streets of Tocopilla are touched with some of the magic realism that animated Gabriel GarcÃ_a MÃ¡rquezâ€™s Macondo on the other side of the continent, and also with a tragic sense of history.

Mr. Jodorowsky was born in 1929, which is the year his tale begins, with a young adolescent boy, also named Alejandro Jodorowsky, living with his shopkeeper parents in the Chilean seaside town of Tocopilla. Chile is enduring the dictatorship of Carlos IbÃ¡Ã±ez del Campo, whose imposing portrait adorns nearly every wall in Tocopilla. Alejandroâ€™s father, Jaime (played by Mr. Jodorowskyâ€™s son Brontis), a Jewish immigrant from Ukraine, has a picture of Stalin hanging in his store, and the three-way resemblance among these mustachioed tyrants, political and domestic, is hardly accidental. IbÃ¡Ã±ez is rounding up opponents, while Stalin is starving peasants in the Jodorowskysâ€™ homeland. On the home front, Jaime is a macho martinet who subjects his son to a series of cruel and capricious humiliations, hoping to make a man out of him.

The title of Lee Jae-kyooâ€™s â€œThe Fatal Encounterâ€ù is a misnomer: The film teems with fatal encounters. It is 1777, in the Joseon dynasty in Korea, and King Jeong-jo (Hyun Bin) â€” known historically as the king of misfortune â€” is surrounded by enemies. Two factions, the Noron and Soron, are at each otherâ€™s throats, and everyone, it seems, has it in for him. Even his trusted clerk, Sang-chaek (an effectively understated Jung Jae-young), a quiet minder of this philosopher-kingâ€™s library, was trained in childhood at a kind of assassin school for slaves. He has positioned himself to strike but discovers that the monarch is a benign ruler and a friend.

Another slave-assassin, Sal-soo (Cho Jung-seok), in order to free himself from a sadistic master-trainer, aims to kill Jeong-jo, but his mission is complicated by his love for a palace maid. Even a little girl is enlisted to poison Queen Jeong-sun (Han Ji-min).

Children are often abused here: They are jailed, interrogated, branded as slaves and even forced to witness an execution. Itâ€™s a cheap dramatic device in a film abounding in lavish, shadowy interiors; meticulously formal, often symmetrical compositions; and grave, hushed pronouncements. Most of the movie precedes a populous, artfully staged palace attack, but getting there involves considerable talk of conspiracies and needless jumps in chronology. For all its spectacle, â€œThe Fatal Encounterâ€ù is wanting for profundity.

The French Riviera scenery from this monthâ€™s Cannes Film Festival may act as an enticement, but onlookers are advised not to imitate the drastic measures taken in â€œThe Love Punch,â€ù a good-natured if strenuously wacky caper comedy about a divorced British couple who plot a diamond heist to save their pensions.

As in â€™60s confections like â€œTopkapiâ€ù â€” a filmmaking tradition â€œThe Love Punchâ€ù self-consciously emulates â€” some wonderful actors add class to the material, which struggles to find a consistent register of cartoonishness. (The quartetâ€™s wedding-crash-by-snorkel-and-cliff-climb might have impressed James Bond.) The antics bear little resemblance to those that follow actual divorce and financial ruin, any more than â€œThe Love Punchâ€ù resembles the films that compete at Cannes.

When that fails, what else can they do but rob a $10.8 million jewel from the villainâ€™s fiancÃ©e (Louise Bourgoin)? A fellow couple (Timothy Spall and Celia Imrie) aid them in this endeavor, which involves kidnapping and impersonating wealthy Texans. As justification, Kate rails against financial fat cats; still, down to its rote soundtrack selections (â€œAll Right Now,â€ù â€œTakinâ€™ Care of Businessâ€ù), the film feels too complacent to embody a true fight-the-man spirit.
â€œThe Love Punchâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Philandering, kidnapping, too much wine.

Because the scheme takes them to Paris and then to Cannes and its surroundings, the ex-spouses, Kate (Emma Thompson) and Richard (Pierce Brosnan), slowly rekindle the spark. After a hedge fund manager (Laurent Lafitte), based in France, strips Richardâ€™s company of its value, Kate agrees to accompany her former husband to Paris, where the two will demand their money back.

But there is a story, and Mr. Oliveira has a special knack for spiking the ends of his slow, discursive films with a sting of surprise. â€œGeboâ€ù doesnâ€™t aim for the transcendent shock that concludes â€œA Talking Pictureâ€ù or the mischievous coup de cinÃ©ma in â€œThe Strange Case of Angelica.â€ù It is quieter, more compact and less thematically ambitious than those â€” an intriguing minor composition by a shrewd and skillful master of the art.

The family in â€œGebo and the Shadow,â€ùManoel de Oliveiraâ€™s 2012 film adaptation of a play by the early-20th-century Portuguese writer Raul BrandÃ£o, has been stuck in a limbo of anguish and tedium. A young man named JoÃ£o (Ricardo TrÃªpa) has been missing for eight years, and every evening his father, Gebo (Michael Lonsdale), loses himself in ledgers and business documents. JoÃ£oâ€™s mother (Claudia Cardinale) and wife (Leonor Silveira) bring Gebo coffee and pester him for news of the prodigal. JoÃ£oâ€™s fate is ambiguous, which makes the grief and anxiety of his wife and mother all the more acute, and his fatherâ€™s evasiveness all the more troubling.

Mr. Oliveira, born in 1908, has an effortless feel for, and an inexhaustible interest in, the manners and customs of an older Europe. Even his films set in the present day evoke a world shadowed by long history and animated by ancient codes of behavior and feeling. â€œGebo and the Shadow,â€ù which seems to take place in the 19th century, belongs both to that time and now. Or it might be better just to say that it happens in the peculiar and recognizable universe â€” a region that is both French and Portuguese, decorous and passionate, classical and romantic, literary and cinematic â€” of Mr. Oliveiraâ€™s imagination.

Until the end, â€œGeboâ€ù is slow and quiet. Never one to rush through a plot, Mr. Oliveira relishes the formality of conversation, and there is great pleasure to be found in listening to the actors and watching the small adjustments of posture and gesture that accompany their words. This is especially true when Jeanne Moreau shows up, wizened and fierce, as a neighbor who has dropped in for coffee.

Fleet-fingered jewel thief, compulsive liar, one-woman race crusader, parasite, parent, performer: Doris Payne could be identified in many ways (in addition to her multiple aliases). But she has also clearly had the time of her life. â€œThe Life & Crimes of Doris Payne,â€ù a rough-edged, brief documentary about this octogenarian career criminal, sketches a peppy and beguiling portrait of a convict whose defiant streak of independence has a way of outshining her wrongdoing.

â€œThe Life & Crimes of Doris Payneâ€ù has an embarrassment of riches in Ms. Payneâ€™s story, and itâ€™s often a ripping good yarn, but, as a film, it lacks the nimbleness and resourcefulness of its subject.

By her account, Ms. Payne grew up in West Virginia with an abusive father and began her decades of thievery by stealing to help her mother. The filmmakers, Matthew Pond and Kirk Marcolina, let their charming, quick-witted and resourceful subject relate her exploits, with commentary from a longtime friend of Ms. Payneâ€™s, her daughter, a sheriff, her lawyer and, appropriately, the writer of a screenplay about her life.

Consequences loom: The sympathetic spine of this broadcast-style documentary is her trial, then impending, on charges of stealing from Macyâ€™s in San Diego. (More recently, in April, Ms. Payne was sentenced to two years in jail and two years under mandatory supervision for another theft, in Palm Desert, Calif.)

Ms. Payneâ€™s higher-end targets â€” including jewelry stores in Europe and the United States â€” easily place her adventures in a realm of escapist fiction, and she confesses to harboring an urge to redress social injustice as she pretends to be one of the rich to steal from them. But among the filmâ€™s insider true-crime details, it also becomes clear that her gutsy stance reflects a willingness to say and do whatever is necessary to con her marks. The compressed filmâ€™s patchy re-enactments and pop psychology donâ€™t entirely capture this complicated woman, though she is admittedly practiced at evading capture of all kinds.

Tyler, 66, a buff Harlem activist, helps run SAGE (Services & Advocacy for Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual & Transgender Elders), marches in the gay pride parade and celebrates the passage of New Yorkâ€™s same-sex marriage bill. His enthusiasm and social commitment underscore a familiar lesson: that positivity and social interaction help deter the bodyâ€™s decline.

Robert, an affable 72-year-old with a penchant for Hawaiian shirts, runs Robertâ€™s Lafitte, a Galveston, Tex., gay bar that hosts weekend drag shows and holiday potlucks. He reminisces about his longtime lover, whom he lost to a stroke after nearly 35 years; and after some heart attacks, Robert is on a pill regimen while his nephew manages more of the business.

Thereâ€™s much sympathy but little tension in P J Ravalâ€™s new documentary, â€œBefore You Know It,â€ù a gentle portrait of three gay men of a certain age. As it hops across the country, the film depicts a generation that has seen profound advances in gay rights but struggles with common issues of aging.

Dennis, a soft-spoken 78-year-old who dresses as Dee, alternates between a solitary life in a modest Florida residence and a retirement home outside Portland, Ore. He mentions weighing â€œexit strategiesâ€ù but admits trying not to think about death too much. He also frets about his sex drive, saying, â€œAt my age, I take what I can get.â€ù Undaunted, he joins a gay Caribbean cruise but essentially remains a loner.
â€œMaleficentâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). There is some bloodless violence, some involving wings.

Angelina Jolie makes a fabulous monster. As the title character in â€œMaleficentâ€ù â€” a divertingly different rethink of an awfully old story â€” she breezes through the movie, part superstar, part superfreak.

She wears them like a crown in this live-action postscript to the visually stunning 1959 Disney animated musical â€œSleeping Beauty.â€ù This time, the focus isnâ€™t on the beautiful, blond Aurora, who falls into a deep, bewitched sleep after pricking her finger on a spindle, but rather on the sinister scene stealer who cursed her in a fit of pique and a puff of acid-green smoke. As it turns out, Maleficent (it rhymes with magnificent) had her reasons and a back story to go with them. Soothingly introduced in voice-over by Janet McTeer, Maleficentâ€™s story opens when she was a happy young fairy (Isobelle Molloy and Ella Purnell) living in, and flying over, the moors, a lush, computer-generated wonderland populated by cute uglies and delicately mossy, twiggy giants.

Trouble enters in the form of a human boy, Stefan, a farmhand whoâ€™s caught pilfering a stone, a seemingly small act that reverberates as loudly as Klaxon horns. Maleficent forgives him; a friendship is born; time rushes by â€” itâ€™s obvious that the filmmakers canâ€™t wait to bring in Ms. Jolie â€” and the friendship evolves into a puppyish romance, sealed with a kiss. Stefan seems nice enough, if bland, and heâ€™s played first by Michael Higgins and then, briefly, by Jackson Bews. Before long, though, Ms. Jolie has taken to the skies while, back in the human realm, Sharlto Copley has brought the adult Stefan ploddingly, disappointingly down to earth. Casting is destiny in a lot of movies; one look at the twitchy, shifty-eyed adult Stefan, and itâ€™s clear that Mr. Copley wonâ€™t be continuing the romance.

Bruno Bettelheim, that great reader of fairy tales, saw â€œThe Sleeping Beautyâ€ù as a story of sexual awakening. She wakes only when physically and emotionally mature enough, when she is ready for love and its familiar handmaidens: sex and marriage. Itâ€™s at that point, Bettelheim writes in â€œThe Uses of Enchantment,â€ù â€œthe wall of thorns suddenly turns into a wall of big, beautiful flowers, which opens to let the prince enter.â€ù Thatâ€™s quite the metaphor, but for women, it has sometimes also been a curse, including in movies, where they have traditionally had to wait for a man to get them to their happily ever after. Thereâ€™s no denying the attractions of that narrative for some of us: Even Lena Dunham got swept off her feet.

But, come on! Thereâ€™s more to life and certainly more to women, which is something that, however imperfectly, â€œMaleficentâ€ù grapples with. Iâ€™m still not sure if the movieâ€™s smack-down between patriarchy and matriarchy is the way to go, but at least nobody here is warbling about what she wants before hitting the road to self-actualization.

He doesnâ€™t. Instead, he betrays Maleficent and, in one of the movieâ€™s muddled sections, helps wage war against her land. Her wings literally clipped, Maleficent retreats into her dark place like a grounded Valkyrie, casting shadows over her world to go with her mood. Stefan assumes the throne and, years later, he and his forgettable queen have a child, Aurora.

That Elsa remains single in â€œFrozenâ€ù has inspired some widely, wildly divergent readings of that movie, with some commentators claiming her as a L.G.B.T. representation, and others denouncing her for the same reason. Itâ€™s entirely possible that â€œMaleficent,â€ù partly because itâ€™s narratively weak and Ms. Jolie is a powerful screen presence, will inspire its share of warring interpretations (and dismissals). The movie, directed by Robert Stromberg from Linda Woolvertonâ€™s script, draws on Disneyâ€™s â€œSleeping Beautyâ€ù and Charles Perraultâ€™s version of the tale. Despite this, the narrative linchpin isnâ€™t Aurora: Itâ€™s Maleficent, who doesnâ€™t fit the fairy tale template largely because of her relationships. Stefan angers her, but she so gets over him and soon shifts her attention elsewhere.

Mr. Stromberg, a production designer making his feature directing debut, does best when he scales down, as in the lovely shots of Maleficent walking next to a floating, unconscious Aurora, an image that telegraphs more about their relationship than any line of dialogue. The action scenes, by contrast, are visually uninteresting, borderline generic and unnecessary. There are also far too many long shots when the digital renderings (especially those with human figures) pull you out of the story instead of keeping you immersed. But thereâ€™s so much to look at in the movie â€” from the wittily designed creatures to the shocks of bilious green and purple â€” that the battles quickly fade. (The colors are, as is a galloping race to the rescue, among the many nods to the 1959 â€œSleeping Beauty.â€ù)

Her red mouth slashes across the screen while her clothes billow like storm clouds, her body framed by enormous shimmering wings and her head capped by a pair of majestic horns. The wings allow her to soar, but the horns mainly give her character a distinctly Freudian kink, some phallic enhancement to go with the fairy tale enchantment. And, my, what big horns they are.

Consciously or not, coherently or not, â€œMaleficentâ€ù tells a new kind of story about how we live now, not once upon another time. And it does so by suggesting, among other things, that budding girls and older women are not natural foes, even if thatâ€™s what fairy tales, Hollywood and the world like to tell us. And while that may sound drippy, itâ€™s exactly the kind of hokey that, movie by movie, may finally make a real difference.

At this point, the filmmakers pick up the â€œSleeping Beautyâ€ù thread and begin weaving it into Maleficentâ€™s story, so, again, there are a christening and a curse, and Aurora is squired away by a troika of pixies (a tolerably amusing Imelda Staunton, Lesley Manville and Juno Temple), who raise her in a forest cottage. There, she grows up (and eventually into Elle Fanning) under the gaze of Maleficent, which is where this rethink gets going.

In broad strokes, â€œMaleficentâ€ù is Disneyâ€™s latest bid to recast a dusty story for a contemporary audience, one that has, over the years, complained with good reason about the companyâ€™s representations, particularly of female characters. For decades, Disney has responded with an array of plucky girls and women whose desires extend beyond romantic longing. Usually, they have adventures, and not just dreams, to go with their wasp waists and froufrou. Sometimes they save the day and their true love, which is better and more fun than waiting to be saved. Yet Disney heroines, whether princesses or not, have almost always ended up as reliably paired off as if they were boarding Noahâ€™s ark. A notable exception is Queen Elsa in â€œFrozen,â€ù a very different kind of heroine.

Ms. Jolie is, unsurprisingly, a visual marvel. Her face has been smoothed into an alabaster Cubist mask, and prostheses elongate her already sharp cheekbones; from some angles, it looks as if she had a second set of vestigial wings riding under her skin. The exquisite attention to detail in both the makeup and costume is routine in major productions like this one, of course, but the mixture of Old Hollywood glamour and contemporary fetishwear doesnâ€™t just turn Maleficent into a pleasurable spectacle, it also serves a character who embodies both the past and the future. Ms. Jolieâ€™s performance is similarly bifurcated, with a controlled physicality that, just when it seems to be edging into catwalk blankness, springs to weird life with grotesque facial contortions and spidery movements.

With its free-floating imagery, â€œElenaâ€ù unfolds like a cinematic dream whose central image is water, which symbolizes the washing away of grief. But more than that, it represents the stream of life, with beautiful images of women floating through time.

Petraâ€™s identification with Elena is so intense that the faces of the two sisters seem almost interchangeable, like the two women in Ingmar Bergmanâ€™s â€œPersona,â€ù one of them an actress (played by Liv Ullmann) suddenly gone mute, the other her nurse (Bibi Andersson), futilely trying to coax her out of a despair beyond words. Another classic film to which â€œElenaâ€ù indirectly refers is Alain Resnaisâ€™s â€œHiroshima Mon Amour,â€ù with its intermingled reflections on passion, time and historical trauma suggested by the mention of â€œHiroshima.â€ù

Petra, who was born in 1983, imagines a spiritual continuum in which personal and historical memory merge in a visual stream of consciousness. Throughout the movie, she addresses her sister as if she were speaking to a ghost. But at a certain point, â€œyouâ€ù is not just Elena, whose essence she tries to resurrect, but herself and her mother.

The film is a dense, impressionistic collage of accumulated fragments from home movies, newspaper clippings, diary entries and excerpts from letters, narrated by Ms. Costa in a tone of dreamy sadness. Her refusal to heed the advice of her mother, an elegant, sepulchral presence threaded through the film, suggests that Petra, like her sister, is an impulsive, volatile young woman, willfully tempting fate in her quest to conjure a sibling with whom she was very close as a young child. It is also an attempt to exorcise her own boundless grief and, in so doing, spare herself Elenaâ€™s tragic destiny.

â€œElenaâ€ù evokes the experience of three generations of Brazilian women. Elena was born in 1969 at the start of the dictatorship that drove many Brazilian artists into exile. Later she lost many friends in the dance world to the AIDS epidemic.

The title character of Petra Costaâ€™s poetic, intensely personal documentary essay, â€œElena,â€ù is her older sister, a Brazilian dancer and aspiring actress who settled in New York City and eventually committed suicide when Petra was 7. Years later, Petra, also an aspiring actress, followed in Elenaâ€™s footsteps and moved to New York to study theater at Columbia. â€œMy mother always said I could live anywhere in the world, except New York,â€ù she recalls. â€œI could choose any profession, except actress.â€ù

In the story, Bruce, told he is first in line for a promotion to chief inspector, sets out to destroy his rivals while halfheartedly trying to solve the murder shown in the movieâ€™s opening scene. Hoping to win back his estranged wife, Carole (Shauna Macdonald), he foolishly stops taking the lithium prescribed by his psychiatrist, Dr. Rossi (Jim Broadbent). Without his medication, he begins to lose what remains of his stability and starts hallucinating about people with animal heads. He seduces Bunty (Shirley Henderson), the ravenously lustful wife of his loyal best friend, Bladesy (Eddie Marsan), a meek accountant, while harassing her with menacing prank phone calls. He blackmails a 14-year-old girl into performing oral sex.

A major difference between Bruce and his wild-man forerunners is his raucous sense of humor, which lends him the dangerous charm of a boorish stand-up comedian you might enjoy from a back row of the theater, where the risk of being singled out is lowest. In one of the funniest scenes, he persuades his fellow detectives to photocopy images of their genitals and pass them around in a guessing game of which picture belongs to which officer. Because Bruce presses the enlarge button when his turn comes, a secretary who fancies him is eventually shocked to discover that he is smaller than advertised.
â€œFilthâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for frequent drug use and graphic nudity.

The haranguing tone of â€œFilth,â€ù whose title is Scottish slang for the police, causes the movie to lose its roughneck charm quickly. After a certain point, watching it is like listening to the ravings of an increasingly incoherent and abusive drunk. Further impeding enjoyment, the charactersâ€™ Scottish accents render swatches of the dialogue impenetrable.

Such is the electrical ferocity of Mr. McAvoyâ€™s performance that you can never again look at him the same way. At times, this pig in a china shop suggests a descendant of Alex from â€œA Clockwork Orange,â€ù and he is sometimes filmed as such, with distorting, wide-angle shots. A coke-crazed, booze-soaked sex fiend and sadomasochist obsessed with erotic asphyxiation, he is a ragingly homophobic, misogynistic bully, given to spewing torrents of profane abuse, sometimes accompanied by vomit. To help explain the character, the filmâ€™s director, Jon S. Baird, has made him clinically bipolar.

James McAvoy goes whole hog in â€œFilth,â€ù an adaptation of a 1998 novel by Irvine Welsh, the Scottish author of â€œTrainspotting.â€ù And by whole hog, I mean exactly that. His character, Bruce Robertson, who narrates the film, is an Edinburgh police detective sergeant on a catastrophic downward spiral. As he loses his sanity, he suggests a wounded wild boar on the rampage, dragging his entrails behind him as he charges around in circles. Compared with this maniac, the rotten policeman of two â€œBad Lieutenantâ€ù films is a garden-variety bad boy.

Mr. Bairdâ€™s visual imagination is more Terry Gilliam-goes-to-the-circus than the inside-the-toilet realism of Danny Boyleâ€™s â€œTrainspotting.â€ù The world as seen through Bruceâ€™s bloodshot eyes is a surreal phantasmagoria that grows more grotesque as his sanity deteriorates. The movie stops short of including one of the bookâ€™s voices: a talking tapeworm inside Bruceâ€™s body.

The film is a vehicle for Livia De Paolis, the director, who wrote it with Sarah Nerboso. She also stars as Elena, a woman in her 30s who is in a relationship with a man in his 60s, Walter (Michael Cristofer).

The new device-aided ways that people have of communicating may indeed turn out to be the defining evolutionary change of our era, but it will be years before we can assess what this has done to us as a species, and certainly this film isnâ€™t up to the task.

Walter has two adopted teenagers from a failed marriage; Elena is working on a Ph.D. that has something to do with communication in the social-media age; and no one can seem to hold a proper conversation face to face. But devices and apps magically bridge all chasms. The most intractable problems will vanish if you can just make a goofy video of yourself, your friend and your friendâ€™s mother doing a goofy dance.
Instead, with its underwritten characters (especially Walter) and scenes, it seems like a generic ABC Family plotline melded to a commercial for Facebook, Twitter and Skype.
Adoption, unexpected pregnancies, blended-family tensions, May-December relationships: â€œEmoticon ;)â€ù is stuffed with complexities. So why does it feel as facile as that irksome title?

How boring is a soldierâ€™s life in the mountains of Afghanistan during the lulls between firefights? A serviceman interviewed in â€œKorengal,â€ù the sequel to the 2010 documentary â€œRestrepo,â€ù recalls that one day he and his Army buddies spent â€œfive or six hoursâ€ù arguing who would win in a fight between George Clooney and Fabio.

A lot more bitterness is expressed in â€œKorengalâ€ù than in â€œRestrepo,â€ù which celebrated the â€œhighâ€ù of combat with a romantic exhilaration. One disillusioned soldier delivers an angry rebuttal to a common response to his post-combat anguish: â€œYou did what you had to do.â€ù In fact, he says, he had a choice; he didnâ€™t have to serve in Afghanistan. A black soldier muses about not feeling fully accepted by his brothers in arms because of his race. Thatâ€™s about as political as the movie gets. No one exalts patriotism, but no one explicitly criticizes the war.
As one soldier succinctly puts it, â€œIâ€™d go back there if I could.â€ù

The documentary, directed by Sebastian Junger, consists largely of interviews with men in a platoon that fought in the Korengal Valley of Afghanistan, where 42 Americans died before the United States military pulled out of the area in April 2010. Where a good part of â€œRestropoâ€ù was filmed in the heat of battle, â€œKorengalâ€ù is a collective meditation on military life by many of the same men, looking back on their time in Afghanistan. Mr. Jungerâ€™s co-director on â€œRestrepo,â€ù the British-American photojournalist Tim Hetherington, who shot much of the early footage in â€œKorengal,â€ù died in 2011 while covering the Libyan civil war.

The sequel is much more than a collection of outtakes from the first film, augmented by footage shot later. It consists mostly of a series of extended interviews with the soldiers. As the camera goes from one to another and then back, the men, photographed in extreme close-up, describe in dispassionate tones the mixture of fear and exhilaration that made combat the most intense experience they had ever known. The brotherhood of men facing death is a bond that eclipses even family ties in its intensity. More than one soldier declares he would gladly die to save one of his fellow combatants.

Many of the soldiers interviewed feel empty. They miss the camaraderie of men who lived together 24 hours a day and depended on one another for survival. They miss the adrenaline of battle and the excitement of having â€œcheated death.â€ù

The redoubtable Dane Mads Mikkelsen embodies Michael Kohlhaas as a strapping, bronzed specimen whose very lovemaking is accompanied by extravagant compliments from his wife. But then a bratty young baron (Swann Arlaud) confiscates two of his horses and quashes his attempts at legal redress, which are made with the help of a cowed lawyer played by Jacques Nolot. (The cast also includes Bruno Ganz, Sergi LÃ_pez, Amira Casar and, as a priestly interloper, Denis Lavant.) With the violence hitting close to home, Kohlhaas and his team invade the baronâ€™s castle on a stealthy assassination mission resembling a modern military covert op, crossbows wielded like assault rifles.

Brooding and intransigent, â€œAge of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaasâ€ù undertakes a brave and foolhardy act, not unlike the prideful horse merchant of the title. Its striking story of rebellion in an age of aristocracy is set in 16th-century France, adapted from a 19th-century novella by Heinrich von Kleist, a text ripe for reappraisal. But the severely beautiful film is painted in a dauntingly austere manner, as if lost in a war against itself, with confrontations underplayed and the rural landscapes making more of an impression than the detoured drama.

Revenge is a dish served rather coolly, however, by the director, Arnaud des PalliÃ¨res (who previously adapted a John Cheever story with his 2008 film, â€œParcâ€ù). At every other turn where the film might flesh out or complicate its themes, it seems to purposely look astray, weighed down by gloom and an oddly slack performance by Mr. Mikkelsen (perhaps by direction). But alongside these problems are nice little tweaks on horse-and-tunic period dramas: the galling youth of the slight-looking baron and a princess (Roxane Duran) who figures later, and the ambiguous position of class occupied by Kohlhaas as a trader.

The story could have been played up for heroic martyrdom, but Mr. des PalliÃ¨res takes his dour film in another direction. Although he makes enervating choices (of focus, of adaptation) that undercut the curiosity of the filmâ€™s portrait of failure, he has managed to leave an impact by underlining the smallness of resistance in the face of entrenched power.

The three would-be eco-terrorists are troubled by smaller matters as well, notably the sexual tension, already present between Josh and Dena, that pulls tighter once they arrive at Harmonâ€™s place. The three main performances are flawless; you get a clear sense of each characterâ€™s personality, including each oneâ€™s capacity to be unpredictable.

Realism is too imprecise a term for Kelly Reichardtâ€™s filmmaking. She is a more of a materialist, determined to capture how the world looks, how it feels and, at a granular level of detail, how it works. Her stories tend to be simple and starkly told. In â€œOld Joy,â€ù two friends take a camping trip that tests their intimacy and raises painful, unspoken questions about their identities as 21st-century American men. In â€œWendy and Lucy,â€ù a young woman and her dog are stranded by car trouble en route to Alaska. In â€œMeekâ€™s Cutoff,â€ù settlers in mid-19th-century Oregon lose their way.
