While Ms. Reichardt (who wrote the screenplay with Jon Raymond, her frequent writing partner) keeps your attention fixed on the procedural elements of the plot, she also invites you to think about other matters. The three conspirators are unwavering in their conviction, but conversations around the table at the family farm where Josh harvests cabbage articulate some of the filmâ€™s ethical themes. So does the juxtaposition of the rhythms of agricultural labor and beauty of the Northwestern landscape with the standardized drabness of parking lots and big-box stores.

Still, it is hard to leave the theater unshaken, and hard to shake the memory of Ms. Fanningâ€™s blend of openness and cunning, Mr. Sarsgaardâ€™s bluff nervousness or Mr. Eisenbergâ€™s brooding, inarticulate silence. You may not be able to figure out what Josh, Dena and Harmon really want, but it would be dangerous to ignore them.

What seems to unite Josh, Dena and Harmon â€” and to cause Josh particular anguish â€” is the longing to find some other way to live. The glimpses of the modern agrarian counterculture have a rough, unassuming authenticity, but the film presents an Arcadia haunted by anxiety, by the unseen but atmospherically palpable specters of climate change, government interference and big money.
â€œNight Movesâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language and hot-tub nudity.

Josh (Jesse Eisenberg) works on an organic farm in Oregon, not far from the town where Dena (Dakota Fanning) works in a New Age spa. They donâ€™t belong to any larger organization but rather seem to be part of a loose movement that seeks to counter corporate power and ecological destruction through local, uncoordinated acts. Their only other comrade is Harmon (Peter Sarsgaard), a friend of Joshâ€™s who lives in a trailer in the woods closer to their target.

They are not necessarily admirable â€” it is not unreasonable to conclude that they are in fact very stupid â€” but the lostness of these young people makes it hard not to care about them. (The same was true of Michelle Williamsâ€™s character in â€œWendy and Lucy.â€ù) In following the logic of their action, however, the movie loses its own way a bit. Ms. Reichardtâ€™s plots are blessedly austere, and it is a little too perverse to say that the problem with this modestly scaled movie is that too much happens. But some of the climactic turns seem to follow the kind of narrative rules that this film, and this filmmaker, have otherwise defied.

As in most good crime movies, a lot of suspense is generated by planning and preparation. Josh and Dena drive out to the suburbs to buy the power boat whose name gives the movie its title and later, with Harmon, try to buy a large quantity of ammonium nitrate fertilizer for their bomb. The audience is in a familiar and by no means unpleasant state of ambivalent dread. Because you canâ€™t help empathizing in some way with the people you see on screen, you root for them to succeed, even as the danger and senselessness of their action make you hope otherwise.

â€œNight Moves,â€ù Ms. Reichardtâ€™s sharp and haunting new feature, comes closer than its predecessors to fitting into an established genre. (If â€œMeekâ€™s Cutoffâ€ù was a western, it was one that shot down every frontier clichÃ© in its path.) This one can be described as a thriller with political overtones, about three radical environmentalists plotting to blow up a dam. Their motives, while not fully articulated â€” there is never a lot of talking in a Kelly Reichardt movie â€” seem to be a mixture of despair, muddled idealism and boredom. Their seriousness is unquestionable, but the film is less interested in assessing the justice of their cause than in probing the contours of their experience.

Charlize Theron plays Anna, the abused, gunslinging wife of Clinch Leatherwood (Liam Neeson), a notorious outlaw and leader of a gang that robs stagecoaches. â€œA Million Ways to Die in the Westâ€ù seems serious about only one thing: its contempt for the gun-crazed macho ethos exalted in countless Hollywood westerns. You might call the movie â€œRevenge of the Ãœbernerd.â€ù

Like Hope, Mr. MacFarlane implies that mischief can turn into mayhem at any second without letting his shell of bonhomie crack. â€œA Million Ways to Die in the Westâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for scatological humor.

You canâ€™t blame Seth MacFarlane, that one-man comedy juggernaut, for wanting to add movie star to his list of credentials. After all, he has succeeded beyond any sane personâ€™s wildest dreams at building a comedy empire by holding a stinky finger to the racing pulse of the collective id.

â€œThe Hornetâ€™s Nestâ€ù lets its soldiers do most of the talking. The action â€” the rapid fire of automatic weapons, the crack of a sniperâ€™s shot, the medevac rescues â€” is vivid. â€œThe Hornetâ€™s Nestâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for profanity and scenes of combat.

First Mr. Boettcher, who has covered war zones for 34 years, and his son Carlos spend a year in country, filing stories about I.E.D. detonations and search-and-clear operations, surviving firefights in the process. Shortly after Carlos departs, Strong Eagle III commences.

â€œThe Grand Seductionâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for harmless sexual innuendo and drug references.

And so they decide to start their own band, only slightly discouraged by the fact that neither plays an instrument. Klara, a cherubic Sid Vicious with a homemade Mohawk, picks up the bass. â€œWe Are the Best!â€ù is honest in just that way. It is also fun, which may come as something of a relief to those who endured Mr. Moodyssonâ€™s recent explorations â€” some of them quite powerful (â€œLilya 4-Everâ€ù), some muddled and misguided (â€œMammothâ€ù) â€” of the worldâ€™s misery and injustice. Life is not entirely fair to Bobo and Klara, but their protest is a source (and a form) of exultation. When Bobo is feeling blue, Klara cheers her up by reminding her that sheâ€™s part of â€œthe greatest band in the world.â€ù No argument here.

Mr. Moodysson, who adapted â€œWe Are the Best!â€ù from â€œNever Goodnight,â€ù  a graphic novel by his wife, Coco, clearly loves music, and sprinkles the soundtrack with the work of obscure (at least to this former â€™80s-vintage teenage punk fan) Swedish bands. More important, he loves the youthful urge to make noise. He captures the peculiar intensity of post-â€™60s, pre-iPod musical devotion: the avid acquisition of LPs and fanzines; the dogmatic pleasure of hating one band and worshiping another (and then switching sides with equal dogmatism); the way a song could make your own private discontent feel like a grand historical cause.

There is hardly a shortage of movies about rock â€™nâ€™ roll, but there are few as perfect â€” which is to say as ragged, as silly, as touching or as true â€” as â€œWe Are the Best!,â€ù Lukas Moodyssonâ€™s sweet and rambunctious new film. The setting is Stockholm in 1982, hardly a legendary place or moment in the annals of modern music, but thatâ€™s kind of the point. Rock â€™nâ€™ roll glory is wherever you find it, and whatever you make of it.

Not that there is anything conventional about Mr. Moodyssonâ€™s style, which is wild, speedy and wonderfully subtle. He trusts the characters â€” and the three amazing young actresses who play them â€” to carry the emotions as his camera zigzags through their daily lives, picking up odd details and scraps of off-the-cuff comedy. A lot of the post-punk music of the early â€™80s (some people called it New Wave, but those were fighting words) was fast, loud and unruly, but it was also embraced for its clarity and lack of pretension. The bands you cared about would never lie to you.

But anyone who has been in a band long enough to fight over what its name should be knows that harmony is elusive. Bobo and Klaraâ€™s friendship, an immutable fact at the start of the movie, is tested and disrupted, first by the arrival of Hedvig and then by their rivalry for the affection of a cute boy punk who lives in another town. We see most of the drama from Boboâ€™s point of view â€” her introspective, melancholy manner makes her a natural magnet for audience empathy â€” and, to some degree, the film takes on the contours of a conventional coming-of-age story. As she makes her way through the school year, Bobo learns something about herself, about friendship, about her parents and also about how to keep the beat (even if sheâ€™d rather be playing bass).

Bobo (Mira Barkhammar) and Klara (Mira Grosin), two 13-year-old best friends, are belated would-be punk rockers tired of hearing that punk is dead, and frustrated with just about everything else. The popular kids at school sneer at their unconventional clothes. Boys are insulting or indifferent, other girls even worse. Nobody at home â€” Klara lives with her parents and two siblings; Bobo with her sad, divorced mother (Anna Rydgren) â€” understands them. The rehearsal room at the local youth center is dominated by Iron Fist, a heavy-metal band whose sludgy grooves give the girls a headache.

Like â€œTogetherâ€ù  (2001), Mr. Moodyssonâ€™s generous, acute anatomy of the 1970s Swedish counterculture, â€œWe Are the Best!â€ù feels less like a nostalgic period piece than like a messy, urgent bulletin from a time that is barely past. Klara, Bobo and Hedvig are creatures of their own present in the way that only adolescents can be. Anything or anyone older, whether itâ€™s Klaraâ€™s well-meaning, clarinet-playing father or the shaggy, dim hippies who run the youth center, is a puzzle or an impediment. The girlsâ€™ gestures of rebellion can be absurd and obnoxious, but they are also inspiring. Klara, in particular, has the exuberant, righteous self-confidence of a true revolutionary.

The stories of these three and others are narrated by the characters themselves, who speak directly to the camera in a casual round-robin style with minimal self-dramatization. Their monologues are interspersed with scenes from their lives.

Partly because the three main characters are involved in the art world, the relationship between art and life in their stories is intensely interactive. Arman and Benjamin talk about movies with the same excitement as 1960s college students infatuated with art films, and the work of Robert Bresson, Alain Tanner and even Judd Apatow is dissected. The movie includes a mini-essay on the photographs of Edvard Munch and a clip from Mr. Tannerâ€™s early-â€™70s film â€œThe Salamander.â€ù

Peripheral characters also have their say. After recovering from his stroke, Benjamin becomes romantically involved with his physical therapist, Katia (Audrey Bastien). His younger sister, Lucie (Pauline Etienne), joins a New Age commune.

The most extreme minor character is Katiaâ€™s cousin Jan (Thomas Blanchard), a Goth rebel who identifies with Ian Curtis of the British band Joy Division. As he dispassionately describes his suicide attempts, his stay in an asylum and his unstable, obsessional relationship with a girlfriend, the movie withholds any suggestion of judgment.

By having the characters speak mostly for themselves in everyday voices, the movie has a quasidocumentary feel. The use of the first-person singular is also a shortcut to familiarity, so that, by the end, you feel that you really know Arman, who is good-hearted, intellectually engaged and has an unshakable core of decency. And we see that AmÃ©lie is smart and attractive but emotionally self-protective and ambivalent.

â€œ2 Autumns, 3 Wintersâ€ù has the stylistic mannerisms of many vintage New Waves films, including a freewheeling use of cinema technology. The movie is divided into two parts. Every scene is prefaced by a title, as though part of a book with chapters and subheadings. This pseudostructure helps organize what might otherwise feel chaotic and scatterbrained. But it also calls attention to the disorderliness of lives that change in unexpected ways.

Life doesnâ€™t proceed as methodically as in the screenplay of a skillfully plotted commercial film. Unforeseen events interrupt the flow and destroy the symmetry. The randomness of life and the capriciousness of human nature were recurrent motifs in French New Wave movies of the 1960s and â€™70s. And in â€œ2 Autumns, 3 Winters,â€ù the Gallic filmmaker SÃ©bastien Betbederâ€™s breezy, lighthearted homage to the films of Jean-Luc Godard and others, fate keeps stepping in to alter the destinies of its three principal characters, Arman (Vincent Macaigne), Benjamin (Bastien Bouillon) and AmÃ©lie (Maud Wyler).

The scruffy, shaggy-haired Arman, a 33-year-old endearingly played by Mr. Macaigne, meets AmÃ©lie, 27, by chance in Paris when they are jogging in opposite directions and he bumps into her. They meet again one evening, when AmÃ©lie is grabbed on the street by two thugs, and Arman, who happens to be passing by, recognizes her and intervenes. The attackers flee, but not before stabbing him, and he nearly dies. They fall in love during her visits to him in the hospital.

The voluble, happy-go-lucky Benjamin, Armanâ€™s best friend from art school, hasnâ€™t been sick a day in his life until he is suddenly felled by a stroke and finds himself face down in a hedge, unable to move or speak until a skateboarder stumbles over him.

The wistful, overarching theme is the passing of time in the lives of young adults, aware of growing older, who seek to ground themselves in relationships and work, but relationships most of all. The movie reminds you with a series of gentle nudges that whether you want it to or not, the future happens.

Scattered throughout are moments that stick out like provocations (such as an excerpt from a conservative lecture that sounds anti-Semitic), some juicy clandestine recordings and too many protest sign montages. Itâ€™s a hodgepodge that Michael Moore (whose movies Ms. Lessin and Mr. Deal have produced) and his editors might snappily dice together, but here the construction falls short.

The limits of what an individual can do in the face of well-financed opposition are shown throughout Tia Lessin and Carl Dealâ€™s film, a jumbled look at the effects of the Citizens United Supreme Court case through the lens of Wisconsinâ€™s recent history. The filmmakers weave together the attempt to recall Gov. Scott Walker over his aggressive stance on unions and other issues; glimpses of Americans for Prosperity and the Tea Party movement; and the campaign of Buddy Roemer for the Republican presidential nomination in 2012. But their movie, which starts off shakily, is naggingly diffuse and bumps up against the problem of recounting the freshly remembered past.

Part of the impact of â€œCitizen Kochâ€ù comes from juxtaposing average Americans with the moneyed interests that grip todayâ€™s political process. When we see a Republican in Wisconsin weighing her dissatisfaction with her party and her stance on abortion, itâ€™s an inspiring sight of a citizen at work, grappling in good faith with the situation at hand. Itâ€™s a world away from the documentaryâ€™s portrayal of Americans for Prosperity, the conservative advocacy group funded by the billionaires David and Charles Koch.

Eventually Borgman leaves, only to return clean-shaven and unrecognized. Having murdered the coupleâ€™s gardener and dumped the corpse â€” its head stuck in a bucket of cement â€” into a lake, he talks his way into a job as the gardenerâ€™s replacement and enlists two sinister assistants who begin tearing up the lawn. Once this scowling sorcerer casts spells on the children and their nanny (Sara Hjort Ditlevsen), the film evokes that fable of ultimate revenge, â€œThe Pied Piper of Hamelin.â€ù â€œBorgmanâ€ù is all the more disturbing for not offering a clear reason for the behavior of Borgman and his tribe. Of the many comparisons that come to mind, the most obvious is Michael Hanekeâ€™s â€œFunny Games,â€ù a sadistic joke on moviegoers in which the unspeakable violence remains just off the screen. â€œBorgmanâ€ù also makes you feel that you are being toyed with by a directorial trickster. â€œBorgmanâ€ù wears just enough of a smirk to suggest that it might be a dark satire about class warfare. Richard, a successful businessman obsessed with office politics, is an unapologetic racist who refuses to consider hiring a nonwhite applicant for the gardening job. There is no one who resembles a sleeping princess, a fairy godmother or a dashing romantic savior in the Dutch filmmaker Alex van Warmerdamâ€™s malevolent adult fairy tale, â€œBorgman.â€ù The storyâ€™s magic is black, its perfidy driven by evil spirits.

The film builds up a heavy sense of dread as Borgman begins controlling the minds of Richard and his family, aided by potions he furtively slips into glasses of water and wine. Sometimes he is accompanied to the main house by two obedient hounds that suggest creatures from the underworld.

The title character (Jan Bijvoet) is a scrawny, beady-eyed vagabond who lives underground but is forced out of his lair when a manhunt led by a priest drives him and several fellow groundlings from their burrows. At last itâ€™s come along: the â€œReefer Madnessâ€ù of gay rights. In D M W Greerâ€™s supposed drama â€œBurning Blue,â€ù a military official worries aloud that if man-on-man sex among its fighter pilots is not punished severely, the Navy could be perceived as being run by a â€œperverse cult.â€ù

The script, by Mr. Greer and Helene Kvale, rolls along with lifeless, profoundly unimaginative dialogue (â€œThe wings on your chest are proof that youâ€™ve accomplished something greatâ€ù; â€œI like womenâ€ù; â€œIâ€™m not gayâ€ù; â€œTears wonâ€™t bring him backâ€ù; â€œNo more liesâ€ù). â€œBurning Blueâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Cursing sailors, a sexual foursome and a recurring nudie photograph.

Mr. Shavitz, the film tells us again and again, continues to live a spartan life by choice and doesnâ€™t much care that he missed out on the big payday. But when â€œBurtâ€™s Buzzâ€ù actually addresses the split between Mr. Shavitz and Ms. Quimby in a maddeningly vague stretch, itâ€™s clear that the story and Mr. Shavitzâ€™s feelings are not so simple. The film leaves the impression that itâ€™s telling the version of its subjectâ€™s life that he wants us to hear.

The film is about Burt Shavitz, a scruffy-looking beekeeper who founded the Burtâ€™s Bees line of personal care products with Roxanne Quimby in Maine in the 1980s. She eventually bought him out, and in 2007 she sold the business to the Clorox Company for $913 million.

The word â€œiconâ€ù is given quite a workout in â€œBurtâ€™s Buzz,â€ù a documentary about the man whose likeness adorns Burtâ€™s Bees products. Itâ€™s to the filmâ€™s detriment. Not only is the word overused these days, but it also has no business being applied to a pitchman for a product line that may have fans but is hardly a dominant cultural force. The film, by Jody Shapiro, seems so hagiographic that when it finally gets around to its 20 minutesâ€™ worth of interesting stuff, youâ€™re not sure whether to trust it.

Via Sunnyâ€™s friendship with the villagers â€” particularly a fellow cinephile (Inaamulhaq) who sells pirated films â€” â€œFilmistaanâ€ù gradually morphs into a serious disquisition on Indo-Pakistani relations and the lingering animus from the nationsâ€™ 1947 partition. The shift toward politics retroactively gives â€œFilmistaanâ€ù some bite, though international rifts are probably beyond the reach of movies to heal.

Teetering somewhere between audacious and offensive, the stylistically voracious â€œFilmistaanâ€ù only intermittently reveals any sense of danger in its comedy. The director, Nitin Kakkar, alternates gallows humor (Sunny attempts to direct his own ransom video) with sappier interludes, as when our hero provides live dialogue after the audio fails during a village screening of the 1989 hit â€œMaine Pyar Kiya.â€ù

â€œFilmistaanâ€ù celebrates the power of cinema to bridge divides, but the mirth doesnâ€™t entirely travel in this Bollywood production about an aspiring actor, Sunny (Sharib Hashmi), who is kidnapped by Pakistani militants. While the film mixes genres in the inimitable Bollywood style, that premise, at least, is played for laughs.

Working in a border region as an assistant director on a documentary, Sunny is taken hostage by a group of extremists who think they have bagged a member of the American media. Comparing his camera equipment with his abductorsâ€™ guns, the ebullient Sunny tries to highlight the similarities in their professions. â€œYou shoot; we also shoot,â€ù he explains. â€œYou use magazines; so do we.â€ù

But there are so many others. Oliviaâ€™s father leaves. Her grandfather, a tribal chief, sides with the rapist. Even her mother doubts her (â€œIf I had been there, I would know.â€ù) and does the wrong thing. A driver declares her â€œuseless, useless.â€ù Some women who work at the hospital seem compassionate, but others reveal hard hearts. Like many women in the film, they are horrifyingly cavalier about the male culture that endorses this behavior. Raping a child, we are told, is considered a good-luck move.
â€œThey do it for ritual purpose,â€ù a gender-violence specialist says. â€œTo get money, to get a job.â€ù

Looking into Oliviaâ€™s huge brown eyes, full of hope despite everything, and then into so many adultsâ€™ cold, dead ones (and the camera does, bravely and pointedly) is appalling. There is no gore here, and no on-screen violence, but this is in every way a horror movie. With a devastating ending.

Looking for a villain in Jessica Valeâ€™s documentary? Thereâ€™s competition. Obviously, in â€œSmall Small Thing: The Olivia Zinnah Story,â€ù about a 7-year-old rape victim in Liberia, there is the man who attacked her so brutally that her genitals were mangled and covered in scar tissue. He was a 20-year-old cousin. She was left with a fistula requiring numerous surgeries to repair, if it could be fixed at all.

Alfred Hitchcock disliked whodunits; he felt viewers became too bound up in guessing the solution. That principle holds true for the director Jane Weinstockâ€™s â€œThe Moment,â€ù a psychological thriller that shrouds its mysteries in layers of hallucination and unreliable narration.

Yet the conceit â€” a photographer can no longer trust what she sees â€” seems too pat to undergird a work of genuine surrealism. The plot device of a therapist (Marianne Jean-Baptiste) who helps Lee discover the truth and resolve lingering guilt over being an absent parent (Alia Shawkat plays Leeâ€™s daughter) grounds the proceedings in conventionality.

As flashbacks that are progressively less withholding unfold, the experience of watching the movie becomes a kind of parlor game: Is Lee capable of murder? Which moment is the moment? Disorientation is a double-edged sword, especially when the ostensible reorientation is as unsatisfying as it is here.

Ms. Weinstock signals narrative slipperiness early on, with shifting focus and a hand-held camera. The use of doubling calls to mind more elegant films by David Lynch. (Surely itâ€™s not coincidental that John has had a car accident on Mulholland Drive.)

Lee (Jennifer Jason Leigh), a war photographer who has grown unstable since she survived a suicide bombing in Somalia, strips naked at an art show and turns mute after her ex-boyfriend, John (Martin Henderson), goes missing. At a psychiatric hospital, she meets a patient (also Mr. Henderson) who resembles her old flame, down to his tattoo. The new relationship begins to mirror the earlier one, which began in an institution.

A commercial romantic comedy might have overplayed the contrasts between Donna and Max, treating them as members of opposing tribes rather than as people who pursued different majors at equally expensive colleges. The narrowness of their milieu â€” yes, Brooklyn, again â€” makes â€œObvious Childâ€ù feel both claustrophobic and accurate. People with nothing better to do than dream up anti-Lena Dunham think pieces will have a field day with this movie, and also miss the point. Looked at from the right angle, the quirks and contradictions of Donnaâ€™s personality â€” the way she zigzags between entitlement and disappointment, laziness and ambition, wisdom and idiocy â€” illuminate an actual social condition.
â€œObvious Childâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Intensive discussion of the human excretory and reproductive systems.

The obstacles between them are a series of misunderstandings and bad decisions (mostly Donnaâ€™s) and, of course, the unintended consequences of their early, alcohol-assisted hookup. For most of the movie, Max is unaware of Donnaâ€™s pregnancy, and the quandary she finds herself in â€” Should she tell him? How? And then what? â€” reflects the challenges Ms. Robespierre and Ms. Slate have set for themselves. Donnaâ€™s situation might have been mined for ugly, trivializing humor or pious pathos, and â€œObvious Childâ€ù could have turned out either obnoxiously silly or insufferably earnest. Itâ€™s both funny and serious without trying too hard to be either, and by trying above all to be honest.

Like many young and youngish comedians, Donna is partial to the word â€œvaginaâ€ù and more than willing to make jokes about hers and about adjacent parts of her anatomy. This talk is sometimes a little gross, in a childish kind of way, but too friendly (and often too funny) to be really offensive. And the genital theme is hardly irrelevant, since the dramatic axle on which this agreeable, observant movie spins is Donnaâ€™s accidental pregnancy and its subsequent termination.

â€œObvious Childâ€ù treads more cautiously over the landscape of modern urban womanhood than some of its television sisters. Itâ€™s tidier than â€œBroad Cityâ€ù and less abrasive than â€œGirls,â€ù partly because a neat, traditional rom-com heart beats within its unkempt, sarcastic exterior. One of its most charming and authentic attributes is the easy, semi-awkward rapport that clicks into place between Donna and Max, who clearly like each other a lot without quite knowing how to proceed.

Which is not to say that everything in â€œObvious Child,â€ù which takes its name from a lovely Paul Simon song, is played for laughs. Donna may be a person who turns every moment into the occasion for a wisecrack (or at least a silly facial expression), but she is also sensitive, earnest and more than a little needy. After she is dumped by her boyfriend (Paul Briganti), she seeks comfort from her artistic father (Richard Kind), her businesslike mother (Polly Draper) and her tough-minded feminist roommate (Gaby Hoffmann). She also has a night of rebound sex with a nice guy named Max (Jake Lacy), whose clean-shaven face and penchant for oxford-cloth button-downs and deck shoes make him an exotic creature in scruffy, plaid-flannel Williamsburg.

Even liberals may balk at the idea of a comedy about an abortion, but Ms. Robespierre, making her feature directing debut (expanded from an earlier short), is more matter-of-fact than provocative in her approach to the issue. There have been a handful of comedies â€” â€œJunoâ€ù and â€œKnocked Up,â€ù most notably â€” about women who choose not to end their unexpected pregnancies, so why assume that the other side of the coin is off limits? Like it or not, abortion is a fact in many womenâ€™s lives and therefore as available for humorous treatment as any other aspect of human experience.

We first encounter Donna Stern, the 28-ish heroine of Gillian Robespierreâ€™s â€œObvious Child,â€ù doing standup in a ratty Brooklyn club, putting her own idiosyncratic spin on the currently popular style of boundaryless, confessional, body-conscious humor. Donna is played by Jenny Slate, whose rÃ©sumÃ© (â€œSaturday Night Live,â€ù â€œParks and Recreation,â€ù â€œBobâ€™s Burgersâ€ù) reads like a Google map of the modern comic universe and who easily juggles the sweet and nasty sides of her temperament.

Thought and feeling are never far apart in the films of Marco Bellocchio. From his precocious beginnings in the 1960s with â€œFists in the Pocketâ€ù and â€œChina Is Near,â€ù Mr. Bellocchio, now 74, has explored weighty ideas â€” about Italian society and politics, about the struggle between faith and secularism in the modern world, about authority, idealism and sexual desire â€” with passionate, at times melodramatic, ardor.

Each section of the narrative circles around the issues raised by the Englaro case, sometimes landing with a loud, schematic clatter as voices are raised and positions staked out. As often happens in multiplotted movies, there are structural problems. The emotional power of specific scenes and situations is lost in a welter of detail.

His native country has provided him with plenty of material, and he has dealt with painful public episodes like Mussoliniâ€™s rise (â€œVincereâ€ù) and the terrorism of the Red Brigades in the 1970s (â€œGood Morning, Nightâ€ù) with ethical rigor and disarming empathy. His 2012 movie, â€œDormant Beauty,â€ù which opens on Friday in New York, draws on the case of Eluana Englaro, a woman who died in February 2009 after having been in a vegetative state for nearly 17 years. Her fatherâ€™s decision to remove her feeding tube and allow her to die was supported by the Italian courts and opposed by the Vatican and the prime minister at the time, Silvio Berlusconi. Ms. Englaroâ€™s fate, like Terri Schiavoâ€™s in the United States a few years earlier, became the subject of a furious and divisive national debate.

Mr. Bellocchio uses the climactic days of the controversy â€” as protesters gather outside a hospital in Udine, and Parliament gathers to vote on emergency legislation â€” to perform a kind of CT scan on the Italian republic and some of its citizens. He follows three sets of characters whose struggles mirror the larger drama that is playing out on ubiquitous television screens. A senator (Toni Servillo) finds himself caught between his conscience and the demands of party loyalty. His daughter (Alba Rohrwacher) has joined the anti-right-to-die protesters and struck up a romance with a young man from the other side. An actress (Isabelle Huppert) follows the Englaro story as her own daughter lies in a coma. A young doctor (Michele Riondino) tries to save an addict (Maya Sansa) who desperately wants to die.

But if â€œDormant Beautyâ€ù does not rank among Mr. Bellocchioâ€™s best movies, it nonetheless still occasionally shows him at his best. His eye for the latent beauty and evident absurdity of Italian life remains acute, as does his appreciation for vivid performance. His cast, made up of some of todayâ€™s finest Italian screen actors (plus the incomparable Ms. Huppert), is never dull, even when the story is less than convincing.

Mr. Voss delivers his dispatches from a ghostly trading floor in an empty Frankfurt high-rise as if he were an archaeologist recounting the fall of a civilization. With Teutonic analysis and a former Young Turkâ€™s prerogative, he bestows a sweeping lowdown: the liberalization in the German banking industry, the fine line between salesmanship and malfeasance, a step-by-step for strong-arming a country like Greece, the nursery school shared by Deutsche Bank families.

The camera pans restlessly, showing us steely-gray lattice views of the business district and cutting away to a big-screen television showing congressional testimony on the financial crisis from the United States. Mr. Voss speaks calmly, and not without some nostalgia, but betraying frustration with the social conformity and sacrifice of his profession. He talks around the deepest wound, an evident distance from his family because of his long hours.

In â€œThe Wolf of Wall Street,â€ù Jordan Belfort cuts short an explanation of his work, because, he says, we probably couldnâ€™t follow the details. â€œMaster of the Universeâ€ù attempts that explanation but offers a sobering antidote to irrational exuberance and a psychological case study in the financierâ€™s mind-set. This indefatigable tell-all documentary from Marc Bauder cedes the floor to Rainer Voss, a German ex-trader who tells us with clarity about how it all works.

Mr. Bauderâ€™s film works more through the steady accumulation of knowledge than, say, the culture-jamming dissections of the German filmmaker Harun Farocki (â€œHow to Live in the German Federal Republicâ€ù). His visual scheme, wrapped in a murmuring electronic score, doesnâ€™t escape monotony. But he touches on the equally hermetic and vulgar aura surrounding such blinkered pursuit of wealth. Mr. Vossâ€™s metaphors pile up helplessly: Finance is like being in the army, like catching a virus and as hard to grasp as quantum particles. The film in which he appears is a vertiginous look inside the bubble behind the financial bubble, with no end in sight.

From its revenge-of-the-nerd narrative to its soaked-in-nostalgia style, â€œPing Pong Summerâ€ù revisits the 1980s with such slavish affection that you suspect its writer and director, Michael Tully, of being notably transformed during those boom-box-blighted years. The film fairly beams with the afterglow of lost virginity.

Whatever the case, this gentle comedy, while entirely unmemorable, releases a genuine warmth that deflects harsh judgment. It doesnâ€™t, however, excuse characters that are little more than props for embarrassing fashion or delivery systems for dated slang. When you have the good fortune to snag Susan Sarandon for a role in a project led largely by young unknowns, then give her little to do beyond skulk in the background and brandish a dead fish, you canâ€™t complain if her moment of glory is anticlimactic.

While displaying none of the caustic originality that characterized his previous films, Mr. Tully nevertheless adheres to a pattern of over-the-top devotion to his subject, whether it be the Florida drug addict of â€œCocaine Angelâ€ù (2007) or the monstrous backwoods family of the less successful â€œSeptienâ€ù (2011). Here, though, his sincerity canâ€™t compensate for a limp hero and a lifeless plot; the attention to detail is impressive, but even parachute pants need somewhere interesting to go.

But Mr. Tully is less interested in climax than in reconstructing teen-movie formula through a deeply personal lens. Unfolding during a seaside vacation in Ocean City, Md., in the summer of 1985, the movie watches indulgently as 13-year-old Rad (Marcello Conte) makes a new friend (Myles Massey, a standout), squares off against two entitled bullies and gawkily woos a local hottie with a sugar addiction.

Captured on Super 16-millimeter film by Wyatt Garfield, these daily dawdlings have the fuzzy-faded look of a vintage postcard, so itâ€™s a shame that much of the action is confined to a dreary game room where the titular sport is perfected. Released to the beach or amusement park, Mr. Garfieldâ€™s camera is happier by far: A visit to Radâ€™s sun-worshiping Aunt Peggy (the scene thief Amy Sedaris) finds it poking cheekily around her tan lines with a perkiness that the rest of the film sorely lacks.

From there, the story line frays into several haunted-apartment-house subplots. The main one concerns a kindly old seamstress (the Hong Kong mainstay Nina Paw, quite good) who, after her husband dies, uses black magic to resurrect him and grows murderous in the process.

Ostensibly in homage, â€œRigor Mortisâ€ù stars Chin Siu-Ho â€” who played one of the main characters in â€œMr. Vampireâ€ù â€” as a defeated, despairing horror film actor, also named Chin Siu-Ho, who moves into a crumbling apartment complex with suicide on his agenda. But this relentlessly creepy film takes its horror straight and contains little comedy. The closest it comes is when Chin tries to hang himself: An evil spirit inhabits him, drawing the attention of Yau (Anthony Chan, also from â€œMr. Vampireâ€ù), apparently the complexâ€™s exorcist. Several other residents cluster around Chinâ€™s door to watch him vomit the spiritâ€™s remains. Welcome, neighbor.

In the 1980s, Hong Kong cinema came up with its own version of a comic monster movie. It was no â€œGhostbusters,â€ù but â€œMr. Vampire,â€ù mixing traditional Chinese folk tales of â€œhopping vampiresâ€ù with action and humor, proved successful, spawning numerous sequels.

It all leads to a battle pitting Chin and Yau against a crew of paranormal adversaries. Though technically a polished directorial debut by Juno Mak, the film bears the stamp of one of its producers: Takashi Shimizu, who directed â€œThe Grudgeâ€ù and its sequels. Applying ghoulish special effects and atmospheric slow pacing, the film also maintains a dark palette of blacks, browns and ash grays, the better to serve as a backdrop when the blood starts spattering.
â€œSupermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordonâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for the kind of tales that come from hanging out with rock stars.

Late in the film, Mr. Myers acknowledges a debt of kindness to Mr. Gordon, who let him crash at his Maui house during a rough stretch, and the entire film looks and feels bathed in a glow. Mr. Gordon, a Long Island-raised broker of talent, access and shtick, did a not uncommon post-1960s California shuffle from loose-limbed, drug-inflected existence to savvy salesman with a magic touch.

A valentine from one friend to another, â€œSupermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordonâ€ù is not entirely kidding about that title, or at least its tone. Directed by the comedian Mike Myers, this clubby documentary lauds the swellness and shrewdness of the talent manager Shep Gordon with the help of celebrities and the sunnily mellifluent subject himself.

Mr. Gordon is likable, though it would be naÃ¯ve to think he is unaware of cultivating his own image here. His ability to connect people and represent clients is evidently world-class, as is his kindness to friends. But some viewers just might balk at being expected to marvel at his pushing Mr. Cooper up the music charts, much less his developing the cursedly enduring notion of the â€œcelebrity chef.â€ù

Everyoneâ€™s under his spell here. When Michael Douglas isnâ€™t joshing about his good friendâ€™s weakness for the ladies, weâ€™re hearing rascally anecdotes about Alice Cooper, Mr. Gordonâ€™s longtime client and buddy. Even archival footage of Jimi Hendrix and others falls into line, playfully synced to the voice-over.

Opening in theaters before airing on HBO on June 23, â€œThe Case Against 8â€ù follows the legal challenge to Proposition 8, the 2008 referendum that banned same-sex marriage in California. Because the Supreme Court effectively nullified the ban last year â€” the decision said the initiativeâ€™s supporters lacked the standing to appeal a federal ruling striking it down â€” this documentary from Ben Cotner and Ryan White is less a work of immediacy than of backstage intrigue.

Through interviews and court-rehearsal footage, â€œThe Case Against 8â€ù conveys the pressure that the plaintiffs â€” Kris Perry and Sandy Stier of Berkeley, Calif., and Paul Katami and Jeff Zarrillo of Burbank â€” felt as standard bearers for a cause whose implications extended far beyond their own lives. The five-year process was delicate, and the plaintiffs were carefully vetted before they were chosen. Mr. Cotner and Mr. White illustrate the extent to which advancing a case relies not only on argument but also on public relations and stagecraft.

Heading the lawyersâ€™ team leading the challenge are Theodore B. Olson and David Boies, who, according to Mr. Boies, became friends while serving as opposing counsels on Bush v. Gore. On several levels, itâ€™s startling to hear Mr. Olson, a onetime Reaganite stalwart, call this probably the most important case of his life.

Although Mr. Cotner and Mr. White have been granted impressive access, from a dramatic standpoint, itâ€™s hard not to wish that we could observe the legal gamesmanship on both sides. Still, â€œThe Case Against 8â€ù functions as a valuable record of the nuts-and-bolts conference room side of advocacy â€” an aspect of civil rights work not often seen on screen.

Though it is a tragic love story, it is also a perfect and irresistible fantasy. Hazel and Gus possess an absolute moral authority, an ability to assert the truth of their experience that few can share and many might covet. They know the meaning of their own lives, and try as it might, the movie canâ€™t help but give cancer credit for this state of perfection. There is something disturbing about that, and also, therefore, about the source of some of the tears the movie calls forth. The loudest weeping you hear â€” including your own â€” may arise not from grief or admiration, but from envy.

As played by Shailene Woodley, a gifted actress grabbing hold of her moment with both hands, Hazel is witty, compassionate and as lovely as a day in June. Her plucky rejection of the usual â€œcancer storyâ€ù sentiments becomes a potent form of sentimentality in its own right, and her brave refusal of self-pity ensures the audienceâ€™s infinite sympathy. â€œThe only thing that bites worse than having cancer is having a kid with cancer,â€ù she says, and her compassion is borne out by the stricken faces of her parents (Sam Trammell and Laura Dern, both excellent in thinly sketched roles).

However it might look in 40 years, â€œThe Fault in Our Starsâ€ù seems at first glance like a much better picture, thanks to Ms. Woodleyâ€™s discipline and to a script byÂ Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber that takes an unhurried, amiable approach to the story. Their earlier screenplays, â€œ500 Days of Summerâ€ù and â€œThe Spectacular Nowâ€ù (also starring Ms. Woodley), were offbeat variations on sturdy romantic-comedy themes, and here they smartly emphasize the dry, idiosyncratic notes in Mr. Greenâ€™s sometimes pushy prose.

â€œThe world is not a wish-granting factory.â€ù That line, from â€œThe Fault in Our Stars,â€ù is undoubtedly true, and it is also true that the movie, like the book before it, is an expertly built machine for the mass production of tears. Directed by Josh Boone (â€œStuck in Loveâ€ù) with scrupulous respect for John Greenâ€™s best-selling young-adult novel, the film sets out to make you weep â€” not just sniffle or choke up a little, but sob until your nose runs and your face turns blotchy. It succeeds.

The quarrel between the novelist and his fans, the only real conflict in the film other than the one with disease, is essentially a battle between argument and feeling. Itâ€™s hardly a fair fight, and the way it is rigged â€” fresh-faced, innocent, possibly dying young people facing off against a cynical, broken-down, alcoholic old wreck â€” provides a clue to the emotional logic of â€œThe Fault in Our Stars.â€ù Itâ€™s less a movie about cancer than a depiction â€” really a celebration â€” of adolescent narcissism.

But then again, a brief survey of the story and its themes might make you wonder how it could possibly fail. The main character â€” whose voice-over narration, drawn verbatim from Mr. Greenâ€™s pages, frames the story â€” is Hazel Grace Lancaster, a teenager who has lived most of her life with theÂ metastatic thyroid cancer she expects will end it very soon. She falls in love with Augustus Waters (Ansel Elgort), known as Gus, a fellow â€œcancer kidâ€ù who has lost part of his leg to the disease but who has been healthy since then and is determined to lead â€œan extraordinary life.â€ù

But what can you say about a girl who ... ? The question is not meant to be a spoiler, but rather a point of reference. A long time ago, a movie called â€œLove Story,â€ù also based on a best seller with terminal illness in its plot, swept through the popular culture and landed its female lead on the cover of Time. The film was potent and memorable without being all that good. And yet it is still possible, all these years later, to laugh at the stilted dialogue and awkwardly staged scenes and find yourself wet-eyed and raspy-voiced at the end.

Ms. Woodley plays nearly every scene with a plastic oxygen tube anchored to her nostrils and splayed across her face (Hazelâ€™s cancer affects her lungs), but her un-self-conscious performance is the perfect mirror of her characterâ€™s pragmatic temperament. Because she never asks for our approval, we are entirely in her thrall. Gus, meanwhile, is such a handsome bundle of chivalry, positive energy and impish self-deprecation that we may swoon over him even before Hazel does. With an unlighted cigarette wedged into his crooked, cocky grin, he is a perfect romantic hero, complete with a semigoofy sidekick (Nat Wolff).

One answer is supplied within the film itself, in the person of Peter Van Houten, a writer whose novel â€” a cancer story called â€œAn Imperial Afflictionâ€ù â€” is a particular obsession of Hazelâ€™s. She shares it with Gus, and the two travel to Amsterdam to find the reclusive author, played with fine, unshaven, whiskey-soaked misanthropy by Willem Dafoe. Van Houten impatiently lectures his visitors on the differences between fiction and reality, but his theoretical points strike them, and are meant to strike us, as both untrue and unkind.
â€œThe Fault in Our Starsâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Normal adolescent language and behavior, but not too much of it.

Iâ€™m about to venture onto dangerous ground. Mr. Greenâ€™s book is beloved, the emotional power of Mr. Booneâ€™s movie is undeniable, and the real-world experiences behind both are so terrible and complicated that mild skepticism can look like gross insensitivity. Part of the ingenuity of â€œThe Fault in Our Starsâ€ù is the way it short-circuits any potential criticism through a combination of winsome modesty and brazen manipulation. These kids are so nice, so wise, so good-humored, and they also may be dying. What kind of a monster could look at them and find fault?

The film follows along as Major League Baseball sends two advisers to the state to train coaches. But itâ€™s never really clear how widespread baseball fever is â€” we see and hear from only a relatively small group of local residents â€” or what the prospects are for the sport. Still, the history lesson is fascinating, and itâ€™s nice to see an American export other than a Hollywood blockbuster engendering good will.

If nothing else, â€œThe Only Real Game,â€ù a documentary about baseball in Manipur, in northeastern India, serves as an antidote to the Disney film â€œMillion Dollar Arm,â€ù which also involves baseball and India. Here, Americaâ€™s game is played with armed troops looking on and with very little prospect of a happy ending.

The film, by Mirra Bank, traces how baseball came to be played in isolated Manipur, a strife-torn state where insurgencies of one sort or another have been bubbling for decades. Americans at a World War II air base introduced the game, and some residents, male and female, children and adults, have been keeping the flame alive ever since.

The director Ti West, whose credits include the very fine horror movie â€œThe House of the Devil,â€ù has a talent for dread. Heâ€™s so good at raising the little hairs on your neck and keeping them on alert that you can only feel let down when he doesnâ€™t deliver a movie that makes good on his setup. Thatâ€™s the case with his latest, â€œThe Sacrament,â€ù a neo-exploitation flick that shifts from the unnerving to the hollow after it becomes evident that Mr. West is more interested in showing how his characters die than how they lived. It doesnâ€™t help that he seems to encourage you to wish the worst on at least some of them, notably a troika that serves as this taleâ€™s metaphoric blind mice.
â€œThe Sacramentâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Mass death.

Movie murder is such easy entertainment; whatâ€™s harder is keeping viewers interested if a filmmaker has no point of view. Jonestown is a ghastly, complex world-historical event: It is the truest kind of horror story. Mr. West sets the scene reasonably well, ratcheting up a sense of unease with old-fashioned shadows and some nighttime scrambling, but he gets lost once he shifts from fooling around in the dark to recreating mass death. Itâ€™s especially disappointing that he shows no interest in the real people who died at Jonestown, much less charismatic totalitarianism and terror. For inquiries into power and its abuses, look to â€œGuyana Tragedy: The Story of Jim Jones,â€ù a 1980 TV movie with Powers Boothe, and â€œLetters to Dad,â€ù Beth B and Scott Bâ€™s 1979 shocker about the tragedy.

The trap is a sprawling community in an unnamed country; the bait is Caroline (Amy Seimetz), a sister of one of the mice, Patrick (Kentucker Audley). Heâ€™s received a letter from Caroline, a former addict who claims to have found deliverance in a utopia called Eden Parish. Disconcerted, Patrick decides to visit her with two Vice Media reporters â€” a correspondent, Sam (a good A. J. Bowen), and videographer, Jake (Joe Swanberg) â€” who hope the trip leads to a story. With its on-screen text, jittery digital visuals and on-camera talking heads, the movie has been constructed to resemble a documentary, an overly familiar horror-genre strategy that is itself an ominous sign.

What the three discover is a compound thatâ€™s loosely modeled on Jonestown, the doomed Peoples Temple settlement founded in Guyana by the Rev. Jim Jones, who, in 1978, ushered more than 900 of his followers into a murder-suicide ceremony. Mr. West, who also wrote the screenplay and edited â€œThe Sacrament,â€ù never mentions Jones or the Peoples Temple, though the identity of the smooth talker in shades, simply called Father (a fine Gene Jones), is obvious. Less clear is what Mr. West thought he was doing with this depressing, grim story, which here becomes a pointless, abjectly impersonal re-creation of mass death, one poisoned sip and fired bullet at a time.

While the first third is promising â€” players share stories of success and redemption, children in favelas kick balls fashioned out of plastic bags, and professionals race across the field to a pulsating beat â€” the subsequent hour is scattershot. The audience would have been better served if the filmmakers had either narrowed their focus or, since the high-profile interviews delve into â€œIconoclastsâ€ù territory, developed a documentary series exploring the science, history and sociology of the objects Mr. Muniz uses in his art. It would be fascinating.

In â€œWaste Land,â€ù Lucy Walkerâ€™s Oscar-nominated 2010 documentary, the Brazilian photographer Vik Muniz trekked around a garbage dump and collaborated with its workers in the name of art. In â€œThis Is Not a Ball,â€ù directed by Mr. Muniz and Juan RendÃ_n, the artist has another project â€” a piece for the 2014 World Cup (less than a week away!) involving 10,000 balls â€” but the process of documenting it only bogs down this film.

As expected, there are wow-worthy stunts and high-flying bodies in â€œEdge of Tomorrow,â€ù which finds its groove after Cage discovers that heâ€™s on seemingly endless repeat. In time, he figures out whatâ€™s going on and sets out to change fate, which leads him to Rita, a legendary warrior with the cutesy moniker Full Metal Bitch. This time around, as it were, the hero isnâ€™t trapped in the maddeningly cute town of Punxsutawney, Pa., as Bill Murray was in â€œGroundhog Day,â€ùHarold Ramisâ€™s mind- and clock-bending 1993 comedy masterwork. The guy caught in the loop here is played by Tom Cruise, a star who doesnâ€™t do ordinary well. He plays Maj. William Cage, a sensationally adaptable individual who, when confronted with Armageddon, courtesy of scuttling extraterrestrials, would prefer to avoid the fight. But this is a Tom Cruise movie, and so stuff happens, and then it happens all over again and again and again, initially with an engagingly light, comic touch and then with escalating seriousness as Cageâ€™s insouciance turns into gravitas in a war that has united the human world against the alien.

Eventually, Mr. Limanâ€™s eccentricities and the morbidly funny neo-screwball vibe that he establishes are swamped by generic pyrotechnics and noise. Thatâ€™s predictable, given the high studio stakes and the industryâ€™s faith in spectacles of destruction, but it doesnâ€™t obliterate the movieâ€™s pleasures. In his afterword to â€œAll You Need Is Kill,â€ù Mr. Sakurazaka explains that he was thinking about video games while writing the novel. â€œI reset the game hundreds of times,â€ù he writes, â€œuntil my special attack finally went off perfectly.â€ù In other words, video games are a type of time machine that allows players, if they put in the hours, to achieve victory. Hence the movieâ€™s clever tagline, â€œLive, Die, Repeat,â€ù which, of course, echoes the faith that every film genre fan embraces: live, watch, repeat.
â€œEdge of Tomorrowâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Intense violence.

In â€œEdge of Tomorrow,â€ù Mr. Liman brings Mr. Cruiseâ€™s smile out of semiretirement and also gives him the kind of physical challenges at which he so brilliantly excels. Mr. Cruiseâ€™s great talent has always been body-based; he doesnâ€™t put across complex emotional shadings, tunneling so deep into a characterâ€™s psychology that it can feel like a transmogrification. Much like old-school, pre-Method movie stars, he takes possession of his characters from the outside in, expressing their qualities and kinks through his extraordinarily controlled physicality. This kind of performance can be easy to overlook, shrugged off as little more than stunt work, as if acting through the whole body were somehow inferior to emoting with a big, TV-friendly face.

This song-and-dance rapidly shifts your understanding of whom Mr. Cruise is playing and how. Heâ€™s funny! And watching him glide through the opening of â€œEdge of Tomorrowâ€ù â€” a suggestion of â€œJerry Maguireâ€ù edging his smile â€” itâ€™s hard not to think, Where has this guy been? â€œEdge of Tomorrow,â€ù which has a script credited to Christopher McQuarrie and Jez and John-Henry Butterworth, opens with lock-jawed earnestness and news reports of a global calamity. Cage demurs, raising his brow and breaking out a small, disbelieving smile before beginning a soft-shoe shuffle toward the door.

Tell me if youâ€™ve heard this one before. A man wakes up and quickly realizes that heâ€™s repeating yesterday, down to the last meal, salutation and conversation. Heâ€™s trapped in a kind of time loop. He canâ€™t escape, but, he realizes, he can change. That may not make sense, given the logic of the space-time continuum, but it works just fine in fiction because, well, itâ€™s fiction. To put it another way, â€œThere are no paradoxes in time travel, there canâ€™t be.â€ù Or so says a character in Robert A. Heinleinâ€™s 1964 novel, â€œFarnhamâ€™s Freehold,â€ù about space, time and the apocalypse.

â€œTrust Meâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). The dialogue is filled with vituperative profanity.

Until it disintegrates in an explosion of sentimentality, â€œTrust Meâ€ù qualifies for what could be called â€œThe Day of the Locustâ€ù award. That imaginary honor, named for the Nathanael West novel, would be bestowed on the yearâ€™s nastiest, most stomach-turning movie about no-holds-barred Hollywood wheeling and dealing. A chance meeting with Lydia (Saxon Sharbino), a fiercely talented, wise-beyond-her-years 13-year-old actor from Oklahoma, offers Howard a second chance to grasp the gold ring. He stands up to her possessive, alcoholic father, Ray (Paul Sparks), and negotiates a three-picture deal for Lydia to star in the franchise, whose first episodes are to be directed by Ang Lee.

Written and directed by Clark Gregg, who stars as Howard Holloway, a scuffling, obsequious agent specializing in child actors, â€œTrust Meâ€ù has an acute ear for profane, hard-boiled agent-speak. Not since â€œSwimming With Sharksâ€ù has a screenplay aimed so many poisoned darts at the venality and bad manners of movie people. In many other respects, however, â€œTrust Meâ€ù is a mess. It throws in a useless subplot in which Howard plays romantic footsie with a neighbor (Amanda Peet) who sells cars. As the movie picks up speed and undergoes sudden, confusing plot reversals, it loses its satirical edge. As pitiable as Howard may be, he seems angelic compared with his archrival, Aldo (Sam Rockwell in an underwritten role), a sneering, icy predator who takes an obscene delight in poaching Howardâ€™s clients. Howard was himself once a child actor whose break came 36 years earlier when he was cast opposite Jan-Michael Vincent in a movie called â€œSurf Campâ€ù that imploded before it was made.

â€œWalking the Camino: Six Ways to Santiagoâ€ù could increase the foot traffic. This documentary by Lydia B. Smith follows six travelers as they make the trip in 30 days or so. The trail, of course, is absurdly photogenic. Sunbeams stream through clouds; valleys are viewed from mountaintops; morning mists hug meadows. The film also catalogs the challenges: blisters, aching joints, the snoring in hostels, the lack of hygiene. Sometimes the sun is too hot, the wind too strong, the rain too soaking. A pilgrimage is not supposed to be comfortable. Over time, Camino becomes a noun, verb and state of mind. As weights are shed â€” from both the pack and the soul â€” everyone is somehow changed. Religious quest or not, one priest says, â€œthe Camino is pure medicine.â€ù

The Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela in Spain, where, legend holds, the Apostle James is buried, has drawn pilgrims since the Middle Ages. So itâ€™s not as if the most popular Camino de Santiago, the 500-mile Camino FrancÃ©s, which starts at St.-Jean-Pied-de-Port in the Pyrenees, needs any publicity. Still, â€œThe Way,â€ù Emilio Estevezâ€™s 2011 film about four modern-day hikers â€” one played by his father, Martin Sheen â€” introduced many to the trek and its meditative pleasures.

Itâ€™s not to be, but Mr. Goldthwait gives us lovely, buttery daylight scenes, nicely relaxed leads and dialogue that pays attention to fluctuating gender dynamics. He also engineers a static, almost wordless 19-minute shot inside a tent that generates more tension than many horror directors achieve with a swarm of foley artists and a healthier budget. This canny exploitation of the power of silence is unnerving; that it should come from one of our most aggressively vocal performers is an unexpected treat.

Simplicity itself, the story sends a Bigfoot fanatic (Bryce Johnson) and his skeptical girlfriend (Alexie Gilmore) deep into the Six Rivers National Forest, armed only with a video camera and youthful enthusiasm. Their destination is the site of a supposed Sasquatch sighting recorded in a 1967 film fragment, but local monster experts (delightfully played by residents of the area) are cautionary. By the time our couple set up camp and night descends, weâ€™ve been teased much too long to be satisfied with anything less than a rampaging, hairy biped.

Which is to say that restraint has not been one of his watchwords â€” until now. With â€œWillow Creek,â€ù a found-footage yarn set in Humboldt County, Calif., Mr. Goldthwait exercises so much caution that you want to get behind his characters and push. This impatience stems at least partly from expectations cultivated by a long line of similar pseudo-documentary creep-outs â€” curious seekers of the supernatural getting more than they bargained for â€” dating all the way back to â€œThe Blair Witch Projectâ€ù in 1999. As if in homage to that ingenious groundbreaker, â€œWillow Creekâ€ù hugs the template with a deliberation that has the unfortunate effect of encouraging our brains to dance ahead of the script.

As a comedian, Bobcat Goldthwait can seem like a colicky baby, spitting punch lines punctuated by random screams. As a filmmaker, however, heâ€™s more focused and less predictable, channeling his choleric style into pointed satires on American society that sometimes hit their marks with uncomfortable directness.

Akshay Kumar has made a career of playing Indian Everymen, sweet goofballs who succeed accidentally while upholding traditional values. He may cut down villains â€” thereâ€™s plenty of fighting in movies like â€œChandni Chowk to Chinaâ€ù and â€œSingh Is Kinngâ€ù â€” but he honors mothers and aunties and helps the poor.
