Thereâ€™s comedy here, too, courtesy of a marriage plot that wends its way through the film, which skips, in typical if not happy Bollywood style, from torture to song and dance. â€œMy heart seems a little poetic,â€ù Virat sings in a lovey-dovey number, and so what if weâ€™ve already seen him snip off a terroristâ€™s finger. (Meanwhile, his intended, played by Sonakshi Sinha, is an occasional boxer, who fights without removing the stud in her nose.)

Comedy and romance, though, are sideshows to the main event here: Virat and his escalating war with the head of a sleeper-cell network (Freddy Daruwala). Dedicated to members of the Indian military and their families, â€œHolidayâ€ù has simple politics â€” army good, terrorists bad â€” and takes pro forma pains to remind us that the dissatisfied come from all religions (just as the army is a rainbow coalition of Indians).

A remake of a 2012 Tamil hit (also directed by Mr. Murugadoss), â€œHolidayâ€ù follows an Indian officer, Virat (Mr. Kumar), on home leave in Mumbai. As the filmâ€™s subtitle, â€œA Soldier Is Never Off Duty,â€ù tips us, holiday does not mean vacation. Virat rides along with a policeman pal, the better to foil a terrorist plot and display his superman, super secret-agent skills. (Heâ€™s actually a member of the Defense Intelligence Agency.)

What is perhaps hardest to imagine, for those of us who did not experience Eastern Bloc Communism firsthand, is the way its cruelty and absurdity were woven into the fabric of everyday life. â€œBurning Bush,â€ù taking place during a period of what the authorities referred to as â€œnormalization,â€ù depicts part of the process of weaving. What is especially striking is how many of the characters affected by Palachâ€™s death and the governmentâ€™s panicked response to it insist on behaving as if they live in a society dedicated to reason and the rule of law.

A welter of subplots, meanwhile, survey an increasingly ugly ethical universe. There are a few acts of courage and conscience â€” including one by a detective whose growing distaste for his work contrasts with his partnerâ€™s enthusiasm for it â€” but mostly a series of painful compromises. The system proves increasingly adept at finding and exploiting weak points, like a fatherâ€™s worry and guilt about his daughterâ€™s well-being, or a magistrateâ€™s concern for her career. Those who cannot be intimidated into collaborating can always be punished or marginalized. Having apparently given up on inspiring loyalty with visions of progress, the government finds that its most effective tools are the cynicism and resignation of the public, especially the professional class.

It hardly seems incidental that the filmâ€™s most determined opponents of injustice are both women. Among the details Ms. Holland illuminates is the sexism that pervades every corner of Czech society. You may be a judge, a lawyer or a student radical, but if you are a woman there will always be a man around who expects you to bring him a cup of coffee.

At first, the young man seems to inspire almost universal sympathy, even as various groups try to use his death to their own advantage. Politicians and public figures allied with the still nominally independent Czech regime express concern for the state of the nationâ€™s troubled youth, while student activists scramble to organize further protests, including a general strike. There are rumors that Palach is the first of many â€œliving torches,â€ù but nobody seems to know if he was really part of any coordinated group. And everyone, including ministers and police officers, is nervous about what the Soviets will do.

Ms. Holland, who was born in Poland in 1948 and whose directing career has taken her to Germany, France and Hollywood, through a Henry James adaptation and episodes of â€œThe Wire,â€ù was studying film in Prague during the Soviet occupation. â€œBurning Bushâ€ù was made as a four-hour, three-part mini-series for Czech HBO, and its reconstruction of the months after Palachâ€™s death feels like a mixture of historical research and personal recollection. (The film begins a theatrical run at the Film Forum on Wednesday and is also streaming at Fandor.com outside New York City). Blending fact and fiction â€” some of the main characters are based on real people; others are composites or archetypes â€” the film does a remarkably persuasive job of capturing the nightmarish and sometimes grimly comical quality of life under totalitarianism.

Ms. Holland, working from a script by Stepan Hulik, a Czech screenwriter born in 1984, turns a sprawling story into a tight and suspenseful ethical thriller. The first episode is crowded with characters â€” students and police officers, doctors, lawyers and shopkeepers â€” but after a hectic stretch it comes into focus. In a moral landscape riddled with corruption, cowardice and dishonesty, there are two clearly heroic figures: Jan Palachâ€™s mother, Libuse Palachova (Jaroslava Pokorna), a widow who sells candy in a provincial railway station, and Dagmar Buresova (Tatiana Pauhofova), a lawyer who agrees to represent her in a lawsuit against a Communist Party official.

On Aug. 20, 1968, Warsaw Pact troops led by the Soviet Union invaded Czechoslovakia, putting a violent end to the reformist socialist experiment known as the Prague Spring. The following winter, a student named Jan Palach set himself on fire in Wenceslas Square, an act of protest that is the starting point of â€œBurning Bush,â€ùAgnieszka Hollandâ€™s thoughtful, gripping, crisply acted new film.

â€œBurning Bushâ€ù joins the ranks of other recent films about the former Eastern Bloc â€” like â€œIdaâ€ù from Poland, â€œQuod Erat Demonstrandumâ€ù from Romania, â€œBarbaraâ€ù from Germany â€” that try to grasp, with the benefit of hindsight but without too much ex post facto gloating, the logic of Communist dictatorship. Ms. Hollandâ€™s use of tense music and rapid cutting creates an atmosphere of claustrophobia and paranoia. At the end you feel a chilly cloud settling over Prague that will not lift for 20 years.

The case is a reminder that the word Kafkaesque was inspired by a son of Prague. The defendant in the suit, Vilem Novy (the great Slovak screen actor Martin Huba), is an avuncular old apparatchik (with an ideologically checkered past) who is accused of giving voice to an outlandish conspiracy about what happened to Palach. His insinuations, which point to an intricate counterrevolutionary double-cross undertaken by student radicals in cahoots with Western powers, are part of an official attempt to cloud Palachâ€™s legacy and defuse the potency of his martyrdom. The trial is a farce of bureaucratic obstructionism and outright cheating; in the face of this, the pursuit of the truth by Ms. Palachova and her lawyer seems both brave and quixotic.

The material may sound offbeat, but the presentation never transcends amateurishness. The jumbled manner in which Mr. Ekanayake cuts together conversation scenes suggests that potentially fluid footage was never filmed. The actors visibly struggle with their lines, including a few howlers worthy of Ed Wood. (Yevgeny, an aspiring author, wonders aloud, â€œDo people really need another book?â€ù)

Perhaps to pad the running time, every scene is followed by a skyline view or streetscape. Pans of the Brooklyn Bridge recall the infamous shots of the Golden Gate Bridge from the midnight movie â€œThe Room.â€ù

The plot concerns a detective, Sal (Damien Bosco), with a vaguely New Age bent, whoâ€™s less interested in solving mysteries than in improving his clientsâ€™ lives. Along with a protÃ©gÃ©, Yevgeny (Sean Bempong), he takes on three increasingly bizarre cases. These involve a two-timed real estate agent (Jennifer Blakemore), incestuous siblings (Clara Schmidt and Matthew Ryan) and a wizard (David A. Steinberg) who hexes his writing partner (Matt Saxon) after their argument over mumblecore escalates.
The final credits optimistically trumpet â€œBreakthrough Weekendâ€ù as â€œNo. 1 of 60â€ù in a series, promising â€œBreakthrough Weekend 2: The Rise of Yevgenyâ€ù in 2015.

The closing credits of â€œBreakthrough Weekendâ€ù list a technical crew of five. That figure doesnâ€™t count the producing team, which consists of two of the actors and the director, or the composer, whose personal website is advertised below his name. This New York shaggy-dog story from Sujewa Ekanayake is an example of extreme-makeshift filmmaking â€” but not, unfortunately, a successful one.

The premise of â€œWhere We Startedâ€ù seems torn from an indie-script textbook: Will (Matthew Brumlow) and Nora (Cora Vander Broek), two lonely strangers locked in unhappy marriages, happen to run into each other on a night that might change their lives.

Itâ€™s one thing when Will, a frustrated actor, and Nora, a frustrated housewife, find themselves in adjacent rooms at a nameless West Texas motel. Itâ€™s another when they share cigarettes, then a late-night meal at a diner. But only when they discover they both love John Hughes films â€” trading quotes from â€œFerris Buellerâ€™s Day Off,â€ù â€œThe Breakfast Clubâ€ù and â€œSome Kind of Wonderfulâ€ù â€” do they bond. (The characters, in their early 30s, are too young to have seen those movies in theaters, but let that pass.)

And, sadly, the Hughes homage â€” the two repeatedly return to his lines â€” winds up swamping the story. After invoking the ending of â€œPretty in Pink,â€ù the film plays out in the only way possible. What would Duckie do?

Before long, the two are smitten, the one-night stand a foregone conclusion, all hemming and hawing aside. The true leap of faith comes afterward, when they talk seriously of leaving their lives for each other and what that would entail. No divorce is simple, but for Nora, a hard-eyed realist, it would be further complicated by the custody battle over her 4-year-old son.

Written and directed by Chris Hansen, this romance has its authentic moments. As it happens, Mr. Brumlow and Ms. Vander Broek are married, but their familiarity hurts as much as it helps. They are good together in later, more intimate scenes. Early on, though, their rapport feels all too glib, a beat out of sync.
â€œ22 Jump Streetâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Adult high jinks.

Itâ€™s no surprise then that Mr. Hill can approximate a cannonball convincingly, yet he also gets mileage out of stillness, as when he drains his face of emotion and widens his eyes, a bit of business that shows how Schmidt is, with total guile, trying to feign guilelessness. At rest, Mr. Tatum, with his half-mast eyes and a neck as big as a redwood trunk, can bring to mind Ferdinand the Bull, the Spanish peacenik who prefers to sit and smell the flowers instead of fight. Like a lot of musclemen, Mr. Tatum can look almost captive to his body, which makes his grace all the more pleasurable, as in a wittily choreographed fight thatâ€™s part jitterbug dance-off, part wrestling match.

And so it goes in â€œ22 Jump Street,â€ù which returns Schmidt and Jenko to school, this time for a stint in college. There, at the fictional, MC State (one billion presumably underserved), the two work their assignment investigating a new designer drug while exploring new interests and friends. Jenko rapidly bonds with a quarterback, Zook (Wyatt Russell), a dumb blond cut from the same cutup cloth as Jeff Spicoli, the stoner from â€œFast Times at Ridgemont High,â€ù while Schmidt cuddles with a fetching young woman, Maya (Amber Stevens). The zingers ricochet amid knowing college-movie clichÃ©s and memorable turns from Keith and Kenny Lucas, as a tag-team duo called the Yangs, and especially a fearless Jillian Bell as Mercedes, Mayaâ€™s petulant-in-pink roomie.

Much like the jokes about â€œ22 Jump Streetâ€ù being a franchise, this kind of doubling flatters the viewer, who, after being pulled in as a paying customer, is recruited as a comedy co-conspirator. (In this way, the movie, naÃ¯vely or not, also mimics the academic idea that fans now enjoy unprecedented control of the production and circulation of popular culture.) Youâ€™re in on the joke, which makes the movie something you watch and root for. In the first movie, the Jump Street operation is restarted, because, as Chief Hardy explains, â€œThe guys in charge of this stuff lack creativity and are completely out of ideas.â€ù That may have registered as a dig at the studio powers that be, but as the sequel affirms, itâ€™s really a smiling affirmation that the guys in charge know precisely what they are doing.

More is more and is, at times, just right in â€œ22 Jump Street,â€ù an exploding piÃ±ata of gags, pratfalls, winking asides, throwaway one-liners and self-reflexive waggery. This is, of course, the sequel to â€œ21 Jump Street,â€ù the 2012 hit that borrowed its title and undercover brother shtick from the old television show best known for its hair-gel hottie, Johnny Depp. For a second time, Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum play lovable undercover cops who â€” in between dodging danger and jokes that fly almost as fast as they do on â€œThe Simpsonsâ€ù â€” insinuate themselves into a juvenile population, whose resistance to these charmers has been rendered completely futile, much like that of the movieâ€™s audience.

As expected, the focus remains fixed on Schmidt and Jenko, who take turns doing the Goofus and Gallant bit. Part of what made â€œ21 Jump Streetâ€ù work was the way it played Mr. Hill and Mr. Tatumâ€™s characters against their off-screen personas: In 2012, Schmidt rode the geek-nation wave and even scored romantically, while Jenko the jock felt the sting of rejection. The new movie somewhat reverses that dynamic even as it continues to milk jokes about whoâ€™s popular and not. Itâ€™s an odd coupling that still tickles a comedy sweet spot partly because both actors are naturally likable and seem to be having a good time. It helps that they look funny together, resembling nothing so much as a sideways exclamation point, with Mr. Tatumâ€™s verticality complementing Mr. Hillâ€™s sphericality.

This kind of self-consciousness is a cornerstone of comedy, deployed by everyone from Buster Keaton to Bugs Bunny and Stephen Colbert, and can be usefully self-regarding. (Look at me, folks!) By pulling back the curtain immediately on the sequel, the movieâ€™s behind-the-scenes smarty pants â€” it was written by Michael Bacall, Oren Uziel and Rodney Rothman, and directed by Phil Lord and Christopher Miller â€” arenâ€™t only drawing on a long comedy tradition, but theyâ€™re also helping to inoculate this second installment against predictable criticism. The operative joke in â€œ22 Jump Street,â€ù at least initially, is that itâ€™s exactly like the last movie, with the same odd-couple partners, the same support team, the same covert sleuthing and almost the same love interests and on and on.

Perhaps as befits their increased celebrity, Mr. Tatum and Mr. Hill spend considerable time apart in the story, which siphons some comedy from the idea that Schmidt and Jenkoâ€™s bromance may be going through a rough patch. While Jenko frolics with Zook, Schmidt plays the spurned partner, a setup that allows the movie simultaneously to mock and exploit the conventions of both the traditional romantic comedy and the bromance. As in the first movie, the guiding comic principle here remains the appearance of ironic detachment followed by an assertion of sincerity thatâ€™s as appealing as it is disingenuous. Itâ€™s a destabilizing strategy that allows the filmmakers to have their cake and scarf it too, as when Jenko rails against a homophobic slur thatâ€™s already been deployed.

Submission is one of the foundations of mass culture: If you bludgeon them, they will come. The pop-culture savants behind â€œ22 Jump Streetâ€ù understand this so well that theyâ€™ve folded this ethos into the movie, which is bookended by self-amused references to its status as franchise fodder. Schmidt (Mr. Hill) and Jenko (Mr. Tatum) enter with their chief, Hardy (Nick Offerman), announcing that theyâ€™ve been tapped to reproduce their first success. â€œNobody cared about the Jump Street reboot,â€ù Hardy deadpans, staring at the guys while all but winking at the camera. But because it worked, â€œthis department has invested a lot of money to make sure Jump Street keeps going.â€ù

Mr. Gerster, of course, means to contrast his own truer, less formulaic movie, and heâ€™s at least partly successful. If â€œA Coffee in Berlinâ€ù has its own kind of formula and a romanticism that reads as both youthful and obscuring, it nevertheless absorbs you and makes you wonder what Mr. Gerster will do next.

Except this is Berlin, where dark history lurks. During the course of his day, Niko (Tom Schilling, sweetly affectless) visits coffee shops, graffitied art spaces and bars. But he also has a beer next to an old man who soon begins to tell him about wandering these streets as a boy on Kristallnacht, worrying that all the glass shards will make it hard to ride his bike.

Earlier, Niko and a friend stop by a film set where a movie about a Nazi officer and his hidden Jewish lover is being shot. An actor in uniform â€” â€œyou look like my grandpa,â€ù Niko says â€” tells him the plot, which seems tricked up and sentimental.

A day-in-the-life story, â€œA Coffee in Berlinâ€ù follows the downward-sloping fortunes of Niko, a scruffily poetic slacker who loses his girlfriend, his driverâ€™s license and his financial support from Daddy. And thatâ€™s before night falls.

This first feature directed by Jan Ole Gerster has plenty of style. Maybe too much. Mr. Gerster has a tendency to aestheticize Nikoâ€™s aimless angst and his city, full of the young and the hanging out. The mood-setting music â€” jazz and melancholy piano â€” and the beautiful black-and-white images (by Philipp Kirsamer) of light-soaked rooms, street scenes and rooftops serve to dull the storyâ€™s barbed comic edges.

Remaking their 2001 movie of the same title, Lucky McKee and Chris Sivertson (who also enjoy individual gore-centric careers) pump up the content and pretty up the visuals. The plot is bananas: Magical stones, multiple reanimations and same-sex make-outs drive the action as MÃ_ddy (Caitlin Stasey, recently seen slinking around the CW drama â€œReignâ€ù), an outlier in the high school ecosystem, seeks to punish the populars for the death of a friend. But when a fatal accident â€” and some witchy intervention â€” turn her and three others into vengeful zombies with a need to feed, the football players will soon become their main course.
One witch and four cheerleaders enact savage revenge on the stars of a high school football team in â€œAll Cheerleaders Die,â€ù a trashy horror caper oozing blood and pheromones.

Shot with a camera as excited as a squirrel-chasing dog, â€œCheerleadersâ€ù has a girls-gone-wild energy and a twisted sense of humor. The story may be nearly incoherent, but the verve of the filmmaking â€” the tone can switch from tough to tender in nanoseconds â€” and a spectacular sound design give the girlsâ€™ many transgressions an unexpected rush. Smooching, scheming, strutting and croaking, these mean queens rule senior year; if they do the same at the box office, the movieâ€™s hint at a sequel will probably become a reality.

While the state coffers stand to receive a tax infusion, investors wait to pounce. After the passage, representatives of an equity firm weigh the market attractiveness of commercial weed. Cannabis, one says, â€œis bigger than corn.â€ù

The proponents of Initiative 502 offer two clean-cut representatives: Alison Holcomb, an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer and the campaignâ€™s director, and Rick Steves, a travel writer and PBS host, who drive around the state in 2011 promoting the measure. Opponents include Steve Sarich, a grizzled provider of medical marijuana and a compulsive tobacco smoker, and Douglas Hiatt, a defense lawyer.

â€œGreat social policy changes are not an easy sell,â€ù says Jonathan Martin, a reporter for The Seattle Times, in Riley Mortonâ€™s assured documentary â€œEvergreen.â€ù Heâ€™s not kidding: This record of Washington Stateâ€™s battle over Initiative 502, which legalized possession of small amounts of recreational marijuana in 2012, is predictably loaded with rancor. The battle isnâ€™t over whether pot should be legalized, but to what extent.

The opponents â€” medical-marijuana sellers are the most impassioned â€” largely contest a provision related to driving under the influence. In the capitol, they try to shout down a presentation Mr. Steves and others make in the rotunda. Nevertheless, the measure passes.

He and his family live in a society that is simultaneously in the grip of lawless violence and stultifying bureaucracy. To say that ordinary citizens like Heli are caught in a war between drug gangs and government authorities would be to presume that anyone could tell the difference. The same agents who strut for television cameras in front of burning piles of confiscated marijuana and cocaine conduct murderous raids on the houses of people suspected of disrupting the traffickersâ€™ supply chain. Mr. Escalante, raised in Guanajuato by a Mexican father and an American mother, paints a harrowing, despairing portrait of a world ruled by various forms of cruelty, in which simple decency can be a mortal risk.

The opening scenes of Amat Escalanteâ€™s â€œHeliâ€ù establish the terrible contradiction that ensnares its main character, a young Mexican factory worker. First, we see a brazen but also unnervingly businesslike act of brutality, in which a group of men drag two bound-and-battered hostages from the bed of a pickup truck and hang one of them, stripped to his underwear, from a highway overpass. Then we meet Heli (Armando Espitia) as he answers a knock on the door and chats with a friendly census worker in a bright yellow polo shirt. Her questions sound reasonable enough at first: How many people in the household? What is your profession? Later they will seem grotesquely irrelevant to the facts of Heliâ€™s life.

â€œHeli,â€ù which won the directing prize in Cannes last year, is at once extreme and unspectacular, a grisly and lurid slice-of-life drama. Its deadpan presentation of terrible actions and Heliâ€™s weary, dazed reactions to them, express a fatalism that could be seen as a species of dark comedy. But this is also, unmistakably, an angry film, an indictment of circumstances that seem to force a choice between impotence and homicide.

But Heliâ€™s troubles start much closer to home. Relations with his wife, Sabrina (Linda GonzÃ¡lez), have cooled since the birth of their baby. His 12-year-old sister, Estela (Andrea Vergara), is secretly dating Beto (Juan Eduardo Palacios), an older teenager and an officer in training with the federal police. Heliâ€™s attempt to protect her quickly spirals into a horrifying ordeal involving stolen drugs, a vicious home invasion and a graphic scene of torture that is all the more disturbing for being so matter-of-fact. A man is beaten, mutilated and set on fire as a group of boys plays video games in the next room. â€œDonâ€™t miss the show,â€ù one of the assailants says.

Every day, Heli bikes down a dusty road to work the night shift at the automobile assembly plant that also employs his father (RamÃ_n ÃÅlvarez). The gleaming, orderly interior of the factory provides another atmospheric contrast between the smoothly administered realm of legal global capitalism and the hellish kingdom of the narcotics trade that is its shadowy twin.

But the whole film seems to be running in place. Too withholding to engage, the script gives Mr. Paul little to chew on and only the vaguest context for Hollisâ€™s extreme disconnection or his attachment to the fixer-upper beach house where he spends so much time. Luckily, Mr. Wiggins, in his first real acting role, is a natural; fighting melodramatic music that threatens to obscure the melancholy of Jacobâ€™s escalating vandalism, he repeatedly reminds us that sometimes a hellion is no more than a lost and angry little boy.

Going nowhere slowly and with great deliberation, â€œHellionâ€ù presents a fractured family locked in a closed loop of adolescent misbehavior and adult retaliation. The instigator is Jacob (Josh Wiggins), a troubled 13-year-old whose father, Hollis (Aaron Paul), has withdrawn into boozy depression after the death of his wife. Now a distant parent and indifferent housekeeper, Hollis provides little for Jacob and his younger brother (Deke Garner), aside from junk food and remonstrations.

Expanding her 2012 short film, the writer and director Kat Candler struggles to shape an undercooked story into compelling drama. The acting is solid, with an unusually low-key Juliette Lewis, as the boysâ€™ sympathetic aunt, doing her best to pierce the filmâ€™s miasma of pent-up testosterone. And the southeast Texas locations â€” a dusty landscape of football and dirt bikes, guns and oil refineries â€” prove entirely hospitable to a downbeat tale of neglect.

Her husband (James Morrison) is concerned, as are her stepfather (Josh Clark) and, to a lesser extent, her stepbrother (Simon Helberg, Ms. Towneâ€™s husband and an executive producer of the film, best known for playing Howard Wolowitz on â€œThe Big Bang Theoryâ€ù).

Gene certainly acts erratically. But he is a painter, a dancer, a Vietnam War veteran â€” everything Rachaelâ€™s sensible, affluent husband is not. As his bond with Rachael grows, it inadvertently nears a disquieting intimacy. Fortunately, his attendant at the home (Jason Ritter), a quasi-love interest for Rachael, saves the movie from complete perversity.

To the mini-trend in films about aging parents in decline (â€œAmour,â€ù â€œAway From Her,â€ù the recent â€œGrand DÃ©partâ€ù), add â€œI Am I,â€ù a wispy vanity project for the writer-director-actress Jocelyn Towne. Rachael (Ms. Towne) is at her motherâ€™s funeral when she encounters Gene (Kevin Tighe), her father, who left shortly after Rachael was born. Gene, his memory dimming, has been in a retirement home. When he meets Rachael, he falls under the delusion that she is her mother, for whom he still carries a torch. Rachael, to know him better, eventually decides to play along.

Little is resolved, though Geneâ€™s memory improbably shows signs of improvement. Ms. Towne, the daughter of the screenwriter Roger Towne (â€œThe Naturalâ€ù), has a tentative, fluttery aspect suggestive of a Jane Adams, but lacking her authority. The cheeky protagonist, Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel), has matured from a wispy little boy in the first film into a vaguely hipsterish young man in â€œDragon 2.â€ù Five years have passed, and this doctrinaire peacenik finds himself obliged to acknowledge that pure evil exists and that some monsters are so bent on power and destruction that no argument for peace and love can make them see the light; fighting back is the regrettable but necessary response to their aggression.

Thatâ€™s the war and peace part. In the humans and animals part, Hiccupâ€™s message to the residents of the Viking island of Berk, including his warrior father, Stoick the Vast (Gerard Butler), has been thoroughly absorbed. Devoted pet care makes loving pets, and everybodyâ€™s happy. If you are kind to your beasties while letting them be themselves (after all, theyâ€™re fire-breathing dragons and youâ€™re not), everyone can coexist harmoniously.
â€œHow to Train Your Dragon 2â€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for intense action, mildly scary sequences and mild language.

â€œDragon 2â€ù is considerably darker and more self-aware than its forerunner. Both films are speedier than the average animated blockbuster. In places, â€œDragon 2â€ù is almost too fast to keep up with, and, in other places, itâ€™s a little too dark, at least in 3-D. The spectacle quotient has been increased exponentially, and you are keenly aware of the divisions between its adagio and allegro passages. Its thundering air-war sequences, with hordes of dragon-riding fighters swarming into battle, have the swooping, gliding kineticism of vintage newsreels of World War II dogfights.

In interviews, the writer and director Dean DeBlois has called â€œDragon 2â€ù his â€œEmpire Strikes Back.â€ù Because he makes more of his filmsâ€™ allegorical implications than most creators of toons, the movie nudges you to consider its subtext.

War and peace. Humans and animals. Contemplation of our bestial versus our spiritual sides. These may be too much heavy baggage to attach to a corporate product like â€œHow to Train Your Dragon 2.â€ù But such matters are there for you to ponder in this sequel to the 2010 blockbuster that recertified DreamWorks Animation, after a fallow period, as a major player in Hollywoodâ€™s cartoon sweepstakes. And pop mythology nowadays has a way of seeping into the culture and sending far-reaching undercurrents.

Hiccup would rather go exploring with Astrid and Toothless than spend time being groomed to be clan chief by his father. One day they discover a fort in shards of green ice that reveals an ominous new species of dragon. This giant, lumbering Bewilderbeast, an alpha dragon, may not fly. But this tusked creature ejects streams of water that turn everything to ice, and its immensity is overwhelming.

He is the slave of Drago Bludvist (Djimon Hounsou), a scowling, sociopathic warrior whom they encounter through Eret (Kit Harington), a rakish dragon trapper who is helping Drago amass a captive army. This fearsome villain bears a distinct physical resemblance to several real-life warlords of recent history.

The story seems to be going somewhere until it comes to a halt with the inevitable showdown between the forces of darkness and the forces of light. Once the war cry has been sounded, it is off to the battlefield.

The movie begins on a sweet, jolly note, with a dragon-racing derby won by Astrid (America Ferrera), who is now Hiccupâ€™s girlfriend and partner in exploration. Astrid has mellowed from a sarcastic, hypercompetitive tomboy to an adventurous sidekick and is much less compelling. The comic scenes of Hiccup, Astrid and their friends Snotlout (Jonah Hill), Fishlegs (Christopher Mintz-Plasse), Tuffnut (T. J. Miller) and his sister Ruffnut (Kristen Wiig) are among the filmâ€™s weakest, but Ms. Wiigâ€™s Ruffnut gets off some caustic remarks.

Temperamentally, Hiccupâ€™s trained dragon, Toothless, is one part horse to two parts dog. Both movies, but especially â€œDragon 2,â€ù demonstrate that dragons come in all shapes, sizes and colors, and that not all are friendly. The movie doesnâ€™t go overboard in trying to humanize its dragons, which have dragon-y quirks, like casually setting fires that must be extinguished.

The narrative coup of â€œDragon 2â€ù is its introduction of a major new player, Valka (Cate Blanchett), Hiccupâ€™s long-lost mother and Stoickâ€™s wife, who was abducted by a dragon 20 years earlier. This â€œcrazy, feral, vigilante dragon lady,â€ù in the words of one character, is no such thing. A beautiful woman with the face of a Celtic goddess and a mellifluous voice, she has devoted her life to saving dragons kidnapped by Eret and sheltering them in a secret Arctic hideaway. This retreat may be the most magical of all the movieâ€™s exotic settings.

Many of those collaborators are now lost to AIDS. But Ms. Goldin, who turns 61 in September, touches only lightly on the emotional and physical bruises that give so much of her work its raw potency. Leaving the more painful snapshots to tell their own story, she matches the filmâ€™s warm, just-before-sunset glow â€” even the indoor scenes have a coppery sheen â€” with smoky musings on religion, self-injury and falling in love with beautiful, sometimes gay men. Listening silently and invisibly, Ms. Lidl provides a respectful, intimate frame for these confidences: cherished memories of a time when friend, lover and subject were often one and the same.

Charmingly slight and casually confessional, this fond, fly-on-the-wall portrait by Sabine Lidl tags along with Ms. Goldin on a sentimental journey from Paris to Berlin, where longtime friends and lovers wait to supplement her candid reminiscences. Images of the extended family of artists, drug addicts and drag queens she once lived among and photographed â€” most of whom wound up in her 1979-96 masterwork, â€œThe Ballad of Sexual Dependencyâ€ù â€” flip beneath her fingers, a collage of defenseless bodies in bathtubs, bars and rumpled beds.

A long time ago, a doctor told the photographer Nan Goldin that she had the genes of an Olympic athlete. Just as well: Even while eliding the details of her colorful, adventurous past, â€œNan Goldin: I Remember Your Faceâ€ù contains enough throwaway references to bodily harm to make her and her admirers grateful for the gifts of biology.

In â€œPoliceman,â€ù Mr. Lapid, making an electrifying feature directing debut, traces the line between the group and the individual in a story that can be read as a commentary on the world as much as on Israel. With a steady camera and cool approach, he devotes the movieâ€™s first part to peeling away Yaronâ€™s life, one layer at a time. Each stratum reveals a new truth about a man who puts up a bland, macho front. His wife, Nili (Meital Berdah), is about to give birth to their first child, a milestone that, with an escalating sense of unease, keeps coming up against another benchmark: charges that, during a raid, Yaron and his team killed some Arab civilians, including a child.

There are moments in â€œPolicemanâ€ù when it feels as if the director Nadav Lapid is drawing one very large noose around his characters. Thatâ€™s especially true early in this hypnotic, slow-building shocker from Israel, before the narrative pieces have slid into place, revealing Mr. Lapidâ€™s intentions. Certainly, nothing looks out of the ordinary in the opening images of five men bicycling up a steep country road. That is until one, Yaron (Yiftach Klein), breaks away and begins riding so hard and fast toward the camera that he looks as if he might break through the screen.

Suddenly, there are two stories where there was one, and a movie that, as it pits one group against another, becomes bracingly dialectical. The shooters are would-be Jewish revolutionaries whose members include a blank-faced blonde, Shira (Yaara Pelzig), and hollow-eyed pretty boy, Nathanael (Michael Aloni). Together with their fellow travelers, Shira and Nathanael are planning a violent action, one with its own revolutionary tract. â€œIt is time for the poor to get rich,â€ù Shira reads from the unfinished tract, â€œand the rich to start dying.â€ù She fusses over the prose, but when she mentions Theodor Herzl, a founder of modern Zionism, Nathanael tells her to cut the reference. He doesnâ€™t want Herzl to confuse matters even if itâ€™s clear that for Mr. Lapid everything about Israeli identity, body and soul, is at stake.

This close attention to the physicality of these characters takes on new meaning with the abrupt introduction of three other men and one woman. Much like Yaron and his policemen brethren, these four are first seen in the countryside, walking in pointed isolation. Theyâ€™re attractive, young, perhaps college age, and seem to be out on a day hike, and when they stop and stand side by side, their image mirrors an earlier one of Yaron and his friends yelling their names across a valley. â€œThis is,â€ù one of the policemen had exclaimed, just before they began shouting, â€œthe most beautiful country in the world.â€ù The four new travelers donâ€™t say anything as memorable; instead, each pulls out a gun and begins firing.

Initially, Mr. Lapidâ€™s forceful visual style â€” characterized by his claustrophobic framing, steady camerawork and strongly graphic yet uncluttered compositions â€” is so distinctive that the plot can almost seem to be an afterthought. Again and again, he strips the characters down and carefully arranges their forms within the frame, giving you ample time to travel across the crests and planes of Yaronâ€™s muscled torso and the rising moon of Niliâ€™s swollen belly. There can be tenderness in Mr. Lapidâ€™s gaze, and heat, particularly in the scenes in which Yaron massages Nili with oil, kneading her flesh in a near-pantomime of sex. Yet thereâ€™s also a diagnostic aspect to Mr. Lapidâ€™s scrutiny, as if he were searching for something in all these arrangements of limbs and faces.

He doesnâ€™t, even if he continues to loom meaningfully large. Along with the other bikers, Yaron works in an antiterrorism unit. Itâ€™s a tight, all-male group, consisting of men who are friends, colleagues, brothers. They look similar, with close-cropped hair and taut, powerful bodies. When one checks out anotherâ€™s woman, there are smiles and laughs all around. When one is ill, the others hang their heads in monkish silence or clap a loving hand on his body. There is beauty in their resemblances, in how they swagger into a room together, collectively turn to admire a young waitress and finish one anotherâ€™s sentences, yet thereâ€™s also something predatory and packlike.

Yet, in some ways, a subtler story is told through the stronger hand of the filmâ€™s cinematographer, AgnÃ¨s Godard. Ms. Godard, known for her collaboration with the filmmaker Claire Denis, suggests an entire movie with Claudiaâ€™s first visit to the household: a five-minute running take that segues from one character to the next with roving shots that are like internal monologues. And the way she shoots and lights the face of Wendy (Wendy GuillÃ©n), Marthaâ€™s heavyset teenage daughter, hiding under a mop of hair, says just as much as an unexpected scene about her cutting her arms and making drug cocktails.
But if thereâ€™s a certain depth missing in â€œThe Amazing Catfish,â€ù the film brings forth the small-scale pleasures and poignancy of an ambling short story.

The Mexican director Claudia Sainte-Luce orchestrates the beginning of â€œThe Amazing Catfishâ€ù to show her sluggish main character â€” a young supermarket clerk, also named Claudia â€” finally waking up, in a manner of speaking. First she literally awakens, in an ineffably eerie, dimly lighted scene. But itâ€™s during a sudden hospital visit, in a room with an older woman named Martha (Lisa Owen), that she feels the unfamiliar tug of family.

Offered a ride home, Claudia (Ximena Ayala) soon finds herself caught up in the lives of Martha and her four children, to the point of sleeping over and helping out with errands. In Ms. Sainte-Luceâ€™s story of an outsiderâ€™s finding a new home, the familyâ€™s bustling harmony harbors an ache thatâ€™s maybe not solely a result of Marthaâ€™s serious illness.

â€œIvory Tower,â€ù a documentary about soaring costs and other problems confronting higher education, canâ€™t seem to decide what points it wants to make and ends up making none. Parts of it seem like free advertising for the institutions it visits, which include Harvard, Arizona State University and experimental institutions like Deep Springs College. Other parts sound the already familiar lament that students come out of college with crushing debts and no prospects for the kinds of jobs that would enable them to pay off those debts. There are suggestions that colleges do a poor job of actually educating students, and that the cost issue is a result of bloated administrative salaries and a rush to build showpiece campuses.

All of it is treated in scattershot fashion, with the film never alighting long on any one topic. The exception is its preoccupation with the battle at Cooper Union last year to keep that institution tuition-free â€” hardly a representative or illuminating example of anything relevant to the sea of graduates (and their parents) who did not have the luxury of a no-cost education.

The film, directed by Andrew Rossi, is at its best when it explores broader concepts, like the evolution of thinking about who is entitled to higher education and how it should be financed. But the film is a primer, at best, on complicated matters that need specific solutions.
â€œIvory Towerâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned), presumably because a few campus parties are depicted.

Am I a hardhearted meanie because I watched â€œLullaby,â€ù a solemn, triple-hankie sobfest about assisted suicide, in a state of dry-eyed impatience? Maybe so. But â€œLullaby,â€ù the directorial debut of Andrew Levitas, a jack of all artistic trades, is the kind of manipulative, clichÃ©-infested hokum that alienates moviegoers by its insistence on hogging all the tears. Its subliminal message â€” â€œIâ€™m more sensitive than you could possibly beâ€ù â€” is exclusionary, and much of its stilted dialogue (â€œItâ€™s hard to love someone whoâ€™s got an expiration date stamped on their foreheadâ€ù) is cringe worthy.

Robert is the most likable character, but he is no paragon of patriarchal benignity. Although he is wealthy, he informs his children that because they are spoiled, he is leaving them nothing. They seem bizarrely unfazed. Robertâ€™s devoted wife, Rachel (Anne Archer), has all the personality of a sopping dishrag that has to be wrung out every few minutes. There is a subplot about their Jewishness, but except for the family name (Lowenstein) and a lifeless, perfunctory scene of a Seder dinner, they have no markedly Jewish characteristics.

It doesnâ€™t help that for much of the movie, the central character, Jonathan (Garrett Hedlund), a surly 26-year-old rock musician who oozes the rancid narcissism of a jaded babe magnet with hipster pretensions, is practically begging for a punch in the face. He is the kind of entitled brat who pulls out a pack of cigarettes and lights up on an airplane.

His 23-year-old sister, Karen (Jessica Brown Findlay), a law student, is an equally obnoxious piece of work who insists on delivering a speech to their dying father, Robert (Richard Jenkins), about the constitutional prohibitions against disconnecting him from his respirator. She goes so far as to file an injunction to prevent the plug from being pulled.
â€œLullabyâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strong language and brief drug use.
Lo and behold, with their help, Jonathan turns out to be a human being after all, and everyone can collapse in a tearful huddle as Robert finally â€” and mercifully â€” expires.

It gets worse. To open Jonathanâ€™s heart, the screenplay throws in two bogus catalysts. One is his ex-girlfriend (Amy Adams), who wanders around the fringes of the movie waiting for this tin man to feel something. The other is a dying 17-year-old patient (Jessica Barden) with late-stage bone-marrow cancer. Jonathan befriends her and grants her request that he take her to a make-believe prom in her heavily decorated hospital room.

Perhaps too slow, as the filmâ€™s methodical pacing and often elliptical dialogue (these are characters who have learned to choose their words very carefully) demand a commitment to the early scenes that takes a while to pay off. By the midway point, however, we feel the clammy grip of a measured political thriller as the story hops between the comfortable Tehran home of a chronically disabled writer and the unsavory road trip of two government-hired killers.

Shot on the fly, with the cast and crew unnamed to avoid reprisals, â€œManuscripts Donâ€™t Burnâ€ù (the title is a quotation from a novel by the Russian writer Mikhail Bulgakov) unfolds in appropriately wintry light. Its violence is low-tech â€” a clothespin and a suppository feature prominently â€” and its look is old-school, but its message could not possibly be more momentous.

Depicting his combustible material with a cool head and a steady hand, the Iranian filmmaker Mohammad Rasoulof â€” defying a 20-year government ban on his work â€” makes â€œManuscripts Donâ€™t Burnâ€ù a slow-motion explosion of anti-authoritarian rage.

Their mission is to track down copies of a manuscript that the writer plans to publish privately. Its subject is the governmentâ€™s attempted assassination of a busload of intellectuals many years earlier â€” a potential embarrassment to a powerful state censor who once shared the writerâ€™s beliefs. Contrasting the high-minded battle of words between these two men with the gruff efficiency of the killers (one of whom enjoys a snack while watching a victim slowly expire), Mr. Rasoulof seems to be mourning the futility of fighting oppression with argument alone.

â€œTest,â€ù set in San Francisco in 1985, captures with extraordinary precision and sensitivity the moment when an H.I.V. test became available, and the cityâ€™s gay men faced the daunting prospect of finding out their status. In those scary days, there was no pharmaceutical regimen that could arrest the disease. And as one man, looking ahead to a future of sexual self-discipline, puts it, â€œMonogamy seems so unnatural.â€ù In the golden era of promiscuity and unprotected sex, the notion of suddenly having to use condoms seemed almost an affront, not to mention inconvenient.

Frankie and his friend Todd (Matthew Risch), a rakish company member who is considering hustling for extra money, have an edgy relationship. Todd, a self-described â€œslut,â€ù gently bullies Frankie, although underneath the conflict simmers a mutual attraction. Frankie and the other male dancers are seen continually examining themselves in the mirror for signs of that dreaded AIDS marker, Kaposiâ€™s sarcoma. An undercurrent of high anxiety seems to run through the company, and one nervous woman asks Todd to wipe off his perspiration.

As Frankie, Mr. Marlowe delivers a quiet, moving performance of such subtlety and truthfulness that you almost feel that you are living his life. In this extremely body-conscious, beautifully lighted film, you notice every skin blemish and are made aware of the mechanics of each complicated dance movement. The period details â€” from tangled telephone cords, to the Sports Walkman Frankie carries, to the period pop music (Sylvester, Bronski Beat) â€” feel right. Here is San Francisco as it was in its bohemian twilight, on the eve of catastrophe.

When not observing the rigorous rehearsals, â€œTestâ€ù follows Frankieâ€™s life during this period of enormous unexpressed fear. His straight roommate leaves to move in with his girlfriend, and Frankie begins an affair with an attractive new partner he meets in a bar but who abruptly decides to leave the city. On a whim, Todd, an intrepid hedonist, persuades Frankie to take Ecstasy with him, and the trip brings them closer together. After several days of contemplation, Frankie musters the courage to take the H.I.V. test, whose results he wonâ€™t receive for two weeks.

The movie, written and directed by Chris Mason Johnson, focuses on Frankie (Scott Marlowe), a shy, slender, handsome understudy in a small dance company, most of whose male members are gay. Even so, Frankie is criticized from within because he doesnâ€™t â€œdance like a man,â€ù although he is by no means conspicuously effeminate. The company is rehearsing a piece titled â€œAfter Dark.â€ù Choreographed by Sidra Bell, it is a twisty, shadowy work of considerable power in which the men dance shirtless. Its ominous, erotic subtext refers obliquely to the epidemic and the fear of infection, but in a spirit of sexual defiance.
â€œThe Roverâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian). Grisly violence and foul language.

Mr. MichÃ´dâ€™s first feature, â€œAnimal Kingdom,â€ù was a brutal and pungent tour of the Melbourne underworld, brought alive by spring-loaded performances (Jacki Weaverâ€™s, supremely) and a gamy, violent sense of humor. This time, he demonstrates once again that he has a knack for violence and suspense. (The sound design in particular is brilliantly sinister.) But he canâ€™t find much of interest beyond the puffed-up, stripped-down glumness that is this genreâ€™s default mood.

Reyâ€™s presence situates â€œThe Roverâ€ù awkwardly between fable and buddy picture. He may not be as dumb as he at first appears, but at the same time, itâ€™s hard to tell much about him, given Mr. Pattinsonâ€™s curious accent (Kentucky? Cajun? Tongue-tied vampire?) and his incessant twitching. Mr. Pearce, in contrast, is all stoical stillness, and watching his actions turns the movie into a not entirely unengaging guessing game. Whatâ€™s this character all about? He shoots a few people in ways that suggest a sociopathic temperament and sheds a few tears that hint at a sensitive soul beneath the whiskers and the grime.

â€œThe Rover,â€ù David MichÃ´dâ€™s new film, takes place in Australia 10 years after an unspecified event called the Collapse, which has left everyone in a bad mood and catastrophically short of shaving supplies. This is not quite the apocalyptic ground zero of â€œThe Roadâ€ù or â€œThe Road Warriorâ€ù (speaking of Down Under dystopias). Roving bands of armed men drive around shooting, but some of them wear uniforms and fill out government paperwork when they catch someone. Money still works (American dollars are preferred over Australian), and there seems to be enough food, gasoline and ammunition to keep everybody alert, mobile and angry.

Early in the film, as Eric is sipping a drink at a dusty makeshift cantina, a pickup full of clownish thugs spins out of control on the road. The truckâ€™s occupants help themselves to Ericâ€™s car, which irks him mightily. Since they left behind their own vehicle, which is in fine running order, you might think that he could let the offense go. But thatâ€™s not how things work around here; and before long, he has set off in pursuit, in the company of a gutshot nitwit named Rey (Robert Pattinson), whose brother (Scoot McNairy) is one of the car thieves.

There is both too much story and not enough. The contours of this desolate future are lightly sketched rather than fully explained, which is always a good choice. But that minimalism serves as an excuse for an irritating lack of narrative clarity, so that much of what happens seems arbitrary rather than haunting. And at the same time, the relationship between Eric and Rey, as it develops into something almost tender, feels as familiar and simplistic as the nihilism that surrounds them.

The angriest and shaggiest man between the horizon and the nearest dust cloud is a fellow named Eric, played by Guy Pearce. (There are very few women around. Only three, most memorably a mysterious grandmother played by Gillian Jones, say anything.)

Mr. Eubank plays with our minds, and Nicâ€™s, for a while, and calls on the services of â€œThe Matrixâ€ù godhead Laurence Fishburne, intoning amusedly from within a Hazmat suit. (Conspicuous throughout, however, is the lazy treatment of Haleyâ€™s character.)

William Eubankâ€™s â€œThe Signalâ€ù demonstrates the fine line between paranoid science-fiction fantasy and demo reel. Both involve impressive visions of reality reimagined, and both defy logic extravagantly and yet somehow casually, too. Mr. Eubankâ€™s diverting but disconnected film might fairly be described as a little bit of each.

The grandiosity of the filmâ€™s setups partly fits in with the guysâ€™ sense of righteous-geek drama, and you wouldnâ€™t be surprised to see Mr. Eubank directing a bigger-budget movie down the road, but this film demonstrates some blanks in his approach that still need to be filled in.

In the movieâ€™s road-trip run-up, two hacker buddies, Nic (Brenton Thwaites) and Jonah (Beau Knapp), set out to ferry Nicâ€™s girlfriend, Haley (Olivia Cooke), to her new university. The boys become fixated on the taunts of a devious Internet show-off, who sends them on a detour to an empty bunker in the sticks.
