â€œThe Signalâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for some thematic elements, violence and language.

The real Leduc (1907-1972) was a messy, mesmerizing piece of work who rose from the demimonde into the most rarefied Parisian literary circles through her talent, friendships, hardships, spleen and a blazing, indomitable will. She was born to an unmarried servant, Berthe Leduc, and AndrÃ© Debaralle, the son of the wealthy family for whom Berthe worked. AndrÃ© never formally recognized his daughter, bequeathing her a lifelong indignity that plagued and inspired Leduc, including in â€œLa BÃ¢tardeâ€ù (â€œThe Bastardâ€ù), a 1964 memoir. â€œIt was inside your belly,â€ù Leduc writes in that book, addressing her mother, â€œthat I lived your shame.â€ù Berthe, Leduc continues, â€œcould not forgive men as a whole for what she had done for one man.â€ù Neither could she forgive her daughter the same wound.

In her book â€œThe Pleasures of the Text: Violette Leduc and Reader Seduction,â€ù Elizabeth Locey argues that for Leduc, writing is at once an attempt to seduce her readers and find salvation through them. That may be true of many writers, but it feels particularly touching for someone who felt as unloved as Leduc did. When she wrote about her time living with Sachs, Leduc admitted that she bored him with her piteous tales about her childhood, but also wrote, â€œI am courting him with my misfortunes.â€ù Itâ€™s a startlingly naked admission that Mr. Provost embraces in a film that conveys how Violetteâ€™s storytelling â€” as with Scheherazade and countless others â€” is also a means of survival. (Mr. Provost directed â€œSÃ©raphine,â€ù about the French painter SÃ©raphine de Senlis.)

When you first see Violette in Martin Provostâ€™s handsome, intelligently absorbing and stirring biographical portrait sheâ€™s sneaking through the dark with a suitcase full of black-market goods, which creates quite the vivid, existential snapshot. Itâ€™s World War II and Violette is living unhappily in the country with a gay writer, Maurice Sachs (Olivier Py), with whom sheâ€™s in love. She plucks at him, desire mixing with desperation. Here, as throughout the film, Mr. Provost and Ms. Devos donâ€™t try to make you like Violette and you donâ€™t, necessarily, even when you feel for her. Maurice pushes her away and tells her to start writing, which she does, scratching out what becomes her first novel, â€œLâ€™Asphyxie,â€ù published in English as â€œIn the Prison of Her Skin.â€ù

They meet or, rather, Violette somewhat stalks Simone, who a stern, appealing Sandrine Kiberlain plays as a cross between a dominatrix and a mother superior. Simone becomes an inspiration for Violette, as well as a coolly aloof object of desire, and their relationship fascinates for obvious reasons. More important, it feels true in its complexities and contradictions, in its emotional push and psychological pull. It also serves as a lifeline for Violette, something she clings to during her frantic desperation, stubborn poverty, emotional squalls and messy friendships, including with Jean Genet (Jacques BonaffÃ©), and a perfumer-patron, Jacques GuÃ©rin (Olivier Gourmet). Violetteâ€™s hold on life can be terrifying, at times ugly, but what she finally makes of that life is beautiful.

Working from a script he wrote with two others, Mr. Provost doesnâ€™t try to fill in every detail of Violetteâ€™s life. Rather, after starting her story when she begins to write, he leaps across time, jumping from one defining moment to the next, the meaning of which may be revealed only later. In one scene, after Maurice and Violette have separated, she visits a Parisian apartment to sell some goods, her flashy clothing and bleach job clashing with the flatâ€™s bourgeois restraint. There she meets an acquaintance who tells her that Maurice has been arrested, and that she may be able to help. The point of the scene seems to be Mauriceâ€™s fate (and her hardness), although later it becomes clear that it is also about her fate because itâ€™s here that Violette notices a book by someone named Simone de Beauvoir.

In â€œViolette,â€ù Emmanuelle Devos plays one of those impossible women who canâ€™t give anyone, most of all herself, a break. For Violette Leduc, a black marketeer turned celebrated writer, life is a series of crushing disappointments, from the mother who never took her hand to the friends who never stay. Early in the film when a friend leaves the home they share, he sneaks out like a thief. He knows her too well. She doesnâ€™t let him go; rather, she chases him down a road, frantically pulling at him and howling. This is a woman who doesnâ€™t feed on misery: She gorges on it.

â€œWitching & Bitchingâ€ù is mostly good fun, though it doesnâ€™t quite sustain its anarchic energy by the time it begins to remake â€œThe Wicker Man,â€ù with the substitution of a giant Venus of Willendorf monster. The busy, effects-laden climax seems out of proportion to the human comedy (and frog bloodletting) otherwise on display.

Not counting a prologue right out of â€œMacbeth,â€ù the Spanish comedy â€œWitching & Bitchingâ€ù begins as a madcap heist picture. In Madrid, a group of hapless would-be criminals â€” dressed as a silver Christ, a soldier, Minnie Mouse, the Invisible Man and SpongeBob SquarePants â€” steals gold from a pawnshop.

These convoluted robberies rarely go according to plan. (Bullets give SpongeBob a few more holes.) Then, during the getaway, JosÃ© (Hugo Silva) discovers that the son heâ€™s brought along (Gabriel Delgado) â€” itâ€™s Dadâ€™s day for custody, after all â€” has left homework at the scene of the crime.

The stickup men have bigger problems. An attempted escape to France lands them in Zugarramurdi, a Spanish border town known for its association with witchcraft. There, a family coven prepares to host what one character describes as a medieval kegger.

Known for his genre pastiches, the director, ÃÅlex de la Iglesia (â€œEl Crimen Perfectoâ€ù), rarely lets the pace flag, and the buddy comedy, gross-out humor and horror elements make for a harmonious mix. (There are also oblique hints of politics, with allusions to the economic crisis and â€” given the witchesâ€™ Basque name â€” issues of national identity.)

Seemingly oblivious to scrutiny, his subjects interact with an easy naturalism as commonplace events (the birth of a baby; the death of a deer) unfold in movie-long arcs. Yet thereâ€™s a stillness to the filmmaking, coupled with Saunder Jurriaans and Danny Bensiâ€™s truly lovely original score, that lends specific shots â€” toddlers bundled up like pastel Ewoks on a snowdrift, or a bakery window glowing like a still life in a gallery â€” a near-heartbreaking melancholy. â€œNorthern Lightâ€ù contains more than one competition, but what itâ€™s really about is the difference between trying to win and trying not to lose.

The filmâ€™s publicity materials may describe it as a portrait of snowmobile racers, but the actual race â€” a grueling, 500-mile slog on sheer ice â€” commandeers only a fraction of screen time. Its anticipation, however, is a unifying thread, an aspirational undercurrent to the familiesâ€™ quotidian struggles. Money is tight, and jobs are precarious; and as the movie slowly accumulates worries over house payments and health care, the $10,000 prize becomes a life-changing brass ring.

Parking his camera in church and truck stops, at family dinners and the gym, Mr. Bentgen is an impassive onlooker who offers no voice-over and only a minimum of on-screen information. Shooting wide and high, he assembles a collage of contrasts: chilly exteriors and warm, bustling interiors; financial fragility and money-no-object generosity; physical degeneration and emotional sturdiness.

Cool in tone and temperature, Nick Bentgenâ€™s â€œNorthern Lightâ€ù turns white vistas and blue language into a sneakily compelling, endlessly patient observation of three working-class families in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.

â€œA Picture of You,â€ù the feature debut from J. P. Chan, who wrote and directed, looks at one of the less cinematic aspects of grieving: packing up a house after a parent has died. A brother and sister, Kyle (Andrew Pang) and Jen (Jo Mei), spend the weekend at their motherâ€™s Pennsylvania home. Purging her computer, they discover evidence of a romantic life neither wishes to ponder.

The mysteryâ€™s resolution is disappointing but irrelevant; â€œA Picture of Youâ€ù is more interested in sketching familial drift. Mr. Chanâ€™s skill with actors â€” particularly with Ms. Mei and Mr. Pangâ€™s persuasive, easygoing banter â€” compensates for the storyâ€™s limitations.

This sort of â€œBig Chillâ€ù getaway has been a staple of filmmakers from John Sayles to Joe Swanberg, yet even with a furtive pot-smoking sequence, â€œA Picture of Youâ€ù subverts clichÃ©. Thereâ€™s enormous warmth when the hipster-ish Doug earnestly picks the wrong time to seek Kyleâ€™s permission to propose to Jen, and a matter-of-factness to the filmâ€™s reflections on Asian-American identity. (â€œDid you just racially profile us?â€ù the kids awkwardly joke whenever theyâ€™re recognized as Judyâ€™s children.)

Should they investigate? For most of â€œA Picture of You,â€ù the mother, Judy (Jodi Long in flashbacks), exists as a structuring absence, evoked through othersâ€™ descriptions and the traces sheâ€™s left behind (such as notes in books). The two siblings have little in common. Kyle, who cared for their mom during her illness, is reeling from divorce. Jen treats the weekend as a social occasion, having invited over her boyfriend, Doug (Lucas Dixon), and a friend, Mika (Teyonah Parris, Dawn on â€œMad Menâ€ù).

While waiting for her, Gaspard is pursued by SolÃ¨ne (GwenaÃ«lle Simon), a friend of Margotâ€™s who insists that they not sleep together immediately. Initially, at least, Gaspard is besotted. These three concurrent relationships tighten into an uncomfortable knot when Gaspard makes multiple commitments to accompany each woman on a short trip to the nearby island of Ouessant.

â€œA Summerâ€™s Taleâ€ù shares a deep kinship with Richard Linklaterâ€™s â€œBeforeâ€ù trilogy, whose first chapter, â€œBefore Sunrise,â€ù was released in 1995. Rohmerâ€™s first seasonal film, â€œA Tale of Springtime,â€ù came out in 1990. Both directorsâ€™ movies are dominated by their charactersâ€™ conversations, which have a way of going around in circles and turning into verbal chess matches.

Their conversations are the spine of a screenplay in which every relationship is a paradoxical dialogue. The more precise and honest the characters try to be, the more they dissemble, often unknowingly. Rohmer captures like no other director a complicated mixture of innocence, impulsiveness and calculation in courtship. In these sophisticated romantic maneuvers, mind games take precedence over sex.

Although â€œA Summerâ€™s Taleâ€ù is only 18 years old, its pace is so measured, and the culture it surveys so placid and homogeneous, that superficially it now feels a half-century behind the times. Because the films of Rohmer, who died four years ago at 89, represent the ne plus ultra of a serene, thoughtful European classicism, this is a slightly mixed blessing. It includes no intimations of future shock, no harbingers of the jangly, wired-up 21st century. But without those distractions, â€œA Summerâ€™s Taleâ€ù has room to focus on Rohmerâ€™s brilliance at revealing human nature through articulate, multidimensional characters, perfectly cast, who in some ways seem to exist outside of time.

Rohmerâ€™s movies exhibit the palpable yearning and nostalgia of a much older man looking back at youth through rose-tinted glasses. His world is very circumscribed. If you are white, well educated and comfortably situated, it may feel like heaven. But for everyone else, it is an exclusive gated community with 24-hour security.

The four main characters, all in their 20s, care about their appearances, but they donâ€™t obsess about their looks. As they play the mating game, they are discreetly competitive but far from cutthroat. This gorgeous movie has such an exquisite sensitivity to subtle changes in the light and weather that it makes you feel as if you were living at the beach.

Eric Rohmer, the French New Wave master, was in his mid-70s when â€œA Summerâ€™s Tale,â€ù the third installment of his â€œTales of the Four Seasonsâ€ù cycle, was released abroad in 1996. The only one of the cycleâ€™s four films not distributed in the United States, it is finally having an American release, and it was worth the wait.

â€œI feel as if the world exists around me, but Iâ€™m not there,â€ù he explains to Margot (Amanda Langlet), a gregarious ethnology student working for the summer as a waitress. â€œI donâ€™t exist. Iâ€™m transparent, invisible.â€ù

In the languid world of â€œA Summerâ€™s Tale,â€ù there is nary a sign of a computer. Telephone communication is conducted over landlines. The tempo of life in the Breton resort town of Dinard, where the story is set, is leisurely, and even the local nightclubbing is subdued. The bodies of the summer bathers are lithe and attractive but reveal no signs of aggressive fitness training or cosmetic enhancement.

Although Margot has a boyfriend overseas, she latches on to Gaspard. As they go for long walks in which they discuss their romantic lives, she subtly signals her interest in being more than friends. Itâ€™s a knowing, witty depiction of an expertly deployed strategy of advance and retreat.

Of the two, Rohmer is the more romantic. From a contemporary perspective, Rohmerâ€™s reveries seem idyllic. As his characters chatter about their relationships, he views them with a keen critical eye tempered by a grandfatherly affection, and takes their amorous dilemmas almost as seriously as they do, while remaining at a polite distance. There are no indications of prurience. In Mr. Linklaterâ€™s films, each side erupts at any second, and the verbal combat can be noisy.

Gaspard has arrived in Dinard expecting to meet LÃ©na (AurÃ©lia Nolin), his sometime girlfriend, who isnâ€™t there when he arrives. She has left no word of when she might appear. When she finally shows up without advance notice, she is a moody, imperious beauty who calls the shots and tells him that in the opinion of her cousins, he doesnâ€™t â€œmeasure up.â€ù

â€œA Summerâ€™s Taleâ€ù focuses on the romantic coupling and uncoupling of Gaspard (Melvil Poupaud), a lean, introverted, bushy-haired math student, aspiring musician and self-described loner suffering from what a therapist might call social anxiety disorder.

Whether talking to the camera or one another, Dr. McGarry and his fellow residents offer a perspective thatâ€™s overwhelmingly young, principled, caring and frustrated. Their ardent and photogenic accord is one of the filmâ€™s weaknesses â€” elder physicians have only slivers of screen time â€” but also an inarguable boon, giving their daily skirmishes with Americaâ€™s battered health care system a fiery momentum that pulls you along.

Slicing through the fat of policy debates to the visceral rush of critical care, the narrative combines existential worries (â€œHow do I protect the ideals I came here for?â€ù) and blood-and-guts immediacy with a seamlessness that made me want to high-five the editor, Joshua Altman (who also shared writing duties with Dr. McGarry). Hooked on the battlefield ambience of the hospitalâ€™s famed trauma bay, known as C-booth, the doctors mourn when earthquake-resistance codes demand a move to brand-new quarters in 2008. Soul-crushing paperwork and spirit-stifling regulations follow.
Idealism and reality collide in â€œCode Black,â€ù Dr. Ryan McGarryâ€™s impassioned record of his training in the embattled emergency room of the Los Angeles County General Hospital.

A vigorous companion piece to Peter Nicksâ€™s revealing 2012 documentary, â€œThe Waiting Room,â€ù â€œCode Blackâ€ù (the title describes the emergency roomâ€™s saturation point) is a keening cri de coeur. Warriors for the neediest among us â€” the unauthorized, Â  uninsured and just plain unlucky â€” Dr. McGarry and his cohort save plenty of lives. What theyâ€™re most in danger of losing is hope.

At some point, though, Mr. Byrkit turns one too many corners (characters, meanwhile, begin bustling in and out of rooms like Marx Brothers extras), and what began as a nifty puzzle feels more like a trap. It may be possible to unkink this story, but when characters and performances are as unengaging as these, itâ€™s hard to feel motivated to try. Mr. Byrkit shot the movie â€” which has a blurred, low-end digital look and a lot of small-screen-ready close-ups â€” without a script in his living room, setting the performers loose for five days of improvisation. Itâ€™s the kind of experiment that may be useful for directors and actors, but here hasnâ€™t led to a satisfyingly realized movie.

Directed by James Ward Byrkit, from a story he devised with Alex Manugian, â€œCoherenceâ€ù largely takes place in a few rooms in a house tucked into an unidentified American neighborhood. There, eight lovers and friends gather together for a would-be convivial evening of food, wine and yammer that soon takes a turn for the woo-woo warped. First, though, hugs and pleasantries are exchanged while metaphoric daggers are politely brandished, most by Em (Emily Foxler), whoâ€™s unsettled that her boyfriend, Kevin (Maury Sterling), once dated another guest, Laurie (Lauren Mahler). This friction functions as something of a red herring while Mr. Byrkit readies his inciting incident.

Itâ€™s a commonplace that speculative fiction speaks to the anxieties percolating in its age. Such seems the case with the likes of â€œEdge of Tomorrow,â€ù which kinks up its narrative by repeatedly cycling back to the past, suggesting that complex theories about space-time are now so mainstream that theyâ€™re the stuff of mass entertainment. The same might be said of the far more modest â€œCoherence,â€ù although itâ€™s also true that digital tools, which allow directors to shoot fast, cheap and sometimes sloppily, are also helping pry loose linear narrativeâ€™s hold on movies.

That proves to be a comet passing over the Earth, which, or so Em insists, may explain why everyoneâ€™s cellphone has gone dead. Soon, the dinner party faces a profoundly more severe crisis when it appears that the comet may have wreaked havoc on the guestsâ€™ sanity, their perception of reality, or perhaps time and space itself. Whatever the case, something weird is happening, and, it soon seems, the people in a nearby house look an awful lot like the progressively freaked-out dinner guests. If that sounds confusing, it eventually is, even if, at first, Mr. Byrkit does a nice job of plotting the storyâ€™s complex coordinates while coaxing the characters (and you) into his maze.

The real star of â€œExhibition,â€ù the third feature by the British filmmaker Joanna Hogg, is an austere but elegant, ultramodern townhouse in West London. Within its chilly spaces, the principal characters have lived and worked for 20 years. Married, childless artists in their 50s, the couple â€” identified only as D (Viv Albertine, an alumna of the rock group the Slits) and H (Liam Gillick, a well-regarded Conceptual artist) â€” work on separate floors connected by an elevator and a spiral staircase, and communicate via intercom.

D is a performance artist whose work obliquely explores sexuality and role-playing. Some of her pieces are solo theatrical displays staged in front of a window facing the street. Because the movie concentrates on D and her fears, it is left unclear exactly what H produces besides intricate architectural designs glimpsed on a computer.

On one level, â€œExhibitionâ€ù is a realistic depiction of a long-term relationship between two people who know each otherâ€™s tics so well that they communicate in verbal shorthand. In one excruciatingly honest moment, H asks for sex, and she obliges by showing up, then lying beside him completely inert. Another astoundingly intimate scene shows her masturbating as H sleeps beside her. Both avow their love at various points, but that love doesnâ€™t relieve the tension between them when H interviews D before a live audience, and she refuses to answer his questions.

The couple are planning to sell the house, which D treasures, although, when left alone there, she is driven into an anxious state by the sounds of its internal workings, amplified to suggest horror movie creaks, groans and clanks. The house isnâ€™t insulated against street noise, and she canâ€™t always determine whether the sounds are emanating from inside or outside. The screech of sirens on the street drives her into a panic, and she rushes outside to discover that it is just a single ambulance.

â€œExhibitionâ€ù is an exquisitely photographed film that requires unusually close attention for it to reveal itself. Even then, it is very withholding of psychological information and rarely voices ideas. But we get the notion that D is high-strung and passive-aggressive, and that H is a bit of a bully.

D is an impatient person who, during a dinner party with neighbors, becomes so bored by the chitchat that she pretends to faint so that she and H can leave immediately. It is a stunt she has pulled before.

There are longueurs â€” especially such scenes of socializing â€” that would try the patience of many filmgoers. Still, if â€œExhibitionâ€ù lacks conventionally developed characters and dialogue, it is visually enthralling. There is the interior itself, with its sliding panels, severe geometric design and blocks of color that in some shots suggest a painting by Mondrian. But the most intriguing tableaus study the world glimpsed through the slats of wall-length Venetian blinds that thoroughly confuse a view of the outside world with what is reflected inside the house. The metaphoric implications are as endless as a hall of mirrors. Interior and exterior: Where does one end, and the other begin?

What distinguishes â€œFonzyâ€ù is its attention to Diegoâ€™s Galician roots. As his character discovers his offspring and his paternal instinct, Mr. Garcia gives the bedraggled but compassionate Diego an aspect slightly more emphatic than his screen forebears. (His ease with Ms. Doval, who has directed him before, is plainly evident.)

Diego Costa (JosÃ© Garcia) is a feckless if amiable 42-year-old who regularly donated his sperm for research purposes 20 years ago, using the name Fonzy (no relation to Fonzie, Henry Winklerâ€™s â€œHappy Daysâ€ù character). A pothead with a vintage pinball machine at home, he is a variation on the moviesâ€™ overfamiliar man-child template. Now Diego learns he has sired 533 children, 142 of whom are looking for him. Oh, and his no-nonsense girlfriend (Audrey Fleurot) is pregnant by him, too. But by customary means.

Other presences â€” Lucien Jean-Baptiste, as the harried best friend contending with an unruly brood; the alternately icy and ardent Ms. Fleurot; and likable actors playing the children, including Alison Wheeler, FranÃ§ois Civil and Solal Forte â€” help immeasurably. On the soundtrack, the French pop group We Were Evergreen offers additional gloss with approximations of the better-known French band Phoenix.

If the premise of â€œFonzyâ€ù sounds familiar, it should. Itâ€™s been done twice recently, by Ken Scott: in the QuÃ©bÃ©cois dramedy â€œStarbuckâ€ù and the Hollywood version, â€œDelivery Man,â€ù starring Vince Vaughn. Isabelle Doval directs this French variation, whose commercial sheen offers charms, despite the closely parallel dialogue.

A second strand focuses on Julia (Mila Kunis), a former soap opera star and the hyper-agitated ex-wife of Rick (James Franco), a successful painter. An impatient lawyer, Theresa (Maria Bello), is helping Julia fight for legal visitation rights to see her young son, whom Rick claims Julia put in harmâ€™s way. A scatterbrained mess who is short of cash and always on the verge of a meltdown, Julia is forced to take a job as a hotel chambermaid. Rick is a cold, vindictive narcissist whose anger at her stems partly from guilt over his own neglectful parenting.

The movie, which runs an interminable 137 minutes, is nothing if not ambitious. Mr. Haggis has cited Michelangelo Antonioniâ€™s â€œBlow-Upâ€ù as an inspiration. â€œThird Personâ€ù is so meticulously acted by the ensemble that you are almost seduced into believing that its parts add up to a grand overview of the human condition, especially as it relates to love. But they donâ€™t, because the main characters are shallow, selfish nincompoops, and there is no love in sight â€” just its absence â€” as these mutually suspicious go-getters jockey for advantage.
â€œThird Personâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for nudity, sexual situations and some strong language.

In Paul Haggisâ€™s film â€œThird Person,â€ù Liam Neeson plays Michael, a Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist who has lost his creative mojo and is holed up in a Paris hotel, completing his latest opus. Accompanying him but staying in a separate suite is his girlfriend, Anna (Olivia Wilde), a wacko celebrity journalist who has literary pretensions that Michael is quick to shoot down. They go at each other with the merciless cruelty of two egotists whose only harmonious moments are bouts of frantic sex.

The third plotline concentrates on Scott (Adrien Brody), a weaselly corporate spy in Paris, visiting the city to steal fashions for cheap copies to be rushed into the marketplace. He meets his match in treachery at a place called the Bar Americano, where he puts the moves on Monika (Moran Atias), a beautiful, haughty Roma woman to whom he impulsively gives money after she tells him that her 8-year-old daughter is being held for ransom on a boat. Or at least thatâ€™s what she says. Once Scott becomes involved, the ransom price escalates.

Their story is one of three that run parallel, bump elbows and, at the very end, unconvincingly intersect in the manner of the multiple narratives of â€œCrash,â€ù Mr. Haggisâ€™s Oscar-winning movie. â€œThird Personâ€ù was filmed predominantly on sets at the CinecittÃ  studios in Rome, with that city effectively standing in for Paris and New York, as the film jumps from place to place.

Itâ€™s hard to pinpoint the moment when that sinking feeling sets in, and you realize that these stories arenâ€™t going anywhere in particular and that no ideas will be voiced beyond pseudo-poetic, wince-inducing statements like â€œwhite is the color of trust; it is the color of belief.â€ù The storytelling is infuriatingly coy, as if Mr. Haggis were trying to fool you (and himself) into thinking that he has something to say. â€œThird Personâ€ù finds Mr. Haggis, like Mr. Neesonâ€™s screen alter ego, running on empty.

Thomas and Vanda are confined, for nearly the entire duration of â€œVenus in Fur,â€ù in an empty Paris theater. She has arrived late for an audition, stumbling in from the rain-swept street with a burst of excuse-making and oversharing. Thomas, eager to get home to his fiancÃ©e and frustrated by the actresses he has seen so far, is unsure whether to indulge Vanda or send her away. He is intrigued that she shares her name with the character in his play, a stage adaptation of Leopold von Sacher-Masochâ€™s 1870 novel, â€œVenus in Furs,â€ù though he is also dismayed at her vulgar ignorance of its themes. â€œItâ€™s S-and-M porn, right?â€ù she asks. (Like most things, this sounds much smuttier in French.) He insists that itâ€™s a great love story. But again, why choose?

â€œVenus in Fur,â€ùRoman Polanskiâ€™s nimble film adaptation of the play by David Ives, might provoke a lively post-viewing argument. Is it about sex or power? Art or life? The nature of theater or the logic of desire?

Mr. Polanski, an exile and a fugitive, a Holocaust survivor and a sex offender, has rarely trafficked in explicit autobiography. But in some of his best films, it feels as he is reckoning, at once feverishly and analytically, with his own demons. One of his characteristic preoccupations is claustrophobia. Again and again â€” in â€œRepulsionâ€ù and â€œRosemaryâ€™s Baby,â€ù in â€œThe Pianistâ€ù and â€œCarnageâ€ù â€” he zeros in on characters who are trapped in spaces, physical and emotional, that they can neither control nor escape.

Why choose? And why exclude the possibility that the movie is also about Mr. Polanski himself? Working from a French translation of the play (which was widely acclaimed when it ran on and off Broadway a few years ago), Mr. Polanski has marked the text with his own fingerprints. One of the two characters â€” the splendidly volatile Vanda, an actress â€” is played by Emmanuelle Seigner, his wife. Her foil â€” a writer and theater director named Thomas â€” is played by Mathieu Amalric in a performance that is very close to a Polanski impersonation. Has Mr. Amalricâ€™s stature grown shorter, his nose pointier, or do his haircut and manner simply create the illusion that we are watching a slightly older incarnation of the guy who sliced Jack Nicholsonâ€™s nostril in â€œChinatownâ€ù?

And in spite of her lack of sophistication, Vanda knows the play by heart, so much that Thomas (and the audience) may begin to suspect that she has walked out of its pages, like Madame Bovary in Woody Allenâ€™s â€œKugelmass Episode.â€ù One of the delights of Mr. Ivesâ€™s play, and of Mr. Polanskiâ€™s nimble rendering of it, is the way it jumps in and out of the play within. As relations between actress and director grow more complicated, the boundary between their various actual and artificial selves twists and blurs. Vanda and Thomas keep turning into Vanda and Kushemski, the dreamy aristocrat at the center of Sacher-Masochâ€™s fable.

What is beyond dispute is the sheer exuberant virtuosity Ms. Seigner and Mr. Amalric bring to the material. He is one of the most reliable â€” and also one of the least predictable â€” embodiments of Gallic intellectualism under duress. She is something else entirely: a whirlwind of ferocious intelligence and canny instinct, elusive and magnetic. And she settles the question of what â€œVenus in Furâ€ù is really about. Itâ€™s about acting and the voyeuristic delight, sensual and cerebral in equal measure, that comes from watching it happen.

Their relationship is as kinky as a box of paper clips, at once archetypal and timely. Sacher-Masoch, like the Marquis de Sade now better known for his last name than his writing, filtered his tale of erotic humiliation and blissful pain through the mores of his own time and place. â€œVenus in Furâ€ù does the same, subjecting both Sacher-Masochâ€™s story and its own characters to the pressures of modern sexual politics. When Vanda calls out the sexism of the original, it is hard to argue with her, though it is certainly possible to quarrel about the feminist and misogynist implications of Mr. Polanskiâ€™s film.

â€œNo Tears for the Deadâ€ù is a feat of structural ingenuity. While Gon and Mogyeong speak face to face early on â€” he meets his target in an elevator without revealing his identity â€” they spend most of the movie communicating by cellphone, as the space between them fills up with potential threats, including a team of assassins from Los Angeles and possibly corrupt cops.

The mother may possess a file that contains financial details about a group of Chinese triadsâ€™ offshore accounts â€” a file the earlier shootout was intended to recover.
