In â€œNo Tears for the Dead,â€ù the writer and director Lee Jeong-beomâ€™s convoluted and stylish new action film, a South Korean-born, American-raised hit man with abandonment issues is assigned to assassinate the mother of a little girl he accidentally killed during an earlier hit. (We see this incident in a prologue, scored to a jazz club rendition of â€œSmooth Operator.â€ù)

Like the culinary geniuses of â€œLe Chef,â€ù French cinema may need a new seasonal menu. This light, disposable soufflÃ© from Daniel Cohen at times suggests â€œRatatouilleâ€ù with humans. For a film about mouthwatering cuisine, it offers only fleeting delectable sensations.

There heâ€™s discovered by his idol, Alexandre Lagarde (Jean Reno), a revered but increasingly passÃ© culinarian and TV personality who is about to be fired from his restaurant. The owner (Julien Boisselier) insists that he use cheaper, chemical-laden ingredients.
â€œLe Chefâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Bad wine pairings.

Mr. Cohen gets some laughs from the Mad Libs quality of modern cooking. (Santiago Segura plays a Spanish chef who experiments with liquid nitrogen and â€œfragmentation of duck.â€ù) But the movieâ€™s cultural conservatism also manifests as ethnocentrism. In a cringingly unfunny interlude, Jacky and Alexandre disguise themselves as Japanese tourists to spy on a rival. The scene leaves a sour taste.

The hero is Jacky (MichaÃ«l Youn), an aspiring chef who canâ€™t keep a gig because he has no patience for his customersâ€™ dining habits. After his pregnant girlfriend (RaphaÃ«lle Agogue) puts her foot down, Jacky takes a job painting a retirement home, but sneaks away to compose lavish meals for its residents.

â€œLe Chefâ€ù is primarily an odd-couple farce, as the stern, micromanaging Alexandre takes the authority-flouting Jacky under his wing. The film rises to the defense of what might be called classical French values, celebrating romance, steak frites and the neighborhood grocer in an era it sees as superficially impressed by iPad menus and molecular gastronomy.

The stakes and tension are lower in â€œJersey Boys,â€ù which is narrated largely in chronological order by the groupâ€™s four members, sometimes while theyâ€™re talking right into the camera. Unlike â€œRashomon,â€ù these memoirists donâ€™t necessarily return to the same scenes. Instead, their story opens with some text that sets the place and time (New Jersey, the 1950s) before settling on Tommy DeVito (a charismatic Vincent Piazza), whoâ€™s speed-talking while sauntering down a street. With the camera tagging along, he guides the story into a barbershop, where a young Frankie Castelluccio (John Lloyd Young), is nervously training, as a local gangster, Gyp DeCarlo (Christopher Walken), holds court in a chair, telegraphing the Mobâ€™s role in this story.

The songs and some of the actors pull you into the story even as other performers and some of Mr. Eastwoodâ€™s choices wrench you out. Mr. Young originated the role of Frankie on Broadway, and he persuasively approximates Mr. Valliâ€™s patented strangled falsetto if not its weird beauty. Mr. Young certainly catches your ear and attention when heâ€™s scaling those heights, but once the music fades, so does he. Thatâ€™s partly because the Frankie of â€œJersey Boysâ€ù turns out to be really dull: nice, square and uncomplicated to a fault. That might not matter if Mr. Young were a more expressive screen presence, yet heâ€™s oddly inert, especially around his eyes, which here â€” partly because of Mr. Eastwoodâ€™s fondness for working with a dark, almost monochromatic palette â€” remain frustratingly opaque.

The old-timey milieu of the barbershop, a favorite staging ground for films about the Mafia (including â€œThe Godfatherâ€ù), is an early indication of Mr. Eastwoodâ€™s self-consciously artificial approach. This is cemented in other early scenes, starting with Frankie and his parents slurping spaghetti while throwing around snatches of Italian, all in view of an ornamental wall clock thatâ€™s bracketed by images of the pope and Frank Sinatra. Minutes later, Frankie is out the door, waiting on a dark street and playing lookout for Tommy, whoâ€™s around the corner trying to steal a safe. A beat cop emerges from the shadows with a smile and asks Frankie why heâ€™s out. Frankie says heâ€™s wooing a girl and starts singing as if to prove it.

The whole thing looks and sounds so canned â€” from the conspicuousness of a set thatâ€™s been vacuumed of the dirt of real life to the goofily contrived setup â€” itâ€™s a surprise that the Bowery Boys donâ€™t swing by, too. (Every scene seems to point to another film allusion.) If the family-dinner caricatures register as mildly amusing, the bit with the cop is played even more broadly. The events that immediately follow, showing Tommy, Frankie and a third pal trying to pinch the safe, actually crosses into full-bore slapstick. This escalation from small laughs to big ones helps establish an inaugural breeziness and serves as a reminder that, as a filmmaker and a performer, Mr. Eastwood has long put myth into play with realism.

That tension reverberates throughout â€œJersey Boysâ€ù as a mythopoeic tale emerges from thick accents (dis, dat and da odder), false starts, personnel shifts and name changes. A genius, Bob Gaudio (a very good Erich Bergen), enters the group courtesy of a mutual friend: Joey a.k.a. the future Joe Pesci (an amusing Joseph Russo whoâ€™s got Mr. Pesciâ€™s â€œO.K., O.K.â€ù down). Frankie rechristens himself Valley only to Italianize it as Valli, and then he and the other guys, including Nick Massi (Michael Lomenda), land on the name the Four Seasons. They meet a producer, Bob Crewe (Mike Doyle, very good), and together find their groove. And, in 1962, they begin mining gold, starting with â€œSherryâ€ù and â€œBig Girls Donâ€™t Cry.â€ù

â€œJersey Boysâ€ù at first seems like a curious choice for Mr. Eastwood, particularly given the heft of many of his films. And it may be that he just liked the show. Itâ€™s hard not to think that thereâ€™s something personal here, too, as suggested by the clip from â€œRawhideâ€ù â€” the 1950s television show that broke Mr. Eastwood â€” that plays before a character loses his virginity. This moment could be read as a Hitchcockian cameo or as a slyly suggestive joke about what turns boys into men. Yet, like the movieâ€™s four finally harmonious narrators and its showstopping finale, the cameo is also a reminder that this isnâ€™t just about a group, its struggles and comeback. Itâ€™s also about an American myth of success and all the singing, the smiling and the dissembling that goes into its making.

Itâ€™s disappointing that Mr. Eastwood, a director who can convey extraordinary depths of feeling in his work, didnâ€™t do more with this material. Frankieâ€™s scenes with his family tend to be embarrassingly bad, including a blowout with his wife, Mary (RenÃ©e Marino), that devolves into a wincing battle between the selfish male artist and the volubly unhappy woman at home. Itâ€™s enough to make you wish that movies like these didnâ€™t bother with the little women in the lives of these big men. Worse yet are the scenes with Frankie and his troubled daughter, Francine (played by different performers), whose role here is, appallingly, to do little more than pump her fatherâ€™s tears. The family stuff seriously undermines the musicalâ€™s claims on the truth.
â€œJersey Boysâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Doo-wop songs and scatting expletives.

â€œJersey Boysâ€ù is a strange movie, and itâ€™s a Clint Eastwood enterprise, both reasons to see it. For those with a love of doo-wop, it also provides a toe-tapping, ear-worming stroll down rock â€™nâ€™ roll memory lane that dovetails with that deeply cherished American song and dance about personal triumph over adversity through hard work, tough times and self-sacrifice. Itâ€™s a redemption narrative thatâ€™s got a good beat, and you can dance to it. No wonder itâ€™s been such a popular trip: The stage version of â€œJersey Boysâ€ù opened in 2005 on Broadway, where itâ€™s still going strong, and has long been printing money around the world, from Australia to South Africa.

Like the original musical, the movie was written by Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice and has a clever, inviting narrative gimmick: all four of the Seasons take turns telling the groupâ€™s tale. This has led to the musicalâ€™s being sloppily likened to â€œRashomon,â€ù a comparison that works only if youâ€™ve never seen that 1950 Akira Kurosawa touchstone. In â€œRashomon,â€ù four characters recount a traumatic episode in a forest â€” a woman is raped and her husband murdered â€” in separate, contradictory flashbacks. Together, the four versions donâ€™t add up to one unified, coherently climaxing story: The mystery remains unsolved and the reminiscences remain contingent, which makes the film as much about storytelling as a crime.

At the end of â€œJersey Boys,â€ùClint Eastwoodâ€™s likable, resolutely laid-back adaptation of the Broadway musical, the actors all freeze. Theyâ€™ve just performed their last song on a set that looks so artificial that you half-expect the Sharks and the Jets to leap into the frame. Instead, that Jersey music man Frankie Valli and the other Seasons, along with a crowd of central-casting types, gather one last time and together warble and fancy-foot down a back-lot street. They finish big and then they all stop, staring straight ahead as sweat pops and bodies tremble under the now harsh lighting. Thatâ€™s entertainment, baby, and it is hard work.

A lot of the time, though, weâ€™re visually at the periphery with Sonu (Nawazuddin Siddiqui), whose greedy brother, Vicky (Anil George), hustles films for a gangster. Sonuâ€™s a bump on a log, but he daydreams of making a romantic movie called â€œMiss Lovelyâ€ù with a woman he spots on a train.

In â€œMiss Lovely,â€ù Ashim Ahluwalia shoves us into a 1980s demimonde of quick-and-dirty Indian exploitation movies, run by gangsters and sweatily intertwined with the sex trade. Itâ€™s the flip side, or backside, of Bollywoodâ€™s sparkle, a place of intimidation, titillation and cash-for-reels deals, with only glimpses of cut-rate glamour.

In that way, thereâ€™s an echo of that behind-the-scenes Italophile fetish object â€œBerberian Sound Studio,â€ù but with less humor and with a pointlessly patchy flow (not helped by a listless voice-over). Though fond of switching up angles and adding hand-held camerawork into the mix, Mr. Ahluwalia seems to resist indulging the many promising characters that populate this sub rosa scene. Though not pretentious, his film feels a tad overthought, held back somehow by a stubborn, dour obscurity clouding its freshly realized, lurid milieu.

Mr. Ahluwalia, however, is more invested in having the camera hang around frantic shoots and offices with safes than in pushing the binary drama of desire and shame. He also directed the documentary â€œJohn & Jane,â€ù about Indian call centers, and â€œMiss Lovelyâ€ù reflects an urge to document, with its prominent vintage telephones and patterned shirts and clunky tiny cars.

More than four hours long, filmed in expansive takes with almost no close-ups and very few camera movements, Lav Diazâ€™s â€œNorte, the End of Historyâ€ù is a tour de force of slow cinema. The movie, something of a sensation at Cannes last year, is not difficult or obscure â€” there is a clear, dramatic story involving characters who solicit both empathy and curiosity â€” but it does require an adjustment of the usual viewing metabolism.

â€œNorteâ€ù is partly a political fable, a smoldering, meticulous indictment of injustice and inequality. After Magdaâ€™s murder, Joaquin is sent to prison, leaving Eliza to support their children and her sister-in-law by selling vegetables from a cart. The dignity with which the two endure their fates is heartbreaking, but untouched by easy sentimentality. Mr. Diaz, patiently surveying the social and physical landscape with his beautiful, asymmetrical wide-screen compositions, makes inequality seem like an aspect of the local climate. The cruelty of laws and economic arrangements is obvious and intolerable, and yet there is no real sense that anything can be done.

The killing doesnâ€™t take place right away. We need to be calmed â€” to absorb the rhythms of life in a coastal city in the northern Philippines â€” before we can be shocked. And so we spend the first few minutes in the company of the filmâ€™s Raskolnikov, a law-school dropout named Fabian (Sid Lucero). He and two of his former professors are in a cafe, slipping between English and Tagalog as they philosophize. Fabianâ€™s ideas about good and evil are radical but also familiar, a stew of Nietzsche, existentialism, political yearning and personal frustration that he insists is not, as a teacher suggests, just another version of postmodernism.

That conclusion would be a fatalistic reading of part of the filmâ€™s title. The end of history might mean the permanent eclipse of any notion of progress. But though it tells a harsh story to sometimes devastating effect, â€œNorteâ€ù is far from a document of despair. This is partly because, like any true work of art, its very existence is an exhilarating triumph over complacency, and also because Mr. Diazâ€™s images are too rich and lovely to create a lasting sense of gloom. But there is also, above all, an almost inexhaustible humanism at the heart of this remarkable film. It is the work of a director as fascinated by decency as by ugliness, and able to present the chaos of life in a series of pictures that are at once luminously clear and endlessly mysterious.

You can spend a lot more time binge-watching a television series, but that would mean cruising through scenes of snappy editing, on-the-nose dialogue and ready-made emotional payoffs. That approach can work on the big screen, too, but Mr. Diaz, a leading figure in the resurgent Philippine cinema, is interested in a different kind of immersion. â€œNorteâ€ù is based, loosely but recognizably, on Dostoyevskyâ€™s â€œCrime and Punishment,â€ù and its duration is analogous to the novelâ€™s thickness. A simple act â€” the murder of a moneylender by a disaffected intellectual â€” becomes the center of a large and layered narrative, the focal point through which an entire world comes into view.

Nor is it just idle thoughts. In arguments with erstwhile classmates (including one whose girlfriend Fabian is sleeping with), he spins out wild revolutionary projects that express a deep generational malaise. His friends share his sense that their country has lost its way, but they would rather drink beer and pursue their studies than take meaningful action.

The action that Fabian ends up taking is meaningless in the sense that it advances no cause or vision. But in another way, because of its consequences for Fabian and others, it is almost unbearably saturated with meaning. Even though he comes from a wealthy landowning family (something we discover much later), Fabian is in debt to Magda (Mae Paner), a bullying matriarch who dispenses small stacks of cash and holds his A.T.M. card as collateral. She also has her hooks in Eliza (Angeli Bayani) and Joaquin (Archie Alemania), a couple whose dreams of opening a modest restaurant are threatened by Joaquinâ€™s leg injury and Magdaâ€™s heartlessness.

The director Jan Troell lavishes almost as much time on the image of Torgny (a fine Jesper Christensen) putting pen to paper, the implement scratching in close-up, as on the scene in which GÃ¶ringâ€™s telegram is read aloud to a roomful of newspaper employees. Or at least thatâ€™s how it registers. Segerstedt is remembered in history books for voicing opposition to Hitler, beginning in 1933, and Mr. Troell, a veteran filmmaker whose titles include â€œThe Emigrantsâ€ù and â€œThe New Land,â€ù clearly sees this protest as one manâ€™s defining moment. Yet itâ€™s one that also fights for attention with a family melodrama, a marital soap opera and many canine reaction shots.

Itâ€™s plausible that Torgny Segerstedt, a crusading Swedish journalist, was every bit as heroic, freethinking and sexually irresistible to women as he is portrayed in â€œThe Last Sentence.â€ù But you will need to take it on faith even after seeing this stultifying movie, a fictionalization of how Segerstedt (1876-1945) positioned himself on the right side of history by writing an editorial that declared â€œHerr Hitler is an insult.â€ù Hermann GÃ¶ring sent a telegram objecting to this boldly tossed gauntlet, one of many such complaints that challenged Segerstedtâ€™s lonely fight.

Itâ€™s too bad that the movie canâ€™t find his pulse and instead delivers a tastefully bland, inert portrait of a man whose personal ugliness it acknowledges without excavating. Although its black-and-white visuals catch the eye, â€œThe Last Sentenceâ€ù soon loosens its hold on your attention by flooding the story with mind-numbing, uninteresting details while real history slips through the cracks. Hitler invades Poland, Torgny walks his dogs, anti-Semitic caricatures arrive, Puste loses her grip: all receive more or less the same narrative weight, which means that none of them stick. The real Segerstedt died on March 31, 1945, a month before Hitler committed suicide in his bunker.

For the next few decades, Torgny keeps up the good fight, writing against both Nazism and what he sees as Swedenâ€™s concessionary stance toward Germany, even during wartime. In between issuing denunciations, he juggles his depressed wife, Puste (Ulla Skoog), and his considerably more vivacious mistress, Maja (Pernilla August), a Jewish heiress whoâ€™s married to his paperâ€™s genial, tolerant publisher, Axel (Bjorn Granath). Puste is sympathetic but a drag; Maya is unsympathetic but a bon vivant; the dogs are altogether charming. For a former theology student, Torgny, whose life has the geometric shape of two often overlapping triangles, comes off as almost rock â€™nâ€™ roll.

Two years later, we find the couples from that story â€” still personable, attractive, well dressed and mostly deserving â€” arriving in Las Vegas for the wedding of Candace (Regina Hall) and Michael (Terrence J), which must be preceded by ill-advised behavior at bachelor and bachelorette parties. The crucial subplot belongs to the best man, Cedric (Kevin Hart), who has splurged on an over-the-top, 12,000-square-foot suite for what he thinks is $4,000 a night but turns out to be $40,000. Things turn loud and desperate and stay that way, and the moral seems to be: Whatever you do, donâ€™t act like a man, because that means unjustified bravado, whoop-it-up antics and adolescent humor.

Well, you canâ€™t fault â€œThink Like a Man Tooâ€ù for being a sequel too much like the original. The first film, inspired by Steve Harveyâ€™s how-to-get-your-guy best seller, â€œAct Like a Lady, Think Like a Man,â€ù was a blatant product promotion, complete with bookstore signings and author appearances.

The one truly distinguished comic performance belongs to Dennis Haysbert as Uncle Eddie, whose come-hither eyes and Al Green voice are intended to distract Loretta (Jenifer Lewis), Michaelâ€™s priggish buzz-kill of a mother. Not that even a night of velvet-smooth seduction could improve this womanâ€™s mood.
â€œThink Like a Man Tooâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Frequent foreplay, profanity, recreational drug use, partial nudity and one rip-roaring strip club fistfight.

At the beginning of the awful Bollywood comedy â€œHumshakals,â€ù our handsome billionaire hero pursues his passion: stand-up. Heâ€™s awful. His jokes are infantile, his style eager to please but clueless.

The word â€œconfusionâ€ù is often chanted on the soundtrack â€” as is â€œhumshakalsâ€ù â€” but thereâ€™s more tedium than manic confusion. Jokes are doubled (humshakals!) or come in triplicate. Did you like the gag about the parathas accidentally made with cocaine instead of flour? Good. You can enjoy it again later when theyâ€™re made with vodka.

Also on the menu: a long, unfunny sequence with our boys in drag; some gratuitous gay caricatures, courtesy of a pair called Pinku and Chinku (who are later turned into another Ashok and Kumar); and a black-clad guard at the mental hospital who admires Hitler.
Still, he doesnâ€™t mind the hostile crowds, who heckle him and then walk out, disgusted. Why should he? His money insulates him from humiliation and buys him repeat engagements.

â€œHumshakalsâ€ù means doubles or dÃ¶ppelgangers. So our billionaire, Ashok (Saif Ali Khan, a good actor but no funnyman), and his sidekick, Kumar (Riteish Deshmukh, who manages a few amusing moments through force of will), have half-witted look-alikes, also called Ashok and Kumar, who live in a mental institution. Their nemesis (Ram Kapoor), who is trying to steal Ashokâ€™s business, also has a double. Eventually, we have three of each.

This is meant to be an endearing quirk, though watching â€œHumshakals,â€ù you may see it as something else: a mirror of the filmâ€™s hubris. During its 159 minutes, this movie bombards you with eager-to-please but clueless shtick, not to mention fantasies of wealth. The director, Sajid Khan, who wrote the script with Robin Bhatt and Akarsh Khurana, seems insulated and unable to tease out the difference between inspiration and indulgence.

â€œHumshakalsâ€ù is one of those Bollywood movies that has dispensed completely with India. Set in and around a London where most people speak Hindi (including Prince Charles), with a detour to Mauritius, it has many degrees of separation from any recognizable reality, comic or otherwise.

This succinct documentary sticks smoothly to its beat. Raised in Boston amid anti-Semitism, Mr. Hentoff notably went on to edit the jazz magazine DownBeat and write for The Village Voice. He established himself as a master critic of a uniquely American art (as well as a deft album producer) and an indefatigable advocate for civil liberties. As thoughtfully edited by the frequent Spike Lee collaborator Sam Pollard, the film alternates between these two professional pursuits. One sequence, for example, shifts subtly from a lovely quotation about solitude in a scholarly liner note by Mr. Hentoff, to his unpopular defense of plans by Nazi sympathizers to march in Skokie, Ill., in 1977.

â€œThe Pleasures of Being Out of Step: Notes on the Life of Nat Hentoffâ€ù is very much in step with the enthusiasms of its nobly bearded 89-year-old subject, the critic Nat Hentoff. The director David L. Lewis presents a man whoâ€™s all about the voice â€” letting it sing, as in the instrumental improvisations of the jazz he loves, and keeping it alive, through his dogmatic defense of the First Amendment.

When it comes to the painful ramifications of Mr. Hentoffâ€™s polemics and contradictions, as with his anti-abortion position, Mr. Lewis plays it a little too soft and low. The end credits glibly assure us that this fiery defender of the underdog still angers people, but what we mostly see is a charmingly matter-of-fact stooped old man with the rolling intonation of an old-fashioned television host. His friends and associates â€” his wife, Margot; his fellow Village Voice veteran Karen Durbin; the writer Amiri Baraka; the First Amendment lawyer Floyd Abrams â€” speak with fondness.

Mr. Lewis shields us from full-throttle orneriness, and skips through some stories too quickly (though he has a feel for a good performerâ€™s presence when using Lenny Bruce footage). But the film also pays tribute to a faded era of alternative journalism and to a model for cultural bonds across racial lines. And itâ€™s one documentary about â€œpopular cultureâ€ù that gets at the potential in that devalued term for true-blue American ideals.

Donning the requisite black-framed glasses, the boyish Pierre Niney plays the wunderkind who was tapped for creative leadership of Dior at the age of 21, ran his own trendsetting fashion house and also struggled through manic-depression. Pierre BergÃ© (Guillaume Gallienne) was his lover, wrangler and business partner, making for a beneficial match that would fray with the stress on both sides. The model Victoire Doutreleau (Charlotte Le Bon) also figures as a friend and mild source of intrigue, though the greater world of fashion feels sketchy.

More dutiful than elegant, â€œYves Saint Laurentâ€ù is one of two new dramas about that beatified French fashion designer. The other feature, Bertrand Bonelloâ€™s â€œSaint Laurent,â€ù had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival last month and posits, with flair and humor, a certain sensual mystery about the shy but passionate couturier and his work. Jalil Lespertâ€™s authorized biopic is the first out of the gate in the United States, however, and it trots out a polite recounting of Saint Laurentâ€™s life in its prime.

The head-turning clothes, including Saint Laurentâ€™s legendary Mondrian numbers, are museum-quality, borrowed for the making of the film (and apparently used for only hours at a time). But you might say the same thing about much of the drama, which feels like a well-appointed exhibition of a life.

Mr. Lespert and his screenwriters tend to telegraph whatâ€™s happening next with on-the-nose dialogue, leaving behind an orderly but not vividly realized biography (or necessarily a complete one). Paris by the decades is recreated, but without a real sense of life in the air. Itâ€™s a film that takes on the mood of Mr. BergÃ© more than that of the prodigy himself, though the depiction of their relationship is at times poignant, if overly restrained.
â€œYvesÂ SaintÂ Laurentâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian). Words uttered in anger and bodies bared in the fashion world.

In most movies, something happens; in â€œArchipelago,â€ù many things happen, quietly yet meaningfully. At the picture-perfect house the family has rented, Edward and Cynthia huddle in the cramped stairwell and politely, stubbornly tussle over which bedroom he should take. When Edward enters the small room that heâ€™s insisted on, he almost immediately bumps his head. Later, as the walls metaphorically close in and the familyâ€™s reserve begins peeling away, emotions churning like the sea outside, his doggedness on taking this tiny room can feel less like a gesture of good will and more like a self-regarding sacrifice.

Each family member also has a role, although Ms. Hogg doesnâ€™t lock them into parts, an acceptance of the mystery of other people. Edward may play the martyr but so does Patricia. The same holds true of the combustible Cynthia, who makes everyone else pay for her sacrifices, as in two scenes centered on a family meal gone wrong. The first, set in an otherwise empty restaurant trembles with violent comedy as, under Cynthiaâ€™s brittle guidance and escalating impatience, the family changes tables several times. By the second meal, violence has trumped comedy; with just a few bites and raised words, an ordinary lunch turns into a stage for the familyâ€™s brutal intimacies.

Joanna Hogg â€” where have you been all my movie-loving life? That thought buzzed through my head after, with intensifying greediness, I tore through this British directorâ€™s three features: â€œUnrelated,â€ùâ€œArchipelagoâ€ù and â€œExhibition.â€ù Theyâ€™re finally receiving American distribution, so if youâ€™re lucky enough to be in New York, run over to the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center and catch them now.

The scene spread out in front of the artist, Christopher (Christopher Baker, a real painter), is a stretch of coast on Tresco, a stunning, wind-swept spit of land off the southwest tip of Britain. He soon bicycles out of the picture only to return later as an instructor for Patricia (Kate Fahy), whoâ€™s on vacation with her two adult children, the sweet Edward (Tom Hiddleston), and the older, sterner Cynthia (Lydia Leonard). The family has gathered to say goodbye to Edward, whoâ€™s leaving for Africa to work as a vaguely defined health counselor. The ambiguity of his position says as much about his poignant inchoate searching as it does Ms. Hoggâ€™s lack of interest in storytelling conventions.

In scene after scene, meaning sneaks in and sometimes roars. Ms. Hogg favors a mix of medium shots and long shots that allow you to see her characters from head to toe, and uses close-ups sparingly, reserving them for critical punctuation. In some movies, especially those operating under the self-conscious rubric of the art film, such choices can feel emptily ritualistic. In â€œArchipelago,â€ù the long shots serve a more basic function: They allow you to see, really see, characters in their natural and unnatural habitats. Itâ€™s not for nothing that when you first see the familyâ€™s cook, Rose (Amy Lloyd), the shot cuts off her head: itâ€™s a virtual beheading that announces her place in this exquisite, terrible world.

Ms. Hogg has a background in photography and television. From the way she shoots landscapes and people, she has also spent hours wandering art galleries and museums. Her painterly eye informs her every image, whether sheâ€™s sweeping over the natural world or closing in on characters arranged with the physical reserve, spatial harmony and otherworldly aura of an old master group portrait. Yet she also has a Modernist side and â€œArchipelagoâ€ù (2010), her second feature, notably opens with a plein air painter giving impressionistic form to the magnificent scenery before him. He has a role to play, including, it seems, as a nod toward Ms. Hoggâ€™s own stippled strokes and holistic vision.

Money and ambition constitute an awkward subtext in â€œBegin Again.â€ù Gretta has strong, not entirely persuasive opinions about authenticity and integrity, which Dan, at once a dreamer and a hustler, both mocks and respects. The filmâ€™s ideas about how musicians make their living are more than a little disingenuous. The bright line it wants to draw between passion and commerce is perpetually blurred, partly because everyone, including the straying boyfriend and the designated record-industry heavy (Yasiin Bey, formerly known as Mos Def), is pretty darn likable.
â€œBegin Againâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A few swear words, but otherwise pretty much what youâ€™d hear over the speakers at Starbucks.

The songs, from Mr. Carney, Gregg Alexander and others, are strings of lyrical and instrumental commonplaces. Thatâ€™s true of a lot of pop classics, of course, which enliven the tried and true with fresh and surprising notes. â€œBegin Againâ€ù has some of those, especially when Mr. Ruffalo shambles into Ms. Keenerâ€™s company. It also handles the possible sexual connection between Dan and Gretta with Henry Jamesian discretion, avoiding creepiness without denying the magnetic attraction that pulses beneath their shared interests.
Iâ€™m trying to praise this movie with faint damnation. Itâ€™s not very good, but it is kind of enjoyable, at times infectiously so. Even bad songs sometimes get stuck in your head.

Which goes for the movie too. But that doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s good. Compared with â€œOnce,â€ù â€œBegin Againâ€ù is a bit like the disappointing, overly produced follow-up to a new bandâ€™s breakthrough album. A large part of the problem is that the music, which is supposed to provide heart, soul and artistic bona fides, ranges from passable to terrible. When Dan first hears Gretta with her acoustic guitar, he imagines a full arrangement for her song, transforming it in his head from a mediocre fake-folk ditty into a mediocre middle-of-the-road radio hit.

But then, amid the exposed brick and overstuffed couches of a downtown open-mike night, Gretta meets Dan (Mark Ruffalo), a music-label executive in a tailspin of his own. Dan is estranged from his wife (Catherine Keener) and is having trouble staying connected to his teenage daughter, Violet (Hailee Steinfeld). His nonmusical interests include whiskey, brown-paper cigarettes and not shaving. After hearing Gretta mope her way through a breakup song, Dan offers her a vague business opportunity that she has too much integrity to accept. Instead, they set out to record an album on the streets and rooftops of Manhattan, a kind of aural valentine to New York, offering the session players back-end promises and musical joy in lieu of up-front payment.

In â€œBegin Again,â€ù he tries to repeat the trick. This time the city is New York rather than Dublin, and the serendipitously matched musicians are played by real-life movie stars. Keira Knightley is Gretta, a British songwriter adrift in the city after a personal and professional crisis. A few months earlier (as seen in one of several too-slick montage sequences) she arrived with her boyfriend and sometime writing partner, Dave (Adam Levine). He had a big-time record deal and quickly succumbed to the temptations of the rock-star life, leaving Gretta crashing on the couch of a busker pal (James Corden) and planning her return home.

But the movie fatally mistakes sincerity for good taste and believes too much of its own nonsense. The New York locations are undeniably real, yet they still somehow look as artificial as studio back-lot sets. (A small, symptomatic point: Dan can always find a parking space for his vintage Jaguar right in front of wherever he has to be.) The loose, off-kilter compositions and ragged editing rhythms donâ€™t quite camouflage the way nearly every dramatic beat and line of dialogue lands squarely on the nose. Despite the unaffected acting, the characters are less individuals than axioms, and their relationships are carefully graphed to yield predictable emotional results.

Before it was a Tony Award-winning Broadway musical, â€œOnceâ€ù was a scruffy and charming movie, written and directed by John Carney, about a man and a woman united by their love of music and their unstated but obvious attraction to each other. Filmed at street level in the lived-in parts of a picturesque city, it managed to be touristic and authentic at the same time, partly because the central pair consisted of a native and an outsider. Mr. Carney pulled off the enviable trick of dressing unabashed romantic sentiment in a style that felt rough and real, so that every clichÃ© he touched felt shiny and new.

Born in 1908, the sisters, Daisy and Violet, were exploited by various managers even as they became relatively famous. Unlike some sideshow acts, they were not content simply to be gawked at; they entertained, after a fashion, with musical routines and such.

It would be hard not to make a thought-provoking, heartstring-tugging film from this source material, and â€œBound by Fleshâ€ù certainly tells the twinsâ€™ story effectively by using standard documentary techniques: vintage photographs and clips, interviews with people who knew the sisters or have studied their lives.

The film traces their rise to prominence, their fight to gain control of their own careers and, most poignantly, their struggles in the years before they died in 1969. Beyond being about the sisters, â€œBound by Fleshâ€ù is the story of changing public tastes, an evolution that ultimately left the twins out of fashion. In that sense, itâ€™s the story of practically every entertainer: Youâ€™re a marketable commodity until, suddenly and often inexplicably, youâ€™re not.

Every few years, it seems, someone rediscovers the Hilton sisters, the conjoined twins who spent decades as a sideshow attraction and then a vaudeville act in the heart of the last century. They are having a moment again: A new production of â€œSide Show,â€ù the stage musical inspired by their lives, has recently opened at the Kennedy Center in Washington, and now â€œBound by Flesh,â€ù a straightforward documentary by Leslie Zemeckis, is being given a theatrical release.

At times, â€œSnowpiercerâ€ù recalls Terry Gilliamâ€™s â€œBrazil,â€ù both in its steampunk dÃ©cor and in its grimly satirical look at the workings of power and privilege in a totalitarian corporate future. Its lessons about human nature are thought-provoking, but perhaps not as memorable as its motley, eccentric display of humanity in extremis. And though the movie is playfully postmodern in its pastiche of styles and its mingling of sincerity and self-consciousness, there is also something solidly old-fashioned about the way it tells its story. Long, crowded and ambitious almost to the point of hubris, it reminded me a little of â€œThe Poseidon Adventureâ€ù and other 1970s-vintage action allegories full of great actors struggling to survive. Thatâ€™s a compliment, by the way. Disaster has become a matter of routine at the movies (in more ways than one). Planetary destruction and human extinction happen a half-dozen times every summer. Itâ€™s rarely this refreshing, though.

In the mood for allegory? Have a look at Bong Joon-hoâ€™s â€œSnowpiercer,â€ù which proceeds from a fantastical premise rich with real-world relevance. After a human-engineered planetary catastrophe (trying to arrest the planetâ€™s warming, we accidentally froze it solid), the remaining people are stuck on a train that never stops moving. A few thousand survivors live in railway cars, sorted into a rigid and ruthlessly enforced social order. In the back are huddled masses fed on gelatinous, insect-based black protein bars and kept in line by a combination of propaganda and brute force. Toward the front, the more fortunate enjoy access to schools, nightclubs, fresh food and the reassurance that they deserve everything they have. An unseen, quasi-mythical entrepreneur is in charge, and a group of rebels have decided to challenge his power and the extreme inequality he represents.

Like most dystopian science fiction, â€œSnowpiercerâ€ù has a lot of explaining to do. The idea of a high-speed train chugging through glaciers has a childrenâ€™s-book charm, and the original graphic novel has some stylistic kinship with Chris Van Allsburgâ€™s â€œThe Polar Express.â€ù But Mr. Bong is interested above all in imagining how the whole thing might work, as a matter of technology and social organization. And so every episode of fighting or conspiring is accompanied by a dollop of exposition, some of it recalling the start of the journey (18 years before the action takes place), some surveying its present condition and some looking around for clues about whether or how it might end.

And if acting is your thing â€” or at least the particular pleasure of watching first-rate screen performers ham it up in a busy genre setting â€” â€œSnowpiercerâ€ù will not disappoint. The reluctant leader of the rebels, a back-of-the-train troublemaker named Curtis, is played by Chris Evans, his clean-cut Captain America charisma obscured by scruffy facial hair and a black wool watch cap. He is a stoical, heroic presence amid the chaos, which means he has less room to be interesting than the other actors, who provide some of that chaos. They include Octavia Spencer, John Hurt and Jamie Bell as some of Curtisâ€™s fellow insurgents, whose careful planning and simmering resentments blossom into revolt after an especially cruel provocation by the authorities. There are soldiers in riot gear, armed with clubs and guns, but for Mr. Bong evil is never anonymous. He gives it a grotesque, human face â€” or rather a series of faces, most memorably Tilda Swintonâ€™s, almost unrecognizable in prosthetic teeth and oversize glasses. She serves as a kind of spokeswoman for Mr. Wilford (Ed Harris), the enigmatic engineer who is both dictator and deity in this postapocalyptic world. As the train moves in its long, winding route around the globe, teetering on the edge of both sustainability and plausibility, Curtis and his comrades undertake a long march toward the engine. They are joined by Minsu (the great shape-shifting South Korean actor Song Kang-ho), a security specialist, and his daughter, Yona (Ko Ah-sung), both addicted to an inhalant called Kronole.
â€œSnowpiercerâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). The language is rougher and the violence grislier than in most summer action movies.

But perhaps, since a summer holiday weekend is approaching, youâ€™d prefer an action movie. â€œSnowpiercer,â€ù based on the graphic novel â€œLe Transperceneigeâ€ù by Jacques Lob, Benjamin Legrand and Jean-Marc Rochette, is unusually satisfying in that regard as well. Mr. Bong, whose previous films include the brilliant psychological thriller â€œMotherâ€ù and â€œThe Host,â€ù a sublimely moving monster flick, is a playful and rigorous visual thinker. Here he stages kinetic fight scenes in narrow spaces and punctuates the noise and speed of the train with moments of eerie, poignant calm as it glides through digitally rendered ice and snow. The violence inside swerves from slapstick to bloodshed and back, producing a volatile blend of humor and horror that pays tribute to the source material while coloring its themes with the directorâ€™s distinctively perverse and humane sensibility.

The carnage, Oscar explains, began with a soccer bet, which netted 1.7 million kroner (close to $300,000) for him and three co-workers at a Christmas tree factory friendly to ex-cons. The men claim to have difficulty with the division necessary to split the winnings. When math fails, the gang resorts to blunter instruments â€” the kind that eventually turn a few of the factoryâ€™s white mini-trees a deep shade of red.

As an absurdist suspense film, â€œJackpotâ€ù mostly hits its marks. As a comedy, itâ€™s less successful, stronger on sight gags than on the detectiveâ€™s sarcasm. The broad interrogation scenes give the film a bit of an odor.

The detective on the case (Henrik Mestad) scarcely believes each new development, while Oscar calmly explains how seemingly impossible coincidences (involving a severed head and a lost body) really come down to chance.

There are few circumstances in which itâ€™s comforting to find yourself under interrogation, but Oscar (Kyrre Hellum), the hero of â€œJackpot,â€ù is in an especially tight spot. Can he explain how he ended up surrounded by eight dead bodies in a Swedish sex shop â€” the last man standing, despite never having fired a shot?

A throwback to the â€œPulp Fictionâ€ù-style deadpan noirs that proliferated in the 1990s, this comic thriller from Magnus Martens, a Norwegian director, combines corpse disposals (which owe a debt to Quentin Tarantino and the Coen brothers) with slapstick humor more suited to â€œWeekend at Bernieâ€™s.â€ù

The dancers â€” often identified only by their stage names, in a choice that makes the film seem guarded â€” vary in insight. Channing credits his interest in stripping to Mr. Soderberghâ€™s movie. J. D. hopes to return to the restaurant business. Cesar (his real name), a veteran of Afghanistan and Iraq, says ex-servicemenâ€™s main options are to work as bodyguards, bouncers or cops. Several ensemble members grow emotional discussing the shooting death of a colleague, Ruben Riguero, in one of the few interludes that depart from self-congratulation.

â€œLa Bareâ€ù seldom shows the dancersâ€™ lives outside of the club. (In this respect, the fictional â€œMagic Mikeâ€ù seems richer than the documentary.) In one excursion, Randy Ricks, known as Master Blaster, who has performed at La Bare since 1979, receives injections and cryogenic treatment to maintain his physique. Thatâ€™s the kind of behind-the-scenes detail worth preserving.
â€œLa Bareâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Les thongs.

â€œLa Bareâ€ù takes its title from the club it chronicles, a male strip joint in Dallas. The name proves unfortunately apt for a rambling, superficial documentary that straddles the line between exposÃ© and infomercial. Directed by the actor Joe Manganiello (who was inspired by his role in Steven Soderberghâ€™s â€œMagic Mike,â€ù set in the world of male revues), this celebratory film argues that male stripping is more strenuous than its female counterpart: It requires a full-fledged act and an athleteâ€™s regimen. We learn a bit about the stagecraft, such as how audience volunteers are selected and why underpants with flies are forbidden.

Ms. Poehler and Mr. Rudd play Molly and Joel, a couple who, when the movie opens, are planning to split up. Tucked into a darkly lit restaurant â€” it shrieks candlelight and Katherine Heigl â€” with Kyle (Bill Hader) and Karen (Ellie Kemper), Molly and Joel recount how they met cute, fell in love and what went wrong or maybe right, not that it matters. If youâ€™ve seen â€œYouâ€™ve Got Mailâ€ù (a rip-off of the peerless â€œShop Around the Cornerâ€ù), Molly and Joelâ€™s back stories, love lives and initial antagonisms will be familiar: Sheâ€™s a lonely gal who runs a tiny no-profit candy store, while he has a feckless girlfriend and works for an all-profit candy conglomerate.

In â€œThey Came Together,â€ù a sloppy, fitfully funny broadside at the romantic comedy, the director David Wain goes after that oft-abused genre with a metaphoric jackhammer â€” as well as a bat, a machete, a couple of knives, one or two missiles and the sort of sizzling cartoon bomb that Wile E. Coyote used to hurl. Mr. Wain has some expert help with his demolition work, namely his stars, Amy Poehler and Paul Rudd, who with another dozen or so cutups, embody assorted romantic comedy stereotypes with wide smiles, seasoned technique and unfettered spleen.
â€œThey Came Togetherâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Crude yuks.

To that end, he trots out all the usual platitudes, scenes and personalities, including a large bunch of second bananas. Melanie Lynskey pops in for a brief turn as do Michael Ian Black, Michael Murphy, Ken Marino and Jack McBrayer, among others. Ed Helms lingers for a while longer, as does Christopher Meloni. Most of the performers are pretty funny or funny enough, despite having little to do but mug and throw around a few jokes. Â Some of these stick, if not for long, mostly because Mr. Wain, who made a delightful comedy with â€œRole Modelsâ€ù and a cult favorite with â€œWet Hot American Summer,â€ù has opted to deliver a series of hit-and-miss sketch-comedy bits rather than a fully realized movie that might have gutted contemporary rom-com clichÃ©s rather than just weakly aping them.

Of course, Molly and Joel are destined for each other: They were written that way. And so, like clockwork or a dog-eared screenwriting manual, they meet on their way to a Halloween party for which, in an absurdist touch, each has dressed as Ben Franklin. If that sounds mildly amusing, it is, partly because, while almost anyone could squeeze laughs out of a bad bald wig, Mr. Rudd and, in particular, Ms. Poehler look endearingly silly in this get-up. Ms. Poehlerâ€™s ability to let you see the vulnerability timorously lurking behind her characterâ€™s self-seriousness deepens the encounter, never mind that Mr. Wain, who wrote the script with Michael Showalter, displays little interest in nuance, even as a principle of storytelling equilibrium. Mr. Wain is going for comedy overkill with a vengeance.

Viewers unencumbered by nostalgia will probably see this zippy, occasionally funny movie as no more frantic or pop-culture-addled than the average multiplex fodder. As Carbunkle â€” having vowed to branch into computer animation â€” threatens at the end: â€œIâ€™ll just move to America! Iâ€™m not even a bad guy there!â€ù

But somethingâ€™s different in â€œPostman Pat: The Movie,â€ù and itâ€™s not just that the quaint stop-motion animation of the TV version has been replaced with the smoothed-over edges of computer graphics. (The movie opens with a swooping long take best suited to Imax nature documentaries.)

British reviewers largely greeted the film as a crass repackaging of a beloved property, but the filmmakers apparently tried to pre-empt that critique, fashioning the movie as a satire of commercialism run amok. As Patâ€™s success grows â€” cue a montage set to Peter Gabrielâ€™s â€œBig Timeâ€ù â€” he gets his own video game, cereal and potential movie project, but soon remembers the importance of family and friends.

In various incarnations, the animated childrenâ€™s series â€œPostman Patâ€ù has been a staple of British television since 1981. The title character is a letter carrier who, along with his cat, Jess, brings joy and generosity to the farm community of Greendale.

No, what was once an earnest trifle has been cloaked in the well-worn garb of meta. Here, Pat (Stephen Mangan for speech, Ronan Keating for song) competes in a talent show hosted by â€œSimon Cowbellâ€ù to win a vacation for himself and his wife, Sara (Susan Duerden). A new executive, Carbunkle (Peter Woodward), seizes on the distraction, initiating a plan to replace the postal serviceâ€™s employees with Pat robots.

Which is one reason that previous foragers in the Dick universe, like Steven Spielberg and Paul Verhoeven, have often had to take significant liberties with the original material. But John Alan Simon, writing and directing his first feature, decided (according to the publicity notes) to take â€œa purist approachâ€ù to a story many believe to be Dickâ€™s most autobiographical work. That it also sounds like the ravings of a broken mind blankets the film in a sadness that the actors, gamely grappling with ridiculous speeches, never quite surmount.

The result is a quaint labor of love blinkered by fidelity to an outdated text. Stiff staging and not-so-special effects accompany Jonathan Scarfe and Alanis Morissette as they endure a despotic alternate reality and get communications from an alien intelligence. The excellent Shea Whigham, as a science-fiction writer, is our guide and narrator, but even his gravitas wonâ€™t keep you from laughing at an extraterrestrial who thinks that hiding subliminal messages in pop songs is the way to start a revolution.

Airless and earthbound, â€œRadio Free Albemuthâ€ù  resembles a weird artifact from the early days of science-fiction television â€” a lost episode of â€œThe Outer Limitsâ€ù or â€œTales of Tomorrow.â€ù Based on the novel of the same title by Philip K. Dick (published posthumously in 1985), this lifeless adaptation only proves that making entertaining movies out of hard-to-swallow ideas is as challenging as you might think.

Mahendra Saini (Rajesh Tailang), the meek, sad-eyed protagonist of Richie Mehtaâ€™s touching film â€œSiddharth,â€ù is a resident of New Delhi, with a wife, a son approaching puberty and a younger daughter. He ekes out a living on the streets fixing zippers, touting his service through a bullhorn, but business has been bad. In the filmâ€™s opening moments, he says goodbye to his son, Siddharth, who is leaving on a bus to work in a factory in distant Ludhiana. The boyâ€™s employer, Om Prakash (Amitabh Srivasta), is a distant cousin of Mahendraâ€™s brother-in-law, Ranjit (Anurag Arora). Both are hardened in ways that Mahendra is not.

On one level, â€œSiddharthâ€ù is a cleareyed neorealist film in the tradition of Satyajit Ray. It gazes unblinkingly at the extremely bare living conditions of Mehendra and his family. Its portrayal of impoverished, careworn people barking at one another and protecting their territory in a daily struggle is bracingly hardheaded.

Mahendra mumbles helplessly: â€œBusiness was slow. We needed the money.â€ù He doesnâ€™t have a single photo of his son; he can only guess that his age is 12 or 13; and he can barely operate a cellphone.

Borrowing money from friends, Mehendra sets out to find his son, first making the 200-mile trip to Ludhiana, where he discovers from the boyâ€™s roommate that Siddharth left behind his possessions. It is a sign that he might have been abducted, a too-common fate in India, where thousands of children are kidnapped and dispatched to the streets to beg. The roommate offers one other possibility. Siddharth may have ended up in Dongri, a place some people have heard of, although no one seems to know where it is. In Mahendraâ€™s mind, it becomes a mythic destination: the end of the rainbow, the place where dreams come true.

The only sign that the movie has a bleeding heart is a too-pretty score by Andrew Lockington that is glaringly out of step with the filmâ€™s vision of urban poverty. As Mahendraâ€™s quest widens, eventually leading him to Mumbai, he begins to lose his grip. At one point, he is so desperate that he begins collaring street boys whom he mistakes for Siddharth. The trip becomes a bitter learning experience for a man who, although only in his 30s, has retained many of the qualities of a child.

Siddharth is scheduled to return home for a holiday after a month away, but when Mahendra meets the bus, he is not on it. Mahendra contacts Om Prakash, who angrily complains that Siddharth ran away two weeks earlier. He would never do that, Mahendra insists. Several days pass, and Mahendra, increasingly worried, consults a traffic cop, who directs him to the police station where Roshni (Geeta Agrawal Sharma), the brusque official in charge of missing persons, scolds him for violating child labor laws. Had he sent Siddharth to school, his education would have been paid for by the government, she says, and scoffs, â€œYou people never learn.â€ù

The one lesson to be gleaned from â€œThe Breakup Guruâ€ù is that money canâ€™t buy you love, something the Beatles said much better in far less time. Of course, the cynical Yuangui learns to open his heart, and he abandons his dubious occupation. He may be happy, but viewers are merely exasperated.

The jokes and sight gags fly in exhausting profusion in â€œThe Breakup Guru,â€ù Deng Chao and Yu Baimeiâ€™s antic, scattershot romantic comedy. Mr. Deng plays the titular fixer, Mei Yuangui, a successful specialist in terminating the relationships of celebrities and socialites through entrapment, public humiliation and other unsavory methods. (These tactics are accompanied by a lot of mugging and extreme grimacing.) Now, with three trusty helpers, Yuangui has one last job: to help a smarmy, Western-style motivational speaker and â€œsuccessologistâ€ù (Liang Chao) unload his Beijing mistress, Ye Xiaochun (Yang Mi). To that end, Yuangui resolves to trick the mistress into falling for none other than himself. Somehow, for all his overemphatic mannerisms, he succeeds.

Ms. Yang, whose character is unconscionably underdrawn, is a pillar of restraint and dignity compared with Mr. Deng, who faintly summons early Jim Carrey at his most manic and ham-handed. Split-screen images, brisk editing and digital animation strain to overcompensate for a plot that ricochets in every direction with attendant shifts in mood. The humor, when it isnâ€™t overcooked, can be downright insulting or worse â€” particularly the persistent use of blackface in scenes set in the African nation of Mauritius.

Making room for the moral and philosophical underpinnings of freedom of information, and questioning the motives of its opponents, the filmâ€™s many contributors â€” including family, friends and experts like Tim Berners-Lee, the inventor of the World Wide Web â€” generate a â€œhow could this happen?â€ù tone that feels agonizingly appropriate. None more so than the writer Quinn Norton, whoâ€™s commendably candid about (and clearly still haunted by) her cooperation with federal prosecutors. Their pursuit of Swartz placed them, she believes, â€œon the wrong side of history.â€ù Few who watch this film will feel inclined to disagree.

Though unapologetically partial to his subject, an idealistic computer genius who committed suicide in 2013 at 26, Mr. Knappenberger keeps his images simple and allows his facts to take precedence. Clips of Mr. Swartz in home movies and at speaking engagements chart his growth from child prodigy to Internet crusader who believed that the contents of public-interest databases should be freely available to all. Detailed in his Guerrilla Open Access Manifesto, this ethos would lead to his 2011 arrest based on charges that he downloaded millions of journal articles from a subscription-only online service â€” or, in the words of the writer Cory Doctorow, â€œfor taking too many books out of the library.â€ù

Moving and maddening in almost equal measure, Brian Knappenbergerâ€™s â€œThe Internetâ€™s Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartzâ€ù is a devastating meditation on what can happen when a prescient thinker challenges corporate interests and the power of the state.

The story is scaffolding for the action, and like every other standing structure it is wrecked in a thunderous shower of metal, glass, masonry and earth. Chicago, pounded almost flat the last time, takes another beating, and is joined by Hong Kong. The obliteration of cities is a commonplace in summer movies, but Mr. Bay is a connoisseur of urban demolition, adept at using digital imagery and fast editing to bend and mock the laws of physics and flout any sense of moral consequence.

If, on the other hand, you are bored by the sight of giant robots fighting, this will feel like a very long art film. Which, in effect, it is, albeit one that was made with unlimited resources. Those looking for conventional, middlebrow cinematic pleasures â€” witty dialogue, credible acting, the play of light and shadow across landscapes and faces â€” will find a few moments of satisfaction. Kelsey Grammer and Stanley Tucci are amusing as the C.I.A. heavy and his tech-mogul sidekick. The evening sun in a place identified as â€œTexas, USAâ€ù (as opposed to Texas, Belgium, I guess) is golden and lovely. So is Nicola Peltz as Tessa, the teenage daughter of an inventor played with cheerful machismo by Mark Wahlberg. Tessa has a boyfriend (Jack Reynor). Thatâ€™s enough plot summary for now.

â€œTransformers: Age of Extinction,â€ù the fourth film in an apparently inexhaustible, profoundly exhausting series based on Hasbro toys, raises, not for the first time, a basic question: Who are these movies for? This one, like its predecessors, is likely to make a lot of money all over the world, but that only makes the matter more puzzling. The â€œTransformersâ€ù franchise seems like the most baldly and cynically commercial calculation imaginable â€” it is merchandising-based entertainment at its purest â€” and yet somehow it does not pander.

But even though these robots with the power to change into vehicles started out as childrenâ€™s playthings, the movies are a little too vulgar, violent and nasty to have been made expressly for the youngest viewers. Theyâ€™re also a little too dumb for the adolescent or adult genre geeks. The mythology seems to have been cobbled together at corporate strategy sessions out of notions ripped off from elsewhere. The elaborate, thematically overloaded martial back story carries echoes of Tolkien and â€œStar Wars.â€ù Lasting 166 minutes â€” though it feels much longer â€” â€œAge of Extinctionâ€ù makes clear what has always been true of the Transformers movies: Although they may look like soulless corporate studio product, they are really examples of personal cinema, expressions of the will and imagination of their director, Michael Bay. The narrative incoherence is a feature, not a bug. (The screenplay is by Ehren Kruger.) Mr. Bayâ€™s strongest films (with the partial exception of â€œPain and Gainâ€ù) are those in which the battle between sense and sensation ends in a rout. You can admire what he does without really enjoying it, and two hours and 46 minutes of pulverized architecture is a lot to endure. But in every Michael Bay movie there are at least a few moments of inspired, kinetic absurdity. Late in â€œAge of Extinction,â€ù a giant spaceship hovering over Hong Kong, equipped with some kind of magnet, sucks up a lot of vehicles â€” buses, trucks, fishing boats, ferries, whatever â€” and drops them onto the city below. Certainly not to women, who are on screen mainly to be ogled, shamed and rescued. Because it has no conventional action or schematic story, â€œUnrelated,â€ù Joanna Hoggâ€™s dyspeptic portrait of upper-middle-class Britons on a summer holiday in Tuscany, is the antithesis of popcorn entertainment. The first film directed by Ms. Hogg, â€œUnrelated,â€ù released in Britain in 2008 and shown here for the first time, announced the debut of a significant writing and directing talent. Mr. Berlinger interviews members of both legal teams and listens in while Mr. Bulger speaks by telephone to his lawyers. The rapidity of Tammyâ€™s stomping, muttering journey to her motherâ€™s is lightly amusing, and itâ€™s the kind of quick, donâ€™t-blink bit of business that â€” with her effortless appeal â€” makes you root for Ms. McCarthy and this movie from the start. How do you solve a problem like Melissa McCarthy? That question feels inescapable after watching her try to powerlift â€œTammy,â€ù her newest and least funny comedy, all by her lonesome. â€œMe and Youâ€ù is the first film in three decades by this 73-year-old Italian director to be made in Italian, and it is his third consecutive feature, after â€œBesiegedâ€ù and â€œThe Dreamers,â€ù whose action takes place in a confined space. â€œLife Itself,â€ù Steve Jamesâ€™s documentary on the life of Roger Ebert, is in many ways like a wake at which intimate acquaintances warmly recall their departed friend in all his aspects, foibles and quirks along with his talents and triumphs. Deep currents of love and sorrow flow under the succession of often funny recollections of a busy life. But it is a wake where the departed is still present.

As we apprehend Ebert through the testimony given here, it becomes clear that his abilities were prodigious â€” a natural writer, he could, by one account, â€œknock out a full thought-out movie review in 30 minutesâ€ù â€” and his personality more than a little eccentrically uncommon. There are glimpses of depression and loneliness withheld from public view and of a controlling temperament that met its match when he was teamed with Siskel, of The Chicago Tribune, for a local show that finally made them both stars.

The film began as a proposed adaptation of Ebertâ€™s 2011 memoir of the same title, a self-portrait whose calm and open tone is the more remarkable for the circumstances under which it was written. Mr. James â€” whose own career was buoyed by his subjectâ€™s early praise for his documentary â€œHoop Dreamsâ€ù â€” first met with Ebert and his wife, Chaz, five months before Ebertâ€™s death in April of last year. He had hoped to track Ebert as he continued to lead his determinedly productive life as critic and commentator, both in print and on the social media in which he had become a major presence.

In retrospect, it seems remarkable that the show existed at all. At the time, other film critics were bothered by the showâ€™s tendency to focus on heavily advertised commercial blockbusters, arguments revisited in â€œLife Itselfâ€ù by the critics Jonathan Rosenbaum and Richard Corliss, but as others emphasize, Ebert brought attention both in print and on television to a long line of such easily overlooked films as Gregory Navaâ€™s â€œEl Norte,â€ùCharles Burnettâ€™s â€œKiller of Sheepâ€ù and Errol Morrisâ€™s â€œGates of Heaven.â€ù

Ebertâ€™s condition deteriorated just before shooting began, so what Mr. James ended up filming were scenes of a hospital and a rehab center, culminating in some extraordinarily raw moments of pain, uncertainty, exhaustion and grief. Any sense of intrusion is mitigated by the feeling that Ebertâ€™s intent is being honored, up to the point where he acknowledges his inability to go on in a terse last email to the director: â€œi canâ€™t.â€ù
â€œLife Itselfâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for brief sexual images and language.

As these scenes unfold, a parallel narrative takes us through Ebertâ€™s past. An actor reads passages from the memoir while we are shown countless artifacts of a well-documented life: the hectographed newspaper he produced himself while still in grade school in Urbana, Ill.; a powerful political editorial from the college paper he edited; his own pen-and-ink drawings of the Cannes Film Festival. Excerpts from Ebertâ€™s film reviews are accompanied by clips from movies important to him â€” from â€œBonnie and Clydeâ€ù to â€œThe Tree of Lifeâ€ù â€” figuring not as milestones of film history but as scenes from his life, peak experiences that prompted eloquent writing.

Ebert was often described as egalitarian and populist in his approach to movies and life. â€œLife Itselfâ€ù opens by citing his definition of cinema as â€œa machine that generates empathy,â€ù and he was not interested in rarefied or exclusionary approaches to aesthetics. Even if he was writing about Bergman or Bresson, he was writing for the widest possible readership. Yet, as A. O. Scott of The New York Times comments, he never pandered or condescended.

This is not only a film about Roger Ebert but also a film very much with and by Roger Ebert, who was the most famous and affectionately regarded of American movie critics, the Pulitzer Prize-winning reviewer for The Chicago Sun-Times who, in company with Gene Siskel, improbably became a globally known television star, and who refused to be laid low by the medical catastrophes of his last years. A friend describes him as having been, early on, â€œnot just the chief character and star of the movie that was his life, he was also the director.â€ù â€œLife Itselfâ€ù is indeed broadly shaped by Ebertâ€™s own interpretation of his life and clearly marked by his sense of what kind of film it should be.

Ebertâ€™s words are joined by those of many others: filmmaker friends like Martin Scorsese and Werner Herzog, and old acquaintances whose deep fondness is apparent but who donâ€™t gloss over his complications and confusions, from his outwardly rowdy days hanging out at Oâ€™Rourkeâ€™s in Chicago (he stopped drinking in the late â€™70s) to the defensive petulance sometimes provoked by Siskel during their on-air critical brawls. (â€œHe is a nice guy,â€ù one friend smilingly comments, â€œbut heâ€™s not that nice.â€ù) There is a rich aura of journalistic camaraderie and Chicago solidarity. When The Washington Postâ€™s editors tried to lure him away with a big-money offer, Ebert told them, â€œIâ€™m not gonna learn new streets.â€ù

It cannot have been easy for Chaz Ebert to be filmed at a time of the most extreme vulnerability. With her wrenching account of his last days â€” â€œHe was beginning to feel trapped insideâ€ù â€” we are at last unavoidably caught up face to face with the absence that even the liveliest of wakes must finally acknowledge.

â€œGene,â€ù an observer notes, â€œwas a rogue planet in Rogerâ€™s solar system.â€ù Shouting matches and withering put-downs were hallmarks of their show â€” critical argument became comic performance art â€” but the tensions were real enough. When Ebert yells, â€œI disagree particularly about the part you like!,â€ù it is almost like intruding on a family argument. A series of outtakes in which they trade insults between fluffed lines is both hilarious and a bit harrowing. Interpersonal dynamics (and eye-popping â€™70s fashions) aside, the frustratingly brief clips shown here provoke an appetite for more.

â€œLife Itselfâ€ù is a work of deftness and delicacy, by turns a film about illness and death, about writing, about cinema and, finally, and very movingly a film about love. Ebert was, by his own and othersâ€™ accounts, transformed by meeting and marrying Chaz when he was 50. She was an African-American civil rights lawyer more interested, as he put it, in who he was than in what he did. He became part of her extended family, and as we watch him in home videos from the good days before his troubles started, it is like watching a man blossoming before our eyes.

â€œClosed Curtain,â€ù as its title suggests, draws on theater as well as film for inspiration. He wonders who she is and why she is there, while she seems to know quite a lot about him.

Before the ban, which was set in 2010 after Mr. Panahiâ€™s arrest in the midst of a widespread government crackdown, his way of blending tough, humane naturalism with formal self-consciousness had made him a leading figure in Iranian cinema. Movies like â€œThe Circleâ€ù (2001), â€œCrimson Goldâ€ù (2003) and â€œOffsideâ€ù (2007) were honest, unsettling explorations of gender inequality and class division in Iran and, at the same time, sly meditations on how cinema can represent such issues. In â€œThis Is Not a Filmâ€ù (2012), he confronted the absurdity of official repression and subverted it, composing a cinematic essay that was at once urgently political and playfully philosophical.

Then again: She might be a figment of his imagination, unless both of them are figments of the directorsâ€™. These things might both be true, if the writer is working on a version of the scenario we are watching, and Mr. Panahi is putting it on film. And yet the director (if that is what he is) seems completely oblivious to the other occupants of his house and too preoccupied with mundane matters (eating lunch, supervising the repair of a broken window) to be making a film. He is not allowed to do that, anyway, and so he allows â€œClosed Curtainâ€ù to unfold in an intriguing limbo of deniability, subverting both its own existence and its officially mandated nonexistence.

For the viewer, this conundrum is both troubling and amusing. On one level, the film (or nonfilm; it was shot on digital video and partly with smartphone cameras) is a mischievous, Pirandellian entertainment. It is also an allegory, dark but not despairing, of the creative spirit under political pressure, and of the ways the imagination can be both a refuge and a place of confinement.

This could be the start of a mystery, and that word would not be completely out of place as a description of â€œClosed Curtain.â€ù But the narrative puzzles that might animate a more conventional film â€” Who is this woman? Why is she here? What is the writer hiding from? What will happen between them? â€” soon give way to other, more complicated enigmas. One of these is precisely what kind of movie this is, a question that has special piquancy because Jafar Panahi, who is credited as a writer and director (with Kambuzia Partovi, who plays the writer), is under a 20-year filmmaking ban imposed by the Iranian government.

Some of that mixture of defiance and whimsy is present in â€œClosed Curtain,â€ù but it is also edged with melancholy and fatigue. When Mr. Panahi, who turns 54 this week, does show up on screen â€” itâ€™s his villa, after all, decorated with European posters advertising his films â€” he looks wearier and older than he did in â€œThis Is Not a Film,â€ù suggesting that several years of legal struggle and professional limbo have taken a toll. Why Iceland? Mitch has his reasons; and while they donâ€™t stick, it also doesnâ€™t matter. Written and directed by Martha Stephens and Aaron Katz, this isnâ€™t a movie for viewers who become easily hung up on narrative niceties like character motivation. As laid back as Mitch is after a few midnight tokes, â€œLand Ho!â€ù is a breezy story of two men making a connection, but it also comes across as an excuse to cut loose two appealing screen presences â€” Mr. Eenhoorn is an indie-film notable, and Mr. Nelson is a real-life surgeon as well as Ms. Stephenâ€™s second cousin â€” in a series of stunning panoramas. And so, after a quiet meal over wine and lonely-guy reminiscences, during which the estranged acquaintances start reheating their friendship, Mitch and Colin take off for the land of fire, ice and BjÃ¶rk.

The road movie, that asphalt playground of fast cars, masculine prerogative, gangland sprees and occasional feminist cri de coeur, is such a durable American genre that you can fly the idea halfway around the world, drop it on Iceland, rev up a car the size of a military tank and still make it work. This pretty much describes what happens in â€œLand Ho!,â€ù a delightful tale of two longtime friends of a certain age, Colin (Paul Eenhoorn) and Mitch (Earl Lynn Nelson), who embark on a classic journey of self-discovery generously embellished with laughter, otherworldly beauty and philosophical inquiries into the nature of existence perfumed by the aroma of cheerfully smoked joints.

There, the men go looking for America â€” well, actually they tour Iceland in a Hummer, accompanied by blasts of pop (notably from the Scottish band Big Country) and on-screen textual scene setters (ReykjavÃ_k, Landmannalaugar and the tongue-twisting like). Early into their adventure, they spend some time with Mitchâ€™s young cousin, Ellen (Karrie Crouse), and her friend, Janet (Elizabeth McKee, Mr. Katzâ€™s wife), whoâ€™ve been touring Europe and are headed home to the States. The four swank it up at dinner and end up at a club where, as Colin notes, he and Mitch are, by far, the oldest people. Age tends to creep into their talks as a rueful metaphysical truth and blunt existential fact, but that same night Mitch also gets stoned with a young guy in a club bathroom.

Mitch and Colin are the star attractions and thatâ€™s as crucial to the movieâ€™s meaning as the fact that theyâ€™re so beautifully lighted and shot. Old age in American cinema rarely inspires the kind of beauty found in the delicate white wisps on Bruce Dernâ€™s head in the film â€œNebraska,â€ù a windblown expression of man on the verge of evanescence. The two characters in â€œLand Ho!â€ù are far more robust: Theyâ€™re healthy and solidly, lustily present, despite the occasional hitch in their step. That theyâ€™ve run off to Iceland is surely a narrative contrivance, but every road movie is also a reflection of its moment and that eraâ€™s concerns and tensions. Old dudes may just want to have fun, but to be truly free â€” including from the ageism of American cinema â€” sometimes you need to hit someone elseâ€™s road.

It would be foolish to hang serious sociopolitical weight on â€œLand Ho!,â€ù a movie that, after all, routinely cranks up the tunes to get from here to there. At times, Colin and Mitchâ€™s trip to Iceland feels like a lark, for them and for the filmmakers. Yet thereâ€™s no denying the deepening effect of a movie in which two older men, with their creases and sags, white and thinning hair, inhabit so much screen time. In too many movies, older characters are repellently cute and kooky, functioning little more than as toys for the younger protagonist to drag around and sometimes chew on, an infantilization of both the characters and viewers, which speaks to a fear of death.
â€œLand Ho!â€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Salty language ahoy!
