The realism is jolting, and so brilliantly realized and understated that it would be easy to overlook. In â€œBoyhood,â€ù Mr. Linklaterâ€™s inspired idea of showing the very thing that most movies either ignore or awkwardly elide â€” the passage of time â€” is its impressive, headline-making conceit. Starting in 2002, he gathered his four lead actors each year for a three- to four-day shoot, working on the script as they went along. (The consummate anti-slacker, Mr. Linklater also shot during that period a clutch of shorts and features, including â€œBefore Sunset,â€ù the second in a trilogy of films with Mr. Hawke; a fictional adaptation of â€œFast Food Nationâ€ù; and a weirdly touching comedy about a murderer, â€œBernie.â€ù)

Instead, the movie ebbs and flows from year to year, interspersed with temporal signposts like a Britney Spears song or a Nintendo Wii. One minute, Mason is looking quizzically at Olivia while she chats with a professor, Bill (Marco Perella); the next, heâ€™s with his sister and Billâ€™s children, Mindy (Jamie Howard) and Randy (Andrew Villarreal), in the backyard the two families now share as one. Some of the transitions are imperceptible, especially when Mason is younger, and all are meaningful. Midway through, when he strips off his shirt to go swimming with his father and then asks about girls, you see the last traces of baby fat and true childhood. By the next section, Mason has shot up and slimmed down, and is now talking to girls, not just about them.

The GTO is a minor authorial marker, and probably helped keep costs down in this relatively inexpensive production. (The movie was heroically bankrolled from the start by its distributor, Jonathan Sehring of IFC Films.) More practically, it works as an expressive emblem to go along with Mason Sr.â€™s absences, his careless parenting, on-and-off facial hair and earnest bohemian rhapsodies. Unforgiving observers may write Mason Sr. off as a deadbeat, but, like Olivia, who sometimes lobs expletives at her unfazed children, heâ€™s deeply loving. These arenâ€™t movie parents with formulaic arcs and storybook solutions, but characters whose honest, raw hurt and moments of casual grace carry the shock of the real. These are people you know, maybe people like you.

Itâ€™s no surprise that watching actors naturally age on camera without latex and digital effects makes for mesmerizing viewing. And at first it may be hard to notice much more than the creases etching Mr. Hawkeâ€™s face, the sexy swells of Ms. Arquetteâ€™s belly and Mr. Coltraneâ€™s growth spurts. You may see your own face in those faces, your childrenâ€™s, too. This kind of identification is familiar, as is the idea that movies preserve time. AndrÃ© Bazin wrote that art emerged from our desire to counter the passage of time and the inevitable decay it brings. But in â€œBoyhood,â€ù Mr. Linklaterâ€™s masterpiece, he both captures moments in time and relinquishes them as he moves from year to year. He isnâ€™t fighting time but embracing it in all its glorious and agonizingly fleeting beauty.
â€œBoyhoodâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). The film contains some familiar expletives and scenes of domestic violence.

What emerged from those dozen years is a series of meticulously textured and structured scenes set to the rhythm of life. The structure is crucial. Mr. Linklater has long experimented with nontraditional narratives, from the baton-relay form of â€œSlacker,â€ù in which he leaves one character to follow the next, to the peripatetic ramblings of his â€œBeforeâ€ù trilogy. His films are sometimes mischaracterized as having no plot, perhaps because they may seem so, when compared with aggressively incident-jammed mainstream movies. One of the fascinating things about â€œBoyhoodâ€ù is that a lot happens â€” there are parties and fights, laughter and tears â€” but all these events take place in a distinctly quotidian register and without the usual filmmaking prodding and cues.

The filmâ€™s visual style is precise, unassuming to the point of seeming invisibility and in the service of the characters, with compositions that remain unfussy and uncluttered, even when the rooms are busy. When Mr. Linklater films a landscape, your eye locks not on the camerawork but on the beauty of these spaces and the people in them â€” the enveloping greenness of the neighborhood in which Mason first rides a bike, for instance, and the tranquillity of the watering hole that, years later, he swims in with his dad. Mr. Linklater is especially fond of showing two people walking and talking, and you learn as much about the charactersâ€™ relationships from how they inhabit space â€” his two-shots speak volumes â€” as from what they say. Heâ€™s a poet-geometrician of intimacy.

Filmed over 12 consecutive years, â€œBoyhoodâ€ù centers on Mason (Ellar Coltrane), whoâ€™s 6 when the story opens and 18 when it ends. In between, he goes to school; argues with his sister, Samantha (Lorelei Linklater, the directorâ€™s daughter); and watches his mother, Olivia (Patricia Arquette), struggle with work and men while paying the bills, moving from home to home and earning several degrees. Every so often, her ex-husband, Mason Sr. (Ethan Hawke), roars into the childrenâ€™s lives, initially in a 1968 GTO. It isnâ€™t a dad car (although it does belong to one: Mr. Linklater). It is, rather, the same model of masculine cool that rumbles through â€œTwo-Lane Blacktop,â€ù one of Mr. Linklaterâ€™s favorite movies, and which heâ€™s slipped into films like â€œSlackerâ€ù and â€œDazed and Confused.â€ù

The first shot in â€œBoyhood,â€ùRichard Linklaterâ€™s tender, profound film, is of a cloudy sky. The second is of a boy staring up at that sky, one arm bent under his head, the other flung out straight on the ground. Heâ€™s a pretty child with calm eyes, a snub nose and a full mouth. Itâ€™s a face that you get to know and love because, even as this child is watching the world, youâ€™re watching him grow. From scene to scene, you see the curve of his jaw change, notice his thickening brows and witness his slender arms opening to embrace the world and its clear and darkening skies.

Itâ€™s almost surprising that no one seems to have made a movie like â€œBoyhoodâ€ù before. Its closest counterpart is probably the â€œ7 Upâ€ù series, Michael Aptedâ€™s multipart documentary project that since 1964 has dropped in every seven years on the same, more or less, British women and men, beginning when they were 7. Watching seemingly carefree children thrive and fail as they age â€” or, more prosaically, turn into dreary, respectable citizens â€” can be like a knife in your heart. It can also be somewhat eerie, simply because the series compresses decades of a human life into scenes that are, by turns, seamless and jagged â€” an eeriness that â€œBoyhoodâ€ù shares as 12 years of Masonâ€™s life slips by in 165 startlingly fast minutes. Weâ€™re here today, gone tomorrow.

Radical in its conceit, familiar in its everyday details, â€œBoyhoodâ€ù exists at the juncture of classical cinema and the modern art film without being slavishly indebted to either tradition. Itâ€™s a model of cinematic realism, and its pleasures are obvious yet mysterious. Even after seeing the film three times, I havenâ€™t fully figured out why it has maintained such a hold on me, and why Iâ€™m eager to see it again. There are many reasons to love movies, from the stories they tell, to the beautiful characters who live and die for us. And yet the story in â€œBoyhoodâ€ù is blissfully simple: A child grows up. This, along with the modesty of its physical production â€” its humble rooms, quiet moments, ordinary lives â€” can obscure Mr. Linklaterâ€™s ambitions and the greatness of his achievement.

For a filmmaker known for the loquaciousness of his characters, Mr. Linklater has an almost un-American rejection of overexplanation. When you first meet Mason at 6, gazing at the sky while lying on a patch of grass, he looks a touch beatific. He also looks like a little kid staring into space. Is he happy, sad or bored? And when he gazes at a dead bird, what does he think?; how does he feel? Mr. Linklater doesnâ€™t say. Instead, he fills the frame with a close-up of Masonâ€™s face, letting the silence and weight of death linger. Mr. Linklaterâ€™s characters can talk a blue streak, but rarely in his work, and never in â€œBoyhood,â€ù do you hear the hum of his narrative design under their words.

Mr. Cage does get to bellow to the heavens, when a stooge dies too quickly atop a waterlogged roof. And he has some fine company in Danny Glover, as a police investigator with a Noltean rasp, and Peter Stormare, as a crime boss in a wheelchair who tries to talk Paul, his former employee, out of his bloodlust. But perhaps the best part of â€œRageâ€ù is, no snark intended, Paulâ€™s grim acceptance of his fate at the end â€” only to be swiftly spoiled by a pointless slow-motion sequence.

A reformed mobster, Paul (Mr. Cage), is the daddy on the warpath after his daughter, Caitlin (Aubrey Peeples), is killed, apparently in a break-in. Goaded at first by his wife (Rachel Nichols), he clumsily throws himself into a series of brutal brawls and knifings with the help of two cronies, soon stirring up old trouble. Mindlessly shaky, circling camerawork, guitar licks and ill-timed flashbacks all insist that this catalog of revengeâ€™s futility is pulse-pounding, but the ramp-ups tend to sap scenes of their energy.

Those expecting Nicolas Cage theatrics in â€œRageâ€ù â€” and why not, with a title that practically cries out for a rhyming tagline â€” may be disappointed. Mr. Cage underplays in his latest role, as a father out for justice after his daughterâ€™s violent death, and itâ€™s at least an attempt at a change-up. But the hand-me-down showiness and sluggish storytelling by the director, Paco Cabezas, underline the monotony in this ordinary revenge thriller.
â€œDawn of the Planet of the Apesâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Animal cruelty.

But this is not â€œDusk of the Planet of the Humans.â€ù The spectacle of yet another desperate population, huddled together in the wake of catastrophe to await the next zombie, alien, robot or monster attack, would be unlikely to inspire much excitement. The real interest lies across the battered Golden Gate Bridge, in Marin County, where our evolutionary cousins, under the benevolent guidance of an upright-walking chimpanzee named Caesar, have built their own civilization. In contrast to the bedraggled human colony, the ape encampment is a thriving city-state with distinctive wooden architecture, domesticated horses, a sophisticated (mostly signed) language and an educational system overseen by Maurice, the gentle, copper-furred orangutan who gave the first movie an extra fillip of soul.

Caesar, who saw the generous, tender side of humanity when he was hanging out with Mr. Franco and Freida Pinto, is willing to give our kind the benefit of the doubt. There is plenty of evidence â€” both in the movie and beyond it â€” to support Kobaâ€™s view, but the film comes down squarely, and maybe a little too squishily, on the side of tolerance and cooperation. The ape and human societies are parallel primitive patriarchies (women nurture and worry, while men lead and fight, a disappointing but hardly surprising failure of imagination on the filmmakersâ€™ part), and they are threatened by symmetrical schisms. As Koba opposes Caesar, so does Malcolm (Mr. Clarkeâ€™s character) find himself increasingly at odds with Dreyfus (Mr. Oldman), who sees the apes as a mortal threat to be confronted with maximum brutality.

Starting with the apes themselves. In the final credits, Andy Serkis receives top billing for his performance as Caesar, a role that continues to redefine screen acting in the digital age. His facial expressions and body language are so evocatively and precisely rendered that it is impossible to say where his art ends and the exquisite artifice of Weta Digital, the special-effects company, begins. The same is true of the other main ape performers: Karin Konoval (Maurice); Nick Thurston (Caesarâ€™s son Blue Eyes); Judy Greer (Caesarâ€™s wife, Cornelia); and especially Toby Kebbell as Koba, Caesarâ€™s lieutenant and eventual nemesis.

A quick montage at the beginning of â€œDawn of the Planet of the Apesâ€ù fills us in on what has happened since â€œRise of the Planet of the Apes.â€ù Three years have gone by for us in the audience, and about a decade for the assorted primates on the screen. James Franco and millions of other people are dead, victims of a lethal virus and the usual apocalypse-causing disease of hubris. After a period of violence and chaos, the survivors have cobbled together a reasonably stable society in the ruins of San Francisco, with Gary Oldman in charge.

And while â€œRiseâ€ù found room for exuberance in the shadow of catastrophe â€” partly because it seemed so justifiably excited by its own ingenuity â€” â€œDawn,â€ù its title notwithstanding, paints a darker, scarier picture of the future. It also has a grave, brooding beauty, intensified by Michael Giacchinoâ€™s wild and subtle score and by the deep, verdant shadows of Michael Seresinâ€™s cinematography. Mr. Reeves has a fine sense of visual detail and also of the eloquence of nonverbal exchanges between characters, digitally enhanced and otherwise. (Ms. Russell and Kodi Smit-McPhee, as her adolescent son, do especially graceful work in limited roles.) The film is full of small, memorable moments and crowded with distinctive personalities on both sides of the ape-human divide.

The arguments â€” in essence, about whether the boundaries of solidarity should stay within the tribe or extend beyond it â€” give â€œDawn of the Planet of the Apesâ€ù a nice allegorical heft. The old movies, which blew the minds and troubled the sleep of many children in the â€™60s and â€™70s (including young Bobby Draper in Season 6 of â€œMad Menâ€ù), arrived at a time of racial conflict, ecological anxiety and a general sense of social breakdown. Since then, cinematic technology has evolved from rubber masks to digital sculpture, and our fears and aspirations have mutated, too, making â€œPlanet of the Apesâ€ù a less abstract, more hauntingly immediate story.

In other words, itâ€™s a satisfying movie and an example â€” a dispiritingly rare one these days â€” of what mainstream Hollywood filmmaking can still achieve. That we have progressed from â€œRiseâ€ù only as far as â€œDawnâ€ù suggests many future sequels, which may, in this case, be a source of hope as well as dread, provided that civilization doesnâ€™t collapse in the meantime.

The sylvan, simian Athens in the Muir Woods is a remarkable achievement and an important part of what makes â€œDawn of the Planet of the Apes,â€ù directed by Matt Reeves from a script by Rick Jaffa, Amanda Silver and Mark Bomback, the best of this summerâ€™s large-scale, big-studio franchise movies. Granted, this isnâ€™t a very high bar to clear: â€œbetter than â€˜Transformers 4â€™Â â€ù barely counts as praise, even with an exclamation mark. But unlike that toy-smashing extravaganza â€” and unlike 2014â€™s visitations from the â€œSpider-Man,â€ùâ€œX-Menâ€ù and â€œGodzillaâ€ù money trains â€” â€œDawnâ€ù is more than a bunch of occasionally thrilling action sequences, emotional gut punches and throwaway jokes arranged in predictable sequence. It is technically impressive and viscerally exciting, for sure, but it also gives you a lot to think, and even to care, about.

Koba, a survivor of scientific experiments, bears the physical and moral scars of human cruelty. The humans, about to run out of fuel, want to restore an abandoned hydroelectric station in ape territory, and they ask Caesar for help. The second half tells the aftermath of that victory. A 2014 scene has the team again meeting with the M.I.T. students, who are all having fine careers in science and engineering; of the Carl Hayden graduates, only one has completed college.

The graceful flow avoids the spoon-feeding of pocket biographies, and even if the material can feel lean at times, Mr. Klinger shepherds along a valuable encounter with a sense of easy, generally uncanned observation.

This is partly a matter of casting. Michael Pitt and Brit Marling (the star and co-writer of â€œAnother Earth,â€ù Mr. Cahillâ€™s haunting debut) play Ian and Karen, blond genetic researchers who speak in earnest whispers and occasionally allow tears to fill their beautiful eyes. Speaking of which, and for good measure, Astrid BergÃ¨s-Frisbey shows up as Sofi, a mysterious, capricious young woman with stunning peepers who captures Ianâ€™s heart and challenges his empiricist ideas about the world. He thinks that the experiment he and Karen are pursuing â€” they are trying to engineer the evolution of sight in blind worms â€” will decisively refute religious accounts of existence. Sofi favors a more mystical view and tries to convince Ian that he may be gifted with second sight.

For about half its running time, â€œI Originsâ€ù wanders suggestively and seductively through the lives of these three extremely attractive people, casting hints about what their activities might mean while spending a lot of time in bed with Ian and Sofi. Mr. Cahill has a dreamy, Malicky camera style and a subtle, elusive approach to storytelling, and for a while this casts an intriguing, melancholy spell. New York looks scruffy and gorgeous and bohemian, and so (at the risk of repeating myself) do Mr. Pitt and Ms. BergÃ¨s-Frisbey. Ms. Marling, too, but at this point, sheâ€™s mostly in the lab, while the others are on picturesque subway platforms and wind-tousled streets.

â€œAnother Earthâ€ù was a heartfelt entertainment that managed to infuse a tantalizing science fiction premise with thought and feeling. â€œI Originsâ€ù is too committed to explaining itself to repeat the trick and falls into the trap of taking its daffy intellectual conceits far too seriously. It may blow your mind, but only if youâ€™re not in the habit of using it.

The eyes are windows to the soul. That fuzzy bit of wisdom is repeated several times, with both reverence and skepticism, in â€œI Origins,â€ù Mike Cahillâ€™s new film. Whatever that may mean, thereâ€™s no doubt that eyes are also the portals through which movies, good and bad, enter our consciousness. Considered strictly as a visual experience, this one, which might be described as a faith-based emo-science romance-thriller, is often quite beguiling.
â€œI Originsâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Some of the philosophical discussions are conducted naked in bed.

Then a lot of stuff happens that is mildly surprising in the moment and grindingly obvious in retrospect. Someone dies, a baby is born, anxious conversations are had, and the action shifts from New York to New Delhi (both exquisitely shot with a Red Digital camera by Markus FÃ¶rderer, the cinematographer). In the midst of it all, the argument between spiritualism and science that has been hovering in the background becomes more explicit.

And also fairly embarrassing to partisans on both sides and ruinous to the movieâ€™s sensuous, twee magic. Ianâ€™s conviction that the data he and Karen have assembled will end the debate is as simplistic and immature as the contrary notion (which gains force as the story advances) that supernaturalism could be experimentally proved. Itâ€™s possible that movies, which so often traffic in illusion, have an inherent bias toward the irrational. But it is usually better â€” as the middle career of M. Night Shyamalan conclusively demonstrates â€” to embrace supernaturalism at the level of effects rather than that of ideas.
K MISSING KINGS
Directed by Shingo Suzuki
In Japanese, with English subtitles
Opens on Friday

For fans who know the series, this should be a sturdy, respectably plotted installment, jumping off from a search for the missing Silver King by his followers and tracing the skirmishes and revelations that result amid glass high-rises and malls. But despite a generous attempt at a series recap, itâ€™s chaotic for the uninitiated. These characters require several episodes of exposure for us to feel that much is at stake in the ebb and flow of honor, hysteria and eternal friendship.

In any case, the animation is often a pure sensual delight. The shimmering cityscape that is the storyâ€™s setting is about as subtly lighted as a nuclear explosion, with intense, flamelike blues and reds. Then there are the lingering anime traditions of teeth-gritting male characters built like blades of grass and breast-and-panty views of at least one female character, suggesting that every summer movie market offers something to sigh in exasperation about.

The Japanese anime series â€œKâ€ù has chalked up a single season on television (at least so far) in the United States but apparently attracted enough of a following, together with its associated manga serials, to warrant the release of â€œK Missing Kingsâ€ù in multiple American theaters. Barely over an hour, though crammed with soapy intrigues, frenzied fighting and errant forelocks, this film from Shingo Suzuki continues the contemporary urban wars and intrigues between clansmen aligned with color-coded kings.

Does Michel Gondry dream of being a toymaker, a watchmaker or the master of his own private circus? That certainly seems likely, given the ingenious contraptions, live-action and animated, that motor and hum through his latest, â€œMood Indigo.â€ù Nominally a romance about a boy and a girl, the movie is more rightly a feature-length expression of Mr. Gondryâ€™s love of whirring, purring creations, including the doorbell that scuttles like a large ring-a-ding insect and the upright piano that whips up cocktails and the mouse that makes mischief and the mechanical cloud that sails over Paris and, and, and. ...

Audrey Tautou stars as the girl, ChloÃ©, who meets the boy, Colin, played by Romain Duris. Both actors are about 30 years too old for their roles, and the strain of pantomiming cute and kooky is evident in their leaden smiles, labored physicality and expressed lack of feeling. Their characters meet at a party and, before long, are shacked up in Colinâ€™s playhouse, which looks like a train and comes with its own metaphoric porter, Nicolas (Omar Sy). A world-class smiler, Nicolas cooks up whimsical, humorously animated meals for Colin by, for instance, catching eels that slip out of the water taps, while dispensing advice on dating and dancing. Much like the resident pet mouse (Sacha Bourdo, miniaturized), Nicolas largely registers as an amusing addition to Colinâ€™s overstuffed chest of toys.

Even at its abbreviated length, â€œMood Indigoâ€ù soon feels almost desperately interminable, a wearying experience that resembles being locked in a very small room with an exceptionally bright, pathologically self-absorbed child who will not shut up or calm down. Mr. Gondryâ€™s imagination, paradoxically, is most liberated when itâ€™s attached to a strong tether, whether itâ€™s the ideas in â€œEternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind,â€ù or the subject of â€œIs the Man Who Is Tall Happy?,â€ù his documentary on Noam Chomsky. Vianâ€™s novel is a formidable work, if only because of its exalted place in French literature. But the bookâ€™s surrealism and its darkness (the ending is a killer) have defeated Mr. Gondry, who here sinks under the weight of unbearable lightness.

Overflowing with vivid and sagging flights of fancy, â€œMood Indigoâ€ù is an example of that subgenre known as the cinematic cabinet of curiosities. (Other practitioners include Terry Gilliam.) Mr. Gondry, who wrote the script with Luc Bossi, follows the sweep of Vianâ€™s novel and occasionally stumbles down a detour that becomes a dead end. A subplot involving Colinâ€™s friend Chick (Gad Elmaleh) and his obsession with a philosopher, Jean-Sol Partre (Philippe Torreton), is especially unfortunate because, at least in this film, thereâ€™s nothing funny about a giant Sartrean pipe. There may have been more of a payoff in the original version: â€œMood Indigoâ€ù ran about two hours when it opened in France in 2013; the cut released in the United States runs 94.

More begets more and then too much in â€œMood Indigo,â€ù which Mr. Gondry adapted from the much loved 1947 French novel â€œLâ€™Ã‰cume des Jours,â€ù by Boris Vian (1920-1959), a prolific author, jazzman and F.O.S. (friend of Sartre). The book has been translated as â€œFroth on the Daydreamâ€ù and the prosaic (and strange) â€œFoam of the Daze,â€ù but the poetically elegiac â€œMood Indigoâ€ù seems the best fit for its arc and tone. Duke Ellington, who was the godfather to Vianâ€™s daughter, Carole, described â€œMood Indigoâ€ù as about a boy and a girl who are around 8. She loves the boy every day he visits her house. But one day he doesnâ€™t come. â€œMood Indigo,â€ù Ellington said, â€œjust tells how she feels.â€ù

What are those goals? No need to say, because all that this film, written and directed by Daniel Lusko, is really trying to do is push the â€œwe are persecutedâ€ù button of its intended audience. The title â€” â€œPersecutedâ€ù â€” and the presence of the Fox News personality Gretchen Carlson in the cast are really all you need to know. Those are the ones he and Annie need to retrieve in a hurry. â€œSex Tapeâ€ù is one of those against-the-clock panic movies â€” like â€œHorrible Bossesâ€ù or â€œDate Nightâ€ù â€” that string together a set of nutty circumstances featuring kooky supporting players. Mr. Segel gallops through a mansion, chased by an angry German shepherd, which is not all that funny, while Ms. Diaz snorts cocaine with Rob Lowe, which is. Rob Corddry and Ellie Kemper are wacky friends along for the ride. Jack Black shows up just when things start running out of gas. Ms. Diaz and Mr. Segel sustain the whole thing with the bright energy of foul-mouthed, anatomically detailed Muppets.

Donâ€™t get your hopes up. Or maybe I should say donâ€™t worry. Because in spite of a title that evokes everything tawdry and salacious in contemporary on-line culture (at least circa 2007), in spite of a steady cascade of obscene language, and in spite of a naked buttock here and there, â€œSex Tape,â€ù directed by Jake Kasdan, is as wholesome as a spoonful of nonfat Greek yogurt. If you are expecting a movie that finds humor in squirming embarrassment and that touches modern anxieties about the loss of privacy and the technological exploitation of the libido, you might be disappointed. But then again, maybe youâ€™d just prefer to stay home with your laptop in the first place, doing research.

The resulting video â€” a three-hour acrobatic extravaganza, highlights of which are shared with the movie audience â€” ascends into the cloud and migrates to a handful of other tablets. Annie and Jay need to get them. The plausibility of this circumstance was recently tested by Lauren Bans, an intrepid GQ writer who made a phone call to Apple tech support. If Jay or Annie had done that, â€œSex Tapeâ€ù would have been quite a lot shorter. One reason for the R rating might be to spare digitally native kids the mortification of seeing how clueless their parents can be.

The Internet, it has been said, is a series of tubes. So is the human body. The intersection of these two systems â€” each one sticky, nasty and fascinating in its own special way â€” is a fact of daily life and also the subject of â€œSex Tape,â€ù a new R-rated comedy starring Jason Segel and Cameron Diaz.

Mr. Segel and Ms. Diaz, long-limbed and likable, play Jay and Annie, a married couple who spent their years as college sweethearts in a frenzy of copulation. The actors, 34 (Mr. Segel) and 41 (Ms. Diaz),play their charactersâ€™ younger selves with what look like digitally smoothed faces, to somewhat creepy, â€œBenjamin Buttonâ€ù-like effect. A pair of kids (Sebastian Hedges Thomas and Giselle Eisenberg) and other tokens of adult responsibility have cooled things down between them, a situation Annie and Jay decide to remedy with the help of a bottle of tequila, a new iPad and an old copy of â€œThe Joy of Sex.â€ù

The hovering question is not â€œCould this really happen?â€ù but â€œWould anyone really care if it did?â€ù While there is some notion that the sale of Annieâ€™s blog to a toy company would be jeopardized if the video were to come to light, she and Jay donâ€™t seem to risk much more than mild discomfort. And the main reason that â€œSex Tape,â€ù while often quite funny, fails to qualify as a comedy is the absence of any real conflict or complication. Annie and Jay clearly love each other, and the notes of strife and alienation that pop up between them in the course of their hectic night are too small and muted to cause any worry. This means that the resolution of their problems has no weight.

But letâ€™s not pick nits. The movie, written by Kate Angelo, Nicholas Stoller and Mr. Segel, also asks us to believe that Annie is on the verge of selling her blog about motherhood for big money, a plot point that inspired raucous (if largely mirthless) laughter from the press rows at my screening. Jay, in case you were wondering, works at a radio station, exactly the kind of cool, vague job that comedy husbands tend to have these days and one that sort of explains why so many people have iPads connected to his.
â€œSex Tapeâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Itâ€™s called â€œSex Tape.â€ù

And the humor has no bite, no friction, none of the transgressive thrill that Mr. Kasdan and Ms. Diaz (with an assist from Mr. Segel) brought to â€œBad Teacher.â€ù â€œSex Tapeâ€ù is a safe and cautious movie, intent above all on respecting the modern taboo against being mean. Jay sustains some cuts and bruises, thanks to some rough physical comedy, but nobodyâ€™s feelings are in danger of being hurt. Cruelty-free laughter can be a challenge, and some of the ways this movie confronts it are less than imaginative. It avoids giving possible offense to nonwhite, nonheterosexual people by pretty much leaving them out of the picture altogether. Still, there are worse things in this world than a light, sweet, silly comedy about two nice people having a good time in bed.

The ruling elite â€” the self-anointed â€œNew Founding Fathersâ€ù â€” justify this yearly cathartic as a kind of collective colonic, a way to flush all the toxins from the body politic. (Well, the movie is set in Los Angeles, that city of detoxifying angels and master cleanses.) The more plausible explanation is that the writer and director, James DeMonaco, like a lot of Americans, read Shirley Jacksonâ€™s influential 1948 short story â€œThe Lotteryâ€ù at an impressionable age. Ritual sacrifice, either of the self or others, may be almost as old as humanity itself, but itâ€™s also enjoying a pop cultural moment, from the purifying spectacle of â€œThe Hunger Gamesâ€ù series to gladiatorial shows like â€œDancing With the Starsâ€ù and that blood-slicked altar of worship known as â€œGame of Thrones.â€ù

Kill or be killed isnâ€™t the official tag line of â€œThe Purge: Anarchy,â€ù but it fits. It would also make a more suitable title for this satisfyingly creepy, blunt, down-and-dirty thriller, one of those follow-ups that improves on the original. Once again, itâ€™s a new morning in future America, and crime is still down, as is unemployment. The only thing that appears to be keeping the peace and assuring prosperity is the government-sanctioned annual bloodletting, that one night a year in which the citizenry can run amok without punishment. The word anarchy is purely superfluous.
â€œThe Purge: Anarchyâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Mass mayhem.

Once these many are one, Sergeant and his timorous little band creep and race through the depopulated cityscape, which, punctuated by eerie screams, sickening pops of gunfire and assorted menaces, has been transformed into a labyrinthine obstacle course cum sicko amusement park. Mr. DeMonaco keeps it nasty and simple, giving the movie an accordion-like rhythm by consistently bringing you close to the characters, only to pull back to show just how imperiled they are. Much of this is the familiar cat and mouse, although the introduction of a class revolutionary, Carmelo (Michael K. Williams in a black beret and beard), indicates that Mr. DeMonaco, who wrote the 2005 remake of â€œAssault on Precinct 13,â€ù has wisely absorbed the lessons of that genre maestro John Carpenter.

For the sequel, Mr. DeMonaco has opened up the story narratively and spatially, setting the action in a series of urban environs rather than inside the confines of one locked-down archetypal suburban house. Heâ€™s also divided the story into three strands that he swiftly weaves together into a pointed, unified whole when a lone stranger and would-be purger, called only Sergeant (the perfectly cast Frank Grillo) rescues two pairs of potential purgees: Eva (the sympathetic Carmen Ejogo) and her daughter, Cali (ZoÃ« Soul); and Shane (Zach Gilford) and his estranged partner, Liz (Kiele Sanchez). Sergeant has some unpleasant plans for the evening, for which he has come fully loaded. Fate, his conscience and Mr. DeMonaco have other plans for him: E pluribus unum, Baby.

As in the first â€œPurge,â€ù the sequel dangles an irresistible grindhouse hook: Every year, for 12 consecutive nocturnal hours, Americans are given a mass stay-out-of-jail card in order to pursue death, liberty and twisted happiness by committing the crimes of their choosing. The only apparent restrictions are on the size of weaponry: Machine guns and flamethrowers are fine, as are machetes, axes and good old-fashioned throttling hands; rocket-propelled guns, not so much. Although most of the population takes refuge, hiding behind fortifications that turn every home into a panic room (a manâ€™s house is his barricaded castle), a small percentage â€” mostly men, itâ€™s worth pointing out â€” roams the depopulated streets, primed to slice and dice strangers, neighbors and even relatives.

Even violence is casually wrist-flicked away, presented as no more or less of an issue than it is in movies. Except that in a movie, youâ€™re usually not the one wielding the gun or strangling the prostitute.

While Queenâ€™s â€œDonâ€™t Stop Me Nowâ€ù honks in the background, Sean Astinâ€™s awe-struck narration provides marshmallow-soft statistics. Did you know, for instance, that a staggering majority of parents think parental controls are useful? I bet youâ€™re as flabbergasted as I am.

In case youâ€™re not already nodding in agreement, several dozen celebrities, game developers and other worthies are waiting to twist your arm. (One man â€” perhaps misconnecting the medical dots â€” even credits gaming for his recovery from a stroke.)

For a documentary about an industry dedicated to seducing our eyes, â€œVideo Games: The Movieâ€ù is disappointingly ugly. Though mostly skating over science to wallow in culture, Mr. Snead fares better with an overview of gaming history that takes us from the creaky pleasures of Spacewar! in the 1960s to the precipice of full-body, virtual-reality scenarios. Thereâ€™s no substantive discussion, however, of gamingâ€™s profound influence on computer development â€” an impact that the crankily engaging AMC drama â€œHalt and Catch Fireâ€ù recently acknowledged. The Bloomsâ€™ precarious middle-class perch is imperiled when Gabe announces that he can no longer pay his grandchildrenâ€™s tuition at a yeshiva because he needs the money for an experimental treatment. Aidan, who refuses to send the children to public school, tries home-schooling them, but Tucker is far too unruly for it to work.

Aidan continues to go out on auditions, but sees his acting dream coming to an end and indulges a childhood fantasy of being a superhero space traveler who saves the world. These forced, cluttered fantasy sequences are deadly. The choice of this particular metaphor is a serious failure of imagination by Mr. Braff, who should know a clichÃ© when he sees one.

The family under the filmâ€™s lens is the Blooms: a Jewish clan whose stern but caring patriarch, Gabe (Mandy Patinkin), a retired microbiologist, is dying of lung cancer. Gabe isnâ€™t a lead role, but Mr. Patinkinâ€™s moving, understated portrayal of a thorny older man facing the end makes him the filmâ€™s emotional center of gravity. He is especially impressive when his voice begins to waver and rise in pitch, and you feel the characterâ€™s deeply submerged emotion.

Mr. Braff is a professed devotee of Woody Allen, and in both films, he has aimed for the same balance of profundity and absurdism that illuminates Mr. Allenâ€™s best comedies. Throughout â€œWish I Was Here,â€ù you are aware of how carefully its elements â€” from fantasy sci-fi sequences to deathbed confessions â€” are measured out in teaspoons.

In the movieâ€™s more contemplative moments, Aidan, who is only nominally religious, considers the meaning of life with a rabbi. But Mr. Braff in a metaphysical mode is at a loss for words. He canâ€™t write Woody Allen-worthy zingers to save himself. â€œWish I Was Hereâ€ù is so eager to please that you are never allowed to feel uncomfortable for more than a minute or two before a reassuringly stale joke rushes in to pat you on the head. (In â€œBullets Over Broadway: The Musical,â€ù Mr. Braff gets to deliver genuine Woody Allen dialogue.)

Until you partly surrender to its underlying good will and sincerity, watching â€œWish I Was Hereâ€ù is like observing an experiment in a cinematic test kitchen. The perky chefs are seeking an ideal blend of familiar flavors and textures as they devise what they hope will turn out to be a new, improved recipe for that old standby, Thoughtful Comic Entertainment.

Mr. Patinkinâ€™s performance helps make â€œWish I Was Here,â€ù with all its weaknesses, a far more persuasive and heartfelt portrait of death and dying than the recent â€œLullaby,â€ù which drowned in its own tears. But thatâ€™s not saying much.

In addition to Aidan are his wife, Sarah (Kate Hudson), who supports the family with a dull office job but whose patience is running out, and the coupleâ€™s children, 6-year-old Tucker (Pierce Gagnon) and his preteen older sister, Grace (Joey King). The wild card is Aidanâ€™s brother, Noah (Josh Gad), a reputedly brilliant but eccentric do-nothing ubernerd who lives in a trailer by the beach and who is happiest trundling around in costume at a Comic-Con event in San Diego.
â€œWish I Was Hereâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for language and some sexual content.

The man in a white lab coat is Zach Braff, who directed the movie from a screenplay he wrote with his brother Adam Braff and who stars as Aidan Bloom, an aspiring actor. Mr. Braff primarily comes out of TV sitcoms (â€œScrubsâ€ù), and it shows. His first feature film, â€œGarden State,â€ù a moderate indie hit 10 years ago, was essentially a TV comedy with pretensions to be a generational touchstone. â€œWish I Was Here,â€ù which studies the turmoil of a middle-class Los Angeles family, is the same deluxe fast food disguised as haute cuisine.

If this sounds unbearably mopey, relief is at hand in the anarchic form of three spirits, onetime goblins whose bad behavior has earned them a kind of afterlife community service. Sentenced to watch over Momo and her mother until her fatherâ€™s soul can take over, these supernatural Stooges, invisible to everyone except Momo, pierce her armor and lift the filmâ€™s mood. From the instant the smallest one â€” a potbellied, button-eyed baby â€” licks her leg with its pink, flypaper-long tongue, their unruly appetites and loony behavior inject a whimsical energy that gives the movie oomph.

Enveloped in a sweetness that buffers the depths of its emotions, Hiroyuki Okiuraâ€™s â€œA Letter to Momoâ€ù explores the stains of loss and regret on a personality too young to articulate them. Yet the filmâ€™s tiniest viewers are more likely to be entranced than distressed by this magical animated tale â€” Mr. Okiuraâ€™s second, after â€œJin-Roh: The Wolf Brigadeâ€ù (2001) â€” even if their parents find themselves surreptitiously sniffling.

This tenderness is what makes â€œA Letter to Momoâ€ù so memorable. As Momo conquers her fears, averts a tragedy and finally sees the beauty of her surroundings, the movie grabs your heart with the softest of hands. It took Mr. Okiura seven years to realize his story, but it doesnâ€™t take Momo nearly that long to comprehend that sometimes only by reconciling with the dead can we be guided back to life.

As fun as they are, these lively interludes donâ€™t derail the soothing, rockabye rhythms of Momoâ€™s journey. Her most deeply felt moments, rendered in smoky grays and palest mauves, are never overwhelmed by the storyâ€™s fantastical elements, while the traditional, hand-drawn animation captures the smallest body movements with painstaking naturalism. When an old aunt gently lays her hand on her husbandâ€™s arm to shush him, the gesture is so familiar â€” and so wonderfully authentic â€” that it takes your breath away.

Shunning the hard, shiny-bright colors of many animated movies, Mr. Okiura uses velvety pastels to paint a sensitive fantasy around Momo, a grieving young girl whose father was lost at sea. Transplanted from Tokyo to her motherâ€™s family home on a remote island, Momo is depressed and lonely, haunted by the angry words she spoke to her father before he left. Unable to appreciate the terraced citrus groves, mossy forests and turquoise seas that encircle her new world, she frets over her most treasured and tormenting possession: a letter her father started but never finished, its blank page a reminder of all that was left unsaid.

Despite his weakened condition and fear of heights, Halvard voices his intention to climb the tower and overcome his acrophobia. That determination is the ultimate indication of his difficulty surrendering control and acknowledging that he is less than superhuman.

In traditional portrayals, Halvard is an imperious architectural eminence who strikes awe and fear into the hearts of those in his orbit. As played by the decidedly unglamorous Mr. Shawn, Halvard is a megalomaniacal little creep without an iota of majesty. Rotund and beady eyed, he exudes a superficial joviality that cannot camouflage a scheming, paranoid control freak who wields power with impunity. He has enough glimmerings of conscience to know what heâ€™s doing and to admit his guilt.

Whether or not they had sex back then remains unclear, but there was almost certainly â€œinappropriate touching,â€ù to use current terminology. Exactly 10 years ago, Hilde declares, Halvard invited her to come live with him and be his princess. Having counted the days ever since, she is now on his doorstep ready to claim her crown. Playing a woman who is part angel and part witch who stands up to Halvard, Ms. Joyce is a seductive, forceful screen presence.

Jonathan Demme, who directed â€œA Master Builderâ€ù in the flat minimalist style of a filmed play, has described his concept as â€œan old-fashioned haunted house movie.â€ù The production was created for the stage by Mr. Shawnâ€™s longtime collaborator, Mr. Gregory (with whom he starred in â€œMy Dinner With AndrÃ©â€ù), and developed over a 14-year period.

The drab country mansion where Halvard and his followers gather has the feel of a dingy mausoleum where everyone except for Hilde nervously tiptoes around the great man. Halvardâ€™s wife, Aline (Julie Hagerty), is a spectral presence eaten up by jealousy and bitterness with a crust of moral self-righteousness. She seems in a state of perpetual mourning for their two children, who died as infants.

Buoyed by Ms. Johanssonâ€™s presence, Mr. Besson keeps his entertainment machine purring. Thank goodness (or the goddess) for male directors who dig strong female characters. Whatever their reasons, these directors often expand the range of roles women play, whether itâ€™s one of Howard Hawksâ€™s dames calling the shots or one of James Cameronâ€™s. That the French director Luc Besson, an industrious multi-hyphenate, has a thing for femmes fortes has been evident since 1990, when he unleashed a pouty toothpick in â€œLa Femme Nikita,â€ù a delirious, violent fantasy that turned an outlaw into a gun-toting gamine and an exploitable commodity that, in turn, spawned both an American big-screen remake (â€œPoint of No Returnâ€ù) and a television series.

None of it makes much sense, but then Mr. Besson has never been one for narrative logic, being a bigger believer in the distractions of fast cuts, ping-ponging camera moves and spectacular bloodshed that sweep you up and away. Heâ€™s also good at casting, and Mr. Choi and Ms. Johansson are fun to watch as the action cranks up, and the drug leaks into Lucyâ€™s system. Itâ€™s then that the movie goes from hyper to hyperkinetic: Suddenly sheâ€™s climbing the walls and scampering across the ceiling and into freedom, having tapped into newfound eerie powers. Given this, â€œLucyâ€ù canâ€™t help registering as the latest brush stroke in Ms. Johanssonâ€™s emerging portrait. The movie opens with her character â€” cheerfully frowzy, with swinging earrings, teetering heels and the telltale cheap cat-print adornment â€” arguing with a shady type, who turns out to be a new fling. Theyâ€™re just two little people dwarfed by the surrounding towers of power, one of which is soon splattered with blood and carpeted with shattered glass and bullet casings. Mr. Besson isnâ€™t a director who likes the slow boil: One minute, Lucy is a good-time gal unencumbered by a pesky back story (history and psychology arenâ€™t essential elements in his auteurist arsenal); the next, sheâ€™s embroiled in an intrigue that goes from Asia to far-outsville.

In between bullets and brawls, Mr. Besson throws out a lot to explain Lucyâ€™s transformation, including reams of on-screen text and one Professor Norman (Morgan Freeman). Mr. Freeman may have taken a break from playing God, but his character is another gloss on his familiar role as the resident kindly father figure who, until the story goes haywire, shepherds the younger co-star and the audience both. Specifically, Norman has charted the brain power of humankind that explains whatâ€™s happening to Lucy. (Seriously, he uses charts to explain his ideas to an audience thatâ€™s a stand-in for us.) Lucy seeks him out, having realized that her rapidly escalating physical supremacy is part of a one-woman human potential movement thatâ€™s leading her into total awesomeness. Ms. Johanssonâ€™s rise as a major star is largely interesting because of its familiar reflexivity. Over a career that began in childhood â€” something that she shares with Elizabeth Taylor, along with sexual expressivity â€” she has taken on her share of unexceptional girls and women, but as her fame has increased, itâ€™s become difficult for her to convey normality persuasively. Even when she has played more stock roles, she radiates extraordinariness, whether as a lust object in â€œDon Jonâ€ù or a dangerous agent in Marvelâ€™s â€œAvengersâ€ù series. More unusual is her disembodied turn as a computer program in â€œHerâ€ù and her fleshed-out performance as a man-baiting, clothes-dropping E.T. in â€œUnder the Skin,â€ù both expressive of elusive, tantalizing, otherworldly stardom itself.

Mr. Bessonâ€™s particular kink for fatal female beauties receives an entertaining workout in his latest film, â€œLucy,â€ù in which he again introduces a young woman who undergoes a remarkable metamorphosis that leads to convulsions of extreme violence and an increasingly frenzied visual style that lay waste to both men and any semblance of story sense. The nonsense begins when the title character â€” played by the improbable yet somehow perfect Scarlett Johansson â€” is pulled into a head-scratching plot in Taiwan, put into motion by a crime boss, Mr. Jang (the excellent South Korean actor Choi Min Sik). Heâ€™s set to begin peddling an experimental recreational drug that she accidentally ingests, and in such enormous quantities that sheâ€™s soon transformed from a slacking expat into super-Scarlett.

Stanley has a briefly seen, occasionally mentioned fiancÃ©e named Olivia (Catherine McCormack), who is a fellow skeptic and an intellectual peer, meaning that she has no chance with him. Mr. Allen has often accomplished much more with a good deal less. Some of his most satisfying pictures â€” â€œZelig,â€ùâ€œSweet and Lowdown,â€ùâ€œBroadway Danny Roseâ€ù â€” are spun from gossamer-thin nostalgic anecdotes. â€œBullets Over Broadwayâ€ù even grew into a Broadway musical, albeit one whose early closing was announced this week. He has also, in movies as varied as â€œThe Purple Rose of Cairoâ€ù and â€œMidnight in Paris,â€ù indulged a taste for whimsical supernaturalism, performing elegant cinematic sleights of hand in a spirit of sweet pop-surrealist mischief.

â€œMagic in the Moonlight,â€ùWoody Allenâ€™s new film, stages a debate that will be familiar to anyone who has seen more than a couple of the previous 43. There are various ways to characterize the argument: between reason and superstition; between doubt and faith; between realism and magic. On one side is the belief in some kind of unseen, metaphysical force governing the universe; on the other is the certainty, shared by the director, that no such thing exists. Not incidentally â€” and not for the first time in Mr. Allenâ€™s oeuvre â€” the opposed positions are advanced by a dyspeptic middle-aged intellectual and a much younger, relatively untutored woman. Among the big jokes this time around: She misattributes a literary quotation and seems never to have heard of Nietzsche.

Stanleyâ€™s target is Sophie (Emma Stone), a pretty and penniless American clairvoyant who has dazzled a rich family with her supposed gifts. While her business-minded mother (Marcia Gay Harden) works to extract money from the credulous, widowed matriarch (Jacki Weaver), Sophie reads minds, summons spirits and endures the ukulele serenades of the familyâ€™s shallow scion (Hamish Linklater), who has fallen in love with her. Stanley wages a grouchy, sarcastic war on her credibility, only to find himself smitten by her gamine charm and persuaded by her claims of paranormal ability.

Nothing like that animates this film, which plods through its picturesque settings (gorgeously shot by Darius Khondji, also the director of photography for â€œMidnight in Parisâ€ù) with the blocky deliberateness of a dinner-theater rehearsal. No credible spark ignites between Mr. Firth and Ms. Stone. She stands in the frame smiling wanly and swinging her arms while he impatiently reels off the kind of pedantic nonsense that is meant to signify superior intellect. She blinks. He scowls. It can only be love.
â€œMagic in the Moonlightâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Mild sexual implications and heavy smoking.

Worse is the sour taste left by the romance between Stanley and Sophie. Ms. Stone, spindly in her flapper dresses, looks younger than 25, which makes the nearly 30-year gap between her and Mr. Firth â€” a discrepancy never alluded to on screen â€” even more striking.

If the idea of a universe of unmotivated chaos seems scary, rest assured that the reality of 98 minutes of unmotivated order is worse. Mr. Allen has had his ups and downs over the years. Rarely, though, has he put a story on screen that manifests so little energy, so little curiosity about its own ideas and situations. â€œMagic in the Moonlightâ€ù is less a movie than the dutiful recitation of themes and plot points conducted by a squad of costumed actors. The tidy narrative may advance with clockwork precision, but the clockâ€™s most prominent feature is the snooze button.

One of Wei Ling Sooâ€™s signature tricks is making an elephant disappear, and â€œMagic in the Moonlightâ€ù is sufficiently tedious that, once youâ€™re done admiring the linen suits, cloche hats and tennis sweaters, you may start thinking about other elephants in the room. Other words may come to mind. Even if it were possible to watch this movie without thinking about Mr. Allenâ€™s personal life â€” or to avoid arguments afterward about whether he is a creep, a monster or a misunderstood artist whose behavior has no bearing on his work â€” it would be hard to miss the complacency at its heart and the purely mechanical expediency of its execution.

That question haunts the 79-minute documentary â€œThe Kill Team,â€ù which looks at the murders and their aftermath through a frustratingly narrow lens. An early shot in the movie â€” of Specialist Winfield in handcuffs â€” is crucial in this respect. The director, Dan Krauss, repeatedly returns to that image of the shackled soldier, turning it into a visual encapsulation of the thesis that, before his arrest, he was also a prisoner of his rogue platoon. Mr. Krauss largely advances this argument through talking head interviews, and videos and atrocity photographs shot by the soldiers. What emerges is a story of victimization, not of the Afghans, but of a fragile, perhaps damaged American who tried to do the right thing but was thwarted at every step, including by the military.

In 2011, five American soldiers were accused of murdering three Afghan civilians for what has often been described in news accounts as sport. The Americans hunted the Afghans, posed in photographs with the corpses (pictures they shared with others) and even took body parts as souvenirs. The soldiers were members of the Fifth Stryker Brigade, Second Infantry Division, which had been deployed in a region near Kandahar. The crimes were ghastly, and seemingly unfathomable. In a 2010 article in Stars and Stripes, a lawyer, Eric Montalvo, representing one of the accused, Specialist Adam C. Winfield, said the entire leadership needed to be looked at, asking, â€œHow was this allowed to happen?â€ù

Itâ€™s a given or, rather, should be, that the relationship between documentary filmmakers and their subjects is never neutral, and that it invariably involves layers upon layers of complex negotiation on and off camera. Although some filmmakers make that mediation part of the movie â€” the French classic â€œChronicle of a Summer,â€ù Jean Rouch and Edgar Morinâ€™s 1961 cinÃ©ma vÃ©ritÃ© tour de force, is a model of filmmaking self-inquiry â€” most directors obscure their process. Sometimes thereâ€™s nothing of interest behind the scenes, but Mr. Krauss might have served his material better if he had pulled the curtain back in â€œThe Kill Team,â€ù if only to explain why a movie that initially seems to be about one thing â€” as its shocker title suggests â€” is a partisan portrait of Specialist Winfield and his family.

Mr. Krauss has said he was drawn to Specialist Winfieldâ€™s story after being startled by news descriptions of him as both a whistle-blower and a murder suspect; Mr. Krauss just couldnâ€™t understand, he has said, how a soldier could be considered in the moral right and in the moral wrong. Intrigued, he reached out to Mr. Montalvo and agreed to do some pro bono work for the defense team as a videographer. In time, Mr. Krauss said, â€œmy bond with Adam and his family deepened.â€ù In â€œThe Kill Team,â€ù that unacknowledged bond seems to get in the way of intelligent choices, as in a juxtaposition of a photograph of one of the murdered Afghan men with a scene in which Specialist Winfieldâ€™s father, Christopher, describes their situation as a nightmare while posed next to the family swimming pool.

Not the first documentary about electronic dance music, the movie updates mainstream audiences on the popularity of the genre, though viewers wonâ€™t learn much about the business (either its sheer size or the perhaps surprising fortunes of the big-name D.J.s on display). The pumped-up concertgoers quoted in the documentary â€œUnder the Electric Skyâ€ù have the misfortune of appearing in something very much like an infomercial.

â€œKick,â€ù directed by Sajid Nadiadwala, tries to give Deviâ€™s violence a righteous flavor. When he knocks heads at a Delhi cafe, itâ€™s because the men there are mistreating women. (This movie loves the sound of thumping body blows, just as it loves a pulsating beat.)

â€œKick,â€ù a remake of a 2009 Telugu hit, has bass-heavy, muscular songs and the usual mix of comedy, romance and action. As Drew, Mr. Blatz puts on a monotonous but fairly credible tough front, bottling up emotion and building to a disarming emotional release after a particularly punishing run. The title card at the beginning of â€œRabindranath Tagore: The Poet of Eternityâ€ù assures us that the film is â€œa pro bono, noncommercial projectâ€ù meant for schools and students. Directed by Partha Bhattacharya, this hourlong documentary is full of encomiums and snippets of performances from the Tagore sesquicentennial in 2011. Though clearly a labor of love by Mr. Bhattacharya, â€œTagoreâ€ù is mostly clumsy as filmmaking. Make no mistake: There is nothing pleasant about â€œChild of God,â€ùJames Francoâ€™s very fine adaptation of Cormac McCarthyâ€™s short, pitiless novel. But then, Mr. McCarthy is a bard of the apocalyptic who, in his unsparing period novel â€œBlood Meridianâ€ù writes that â€œwar is the truest form of divination.â€ù His is no country for old men, to borrow the title of one of his few books that have been turned into a successful film; neither is it a place for bromides about the triumph of the human spirit, one reason most of the screen adaptations have failed. There isnâ€™t a war per se in â€œChild of God,â€ù just good and (mostly) evil in a Christ story in reverse about a mystery who becomes a man.

Mr. Franco follows Mr. McCarthyâ€™s lead in setting this crucial scene, from the bluegrass band in the bed of a pickup to the gawking locals who have gathered, as if on a Sunday outing. In another story, the auction might be the sceneâ€™s meaningful event, the reason for its existence. But Lester is so weirdly bedraggled and menacing, and the ax swings so fast that your attention quickly moves from the auction to his appearance and then the blow. Instead of focusing on what is being done to Lester â€” through the violence of the sale, which will leave him homeless â€” your eyes and interest (much like the attendees) have settled on what Lester is doing, which is scaring people.

This shift in focus mirrors the larger social dynamics in the story. Lester is the child of God in the title, â€œmuch like yourself perhaps,â€ù Mr. McCarthy writes, although given his dim worldview, the â€œperhapsâ€ù strikes the ear as an all-important and jaundiced qualifier. But abandoned, shunned and just ignored, Lester is also a product of a fallen, all-too human world. Mr. Franco, who adapted the novel with Vince Jolivette, pares down that world, narrowing and depopulating it, doubtless because of budget constraints. The movie looks good, given those limitations, even with digital cinematography that never locates the sensual beauty and texture that might have better translated Mr. McCarthyâ€™s full-bodied language into visual terms.

What Mr. Franco does have is Mr. Haze, whose mesmerizing performance gives the movie its ballast and its fitful, nervous energy. Dirtied up and thinned down, he looks a sight, hunched and scrawny, more beast than man. (With his jaw tucked into his chest, the whites of his eyes shining, Mr. Haze initially also evokes Jack Nicholson.) Although Lester occasionally interacts with some locals, including the hostile sheriff, Fate (Tim Blake Nelson), and his deputy, Cotton (Jim Parrack), much of the time heâ€™s alone, wandering along country roads and running through the woods. Lester also talks to the animals, some stuffed, and the corpse of a woman (Nina Ljeti) that he makes his lover, a turn that sets him and the story down a progressively gruesome yet humanizing path.
â€œChild of Godâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Gun violence, necrophilia, on-screen defecation.

In the novel â€œChild of God,â€ù a man emits â€œa gout of yellow snot into the grass,â€ù an image that Mr. Franco faithfully reproduces. Bodies ooze in Mr. McCarthyâ€™s work, leaking mucus and sputtering blood: In â€œBlood Meridian,â€ù another man grabs his nose and blows â€œtwo strings of snot onto the floorâ€ù; in â€œOuter Dark,â€ù a woman sneezes â€œforth a spray of mucus.â€ù Thereâ€™s an intense visceral quality to these emanations, which are brute, vivid reminders of all the liquid sloshing around inside us (under our thin skins) and that could, at any moment, pour out. This is language that at its most specific and horrifically familiar reverberates in your body and that â€” as in this admirably tough and unapologetically ugly movie â€” is an assertion of a deep humanity.

The title character in â€œChild of Godâ€ù is Lester Ballard â€” played by a ferocious Scott Haze with mad eyes and what sounds like a mouthful of marbles â€” a pariah in rural 1960s Tennessee who descends into madness and murder. Abandoned by a runaway mother and a father who hanged himself in the family barn, Lester lives in profound isolation. When the movie opens, heâ€™s physically apart from a crowd of men and women, hunched and watching the auction of his house, which has been seized by the bank. When Lester threatens the auctioneer with his rifle, heâ€™s hit on the head with an ax, a blow that leaves him bleeding on the ground and attendees open mouthed. â€œLester Ballard never could hold his head right after that,â€ù Mr. McCarthy writes.

Better actors would have helped. Playing to the cheap seats, the film reaches its nadir during a brawl in which a decaying buxom lab assistant (Lydia Hearst) and Marcusâ€™s brotherâ€™s ailing girlfriend (Jillian Murray) literally rip each other apart. Up next: Russ Meyerâ€™s â€œCabin Fever.â€ù

Heâ€™s especially fond of setting up a human value (say, devotion) only to knock it down, kick it in the teeth and then prop it up again for another go-round. Time and again, a pair of characters face off â€” with each either significantly isolated in the frame or meaningfully crammed into a tense two shot â€” and talk and then talk some more. In the beginning was the Word; later, came all the human psychodrama.

Most of the movieâ€™s many, many conversations suggest that Mr. McDonagh has read his share of Hegel along with the Gospels, and the appeal and the limitations of â€œCalvaryâ€ù are summed up by the insistent, dialectical chatter that almost mechanically pings and pongs between lightness and darkness, glibness and seriousness, insincerity and honesty, faithfulness and despair.

Mr. McDonagh returns repeatedly to the beach and the rolling hills flanking it, beginning with the soaring opening aerial shots, images that are known as birdâ€™s-eye or, more fittingly here, Godâ€™s-eye views. (The director of photography, Larry Smith, also shot Mr. McDonaghâ€™s first feature, â€œThe Guard.â€ù) The stark, natural landscapes are among the movieâ€™s most seductive attractions, even if the characters populating them seem calculated for maximum repulsion. Thereâ€™s the butcher and possible wife beater, Jack (Chris Oâ€™Dowd), who may take a fist to his missis, Veronica (Orla Oâ€™Rourke), but doesnâ€™t seem terribly put out that sheâ€™s carrying on with a mechanic, Simon (Isaach de BankolÃ©). Thereâ€™s also a dying writer, Gerald (M. Emmet Walsh), and a dyspeptic surgeon, Frank (Aidan Gillen).

The Anglo-Irish writer and director John Michael McDonagh opens his cold, mordantly funny murder mystery, â€œCalvary,â€ù with a misleadingly pacific image: a close-up of the Irish actor Brendan Gleeson. An imposingly big man whoâ€™s often called on to suggest authority, Mr. Gleeson has played cops, criminals and Winston Churchill, and had the recurring role of Mad-Eye Moody in the Harry Potter series. In â€œCalvary,â€ù he plays a world- and time-tested expert of another sort: Father James, a conscientious priest and widower whose faith isnâ€™t shared by his flock, which includes a serial sinner, a hostile Buddhist, a dog hater and other furious souls, including one self-professed future executioner.

The killer makes his entrance right after Father James, seated off screen in a confessional and issuing convincing threats. This seeming penitent, or rather Mr. McDonagh, makes his intentions immediately clear: The confessor has singled out Father James, whom he calls a good priest, to take the fall for the sins of the Roman Catholic Church and its bad priests. â€œIâ€™m going to kill you because youâ€™re innocent,â€ù the confessor promises, words that â€” with the title â€” seem to tip Mr. McDonaghâ€™s hand. Calvary is the name of the Jerusalem hill on which Jesus is said to have been crucified; the would-be murderer prefers a more level playing field: He tells Father James to meet him in a week on the wildly beautiful, wind-swept beach that hugs this provincial Irish hell.

Frankâ€™s worldview is best expressed in a shot of him extinguishing one of his cigarettes on a human organ. It looks like a heart, although that isnâ€™t a part of the human animal that Mr. McDonagh is especially interested in: Heâ€™s more of a spleen man. Still, he has a few soft spots, mostly evident in Father Jamesâ€™s relationship with his adult daughter, Fiona (Kelly Reilly), who shows up with bandaged wrists and other, far-older wounds.
â€œCalvaryâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong adult language, a slit throat and graphic gun violence.

As the days pass, the vultures swoop in closer. Like the condemned man he may turn out to be, Father James counts down the hours as he tends to his daughter and his aggressively thankless, sometimes threatening flock. (Mr. McDonagh signals the passage of time with on-screen text announcing the day of the week, a narrative device that can make viewers, including this one, more antsy than enthusiastic about where the story is headed.) Things happen, but mostly there are conversations as Father James convenes with one after another parishioner. The most memorable feature a robber baron, Fitzgerald (an excellent Dylan Moran), whose taunting, theological exchanges with the priest suggest the temptation of Christ, except that this Satan comes with a fat checking account.

Mr. Gleesonâ€™s ability to project palpable, gruff warmth is nicely showcased in his scenes with Ms. Reilly, even if their characters and some of their exchanges veer into sentimentalism. (A scene of Father James casting a fishing line â€” an activity that requires a balance of slackness and tension â€” is a nice metaphor for Mr. Gleesonâ€™s performative gifts.)

However familiar, Gamora turns out to be better than most Strong Female Characters â€” you know those girls: Theyâ€™re fierce and finally inconsequential â€” that the blogger Tasha Robinson went after in a recent post about the so-called Trinity Syndrome. Gamora is given more to do than make a splashy entrance and wear tight costumes, and Ms. Saldana remains a charismatic screen presence, even when she trades in her Emma Peel-ish catsuits for a miniskirt, a costume change thatâ€™s accompanied by the image of a soft female hand resting on a strong male shoulder. Thatâ€™s a relief, because the movie doesnâ€™t start promisingly, opening with not one but two female clichÃ©s: the dead mother and the disposable chick. Both belong to Quill â€” he tells the chick, who enters with bed hair and not much else, that he forgot she was even there â€” and they suggest that however futuristic the movie may be, its sexual politics and worldview are antediluvian. (You have to wonder if the people who make these entertainments ever think about what such tired stereotypes say to young viewers, not to mention their own sons and daughters.) The sense that the movieâ€™s appealingly old-fashioned jocularity, reminiscent of late Howard Hawks, has its fatal drawbacks dissipates with the introduction of Gamora (Zoe Saldana), a green, mean, not-so-jolly killing machine.

Lifted by a cast of professional charmers and a â€œWhat, me worry?â€ù vibe, â€œGuardians of the Galaxyâ€ù is one of those interstellar westerns about a motley group of appealing baddies who rise to the heroic occasion and ride to the rescue, on spaceships rather than Appaloosas. The John Wayne role here â€” or, really, the 1970s Harrison Ford one â€” belongs to Chris Pratt, an easygoing, comic performer whoâ€™s very good at putting up a persuasive cute-dumb front and then shifting into a slyer, more knowing register. Wearing a swinging duster and some fetishistic head gear, Mr. Pratt slides into â€œGuardians of the Galaxyâ€ù doing a Gene Kelly soft shoe, but is soon flexing his action-hero bona fides (bang-bang, etc.) as Peter Quill, a heavily armed professional scavenger.

Quill is a good and a sometimes bad guy who fights and jokes amid swirling, polychromatic smoke and cascading words like Xandarians, Morag and the Celestial (and awesome) Head. He comes into possession of a pretty blue rock that everyone would risk death trying to get, hence a throwaway about â€œThe Maltese Falcon.â€ù You see, in 1539, some crusading knights persuaded the king of Spain to give them the island of Malta. ... Thatâ€™s not what happens in â€œGuardians,â€ù which is based on a comic that first hit in 1969, but no matter. What counts are the dreams of Quill and his compatriots, including a wisecracking raccoon and an ambulatory tree, which have been ushered into existence by the director, James Gunn, with an eye to those who donâ€™t know or care about the source material.

Itâ€™s old news that the major studios, having long absorbed the lessons of B-movie titans like Roger Corman, are now primarily in the business of churning out big-ticket exploitation flicks. (As a studio executive said way back in 1975, â€œWhat was â€˜Jawsâ€™ but an old Corman monster-from-the-deep flick?â€ù) Itâ€™s perfect, then, that Mr. Gunn, having started out working for Troma Entertainment, that gleeful purveyor of barrel-scraping trash, has been tapped by Marvel for its latest bid at box-office domination. Heâ€™s a funny guy who brings a light touch to cartoon violence, whether heâ€™s going for giggles (as in â€œSlitherâ€ù) or uglier yuks (â€œSuperâ€ù). But in â€œGuardians of the Galaxy,â€ù he also summons up some emotion and even quiet desperation amid the scares and the brutes like Drax (a terrific Dave Bautista).

Given these moments of feeling, it doesnâ€™t seem accidental that two of the brightest characters in the movie, which Mr. Gunn wrote with Nicole Perlman, are the raccoon and the tree, both surprisingly melancholic figures whose presence proves more resonant than their patter. The raccoon, Rocket (given an effectively grating screech by Bradley Cooper), is a nasty, often crude piece of work whoâ€™s never as funny as he thinks. But, much like the tree, a gorgeously rendered creature called Groot (Vin Diesel, in his finest role since â€œThe Iron Giantâ€ù) â€” who nibbles his own tender sprouts and, in a nod to the 1931 film â€œFrankenstein,â€ù offers a child a bloom â€” the raccoon carries with him an air of regret, a sense of loss and despair that, in the end, speaks more to our world than to that of the movie.

Talking about directing in blockbusters is sometimes nothing more than wishful thinking. Most are such impersonally operated machines â€” dedicated to the business of brand storytelling â€” that they tend to obliterate any whisper of individuality. That thereâ€™s a palpable directorial sensibility in â€œGuardians of the Galaxy,â€ù along with other signs of genuine life, helps separate this latest Marvel cash grab from a lot of off-the-rack movie cartoons. â€œGuardians of the Galaxyâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Bloodless violence and soft expletives.

Filled with a multihued populace, Xandar is shiny, clean and bright, and looks familiar because it evokes both our world (one building suggests the Gherkin in London) and your favorite tattered science-fiction paperback. Itâ€™s nice if a little ho-hum (as utopias tend to be in movies), particularly when compared with the darkly colored, visually seductive realms and spaces conjured up by Mr. Gunn and his team. In other words, you donâ€™t need to be held hostage by the Marvel Weltanschauung to enjoy â€œGuardians.â€ù The story may be confusing and generic by turns, but if you shake off the bonds of narrative coherency itâ€™s liberating letting the weird words â€” Yondu, Necrocraft, Sakkaran â€” just slide right past you, much like the zigzagging, exploding 3-D spaceships. What sticks are the fantastical landscapes, the beautiful creature designs and the actors delivering lively performances, even with strata of makeup and digital wizardry. Among the many amusements is the floating head (kind of like in â€œThe Wizard of Ozâ€ù) that yells at a villain, Ronan (Lee Pace, with notes of â€œStar Warsâ€ù and â€œPrometheusâ€ù) who wants the blue rock so he can destroy Xandar, a post-racial Eden run by Nova Prime, a space-age Hillary Rodham Clinton (Glenn Close).

The behind-the-scenes component, juiced with razzle-dazzle excerpts from the â€œFela!â€ù production, is sound, in theory. But â€” like many sequences â€” itâ€™s not so tightly executed, and this strand tends to knock the documentary off balance.

With the perilously stuffed documentary â€œFinding Fela,â€ù the director, Alex Gibney, tries to reckon with this audacious child of the Nigerian elite who courted execution with his brickbats, and megalomania with his extravagance. And Mr. Gibney gives his rise-and-fall treatment an extra critical filter through a â€œmaking ofâ€ù look at the recent Broadway musical â€œFela!â€ù

Accordingly, we learn through interviews and lively clips about Felaâ€™s musical and political evolution in the 1960s and â€™70s, but we also hear from the â€œFela!â€ù director, Bill T. Jones, about portraying the man, who died in 1997. Mr. Jones is both razor-sharp and candid about his mixed feelings, and heâ€™s part of a robust core of commentators, including the biographer Michael Veal, the former New York Times correspondent John Darnton and the former Black Panther Sandra Izsadore, a formative influence on Fela.
Directed by Alex Gibney

Mr. Gibneyâ€™s approach has built-in limitations (and a milquetoast title: whereâ€™d Fela go, exactly?). But maybe itâ€™s a tall order for any conventional documentary to get its arms around a man whose 30-minute-plus jams routinely broke free of their moorings.

The small gesture was not Fela Kutiâ€™s style. With his band the Africa 70, this Afrobeat pioneer rolled out monster-size grooves, chugging along with soulful beats, keyboards and horns. His lyrics, partly in pidgin, called out the Nigerian military dictatorship; at home he declared his Lagos house to be an independent territory. As for marriage, he embraced polygamy, in the cultlike double digits.

It is one of several scenes in which he mistreats his musicians, many of whom abandon him, beginning with his original gospel group, the Famous Flames. Only Bobby Byrd (Nelsan Ellis), his longtime best friend, returns. They met as teenagers while both were in jail in Toccoa, Ga. After Brown serves his sentence, Byrd persuades his mother to let the young prisoner live with them. Throughout the movie, wives and girlfriends come and go, but their embattled friendship persists, although it, too, is eventually severed.

Brownâ€™s childhood and youth are depicted in larger-than-life, cartoonlike sequences. The opening moments show an exaggerated high-speed police chase that ends with Brownâ€™s arrest (the first of many). As he arrives in Vietnam in 1968 to entertain the troops, his plane is nearly blown out of the sky in a hail of thunderous explosions. A sequence with Brown and the Famous Flames outfitted in collegiate garb for a Frankie Avalon movie is played for satire. Only one incident, late in Brownâ€™s career, in which he punches one of his wives, stands for the many instances of his spousal abuse.

The movie shows how Brownâ€™s early exposure to gospel at a revival meeting directly affected his style. We observe an early encounter with Little Richard at a juke joint in 1954 that transformed not only Brownâ€™s vocal delivery but also his extravagant self-presentation. But even before he became a proto-rap funkster and gymnastic phenomenon, Brown was a compelling vocalist whose first hit, â€œPlease, Please, Please,â€ù conveyed an extreme, desperate urgency seldom heard in R&B.

Brownâ€™s music and show business ascendance are the heart and soul of a movie that takes his art very seriously. None other than Mick Jagger, who has made no secret of his indebtedness to Brownâ€™s stage moves, is the music producer of this film, which puts music front and center, where it belongs. Brownâ€™s real voice, which never sounds dubbed, is used in remixes of his original recordings.

One of the most revealing scenes in a movie that struggles mightily but not always successfully to cast off the clichÃ©s of musical biographies shows a brutal rehearsal in which Brown, at his most tyrannical, grows increasingly exasperated with his musicians during a run-through of the seminal funk song â€œCold Sweat.â€ù Brown finally hammers home his point by shouting that no matter what their instruments may look like, they are all drums.

Brownâ€™s impoverished childhood in the backwoods of South Carolina, where he was born and brought up in a cabin, is a mythic, storybook, mural-like portrait of rural hardship in which his father (Lennie James), a laborer, and mother (Viola Davis), physically struggle for possession of him before she leaves. Brownâ€™s observant childhood self is portrayed by twins: Jamarion and Jordan Scott. In Augusta, Ga., he is a brought up by a paternal aunt, Honey (Octavia Spencer, underused), who has a mystical faith in his eventual triumph.
â€œGet On Upâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Mild sexual content, some drug use, some strong language and violent situations.

â€œGet On Up,â€ù directed by Tate Taylor (â€œThe Helpâ€ù), thrillingly captures the frenzy of Brownâ€™s music, and the forces driving that frenzy, both musical and personal. Like its gyrating, spasmodic staccato beats, â€œGet On Upâ€ù refuses to stand still. It whirls and does splits and jumps, with leaps around in time and changes in tempo that are jarring and abrupt and that usually feel just right.
