But Brown, despite the popularity of his anthem â€œSay It Loud â€” Iâ€™m Black and Iâ€™m Proud,â€ù alienated black audiences because of his support of Richard M. Nixon. In the end, he stood above it all. Having won the game, he dwelt in his own realm, where he ruled once and for always as the Godfather of Soul.

â€œGet On Upâ€ù largely skirts the issue of race. In the most provocative scene, Brown, along with other young black boys, is put in a boxing ring, blindfolded, and told to fight for the entertainment of white Southern gentry. Much later, after the King assassination, he refuses to cancel his scheduled concert in Boston Garden and quells the stirred-up fervor of the crowd as it overflows onto the stage.

If musical genius is a gift randomly bestowed, it requires intense monomaniacal cultivation to reach fruition. Witness James Brown, a.k.a. â€œthe hardest-working man in show business,â€ù as portrayed indelibly by Chadwick Boseman in the viscerally explosive biopic â€œGet On Up.â€ù A monumental egotist, perfectionist and harsh taskmaster with a streak of paranoia, Brown reigned as the absolute monarch of his personal kingdom, answering to no one but himself.

On her first night as a visitor, Jenny, while attending a party with her old friend Carson (Lena Dunham), passes out from dope and booze, and Jeff, awakened by an emergency phone call, has to fetch her. Mr. Swanberg comes out of the so-called mumblecore movement of homemade, no-budget movies by young filmmakers and their friends. â€œHappy Christmasâ€ù is a quiet, serious comedy about marriage, parenthood and the everyday strains of bringing up a rambunctious toddler while struggling to sustain a creative life. â€œSpelled wrong, almost every word seems funny,â€ù says Karin (Anjorka Strechel) in â€œThe Strange Little Cat.â€ù Sheâ€™s referring to the habitual writing errors of her sister, Clara, but she might also be describing the method of the movie, a radically disorienting, disarmingly odd first feature from Ramon ZÃ_rcher.

That life makes great copy. A bootstrapping newsboy as a kid, Fuller became a professional reporter in high school, then hit the road to file dispatches on a depressed America. Screenwriting came next (and naturally). During World War II, he enlisted in the Army and fought in North Africa, Sicily, Normandy and beyond. In love with Americaâ€™s ideals yet cleareyed about its realities, he was that vanishing breed of filmmaker whose career was grounded in actual, lived, brutal experience. (Fuller died in 1997 at the age of 85.)

â€œItâ€™s not me talking, itâ€™s my character.â€ù Thatâ€™s how Samuel Fuller responded to critics â€” for example, J. Edgar Hoover â€” who objected to the sketches of American lowlifes, mad men, racists and cynical soldiers in his thrillingly alive films. A shaky labor of love, â€œA Fuller Lifeâ€ù repays this filmmakerâ€™s empathy by letting him have his say from beyond the grave through excerpts from his autobiography.

As directed by his daughter, Samantha Fuller, the film recounts a life journey through something like an evening of staged tribute readings, with good intentions and highly variable turns. Actors who worked with Fuller (Bill Duke, Constance Towers); veteran directors and writers (William Friedkin, Buck Henry); and James Franco intone Fullerâ€™s punchy writings from within his cluttered office. Clips from his films, including â€œShock Corridor,â€ù â€œThe Big Red Oneâ€ù and the obscure â€œMadonna and the Dragon,â€ù zip by, Fullerâ€™s directing career a bit shortchanged by the lopsided timeline. (Thereâ€™s also his rare footage from a liberated Falkenau concentration camp.)

This is both a virtue and a limitation. The viewer does get a close, detailed sense of life in Daxing Boot Camp, but the film lacks either the immersive intensity that would galvanize emotions or a context that would provide enlightenment. Its brief tour of an unpleasant corner of reality feels less revelatory than voyeuristic.

Does the treatment do the boys any good? Is their â€œdiseaseâ€ù an acute problem in its own right or part of a more widespread dysfunction? In keeping with the modern dogma of documentary reticence, which emphasizes showing over explaining, â€œWeb Junkieâ€ù refrains from trying to answer such questions.

In the course of procrastinating over a deadline â€” I mean conducting research for this review â€” I typed â€œIs Internet addiction realâ€ù into a Google window and received 29 million results and no conclusive answer. Some experts think the addiction model fits compulsive, time-sucking online behavior perfectly, while others are skeptical. After a while, I stopped reading to check for Twitter updates and take a quiz or two, but two hours later, Iâ€™m not ready to admit that I have a problem.

The parents, who seem to be striving members of Chinaâ€™s new middle class, weep openly at their failure to control their sons. The sons are sullen, resigned and resentful, united above all in their hatred of life at the institute, which does look pretty grim. A few therapists, most of them women, provide islands of compassion amid all the in-formation drills and mandatory browbeatings. Though there do seem to be girls around, we never hear their stories or learn why they are there.

The place is run by Dr. Tao, who wears a gold-braid-bedecked uniform and delivers scientifically questionable lectures with great authority. His methods include calisthenics, family discussion sessions and punitive stints in solitary confinement. Some of the episodes and conversations are glumly comical â€” as when a group of boys compares notes about marathon World of Warcraft binges â€” but most are sad and disturbing.

â€œWeb Junkie,â€ù a new documentary by Shosh Shlam and Hilla Medalia, makes clear that the government of China is not interested in ambiguity or excuses. The filmmakers report that China is the first country to designate Internet addiction as a clinical disorder, and the film observes efforts to address it as both an individual affliction and a social problem. Shot almost entirely at Daxing Boot Camp, a center in Beijing that offers treatment to young addicts, most of them teenage boys, â€œWeb Junkieâ€ù offers a troubling glimpse into anxieties that are hardly Chinaâ€™s alone.

In some ways, Daxing resembles those controversial, privately run American rehabilitation facilities where desperate parents send unruly adolescents to be straightened out. Some of the boys report being tricked or drugged by their fathers and mothers after other measures failed. Once admitted, the patients â€” who are more apt to describe themselves as prisoners â€” are subjected to a blend of militaristic discipline, medication and therapy.

This is a familiar gimmick by now, and if you like delayed gratification and rewinding a movie in your head, once youâ€™ve learned the secret, to see if the story made sense, this is a decent example of the genre. If, on the other hand, you find this kind of manipulation annoying, well, this film is annoying.

A portrait of the artist as a refusenik, a recluse, a survivor and a stubborn question mark, â€œFifi Howls From Happinessâ€ù registers, by turns, as a celebration, an excavation and an increasingly urgent rescue mission. The movie was directed by Mitra Farahani, an Iranian filmmaker who lives in Paris. In 2010, she discovered that the long-disappeared Mr. Mohassess, a septuagenarian, had been living in a hotel in Rome for decades. She grabbed a digital video camera and â€” with his insistent, sometimes humorously bossy input on how she should proceed â€” began shooting, recording his reminiscences of his life in and out of Iran and sharing images of his art. Along the way, she invited Ramin and Rokni Haerizadeh, Iranian artist-brothers living in exile in Dubai, to join the conversation.

It may be that after so many years in exile, Mr. Mohassess had forgotten (or abandoned) the role of the self-aware artist eager to share his ideas, work and self. You see a glimpse of that man in clips from a 1967 interview filmed in Tehran. The footage â€” battered, vibrant â€” shows him painting and, yes, smoking while talking about his art. (â€œOf course I am a historic figure.â€ù) Ms. Farahani repeatedly returns to this film, which puts the past into play with the present. It also captured Mr. Mohassess at a moment when his place in history appeared to be assured.

The idea that art memorializes â€” artists, schools and worlds â€” obviously changes when that art is destroyed by its creator, a patron, a vandal, a censor or a ruler. Mr. Mohassessâ€™s penchant for representing dangling penises in his work produced official consternation in Iran; itâ€™s less evident whether his exile was, at least in part, because heâ€™s gay, a topic that emerges in cackling asides and harangues. What is absolutely unambiguous is that the lines between his life and his work tend to blur. You see that when, over the duration of â€œFifi Howls,â€ù he points to one photograph after another of paintings and sculptures that he says have â€œdied.â€ù These deaths (or perhaps more rightly, murders) may have been acts of resistance, however perverse. Truly, they feel like self-mutilations.

Among the works that Mr. Mohassess discusses is a life-size figurative sculpture of the shah and his family that may be lost. The 1979 revolution is one reason for his workâ€™s disappearance; Mr. Mohassessâ€™s habit of destroying his paintings and sculptures is another. The reasons for this destruction are complex and emerge primarily through Mr. Mohassessâ€™s recollections and Ms. Farahaniâ€™s contrapuntal voice-over. Their voices arenâ€™t exactly dueling: She wants to pay tribute to him, and he seems happy to be commended. Even so, as she asks questions, politely prodding and circling him â€” Iâ€™m uncertain if her oblique approach is a critical strategy or a matter of culture or gender or both â€” it becomes clear that he doesnâ€™t necessarily want to answer her.

It isnâ€™t until late in â€œFifi Howls From Happinessâ€ù that you learn the meaning of the cryptic title. Even so, you may soon intuit that thereâ€™s a strong link between the howling and the cackling that regularly erupts from the movieâ€™s subject, the Iranian artist Bahman Mohassess. Itâ€™s an unnerving sound because of its wincingly harsh, broken resonance, but also because of the eerie juxtaposition created by the image of Mr. Mohassessâ€™s cigarette smoke curling around his head, not far from a portable oxygen device. Itâ€™s hard not to think that he may be on a suicide mission, though this thoughtful, moving documentary does make you wonder if, after a lifetime of trouble, heâ€™s just laughing at fate.

On its website, the British Museum, which has acquired some of Mr. Mohassessâ€™s collage pieces, proclaims him â€œone of the most significant Modernist artists of Iran.â€ù And he was featured in a recent show, â€œModern Iran,â€ù at Asia Society in New York. Beyond that, there is not much about him online in English. This alone makes â€œFifi Howls From Happinessâ€ù important, although I wish Ms. Farahani had grabbed a better camera when she ran out to meet Mr. Mohassess. The digital-video images look badly smeared when projected, which is frustrating in a movie with a lot of photographs of lost and little-seen art. That Ms. Farahani found Mr. Mohassess and persuaded him to share his story is a terrific coup, even if a great deal of his lifeâ€™s work remains elusive.

â€œThe Hundred-Foot Journeyâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). A few hints that eating is a sensual activity connected with other sensual activities.

If the food were any good, such lapses might be more tolerable. But despite a late, knowing excursion to Paris and the trendy world of molecular gastronomy, â€œThe Hundred-Foot Journeyâ€ù is at its worst when it steps behind the stove. At one point, we are treated to a brief lesson on the five canonical sauces that are the basis of classical French cooking. One of these is hollandaise, which then appears to be prepared with olive oil, which would make it aioli, or perhaps mayonnaise, but not hollandaise as Madame Mallory and her old-school ilk would recognize it. This may sound like a small, pedantic quibble, but a movie that continually proclaims its reverence for the discipline of the kitchen and the glories of tradition should pay attention to such details.

If it did, it might find a place alongside â€œRatatouille,â€ù â€œBabetteâ€™s Feastâ€ù and other touchstones of foodie cinema. But this film is not in love with food; it is commercially invested in the idea that food is something people think they love. It is an empty pastry shell, an artificially sweetened meringue, with no substance or conviction. Early in the film, Hassan samples a sea urchin. â€œIt tastes like life,â€ù his mother tells him. Maybe so, but the dominant flavor of â€œThe Hundred-Foot Journeyâ€ù is pure banality.

Who could stop her? But, on the other hand: Who would believe her? There is a lot of soft-core culinary montage in the movie, directed by Lasse Hallstrom with the easygoing blend of elegance and vulgarity that has been his signature at least since â€œChocolat.â€ù Eggs are cracked in slow motion and whisked to the sounds of A. R. Rahmanâ€™s transnational airport music score. Vegetables are chopped with melodramatic frenzy. Tomatoes fairly burst in the golden sunlight of southern France. Words like â€œcÃ¨pes,â€ù â€œgaram masala,â€ù â€œÃ©crevissesâ€ù and â€œtandoorâ€ù are uttered with almost erotic intensity. And yet â€œThe Hundred-Foot Journeyâ€ù is likely neither to pique your appetite nor to sate it, leaving you in a dyspeptic limbo, stuffed with false sentiment and forced whimsy and starved for real delight.

Instead, there is a culture clash gastro-rom-com spooned out with extreme caution. The main character is Mr. Kadamâ€™s son Hassan (Manish Dayal), a gifted and handsome cook, who supplies early voice-over narration and later exchanges smoldering glances and stolen kisses with Marguerite (Charlotte Le Bon), a sous-chef in Madame Malloryâ€™s restaurant. She lends him classic French cookbooks, and he cross-pollinates their tried-and-true recipes with flavors and techniques from back home.

The first faces on screen at a recent advance showing of â€œThe Hundred-Foot Journeyâ€ù belonged to Oprah Winfrey and Steven Spielberg, who do not appear in the movie itself but are credited among its producers. Itâ€™s a bit unusual to be subjected to a promo trying to sell you on a movie you have already committed to seeing, but Mr. Spielberg and Ms. Winfrey clearly could not contain themselves, and took a moment to share their enthusiasm. In the clip (which has also aired on television), Ms. Winfrey, using the trademark falsetto singsong that is her version of conversational italics, tells us how excited she is to present this amazing movie, while Mr. Spielberg uses variations on the word â€œincredibleâ€ù at least three times. Noting that â€œThe Hundred-Foot Journey,â€ù based on a popular novel by Richard C. Morais, is about food, Ms. Winfrey asks, â€œCan I say itâ€™s delicious?â€ù

All of which would be fine, even captivating, if â€œThe Hundred-Foot Journeyâ€ù were really interested in food, culture, ambition, family or any of the other themes it reduces to slogans and clichÃ©s. But it is so systematically wrong about all of these things as to seem actively dishonest. Hassan and his family flee Mumbai in the wake of political violence described as following from â€œsome election or other.â€ù French xenophobia receives similarly cursory, abstract treatment. There are some racist hooligans in the village, and one in Madame Malloryâ€™s kitchen, which is plausible enough.

Well, maybe not entirely. Helen Mirren and Om Puri are the top-billed players here, and time spent watching them is never entirely wasted. Mr. Puri is Papa Kadam, the patriarch of an Indian family that has been in the restaurant business for generations. He and his four children arrive in a small town in the south of France and set up Maison Mumbai, where the smell of their spices and the sound of their music offends the sensibilities of Madame Mallory (Ms. Mirren), proprietress of the venerable Michelin-starred establishment across the street. The clash of imperious and irascible that these two well-seasoned actors perform is spirited and effortless, but there is nowhere near enough of it.

Madameâ€™s culinary chauvinism, in contrast, seems as dated and stereotypical as the frogâ€™s legs and escargots on her menu, and the filmâ€™s assumptions about gender and cooking. Women here can nurture and spot talented chefs, but that status is implicitly reserved for men.

The French are fussy and snobbish, the Indians clannish and boisterous, and the movie is in such a hurry to avoid real conflict that it also avoids suspense, drama and emotional impact. Mr. Dayal, in spite of his sensitive, brooding good looks, has a way of disappearing on screen, and no real heat develops between him and Ms. Le Bon. The plot lurches and meanders, stapling tepid scenes of comedy to flimsy bits of melodrama with musical passages and repetitive long shots of the pretty countryside. Mr. Hallstrom seems to lack either the ability or the desire to flesh out secondary characters or to attend to the textures of local life. You have caught more evocative glimpses of France and Mumbai in television commercials.

With performers as capable as these (including Adam Driver and Mackenzie Davis as rambunctiously randy sidekicks), this sugar bomb could easily have been given the acidic edge it so desperately needs. Certainly, who among us would strap ourselves into what looks like a giant green thumb drive and sink, alone, to the bottom of the Mariana Trench? It turns out that the true story bit about â€œDog Day Afternoonâ€ù was, well, pretty true. Thatâ€™s one of the jaw droppers in â€œThe Dog,â€ù an absorbing, rollicking documentary about John Wojtowicz, whoâ€™s best known as the guy Al Pacino performed, with heart, soul and a river of flop sweat, in â€œDog Day Afternoon.â€ù In Sidney Lumetâ€™s magnificently squalid 1975 classic, Mr. Pacino plays Sonny Wortzik, whose new career as Clyde Barrow goes south as soon as he pulls out a gun in a Brooklyn bank. Thwarted by bad planning and legions of cops, Sonny eventually ends up in cuffs. The same pretty much happened to Mr. Wojtowicz, except that he was immortalized in a Hollywood masterwork.

Mr. Wojtowiczâ€™s romanticism was as raw as a Charles Bukowski sonnet, which becomes evident early in the documentary, when he likens another manâ€™s sexual gifts to â€œa summer breeze.â€ù (This glorious bit of poetry will forever change how you hear the Seals and Crofts song.) Bukowski titled a collection of his poems â€œLove Is a Dog From Hell,â€ù which could serve as an epitaph for Mr. Wojtowicz. In 1972, though, when Mr. Wojtowicz took over a Brooklyn bank at Avenue P and East Third Street, he wasnâ€™t yet the Dog. He was just Little John and â€œa hell of a pleasant guy,â€ù as one neighbor described him after the robbery. He was a Vietnam veteran, a father and a husband.

Drawing on extensive interviews and digging deep into archives, including Mr. Wojtowiczâ€™s personal stash, Ms. Berg and Mr. Keraudren revisit the bank robbery while doing so much more. â€œThe Dogâ€ù is, as its title suggests, a documentary portrait, but itâ€™s also an exploration of that sometimes messy thing called identity. Part of what makes Mr. Wojtowicz such a fascinating character is that he seemed to rotate identities as easily as other people change socks, and without angst. Like Zelig, he popped up a lot in some unexpected places: At one point, he campaigned as a Goldwater Republican; not too long afterward, he was agitating with the Gay Activists Alliance, a rights group with a theatrical streak. His transformation from activist to outlaw appeared equally seamless.

You have to wonder what Mr. Russo, who died in 1990, would say about Sonny and â€œDog Day Afternoonâ€ù now, much less â€œThe Dogâ€ù and Mr. Wojtowiczâ€™s later, distressingly hard life. Thereâ€™s no question that the bank robbery was a wild bit of theater, with or without its leading man, one that Mr. Lumet and Mr. Pacino restaged with relative restraint. Yet itâ€™s also true that the gaga media attention was fueled by homophobia and the straight worldâ€™s confused reaction to a self-identified gay man declaring his love for someone named Ernest. All these years later, as marriage equality heads toward universal acceptance, Mr. Wojtowicz doesnâ€™t remotely register as a freak. He was a lot of things when he tried to rob that bank, as this sympathetic documentary makes clear, including a man in love.

He was also 27 and separated from one wife, Carmen Wojtowicz, with whom he had two children, and having problems with a second, Ernest Aron a.k.a. Liz Eden, a transgender woman. What might have been just another ho-hum heist turned into screaming headline news when, shortly after the police descended on the bank, Mr. Wojtowicz announced that he wanted Ms. Eden released from a psychiatric ward. â€œIâ€™m gay,â€ù Mr. Wojtowicz explained. â€œWhen I get Ernest back, then Iâ€™ll release one of the hostages.â€ù Pandemonium ensued, and the crowd outside the bank swelled to an estimated several thousand, who alternately cheered and jeered at a spectacle that included appearances from Mr. Wojtowiczâ€™s mother, Terry, and several specially delivered pizzas.

In his landmark survey â€œThe Celluloid Closet: Homosexuality in the Movies,â€ù the historian Vito Russo â€” who was also involved in the Gay Activists Alliance â€” disparagingly mentions â€œDog Day Afternoonâ€ù in passing. The movie, he wrote, â€œwas the ultimate freak show, a film that used the sensational side of a true story to titillate a square audience.â€ù Sometime later, he returns to the film by quoting a line that Sonny says after his accomplice, Sal, complains that heâ€™s being erroneously called gay in television news reports. Sonny shrugs the whole thing off, telling Sal that â€œitâ€™s only a freak show to them.â€ù Mr. Russo agreed. â€œThat was all the movie was to Middle America,â€ù he wrote, â€œa freaky, only-in-New York story that made a fair two-hour yarn but failed to touch their lives.â€ù

The directors Allison Berg and Frank Keraudren explore the tension between movie-made truth and real-life fiction in â€œThe Dog,â€ù which, among other things, is also about a search for identity in an age of pseudo-celebrity. They rightly begin their story with Mr. Wojtowicz, whom they met in 2002. He was in his late 50s, a small man with a fleshy face, a pasty pallor and jagged, discolored teeth that listed like a Lower East Side tenement. (Cancer would later shrink him in body, if not spirit.) His accent was straight out of Brooklyn, and his sentences were peppered with dese, dems and the usual blue notes. As the world came to know, he was somewhat of a romantic.

It begins with breaking into the 2010 Coachella festival. A penniless Mr. Haney and a friend jump a fence and make it backstage before being ejected. But Mr. Haney gets great shots. Per disaster movie tradition, people trade banter, jargon and heart-to-hearts: a crew of storm chasers, a vice principal and his two sons, and other walking targets. A different breed from â€œTwisterâ€ù (1996), â€œInto the Stormâ€ù raises a question with its finest shots: Would the painter J. M. W. Turner just make disaster movies today?

Shot over a year, during which its maker, Joaquim Pinto â€” a mainstay of Portuguese cinema for more than 30 years â€” participated in clinical trials to treat his long-term H.I.V. and hepatitis C infections, this hypnotic video essay eases the discomforts of the flesh with the comforts of moviemaking. Simple, light-filled compositions give way to the occasional visual experiment, signifying drug disturbances that leave Mr. Pinto feeling woozy and faded. But thereâ€™s nothing muddled about his thinking. Narrating in soft, contemplative cadences, he flits from past to present, from politics to philosophy, weaving cinema history and early AIDS awareness together in a way that suggests that itâ€™s hard for him to think about one without the other.

Whether watching a virus replicate under a microscope or a dragonfly wobble interminably on a blade of grass, this meditation on mortality conveys more than anything the joy of being alive.

The â€œStep Upâ€ù series is the rare franchise that has grown more ambitious with each installment. As the dance numbers have become flashier and splashier, the stories have become more fanciful, occasionally even supplementing their be-yourself bromides with socially engaged ideas.

Sean (Ryan Guzman), the hero of the last movie, struggles to start a career as a dancer in Los Angeles. Having lost the confidence of his crew, he plans to enter a televised contest in Las Vegas, whose prize is a three-year booking.

Moose (Adam Sevani), now happily living with Camille (Alyson Stoner), but resigned to working as an engineer, helps him find a new team, which, of course, means recruiting characters fromÂ â€œStep Up 2 the Streetsâ€ùÂ  andÂ â€œStep Up 3D.â€ù Â These include Andie (Briana Evigan), who tests Seanâ€™s resolve with a lively dance-off in a costume warehouse.
â€œStep Up All Inâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Vegas or no, itâ€™s a lot milder than â€œShowgirls.â€ù

Most numbers aim for maximum ostentation (the Frankensteinâ€™s-lab-themed audition video, with shattering beakers in 3-D, is a hoot), but the filmsâ€™ highlights have often been quieter expressions of joy. When Sean and Andie dance to Bobby Brownâ€™s â€œEvery Little Stepâ€ù through the spinning cars of an empty amusement park ride, â€œAll Inâ€ù briefly sheds its flash and calculation and exudes the infectiousness of an old-fashioned movie musical.

The advocacy documentary â€œA Will for the Woodsâ€ù ostensibly focuses on natural burial, a way to minimize a burialâ€™s impact on the environment. The closing credits even invite viewers to go online for further information. But the movieâ€™s real subject may be facing death with equanimity.

The film shows how funeral planning can be a palliative â€” a way to give meaning to an otherwise pointless death, Dr. Wang says â€” and an opportunity to shape a legacy. He contemplates having honeysuckle planted on his grave. â€œMost people donâ€™t think of me as very sweet now,â€ù he says. â€œBut maybe later, this might change their mind.â€ù

Commentary from Joe Sehee, founder of the Green Burial Council, gives â€œA Will for the Woodsâ€ù the feel of a commercial, though the movie remains frustratingly light on statistics. The film follows a psychiatrist, Clark Wang, of Durham, N.C., who learned he had lymphoma roughly seven years before the shoot. He died in 2011. We watch as he copes with worsening medical news and makes arrangements for his funeral. Admirably, at times eerily calm and good-humored about his fate, he reveals relatively little about his life.

It is hard to imagine that any other actress could muster the stubborn ferocity that Isabelle Huppert brings to the role of Maud, a successful French filmmaker recovering from a stroke in Catherine Breillatâ€™s â€œAbuse of Weakness.â€ù Like many of Ms. Huppertâ€™s screen characters, Maud is an imperious, willful woman with a perverse drive to play with fire. She refuses to be stopped, even after her left side is paralyzed, and she is barely able to walk.

She also commissioned Mr. Rocancourt to write a screenplay about his colorful love life and lent him nearly a million dollars from her personal savings. In 2009 she published a book, â€œAbus de Faiblesse,â€ù whose title is a legal term meaning â€œabuse of weakness,â€ù in which she accused Mr. Rocancourt of taking advantage of her vulnerability to swindle her.

Vilko begins asking Maud for sizable loans. And the sight of her blithely writing him checks suggests that the two are playing a dangerous game of chicken, in which Maud foolishly imagines that she can tame him. He eventually promises to pay her back through a scheme he has hatched that involves buying a restaurant with her money, fixing it up and selling it at an enormous profit. In the meantime, Maud, for reasons that are never specified, simultaneously spends a great deal of money renovating her own home.

â€œIt was me, and it wasnâ€™t me,â€ù she says with a shrug. Even then, her attitude is that of a rebellious, spoiled adolescent who refuses to admit culpability. In her manipulative, roundabout way, Maud is as much the abuser as Vilko is in this chilly, dark portrait of two control freaks locking horns.

When Maud is nearly broke, a family meeting is called, and she is asked to explain her disastrous extravagance to her siblings and her children. Ms. Huppert makes excellent use of one of her signature expressions. With her jaw clenched and wearing the cold, dispassionate gaze of a stubborn animal, she refuses to make excuses.

Mr. Shen is this filmâ€™s equivalent of the Italian porn star Rocco Siffredi, whom Ms. Breillat cast in two previous films, including the notorious â€œRomance,â€ù in which he was shown in a state of arousal. That film conveyed a more explicit version of the same tug of war driving â€œAbuse of Weakness,â€ù in which the director subtly uses an actorâ€™s erotic power against him.

â€œAbuse of Weaknessâ€ù tells a fictional version of the same story, with the French rap star Kool Shen, 47, playing Vilko, an arrogant crook whom the disabled Maud impulsively invites to star in her next film.

This semi-autobiographical film takes off from real events in the life of Ms. Breillat, 66, who was immobilized a decade ago by a brain hemorrhage. One hand hanging limply, her mouth drooping, Ms. Huppert graphically depicts the symptoms of a stroke and the painful rehabilitation. More than frightened, Maud is frustrated and enraged by her sudden incapacity. The stroke is a cosmic insult and a rebuke to the freewheeling independence she had taken for granted.

The back story: While recovering, Ms. Breillat met Christophe Rocancourt, a notorious con man 19 years her junior who once boasted that his schemes had yielded him more than $40 million. He had already served five years for his crimes. Transfixed by his charisma after seeing him interviewed on television, Ms. Breillat met with Mr. Rocancourt and offered him a leading role, opposite Naomi Campbell, in a movie based on her novel â€œBad Love.â€ù The film was never made.

Mr. Shen, who resembles a middle-aged Jean-Paul Belmondo, oozes a thuggish animal magnetism. Cocky and unrepentant about his life of crime, Vilko initiates a diabolical power struggle with Maud that is infused with sexual provocation, although no sex between them actually occurs. (She immediately rebuffs his swift move to kiss her.) Vilko is married to Andy (Laurence Ursino), a sleek young model he later sheds to Maudâ€™s approval.

What follow are scenes of unremitting brutality and sadism, as the thuggish guards set about transforming their charges into model citizens. Presided over by a retired colonel (an excellent James C. Burns), the place â€” a drab, cramped hellhole of Darwinian violence â€” offers few opportunities for the cinematographer, Jayson Crothers, to please our eyes. So when brief flashbacks to Bradâ€™s pre-lockup life allow him to escape the filmâ€™s military palette of dusty greens and slicing shadows, the lightness of the images suggests that maybe the inmates arenâ€™t the only ones here who feel confined.
Proceeding in a tone of unrelieved misery, â€œColdwaterâ€ù is a punishing, predictable drama thatâ€™s almost rescued by strong acting and good intentions.

Centering on Brad (P. J. BoudousquÃ©), an angry teenager and small-time drug dealer, the story (by the director, Vincent Grashaw, and Mark Penney) follows his downward skid from minor scraps to full-blown tragedy. In desperation, his widowed mother arranges to have him taken to a privately run juvenile reform institution in the middle of nowhere: a roach motel for recalcitrant youths who have no idea when they will be sprung.

Though sincere in its attempt to draw attention to the problems of for-profit boot camps (including a number of reported deaths), â€œColdwaterâ€ù is too unvaryingly grim to draw us in. Unfolding with hardly a moment of warmth or human connection, Mr. Grashawâ€™s cheerless first feature is, like Bradâ€™s detention, simply to be endured.

The other planets include the nearly silent drummer and bassist (Carla Azar and FranÃ§ois Civil), who mostly send scowls and mutters Jonâ€™s way. More overtly hostile is Clara (Maggie Gyllenhaal), who plays theremin and synthesizer and punctuates her chain-smoking with instrument-smashing rages.

Since the audience sees Frank primarily through Jonâ€™s eyes, we share his image of a willfully peculiar, unorthodox genius. The giant head, which never leaves Frankâ€™s shoulders, even in the shower, looks more like an affectation or a long-term art project than a necessary source of psychic protection. In Ireland, Frank is funny, charismatic and compassionate, but it is only later that we and Jon come to see how fragile and unstable he is.

And â€œFrankâ€ù is resolutely honest about the relationship between its title characterâ€™s gifts and his illness, avoiding facile explanations or sentimental equations. Mr. Abrahamsonâ€™s main achievement, enabled by the sensitive and resourceful cast, is to find a tone that is funny without flippancy, sincere without turning to mush.
â€œFrankâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Smoking, swearing, sex.

That session eats up almost a year and most of Jonâ€™s savings. It also occupies much of the filmâ€™s running time, in a defiance of the usual routines of plot that matches Frankâ€™s own indifference to creative and commercial norms. Living in a couple of scruffy bungalows on the shore of a lake, the musicians record natural sounds, engage in mock-gladiatorial combat (which sometimes causes real injury) and occasionally pick up their instruments. Frank, the guiding artistic spirit, falls somewhere on the spectrum between camp counselor and cult leader. He is encouraging but also demanding, and his evident talent is entangled with mental illness.

Popular music has always had a place for eccentrics and visionaries, artists whose inventions sometimes take them to the borderlands of madness. â€œFrank,â€ù a captivatingly low-key new film directed by Lenny Abrahamson, was inspired by the life and work of one such musician, a singer known as Frank Sidebottom, who flourished in Britain in the 1990s. At one point, Mr. Sidebottom hired a keyboard player named Jon Ronson â€” though â€œhiredâ€ù may suggest too conventional an arrangement â€” who later embellished, edited and updated his experience into the screenplay for this movie, which takes place in the present-day world of social media and South by Southwest.

That would be Frank, the center of a strange musical solar system, played by Michael Fassbender in a performance all the more extraordinary for his being masked and muffled. (His long, swinging arms and craggy, elegant hands become his primary tools of expression.)

The movie falters at some points, and Mr. Gleeson strikes a few gratingly overeager notes, but it is well served by a ragged, quizzical style. Itâ€™s not going anywhere terribly important and is in no hurry to get there, but â€œFrankâ€ù is an accumulation of memorably offbeat moments, like an album made up of B sides and lost demo tracks that you stumble across and canâ€™t stop replaying.

Jon does not quite understand this, and his misjudgment is what brings the drama and pathos of â€œFrankâ€ù into relief. As he grows to love Frank, he starts to believe that he can build a bridge between this profoundly idiosyncratic, fiercely experimental artist and the rest of the world. He wants to spread the word, find an audience and bring Frank and the others the fans they deserve: all perfectly reasonable ambitions, but dangerously incompatible with Frankâ€™s temperament and based on Jonâ€™s naÃ¯ve and romantic assumptions about his condition.

The manager, who can hardly manage himself, is Don (Scoot McNairy), a bit nicer to Jon than the others but not entirely reassuring in his explanations of how the outfit works. Jonâ€™s debut goes more or less smoothly â€” not really, but nobody quits or winds up in the hospital â€” and he is invited to join the others at a recording session in Ireland.

Mr. Ronsonâ€™s alter ego, and the audienceâ€™s guide to Frankâ€™s peculiar musical and emotional world, is Jon (Domhnall Gleeson), a rock â€™nâ€™ roll dreamer living in middle-class tedium with his parents. When he isnâ€™t in his office cubicle, Jon struggles mightily to transform everyday observations into songs. The results are dispiriting (sample lyric: â€œLadies/Have babies/Thatâ€™s just how it worksâ€ù), as is Jonâ€™s tally of Twitter followers, which barely breaks into double digits. But then one day he witnesses a strange incident on a windswept beach â€” an apparent suicide attempt â€” and finds himself recruited into a band led by a man in a cardigan and a large papier-mÃ¢chÃ© head.

Itâ€™s such a poetic title, â€œI Am Happiness on Earth,â€ù but itâ€™s also a purposeful con. On earth, in the Mexican director JuliÃ¡n HernÃ¡ndezâ€™s artful vision, thereâ€™s not much happiness, at least not in the dour, sexually explicit couplings and triplings among the men and women in this film.

Like the title, the story is filled with misdirections: It develops in its own interest-challenging manner, with a protagonist who isnâ€™t clear until late in the film. Itâ€™s not the boyish (and very good) dancer we first meet, Octavio (Alan RamÃ_rez), nor is it the sensitive hustler, Jazen (Emilio von Sternenfels), who comes into play later. Itâ€™s the brooding film director, Emiliano (Hugo CatalÃ¡n), who beds them both, joylessly. Without much signal of whatâ€™s happened â€” yet another misdirection â€” â€œI Am Happinessâ€ù turns its focus midway to three new characters who may be part of Emilianoâ€™s rather pornographic work.

If you hang on, the slow-paced â€œI Am Happinessâ€ù may teach you how to appreciate its scoreless, flat, dreamlike flow. I wasnâ€™t convinced; at one point my notes included the gut reaction â€œThis is awful.â€ù But the film does land somewhere â€” clichÃ©d, but still â€” and I grew to respect its aims.

That shifts again but leads to meta moments, like this statement from Jazen, who admires Emilianoâ€™s films, though his friends donâ€™t: â€œThey donâ€™t understand art house films,â€ù the subtitle reads. â€œThere are no dialogues, and the movie is really long.â€ù The line, of course, is an impudent tease. Still: Be forewarned.

Quotations from sources as varied as Thelonious Monk, Mark Twain and Dr. Seuss appear on screen, imbuing the movie with unearned significance. When Jake wonders why his problems matter, a bikini-clad hot-tub guest cites Homer.

Looking to settle down, Jake mentally auditions past flames for companionship. The candidates are a distant cousin (Liana Liberato as a teenager, Jane Seymour as an adult); a girlfriend in Chicago (Jennifer Jason Leigh); and an inexplicably smitten best friend (Virginia Madsen).

The title â€œJake Squaredâ€ù is exponentially insufficient, as Jake himself (Elias Koteas) eventually acknowledges. Jake is a filmmaker frustrated with parenthood and lonely after a divorce. What better way to solve this existential crisis than to make a movie about his life?

As the four nonactor Jakes debate which woman is â€œthe one,â€ù â€œJake Squaredâ€ù combines the most grating tendencies of meta navel-gazing with the sexism of reality television â€” pushing the limit of viewer tolerance to zero.

â€œJake Squaredâ€ù aspires to the tradition of â€œ8 Â_â€ù and â€œSynecdoche, New York,â€ù phantasmagorical portraits of artists seeking perspective on their lives. Unlike in those films, though, the conceit makes little sense. Actors, ghosts and past selves intermingle. Jake watches impossible footage on his iPhone.

The setting will be a house party, with a significantly better-looking actor (Mike Vogel) playing Jake. Yet somehow the attendees also include Jakeâ€™s 17-year-old self (Kevin Railsback) and the 30- and 40-year-old incarnations (both played by Mr. Koteas).

Ms. Mouglalis, tall, angular and inclined to frowning, is a perfect match for the younger Mr. Garrelâ€™s moody sensitivity. If â€œJealousyâ€ù contained just the two of them, it would be beautiful and agonized, a duet of star-crossed passion not unlike â€œI Can No Longer Hear the Guitar,â€ù Philippe Garrelâ€™s 1991 film based on his affair with the German singer Nico. This film feels lighter, warmer and more accessible than some of its predecessors, in no small part thanks to Olga Milshteinâ€™s lively performance as Charlotte, the daughter of Louis and Clothilde. A natural screen presence with an authentic sense of mischief, Ms. Milshtein, like her character, disrupts the self-absorption of the adults with her frankness and her expectation of attention.

You may wonder how much she understands about what her mother, her father and her fatherâ€™s lover are up to. To the extent that this is autobiography, of course, she is the directorâ€™s surrogate, and her perspective is therefore his â€” curious about grown-up love and its discontents, inclined to forgive but too honest to forget anything.

â€œJealousy,â€ù Philippe Garrelâ€™s new film, begins in tears and proceeds through seasons of romantic melancholy, unfolding on Paris streets and in Bohemian apartments filmed in lovely shades of gray. The black-and-white images (captured by the great Belgian cinematographer Willy Kurant) seem to float free of time, accompanied by the disarmingly sweet tones of Jean-Louis Aubertâ€™s music. The main character, a young actor named Louis, is based on Mr. Garrelâ€™s father and played by his son (also named Louis). This tale of emotional ambivalence and wayward passion seems to be happening equally in the present, in the Nouvelle Vague era of the directorâ€™s young manhood, and at any other point in the long history of Gallic love trouble.

In a brief 77 minutes, â€œJealousyâ€ù provides a remarkably full â€” and also an intriguingly partial â€” portrait of a group of struggling artists as no-longer-entirely-young men and women. Louis belongs to a theater company that performs intense and rigorous productions of French classics, while both Clothilde and Claudia are actresses whose careers have stalled. Claudia, while professing her love for Louis, also impulsively hooks up with a stranger in a bar and later gravitates into a cynical affair with an architect.

There is obvious potential for melodrama here, but Mr. Garrel has never been interested in the traditional telescoping of feeling into big scenes and confrontations. At times his films feel as if they were entirely composed of what more conventional narrative features would leave out â€” the interstitial and transitional moments that invisibly link the well-marked stations of the plot. Those are the places where the richest information is stored, where the mysterious and self-evident truths of personality and feeling reside. Mr. Garrelâ€™s method goes beyond realism to achieve a kind of psychological intimacy that is rare and, in its low-key, meandering way, tremendously exciting. It is almost uncanny how well you feel you know these people, even as their motives and behavior remain opaque to one another.

Which is not to suggest that there is anything generic or imprecise about the film. On the contrary, it is almost achingly specific, a close and rigorous study of the nuances of feeling that bind and separate Louis and the women in his life. When we first meet him, he is leaving Clothilde (Rebecca Convenant), with whom he has a daughter, for reasons that seem both urgent and abstract. Clothilde begs him to stay, but Louis breaks free and goes to live with Claudia (Anna Mouglalis). At first, Claudia is terrified that he will leave or betray her, but as time goes by the poles of their relationship reverse, and he becomes the jealous one.

â€œYouâ€™ve been watching too many movies,â€ù says a detective (Andy Garcia) during an interrogation in â€œLetâ€™s Be Cops.â€ù The same could be said for the filmmakers, who hit predictable beats in this disposable comedy.

Justin (Damon Wayans Jr.) and his roommate, Ryan (Jake Johnson, Mr. Wayansâ€™s â€œNew Girlâ€ù co-star), have confidence problems: Justin, a video game designer, wonâ€™t assert himself at work, and Ryan canâ€™t get over an accident he had years ago that kept him out of pro football. But when they attend what they think is a costume party, dressed as cops â€” and discover the authority their attire brings them â€” they embrace their empowerment.

Ryan finds an authentic-looking police car on eBay, and theyâ€™re off on patrol, being pummeled during a domestic dispute between shrieking women and colliding with a naked 350-pound thief in a store break-in. And they meet gun runners in cahoots with a crooked cop. Do they rise to their disguises? Does Justin learn to fight for himself? Does Ryan regain his self-respect? Contain your suspense.
â€œLetâ€™s Be Copsâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for obscene language and drug use.
LETâ€™S BE COPS
Directed by Luke Greenfield
1 hour 44 minutes

Mr. Wayans and Mr. Johnson share an easy rapport, and Keegan-Michael Key (of â€œKey & Peeleâ€ù), as a sympathetic thug, joins in. Nina Dobrev, as Mr. Wayansâ€™s love interest, has an earthy appeal squandered here. But the comedian Natasha Leggero, playing a floozy on a surveillance stakeout, milks her moments for every comic-sexy second theyâ€™re worth, turning, however briefly, piffle into gold. ANDY WEBSTER
Opened on Wednesday

Written and directed by Jeff Baena, this first feature feels sloppily plotted and uncertain of its destination. Seasoned actors are left to yell pointlessly at one another, while Beth and the zombie angle slowly decompose.

And for an aimlessly crashing-around comedy, thatâ€™s a big deal. Reappearing not long after her funeral, Beth is blissfully unaware that sheâ€™s past her expiration date. Her parents (Molly Shannon and John C. Reilly) refuse to tell her, and her grieving boyfriend, Zach (Dane DeHaan), will tolerate anything â€” even fetid breath and a tendency to gnaw on his carâ€™s upholstery â€” to keep her around. As for Beth, she just wants to copulate and listen to smooth jazz.

By contrast, recent television series have proved how fertile this kind of reassimilation story can be, whether handled with the eerie poetry of Sundance TVâ€™s â€œThe Returned,â€ù or with the whip-smart, working-class pragmatism of BBC Americaâ€™s â€œIn the Flesh.â€ù In that show, the so-called Partially Deceased Syndrome Sufferers made us laugh, weep and worry about all-too-real evils; Beth just makes us wish she had more reasons to smile.

Aubrey Plaza has large, intelligent eyes and a startlingly gorgeous smile â€” one thatâ€™s unleashed all too rarely in her role as a lovable misanthrope on â€œParks and Recreation.â€ù Sadly, playing a lusty, undead girlfriend in â€œLife After Bethâ€ù gives her even fewer opportunities to beam, but when she does, the whole film seems to slow down and soften.

Part grotesque comedy, part soft-core fetish curiosity, â€œMoebiusâ€ù is, you hope, not seriously intended as much else. The South Korean director Kim Ki-duk throws down the gauntlet (and something else) with his opening setup, in which a maddened mother slices off her sonâ€™s penis in revenge for her husbandâ€™s infidelity. (Thatâ€™s after trying her spouse first.) Love does not quite conquer all afterward, though it does eventually lead to an especially altruistic father-son transplant.

Mr. Kim often dons a number of hats in making his films, and here his duties extend beyond writing, editing and producing to handling the camera himself. That suggests â€œMoebiusâ€ù as something he felt an uncontrollable urge to bring into the world, at any cost. Itâ€™s one from the heart, and a twisted tale it is.

Despite that horrifying development, Mr. Kim somehow maintains a deadpan amusement at the follies of carnal desire. His silent-comedy sequences simply happen to feature severed body parts and impalement. Heâ€™s aided by the decision to omit spoken dialogue, in addition to letting his actors go through their paces with an eye-bulging air of helplessness.

That comic knack is disarming, and also a little disturbing, as Mr. Kim shows off a Lars von Trier-esque talent for ratcheting his puppets and their boldfaced psychosexual issues into motion, but with convenient gaps in emotional intelligence. This isnâ€™t quite the â€œsexual terrorismâ€ù that Mr. Kim, the director of â€œ3-Ironâ€ù and â€œPieta,â€ù was accused of during his more popular days a decade ago. But the withholding of speech ultimately feels less like purist visual storytelling and more like a sadistic hobbling of his characters.

Raggedly shot with a hand-held camera, this violent film presents Mr. Kim at his weakest, indulging in crass characterization and brute-force profundity. The characters remain nameless, and after Mother (Lee Eun-woo) conveniently disappears for the moment, Father (Cho Jae-hyun) makes amends by searching the Internet for solutions to his sonâ€™s plight. These will involve an indirect variation on frottage involving stones, though Son (Seo Young-ju) at first pursues his own sexual outlet by joining a gang that rapes Fatherâ€™s mistress (surprise: Ms. Lee again) in her convenience store.

All that said, â€œMoebiusâ€ù is not grounds for outrage â€” just a blunt instrument with identifiable fingerprints. Celebrated in the past for better work, Mr. Kim does show an abiding concern here for the unsubtle realities of human libido and cruelty, but heâ€™s alarmingly tone-deaf as he makes his points, and shows disregard for his female characters as he uses them up.

The mock-clichÃ© title of â€œBoy Meets Girl,â€ù Leos Caraxâ€™s debut feature, which he made in the 1980s when he was in his early 20s, belies its fresh, shooting-star romanticism and visual originality. These qualities streak throughout the work of Mr. Carax, who, as amply illustrated by â€œMr. X: A Vision of Leos Carax,â€ù gives the sense of discovering the art and romance of cinema anew with each film.

Tessa Louise-SalomÃ©â€™s short but rich documentary at first plays up the enigma of Mr. Carax, the French filmmaker (born Alex Christophe Dupont) celebrated for â€œHoly Motors,â€ù his mysterious 2012 story of a limo-riding shape-shifter. Though Ms. Louise-SalomÃ©â€™s film strikes a potentially irritating pose as a kind of artistic sÃ©ance â€” shrouding interviewees in shadow, conjuring up clips with the drifting rhythm of the unconscious â€” it delivers articulate insights and has an elegant construction.

Denis Lavant, Mr. Caraxâ€™s acteur fÃ©tiche (as the French might call a favored performer) since â€œBoy Meets Girl,â€ù is one of many witnesses here to the filmmakerâ€™s collaborations and sense of an artistic search. The press-averse Mr. Carax, who has made only five features in three decades, appears, disembodied, on the soundtrack, direct and eloquent. Ms. Louise-SalomÃ© finds telling production details, even putting the notoriously expensive â€œThe Lovers on the Bridgeâ€ù into perspective, and also sits down fellow filmmakers like Harmony Korine and Kiyoshi Kurosawa for comment.

Documentaries like this can leave you simply impatient to see the subjectâ€™s movies on display. Fortunately, the weeklong run of â€œMr. Xâ€ù at Film Forum accompanies a retrospective of Mr. Caraxâ€™s beguiling films.

Generously packed with film clips and interviews with three other prominent blacklisted names â€” Paul Jarrico, Ring Lardner Jr. and Alfred Levitt â€” â€œRed Hollywoodâ€ù is an intellectual tour through some of American cinemaâ€™s most politically idealistic moments and some of its most pessimistic. It was directed by Thom Andersen and NoÃ«l Burch, and is something of a companion piece to a 1985 article by Mr. Andersen in which he argued that those who were blacklisted were actually doing what the House Un-American Activities Committee accused them of doing â€” subverting Hollywood. As Mr. Andersen wryly wrote and, as he and Mr. Burch argue on screen, â€œIt would be an injustice to those who were blacklisted to say they did nothing to deserve it.â€ù

â€œRed Hollywoodâ€ù may suggest the rivers of blood that flood our screens. But the red in the title of this fascinating essaylike movie refers to the home-front Communists and other American radicals â€” actual and accused â€” who once upon a Hollywood time made socially conscious movies that took on the world and its woes. These were true believers, like the fiery Abraham Polonsky who, with films like â€œForce of Evilâ€ù (1948), challenged reigning ideologies and at times cast pitch-black shadows over the scene to make class, race and sexual inequality all part of the big picture.

Garfield was never a Communist but was forced to testify; he died from a heart attack at 39 in 1952 and is often cast as a blacklist martyr. Years later, Mr. Polonsky (who died in 1999), wrote of that fallen star: The Group Theater â€œtrained him, the movies made him, and the blacklist killed him.â€ù In contrast to a lot of surveys of Hollywood and McCarthyism, however, Mr. Andersen and Mr. Burch keep their focus on the films in question instead of personalities, advancing their argument in sections â€” the movie is narrated by the director Billy Woodberry â€” titled war, class, sexes, and the like. Insistently cinematic and dialectical, â€œRed Hollywoodâ€ù has another virtue: It doesnâ€™t toss everyone into a single leftist lump. Differences are articulated and illustrated, as individual voices rise and fall, fade and endure.

Mr. Andersen and Mr. Burch, who have remastered and re-edited their 1996 video version of â€œRed Hollywoodâ€ù for this iteration, register as less interested in memorializing the blacklisted as victims than in making an argument for the worth of their films. (Mr. Andersenâ€™s other movies include â€œLos Angeles Plays Itself,â€ù about that city and its cinematic representations. Mr. Burch is also known for his book on Japanese cinema, â€œTo the Distant Observer.â€ù) One jumping off point for â€œRed Hollywoodâ€ù is Billy Wilderâ€™s widely repeated quip about the so-called Hollywood 10, or Unfriendly 10, who appeared before the House committee: â€œOnly two of them have talent. The rest are just unfriendly.â€ù Methodically, movie by movie, Mr. Andersen and Mr. Burch demolish that gibe, as in a section on the heartbreaking John Garfield, who worked with Mr. Polonsky.

â€œAll films about crime are about capitalism,â€ù Mr. Polonsky says, eyes shining and dukes forever raised, â€œbecause capitalism is about crime. I mean â€˜quote unquote,â€™ morally speaking. At least thatâ€™s what I used to think. Now Iâ€™m convinced.â€ù

â€œRed Hollywoodâ€ù doesnâ€™t delve deeply into the history of McCarthyism; to an extent it assumes its audience already knows that story and can jump right in. So, instead of the usual historical preamble, it opens with a slavering, juicy clip from â€œJohnny Guitar,â€ù the delirious 1954 western starring a gun-toting Joan Crawford as a saloonkeeper with an insanely troubled personal life. Directed by Nicholas Ray, the movie was credited to the screenwriter Philip Yordan, who may have been a front for the blacklisted Ben Maddow. It gets thornier. After years of silence, Maddow apparently did name names. Another blacklisted screenwriter, Walter Bernstein, wrote that Maddowâ€™s testimony had nothing to do with politics, money or fear: â€œHe simply could no longer stand living in the shadows.â€ù
â€œDinosaur 13â€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Sad scientists and big bad government.

Faced with a dauntingly dry regulatory tangle (which eventually flowered into a jaw-droppingly complex criminal trial and a bewildering prison term for Mr. Larson), the director, Todd Douglas Miller, extracts a clear â€” and clearly lopsided â€” narrative from the confusion. Using unobtrusive dramatizations, lively archival film and interviews with not-too-talky heads, he holds us tight to the thread of the story. But itâ€™s his use of emotion, relentless and brilliant, that really keeps us from straying.

Maybe his director did, too, just a little. Silver-haired, bespectacled and with a cowboy-professor air, the filmâ€™s homey hero oozes underdog charm. Yet however enamored, Mr. Miller does his story (based on Ms. Donnan and Mr. Larsonâ€™s 2002 memoir) a disservice by failing to open it up, even slightly, to the tension between academic paleontologists and their commercial counterparts. Preferring not to dig into the ethics of for-profit fossil collecting and the auctioning off of prehistory to the highest bidder â€” or even to cast a questioning eye over the instituteâ€™s operations â€” he cedes point of view to his subject and throws balance out the window.

In fairness, a number of those approached by Mr. Miller either declined or were unable to appear in the movie, but the taint of bias lingers. â€œDinosaur 13â€ù may not be the best documentary, but as a scientific soap opera, itâ€™s a doozy.

A stirring blend of love story, courtroom drama and professional tragedy, â€œDinosaur 13â€ù (before Sue, only a dozen T. rex skeletons had been discovered) is a nonfiction weepie that manages to skirt its most troubling questions. When the F.B.I., suspecting theft from federally owned land, conducted a 1992 raid on the Black Hills Institute (a commercial supply house of fossils and minerals), its seizure of Sue and other specimens ignited a public outcry. The ensuing fight for custody of the tyrannosaur â€” and, later, for Mr. Larsonâ€™s freedom and that of his colleagues â€” would place multiple federal agencies and an Indian tribe at the center of years of legal action and heated debate.

Life sure wasnâ€™t easy for a dinosaur named Sue. As revealed by the skeleton, excavated in 1990 by the paleontologist Peter Larson and his team from the Black Hills Institute for Geological Research in South Dakota, Sueâ€™s journey through the late Cretaceous period had been fraught by an unusual number of broken bones and other injuries. Almost 70 million years later, these magnificent remains â€” constituting the most complete Tyrannosaurus rex ever found â€” would embark on another journey, this time through a labyrinthine legal battle that would leave their caretakers equally scarred.

â€œPeter was in love with that dinosaur,â€ù Marion Zenker, the instituteâ€™s office manager, tells us; and here is Mr. Larson, moist-eyed and denim-clad, heartbreakingly affirming his devotion. Sympathetic witnesses to the seizure, including the photographer and filmmaker Louie Psihoyos, dignify his pain, as does moving video footage of distressed crowds and impassive National Guardsmen. Even the journalist Kristin Donnan, invited by Mr. Larson to cover the story, confesses to falling in love with her host.

Naval strategy, re-enacted with a mix of model warships and computer-generated effects, occupies the bulk of the filmâ€™s attention. Title cards provide updates on the hour and sailing conditions. Yiâ€™s men lure a Japanese ship into close contact before bombarding it with cannon fire. A whirlpool makes control difficult for the invading army and calms the surrounding waters, improving Yiâ€™s troopsâ€™ accuracy.

At the outset, Yi returns to his command after being tortured in an undeserved disciplinary action. He prepares to fend off an assault led by Kurushima (Ryu Seung-ryong), nicknamed the Pirate King. Unlike the Japanese general (Cho Jin-woong) serving as his second in command, Kurushima hasnâ€™t fought Yi before and doesnâ€™t fear him.

These large-scale battle movements are presented at length with the unvaried jingoism of a Michael Bay action sequence. The film is already a hit in South Korea, but it lacks the character interest that might make it connect elsewhere.

Yiâ€™s men know they face slim odds, but the admiral strives to turn cowardice into courage. He sets fire to his own military encampment, goading his troops into battle by assuring them that death will come on land or at sea.

A turgid, foursquare naval epic, the South Korean drama â€œThe Admiral: Roaring Currentsâ€ù memorializes the 1597 Battle of Myeongnyang, in which the military leader of the title, Yi Sun-shin (Choi Min-sik, from â€œOldboyâ€ù), with a dozen ships, held off an encroaching Japanese army. The movie, directed by Kim Han-min, stages this David-and-Goliath pairing with a nationalistic fervor.
â€œThe Expendables 3â€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for action stars going about their business.

Walking past Madame Tussauds after a preview screening of â€œThe Expendables 3â€ù on 42nd Street in Manhattan brought on a mysterious feeling of dÃ©jÃ  vu, until I realized that both franchises share an operating principle: Cram a bunch of famous faces together and bank on the immediate joys of recognition.

Sylvester Stallone again leads a lineup of distinguished colleagues, and soon enough heâ€™s rounding up a younger batch of killers for a mission against a nemesis long thought dead (energetically played by Mel Gibson, whose career has been in a similar state). When the youngsters are detained in the villainâ€™s lair amid far-flung postwar ruins, Mr. Stallone and his originals save the whippersnappers by shooting stuff and making strategic quips.

The director, Patrick Hughes, pours these gunfire barrages, explosions and a few leaping stunts into rambling set pieces, as if turning an action hose on and off. A little pizazz comes from Antonio Banderas as a gabby Spanish killer and from Wesley Snipes as a loose cannon, reconfirming his potent screen presence. Harrison Ford gets an extended grimacing turn as a government agent, and Arnold Schwarzenegger plays a big friendly guy who turns up occasionally to hang out.

Itâ€™s all a bit like a classic-rock tribute concert, or playing with all your action figures at once, or maybe â€œCannonball Run,â€ù with the strained buddy-buddy back-and-forth. Itâ€™s also a leisurely action movie that feels as though itâ€™s spread pretty thin across its more-is-better cast.

â€œThe Giver,â€ù the first book in the Giver Quartet, was published in 1993 and almost immediately eyed by Mr. Bridges as a screen property. In the decades since, publishers and filmmakers have continued to exploit the seemingly interminable craze for young-adult bummers with varying success. Ms. Lowryâ€™s â€œThe Giverâ€ù preceded both the â€œHunger Gamesâ€ù and â€œDivergentâ€ù book series, to name two popular feel-bad sagas. Yet because both â€œThe Hunger Gamesâ€ù and â€œDivergentâ€ù hit the screen first, the movie version of â€œThe Giverâ€ù â€” scene by formulaic scene, narrative clichÃ© by clichÃ© â€” canâ€™t help but come off as a poor copy of those earlier pictures.

What follows is the usual heroâ€™s journey mixed in with sloppy montage sequences that are meant to represent the memories the Giver is passing to Jonas but mostly evoke one of those tear-jerking commercials that sell their wares with gurgling babies and squirming puppies. The director Phillip Noyce â€” working with a lamentable script credited to Michael Mitnick and Robert B. Weide, and saddled with cheap digital effects and sets that needed more money or imagination or both â€” canâ€™t do much here, but doesnâ€™t seem to be trying hard, either. About the only other thing worth mentioning is that this is yet another cinematic dystopia, in the wake of â€œElysiumâ€ù and â€œDivergent,â€ù with a villainous female leader. That old Sonic Youth line about â€œfear of a female planetâ€ù is in no danger of becoming irrelevant.

By the time the sounds of the Von Trapp children warbling â€œSilent Nightâ€ù drift through â€œThe Giver,â€ù you may find yourself wondering what fresh movie hell this is. In truth, the enervating hash of dystopian dread, vague religiosity and commercial advertising-style uplift is nothing if not stale. Adapted from Lois Lowryâ€™s book for young readers, the story involves an isolated society that, with its cubistic dwellings, mindless smiles, monochromatic environs and nebulous communitarianism, seem modeled on a Scandinavian country or an old Mentos commercial.

Jonas becomes the Receiver of Memory, which means that he gets to hang out with the only jumpy cat in this mausoleum, the Giver, an older dude played by Jeff Bridges with a muffled voice and a grizzled beard. The inhabitants of this world, like members of some crazy cult, decided long ago to banish memories along with bright colors, flattering clothing and emotions. Well, more or less: They also decided that one resident would always be the societyâ€™s custodian of collective memories and would, in time, pass this storehouse of remembrances on to the next Receiver. Thatâ€™s how and why Jonas ends up in a house filled with books and perched at this worldâ€™s outer limits.

The black-and-white world of the setting also suggests that youâ€™re back in Kansas, as do the flickering rainbow colors that can be seen only by Jonas (Brenton Thwaites). Jonas lives with his â€œfamily unitâ€ù (Alexander Skarsgard and Katie Holmes play his folks) in a culture as quiet, cold and inert as a crypt. Along with his friends, Fiona (Odeya Rush) and Asher (Cameron Monaghan), Jonas is about to become a worker bee. Once grown, each citizen is assigned to a specific job, explains the Chief Elder (Meryl Streep, who seems to have borrowed her severe gray â€™do from Holly Hunter in â€œTop of the Lakeâ€ù). Some are designated nurturers; others become pilots, gardeners and so on.
In the end, it taketh â€” your time, patience and faith in newly imagined dystopias â€” more than it giveth.
â€œThe Giverâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Infanticide and child endangerment.

Hanging out with Romantic ghosts does put the two travelers in a thoughtful mood, particularly about life and death, though itâ€™s impossible to know if these intimations of mortality generate from them or Mr. Winterbottom. Whatever the case, the movie is shot through with references to shuffling off this mortal coil, a topic that manifests in various ways, including a quick visit to a crypt, an aside about Roberto Rosselliniâ€™s 1954 masterpiece â€œJourney to Italyâ€ù and the arrival of Mr. Cooganâ€™s fictional teenage son, Joe (Timothy Leach). Narratively, Joe seems to have been brought in to introduce a (modest) jolt of young male energy to the proceedings. Itâ€™s a jolt that by rights should complement a talk Mr. Brydon and Mr. Coogan have about how young women no longer look at them.

And so with Mr. Brydon and Mr. Coogan now playing tag-team critics, they tool around Italy in a Mini Cooper blasting Alanis Morissette in between sampling luscious meals and bedding down in heavenly hotels. This time their literary touchstones include Lord Byron, who moved to Italy in 1817 before setting off in 1823 to participate in the Greek fight for independence from the Ottoman Empire. Mr. Coogan and Mr. Brydon carve out a mini Romantic poets tour, visiting a home, a statue and a cemetery and, at one point, lingering on a beach with a reproduction of Louis Ã‰douard Fournierâ€™s 1889 painting â€œThe Funeral of Shelley,â€ù which shows Byron mourning his friend. The relationship between Mr. Coogan and Mr. Brydon is a bit less eternal.

Ah, to be famous or just funny enough for someone to pay for your freewheeling jaunt along the Amalfi Coast! You wouldnâ€™t always know it from his compendium of lip twitches and often comic and sour asides, but Steve Coogan is one lucky man, as is Rob Brydon, his returning partner in clowning and mileage. As in â€œThe Trip,â€ù their 2010 excursion into British cuisine, the two have teamed up for a journey, ostensibly so that now they can review six Italian restaurants for The Observer of London. In other words, this is â€œThe Tripâ€ù with pasta.

That conversation briefly points the movie toward rockier, more difficult terrain than Mr. Winterbottom or his co-conspirators choose to explore. Thatâ€™s too bad, although maybe not. Like its predecessor, â€œThe Trip to Italyâ€ù flirts with seriousness yet invariably, perhaps rightly, it always goes for the joke, the pun, the fun and the sun. (The food seems even more incidental here than it did in the first movie, although thereâ€™s plenty of epicurean oohing and ahing.) Time and again, these travelers dodge reality, including any mention of the cost of all those wines, meals and rooms, and whether the women who do look at them would do so if these funnymen werenâ€™t also famous. In the end, they turn a few of Lord Byronâ€™s words into something like an ethos: â€œAnd if I laugh at any mortal thing, â€™tis that I may not weep.â€ù

Last time around it was Mr. Coogan who had been tapped to review restaurants in northern England, a gig that resulted in many on-screen glasses of wine, fancy dishes and dueling impersonations with Mr. Brydon. To wit: One traveler executed a brilliant Michael Caine and the other raised the stakes with Sean Connery, and then they threw around allusions to Coleridge and Wordsworth amid one manâ€™s romantic tryst and some misbegotten sentimentalism. As in the earlier film, that chameleon Michael Winterbottom has assumed the off-screen role of director, a part he plays here with a light touch, technical competency and no particular point of view, auteurist or otherwise. Both trips originated as BBC television series that have been cut down for theatrical release.

As the film opens, Tom learns that his sonâ€™s death was a ritual sacrifice by a cult; heâ€™s told that a similar incident occurred in Providence, R.I. According to an investigating F.B.I. agent (James Naughton), the group has proved difficult for an undercover operative (Quincy Dunn-Baker) to infiltrate. The only question is whether the well-connected Tom, barely punished after attacking one of the cultâ€™s members in a courtroom, will act on his desire to â€œspeed up the processâ€ù of capital punishment.

â€œThe Wordâ€ù is never boring, though that has as much to do with the mounting absurdities and ripe acting as it does with the resourceful use of crosscutting by the director, Gregory W. Friedle. Movie-induced tears, though they may be involuntary, are not necessarily simple and are always worth subjecting to chemical analysis. â€œIf I Stay,â€ù based on a novel by Gayle Forman, hits the audience with a series of tragedies that ripple out from a single horrific event â€” a car accident on a snowy Oregon road â€” and it delivers each piece of bad news with carefully considered, maximally sadistic timing.

This summer has been bookended by two movies, both based on young adult best sellers and starring gifted and ambitious actresses, about smart, independent-minded teenage girls finding love in the shadow of death. It is hard to avoid comparing â€œIf I Stay,â€ù which opens on Friday, with â€œThe Fault in Our Stars,â€ù but there is also no reason to choose between them. Each one is a cleanly directed, credibly acted machine for the production of tears.

The second question has two answers, which are sometimes complementary, sometimes contradictory: Adam and the cello. Adam (Jamie Blackley), a year ahead of her in high school when they meet, is a rock â€™nâ€™ roll dreamboat, an archetypal bad boy who isnâ€™t really bad at all. He is smitten with Mia when he sees her playing in a school practice room, and her passionate devotion to the instrument awakens his interest. It also eventually threatens to pull them apart, as her ambition leads her to apply to Juilliard. Even though his band takes him out on the road for weeks at a time, he is committed to staying local and wants her to do the same.

The other actors struggle to stay on the quirky side of generic. (The only exception is Stacy Keach, gruff and restrained in a few scenes as Miaâ€™s grandfather.) Miaâ€™s parents, Denny (Joshua Leonard) and Kat (Mireille Enos), are a couple of punk rockers turned cool neo-traditionalists, and they speak to each other and to their kids (Mia has a younger brother, played by Jakob Davies) with a peppy sarcasm that seems to have been learned from sitcoms. The divide between their musical tastes and their daughterâ€™s is perhaps a little overstated (though it is more of an issue in Ms. Formanâ€™s book), but they are such friendly people that it seems impolite to complain about them.

This is morbid, but also effective. The narrator and protagonist is Mia (ChloÃ« Grace Moretz), who for much of the movie hovers in limbo between life and death, her spiritual self wandering barefoot and invisible through the halls of the hospital where her body lies in a coma. The conceit, put into words by a helpful nurse (Aisha Hinds) and implicit in the filmâ€™s title, is that it is up to Mia to decide whether to let herself die or keep on living. The long flashbacks that alternate with her bedside vigil can be seen as attempts to balance the ledger of her short time on earth. Has it been enough? What and whom would she leave behind? What would she have to live for?

The power of this question comes not only from the dreadful circumstances in which it is made, but also from its authenticity as an expression of adolescent feeling. The achievement of â€œIf I Stay,â€ù as of â€œThe Fault in Our Starsâ€ù and other books of the same type, is that it attaches life-or-death stakes to a basic modern identity crisis. Whom to love, where to go to school, how to be nice to your parents and also be free of them â€” these are the real, sometimes painful choices this movie is about, and the real, half-hidden sources of the tears it will inspire.

It may be that Ms. Moretz captures Miaâ€™s seriousness about her art â€” and her joy in it â€” so credibly because it reflects her own. At 17 and already a decade into her career, this remarkable actress is still exploring the far reaches of her range, and itâ€™s always exciting to watch her test herself. Playing a more or less ordinary teenager facing more or less typical pressures is not easy, and to the extent that â€œIf I Stayâ€ù is genuinely interesting as well as weep-worthy, it is largely because of her.

The grief and sorrow are punctuated, and to some extent made bearable, by jabs of warmth and humor arising from family affection and adolescent romance. The director, R. J. Cutler, whose previous work has mostly been in big- and small-screen documentaries, has a way of underplaying large feelings and amplifying subtle shifts of mood. The film, based on a well-shaped screenplay by Shauna Cross, moves in waves and surges of emotion. Everyday experiences of longing, regret, contentment and hope are given special melodramatic intensity because they are played out on the edge of the grave.
â€œIf I Stayâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Carefully rationed swear words, sexual situations and scenes of underage drinking.

The music is both the best and the corniest part of â€œIf I Stay,â€ù which makes excellent use of the classical cello repertoire, beyond just the Bach suite that has become one of the most overplayed pieces in modern cinema. Zoltan Kodalyâ€™s haunting and romantic Sonata in B minor is an important touchstone in Adam and Miaâ€™s relationship. Miaâ€™s Juilliard audition piece is Camille Saint-SaÃ«nsâ€™s dazzling Cello Concerto in A minor (with piano accompaniment), and she attacks it with a fervor that takes even her by surprise.

A major point made in â€œK2: Siren of the Himalayas,â€ù a documentary from the first-time feature director Dave Ohlson, is that one of the toughest parts of mountain climbing isnâ€™t reaching the summit but having the awareness to realize when you canâ€™t. â€œWe donâ€™t fake anything,â€ù a friendly director tells us in â€œKink,â€ù a fascinating profile of the online pornography provider Kink.com, the go-to destination for bondage and sadomasochism enthusiasts. Wonderful!â€ù) and the ominous (â€œWeâ€™re gonna need a longer pipeâ€ù), and interviews with employees are as likely to feature feminist views on pornography as to demonstrate the safest way to step on a penis.
