Only once did I experience a twinge of dread, as Mr. Acworthâ€™s tour is interrupted by unearthly noises somewhere behind him.
â€œI donâ€™t know if you want to investigate that?â€ù he offers, politely. Speaking for myself, Iâ€™m good.

Benâ€™s situation is more complicated and is really at the heart of this sensitive, acutely observed, resolutely nonmelodramatic film. Though he tries to be courteous and considerate, his presence starts to annoy Joey, who sleeps on the bunk below, and Kate, a novelist whose daily writing routine is disrupted by Benâ€™s chatty, needy presence.

This being New York, nobody has enough space for both of them. The one relative who might has a big house in Poughkeepsie, which is out of the question for these nondriving Manhattanites. Mr. Sachs may be fudging reality a bit to get his story moving, but it would be gauche to object too strenuously. And so Ben moves to the airy Brooklyn apartment where his nephew, Elliot (Darren Burrows), lives with his wife, Kate (Marisa Tomei), and their teenage son, Joey (Charlie Tahan). George accepts a spot on the living room couch of his former neighbors Ted (Cheyenne Jackson) and Roberto (Manny Perez), who are both New York City police officers.

One of the strengths of this wise and lovely film is that it declines fully to answer these and other questions. The story of George and Ben seems to have been plucked from a meadow of narrative possibilities; an interesting movie could have been made about everybody in this one. â€œLove Is Strangeâ€ù is Mr. Sachsâ€™s fifth feature as a director, and its title would suit almost all of them. The strangeness here may have less to do with the affection that binds the central couple than with the ties of kinship and friendship between them and the rest of the characters.

Mr. Sachs, who wrote the script with Mauricio Zacharias, casts an occasional discreet glance backward at the post-Stonewall history of gay men in New York, a complicated chronicle of tragedy, resilience, struggle and fun. But that history nonetheless feels implicit in every frame, infusing what might otherwise be a touching anecdote about real estate troubles and houseguest etiquette with gravity and grace.

But Mr. Sachs is an especially careful student of the odd rhythms and quiet intensities of couplehood, both gay and straight. (â€œMarried Life,â€ù his 2008 comedy noir, also has a title that could cover a lot of his oeuvre.) Mr. Lithgow and Mr. Molina, seasoned and subtle actors, beautifully capture the small pleasures and petty irritations Ben and George live through, and also their pride at having survived, together, for so long.

From the first moments we see them together â€” waking, washing and dressing in the Manhattan apartment they have shared for decades â€” it is clear that Ben (John Lithgow) and George (Alfred Molina) are a walking illustration of the phrase â€œold married couple.â€ù They know each other so well and have adapted, graciously and sometimes a little fractiously, to each otherâ€™s peculiarities. State law, at long last, has caught up with the reality of their relationship: The first scenes in Ira Sachsâ€™s â€œLove Is Strangeâ€ù take place on the morning of George and Benâ€™s marriage, which is solemnized in an alfresco ceremony followed by a relaxed and lively party at home.

But the coupleâ€™s bliss is disrupted by bigotry that is at once unexpected and sadly unsurprising. George loses his job teaching music at a Roman Catholic school because his marriage amounts to a public avowal of his sexuality and is thus a violation of the terms of his contract. The loss of his income â€” Ben is retired â€” means they can no longer afford their mortgage, and so must sell their co-op and rely on the hospitality of some of the people we know from the wedding, who are all eager to help.

Ben tries to mind his own business, but latent tensions and fissures in the household seem to pop into relief when he is around, and impertinent questions start to percolate in the viewerâ€™s mind. Whatâ€™s going on with Joey and his friend Vlad (Eric Tabach)? And for that matter, whatâ€™s going on with Kate and Elliot, whose interactions seem increasingly strained and chilly?
â€œLove Is Strangeâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Frank talk.

Various forms of awkwardness ensue. George, whose tastes run to Chopin and quiet evenings with a book, finds himself adrift in a household prone to impromptu parties and loud Dungeons & Dragons sessions. His hosts are unfailingly kind (and he appreciates being introduced to the pleasures of â€œGame of Thronesâ€ù), but also a bit clueless about the extent of his loneliness and his need for peace.

The impact of the final scenes â€” tears are highly probable â€” comes from the curious, cumulative sense of intimacy. By the time the movie is over, you feel as if the people in it were friends you know well enough to tire of, and to miss terribly when they go away.

May must also contend with her divorced mother (Hiam Abbass), a Christian apparently trying to curse the nuptials, and her father (Bill Pullman), an American now married to a somewhat younger Indian woman (Ritu Singh Pande), who struggles to ingratiate herself with the family.
The May of â€œMay in the Summerâ€ù is not the month but the main character (Cherien Dabis, who wrote and directed), a New York-based writer who returns to Amman, Jordan, to marry.

Alfred Hitchcock liked to distinguish between surprise and suspense, between the bombs that shock us (boom!) and those that put us on edge (tick, tick, tick). Like other pop culture figures, George Takei â€” a.k.a. Mr. Sulu on â€œStar Trekâ€ù â€” cultivated a loyal fan base and became politically engaged. Along the way, we learn about the importance of professional photographers in the segregated South and in Northern cities; about the semi-visibility of gay and transgender aunts, uncles and cousins in the collective black family album; and about the depth and variety of the African-American photographic tradition.

At times, Mr. Harrisâ€™s voice-over narration veers into academic abstraction or lyrical emotionalism in ways that undercut the eloquence of the images, but over all he is a wise and passionate guide to an inexhaustibly fascinating subject.

The contrast is jarring, to say the least. The familiar genres of domestic photography â€” graduation pictures, family reunion group shots, professional and amateur portraits of newlyweds and newborns â€” are juxtaposed with images that are horrific, demeaning and, sadly, just as familiar. Postcards depicting blacks as servile, lazy or criminal once circulated widely among white Americans, as did photographs taken of lynchings, not by outraged witnesses but by proud participants.

And Mr. Harris, an artist as well as a filmmaker, argues that the humanity, the full membership of African-Americans in the larger American family, is precisely what has been at stake in the work of black photographers. He tells their stories partly as a way of looking at history from a new angle and partly because their careers are fascinating and revealing in their own right.

The family album serves as both a resource and a metaphor. The film examines the photographic record black Americans have made of their own experiences and also the ways they have been depicted by the larger society.

To describe Thomas Allen Harrisâ€™s â€œThrough a Lens Darkly: Black Photographers and the Emergence of a Peopleâ€ù as a history of African-American photography would be accurate but incomplete. Inspired by the book â€œReflections in Blackâ€ù (2000), Deborah Willisâ€™s groundbreaking and thorough excavation of a vital and neglected photographic tradition, Mr. Harrisâ€™s film is a family memoir, a tribute to unsung artists and a lyrical, at times heartbroken, meditation on imagery and identity. The film is always absorbing to watch, but only once itâ€™s over do you begin to grasp the extent of its ambitions, and just how much it has done within a packed, compact hour and a half.

Mr. Harris begins on a personal note, with an anecdote about his father, depicted in old snapshots as a handsome man with a distinctly melancholy, distracted air. We never learn too much about him, but we do travel back through the generations, spending a fair amount of time looking at formal and candid photos, many of them taken by the filmmakerâ€™s maternal grandfather.

Such images can still cause pain, in no small part because the attitudes they reflect donâ€™t entirely belong to the past. â€œThrough a Lens Darklyâ€ù takes on a grim timeliness when you think about the role that photographs â€” shared and sometimes counterfeited on the Internet and social media â€” played in the aftermaths of Michael Brownâ€™s death in Ferguson, Mo., and Trayvon Martinâ€™s killing in Florida in 2012. It is still depressingly easy to find images that pathologize and dehumanize young black men.

A lot of knowledge about slavery, abolitionism, Jim Crow and the civil rights movement comes to us through pictures, but we donâ€™t always think about their sources and meanings. Mr. Harris marshals an impressive collection of scholars, artists and photojournalists to help us understand what we see in portraits of enslaved blacks and 19th-century antislavery crusaders like Frederick Douglass and Sojourner Truth, and to appreciate the vision of pioneering 20th-century photographers like James VanDerZee and Gordon Parks.

The title of â€œStarred Up,â€ù David Mackenzieâ€™s brutal and boisterous new prison drama, refers to the status of its main character, Eric. Though he is legally still under age, Eric, played with method actor inwardness and movie star magnetism by Jack Oâ€™Connell, has been promoted to adult status in the British penal system. Itâ€™s not hard to see why. Brawny and athletic, he looks less like a child than like a young bull, and his capacity for violence unnerves even some of the hardened older criminals in whose midst he finds himself.

â€œStarred Up,â€ù based partly on the screenwriter Jonathan Asserâ€™s experiences as a prison volunteer, puts the setting in front of the characters and the plot. Though it is, finally, an affecting story of two damaged men bound by blood and something like love (and also a thrillerish catalog of double crosses and shifting allegiances), it is, above all, a study in the patterns of chaos that govern penitentiary life.

Oliver, tough but compassionate, his idealism always on the brink of collapsing, represents another of the clichÃ©s that â€œStarred Upâ€ù flirts with and rejects. This could easily have been the story of a noble healer â€” a variation on the heroic big-city teachers so beloved at various points in Hollywood history â€” reaching out to a hard case. And, in retrospect, maybe it is that, but in the moment, the film is far too raw and scary to be reduced to such formulas.

Eric and Neville sometimes meet in group sessions organized by Oliver (Rupert Friend), a therapist whose attempts to help the inmates work out their issues with words rather than fists are looked on by the prison governors with condescending tolerance or contempt, depending on how many fights they have been called in to break up lately.

One of them is his father, Neville (Ben Mendelsohn), a powerful inmate with a network of prisoners and guards at his beck and call. Eric and Nevilleâ€™s relationship, full of rage, suspicion, shaky loyalty and blocked tenderness, is the dramatic heart of the movie, but Mr. Mackenzie (whose previous films include â€œHallam Foe,â€ù â€œYoung Adamâ€ù and â€œTonight Youâ€™re Mineâ€ù) is not one for sentimental tales of reconciliation.

The feeling induced in the audience is something close to panic, a perfectly appropriate response and exactly the one that Eric canâ€™t permit himself to show. Stripping down and soaping himself up for a battle in his cell that he knows he wonâ€™t win, he seems caught between pleasure and terror. He expects to be hurt and also to prove that he is someone not to be messed with. But at the same time, and throughout the film, you catch a flicker of sensitivity in his eyes and a hint behind his impassive features of the confused child he may still be.
Like that movie, this one turns the complicated dynamic between a young prisoner and his problematic mentor into a ferocious psychodrama that locks you in and refuses to let you go.

The usual language of realism doesnâ€™t quite apply to Mr. Mackenzieâ€™s methods, which aim for visceral, nerve-jangling authenticity. He and the cinematographer, Michael McDonough, let the camera run through the cellblock, a noisy, unbearably tense place where peace consists of the temporary absence of bloodshed.

Much of the credit for that goes to Mr. Oâ€™Connell and Mr. Mendelsohn, whose performances unfold in a counterpoint of brute force and deep craft. Mr. Mendelsohn, an Australian character actor with a long record of memorable performances (not always in memorable movies), plays Neville as a fox whose viciousness is masked by a calm, almost philosophical slyness. Mr. Oâ€™Connell, like Eric himself, seems blunt and guileless, turning his inchoate feelings into terrifying action.

â€œStarred Upâ€ù is not a film that uses prison to explore political or social problems, except insofar as incarceration is itself such a problem. It does not operate in the mode of â€œIn the Name of the Fatherâ€ù or â€œThe Green Mileâ€ù or even â€œOz,â€ù the American premium-cable penitentiary soap opera. It most resembles â€œA Prophet,â€ù Jacques Audiardâ€™s 2010 tour de force about power relations and male behavior in confinement.

The droning of insects is incessant, and every crack of a twig or screech of a monkey is cause for alarm. When he encounters another soldier, the initially tense confrontation gives way to a sense of relief: The fighter (Mo Tzu-yi) is Chinese. For the situation his character has fallen into, a serviceable Mr. Chittenden has a limited range of expressions. Mr. Mo, however, tends to be a bit more convincing. We first see the central character, an Australian fighter pilot (Khan Chittenden), dangling from a tree in the jungle. It is 1942, and the battle for Singapore has commenced. Now behind enemy lines, he must avoid detection by the Japanese troops who have come ashore. His provisions are meager (a compass, a map and a chocolate bar are deemed worthy of keeping), and the tropical surroundings imposing (tall grass, knee-deep mud and steam-room-level humidity).
â€œCanopyâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). War is brutal.

While not much is said in the Australian director Aaron Wilsonâ€™s small-scale first feature, â€œCanopy,â€ù the film conveys volumes about war and humanity. It is an immersive experience akin to J. C. Chandorâ€™s â€œAll Is Lostâ€ù and Alfonso CuarÃ_nâ€™s â€œGravity,â€ù though our hero is facing off against not only nature but also man.

With its swooping close-ups, Ennio Morricone-lite score and horseback riders heading into a sunset, â€œKundo: Age of the Rampantâ€ù could be a western. But itâ€™s a martial arts spectacle, set in 1859 and loaded with familiar elements, including a corrupt ruler, a motley bandit gang stealing from the rich to feed the poor, and, of course, a revenge story. For all its gloss, â€œKundoâ€ù fails to resonate. You appreciate the execution, but the film is hindered by its lack of novelty and metaphorical weight. â€œThe Notebookâ€ù is a skillfully made movie, with sequences that may haunt you after you leave the theater. But it lacks the power to turn its virtuosity, or the emotional discipline of its remarkable young leads, into a source of insight.

For every â€œPanâ€™s Labyrinth,â€ù which mines archetypes and fairy tales to unearth the hidden truth of Spanish fascism, there is â€œThe Boy in the Striped Pajamas,â€ù which turns the Holocaust into maudlin kiddie-kitsch.

Mr. Szasz uses ear-stabbing, slasher-film music and off-kilter camera angles to heighten the terror and disorientation, but the most unnerving effect in â€œThe Notebookâ€ù may be the twins themselves, played by actual siblings, Laszlo and Andras Gyemant. Aiming to capture a time when youâ€™re just envisioning a life, â€œGod Help the Girlâ€ù (which began as a 2009 album) has a childlike innocence that showcases Mr. Murdochâ€™s ethereal songs. Belle and Sebastian fans will be fully sated; everyone else might feel as if theyâ€™d consumed a meal consisting entirely of meringue.

Within its formulaic outlines, â€œKelly & Calâ€ù largely avoids seeming pat and contrived. It goes out of its way to flesh out subsidiary characters, like Calâ€™s caring mother (Margaret Colin), whom he disparages behind her back, and Kellyâ€™s strait-laced mother-in-law (Cybill Shepherd), who pressures her into a cosmetic makeover after she dies her hair blue. The film parallels Kellyâ€™s difficulty in bonding with her young son and Calâ€™s reflexive hostility toward his mother.

Politeness doesnâ€™t come naturally to her character, Kelly, a former punk rocker accustomed to expressing herself in blunt profanity. Kelly was once in an all-female punk band named Wetnap and has the audiocassettes to prove it. A fragment of the groupâ€™s best-known song, â€œMoist Towelette,â€ù is heard in the movie. If it doesnâ€™t sound flagrantly transgressive, you still get the idea.

Sexually frustrated, acutely aware of her age and nostalgic for the old days, if a little embarrassed by her past, Kelly finds an unexpected soul mate in Cal (Jonny Weston), a disabled 17-year-old who lives down the street. They first meet at her backyard fence, where he asks if he can bum a cigarette and compliments Kelly on her figure, using inappropriate language.
Most important, the performances of Ms. Lewis and Mr. Weston crackle with authenticity. Like a good punk-rock song, this bracingly honest, tough-minded vignette stays true to itself.

Where Kelly feels emotionally confined in her placid suburban environment, Cal is physically confined. He sustained a spinal injury from a fall he suffered while trying to impress his high school sweetheart in a dangerous stunt and now uses a wheelchair. Adding to the sting, the girl subsequently took up with his best friend.

Now a wife and mother who has recently settled with her husband, Josh (Josh Hopkins), in a quiet suburb where she doesnâ€™t know anyone, Kelly is having trouble bonding with her colicky 6-month-old son, Jackson. Her husband, once an aspiring artist with a rebellious streak, is now an advertising executive who toils long hours. Although their flaming passion has diminished to a flicker, he is a patient, devoted mate. At one point, Kelly is shown fondling herself while looking at a picture of George Clooney.

The distance between riot grrrl and suburban mom is quite a stretch. But as middle age approaches, time has a way of landing mouthy young rebels in roles they never expected to inhabit. Take Juliette Lewis, the personification of scary defiance alongside Woody Harrelson as her partner in crime in â€œNatural Born Killers.â€ù

But people grow up. In â€œKelly & Cal,â€ù Ms. Lewis, 41, conveys the excruciating discomfort of a slightly crumpled former upstart struggling to adapt to a staid, middle-class existence. That means reining in the anarchic impulses of her youth and tolerating polite, buttoned-up in-laws.

Instead of trying to elicit tears, â€œKelly & Calâ€ù is a small, sensitive portrait of two lonely people uncertainly exploring personal boundaries. Cal is not a noble sufferer, but an angry former daredevil fuming after an unfortunate mishap. He makes no secret of his attraction to Kelly, who doesnâ€™t respond until she lets herself go one evening when they play at being prom dates and break into an empty high school gym. As she sits on his lap, he wheels them around in a playful delirium that culminates with a spontaneous kiss.

A capsule summary of â€œKelly & Cal,â€ù the directorial feature debut of Jen McGowan, from a screenplay by Amy Lowe Starbin, might make it sound like a sentimental celebration of the healing power of friendship between alienated individuals facing uncertain futures. But this modest, finely acted movie avoids the usual detours that are the bane of films about disabled youth.

Instead, the film spends a lot of time on a history of the school, which was founded in 1868, and on the monksâ€™ version of what ails young people in poor neighborhoods, all of it obvious and familiar: broken homes, abuse, lack of role models, pressure to join gangs. The fragments of classroom work and extracurricular life that we do see look commendable enough, but the practicalities of translating the success of St. Benedictâ€™s to an entire city are left unexplored.

The school is run by the monks of Newark Abbey, and the filmâ€™s title, weâ€™re told, refers to principles enumerated in a 1,500-year-old monastic handbook. Itâ€™s hard to argue with those principles â€” â€œtrust,â€ù â€œleadership,â€ù â€œcommitmentâ€ù and so on â€” but â€œThe Rule,â€ù by the married filmmakers Marylou and Jerome Bongiorno, doesnâ€™t show us enough detail about how theyâ€™re applied to distinguish St. Benedictâ€™s from countless other parochial schools, private institutions and military academies.

â€œThe Rule,â€ù a film about St. Benedictâ€™s Preparatory School in Newark, opens with the implied promise that the methods used there can solve all of urban Americaâ€™s educational problems. Though it has interesting elements, it doesnâ€™t really deliver on that promise, leaving it feeling more like a promotional video than like a rigorous documentary.

A hard candy with a soft and sweet center, â€œWetlandsâ€ù can sometimes signal its themes too literally â€” in one scene, a fetishistic man dons a headlamp to shave Helenâ€™s privates â€” but its explicit imagery is never pornographic. The tone is breezy, bright and brash, vividly illuminated by Ms. Juriâ€™s extraordinarily unprotected and utterly fearless performance. With her dirty-blond curls and angelic smile, Helen is fully alive in a way thatâ€™s all too rare on our movie screens. Sheâ€™s not out to shock or sicken; thatâ€™s your problem, not hers.

The title of â€œWetlandsâ€ù strongly suggests a nature documentary, and thatâ€™s not so far off the mark. Doing â€” and smelling and tasting â€” what comes naturally is the singular obsession of the filmâ€™s rollicking heroine, Helen (Carla Juri, sensational), an 18-year-old student of vaginal flora and bodily fluids. Helenâ€™s cheerfully experimental sex life and rebellious attitude toward personal hygiene may shock her Catholic mother, but her unwavering affection for her body, in all its secreting glory, is nothing less than thrilling.

We meet her in a filthy public restroom, finger slathered in hemorrhoid cream and heading toward her itchy anus. Getting into the spirit, the camera follows that digit to its destination before diving toward a hair perched stickily on the toilet seat. Suddenly, the screen erupts into an animated purple-and-orange jungle of jiving germs, like an alien nightclub. (The marvelously vivacious cinematography is by Jakub Bejnarowicz.) This technique â€” disgust derailed by musical comedy â€” is repeated throughout the movieâ€™s memoirlike chain of exploratory vignettes, and itâ€™s one of the reasons that â€œWetlandsâ€ù is much less repellent to watch than to describe.

Adapting Charlotte Rocheâ€™s wildly popular and polarizing novel, Mr. Wnendt, who wrote the screenplay with Claus Falkenberg, locates the poignancy in Helenâ€™s provocations. Helen may be a walking middle finger to cultural norms of femininity, but sheâ€™s more than a political symbol. When an intimate shaving accident lands her in hospital with a painful anal fissure, her extreme attempts to reconcile her divorced parents (Meret Becker and Axel Milberg) reveal a touching vulnerability, as do flashbacks to her 8-year-old self. But Mr. Wnendt isnâ€™t interested in a narrative of blame and redemption; heâ€™s creating a space where Helen, whose enthusiastic voice-over guides us along, can define herself.

And even if some scenes are tailor-made for John Watersâ€™s scratch-and-sniff cards, the director, David Wnendt, has such an intuitive grasp of tone and commitment to his insouciant star that itâ€™s tough to take offense.

The Paris Peace Accords of 1973 had provisionally maintained the partition of Vietnam into North and South. As soon as the American forces were gone, the Communist North began to unify the country by force, sweeping quickly through Da Nang and other Southern cities and closing in on Saigon by April of 1975. For tangled reasons that Ms. Kennedy and her interview sources manage to clarify impressively, plans for evacuation were delayed until the 11th hour. Thousands of Vietnamese who had loyally served the American cause and the South Vietnamese government were in imminent danger, and â€œLast Days in Vietnamâ€ù is largely a chronicle of efforts to get them and their families out.

This almost delusional stubbornness â€” which Ms. Kennedyâ€™s interviewees still marvel at 40 years later â€” revealed another side as the Communist capture of Saigon (now Ho Chi Minh City) drew near. Defying prudent advice and at some risk to his own safety, Ambassador Martin delayed his own departure from the embassy for as long as he could, so that as many Vietnamese as possible could escape.

Pictures, moving and still, have always been part of the American collective memory of Vietnam. The fall of Saigon conjures up the image of a helicopter on a rooftop as desperate people try to climb aboard. One thing I learned from â€œLast Days in Vietnamâ€ù is that it was not the roof of the embassy, as is sometimes assumed, but of the building where the C.I.A. station chief lived, in another part of the city. What happened at the embassy â€” and in the waters off the coast of Saigon â€” was desperate and dramatic and much more complicated.

Perhaps the most striking thing about â€œLast Days in Vietnam,â€ù Rory Kennedyâ€™s eye-opening documentary about the 1975 evacuation of the American Embassy in Saigon, is how calmly it surveys what was once among the angriest topics in American political life. The story is full of emotion and danger, heroism and treachery, but it is told in a mood of rueful retrospect rather than simmering partisan rage. Ms. Kennedy, whose uncle John F. Kennedy expanded American involvement in Vietnam and whose father, Robert F. Kennedy,  became one of the ensuing warâ€™s most passionate critics, explores its final episode with an open mind and lively curiosity. There are old clips that have never been widely seen and pieces of information that may surprise many viewers.

The narrators are an assortment of American and Vietnamese men who witnessed the events firsthand, and whose accounts are deftly woven into a concise and gripping film. Some are well known, like Henry A. Kissinger, the secretary of state and national security adviser at the time, and Richard L. Armitage, who went on to serve in the State Department in the administration of George W. Bush. At the time, he was a naval officer, and he remains a natural-born storyteller with a gruff sense of humor and a vivid sense of detail. Hour-by-hour accounts of the airlifts that brought thousands of people from the embassy to American ships are provided by embassy guards, journalists and military personnel. We hear from residents of Saigon who made it out, and also from some who didnâ€™t.

Not that this is a story with a happy ending. What followed was brutality and repression on the part of the victors, and a refugee crisis among their victims. Now that so much time has passed, and relations between the United States and Vietnam have normalized, it might have been good to hear a voice or two from the other side, to learn what was going through the minds of the soldiers entering Saigon as the Americans left. But this omission does not diminish what Ms. Kennedy has accomplished, which is fairly and compassionately to reconstruct a messy episode in history.

The central figure in the drama is the American ambassador, Graham Martin, who died in 1990 and could not be interviewed for â€œLast Days in Vietnam.â€ù That is unfortunate, but the portrait that emerges from archival news footage and the memories of others is fascinating in its ambiguity. As the North Vietnamese armies routed the Southern forces, he refused to plan an exit strategy, believing in the face of overwhelming evidence that South Vietnam would survive.

That also sounds like a business philosophy that the old Hollywood chieftains could have gotten behind, and it may well be that Harvey Weinstein or a compatriot once said something like it when discussing the art and eroticism of movie marketing. Sheâ€™s lovelier now; a better actress, too. Green however has no use for the real woman. He wants to digitize Robin so he can exploit her avatar in perpetuity.

Ari Folmanâ€™s genre mash-up â€œThe Congressâ€ù could use a freakier title, something either more appealing or appalling to go with the weird, sometimes wonderful visions flowing through it. Not that itâ€™s all entirely strange. Thereâ€™s the opening image, for starters â€” a close-up of Robin Wrightâ€™s face, a familiar, delicate facade thatâ€™s well enough known to ignite a chain of signification: beauty, actress, star, Sean Penn, â€œHouse of Cards,â€ù â€œThe Princess Bride,â€ù middle age, under-sung, career rebirth.

It may seem vulgar to invoke Ms. Wrightâ€™s well-documented relationship with Mr. Penn, which was folded into high- and lowbrow tabloid narratives during their years together, becoming a crucial part of their public personas. Yet, in casting Ms. Wright to play a version of herself â€” a midcareer actress named Robin Wright who, once upon a Hollywood time, starred in â€œThe Princess Brideâ€ù â€” Mr. Folman is counting on our familiarity with star personas. Heâ€™s banking on our knowledge of celebrity dramas and divorces; with Ms. Wrightâ€™s adding and dropping Penn from her name; with her turns in movies like â€œForrest Gumpâ€ù and â€œNine Livesâ€ù; and how all of that blurs with the appealing, elusive fantasy woman sheâ€™s playing here.

Critics say you canâ€™t offend â€™em with your phallus or pudendum!â€ù

The dehumanization wrought by the movie business is one of the themes that Mr. Folman plays with, if not deeply. That said, by the time the live action gives way to eye-tickling animation â€” and a smiling octopus is sailing through the sky, and a Clive Owen look-alike named Dylan (voiced by Jon Hamm), is helping stir up kaleidoscopic chaos â€” you may not care that a Soviet-era political allegory doesnâ€™t fit all that well with a savaging of the movie business. The boy, Ryan, can sing and dance like nobodyâ€™s business, and as an adult, played by Blake Rayne, he bears a striking resemblance to Elvis Presley â€” or Drexel Hemsley, as the filmâ€™s Elvis-like stand-in is known. â€œThe Identicalâ€ù is thus the story of what might have happened if Mr. Presleyâ€™s real-life stillborn twin had survived and, not knowing his identity, parlayed his fandom into a career as an Elvis impersonator.

With one especially elegant shot of worshipers crisscrossing bridges, Mr. Nalin demonstrates his ability to conjure some of the essence of this spiritual journey. But the organic nature and hard-to-fathom scale of Kumbh Mela demand a more systematic strategy.

Described as lasting 55 days and drawing up to 100 million people last year, Kumbh Mela is awe-inspiring. The metropolis of temporary dwellings; the devotion to ritual, even at the risk of personal injury; and the groups of naked, white-powdered worshipers make for a spectacle.

But he lets the sprawl slacken his overlong filmâ€™s grasp and, strangely, underplays the nuances of the eventâ€™s spiritual aspects.

The filmâ€™s attention alights on two such lonely people, whose paths cross at the airport Hilton. Gary Newman (Josh Charles) is a Silicon Valley businessman, stopping overnight for a quick meeting en route to Dubai. Audrey Camuzet (AnaÃ¯s Demoustier) is a college student (or maybe a recent college dropout) who works cleaning rooms at the hotel. Neither is entirely alone in the world â€” she has a nagging father on the other end of the phone, he has a wife, children and co-workers tracking his movements â€” but each seems to float in a bubble of alienated solitude.

â€œBird Peopleâ€ù begins with a series of calm aerial views of human beings in transit: crossing the terminal concourse at Charles de Gaulle Airport, filing through the turnstiles at the nearby commuter rail station, dozing and daydreaming on the train. The images add up to an affecting composite picture of a familiar modern paradox. We never seem more alone, more adrift from one another, than when we are bustling along in impromptu crowds, migratory flocks of isolated souls.

Which is not to suggest that this film is a sentimental or softheaded fable. On the contrary, Ms. Ferran is attuned to the sorrow that Audrey and Gary carry with them, and also to the spiritual emptiness and the moral indifference of the world around them. (In one poignant sequence, Audrey discovers that the hotelâ€™s dapper and confident night receptionist, played by Roschdy Zem, has no home and sleeps in his car.) Viewed from a certain angle, â€œBird Peopleâ€ù is a very sad movie. But itâ€™s also a lark.

Garyâ€™s disaffection suddenly blooms into a crisis. He decides, impulsively but irrevocably, to walk away from his life â€” his job, his family, his responsibilities â€” and start something new. This does not go over well back home, and a series of heated phone calls and one very long, very painful video chat (between Gary and his wife, played by Radha Mitchell) suggest both the causes and the costs of his action. Ms. Ferran observes it all with tender objectivity, and Mr. Charles (known to fans of â€œThe Good Wifeâ€ù as Will Gardner) does not strain to make Gary either especially likable or overtly unsympathetic. Ms. Demoustier, for her part, hints at a complicated and volatile inner life behind Audreyâ€™s quiet, slightly mousy appearance.

It is not inaccurate to describe â€œBird Peopleâ€ù as the story of an encounter between a drifting young woman and a man facing the confusion of impending middle age â€” a variation on the themes of Sofia Coppolaâ€™s â€œLost in Translation,â€ù perhaps, though, of course, the premise could be exploited in tawdrier or more provocative ways. You may, based on this description â€” or during the first half of the movie â€” think that you know where this story is going. I guarantee that you are wrong.

Pascale Ferran, the director and co-writer (with Guillaume BrÃ©aud) of this entrancing and surprising film, starts out by following Audrey and Gary through cycles of boredom and distraction, with some attention to the small pleasures that help relieve the anomie. Gary soothes himself with cigarettes and minibar scotch. Audrey discreetly eavesdrops on hallway conversations and darts like a hermit crab from room to room, as if briefly occupying the lives of whoever was just there.

There are plot twists, and then there is what Ms. Ferran does here, which is to transform â€” impetuously, improbably and altogether marvelously â€” this somber, realistic tale into something else entirely. I donâ€™t want to say exactly what, and Iâ€™m not sure I can. But Ms. Ferran manages to find a strange and yet still completely persuasive point of contact between the literal and the magical, between the austere, responsible aesthetics of contemporary art cinema and a realm of imagination suggestive of fairy tales, Ovidâ€™s â€œMetamorphosesâ€ù and the fiction of Haruki Murakami.

Let me come down to earth before I fly into a spoiler. Ms. Ferran, whose â€œLady Chatterleyâ€ù (2007) turned an early version of D. H. Lawrenceâ€™s barnyard bodice-ripper into a sensuous, flower-bedecked pastoral, is an audacious and idiosyncratic filmmaker with the ability to find unexpected shades of emotion in characters and places. The environs of an international airport are, almost by design, drab and soulless, but in â€œBird People,â€ù the human presence and the persistence of nature (in the shape of errant sparrows and scraps of greenery) create the potential for beauty and meaning.

â€œThe Skeleton Twinsâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has some strong language, drug use and sexual situations.

Lance, an unflappably optimistic and confident outsider, is aware of Maggieâ€™s instability, which he takes in stride, cheerfully referring to her moods as â€œland minesâ€ù that he has no problem navigating. The point of no return in â€œStray Dogs,â€ù Tsai Ming-liangâ€™s glum, humorless exercise in Asian miserablism, is an 11-minute scene of a homeless man smothering and devouring a cabbage with a face painted on it.

The scene brings to mind the moment in â€œGone With the Windâ€ù when Scarlett Oâ€™Hara, half-starving, digs up a radish, bites into it, vomits and vows never to be hungry again. Beginning with the cabbage scene, the momentum grinds to a halt. There is nothing fancy here; no Skype group-sing of â€œWe Are the World.â€ù Itâ€™s just youngsters talking about their lives and aspirations, with Ms. Bailey providing an unobtrusive framework by creating subject groupings: home, school, war. The project could easily have seemed like a smarmy Nickelodeon special or some variant of â€œKids Say the Darndest Things,â€ù but Ms. Baileyâ€™s willingness to let the children talk and to let the viewer impose broader meaning elevates it.

As for the future, some have concrete ideas involving marriage and children, and others have visions that are a bit more off the wall. â€œMaybe in the year 2222, there are flying cars or dogs who eat screws and batteries,â€ù a German girl named Luca says, â€œand aliens have captured the world.â€ù

Why 11? The age was chosen because it is a transition point between childhood and a more grown-up world, and Ms. Bailey captures this beautifully. The children are diverse, racially and economically, but theyâ€™re also diverse in terms of where they are in that transition. Some talk about subjects like geopolitics and solar power with a surprising maturity â€” or maybe just a knack for repeating what a parent has told them â€” but others are preoccupied with wedgies or a pet.

Sometimes the simplest of ideas can prove surprisingly engaging, and not so simple after all. A case in point is â€œI Am Eleven,â€ù a charming documentary by Genevieve Bailey built of interviews with 11-year-olds in 15 countries.

Those conversations have a nice crackle to them, as do the scenes with Ms. Chastain and Ms. Huppert, Ms. Chastain and Mr. Hurt â€” Ms. Chastain and everyone else in the movie, come to think of it, including Mr. McAvoy. She is an actress who short-circuits conventional distinctions between tough and vulnerable, showing exquisite control even when her character is losing it, and keeping her balance even when the movie pitches and rolls toward melodrama.

The death of a child, as an ingredient in a fictional narrative, should be kept on a very high shelf, to be used with the utmost caution. Too often, this species of tragedy â€” for some of us, the single most terrible thing we can contemplate â€” is used as a shortcut, a foolproof means of raising the emotional stakes in a domestic drama. Of the countless novels and movies that take up this grim theme, few find the right blend of tact, horror and honesty. â€œEleanor Rigbyâ€ù is not one of them.

Nearly everything on screen takes place after that event, but an earlier calamity casts a heavy shadow, as does the happiness that preceded it. A few flashbacks show Eleanor and Conor (Mr. McAvoy) in the bliss of new love, and the main question Mr. Benson explores is where that love went. The answer is at once too precise and overly vague, which leaves â€œThe Disappearance of Eleanor Rigbyâ€ù in an odd kind of limbo. As a whole, it doesnâ€™t quite work, but the parts â€” particular moments, observations and insights about the way people behave and perceive themselves â€” are frequently excellent. So is the shallow-focus cinematography, by Chris Blauvelt, and the evocation of Manhattan at night.

This is not a movie about the sufferings of young parents but rather about the uncertainties of adult children and about how their elders both help and hinder their progress toward maturity. In addition to her parents, Eleanor finds a mentor in Lillian Friedman (Viola Davis), a professor whose blunt cynicism masks (what else?) abundant warmth and wisdom. They eat hamburgers together and drink espresso, as Eleanor takes tiny steps toward recovering her self-confidence and figuring out what to do with the rest of her life.

In due course, we learn that Eleanor and Conor had a baby boy who died, and that everything happening to them now is part of a nightmare of shock and grief from which they struggle to awaken. As that story, â€œEleanor Rigbyâ€ù is not especially credible. It posits cause and effect â€” dead baby, broken relationship, suicide attempt â€” without establishing the logical and psychological connections among them. It treats Eleanor and Conorâ€™s loss not as a terrible fact but as an excuse for whatever they might be doing or feeling at any given moment.
â€œThe Disappearance of Eleanor Rigbyâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Smoking, swearing, crying, sex.

The film is an expansive, roaming, sometimes unwieldy excursion across a landscape mined with sorrow, secrets and unresolved questions of identity, a study of friendship and intergenerational miscommunication as well as romantic failure.

One mystery is cleared up before too long. Eleanor Rigby is the name of Ms. Chastainâ€™s character, whose father (William Hurt) was a longtime Beatles fan with a convenient surname. He and her mother (Isabelle Huppert, brilliantly cast, and not because her red hair and fine features match Ms. Chastainâ€™s) live in a handsome Colonial in Westport, Conn., where Eleanor ends up after a suicide attempt.

As Eleanor settles in, a bit awkwardly, with Mom and Dad and her single-mom sister (Jess Weixler), Conor is also thrown back into the parental nest, taking the guest room in the home of his father, a leathery, much-divorced restaurateur played with old-school suavity by Ciaran Hinds. There is an Oedipal dimension to their relationship, since Conor is trying (and failing) to make it in his fatherâ€™s business, managing a wine bar where his best friend (Bill Hader) is the talented but undisciplined chef and where the bartender (Nina Arianda) is a sympathetic presence.

â€œThe Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby,â€ù written and directed by Ned Benson, is a strikingly ambitious debut feature. Shot in and around New York, it sets out to chronicle the end of a marriage in all its emotional complexity.

But the movie that opens on Friday is only part of the story. In a few weeks, the Weinstein Company will release another version â€” really two other versions â€” subtitled â€œHim/Her,â€ù which splits the perspectives of the central couple, played by Jessica Chastain and James McAvoy. The conventions of reviewing dictate that â€œHim/ Herâ€ù will be taken up here when it arrives in theaters, when audiences can make comparisons and assess the project as a whole. But in the meantime, there is quite a lot to see and to ponder in this rendering, which was first shown at Cannes in May with the subtitle â€œThem.â€ù

The strange and almost wonderful thing about â€œThe Disappearance of Eleanor Rigbyâ€ù is that it is possible for a viewer to do what these bereaved parents cannot, which is to forget about their specific loss and focus on the details of their efforts to negotiate the confusion of young post-couplehood. That movie turns out to be interesting, affecting and impressively astute.

The filmâ€™s battered, blue-collar, white ethnic Brooklyn, where every hubcap and kitchen table has been selected for maximum down-market authenticity, turns out to be a remarkably cosmopolitan place. In addition to Mr. Hardy, who is British, the cast includes actors from Sweden, Australia and Belgium (which is also the directorâ€™s homeland), as well as more locally sourced talent. As a character in a hard-boiled piece of genre fiction, Bob (Tom Hardy) himself is a familiar type: a quiet man with a murky past and a latent capacity for violence behind his gentle demeanor. The other people he encounters are also recognizable, mostly from crime novels and similar movies. Bob Saginowski, the hero and sometime voice-over narrator of â€œThe Drop,â€ù is a Brooklyn bartender. Not the currently fashionable kind â€” a liberal arts graduate with an armful of tattoos and a carefully cultivated beard who plies artisanal bitters and obscure craft beers â€” but a more traditional variety. He pours shots and brews to working stiffs in Giants jackets at a roughed-up establishment in a hipster-free, ungentrified and somewhat mythical stretch of the borough.

This might be the time to note that â€œThe Dropâ€ù was written by Dennis Lehane, who adapted it from his short story â€œAnimal Rescue.â€ù While this movie, directed by Michael R. Roskam (â€œBullheadâ€ù), doesnâ€™t have the grandeur of â€œMystic River,â€ù the emotional sting of â€œGone Baby Goneâ€ù or the nutty audacity of â€œShutter Islandâ€ù (or any Massachusetts accents), it nonetheless demonstrates some solid Lehanean virtues. The material may be warmed over, but the writing is meaty and pulpy enough to sustain a handful of satisfying performances.

The daw-ug in question is a sweet little pit bull that Bob finds, scared and bloody, in a garbage can belonging to Nadia (Noomi Rapace). She is the ex-girlfriend of the dogâ€™s apparent owner, a scary nut named Eric (Matthias Schoenaerts), who boasts of having killed someone 10 years earlier. The dead man was last seen at the bar where Bob works under the weary eye of his Cousin Marv (James Gandolfini), who used to own the joint but now runs it for a family of Chechen mobsters (led by Michael Aronov). They sometimes use it as a place to park their dirty money, which is why the movie is called â€œThe Drop.â€ù

Mr. Roskamâ€™s direction is gratifyingly loose. He lets the story, which is really the least interesting part of the movie, more or less take care of itself, allowing us to savor pungent morsels of dialogue and bits of low-key actorly showboating. The counterpoint between Mr. Hardy, compact and intense, and Mr. Gandolfini, expansive and subtle, is engaging (though also sad, of course), and so is the cop-show banter whenever Mr. Ortiz arrives on screen.
â€œThe Dropâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Blood and bad language.
There is nothing especially believable about â€œThe Drop,â€ù but it is credible enough to be moderately entertaining, and vice versa.

A late-night robbery at Marvâ€™s place sets in motion the kind of plot in which odd coincidences and apparently random events coalesce into a slightly too tidy package. (John Ortiz is the detective whose relentless questions serve as explanations for the audience.) If â€œThe Green Princeâ€ù sustains the tension of a well-executed thriller, it is achieved at the cost of a dispassionate objectivity. The emotional core of â€œThe Green Prince,â€ù Nadav Schirmanâ€™s gripping documentary thriller, is the deepening relationship of Mosab Hassan Yousef, a Palestinian recruited as a spy by the Shin Bet, Israelâ€™s internal security agency, and his Israeli handler. Mr. Yousef, whose memoir, â€œSon of Hamas,â€ù inspired the film, wasnâ€™t a Palestinian fighter infused with jihadist fervor. But because his father, Hassan Yousef, was a founder of Hamas, he was a prize catch for the Israeli agency, which manipulated him with diabolical efficiency to glean vital intelligence. In turn, he was protected from exposure.

The film is fleshed out with repetitious stock footage of bombing targets observed from the air, and such wasted time would have been better spent filling out the history. For all his intensity, Mr. Yousef never really tries to explain why he acted as he did. Perhaps there is no explanation beyond his revulsion at the carnage of war.

Mr. ben Yitzhak is a likable man whose deepening affection for Mr. Yousef during their decade-long partnership led him to break the rules of a game as complex and duplicitous as the plot of a John le CarrÃ© novel. The word â€œgameâ€ù is not chosen lightly. As Mr. ben Yitzhak describes the manipulation of Mr. Yousef, you have the disconcerting sense of monitoring a chess match in which strategical maneuvering and intellectual gamesmanship take precedence over the human cost.

In one of many re-enactments, Mr. Yousef is first seen wearing a hood, while tied to a chair in a dimly lighted interrogation room. He is a fervently intense young man who, like Mr. ben Yitzhak, speaks perfect English. His reminiscences return repeatedly to the concept of shame. His acute sense of it began when he was raped as a young boy, an assault that he says he dared not tell anyone about because of the stigma attached. By the end of the film, this sense of shame has widened to include his betrayal of his family and the Palestinian cause and has become a defining theme of his life. Mr. Yousef, who eventually rejected Islam, now lives in the United States.

His wooing by the Shin Bet began after his arrest and incarceration in the mid-â€™90s for buying and transporting weapons. Repulsed by Hamasâ€™s killings, he was a relatively easy recruit to the other side. As his fatherâ€™s â€œgatekeeper,â€ù he provided vital information to Israel on Hamasâ€™s activities and plans.

Mr. Yousefâ€™s antipathy for Hamas further solidified after a series of suicide bombings in 2001, whose devastating consequences are seen in vintage news footage. His intelligence work involved elaborate, deceptive charades that included his serving grueling stints in Israeli prisons, to counter any suspicions of his betrayal.

The film alternates the recollections of Mr. Yousef, code-named Green Prince, and his Israeli handler, Gonen ben Yitzhak, in a he-said, he-said format. In this case, the two stories augment, rather than contradict, each other.

With less than 24 hoursâ€™ notice, Screen Gems announced that it would cancel Wednesdayâ€™s press screenings for â€œNo Good Deed.â€ù Officially, this unusual step was intended to help the studio protect a plot twist. This twist, it turns out, hardly warrants any fuss or curiosity.

Sooner or later, he might have added, a writer must also confront the uncomfortable reality that everything he puts down on paper comes out of his own head and no one elseâ€™s. Despite snatches of songs here and there, it is not until the end that the film bursts into a flood of music with a symphonic performance by Mr. Cave and the Bad Seeds at the Sydney Opera House: a grandiloquent finale in which his agonized introspection finds transcendent release.

He visits his archive and sorts through memorabilia and drops in on Warren Ellis, a songwriting collaborator and band mate. The pervasive mood is a brooding hyperawareness of time and the brevity of existence. Sensationalism and salaciousness are minimal. Mr. Caveâ€™s onetime heroin addiction is mentioned but only in the context of Christianity, with which Mr. Cave, when asked about religion, says he flirted with during that period. Mr. Cave, who will turn 57 on Monday, was born in Australia and now lives in Brighton, England, where the turbulent weather reflects his churning, gothic musical melancholy. The film opens with a spectacular three-minute montage in which streams of images from his life are clocked as a counter speeds to the number 20,000, after which Mr. Cave is shown waking up in the morning on that magic day.

He drives around Brighton in a car, in which various collaborators and friends materialize. One is the actor Ray Winstone from the 2005 film â€œThe Proposition,â€ù whose screenplay Mr. Cave wrote. Others include Blixa Bargeld, a former guitarist with his band the Bad Seeds, and the Australian pop star Kylie Minogue, with whom he had his only major hit, â€œWhere the Wild Roses Grow,â€ù from his â€œMurder Balladsâ€ù album in the mid-â€™90s.

So observes the dour songwriter Nick Cave during an interview with the noted British psychoanalyst Darian Leader, in â€œ20,000 Days on Earth.â€ù The film, a fusion of documentary and drama directed by Iain Forsyth and Jane Pollard, is a fictional re-creation of the 20,000th day of Mr. Caveâ€™s life, when he started recording his 2013 album, â€œPush the Sky Away.â€ù It is as intimate and honest a portrait of a rock artistâ€™s creative roots as any film has attempted.

What Mr. Cave fears most, he muses to the doctor, is losing his memory. He knows that for any writer, memory is the source of creativity and the seat of identity. His narrative songs, he says, constitute a whole world created out of â€œthose original precious memories that define our lives: memories that we spend forever chasing after.â€ù

Mr. Cave is matter of fact about the ruthlessness of the creative process, confessing to â€œcannibalizingâ€ù his marriage to Susie Bick, the British model he wed in 1999, and to â€œtormentingâ€ù her. (Ms. Bick is barely glimpsed during the film.) In the movieâ€™s most emotionally extravagant outburst, he rhapsodizes about their first meeting while we see a montage of legendary beauties. No other major relationships are mentioned.
â€œMemory is what we are. Your very soul and your very reason to be alive are tied up in memory.â€ù

As one of the sharper young horror directors working today, Adam Wingard likes to take familiar genre setups â€” the serial killer or the home invasion â€” and warp them just enough to pique our interest. Together with the writer Simon Barrett, whose canny scripts flip and swerve at unexpected moments, Mr. Wingard is building a rÃ©sumÃ© that pays at least as much attention to character and story as it does to scares and body count.

The teamâ€™s latest collaboration, â€œThe Guest,â€ù opens on a shot of a man (a terrific Dan Stevens) running away from us. â€œThe Guestâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires an accompanying parent or adult guardian). Guns, drugs and devilish grins.

The marriage becomes the most fully realized strand of â€œA Life in Dirty Movies,â€ù and it is illustrated by quotidian glimpses of the coupleâ€™s routines and stories of their courtship. Their enduring love turns out to be the core of this documentary about a typically quick-and-dirty genre.

In Joe Sarnoâ€™s sexploitation movies, with titles like â€œSin in the Suburbs,â€ù sex is only one part of the picture. Mr. Sarno, a classic example of an auteur laboring in the shadows, used his genre to delve into thornier truths and anxieties about desire. Nasty, brutal and unforgiving, â€œA Walk Among the Tombstonesâ€ù is one of those rare contemporary cinematic offerings: intelligent pulp. It was written and directed by Scott Frank, a script writer whose credits include â€œGet Shortyâ€ù and â€œMinority Report,â€ù which means that heâ€™s spent time transposing the likes of Elmore Leonard and Philip K. Dick to the screen. Mr. Frank is working with uglier, less pleasurable material here: a 1992 novel by Lawrence Block featuring his continuing character Matthew Scudder. Itâ€™s a story of good and evil in which men are as tough as nails and women little more than meat. The nail image is a metaphor; the meat less so.
â€œA Walk Among the Tombstonesâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence.

Mr. Frank, to be clear, doesnâ€™t play their meeting or much of anything else for laughs. True to its title, â€œTombstonesâ€ù is grim and foreboding; somewhat unusually for this type of genre movie, itâ€™s also fairly quiet. It opens with a bang, several actually, during a 1991 bar robbery that interrupts what looks like Scudderâ€™s usual pick-me-up: two boozy shots to go with his coffee. Scudder, his hair darkened and wearing a messy goatee, shoots two robbers and chases a third, all but dancing down some stairs before shooting the runner dead. The full impact of this violent scene emerges only later, but the nihilism of Scudderâ€™s jig immediately sets the mood and defines the man.

However attractively shot, with its moody palette and scrupulous framing, â€œA Walk Among the Tombstonesâ€ù can be tough to watch, particularly in its fleeting images of tortured women. Mr. Frank doesnâ€™t shy away from the storyâ€™s horrors, and you may never want to visit a butcher shop again. Yet the only throat he shows being cut belongs to a man. Women die, but without becoming cinematic spectacles, a relief given how often their dead bodies are used as ornaments elsewhere. That decision distinguishes this movie from the usual genre fodder and dovetails with what emerges as its almost obsessive interest in the devastations of male misogyny and violence. This is a manâ€™s world, Mr. Frank makes clear, from bloody start to finish.

An eerie quiet settles over the movie thereafter, as the story shifts to 1999 and a cleaned-up, clean-shaven Scudder. Mr. Frank throws in too many distracting references to the perceived threat of the looming Y2K, yet the shrieking headlines do suggest a climate of fear and the specter of another, graver threat to come. Unsurprisingly for a screenwriter, Mr. Frank gives the characters lots to talk about, both on and studiously off point. He also streamlines the bookâ€™s story and jettisons some characters, including Scudderâ€™s prostitute girlfriend, whom he blithely refers to as a whore. At first, it seems too bad that Mr. Frank kept TJ (a fine Brian Bradley, known as Astro), a teenager with a taste for detective fiction whom Scudder befriends while researching Kristoâ€™s case.

Early on, TJ seems like one of those familiar audience surrogates whoâ€™s supposed to help younger viewers relate. He also comes off as too cute for the pervading bleakness, and his genre-conscious name-dropping of Philip Marlowe and Sam Spade registers as a self-amused authorial flourish. Narratively, though, TJ is redeemed by becoming the receiver of terrible knowledge passed to him by Scudder. An amateur comic-book artist, TJ has a default mode that is jocular and deflecting. Heâ€™s street tough, if only on the surface, and Scudderâ€™s world is an excuse for him to play good guys and bad. (After TJ steals a gun, Scudder tells him to shoot himself.) As the story unfolds, the last vestiges of innocence fall away.

Mark A. Landis, the cadaverous, soft-spoken art forger profiled in the documentary â€œArt and Craft,â€ù is not a fictional character, except perhaps in his own mind. In 30 years of deception, he has donated at least 100 pieces â€” many of them doctored photocopies of small works â€” to at least 46 museums in 20 states.

â€œI didnâ€™t do anything wrong or illegal,â€ù he says of his â€œphilanthropy,â€ù which, to the embarrassment of museum personnel, has landed multiple copies of the same work in several institutions. When confronted, Mr. Landis replies mischievously, â€œWhere would the church be if St. Peter hadnâ€™t lied?â€ù Since Mr. Landis didnâ€™t commit legal fraud by earning money from his forgeries, he was able to get away with his charades for many years.

But what a fascinating character Mr. Landis, 59, turns out to be. In one of his several guises, inspired by the G. K. Chesterton character Father Brown, he dressed as a priest to visit art museums under the pseudonym Father Arthur Scott.

It was an article in The New York Times about him in January 2011 that attracted the attention of the filmâ€™s directors, Sam Cullman and Jennifer Grausman. (Mark Becker is credited as co-director and editor.)

His soft voice, with its Southern inflection, evokes Truman Capoteâ€™s. His unfailing politeness and obsession with his mother bring to mind Anthony Perkins as Norman Bates, and Mr. Landis has received a diagnosis of schizophrenia. His hushed delivery and creepy stillness at times also recall Peter Lorre. If a feature film were made of his life, the ideal actor to play him might be Zeljko Ivanek, that master of sinister furtiveness.

Mr. Landis, who lives in Laurel, Miss., and has operated under several pseudonyms, is the enigmatic core of a movie that becomes pedestrian only when the focus switches to a one-man crusade to expose him. Matthew Leininger, a blustery former registrar at the Oklahoma City Museum of Art, is the self-appointed prosecutor of Mr. Landis. But the movie fails to give dramatic heft to their cat-and-mouse game, which seems to end when a museum in Cincinnati mounts an exhibition of Mr. Landisâ€™s fakes, and both attend.

The film shows him creating several of these pieces, which seem authentic if you donâ€™t look too closely and notice that the paintings are copies augmented with pigment and placed in carefully distressed frames, many purchased at Walmart. There is no question that Mr. Landis is an excellent draftsman schooled in the intricate rituals of the art world. Some of the works are donated in memory of a sister who never existed.

â€œArt and Craftâ€ù adds fuel to the argument that the art market is a rigged game manipulated by curators and gallerists spouting mumbo-jumbo. Whom can you trust in a world where Norman Rockwell, dismissed for years as a mere â€œillustrator,â€ù ascends to the pantheon of American greats? Whatâ€™s the difference between a Warhol silk-screen and a Landis copy? Itâ€™s not out of the realm of possibility that forgeries could one day become the next big thing in art.

A sinister, hollow-cheeked American art dealer (Norman Newkirk), who later says he is a Croatian immigrant (thank you for being specific, sir), befriends them with criminal intentions, leading to life-or-death fight scenes with armed men. Another lucky break is that all the Americans have apparently taken kickboxing lessons, so these are balanced fights.
Directed by Livi Zheng
1 hour 28 minutes; not rated

Although the characters repeatedly express their worship of â€œoriginal artâ€ù in gilded frames, the script consists of singularly unoriginal dialogue. But it does succeed in being colloquial. â€œLet it go, Ken,â€ù Alice urges when she is truly just off the boat.

We do know that they arrived in Seattle with a group inside a shipping container, the kind that might normally hold furniture purchased abroad; that they have no money; that Alice is an artist whose paintings no one at the street market wants to buy; that Americans are more impressed by Kenâ€™s kickboxing moves; and that both of them really want strawberry pancakes.

One of the many strange things about this genre-confused film is that Alice and Ken, who are fictional siblings portrayed by real ones, never say where theyâ€™re from. The opening images of â€œThe Zero Theoremâ€ù could hardly be more arresting: a man, naked and hairless, sits in front of an oversize computer screen in surroundings that are at once archaic and futuristic. The technology is advanced, while the dÃ©cor hovers somewhere between late Victorian and mid-20th-century modern. The manâ€™s name, which people often forget or get wrong, is Qohen Leth. He lives in an abandoned church and commutes on foot through chaotic city streets to a soul-crushing job doing something with data for a corporation owned by an elusive Big Brother-like figure known only as Management.

Management eventually shows up in the person of Matt Damon. Qohen is played by Christoph Waltz as a fast-talking, perpetually anxious holy fool who refers to himself in the first person plural. Other significant characters include Managementâ€™s teenage son, Bob (Lucas Hedges); Bainsley (MÃ©lanie Thierry), a young woman who awakens Qohenâ€™s long-dormant romantic and sexual interests; and Joby (David Thewlis), Qohenâ€™s cheerful and obnoxious supervisor at work. Qohenâ€™s therapist is a bit of software that turns into Tilda Swinton on his computer screen. All of them and the funky dystopia they inhabit spring from the fertile, undisciplined imagination of Terry Gilliam.

Management enlists Qohen in the top-secret, super-important project of proving the hypothesis that gives the film its title. The theory, in a nutshell, is that â€œeverything adds up to nothing,â€ù and poor Qohen chases mathematical confirmation through an endless, Lego-like virtual landscape. He takes a break for cyber-canoodling with Bainsley, a thinly imagined erotic fantasy who nonetheless restores some of his humanity. But even as Mr. Gilliam assails the tedium and pointlessness of Qohenâ€™s existence, â€œThe Zero Theoremâ€ù succumbs to those forces, spinning its wheels and repeating its jokes in a manic frenzy that is never as funny or as mind-blowing as it wants to be.
â€œThe Zero Theoremâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Language and nudity.

Admirers of that movie will find echoes of its themes and traces of its look here, but they will miss its intellectual vigor and narrative momentum. The ideas that animate â€œThe Zero Theoremâ€ù â€” about the erosion of individuality in a technocratic, corporate-dominated society and about the collapsing boundary between work and leisure â€” are certainly no less relevant now than they were in the 1980s. They just donâ€™t feel very fresh or fully integrated into a coherent speculative world.

That fact makes â€œThe Zero Theorem,â€ù written by Pat Rushin, a lively viewing experience, thanks to Mr. Gilliamâ€™s perpetual-motion shooting style and his witty, allusive visual vocabulary. Every frame is dense with information, some of it in the service of the filmâ€™s allegorical intention, some of it there for fun. Mr. Gilliam has been, since his days as an animator for â€œMonty Pythonâ€™s Flying Circus,â€ù a tirelessly inventive filmmaker. He has also occasionally ascended to the level of visionary, in particular with the prescient, still-potent science-fiction satire â€œBrazil.â€ù

With her woman warrior, the writer and director Claudia Myers has landed on a good, urgent, relevant theme. She augments it with some nice details (Maggie proves somewhat of a gear head) and a few scenes that express the existential reality of the soldier-mother (to get to work on time, Maggie takes Paul to day care before sunup). But Ms. Myers too often tells rather than shows, and she doesnâ€™t have the cinematic skill set to transform her idea into a fully satisfying movie, especially at this low-budget level. The cinematography is dreary-looking; the blocking often awkward and unimaginative. The performances are hit and miss, though now and again the secondary actors, notably Mr. Livingston, pull their weight so that Ms. Monaghan doesnâ€™t have to shoulder it alone.

A story about finding peace during wartime, â€œFort Blissâ€ù turns on the struggles of an Army medic, Maggie Swann (Michelle Monaghan), whoâ€™s trying to make it back to normal after a tour in Afghanistan. You first meet her while sheâ€™s dodging battlefield bullets. Soon sheâ€™s slicked in someone elseâ€™s blood, and on her way to a commendation. A few beats later, though, Maggie has moved onto the El Paso base that gives the movie its name and is trying to reconnect with her confused, alienated 5-year-old, Paul (Oakes Fegley), after a lengthy separation.

In â€œFort Bliss,â€ù Ms. Monaghan delivers a fine performance and ends up serving as somewhat of a guideline as she helps you through the movieâ€™s shakier passages. Importantly, she gets you over the hump of its opener, an awkwardly staged and shot action scene that almost loses you before youâ€™ve had a chance to settle into the story. Things â€” and the filmmaking â€” improve once sheâ€™s in Texas, where she eases into a new job training medics and bristles at the constraints of the home front, where Paulâ€™s anger is matched by the demands of her ex, Richard (Ron Livingston, convincing in whiny â€œwifeâ€ù mode). She also starts seeing a mechanic, Luis (Manolo Cardona), one of those dirty-T-shirt romantic foils who noses the story toward Harlequin territory.

Itâ€™s rough, not only because Maggie is good at her job but also because sheâ€™s good in a fight. War becomes her, and while the filmmaking doesnâ€™t always make a convincing case for this character, Ms. Monaghan keeps you in her corner. One of those performers youâ€™re always happy to see, she radiates intelligence, no matter how silly or slight the role: You see the thoughtfulness in her eyes, the mischief, too. In the old Hollywood, she would have stayed busy playing fatal beauties, seductive debutantes, hungry heiresses; Preston Sturges would have known what to do with her. Even with slimmer pickings, she makes an impression, whether popping up in titles like â€œSource Codeâ€ù or helping make a character like Woody Harrelsonâ€™s wife in â€œTrue Detectiveâ€ù seem a little less like an afterthought.

Mr. Tropperâ€™s novel, while it often works too hard (for my taste, anyway) to find a tone of rueful wackiness, at least does the work of constructing a credible family milieu. This is a matter of timing, structure and psychological insight, all of which seem to have vanished on the way to the screen. One of the themes of â€œThis Is Where I Leave Youâ€ù (both book and film) is that the older generation â€” the late Mr. Altman and his wife â€” had life figured out in a way that their children, flailing around in unhappy approximations of adulthood, can never quite match. Itâ€™s an interesting, potentially provocative idea, but one that this film illustrates in the most self-defeating way imaginable, by reminding you of older, better movies.

Ms. Hahn, one of the funniest people in movies today, fares much worse, since sexual humiliation is all the movie has in mind for Annie. Ms. Britton (as Phillipâ€™s older lover) and Ms. Byrne (as Juddâ€™s potential romantic rebound) do what they can to find a note or two of authenticity. Ms. Fonda seems to float through the proceedings as if on her way to a more elegant and sophisticated event somewhere far away.

They were teenage sweethearts until an accident left Horry with a brain injury and Wendy with a permanent burden of guilt and yearning. But their story, like everyone elseâ€™s, is shoehorned into a few lumpy, on-the-nose scenes that explain more than they express. The same happens with the struggle of Juddâ€™s brother Paul (Mr. Stoll) to conceive a child with his wife, Annie (Ms. Hahn), who once dated Judd. Mr. Stoll, with his broad frame and sad eyes, gives the most affecting performance. Mr. Driverâ€™s â€” as Phillip, the youngest Altman and the black sheep of the family â€” is the most energetic. But both actors struggle with parts that are stock figures rather than fully imagined people.

Shortly after Judd Altman discovers his wife in bed with his boss, he learns that his father has died. The old manâ€™s dying wish was that the Altman family â€” his widow and their four children â€” observe the Jewish custom of sitting shiva, even though he was never especially religious. That means spending seven days together in a big suburban house, accepting condolences amid platters of food. For Judd, embodied by Jason Bateman with his usual air of beleaguered responsibility, a family reunion following a marital calamity is a nightmare. For â€œThis Is Where I Leave You,â€ù Shawn Levyâ€™s adaptation of Jonathan Tropperâ€™s comic best seller, itâ€™s a promising start.

The cast also sets up high expectations. In addition to Mr. Bateman, we have Adam Driver, Tina Fey and Corey Stoll as Juddâ€™s siblings, and none other than Jane Fonda herself as the matriarch of the Altman clan. Not much plausible family resemblance there, maybe, but no shortage of opportunities for sparks to fly. Add Kathryn Hahn as a frustrated sister-in-law, Ben Schwartz as a goofy rabbi and Rose Byrne as a kooky hometown girl with a crush â€” and also Dax Shepard, Timothy Olyphant and Connie Britton, for goodnessâ€™ sake â€” and the movie canâ€™t fail to at least generate some interesting chaos.
â€œThis Is Where I Leave Youâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Lots of naughty stuff.

â€œI donâ€™t do complicated,â€ù Judd says more than once. Circumstances are supposed to teach him how, but busy is not the same as complicated. Each character in the movie is a bundle of traits in search of a personality, which the audience struggles to fill in based on previous associations with the actor in question. We know Ms. Fey is clever and witty, so we assume that her character, Wendy, must be, too. But all we see is that her husband ignores her, that one of their kids is in the middle of potty training, and that she still carries a torch for Horry (Mr. Olyphant), who lives across the street.

Or so you would think. But instead of smiles or tears, â€œThis Is Where I Leave Youâ€ù is most likely to inspire a Kickstarter campaign to reunite its main performers for a different project. Maybe a game of charades or a chili cook-off. Aiming for a home-for-the-holidays blend of pathos and giggles, of zany antics and lump-in-the-throat lesson learning, Mr. Levy, working from Mr. Tropperâ€™s screenplay, puts together a lifeless, laughless sitcom-soap that stumbles from one generic situation to the next. There is almost nothing here that you havenâ€™t seen a dozen times before, and even the surprises feel flat and familiar. More dispiriting still is that this drab complacency is wrapped around messages of daring, honesty and spontaneity.

Nan, despite her superficial daftness, naturally proves to be the wiliest of the bunch, announcing a â€œfollow that carâ€ù plan when she suspects that someone has stashed the loot. From its name, the Irish-Swedish co-production â€œLifeâ€™s a Breezeâ€ù might sound like a jaunty romp, but the title actually comes from an air freshener. Mumbly dialogue, relentlessly jittery camerawork, a star who is also co-director and co-writer: Yes, itâ€™s time for another movie that mistakes the claustrophobic world of young New York artsy types for something interesting.

A jauntily self-aware fabulist, Mr. Smith doesnâ€™t have it in him to dispirit for long, and â€œTuskâ€ù proceeds with an ingratiating good cheer that deflects critical grumbling. A bizarre blend of loony kidnap drama and surreal Frankensteinian horror, the movie sends Wallace (Justin Long, working a mustache that signals a high ranking on the jerk scale), an American podcaster, to Canada in search of a story. While the script takes potshots at Canadian politesse, Wallace washes up at a back-of-beyond mansion where a grizzled raconteur (Michael Parks) crouches in a wheelchair, offering tea and tales of a seafaring past.
