â€œTuskâ€ù is a Kevin Smith film, which is to say that itâ€™s savvy enough to confirm that it was made by an adult, yet goofy enough to assure its audience that the adult in question remains unlikely to be caught wearing long pants.

â€œTracks,â€ù a high-mileage, low-energy story about an Australian woman, her trusty dog, four charming camels and the siren call of adventure, comes coated in a layer of sand. At times, the sand rolls on and on like an endlessly unfurling, magically variegated carpet that shifts from blood red to burnt sienna, pale pink and dung brown. At other times, it violently rises off the desert floor, swirling and churning into dusty whirlpools. The adventurer, Robyn Davidson (Mia Wasikowska), may blink â€” at the sandy dust and one deranged hallucination â€” but she keeps going, at times with nothing other than some cloth between her and a seemingly asphyxiating end.

The dust isnâ€™t yet whirling when Robyn lands in Alice Springs. There she moves into an abandoned house (using some cloth for a roof), learns all about camel wrangling and, after a narratively compressed stretch, obtains four beasts of burden to call her own: Dookie, Zelly, Bub and Goliath. One of the things you learn during this windup is that these creatures are insanely, unwaveringly watchable, whether theyâ€™re eyeballing the camera or the males in heat are working up a lather of sex-fueled drool. With the cinematographer Mandy Walker, Mr. Curran plays up the camel angle nicely, putting you at flirty eyelash level and then taking you lower for a bloody peek at a camel castration.

â€œWhen people ask me why Iâ€™m doing it,â€ù Robyn says at one point, â€œmy usual answer is â€˜Why not?â€™Â â€ù Thatâ€™s a cool retort or something, but it isnâ€™t necessarily enough for an enthralling movie, despite the camels and ravishing scenery. Years later, when Ms. Davidson looked back at her journey, she wrote that â€œA more pertinent question might be, why is it that more people donâ€™t attempt to escape the limitations imposed upon them?â€ù Itâ€™s a better question by a long mile, because it suggests that the younger traveler portrayed so wanly in the movie was motivated by real limitations â€” including race and sex â€” beyond the personal trauma thatâ€™s teased out in the flashbacks. Once upon a time, a white woman took a walkabout in the Australian desert where she discovered a world and not just herself.

This one, directed by John Curran from a script by Marion Nelson, is all about Ms. Davidsonâ€™s great trip, which in the movie begins with her arrival in Alice Springs, an Outback town in a part of the Northern Territory called the Red Center. She has next to no money; what she does have is a dog, Diggity, and a vague and crazy plan. She will train wild camels and load them up for a journey into and around the central desert. It was, Ms. Davidson admits in her book, a â€œlunatic idea,â€ù but she had the grit or maybe the arrogance to execute it. Whatever the reason â€” one of the frustrations of this movie is that it captures the beauty of her trip without tapping its deeper resonance â€” she took the leap.

The real Ms. Davidson wrote about that sand in â€œTracks,â€ù so you know that she didnâ€™t choke on it. Instead, in 1977 and in her 20s, she braved dust and demons for 1,700 miles. She later wrote about this epic journey for National Geographic, which both helped subsidize the trip and paid the photographer, Rick Smolan (Adam Driver), who did his part to immortalize her with the kind of gorgeous, glossy photographs that turn readers into armchair explorers. The book came out a few years later and became a best seller, and she continued to move across continents and through rarefied circles. Doris Lessing gave â€œTracksâ€ù her blurby blessing; Ms. Davidson was involved with Salman Rushdie when he was writing â€œThe Satanic Verses.â€ù But all that is grist for other screen stories.
â€œTracksâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). The death and killing of animals.

As it turns out, nothing else in â€œTracksâ€ù matches the dramatic pow of a camel being relieved of his testes. Despite the otherworldly scenery and some predictable tragedy â€” Robyn can be maddeningly careless about her animalsâ€™ welfare â€” this proves to be a rather logy amble. Mile after mile in close, medium and long shot, Robyn squints and walks, driving her herd if not the story in a journey thatâ€™s interrupted by elliptical flashbacks, wild camels, nosy tourists and some expressive voice-overs. Ms. Wasikowska tends to be a recessive screen presence and here, with little to do but walk and squint, sheâ€™s mostly persuasive as a determined voice. Every so often, Rick pops by and Mr. Driver gives the proceedings a jolt; for a time, an Aborigine, Mr. Eddy (Rolley Mintuma), tags along.

Produced in conjunction with the nonprofit Fuel Freedom Foundation, â€œPumpâ€ù is less a movie than a webpage in motion. But the arguments have an appealing logic for those concerned about the environment. The film explores Americaâ€™s dependence on oil, from John D. Rockefeller to the dismantling of the nationâ€™s streetcars, and traces oilâ€™s effects on the broader economy.
â€œPumpâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Pollution.

But the movie goes beyond alarmism with solutions that on the surface would seem to find common ground between environmental advocacy and unfettered capitalism. (One interviewee, an adviser to Fuel Freedom, is John Hofmeister, the former president of Shell Oil.) The presentation, at least, is smooth.

As filmmaking, â€œPumpâ€ù sometimes resembles a Super Bowl commercial. Its rhetorical methods tend toward strong-arming, with Jason Bateman, who narrates, discussing how â€œnobody can denyâ€ù the roots of Detroitâ€™s failure and a too-rapid discussion of a correlation between oil prices and the financial crisis.

Electric cars offer a distant solution, but â€œPumpâ€ù suggests that biofuels can provide an interim fix. The movie showcases an apparent success story with ethanol sales in Brazil; it turns hands-on with instructions on how to hack your car to make it run on different types of fuel. The owners of an independent gas station promote the benefits of providing consumers with a choice.
â€œReclaimâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for obscene language and fairly tame violence.

The elements are familiar in Alan Whiteâ€™s thriller â€œReclaimâ€ù: white, affluent Americans stuck in a lower-income tropical city with police officers of ambiguous morals (one played here by Luis GuzmÃ¡n); foot pursuits through slums; and car chases with gunplay on winding country roads. Thereâ€™s even an auto teetering on a cliff as the driver tries to yank the passengers out just in time.

Fortunately, there are seasoned actors in villainous roles, in this case a persuasively sleazy John Cusack and the formidable Australian Jacki Weaver (who received Oscar nominations for â€œAnimal Kingdomâ€ù and â€œSilver Linings Playbookâ€ù). They play a pair of child traffickers assisted by an underdrawn moll (Veronica Faye Foo) and henchman (Jandres Burgos). And thereâ€™s the appealing Rachelle Lefevre (from â€œUnder the Domeâ€ù) as the wife of a Chicago toy designer (a bland Ryan Phillippe) to bring a spry, coltish energy to the efficient, if routine, goings-on.

The plot? Mr. Phillippe and Ms. Lefevreâ€™s characters seek to adopt a 7-year-old Haitian earthquake survivor (an adorable Briana Roy), only to find themselves ensnared by a shady operation that brokers an â€œadoptionâ€ù for hefty fees and then â€œreclaimsâ€ù â€” essentially, kidnaps â€” the youngster and leaves town with the money.
A message before the closing credits cites the widespread incidence of child trafficking, but any social import is lost. This isnâ€™t activism; itâ€™s by-the-numbers suspense.

Liv Tyler plays a wholesome new arrival on the ship, where the closeted captain (Patrick Wilson) bottles up his rage and shame over his loverâ€™s departure. Others include a Valium-popping woman whoâ€™s cheating on her sensitive, robotic-handed, working-class husband; their bespectacled daughter, broken up over her cannibalistic gerbils; and a status-obsessed couple with a mother-in-law in cryogenic freeze.

The ship is a pristine version of those smooth-cruising predigital models that roamed the galaxy after â€œ2001: A Space Odyssey.â€ù References ricochet furiously throughout its decks â€” a robot therapist (â€œDr. Botâ€ù), lupus, VHS tapes used to record hologram transmissions.

But the director Jack Plotnickâ€™s period re-creations make for a confounding journey. The pointedly outdated gender stereotypes are practically highlighted in yellow, to decreasing payoffs, and Mr. Wilsonâ€™s performance is too indebted to Will Ferrellâ€™s pompous, clueless alpha males. 1 hour 33 minutes
Not that Dr. Bot and the oblivious self-righteousness wonâ€™t delight certain fans, but this remains a protracted, scattershot comedy sketch that never quite nails its tone.
Directed by Jack Plotnick
Opens on Friday
â€œSpace Station 76â€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for graphic nudity and some drug use.

From the authoritative male scientists of 1950s science fiction to the malaise-steeped dystopias of the 1970s, films about the future often betray the imprint of their times. For its part, â€œSpace Station 76â€ù attempts a science-fiction parody-melodrama, outfitting a Nixon-era ship with neuroses and touchstones from countless TV movies and martini-soaked suburban tales of woe.
SPACE STATION 76

â€œStop the Pounding Heartâ€ù transcends both the red state-blue state split and limited, didactic ideas of cinematic realism. Its scenes, quiet and undramatic, are nonetheless suffused with an almost lyrical intensity, and its sympathy is as limitless as its curiosity. Mr. Minervini practices a kind of ecstatic humanism masquerading as ethnography. The people in his film, as we come to know them, seem very familiar, and if they also seem mysterious, it is partly because the rest of us are, too.

â€œStop the Pounding Heartâ€ù could be described as a story of teenage romance, though its plot is a mere whisper. When Sara (Sara Carlson), one of 12 children in a Christian, home-schooling farm family, meets a young rodeo rider named Colby (Colby Trichell), the abashed looks and polite words they exchange suggest something stirring between them. Dating is no more a part of Saraâ€™s life than commercial popular culture, and Colby is both too respectful and too easily distracted to pursue her with much zeal.

But this is hardly a tale of forbidden love. It is, instead, an investigation of Saraâ€™s inner life â€” of the state of her soul â€” wrapped in an exploration of her social environment. It may be hard for an audience at Lincoln Center (where â€œStop the Pounding Heartâ€ù opens on Friday) to avoid looking at the film from across a cultural and ideological divide. Sara and Colby, for all their differences, both live in a world where literal interpretation of the Bible and commitment to the Second Amendment are pillars of behavior and belief. In Saraâ€™s case, submission to male authority is a principle of family life, explained by her mother in lessons to Sara and her sisters.

In Roberto Minerviniâ€™s â€œStop the Pounding Heart,â€ù nonprofessional actors play versions of their real-life selves. This practice, which can blur the distinction between drama and documentary and allow a glimpse at truths otherwise invisible to the camera, flourished in the Italian neorealism of the 1940s and the work of Iranian filmmakers like Abbas Kiarostami and Mohsen Makhmalbaf in the 1990s. Mr. Minervini, an Italian director who has now made three features in rural Texas, extends this tradition with impressive sensitivity and skill.

â€œThe Maze Runner,â€ù adapted from James Dashnerâ€™s novel, is a perfectly serviceable entry in the young-adult dystopian sweepstakes. It combines elements of â€œLord of the Fliesâ€ù with the Minotaur and Orpheus myths, but it plays as something closer to â€œThe Hunger Gamesâ€ù experienced through a dissociative fog. Much suspense comes from wondering which favored Hollywood twist the movie will employ. Is this actually the present day? Has someone blown up the planet?
THE MAZE RUNNER

Whatever cataclysm has ailed society has inspired the cinematographer to bathe everything in bluish gray. The Grieversâ€™ limbs tumble over one another in an indistinct mash of menace. The dime store explanations are unsatisfying, but the movie does its main job: raising curiosity for a sequel. Problem solved.

Yet by keeping its cards so close, â€œThe Maze Runnerâ€ù remains compelling. Sent to the Glade for mysterious reasons, a messianic figure, Thomas (Dylan Oâ€™Brien), discovers that the changing maze can be used against the Grievers.
Directed by Wes Ball
â€œThe Maze Runnerâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Fearmongering, giant spiders.

In â€œThe Maze Runner,â€ù the ratio of vocabulary to explanations is alarmingly high. The main setting is the Glade, where a â€œGreenie,â€ù or newcomer, arrives each month with supplies for a platoon of lost boys. The Glade is surrounded by a giant maze monitored by â€œGrievers,â€ù monsters that have features of spiders, scorpions and robots. During the day, â€œRunnersâ€ù map the maze, but moviegoers may feel as if they were the ones being tested.
1 hour 53 minutes
Opens on Friday

Disney, never a stranger to princesses, crowns another as it ventures further into Bollywood with Shashanka Ghoshâ€™s romantic confection, â€œKhoobsurat,â€ù a variation on Hrishikesh Mukherjeeâ€™s 1980 film, â€œKhoobsoorat.â€ù And the studioâ€™s specialty proves a pretty good fit.

Anne Hathaway made a splash in Disneyâ€™s â€œThe Princess Diaries,â€ù and the rangy Ms. Kapoor (who descends from a Bollywood dynasty) shares some of her early incandescence, along with a Julia Roberts-like smile. (Mr. Khan wisely underplays against her supernova, never trying to eclipse her.)

Mili Chakravarty (Sonam Kapoor) is a high-energy, middle-class and somewhat daffy physiotherapist for a New Delhi cricket team when she is hired by an aristocratic family near Jaipur  to rehabilitate its patriarch (Aamir Raza Hussain), whoâ€™s been using a wheelchair for years. His son, Vikram (the heavy-lidded Pakistani heartthrob Fawad Afzal Khan), a shrewd businessman, is not only engaged to a woman of his economic station but is also monitored by his imperious, upper-crust mother (Ratna Pathak Shah). The brash, often clumsy Mili, in her mixed-pattern ensembles, descends on their estate like a tornado, bumping into statuary, dancing with the servants and winning hearts, especially Vikramâ€™s.

Bollywood films have appropriated Hollywood genres and imagery for years, but Mr. Ghosh, using a pleasing pastel palette, deftly achieves a particularly Disney-like polish. And he avoids making-of-a-royal pitfalls: Ms. Kapoorâ€™s character never abandons her humor for refinement. Twice, Mili says that she was raised to speak up for herself. Not a bad characteristic for a future Rajput princess.

â€œAdvanced Styleâ€ù is undeniably captivating, even uplifting at times. But Mr. Cohen and Lina Plioplyte, the director, present a disconcerting mixed message. Women can be knockouts at any age, they contend, yet what we see here are ludicrously over-the-top choices: spiky pink or orange hair; hats that resemble spaceships or potholders; eyeglasses the size of hors dâ€™oeuvre plates; bright red, foot-long false lashes made from a nonagenarianâ€™s own hair. If the younger people who appear in the film seem to view these women with a certain condescension, no wonder. Is eccentric the only interesting look after 60?

â€œI saw all these incredibly dressed older women on the streets,â€ù says Ari Seth Cohen, a photographer who recalls being very close to his grandmothers. His photos inspired a blog, a book and now a documentary, â€œAdvanced Style.â€ù Simon Doonan, the fashion pundit, calls Mr. Cohenâ€™s concept â€œquite anarchic,â€ù so it must be fabulous.

Seven New York women are profiled in the film, making intense fashion statements. Tziporah Salamon, known as Zippy, is the baby of the group, at 62 (during the filming). She shows off her vintage ensembles while bicycling around Manhattan. Zelda Kaplan, 95, is the eldest, a connoisseur of woven fabrics whose last visit to Fashion Week is the filmâ€™s most dramatic development. Joyce Carpati, 80, seems the most elegant, with a silver Frances Farmer braid, pearls and an antiques-filled apartment â€” until the group appears on â€œThe Ricki Lake Show,â€ù and Ms. Carpati, intoxicated by the cameraâ€™s red light, turns into Honey Boo Boo in pageant mode.

A smart, sly comedy about what its director, Will Bakke, calls â€œthe power of platforms,â€ù â€œBelieve Meâ€ù parodies the machinery of faith-based fund-raising with its heart on its sleeve and its jokes above the belt.
1 hour 33 minutes
â€œBelieve Meâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Advice on how to swear, worship and fleece like a Christian.

The filmâ€™s congeniality, however, in no way dulls its humor or the sharpness of its observations. The ethical conundrum intensifies when the group is invited to spearhead a genuine mission on a nationwide tour. Buttressed by the good will of sincere evangelicals, the young men and their counterfeit charity â€” a plan to provide clean drinking water to Africa, cheekily tagged Get Wells Soon â€” begin raking in the cash.
Directed by Will Bakke
Opens on Friday

Positing that belief in God is not essential for using him as a sales tool, Mr. Bakke â€” who was raised Christian and cut his filmmaking teeth on two faith-themed documentaries â€” takes aim at religious frauds without ridiculing their victims. â€œGone Girlâ€ù is set in the recessionary present in a small fictional Missouri town, North Carthage. Around the time you meet Nick, Mr. Fincher folds in some typical snapshots of desperate Anytown, U.S.A.: empty shops, vacant streets and homeless people tramping into the void. Nick and his wife, Amy (Rosamund Pike), arenâ€™t headed for Brokesville quite yet, but theyâ€™re clinging hard to the status quo. Theyâ€™re leasing their big, ugly house, and their bank account is running on fumes. The screenwriter, Gillian Flynn, adapting her novel of the same title, was a television critic for Entertainment Weekly who was laid off, and her characters share the same hard-knock fate: Nick, some kind of magazine writer, lost his New York job, as did Amy, who wrote quizzes for womenâ€™s magazines. (Was that a job? A. Yes, B. No, C. I doubt it.)

Amyâ€™s voice-overs disrupt the movieâ€™s inaugural seriousness. In flashbacks introduced by her scribbling in her diary, she reveals that sheâ€™s the inspiration for a beloved and profitable book series about a girl, Amazing Amy, created by her psychologist parents, Rand and Marybeth (David Clennon and Lisa Banes). Like Hannibal Lecter (a psychiatrist), Amyâ€™s parents have profited from messing around in other peopleâ€™s heads. (Your parents plagiarized your childhood, Nick says with husbandly commiseration.) Theyâ€™re cartoons, but then, so is Amy, whose narration Ms. Pike delivers in an affectedly hushed, conspiratorial voice thatâ€™s so arch that you can picture Amyâ€™s lips curling at the edges. Mr. Fincher doesnâ€™t show you her sneer; he doesnâ€™t have to. It imbues every word she says, instantly casting her as an unreliable narrator.

By the movieâ€™s second half, you may wish that Amy would stay gone. Ms. Pike has some fine scenes in this section, notably with a pair of hilariously sly lowlifes, Greta and Jeff (Lola Kirke and Boyd Holbrook), who, taken with a pompous, wealthy fool (Neil Patrick Harris as Desi), suggest that the movie is about to go deeper, that it will surprise you or stir you or say something, anything, maybe by making good on its scene-setting images of empty American stores. That never happens, and instead, the movie just hums along like the precision machine it is, even after it shifts tones again and enters Grand Guignol territory, with a flashing knife, gushing blood and surveillance footage of a seemingly tortured, horrifically abused and screaming woman. Itâ€™s a ghastly vision, although not for the reasons this movie would like.
(â€œGone Girlâ€ù opens the 52nd New York Film Festival on Friday and opens in theaters next Friday.)

Mr. Fincherâ€™s compositions, camera work and cutting are, as always, superbly controlled. Working again with the cinematographer Jeff Cronenweth and the production designer Donald Graham Burt, he fashions an ever more haunted, haunting world that wavers so violently between ordinariness and aberration that, as in his other movies, the two soon blur. Nick may feel at home in North Carthage, but, from that first shot of him alone in front of his house â€” and from his first conversation with his sister, Margo (Carrie Coon), in which they trade insults about Amy â€” he comes across as alienated, lost. Mr. Fincher underlines that isolation by showing Nick both alone in the frame and in his house, where heâ€™s at times dwarfed and almost swallowed up by its generic, oversize rooms.

â€œGone Girl,â€ù the latest from that dark lord of cinema, David Fincher, opens with a man softly talking about his wifeâ€™s head. The image of his hand caressing a womanâ€™s sleek blond hair in close-up indicates that itâ€™s a lovely head, a lovely wife, too. Yet the violence of his words â€” he speaks of cracking her skull open and â€œunspoolingâ€ù her brain â€” wakens an unease that trembles throughout this domestic horror movie. Those familiar with Mr. Fincherâ€™s work may wonder, perhaps with a shudder or a conspiratorial smile, whether this head will share the fate of another head belonging to another pretty wife, a gift that was boxed and delivered in one of the hellish circles girdling his shocker â€œSeven.â€ù

Mr. Fincher, for all his modern themes and bleeding-edge technologies, is a classicist, and in â€œGone Girl,â€ù he creates a sense of Nickâ€™s subjectivity the usual way, mostly by placing the camera next to the character and deploying point-of-view shots that are seamlessly integrated with shots of, and generated by, other characters. Shortly after the movie opens, the plot fires up, as you watch Nick return home to find that Amy has gone missing. You see him pick up their cat and watch him fling open doors, roam the halls and discover a broken glass table. In other words, here you know what Nick knows, which, as it will turn out, isnâ€™t much. Amy is gone, and as Nick, the police, the town, the news media and the country shift into progressively more hysterical crisis-and-circus mode, she stays gone.

Given that the first half of â€œGone Girlâ€ù is structured as a mystery, this unreliability presents a problem because it throws everything Amy says into doubt. Along with Mr. Affleckâ€™s supple, sympathetic performance, Amyâ€™s voice-over tips the scales so far in Nickâ€™s favor that it upends Ms. Flynnâ€™s attempt to recreate the even-steven dynamic from her book. Then again, the movie is on Nickâ€™s side from the start, making the case for him, from the way he services Amy sexually to the gentle way he treats their cat. He sometimes explodes, as when he throws a glass to the floor while talking to two cops, Boney (an excellent Kim Dickens) and Gilpin (a dryly funny Patrick Fugit). The Nick here, like so many noir heroes, is simply, too simply, a decent, deflated, ordinary sap with serious woman problems.

Times are hard, kind of, for Nick and Amy, but, as you discover in a series of flashbacks, they moved to North Carthage only when Nickâ€™s mother received a cancer diagnosis. She died, and shortly after, so did the bloom on the marriage, though how it fades depends on whoâ€™s confessing and complaining. In the book, the narrative duties are fairly evenly distributed between Nick and Amy, who recount alternating versions of their happy times and unhappily ever after, with him taking you through events as they happen in the first person, while her point of view comes into focus partly through her detailed diary entries. The movie more or less duplicates this he-says, she-writes pattern, although with a critical difference: Nickâ€™s story doesnâ€™t unfold wholly through his first-person account.

The same is true of this movie. At its strongest, â€œGone Girlâ€ù plays like a queasily, at times gleefully, funny horror movie about a modern marriage, one that has disintegrated partly because of spiraling downward mobility and lost privilege. Yet, as sometimes happens in Mr. Fincherâ€™s work, dread descends like winter shadows, darkening the movieâ€™s tone and visuals until itâ€™s snuffed out all the light, air and nuance. As Nick becomes mired in the search for Amy, she confides how romance gave way to marital dreariness, accusations, his mounting loathing, her growing fear. One minute, he was leaving empty takeout containers strewn about and playing video games; the next, she says, he was raising a hand to her and she was cowering in their bed. She has the victim thing down cold.
â€œGone Girlâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Extreme violence.

Unspooling is such an inapt word â€” can brains, after all, be unspooled? â€” that it immediately puts dread in check. No matter how brutal the images generated by these words, surely thereâ€™s more in store than blunt-force entertainment. Well, yes and no, which is sometimes the case with Mr. Fincher. One of those filmmakers whose technical prowess can make the mediocrity of his material seem irrelevant (almost), Mr. Fincher is always the star of his work. His art can overwhelm characters and their stories to the point that they fade away, leaving you with meticulous staging and framing, and edits as sharp as blades. Itâ€™s no accident that the first time you fully see Nick Dunne (Ben Affleck), the man who had been discoursing so vividly about his wifeâ€™s head, heâ€™s alone.

The manor is owned by Elizabeth (Ms. Janney), a famous actress whose career is in eclipse. She arrives with her younger lover, Peter (an inert, expressionless Mr. Camargo), an opportunistic filmmaker with a roving eye. Also on hand are her desperately unhappy son, Eric (Ben Whishaw), an aspiring multimedia artist whose work she viciously derides; her ailing brother, Herb (Mr. Hurt); and Herbâ€™s resident doctor (Jean Reno).

Ms. Janneyâ€™s bitter diva has none of the self-deluded grandeur of her Chekhovian prototype, Irina Arkadina. No slouch when it comes to playing angry, jealous women of a certain age, Ms. Janney oozes a malicious narcissism. She and Mr. Whishaw, whose character is modeled after Irinaâ€™s son, Konstantin, give the fullest performances, and the ensemble acting is fluid.

They are joined by the estateâ€™s gun-happy caretaker (Michael Nyqvist); his wife (Ms. Jones); and their daughter (Katie Holmes), who is married to a local ornithologist (Mr. Rylance); and by Eva (Juliet Rylance, Mr. Rylanceâ€™s stepdaughter, who is married to Mr. Camargo), a restless neighbor whom Eric adores and Peter ogles.

The cast list for â€œDays and Nights,â€ù a modern reworking of Chekhovâ€™s â€œThe Seagull,â€ù is so juicy that I approached the movie with lip-smacking expectations of scenery being chewed and spit out with histrionic gusto. Even at its worst, how bad could an updated version of the play be, if actors of the caliber of Allison Janney, William Hurt, Cherry Jones and Mark Rylance had signed on? The answer is worse than you could imagine.

But â€œThe Seagull,â€ù with its depiction of fin de siÃ¨cle ennui, has been hollowed out and trivialized. So little time is given to the subsidiary characters in â€œDays and Nightsâ€ù that, at times, the movie barely makes sense. The avian symbol has been changed from a sea gull to a bald eagle. What remains is a cracked shell.

The truncated shambles on the screen is evidence, if any more proof were needed, that great actors can go only so far (not very) to salvage an artistic shipwreck. Written and directed by Christian Camargo, the film, which runs a scant 92 minutes, is set at a lakeside estate in Connecticut during Memorial Day weekend in 1984.

Teddyâ€™s elegantly tailored suits hide a chest full of prison tattoos, and his sneering sadism and fastidious diction mark him out for an especially painful death, though the rules of the genre dictate that weâ€™ll have to wait for it. Once he shows up, painful death is pretty much all â€œThe Equalizerâ€ù has on its mind. Alina, the innocent, vulnerable pretext for all the killing, pretty much disappears, though one of her colleagues (Haley Bennett) takes a turn in the victim role. Violence against women is handled discreetly, but the men stomp, stab, shoot and bludgeon one another with showy abandon and an almost erotic intensity.
â€œThe Equalizerâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Swearing and killing.

Bob, who works at a Home Depot-like building supply store, is a widower with meticulous habits and friendly relations with most of the people he meets. A ready source of self-help catchphrases that would sound silly coming from anyone other than Mr. Washington, he is a mentor to a younger co-worker (Johnny Skourtis). When insomnia hits, Bob repairs to a 24-hour diner, where he drinks tea, reads classic novels and makes avuncular small talk with Alina, a young prostitute whose street name is Teri (ChloÃ« Grace Moretz).

Bob â€” it might not be his real name â€” is chaste, and his motives are pure, though, in his past, he might have done some of the usual vaguely alluded-to â€œterrible things.â€ù His decency licenses both his extreme brutality and our enjoyment of it. We can persuade ourselves that we are watching the spectacle of enacted justice rather than the sentimentalization of a homicidal sociopath.

And then Bob takes out a room full of Russian mobsters, and the fun â€” which is to say the escalating bloodshed â€” begins in earnest. That first batch of bad guys, gored with corkscrews, brained with paperweights and sent off into the next world with anything else that comes to hand, were guilty of hurting Alina. It turns out that they sit at the bottom of a pyramid of depravity that reaches all the way to a man named Pushkin back in Moscow. Thinking that rival gangs might be moving in on his territory, Mr. Pushkin (Vladimir Kulich) sends a lieutenant known as Teddy (Marton Csokas) to straighten things out and to provide enough evil mayhem to justify more righteous brutality on Bobâ€™s part.

Eventually, heâ€™s going to kill someone, of course, but before he does, â€œThe Equalizerâ€ù is disarmingly quiet, almost as if it were committed to remaining the low-key, lower-middle-class character study that nobody in the theater has bought a ticket to see.

Really, though, Iâ€™m splitting ethical hairs. Mr. Washington is, with Liam Neeson, one of our leading middle-aged action heroes, a rugged avenger whose craft and discipline endow even exploitative nonsense like this with a center of gravity. For his part, Mr. Fuqua, while not the worldâ€™s most subtle filmmaker, directs the action sequences with bluntness and clarity and effectively uses his star as an oasis of calm in a jumpy, nasty universe.

But what about the lower-ranking muscle, the bald dudes with tattoos who have to open the doors of the black S.U.V.s and throw the first punches at a man they have no way of knowing is really an elite super-assassin? Were they warned about this in the job interview? Do they have health insurance? Theyâ€™re really just working stiffs, too, and the way theyâ€™re treated seems a little unfair.

As the music ebbs, flows and explodes, so do the visuals. For the most part Mr. Ridley avoids big scenes and long speeches, although he does give Jimi some nice cosmic aperÃ§us and trippy philosophical thoughts. And rather than hewing to a strict narrative line, Mr. Ridley takes a generally more fragmented and associative approach to the material. Rather, it looks at the year he went from discovery to detonation. It happened fast: In 1966, Hendrix â€” played with dreamy reserve here by AndrÃ© Benjamin, a.k.a. AndrÃ© 3000 of Outkast â€” was a cool cat who was calling himself Jimmy James and playing with Curtis Knight and the Squires, an R&B band. The following year he was off to London, where after changing his name and threads, he emerged as the star child Jimi Hendrix.

Did it happen this way, and does it matter? One reason â€œAll Is by My Sideâ€ù works is that the story â€” with its girl, guy, guitar and revolution â€” is enjoyable, whether itâ€™s precisely true or not. And Mr. Ridleyâ€™s style and method are invitingly playful even if the movie doesnâ€™t approach the radicalness of Todd Haynesâ€™s â€œIâ€™m Not There,â€ù an experimental inquiry into Bob Dylan. Thereâ€™s too much melodrama in â€œAll Is by My Side,â€ù especially with Jimiâ€™s needy, abused lover, Kathy Etchingham (Hayley Atwell), and a painful phone call with Jimiâ€™s father, Al (Geoffrey Burton), only opens unanswered questions. But Mr. Ridleyâ€™s ambitions and refusal to treat Hendrix as a solvable mystery are welcome, given how often biopics re-embalm their subjects. Here, a legend is born, and a man too.

Mr. Ridley largely charts Jimiâ€™s sojourn in London through streaming music and a surprisingly unorthodox visual approach. Itâ€™s initially surprising and disappointing that none of Hendrixâ€™s original music is in the movie. Mr. Ridley has said that the Hendrix estate, as it has in the past, denied permission for its use. So, he gets the storyâ€™s groove on by using some of the songs that Hendrix covered, like â€œWild Thingâ€ù and â€œSgt. Pepperâ€™s Lonely Hearts Club Band.â€ù You donâ€™t hear the real Hendrix, his chords, rhythms and feedback yowls, but Mr. Benjamin sings while the guitarist Waddy Wachtel provides Jimiâ€™s guitar licks. Among the most instrumental figures is Linda Keith (Imogen Poots, warm and lovely), a British It Girl who has more going for her than her boyfriend Keith Richards. The writer and director John Ridley ends his movie right before Jimi plays at the 1967 Monterey Pop Festival, where he would burn down the house and his guitar with it, dive-bombing into history. Pennebakerâ€™s 1968 concert documentary, â€œMonterey Pop.â€ù) Instead, Mr. Ridley cherry-picks crucial characters, crystalline moments and signature covers to summon a life and its times.

The strike was well underway when Mark Ashton (Ben Schnetzer, â€œThe Book Thiefâ€ù), a fervent politico, began recruiting friends at a gay pride march in London to raise money to help the miners and their families. Both groups, he argued, were targets of repression by the Thatcher government, the police and the tabloid media. The cops were so focused on breaking the strike in Wales, he pointed out, that their harassment of gay people in London had temporarily abated.

Complicating the story is the AIDS epidemic, which begins diverting the attention of the gay activists. â€œPrideâ€ù makes little of the schism, and it draws the line at portraying the ravages of H.I.V., which infects at least one group member. (Mr. Ashton died of AIDS in 1987.)

â€œPrideâ€ù is a descendant of morale-boosting British World War II movies that celebrated people pulling together in hard times. But the enemy here, the conservative government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, is within rather than without. In a TV clip, Thatcher is shown baring her teeth in a feral smile, her eyes gleaming, as she vows to crush the National Union of Mineworkers.

Various degrees of antigay sentiment are expressed by the miners, yet the movie refuses to demonize anyone except Maureen (Lisa Palfrey), an intractably homophobic minerâ€™s wife who leaks the news of the coalition to a tabloid. An article sneeringly headlined â€œPits and Pervertsâ€ù rains ridicule on the alliance and embarrasses the miners enough for them to discourage further gay support. But the Londoners continue their campaign and adopt â€œPits and Pervertsâ€ù as the name of a lucrative fund-raising concert featuring the gay dance-pop trio Bronski Beat.

That film tradition was revived in the late 1990s with â€œThe Full Monty,â€ù a celebration of working-class ingenuity in which six unemployed steelworkers in Sheffield form a striptease act to raise money. â€œPride,â€ù unlike â€œThe Full Monty,â€ù isnâ€™t a comedy, but laughs are harvested from the collision of macho working-class miners in South Wales and young Londoners, mostly male, who gather at a gay bookstore.

The minersâ€™ wives are the first to warm up to their guests. The first layer of ice is broken when Jonathan (an improbably cast Dominic West, of â€œThe Wireâ€ù), an actor and gay party animal, improvises a wild â€œSaturday Night Feverâ€ù-style solo to Shirley & Companyâ€™s â€œShame, Shame, Shame.â€ù The women are thrilled.

The classic union anthem â€œSolidarity Forever,â€ù sung by Pete Seeger, introduces â€œPride,â€ù a stirring film about the uneasy coalition of British mineworkers and gay and lesbian activists during a labor strike in the mid-1980s. Directed by Matthew Warchus (â€œMatilda the Musicalâ€ù), it is the kind of hearty, blunt-force drama with softened edges that leaves audiences applauding and teary-eyed.

Although the miners were ultimately defeated in the strike, the movie, which begins and ends with gay pride parades a year apart, refuses to accept that defeat. Instead, it pins its hopes on the touching ways that the spirit of solidarity can transcend fear and bigotry.

Despite the minersâ€™ appreciation for their support, the visitors are greeted with suspicion and some hostility. The Londoners, in turn, are wary of their hosts, but, by degrees, a tentative rapport is established.

The union side includes Hefina (Imelda Staunton), a gung-ho, unflappable organizer who enthusiastically welcomes the gay contingent, and Cliff (Bill Nighy), the unionâ€™s polite, haltingly shy secretary.

Stephen Beresfordâ€™s evenhanded screenplay has a lot of ground to cover and more characters than it can comfortably handle, but it manages to humanize almost everyone. The gay supporters, besides Mark and Jonathan, include Jonathanâ€™s lover, Gethin (Andrew Scott), who grew up in Wales, fled to London and hasnâ€™t been home since, and Joe (George MacKay), a shy, semi-closeted college student.

Contributing to its appeal are that the story is based on actual, though little-known, events; that its heroes and villains are clear-cut; and that its tone is resolutely upbeat but not pie-in-the-sky feel-good. The movie accentuates the positive without descending into mawkish sentimentality, although here and there it comes close.

His fledgling organization, Lesbians and Gays Support the Miners, tries to get in touch with the union and eventually reaches a local chapter in a South Wales village. Its union rep, Dai Donovan (Paddy Considine), travels to London to meet the activists and invites them to visit the miners. They pile into a brightly decorated minibus and drive to the Welsh countryside.

Except that Eggs, like Tarzan and a dozen Disney heroes, is not like everybody else. Stephen King hasnâ€™t personally adapted one of his stories for a feature screenplay since â€œPet Sematary,â€ù in 1989. But youâ€™d never guess it from watching the low-key, assured thriller â€œA Good Marriage,â€ù from his novella of the same title.

â€œThe Good Lieâ€ù focuses its attention on a group of refugees, three of them siblings, who are driven into exile by militias from northern Sudan. With their parents slaughtered and their village destroyed, Theo (Okwar Jale), his younger brother, Mamere (Peterdeng Mongok), and their sister, Abital (Keji Jale), the children of the village tribal chief, flee on foot only to find that war has seeped into neighboring countries where they had hoped to find safety.

Their destination is Kansas City, Mo. But Mamere (Arnold Oceng), now grown up, is beside himself when the rules, which require separating the men and women, place Abital (Kuoth Wiel), whom Mamere has sworn to protect, with a Boston family.

Directed by the Canadian filmmaker Philippe Falardeau (â€œMonsieur Lazharâ€ù) from a screenplay by Margaret Nagle (â€œBoardwalk Empireâ€ù), â€œThe Good Lieâ€ù may be a little too soft. But it largely avoids mawkish sentimentality and casts a glow that is increasingly absent nowadays from films depicting international strife.

Along the way, the siblings meet and befriend Jeremiah (Thon Kueth) and Paul (Deng Ajuet), who have fled other parts of Sudan. After 13 years in the camp, they are given a chance to emigrate to the United States with the stipulation that they eventually pay back their airfare.

Goodbye, Elle Woods. Hello, Carrie Davis. The spunky, cutesy-pie go-getter embodied by Reese Witherspoon in the â€œLegally Blondeâ€ù movies has morphed into a still-spirited but somewhat less glamorous do-gooder in â€œThe Good Lie.â€ù Her jaw remains thrust out in an attitude of fierce determination. Her eyes snap with impatience.

During an English class, Mamere learns about â€œthe good lieâ€ù â€” prevarication for a higher purpose â€” while studying â€œThe Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.â€ù The concept later inspires the noble act that gives the film its title.

The movieâ€™s even tone is similar to two documentaries about Sudanese refugees: â€œThe Lost Boys of Sudanâ€ù and the tougher â€œGod Grew Tired of Us,â€ù which elaborated the enormous difficulties these immigrants faced in trying to assimilate into fast-paced, hard-edge American culture.
When the men land in Kansas City, Ms. Witherspoon is there to meet them and to help them hunt for jobs and adjust to their new home.

Ms. Witherspoon is the nominal star of this warmhearted fictionalized account of the humanitarian program that brought 3,600 South Sudanese refugees to the United States shortly before the events of Sept. 11 forced an end to the program. But she doesnâ€™t appear until nearly 40 minutes have passed.
For all its softening, â€œThe Good Lie,â€ù like â€œMonsieur Lazhar,â€ù has a core of decency, humanity and good will that feels authentic. You wonâ€™t curse yourself for occasionally tearing up.

When Theo, their designated chief, is captured and forcibly conscripted into the rebel army, his siblings have few expectations of seeing him again. Mamere, who is barely pubescent, assumes leadership. One scene, in which dehydration forces the children to drink their own urine, suggests the deprivation and physical hardships they endure in an odyssey that takes them 735 miles before they find food and shelter in the Kakuma refugee camp in Kenya. But the movie scrupulously minimizes unsettling scenes and regularly pauses to take in a magnificent vista or a breathtaking sunset.
â€œThe Good Lieâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It has scenes of wartime violence, strong language, and drug use.

The inevitable culture shock the immigrants experience is played mostly for gentle, sweet-natured comedy. The men have never seen a telephone, and when one rings they assume it is some sort of alarm. The Sudanese are sharply etched characters. Jeremiah (Ger Duany), who finds a job stocking grocery shelves, is a tall lanky Christian who carries a Bible and quotes Scripture. The high-strung, fiercely independent Paul (Emmanuel Jal), a talented mechanic, finds work at a faucet factory and chafes against authority. Mamere, the storyâ€™s reassuring anchor and moral grounding wire, wants to be a doctor and dreams of reuniting his family.

But â€œKeep On Keepinâ€™ Onâ€ù offers something much richer and more unusual than the biography of an eminent musician. Mr. Terry was a pioneer in jazz education, and his first student was a 12-year-old horn player named Quincy Jones, â€œso skinny he could ride a rooster,â€ù in Mr. Terryâ€™s words. Now in his 80s, Mr. Jones is a producer of this film and also, especially toward the end, a crucial on-screen presence. He is one bookend of Mr. Terryâ€™s career as a teacher, and Mr. Kauflin, a quiet young man with an irrepressible smile and evident talent, is the other.

The older man, meanwhile, suffers the effects of age and diabetes, sometimes struggling to hold on to the optimism that is the dominant feature of his temperament. The audience visits him and his wife, Gwen, at their home in Pine Bluff, Ark., and accompanies them to a hospital as his health declines. Mr. Kauflin is also a frequent visitor, receiving instruction from his teacher even when Mr. Terry is too weak to sit up in bed.

Mr. Kauflin, who was born in 1986 with impaired vision, lost his eyesight completely when he was 11 and became serious about the piano around the same time. At the start of the movie, he is living in New York, trying to break into the professional jazz scene and having a hard time. We follow him through various setbacks and triumphs â€” a move back to his parentsâ€™ home in Virginia Beach, a tense appearance at the Thelonious Monk International Jazz Piano Competition â€” but the one constant is his friendship with Mr. Terry.

Mr. Terry, who celebrates his 91st and 92nd birthdays in the course of the film, is an artist whose rigor is matched by enthusiasm and generosity. Described by one admirer as possessing â€œthe happiest sound in jazz,â€ù he is shown in archival clips unleashing cascades of bright, clear notes with startling verve and velocity. Dizzy Gillespie thought Mr. Terry was the best trumpeter around, and his influence extended through jazzâ€™s heroic midcentury decades and into the present. Born in St. Louis in 1920, he started out in Count Basieâ€™s band, which he fondly recalls as his â€œprep school for the University of Ellingtonia,â€ù a reference to the Duke Ellington Orchestra, where he was a mainstay through the 1950s. He also did a stint in the â€œTonight Showâ€ù band, becoming the first African-American musician hired full-time to play on the air at NBC.

The old-timer and the young striver are a wonderful pair, and the privilege of their company is not something you should refuse. At one point, Mr. Terry and Mr. Kauflin muse on what separates the amateurs, of whom there is never a shortage, from the masters, a vastly smaller company. Itâ€™s the drive to be better than anyone else, Mr. Terry says, acknowledging both a general truth about art and the specific competitive ethos of jazz, where the motive is often to play a rival off the bandstand. Like other stories of musical tutelage, â€œKeep On Keepinâ€™ Onâ€ù is ultimately an examination of the pursuit of greatness. It is a grueling and demanding endeavor, for sure, but also, for Mr. Terry and anyone lucky enough to enter his orbit, a source of unending joy.
â€œKeep On Keepinâ€™ Onâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). A handful of expletives, perfectly in tune.

Learning is a basic and universal human process, but itâ€™s also mysterious. How does one person communicate complex knowledge and technique to another? To see Mr. Terry and his student together is to experience a moving and revelatory answer to this question. Mr. Kauflin sits at a keyboard, working on passages of melody and rhythm, while Mr. Terry, trained in a completely different kind of instrument, answers with scat singing that homes in on fine points of phrasing and articulation. This method, known as doodle-tonguing (and related to Mr. Terryâ€™s vocal performance of â€œMumblesâ€ù), is musical discipline masquerading as verbal nonsense. Occasionally, Mr. Terry will look up from his bed and ask what time it is; itâ€™s long after midnight, and he and Mr. Kauflin have been working for hours, oblivious to the passage of time.

By happy coincidence â€” though it might be a cultural trend of profound significance â€” we are in a season full of movies about musical mentors. Next week brings â€œWhiplash,â€ù Damien Chazelleâ€™s tale of a jazz instructor whose main pedagogical methods are sadism and terror. Ethan Hawkeâ€™s â€œSeymour: An Introduction,â€ù part of the New York Film Festivalâ€™s documentary lineup, portrays a more benign teacher, who attends to his pupilsâ€™ spiritual health as well as their musical skills. And opening on Friday is â€œKeep On Keepinâ€™ On,â€ù Alan Hicksâ€™s affectionate and moving look at the relationship between the great trumpeter Clark Terry and Justin Kauflin, a talented young pianist.

The filmâ€™s on-the-ground approach is impressive, including a visit to a radio station, where a worker must put up with ominous, anonymous cellphone calls. But itâ€™s never quite as incisive as another (yet to be released) hijack documentary, â€œThe Captain and His Pirate.â€ù This film could have been more surely and deftly put together.

Piracy is apparently hard to get out of your system, as the filmmakers Tommy Pallotta and Femke Wolting find out in â€œLast Hijack,â€ù a look at a man in Somalia having trouble going straight. Itâ€™s a character that Mr. Murray knows something about, having played a version in the 1988 comedy â€œScrooged.â€ù â€œSt. Vincentâ€ù isnâ€™t technically a redo of â€œA Christmas Carolâ€ù (and God bless us, everyone), but its writer and director, Theodore Melfi, has borrowed from so many fictional forefathers that Dickens is just built into his scriptâ€™s DNA. Mr. Murray is 64 now, or 105 in American movie industry years, which means heâ€™s transitioned into codgerdom. The business has always found a way to employ its silver foxes and grizzled geezers, one reason there are so many variations on the codger, including the leathery badass (John Wayne, Clint Eastwood, Liam Neeson); the comic coot (Gabby Hayes, Walter Brennan); the wise elder (hello, Morgan Freeman); and the scrooge, both unreconstructed and reformed (Lionel Barrymore in â€œItâ€™s a Wonderful Lifeâ€ù and the voice of Ed Asner in â€œUpâ€ù). The scrooge is a particularly durable type, because his struggle is with his own self, and because his transformation has the feeling of a revelation even as itâ€™s also hard won, having transpired over a long night into memory and soul.

Mr. Melfiâ€™s quick-sketch setup makes it clear Vincent isnâ€™t bad, and not only because heâ€™s played by Mr. Murray, whose world-weary shtick is now as purely decorative as a string of puka beads. Vincent is just a bit more unkempt than the usual curmudgeon whoâ€™s being prepped for uplift. He smokes, drinks, gambles and apparently doesnâ€™t dust. He isnâ€™t polite to bankers. He is nice, though, to a pregnant Russian prostitute, Daka (Naomi Watts, wearing a stomach prosthesis and a beautiful tight smile), whoâ€™s first seen playing giddy-up horsey with Vincent, her swollen belly bouncing. Daka is an impossible creation (heart of gold, buns of steel) whoâ€™s saved â€” as is true throughout this exasperating movie â€” by an actor who roots around in a clichÃ© and pulls out something human.

The same is true of Melissa McCarthy, who as Vincentâ€™s new neighbor, Maggie, takes a conceit and layers it with complication, and by a wonderful Jaeden Lieberher, who plays her 12-year-old, Tiny Tim. (Heâ€™s actually named Oliver!) The actors donâ€™t do all the heavy lifting by themselves. The uniformly good performances make it clear that Mr. Melfi knows how to handle actors, and there are some funny bits â€” a Tom-and-Jerry knockabout performed solo by Mr. Murray â€” that suggest Mr. Melfi needs to let his inner Jerry Lewis out more often. He needs to cut loose in other ways, too: His dialogue can have the cadence of real life, but his scenes and situations tend to be canned. The story â€” Vincent starts babysitting for Oliver, a friendship is born and tested â€” is the least of it. Resistance is understandable but futile.

A big, sloppy wet kiss of a movie about an old grouch, a sweet kid and their odd-couple friendship, â€œSt. Vincentâ€ù has a couple of things going for it, mostly Bill Murray. For some time now, Mr. Murray has been burnishing his cult in Wes Anderson films, where he adds Murrayesque mystery and bite â€” is he deep or just dyspeptic? â€” and his unforgettable silent-clown mug to Mr. Andersonâ€™s worlds of wonder. Sometimes, Mr. Murray pops up for a paycheck, while at other times, he slips into a character that promises something more than the usual slop offered men over 60, like Franklin Delano Roosevelt in â€œHyde Park on Hudsonâ€ù or an architect on a World War II mission in â€œThe Monuments Men.â€ù

Raising significant questions about the psychological effects of poverty on young children, this unsettlingly direct stab at atonement feels genuine. Mr. Monroeâ€™s past is studded with examples of deception; it will be up to the viewer to decide if his remorse is one of them.

Assembled over seven years (some of them while Mr. Monroe was in film school at New York University), â€œEvolutionâ€ù comes across as part exorcism, part cleansing confession â€” the fifth step in a 12-step agenda of rehabilitation and renewal. The crime itself, conducted with two accomplices and an unloaded shotgun, unfolds in unglamorous re-enactments. Yet it underscores Mr. Monroeâ€™s clear intelligence (he called in a bomb threat to his high school to keep the police busy that day) and leaves niggling loose ends â€” not the least of which being the vague accounting for the more than $100,000 that Mr. Monroe later left on his motherâ€™s bed.

Constructed with an unvarnished simplicity that â€” perhaps deliberately â€” bolsters our impression of guilelessness, Mr. Monroeâ€™s tale unfolds primarily through the eyes of a parade of witnesses, most of them family members. Not one of these would have believed Mr. Monroeâ€™s 16-year-old self capable of executing the 1997 bank robbery that would send him to prison for five years. Instead, they recall â€œa warm childâ€ù with excellent grades whose sensitivity to his motherâ€™s deepening financial difficulties radically transformed both his personality and his future.

Neil Berkeleyâ€™s indulgent but not always illuminating new documentary, â€œHarmontown,â€ù embraces the cult of personality surrounding Dan Harmon, creator of the NBC television show â€œCommunity.â€ù Mr. Berkeleyâ€™s insistent film follows Mr. Harmon on a comedy tour for his podcast (titled â€œHarmontownâ€ù), taking care to praise his skills and parse his needy personality.
Opens on Friday

The relationship between Mr. Harmon and his long-suffering girlfriend gets a few pointedly uncomfortable moments, though the notion that living with a maniac television writer on the road has its ups and downs isnâ€™t the biggest surprise, or fully done justice. Despite the confessional aspect of his film, Mr. Berkeley aims to influence audience reactions in a manner recalling sitcoms of older vintage.

Mr. Harmon puts (much of) his life as a brilliant, procrastinating wordsmith on display, including his nearly mythologized dismissal from his own show. (He was eventually rehired.) Yet Mr. Berkeleyâ€™s film proves as stiflingly eager to please as its subject. Repeated praise of Mr. Harmonâ€™s nerdy fan base keeps emphasizing how appreciative its members are for his shining a light. Little splurts from an ingratiating score nudge us along.
Directed by Neil Berkeley
HARMONTOWN

Mr. Harmonâ€™s live show consists of him and Jeff B. Davis bantering in front of audiences, with dry assists from a bearded dungeon master named Spencer Crittenden. Mr. Harmon is delightfully talented at improvisation, freestyling nonsense lyrics. Mr. Berkeley, on the other hand, proves himself a dismayingly predictable chronicler, making sure that we know exactly what weâ€™re supposed to think and efficiently packaging jokes and revelations.
1 hour 41 minutes; not rated

Every Muhammad Ali documentary has its own hook. The Oscar-winning â€œWhen We Were Kingsâ€ù (1996) chronicled his 1974 Rumble in the Jungle with George Foreman. â€œThe Trials of Muhammad Aliâ€ù (2013) zeroed in on his politics and refusal to fight in Vietnam. â€œI Am Aliâ€ù focuses on his personal life, showcasing private audio recordings he made for posterity. Itâ€™s divided into chapters by interview: â€œThe Brotherâ€™s Story,â€ù for Rahman Ali; â€œThe Trainerâ€™s Story,â€ù for Angelo Dundee; â€œThe Rookieâ€™s Story,â€ù for Mike Tyson, and so on.
â€œI Am Aliâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Allusions to Mr. Aliâ€™s infidelities.

This overlong film also illuminates Mr. Aliâ€™s evolving relationships with opponents, from Mr. Foreman to Joe Frazier. His present-day absence from the screen â€” he has had Parkinsonâ€™s disease for many years â€” remains an understandable if unfortunate omission.

Yet thereâ€™s so much great vintage footage of Ali â€” â€œI understand you have a queen of England, but you donâ€™t have a king,â€ù he says to the British media after showing up for a fight, wearing a crown â€” and heâ€™s so charismatic, it would be hard to watch the movie and not take something from it.

Although not strictly chronological, the movie covers ground from the day Mr. Ali took up boxing to his final fight in 1981. Not all of the material feels fresh. George Lois, who designed the 1968 Esquire cover that posed Mr. Ali as a St. Sebastian, shares the same anecdote that he did in the recent film â€œSmiling Through the Apocalypse.â€ù

The long, intricate final scene transcends psychological drama with a surge of pure musical inspiration, pushing the audienceâ€™s response from curiosity to empathy to awe. Just try to sit still in your seat. â€œWhiplashâ€ù may not quite be a great movie, but thereâ€™s no doubt that it knows a thing or two about what greatness means.

Andrew is a young man at a crossroad. He can either pursue normal activities for a person his age â€” dating Nicole (Melissa Benoist), a Fordham student; going to the movies with his dad (Paul Reiser) â€” or he can practice until blood splashes on the skins of his drums in hopes of impressing his mentor. â€œWhiplash,â€ù which takes its title from one of the tunes Andrew must master, neatly maps out the nature and cost of this choice, and the anguish and exhilaration it brings him.

You can think of the mad-mentor plot as a songbook standard, a familiar composition transformed by the distinctive interpretation of a gifted group of performers. Mr. Teller and Mr. Simmons work through a lively and complicated duet of aggression, suspicion and unspoken complicity, with spellbinding results. They know how to play serious artists, because thatâ€™s exactly what they are.

But Andrew eagerly signs up for Fletcherâ€™s cult of perfection, though whether in the role of acolyte or human sacrifice remains in question for most of the movie. Andrew is not one for modest aspirations: He wants to vault beyond the masses of session guys and second-stringers into the pantheon, to keep company with Buddy Rich and Charlie Parker and the other giants of the art form. This makes him a bit insufferable, and Mr. Teller, adept at finding the ambiguous middle ground between self-confident nice guy and smug jerk, is not shy about demonstrating Andrewâ€™s arrogance. (A recent interview in The New York Times suggests that he may share his characterâ€™s seriousness and self-confidence.)

Still, the battle of master and disciple is exciting and terrifying to witness, and, at its best, the film can feel as wild and spontaneous, as risky and precise, as a live jam session. The music â€” original compositions by Justin Hurwitz, Mr. Chazelleâ€™s collaborator on â€œGuy and Madeline,â€ù supplemented by some classic jazz numbers â€” is potent and pungent.

Fletcher has a first name, but nobody has the nerve to use it, and in classic drill sergeant or gym teacher fashion, he calls his students by their surnames, generally in the course of browbeating and humiliating them. Progressive pedagogical methods have not penetrated the room where his studio band practices, a virtually all-male preserve of sarcasm, sadism and enforced virtuosity. There is nowhere Andrew would rather be.

Mr. Chazelle, a 29-year-old natural-born filmmaker whose previous feature was the stylistically daring, hipster-cute musical romance â€œGuy and Madeline on a Park Bench,â€ù has an aficionadoâ€™s ear for jazz and an offbeat sense of genre. He and the director of photography, Sharone Meir, give â€œWhiplashâ€ù the brooding, spooky look of a horror movie, turning the New York streets and the school hallways into a realm of deep, expressive shadows. There is an atmosphere of whispery menace, and Mr. Simmons prowls the screen with a vampireâ€™s stealth and a killerâ€™s wry half-smile. Fletcher is a seductive monster, swiveling from charm to nonchalance to violent rage with a snap of the fingers. The scariest words a studio band player will ever hear are â€œnot quite my tempo.â€ù

The world worships excellence and runs on mediocrity. Most of us are fated to dwell in the fat middle of the bell curve, admiring and envying those who stake out territory in the higher realms of achievement. There is a wide gulf between doing your best at something and being the best at it, a discrepancy in expended effort and anticipated reward that is the subject of â€œWhiplash,â€ù Damien Chazelleâ€™s thrilling second feature.

This story of an ambitious young striver and his difficult mentor could easily have been a sports movie, and structurally, it resembles one. There are montages of grueling practice scattered among scenes of tense competition, all of it building toward a hugely suspenseful (but also, to some extent, never in doubt) championship game moment of reckoning. But Andrew Neiman (Miles Teller) is a jazz drummer rather than an athlete, enrolled at a highly selective Manhattan school (Juilliard in all but name) and under the sway of a charismatic and terrifying instructor, Fletcher (J. K. Simmons).

By going deeper into the details of musicianship than most such movies â€” by allowing us to hear things as Andrew and Fletcher do, and to understand the endless and exacting discipline of their work â€” this one breaks free of the constraints of realism and takes wing toward the sublime. It may get a few things wrong, but it aims at, and finally achieves, an authenticity at once more exalted and more primal than mere verisimilitude.

Maybe a little too neatly at times. For all its dexterity and assurance, the movie has its share of false notes and rhythmic stumbles. The contrast between Fletcher and Andrewâ€™s father, who long ago gave up his dreams of literary glory to become a teacher, is drawn a little too emphatically, as if nice guy and artist were completely antithetical. A few plot twists test the limits of credibility. And there is something a little dispiriting â€” if sadly unsurprising â€” about the way Mr. Chazelle turns a historically African-American art form into the existential arena for a couple of white guys.
â€œWhiplashâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Unkind things are said about mothers, even though no mothers appear in the film.

Mr. Cuesta does his best work in the early scenes of Garyâ€™s sleuthing, which develop a nice, agitated pulse. And because Garyâ€™s dawning awareness of the storyâ€™s magnitude mirrors your experience as a moviegoer (you figure it out together), and because Mr. Cuesta keeps you close at Garyâ€™s side, you feel invested in his fate. But the film falters as the story swells and churns, and real people like Representative Maxine Waters of California enter the fray in clips alongside fictionalized scenes meant to look like documentary footage. Garyâ€™s story comes under attack, including from big media types, and he enters a downward spiral as so, too, does the film. There are high-horse speeches, long goodbyes, enveloping sadness, a sense of doom; mostly, there is a journalist betrayed by many factors, including his own calling.

Written by Peter Landesman, â€œKill the Messengerâ€ù is based on a book by Nick Schou about Mr. Webb, his rise and fall, and Mr. Webbâ€™s own book, â€œDark Alliance,â€ù his 1998 follow-up to his much-heralded, much-contested 1996 Mercury News series. The film tracks Gary as he reports the story, opening soon after a slinky number, Coral Baca (Paz Vega), hands him a Pandoraâ€™s box of a tip. Baca points Gary in the direction of Danilo Blandon (Yul Vazquez), a Nicaraguan drug smuggler and contra supporter who supplies product to a Los Angeles dealer, Ricky Ross (Michael Kenneth Williams). Suddenly, Gary is at a foreign prison visiting another shadowy power player, Norwin Meneses (Andy Garcia), who swans around the yard in a straw hat twirling a golf club.
â€œKill the Messengerâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Adult language.

The big speech in â€œKill the Messenger,â€ù a likable if formulaically pulse-pounding fiction about a real investigative reporter, Gary Webb, arrives near the end. By then, Gary (Jeremy Renner, affable and on cruise control), has tramped, in victory and defeat, through his newspaper, The San Jose Mercury News, and parachuted in and out of danger while chasing a name-making story. Itâ€™s the mid-1990s. Mobile phones are as big as clown shoes, and a cutie named Monica Lewinsky has been working in the White House. Gary should be riding high after reporting a series, â€œDark Alliance,â€ù linking the Central Intelligence Agency with Nicaraguan contras and the wildfire-like spread of crack through black neighborhoods in Los Angeles. Instead, he sounds and looks haunted or maybe hunted.

The director Michael Cuesta started as an independent filmmaker (his credits include â€œL.I.E.â€ù) but, like many other indies, also works in television. He directed the pilot of â€œHomelandâ€ù (heâ€™s one of its executive producers) and helped establish its insinuatingly intimate, often claustrophobic feel and nervous rhythms, partly through its hand-held camerawork. The look that Mr. Cuesta and his director of photography, Sean Bobbitt, give â€œKill the Messengerâ€ù at times evokes â€œHomeland,â€ù but the movieâ€™s cinematography isnâ€™t as frenetic and self-consciously raw, and thereâ€™s less bobbing and weaving. Even so, the visual choices in the movie, including all the close-ups of Garyâ€™s face as it lightens and darkens, help create the sense that something deeply personal is at stake.

At some point in almost every movie set in the world of journalism, someone drops a big speech about the Truth. â€œNothingâ€™s riding on this,â€ù an editor growls at Woodward and Bernstein in the film â€œAll the Presidentâ€™s Menâ€ù amid the horror-flick gloom, â€œexcept the First Amendment of the Constitution, freedom of the press and maybe the future of the country.â€ù The rare exception to this big speech rule may be â€œHis Girl Friday,â€ù the greatest movie ever set in a newsroom, which ditched sanctimony for the syncopated report of wits firing at each other like Tommy guns.

The dreary action film â€œKiteâ€ù takes place in a dystopian city with an impressive range of accents and acting styles. Children are trafficked in sex slavery by â€œflesh-cartels.â€ù Sawa (India Eisley) makes it her mission to free them and to avenge her parentsâ€™ deaths. Sheâ€™s aided by her fatherâ€™s former partner, Karl (Samuel L. Jackson), a cop who supplies her with weapons and plies her with a memory-erasing drug.

Furthering the atmosphere of designer slaughter, Sawa shoots the villains with grenade ammo that redundantly explodes the corpsesâ€™ skulls. Other pleasantries include Ms. Eisleyâ€™s engaging in an elaborate Mata Hari seduction and being tortured with a vat of fryer grease. (Until now, she has been best known for her work in televisionâ€™s â€œThe Secret Life of the American Teenager.â€ù)
â€œKiteâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Everything.

Nasty for nastinessâ€™s sake, â€œKiteâ€ù drags to achieve its brief running time; you wonder whether the slow motion is an artistic device or a stalling tactic. Ms. Eisley may be flustered on purpose (Sawa is a traumatized addict), but she has no chemistry with Mr. Jackson, whose phoned-in performance suggests he can relate to his characterâ€™s mercenary instincts.
â€œMeet the Mormonsâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Implicit proselytizing.

â€œMeet the Mormonsâ€ù begins from an oddly defensive posture, with its M.C. and narrator, Jenna Kim Jones, interviewing passers-by in Times Square about their perceptions of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Television and movie clips bolster the notion that the media fosters stereotypes of the religion. (The blockbuster musical around the corner goes curiously undiscussed.) â€œWhat are Mormons really like?â€ù Ms. Jones asks. â€œYou decide.â€ù

One subjectâ€™s discussion of his efforts to â€œput the Lord firstâ€ù exemplifies how the film preaches to the converted. The narration promises surprises (â€œThis story may challenge what you think you know about the roles men and women play in Mormon homesâ€ù), but the movie might have started by examining its straw-man conception of the audience.

The most compelling figure is Gail S. Halvorsen, a nonagenarian pilot who dropped candy during the Berlin airlift. As much as the film tries to draw a connection, whatâ€™s noteworthy about his story has little to do with religion.

To support its pitch, this infomercial-like documentary takes us into six homes. We meet an African-American bishop in Atlanta; a United States Navy football coach who avoids meetings on Sundays; a kickboxing husband and wife in Costa Rica; and a humanitarian in Katmandu. A once-homeless mother living in Salt Lake City offers the clearest explanation of how becoming a Mormon changed her life. But mostly the idea is just that these are diverse, interesting families â€” as if that should be so shocking.

Probably not. â€œAlexander,â€ù directed by Miguel Arteta, written by Rob Lieber and based on Judith Viorstâ€™s beloved 1972 picture book, is less an act of spite than a failure of nerve. It approaches its young audience with an anxious, condescending smile that masks an unmistakable panic. What if they donâ€™t like it? What if theyâ€™re bored? Or scared? Or upset? What if their parents take offense? To guard against such unwelcome responses, the movie tosses out a hectic barrage of almost-naughty jokes and gags (vomit is shown; poop is mentioned), reassuring speeches and constant signals that no matter what goes wrong, everything will be all right in the end.

But in turning Ms. Viorstâ€™s book (which has previously been adapted as a musical for the stage and an animated HBO short film) into a family caper, the filmmakers have robbed it of its empathy and insight. The original both has fun with and makes fun of Alexanderâ€™s frustration with the unfairness of the world and his own impotence. It is not afraid to show the conflicts that can roil even the most loving family.

On the eve of his 12th birthday, Alexander (Ed Oxenbould) finds himself the odd man out in his relentlessly upbeat family. Mom (Jennifer Garner), who works at a publishing company, is in line for a big promotion if her latest title â€” an inspirational toilet-training manual for toddlers and their parents â€” takes off. Dad (Steve Carell), a laid-off aeronautical engineer turned cheerful stay-at-home father, has a job interview with a video game company. Alexanderâ€™s big sister (Kerris Dorsey) has the lead in the middle school production of â€œPeter Pan,â€ù while his big brother (Dylan Minnette) has a prom date with â€œthe hottest girl in schoolâ€ù (Bella Thorne). The baby is content until Alexander accidentally destroys his favorite pacifier.

The movie is terrified of just that and goes so far in its insistence on harmony that it starts to feel actively dishonest, repressing the very energies it is pretending to unleash. Rather than recognizing themselves, their parents and their siblings on the screen, children in the audience are likely to wonder just who these smiling, anxious people are supposed to be. And then to forget the whole thing.

In frustration, Alexander wishes a bad day on all of them and then is appalled when it seems that his curse comes to life. Everything goes wrong, but somehow not quite wrong enough. The mishaps never rise to the level of true farce, in spite of Mr. Carellâ€™s gifts as a physical comedian and Ms. Garnerâ€™s knack for acting stressed out.
â€œAlexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Dayâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). Mildly provocative humor and very bad driving.

â€œAlexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Dayâ€ù is the latest example of a wonderful childrenâ€™s book turned into a mediocre movie. This kind of thing happens so frequently â€” exceptions like â€œWhere the Wild Things Areâ€ù and, arguably, â€œShrekâ€ù prove the rule upheld by every recent big-screen Dr. Seuss adaptation â€” that you could almost believe that there is malice involved. Movie studios do a pretty good job of making pleasing, sometimes transporting family entertainment out of original ideas or ancient folklore. Why do they keep messing up the kiddie lit? Are they doing it on purpose?

In the film, which shares a title with Mr. Pottsâ€™s memoir, Paul (played as an adult by James Corden) grows up bullied, with a passion for opera and a lack of confidence. He travels to Venice for training but falters during a performance for Luciano Pavarotti, an episode apparently embellished here. â€œOne Chanceâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Bullying, innuendo.

The appealing Mr. Corden manages the not insignificant task of maintaining interest in a story whose climax has already been passed around on YouTube. When the amateur opera singer Paul Potts took top honors on â€œBritainâ€™s Got Talentâ€ù in 2007, he probably didnâ€™t foresee the additional reward of a biographical movie â€” much less one produced by Simon Cowell, a notoriously surly judge on that show.

In â€œCatch Hell,â€ù Ryan Phillippe plays a young actor who has seen better days, especially once heâ€™s been kidnapped by two bayou thugs and brutally beaten. Thereâ€™s a dull edge of satire to the setup: Reagan Pearce (Mr. Phillippe) arrives in Shreveport, La., for an apparently amateur-hour shoot. The next morning, a van whisks him away â€” not to the set, but to a swamp-side shack. Chained abuse and modern celebrity nightmares (such as the appropriation of his Twitter account) follow. His captors are Mike (Ian Barford), a well-groomed security guard whoâ€™s unhinged but not very frightening, and his doting nephew, Junior (Stephen Louis Grush).

What to make of an actor-turned-director giving someone like himself the third degree? A confessional ending oddly suggests penitence for unhealthy living, and what sticks out most is the filmâ€™s earnestness â€” that, and the goofball credit sequence featuring Junior in a gator suit shaking a tail feather for Pearce.

Mr. Phillippe, his looks suitably softening and his character daubed with a neat slash of blood, plays an average-dude actor with a filmography a bit like his own (â€œCruel Intentions,â€ù â€œGosford Park,â€ù â€œCrashâ€ù). This is his feature-length directorial debut, and the suspense isnâ€™t well orchestrated. Neither is Pearceâ€™s move from dejected acceptance to iron-willed resistance. And the treatment of the shackâ€™s space becomes erratic, as does the obliviously guitar-skittering score.

Holly (Madeline Zima), a lawyer, and Guy (Joel David Moore), an accountant, meet in a bar, sleep together and must continue to coexist the next morning because her carâ€™s back at the lot. What follows might have made for a stage play in the 1980s, but it unfolds as more of a 1990s indie affirmation of our capacity to be loved if we just open up to one another.
