Largely a two-hander, or a two-seater, â€œ#Stuckâ€ù sticks with a man and a woman who are cooped up together during an interminable Los Angeles traffic jam, and every minute of their captivity is keenly felt. All they start with in common is a drunken hookup the night before, and this allows the filmâ€™s writer and director, Stuart Acher, to lead us down a nattering road to mutual appreciation and triumph over shame.

Holly is supposed to be out of Guyâ€™s league, but neither of them is up to carrying scene after scene of weak sparring and punny flirting. Their frustrations prove contagious, and the prospect of romance is less persuasive than the implicit argument for a better public transportation network.

David Williams hates it when people call him a librarian, especially his glamorous wifeâ€™s snobby friends. David (Rupert Evans), the protagonist of â€œThe Canal,â€ù is a film archivist, and his viewing of some newly donated footage sets this Irish horror story in motion. Not so much because that footage documents a grisly 1902 family blood bath, but because the murders took place in Davidâ€™s house.

When his wife (Hannah Hoekstra) disappears and is found drowned, David is the prime suspect. Yet a growing body of evidence suggests to him that it was the 1902 murderer, whose demonic spirit still lives in the house.

The film is helped by an array of fine, low-key supporting performances, by Antonia Campbell-Hughes as Davidâ€™s quiet (and possibly adoring) co-worker; Kelly Byrne as the baby-faced nanny; Anneke Blok as his mother-in-law; and Steve Oram as the cynical detective who never believes a word David says. And Calum Heath, as Davidâ€™s baffled little son, Billy, is fantastic in a way that seems otherworldly but could be beginnerâ€™s luck.

The filmâ€™s writer and director, Ivan Kavanagh, and his team pull off a few enjoyable, decently creepy scares, but over all, the action is too cryptic, and the pedestrian dialogue doesnâ€™t help. Neither does the completely unconvincing â€œold film.â€ù Still, thereâ€™s a hint of frisson, just enough to make you hope for a Hollywood remake. Meanwhile, beware of cracks in the wall; things can get in â€” and out.

Or, as Forster puts it: â€œÂ â€˜The king died, and then the queen diedâ€™ is a story. â€˜The king died, and then the queen died of griefâ€™ is a plot.â€ù If the queen dies, and no one knows why until itâ€™s discovered that she died from grief, mystery enters, allowing the plot to suspend the time-sequence and move â€œas far away from the story as its limitations will allow.â€ù
â€œThe Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Him/Her is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Violence, drinking and the usual adult language.

No matter how he shuffles the pieces, Mr. Benson canâ€™t shake free of the old storytelling ideas, from his steamroller plot to his programmatic characters and narrative beats that, by their very existence, signal that everything will slide into place as expected. Mr. Bensonâ€™s plot contortions brought me back to E. M. Forsterâ€™s discussions of plot and story. In â€œAspects of the Novel,â€ù Forster writes that a story is â€œa narrative of events arranged in their time-sequence.â€ù A plot â€œis also a narrative of events, the emphasis falling on causality.â€ù

My colleague A. O. Scott reviewed â€œThemâ€ù when it opened. (Think of that review as His; think of this one as Hers.) Since the basics in â€œHim/Herâ€ù are the same as in â€œThem,â€ù you may want to read that review before reading more. I donâ€™t have much to add, other than that I didnâ€™t believe the characters, their exchanges or existential conditions, partly because Jessica Chastain, who plays Eleanor (Her), and James McAvoy, who plays her husband, Conor (Him), donâ€™t register as people who have suffered catastrophic loss. This is less about puffy eyes than the absence of a deep, engulfing grief that can close the distance between you and the screen.

In â€œEleanor Rigby,â€ù Mr. Benson recurrently plays with the storyâ€™s time-sequence â€” Eleanor and Conorâ€™s son died, and then their marriage fell apart â€” by slipping back and forth between the past and present and his and her sides. The idea, it seems, is to show how they experience life, together and apart, as they struggle to put their pieces together, a struggle that mirrors the directorâ€™s. Thatâ€™s because, try as Mr. Benson might, his narrative ambitions are thwarted by narrative conventions that lead him to smooth every jagged edge and dry each teary eye. â€œCharacters must not brood too long,â€ù as Forster also dryly observed, or â€œwaste time running up and down ladders in their own insides.â€ù They have to serve the big finish â€” or, in this case, three.

If â€œThe Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Him/Herâ€ù sounds familiar, thereâ€™s a reason. Last month, a variation on the same story â€” and featuring the same actors, locations and so on â€” opened under the title â€œThe Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby.â€ù Running a bit over two hours, that â€œEleanor Rigbyâ€ù tells the sad tale of a broken marriage from the blended perspectives of a husband and wife after the death of their baby. The director and writer Ned Benson calls this first movie â€œThem.â€ù â€œHim/Herâ€ù is actually two movies that are being released in a single 3 hour and 16 minute heave that splits the drama in half, with each part centered on one spouseâ€™s point of view. (Their order depends on when and where you see the movie â€” you could see â€œHer/Himâ€ù.)

Although â€œHerâ€ù and â€œHimâ€ù relate many of the same events, they do so through Eleanorâ€™s and Conorâ€™s separate perspectives and, to that end, share some scenes that look similar yet also somehow different in their palettes, camera angles and the like. These modifications largely feel like tinkering; they donâ€™t enlarge the story or deepen the characters, not even when Eleanor and Conor declare their love. There seem to be fewer shared scenes in â€œHim,â€ù which makes Conorâ€™s account more engaging because you havenâ€™t already watched (and rewatched) the same events. Although the novelty of this repetition and Mr. Bensonâ€™s adjustments pull you in like a new puzzle, his actual ideas â€” about people, their stories and how to tell those stories â€” turn out to be fairly straight.

The premise: Five friends go on a road trip in search of off-the-grid Halloween haunted houses â€” those that are rumored to be far scarier than the mainstream versions that cater to 12-year-olds. Various legends are duly noted early on, about haunted houses that use actual body parts instead of props, haunted houses where people have died, and so on. You know this trip is not going to end well.

Fifteen years after â€œThe Blair Witch Project,â€ù can the found-footage gimmick still result in a scary movie? â€œThe Houses October Builtâ€ù dares to ask that question, and sure, if youâ€™re relatively easily scared or are in a theater full of people who are, the film might be good for a few screams. But only if youâ€™re the patient sort. It takes almost an hour to get to the good stuff.

But the film is two-thirds gone before the five are placed in any real jeopardy, which seems like a long time to wait for the payoff. And the pivotal sequence involves black hoods, the kind used in the real-life horror stories coming out of the Middle East recently. Itâ€™s a coincidental reference â€” the film was shot several years ago â€” but found-footage movies work only if you can stay immersed in the fantasy.

Who doesnâ€™t? Various secrets come dribbling out â€” about the paternity of Samanthaâ€™s daughter (Leighton Meester), about the car accident that ruined Glenâ€™s baseball career and about the judge himself. They add up to a sprawl of narrative that is as unconvincing as the suspiciously sprawl-free, nostalgia-tinged town where it all takes place.

Early in â€œThe Judge,â€ù Hank Palmer, a hotshot Chicago defense lawyer played by Robert Downey Jr. with his usual fast-talking swagger, learns that his mother has died. He packs a bag, says goodbye to his unfaithful wife and his adorable daughter (Emma Tremblay), and jumps in his Ferrari.

The road to that touching, foreordained moment passes through enough dramatic incident for three movies, none of them terribly original. For a while, Hankâ€™s prodigal return is played for gentle, knowing laughs, as a comedy about a city slicker slumming it with the good country folk and rediscovering his roots in the process. He also rediscovers his high school sweetheart, Samantha, played by Vera Farmiga.

Once home, Hank rediscovers the family from which heâ€™s been mostly estranged and runs into a few other people too, all of them played by fine actors encouraged to graze in a meadow overgrown with thickets of plot and clumps of easy sentimentality. Hank is the middle brother in a trio, flanked by Glen (Vincent Dâ€™Onofrio), a high school baseball star settled into middle-aged disappointment, and Dale (Jeremy Strong), who has the kind of mental disability encountered only in movies: He walks around with a Super-8 camera, asking naÃ¯ve questions that are alternately good for a cute laugh and preternaturally wise. He is less a sibling than a mascot.

The patriarch of the Palmer brood is the title character and the only reason to take an interest in this movie, since he is played by Robert Duvall. Judge Palmer (even his sons call him that) does not represent anything new for Mr. Duvall. Heâ€™s crusty, but with an occasional twinkle in his eye and a well-hidden soft spot. He is, more precisely, a collection of personality traits in search of a coherent character, which Mr. Duvall, by dint of sheer professionalism, comes very close to supplying.
â€œThe Judgeâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Father-son swearing contests.

He drives only as far as the airport, however. Even though his Rockwellesque hometown is in Indiana, just one state over, Hank decides to fly rather than drive. Presumably to save time â€” something this long, baggy, meandering film, directed by David Dobkin from a screenplay by Nick Schenk and Bill Dubuque, otherwise has very little interest in doing.

What we know about the judge at the outset is that he was a domestic autocrat (a somewhat kinder version of the bad dad from â€œThe Great Santiniâ€ù) who doted on his wife and has been sober for nearly three decades. On the bench, he is stern but fair, tempering his reverence for the law with a sense of humor and an occasional display of mercy. He and Hank donâ€™t get along, though the smart money will be on their eventual reconciliation.

And then â€œThe Judgeâ€ù turns into a crime story, and a supershouty, macho-weepy, buried-family-secrets melodrama. A fellow just out of the penitentiary has died in a hit and run, and his blood turns up on the fender of the old manâ€™s Cadillac. Guess who represents him in the murder trial that unfolds in his very own courtroom? THE OVERNIGHTERS
â€œThe Overnightersâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Sex is discussed, and individuals are menaced by gun and broom.

â€œThe Overnightersâ€ù is an onion of a movie. Composed of multiple layers â€” more than one of which might bring tears to your eyes â€” this shape-shifting documentary begins as one thing and ends as quite another.
Directed by Jesse Moss

â€œItâ€™s easy to become a facade,â€ù Pastor Reinke allows at the beginning of the film. What he becomes, however, is a complex, sometimes prickly good Samaritan who may be using the pain of others to mask his own â€” a living embodiment of the maxim that no good deed goes unpunished for long.

1 hour 40 minutes

Filming alone from 2012-13, the director, Jesse Moss, plays it as it lays. An observational, near-invisible presence, he fills the frame with the faces of economic deprivation and bad choices, neither judging nor sugarcoating. What emerges is a blue-collar meditation on the meaning of community and the imperative of compassion, one that endures even as an unexpectedly prurient drama unfolds at its center.

Straddling both is Jay Reinke, a Lutheran pastor whose small town in North Dakota has been overrun by thousands of migrant workers drawn by the booming oil business. Opening his church and his home to shelter men with nowhere to sleep â€” and sometimes with criminal records â€” soon draws the ire of his congregation and neighbors. But as Pastor Reinke tirelessly advocates tolerance from city officials and anxious residents, his commitment to the men develops an intensity that begins to seem borderline codependent.

When we meet the principals of â€œThe Pact 2,â€ù they are already intimately acquainted with death: Not only does June (Camilla Luddington of â€œGreyâ€™s Anatomyâ€ù) work by day as a cleaner of grisly crime scenes, but she also moonlights drawing horror comics. Her boyfriend, Daniel (Scott Michael Foster), a cop, had a father who ran a mortuary. So maybe we shouldnâ€™t be surprised when the Judas killer (Mark Steger), a malevolent spirit, comes a-knocking for June.

The directors, Dallas Hallam and Patrick Horvath, are fluent in the genreâ€™s staples (creaky interiors, slamming doors, yada yada yada), lighting schemes and startling edits. And they draw decent work from their actors, who commit to the wispy, subtext-free material.

Fortunately, sheâ€™s aided by Annie (a steady, appealing Caity Lotz), back from â€œThe Pact,â€ù who offers insight and company while June pokes around a dark, empty house, seeking the homicidal wraith who killed her mother. Also offering counsel are a mysterious blind medium (an effective Haley Hudson, another â€œPactâ€ù alumna) and an F.B.I. agent (Patrick Fischler) on the murdererâ€™s trail.

Was it budgetary concerns that deprived the featured baddie of a distinct visual gimmick, like Freddy Kruegerâ€™s blade-fingers or Leatherfaceâ€™s leathery face? The Judas killer has only a muscular physique and what appears to be a bullet hole in his forehead. Will he be denied another sequel? Not bloody likely.

Unseen and unheard, the Romanian director Teodora Ana Mihai â€” whose parents fled to Belgium during the Ceausescu regime, leaving her behind for a year as collateral for the secret service â€” captures the siblingsâ€™ emotional limbo with evident empathy. Their home is a cramped apartment in Bacau, their daily routine giving Georgiana little time to study for important exams. Capably mediating disputes and comforting the little ones, she never complains; only on rare outings with friends do we see her serious, patient features transform into those of the carefree teenager she may never have the chance to become.

â€œGod, Iâ€™m not having any children,â€ù Georgiana Halmac, 15, says with mock severity midway through â€œWaiting for August,â€ù a fly-on-the-wall portrait of seven Romanian siblings whose mother is working as a housekeeper in Italy. Even if Georgianaâ€™s pronouncement were in earnest, who could blame her? As cook, cleaner, laundress and caretaker â€” thereâ€™s no father in the picture â€” Georgiana is the de facto adult in a household of children and teenagers, who all accept their temporarily orphaned status with admirable equanimity.

Soft in tone and muted in color, â€œWaiting for Augustâ€ù is a childâ€™s-eye view of one family â€” among many in todayâ€™s Romanian economy â€” rising to the challenge of living without parents. On Skype and on the telephone, in conversations and in the mail, the mother is a constant, longing presence, her summer return a fixed point of anticipation. For Georgianaâ€™s sake, we hope it will be for good.

Staying loyal to â€œYouâ€™re Not Youâ€ù requires a huge leap of faith early in the movie, when Kate overrules Evanâ€™s choice of a caretaker and insists on hiring Bec, who is clumsy, canâ€™t cook and has no nursing experience beyond some volunteer work while in high school. An indication of her domestic ineptitude is the mess she makes by packing vegetables in a blender, then running the machine without putting on the lid. Despite her motherâ€™s scorn, Bec sticks to her job, learns how to cook and becomes Kateâ€™s medical advocate. But why Kate chose Bec remains a mystery.

The movieâ€™s central relationship is the fraught bond between Kateâ€™s demure classical musician and the tempestuous Bec. Ms. Rossumâ€™s performance is equal in power to Ms. Swankâ€™s. The movie pointedly contrasts Kateâ€™s upper-class decorum with Becâ€™s rowdiness. And when the film brings in Becâ€™s mean, disapproving mother (Marcia Gay Harden), who sneers that her daughter squanders her time and energy on projects doomed to fail, you understand why Bec is driven by self-loathing rebellion.

â€œYouâ€™re Not Youâ€ù doesnâ€™t have the feisty, larger-than-life vitality of a character like Aurora Greenway, who was played to the hilt by Shirley MacLaine in â€œTerms of Endearment.â€ù The closest equivalent is Bec, Kateâ€™s unlikely caretaker (Emmy Rossum). A hard-drinking, drug-taking, promiscuous college student and aspiring singer-songwriter, Bec reflexively rebuffs romantic overtures once sex is over. Many of the characters in the film, set in Texas, have a Lone Star swagger, but Bec is the most combative.

The story doesnâ€™t politely halt as Kateâ€™s death approaches. There are heated arguments about whether to follow her end-of-life wishes. Despite holes in the storytelling, Ms. Swank and Ms. Rossum keep it real.
â€œLetâ€™s get one thing clear,â€ù she declares to a man she picked up in a bar the previous night and pounced on voraciously. â€œIâ€™m not girlfriend material!â€ù

â€œOh, no,â€ù you may say to yourself. â€œAnother disease-of-the-week tear-jerker!â€ù But in its forthright honesty, â€œYouâ€™re Not You,â€ù directed by George C. Wolfe from Shana Feste and Jordan Robertsâ€™s adaptation of Michelle Wildgenâ€™s popular novel, belongs to the upper ranks of a genre whose modern prototype remains James L. Brooksâ€™s 1983 blockbuster, â€œTerms of Endearment.â€ù

Ms. Swank registers every subtle change in Kateâ€™s body and mind as her condition worsens. You feel the despair of a musician whose abilities are taken away and her rage and humiliation when she discovers that Evan has betrayed her. That is followed by her guilt and sorrow over â€œwhat I did to your life,â€ù as she tells him later.

As everyone surely must know, thanks to the widely publicized ice bucket challenge to raise money for A.L.S. research, this progressive ailment â€” also known as Lou Gehrigâ€™s disease â€” affects nerve cells in the brain that control voluntary muscle movement. As their condition worsens, patients have increasing difficulty walking, talking and breathing. Many die from respiratory failure. Ms. Swankâ€™s meticulous, unsparing depiction of the symptoms, which can be excruciating to observe, seems to come from deep inside.
â€œYouâ€™re Not Youâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has sexual content, strong language and brief drug use.

â€œYouâ€™re Not Youâ€ù begins with Kateâ€™s 35th-birthday party. She and her husband, Evan (Josh Duhamel), are blissfully in love and surrounded by friends. When Kate sits down at the piano to play Chopinâ€™s Polonaise in A flat major, she notices a tremor in her fingers. Wasting no time, â€œYouâ€™re Not Youâ€ù leaps ahead a year and a half. Kate, no longer able to play the piano, is feeble and uses a wheelchair. Her enunciation is beginning to be garbled.

In â€œYouâ€™re Not You,â€ù Hilary Swankâ€™s portrayal of Kate, a gifted concert pianist with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, is so intensely persuasive that once youâ€™re engaged by her wrenching ordeal, you mostly forgive the movieâ€™s emotional manipulation.

If there were an award for best-looking cast, the director Bille Woodruffâ€™s â€œAddictedâ€ù would take the prize â€” or at least be nominated. Led by Sharon Leal and Boris Kodjoe, the actors are uniformly handsome and mostly serviceable, though the same canâ€™t be said about the filmmaking or the writing.

Zoe seems to have it all, but there are cracks in the foundation of the life she has built with her husband (Mr. Kodjoe, effective despite being given too little to work with). They have a seemingly healthy sex life â€” sometimes they have sex two or three times a day â€” but she still yearns for more. Maybe itâ€™s that craving that has blinded her to the laughable come-ons of a painter (William Levy), a Latin lover clichÃ© with mommy issues. In no time they are in a torrid affair. (He had her the moment he proposed to paint her and put the picture above his bed â€œso when youâ€™re not here I can satisfy myself with the mere thought of you.â€ù)

The screenplay, adapted by Christina Welsh and Ernie Barbarash from the best-selling erotic novel by Zane, is anything but subtle. This cautionary tale charts what happens when a restless businesswoman, Zoe (Ms. Leal), with an incredibly doting husband (their love is forever, â€œalways has been, always will beâ€ù), two adorable children, a helpful live-in mother and a raging sex drive, suppresses her needs for too long. But itâ€™s also a sultry, melodramatic romance, a flaccid thriller and a sloppy attempt to seriously explore sex addiction, and something rarely seen on the big screen: black female sexuality.

As Zoe takes on another lover (Tyson Beckford) and falls deeper into sex addiction, her world begins to crumble. (She misses her sonâ€™s soccer games and an important meeting with a businessman.) Her concerned therapist (Tasha Smith) is ineffectual, but she never really stood a chance. Instead of delving into the real problems, there are more sex scenes, which, in this film at least, are Mr. Woodruffâ€™s strength. With a mix of shots, including close-ups of sculpted body parts, there is a propulsive energy in these scenes that the movie as a whole lacks.
â€œAddictedâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Sex (in the shower), sex (on the hood of a car), sex (in a public bathroom) and more sex (sometimes in a bed).

The story of Nordlingâ€™s contribution to saving Paris has been told on film before, in RenÃ© ClÃ©mentâ€™s â€œIs Paris Burning?â€ù (1966), an artifact of the grand era of international co-production, which cast Orson Welles as the Scandinavian diplomat, and Gert FrÃ¶be as the German general. Mr. SchlÃ¶ndorffâ€™s film, though it offers a few scenic glimpses and an occasional burst of gunfire, presents a more concise narrative. It is a two-person chamber drama unfolding over a long, tense August night in a single enclosed space, von Choltitzâ€™s suite at the Hotel Meurice.

You could say that the answers donâ€™t matter, insofar as Nordlingâ€™s diplomacy was successful, and we still have Paris. But the value of â€œDiplomacyâ€ù is that it produces at least as much unsettlement as relief, compelling the viewer to remain haunted by nightmarish thoughts of what might have happened. Other cities were flattened, after all, and other populations were wiped out during World War II, which permanently collapsed the distance between the unthinkable and the actual. What seems unimaginable now was, a mere 70 years ago, not only imagined but also carefully planned and very nearly carried out.

Mr. Arestrup, a broad-chested, brooding bull of a man â€” so terrifying and charismatic as the jailhouse kingpin in â€œA Prophetâ€ù â€” declines to portray the character as a mensch in monsterâ€™s clothing. Von Choltitz may have good taste in food and art and an appealing sense of irony, but he is someone who has, without hesitation or compunction, supervised the massacre of Jews near the Eastern front and the leveling of cities less glamorous than Paris.

Von Choltitz, a veteran of both world wars from an old German military family, is blunt and brutal. He is also exhausted and demoralized, suffering from terrible asthma and the realization that the cause he has served is on the verge of defeat.

Mr. SchlÃ¶ndorff, who served his apprenticeship in France with Louis Malle and Jean-Pierre Melville before becoming one of the leading figures in the New German Cinema of the 1970s, turns the talkiness and the staginess of â€œDiplomacyâ€ù to the filmâ€™s advantage. His precise, restless camera creates a feeling of claustrophobic suspense as the plot races against the clock toward what is, for the audience at least, a foregone conclusion. The real mystery lies not in the outcome but in von Choltitzâ€™s motive. Has Nordling tapped into a hidden spring of decency, or does von Choltitz, like so many Germans (including Hitler) harbor a sentimental affection for Paris? Does the general care more about the safety of his wife and children in Germany or about the status of his nation in postwar Europe?

The general is a puzzle for the ambassador to solve. Mr. Dussollier, a fixture in the intellectually nimble work of Alain Resnais, is as elegant as Mr. Arestrup is rough, and his Nordling is a smooth and dapper gentleman whose impeccable manners disguise a gift for guile. Though he insists that he and his government are unwaveringly neutral, he is clearly in communication with the Resistance and has been spying on his interlocutor. He disarms the general with tales of bygone Parisian intrigue â€” they are in the very room where Napoleon III kept one of his mistresses â€” and appeals, in turn, to his conscience, his vanity and his self-protective instincts.

The man charged with carrying out the demolition was Gen. Dietrich von Choltitz, the German military governor of Paris. That he disobeyed the FÃ_hrerâ€™s orders is obvious enough, even to those who donâ€™t know the historical details. How and why he did so is the subject of â€œDiplomacy,â€ù a fascinating film directed by Volker SchlÃ¶ndorff and based on Cyril Gelyâ€™s play, in which General von Choltitz is portrayed by the great French actor Niels Arestrup, who originated the role onstage and who is joined by AndrÃ© Dussollier as Raoul Nordling, the Swedish ambassador to France.

The conversations depicted here, in which Nordling uses all of his diplomatic skills to persuade von Choltitz to spare the city they both love, never took place, though the filmâ€™s timeline is otherwise accurate. It is, in any case, less a docudrama than an allegory, an attempt to distill the moral and psychological essence of a complex historical moment, and to illuminate that moment through the verbal interaction of two very different personalities.

â€œWeâ€™ll always have Paris,â€ù Rick promised Ilsa at the end of â€œCasablanca,â€ù recalling a romantic idyll cruelly interrupted by the German occupation. In the real world, in the late summer of 1944, as the Allied armies drew closer, the Nazis decided that if they could not have Paris, nobody else would, either. Hitler ordered the complete destruction of the city. Bridges and monuments â€” the Opera, the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre â€” were to be blown up; he hoped to leave tens of thousands dead amid the rubble and erase centuries of art, architecture and civilization.

This two-track meditation wraps ethereal glimpses of age-old Slavic locales around a fairy tale told through hand-drawn illustrations. Electronically scored footage, shot on Super 16-millimeter film with every last numinous ray of dawn sunshine, drifts among farmers, loggers, weavers, mushroom foragers and icon-kissing churchgoers. These scenes periodically open up to vistas of valleys, streets at night and overgrown ruins, some of which suggest similar post-Soviet territory covered by the filmmakers Chantal Akerman and Naomi Uman.

The animated story from which the movie takes its title follows two children who flee soldiers into the forest, where a bony-fingered crone sets them impossible tasks. This strand, narrated in creaky tones and gently set in motion, acts as the primal heart of the film, and its foreboding mood of menace and mystery comes to pervade the film as a whole.

Weighty textual quotations are sometimes displayed and sometimes read by a male voice-over actor, but they tend only to underline the sense of a film that, like a daydream, is almost always on the verge of drifting away.

A daunting roll call of thinkers appears in the credits for â€œThe Vanquishing of the Witch Baba Yaga,â€ù an enchantingly shot visual essay from Jessica Oreck about the sylvan soul of Eastern Europe. Among those on that list are the theoretician Theodor Adorno, the poet Czeslaw Milosz and the folklore decoder Vladimir Propp. Ms. Oreck quotes or refers to some of them, but her imagery casts more of a spell.
â€œPeople give jobs to their friends and relatives,â€ù one woman with a resigned expression reports.
Directed by Richard Wolf
Opens on Friday
A REQUIEM FOR SYRIAN REFUGEES

A young woman dabs at her tears with the ends of her head scarf and says to the camera, â€œHelp Syria.â€ù A white-bearded man, asked what heâ€™d like to tell the outside world, offers, â€œAre you deaf?â€ù The solemn father of a paralyzed boy and a girl with Down syndrome semi-shrugs and says: â€œThis is my fate. It is from God.â€ù

Richard Wolfâ€™s documentary â€œA Requiem for Syrian Refugeesâ€ù is as powerfully direct as it is unfortunately heavy-handed, with lingering black-and-white close-ups of barbed wire and childrenâ€™s wide eyes. But the film is eloquent, too, thanks to the voices of the refugees themselves. The subtitles are sometimes stilted, too faithful to word-for-word translations, but we get a palpable sense of what life is like in one camp in northern Iraq. About half the children there attend a Unicef school. One family opens its food-program box and unpacks plastic bags of pasta. In a refugee-owned nail salon and boutique, elaborate evening dresses hang incongruously on tent walls. And as in any â€œcityâ€ù of 12,000 people, politics has taken hold.

To remind us that these are people who had quotidian lives, one refugee holds up his smartphone and shows a video of people playing in the snow in his hometown. One man recalls watching news broadcasts about the Arab Spring.
â€œSuddenly it started in Syria,â€ù he says. â€œWe saw a demonstration on TV.â€ù And here he is. ANITA GATES
In Kurdish, with English subtitles
1 hour 11 minutes; not rated

The movie begins with a quick shot of the World Trade Center attacks and the arrest of Ali, who is grabbed from behind in Bremen, Germany, and blindfolded. Then it jumps ahead eight years to observe the arrival of a new recruit, the Army private Amy Cole (Kristen Stewart), at GuantÃ¡namo. â€œCamp X-Rayâ€ù is the first film to prove that Ms. Stewart can really act, and it makes excellent use of her sullen, enigmatic screen presence. We learn that Amy grew up in a small town in Florida where she felt confined.

Whether youâ€™re a guard or an inmate at the GuantÃ¡namo Bay prison in Cuba, the place, as depicted in â€œCamp X-Ray,â€ù is a living hell, but not in the most obvious ways. Itâ€™s not a rank dungeon with clanging torture chambers. This relentlessly dour first feature, directed and written by Peter Sattler, was actually shot in an abandoned juvenile prison in Whittier, Calif., just outside Los Angeles. As you observe the 24-hour-a-day surveillance in which guards, two to a shift, go round and round, peeking into each room every three minutes to make sure a detainee hasnâ€™t attempted suicide, you have the sickening sense of people locked in a miserable, dehumanizing ritual from which there is no exit. We learn early in the film that the word â€œprisonersâ€ù is not permitted because it would support the argument that those behind bars are subject to the terms of the Geneva Conventions.

As the days pass, Amy stoically endures humiliations that include being sexually harassed by a fellow soldier and smeared with a detaineeâ€™s feces, all the while remaining an obedient cog in a military machine.

The core of the film is the combative, unlikely and ultimately caring friendship that develops between Ali and Amy â€” whom he calls Blondie, breaking down her reserve by badgering her with questions. One of Amyâ€™s tasks is to supply the detainees with reading material. The one thing Ali wants than more anything is the latest Harry Potter book.

At the same time, it shows the fury and hatred the inmates feel toward their captors. The attitude of the guards toward their charges is summed up in a disgusted officialâ€™s description of his job as â€œbabysitting a bunch of sheep herders.â€ù
â€œCamp X-Rayâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Strong language and scenes of attempted rape and force-feeding.

Everyone, inmates and guards alike, is behind bars. For the guards, who circulate like rats in a maze, there are the strict rules of standard operating procedure, or S.O.P. One scene shows a particularly obstreperous inmate about to be force-fed, but breaks off just as a feeding tube is inserted into a nostril. If the scene had gone further, â€œCamp X-Rayâ€ù might have been unbearable to watch.

The movie takes extraordinary pains not to be an exposÃ© of harsh prison conditions or to show acts that might be construed as torture. It is studiously neutral about the guilt or innocence of the inmates, including the detainee Ali Amir (Payman Maadi), on whom it focuses.

Gradually, Amyâ€™s defenses crumble, and signs of light begin to glimmer through her glum, robotic demeanor. Where a less austere movie might imply the development of a romantic attraction, there is no suggestion of an erotic undercurrent. Ali is desperately lonely, bored, and despairing of ever leaving GuantÃ¡namo. Mr. Maadi, the Iranian actor who starred in â€œA Separation,â€ù brings as much dimension as an actor could to a role that deliberately omits any back story. Although abrasive, manipulative and angry, his character has a likable human side.

By staying mostly indoors, the film takes on a creepy, metaphysical dimension. For all we know, the 24-hour watches could go on until the end of time, because here there is no time, just repeated action in a sterile setting where the lights never go out. (The real-life Camp X-Ray at GuantÃ¡namo actually consisted of chain-link cages from which detainees were transferred more than a decade ago.)

Despite the movieâ€™s gripping performances and the verisimilitude of many elements, I simply donâ€™t believe the story. Why, for instance, is Amy permitted to engage in long late-night conversations with Ali, which gives parts of the film the stiffness and artificiality of a play? When â€œCamp X-Rayâ€ù finally turns sentimental, you may feel betrayed.

Like a haiku to male violence â€” especially once Flem (Nicholas Hoult), a ruthless neighbor with designs on both Ernestâ€™s land and the cushiony Mary, enters the scene â€” â€œYoung Onesâ€ù distills primal passions to few words and fewer details. All the particulars are in the visuals: Mary washing the dinner dishes in a tub of dirt, and Ernestâ€™s paraplegic wife (Aimee Mullins) gliding toward him in a computerized suit buoyed by wires and air. A robotic farm machine that looks like a flatbed truck on legs will prove critical to the plot and substantially more endearing than any of the humans around it.
Opens on Friday
1 hour 39 minutes
The setting is futuristic, but the themes are ancient in â€œYoung Ones,â€ù Jake Paltrowâ€™s eccentric merger of frontier western and science-fiction gadgetry.
â€œYoung Onesâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Lives are taken, a baby is sold, and innocence is lost.

Structured in three acts and set in a near-future America in the grip of a lengthy drought, the story (by Mr. Paltrow) introduces a small rural family whose once-fertile land is now dust and rubble. At its head is Ernest (Michael Shannon), an alcoholic in white-knuckle recovery who, helped by his teenage son (Kodi Smit-McPhee), delivers hooch to workers building a pipeline to irrigate corporate farms. Back home, a hostile daughter, Mary (Elle Fanning), frets less about the lack of rain than about the scarcity of frocks and jewelry.
YOUNG ONES

Concerned only with the menâ€™s points of view, this spare but potent melodrama revels in the desiccated landscapes provided by South Africa and photographed with dusty purity by Giles Nuttgens. Through his lens, the spectrum of sunbaked skin and parched dunes is as rich as any rainbow.
Directed by Jake Paltrow

Action creates reaction, and together they create flowing, organic form in â€œBirdman.â€ù Riggan isnâ€™t the only man on the move: So is Mr. IÃ±Ã¡rritu, who has staged and shot the movie so that it looks like everything that happens, from airborne beginning to end, occurs during one transporting continuous take. The camera doesnâ€™t just move with the story and characters, it also ebbs and flows like water, soars and swoops like a bird, its movement as fluid as a natural element, as animated as a living organism. (Like that famous Steadicam shot in â€œGoodFellasâ€ù but longer.) Mr. IÃ±Ã¡rrituâ€™s partner in illusionism is the director of photography, Emmanuel Lubezki, a Houdini of fluid camera movements whose genius is for keeping you watching rather than distractedly wondering.

You can dig or just skate in this significantly better new one, the full title of which is â€œBirdman or the Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance.â€ù That phrase appears late in the movie, by which time Riggan has dodged various bullets, including a lover, Laura (Andrea Riseborough, amusing); an ex-wife, Sylvia (Amy Ryan, touching); and his frantic producer, Jake (Zach Galifianakis, deftly funny). Riggan has also crossed paths with a terribly mean theater critic for The New York Times, the rhymes-with-witch Tabitha (Lindsay Duncan), who threatens to close his play before seeing it. Her threat provokes a savage verbal assault on her from Riggan, an invective that by its very heat, expresses a conflicted desire for her benediction. This, you see, is also what we talk about when we talk about love.
â€œBirdmanâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Bloodshed and words.

â€œBirdman,â€ù a big bang of movie razzle-dazzle from Alejandro G. IÃ±Ã¡rritu, opens with a winking sleight of hand. Riggan Thomson, a Hollywood has-been turned Broadway second-chancer played by a blissed-out Michael Keaton, is hanging out in his dressing room at the St. James Theater in Times Square, by which I mean floating, like a mystic whoâ€™s passed transcendence and gone straight to nirvana. Itâ€™s a destabilizing liftoff for a funny, frenetic, buoyant and rambunctiously showboating entertainment in which Mr. IÃ±Ã¡rritu himself rises high and then higher still.

The camerawork in â€œBirdmanâ€ù is an astonishment, and an argument that everything flows together, which in this movie means the cinematography, the story, the people, even time and space. And as soon as Riggan floats down to earth, a series of walls â€” between character and actor, onstage and off, representation and reality â€” begin to collapse. The most obvious divide is between Mr. Keaton, who, starting in 1989, played Batman in two movies directed by Tim Burton, and Riggan, who made a killing playing Birdman, a feathered franchise jackpot. Years later, Riggan appears haunted by Birdman, whose image stares out from a poster hanging in the actorâ€™s dressing room and who, in a creepy basso profundo rasp, offers a stream of Sammy Glick-isms about career and fame.

Heâ€™s also given the finger wagging a rest. To that end, itâ€™s worth drawing your eye to the small card stuck on one of the mirrors in Rigganâ€™s dressing room that reads, â€œA thing is a thing not what is said of that thing.â€ù It sounds a bit like Gertrude Stein or poorly translated Kant, but is attributed to Susan Sontag. It may be a gloss on a line from â€œAgainst Interpretation,â€ù her book of essays on impoverished criticism and its â€œshadow world of â€˜meanings.' â€ù (â€œA work of art is a thing in the world,â€ù she writes, â€œnot just a text or commentary on the world.â€ù) Thereâ€™s plenty to embrace in Sontagâ€™s polemic, though a critic can perhaps be forgiven for rooting around in the shadow world of meanings if the artwork has cloaked itself in Meaning and Importance, as some of Mr. IÃ±Ã¡rrituâ€™s movies have done.

A few movies back, Mr. IÃ±Ã¡rritu parted ways with his frequent collaborator, the writer Guillermo Arriaga. The two had joined forces with the 2000 triptych â€œAmores Perrosâ€ù and then proceeded to win new admirers and detractors with other multi-stranded narratives, â€œ21 Gramsâ€ù and â€œBabel.â€ù I fell for â€œ21 Gramsâ€ù despite its absurdities, largely on the strength of its performances by the likes of Naomi Watts, who, in â€œBirdman,â€ù plays an actress, Lesley. But Mr. IÃ±Ã¡rritu lost me with â€œBabel,â€ù less because of its melodramatic excesses than because of its mechanistic quality and sanctimony. â€œBirdmanâ€ù marshals its enjoyable excesses into a rigorous form, too, but here a newly generous Mr. IÃ±Ã¡rritu has made room for the audienceâ€™s pleasure.

Embracing the principle of more, Mr. IÃ±Ã¡rritu packs the movie with multitudes, assorted backstage shenanigans, showbiz clichÃ©s and commedia dellâ€™arte types. As Riggan moves onstage and off, from rehearsal to dressing room, he finds romance in the wings, instigates a little cloak and dagger, and powers through some heart-to-heart encounters with his rehabbed daughter, Sam (a wonderful Emma Stone in sexy-cynical ragamuffin mode). A supercilious theater actor, Mike, played by a pitch-perfect, perfectly cast Edward Norton, challenges Riggan mentally and physically by declaring his allegiance to the theater (truth or bust!) at one point wielding a copy of Borgesâ€™s â€œLabyrinthsâ€ù so ostentatiously that even the most myopic moviegoer should be able to read the title.

Itâ€™s a nice change of direction for Mr. IÃ±Ã¡rritu, who has tended to pull viewers low and then lower in beautiful bummer movies, like his last one, â€œBiutiful,â€ù about a terminally ill man who communes with the dead. For â€œBirdman,â€ù he has lightened both his mood and metaphysical load to productive effect by concentrating on Rigganâ€™s efforts to stage â€” as writer, director and star â€” an adaptation of the Raymond Carver short story â€œWhat We Talk About When We Talk About Love.â€ù It sounds like an alarming idea (and a strange fit, especially given Carverâ€™s minimalism and Mr. IÃ±Ã¡rrituâ€™s maximalism), yet Riggan has bet his career on it in hopes that the play will deliver him from his ignoble, lucrative past playing a screen superhero called Birdman.

Did someone say Icarus? Well, no, that name doesnâ€™t come up in this backstage comedy (and sometimes drama), at least not that I remember, although Mr. IÃ±Ã¡rritu and his co-writers (NicolÃ¡s Giacobone, Alexander Dinelaris Jr. and Armando Bo) toss others including Roland Barthes, Jorge Luis Borges and Martin Scorsese. The story is as old as time â€” the playâ€™s the thing, once again â€” and unwinds over several dreamily integrated days and nights that take Riggan from his meditative calm through the labyrinthine halls of the St. James in the hours and minutes leading up to the opening, during which (big breath): He rehearses an actor, receives a kiss, throws a punch, downs a drink, smokes a joint, walks a street and waxes poetic, comic, tragic and melodramatic.

And then there is Lionel (Tyler James Williams, faintly recognizable to fans of â€œEverybody Hates Chrisâ€ù), a gay nerd â€” though he detests such labels â€” with an unruly Afro and a clear allergy to the posturing and position taking that surrounds him. Recruited by the school paper to report on race relations at Winchester (and also on Samâ€™s campaign), he endures condescension, curiosity and contempt as his white and black peers try to slot him into a pre-existing stereotype, refusing to see him as the brainy, observant, yearning intellectual that he is.

â€œDear White Peopleâ€ù is also the title of a series of campus radio broadcasts and viral Internet videos concocted by one of the movieâ€™s major characters, a college student named Samantha White, played with heartbreaking poise by Tessa Thompson. Sam, as she is called, uses â€œDear White Peopleâ€ù to call out the hypocrisies, blind spots and micro-aggressions that African-Americans experience in their daily encounters with well-meaning Caucasians. Such people, including many of her fellow undergraduates at the Ivier-than-Ivy League Winchester University, make up a big part of Samâ€™s fan base. This is less because they want to subject themselves to her scolding than because they crave reassurance that they donâ€™t really need it. The eagerness of some whites to prove that they â€œget itâ€ù on matters of race â€” their clumsy appropriations of African-American idioms and pop-cultural forms â€” is one of the targets of Samâ€™s critique and Mr. Simienâ€™s satire.

Such misrecognition is the universal currency at Winchester and also, implicitly, beyond its walls. â€œDear White Peopleâ€ù brilliantly uses the complexities of Obama-era racial consciousness to explore a basic paradox of interpersonal interaction. We are all stereotypes in one anotherâ€™s eyes and complicated, unique individuals in our own minds. Somehow, within the compass of a compact, modestly budgeted (and independently financed) feature, Mr. Simien holds the antics of an astonishing variety of recognizable human types up to critical scrutiny. At the same time, he explores the desires and frustrations of a motley collection of plausible human beings with amused compassion.

Samâ€™s current lover, a teaching assistant in her film class, is also white, which may be why she keeps their relationship secret, tolerating the amorous attention of Reggie (Marque Richardson), her ally in militancy and, perhaps in her own mind, a more appropriate romantic partner. But the heart rarely obeys the imperatives of ideology, which can be confusing enough on their own. Samâ€™s struggles are mirrored by those of two other African-American students seeking a way to fit in at Winchester while staying true to themselves. One is Coco (Teyonah Parris), who tries to set herself up, in web videos and in the way she dresses, talks and does her hair, as Samâ€™s antithesis, an advocate of assimilation and upward mobility. She also wants to impress a reality-show producer who is sniffing around campus looking for provocative material.

And so, at least for this director, is the tendency of some black people to poke at that insecurity, and to engage one another in fierce battles about authenticity, appropriate conduct and political strategy. â€œDear White Peopleâ€ù deals out a deck of race cards, most of them jokers. To change the metaphor, the film leads its characters and its viewers â€” pale-skinned critics very much included â€” down a path strewn with eggshells, some of which sit on top of land mines.

Not that anyone is let off the hook. â€œDear White Peopleâ€ù does not point the way toward a happy, huggy, post-racial future. Nor does it prophesy a revolutionary fire next time. And it does not pretend that â€œraceâ€ù is a symmetrical problem to be solved by acts of reciprocal good will on both sides. This is in part a movie about racism, about how deeply white supremacy is still embedded in institutions that congratulate themselves on their diversity and tolerance. It is, in other words, about how the distance from a place like Winchester to a place like Ferguson, Mo., is not as great as some of us might wish or suppose.

Sam, a mass of contradictions in her own right, is just one element in a sprawling and intricate narrative machine. Mr. Simien audaciously sets in motion at least a half-dozen crisscrossing plots, all of which converge at a campus party that goes terribly and all too believably wrong. Sam is running for the leadership of a dormitory whose traditional character as an all-black residence is threatened by a change in university housing policy. Her rival is Troy (Brandon Bell), a square-jawed, clean-cut Big Man on Campus who is also her ex-boyfriend. His father (Dennis Haysbert) is the dean of students, and Troyâ€™s current (white) girlfriend, Sofia (Brittany Curran), is the daughter of the university president (Peter Syvertsen). Sofiaâ€™s brother, Kurt (Kyle Gallner), is the editor of the college humor magazine and a proudly politically incorrect provocateur (and, as such, kind of a jerk).

Everyone should see this movie, and everyone will see it a little differently. Maybe you will think it goes too far, or not far enough. Since I happen to belong to the group to which it is explicitly addressed, a direct response seems warranted. Dear â€œDear White Peopleâ€ù: Got your message. Keep in touch.

â€œDear White Peopleâ€ù is the name of Justin Simienâ€™s first feature film, and Iâ€™ll say right away that it is as smart and fearless a debut as I have seen from an American filmmaker in quite some time: knowing but not snarky, self-aware but not solipsistic, open to influence and confident in its own originality. Itâ€™s a clever campus comedy that juggles a handful of hot potatoes â€” race, sex, privilege, power â€” with elegant agility and only an occasional fumble. You want to see this movie, and you will want to talk about it afterward, even if the conversation feels a little awkward. If it doesnâ€™t, youâ€™re doing it wrong. There is great enjoyment to be found here, and very little comfort.
â€œDear White Peopleâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Offense freely given and eagerly taken.

Mr. Simien serves harsh medicine with remarkable charm and good humor. He is an incisive writer and a disciplined and decorous filmmaker, framing and cutting his scenes with clean, almost classical economy. Someone says of Sam, an aspiring filmmaker, that she secretly likes Ingmar Bergman more than Spike Lee. Mr. Leeâ€™s â€œSchool Dazeâ€ù is a clear reference point here, and while Bergman is not an obvious influence, itâ€™s possible to catch echoes of Whit Stillman, Claude Chabrol and even Pedro AlmodÃ_var in Mr. Simienâ€™s feel for the nuances and perversities of social life.

Winchester is a hothouse of inflamed sensitivity and warring identities, populated mainly by young people who are eager to do the right thing as well as all the other things that college students usually do: drink beer, hook up, make friends, incubate careers and maybe even take a class or two. Like real-life American institutions of higher learning, this make-believe college strives to resolve painful and intractable social divisions, only to end up reproducing them on a smaller scale and in a more rarefied and intensified form.
The aggressively silly sendup â€œEternity: The Movieâ€ù seems to have been constructed on the premise that all you need to make a parody are a few 1980s props and a relentless synth-pop beat.
