column5: Closer in spirit to a down-budget Off Broadway revue than to the wit and snap of â€œThis Is Spinal Tap,â€ù â€œEternity: The Movieâ€ù has three basic strains of humor. The first is predicated on a snickering â€™80s nostalgia (the sight of an oversize cordless phone). The second assumes that puns are endlessly funny. (â€œIt turns out even Eternity doesnâ€™t last forever.â€ù) In the third, Todd and B. J., despite outwardly competing for the affections of a songwriting friend (Nikki Leonti), seem by all appearances to be deeply in love with each other.

A catalog of these jokes might make â€œEternity: The Movieâ€ù sound amusing, but thereâ€™s much more dead air than laughs, despite a certain anything-goes enthusiasm from the leads. Original songs like â€œMake Love, Not Just Sexâ€ù and â€œSambuca & Ciderâ€ù more than outdo their models in tackiness.

Centering on three detectives, each at different stages of life and career, the story opens on a drug raid as Malcolm (Joel Edgerton) survives a shooting, then heads to the pub to celebrate the wonders of a Kevlar vest. Fully soused, he gets behind the wheel and promptly collides with an Indian boy on a bicycle. Enter Carl (Tom Wilkinson, terrific as ever), a veteran officer who helps engineer a cover-up, only to find that his rookie partner, Jim (Jai Courtney), smells a rat and is determined to hunt it down.

Encasing low-rent ideas with a buffed veneer of sophistication, â€œFelonyâ€ù (as written by Mr. Edgerton and directed by Matthew Saville) solicits sympathy for the Devil at every turn. Surely, our ladsâ€™ ability to catch drug dealers and pedophiles is much more important than penalizing them for one tiny mistake? Yes, Malcolm lied and drove while wasted, but see how heâ€™s suffering and how much he loves his own young son. As for Carl, his professional smarts and personal tragedies should certainly earn him a pass for his reprehensible behavior.

Even more repellent is Jim, the supposedly straight-arrow novice who sexually exploits the vulnerability of the comatose boyâ€™s mother. â€œWho is right and who is wrong?â€ù the publicity notes wonder, as if any decent person would ever have the slightest doubt.
A deeply cynical movie masquerading as a complex moral dilemma, the Australian drama â€œFelonyâ€ù proves only that skilled actors and slick photography can tart up even the most problematic script.

In a morbid synthesis of two Paul Greengrass movies, â€œUnited 93â€ù and â€œCaptain Phillips,â€ù the found-footage film â€œDefaultâ€ù imagines the hijacking of a United States news crew after a visit to the Seychelles. Somali pirates storm the crewâ€™s plane; as the aircraft sits on the tarmac, the hijackersâ€™ leader, Atlas (David Oyelowo), insists on having cameras set up everywhere. He demands an interview in response to an earlier segment that the network has run.

The film is stronger with its moment-to-moment tension than with its cynical, shallow media satire. (The title refers to the method by which the group was selected. â€œA-list newscasters donâ€™t visit East Africa as much as they used to,â€ù Atlas explains.) Yet even the failure to find a persuasive closing note doesnâ€™t detract from Mr. Oyelowoâ€™s riveting performance.

The director, Simon Brand, makes effective use of shifting video formats to distinguish different types of footage. As is customary for this genre, â€œDefaultâ€ù resorts to loopholes and odd angles to ensure continued filming. The pulsing score also distracts from the verisimilitude.

But â€œDefaultâ€ù proves less interested in realism or current events than in mind games. When Atlas sits down with a veteran journalist, Frank Saltzman (Greg Callahan), they argue semantics. Atlas resents the use of the word â€œpiratesâ€ù instead of â€œterrorists,â€ù which he thinks American television reserves for Arabs. Clouding his motives, Atlas proposes a bet as to whether one would terrify Frankâ€™s crew more: captors motivated by money or ideology.

Mr. Tukelâ€™s basic strategy is to set himself loose among comic straight men and women, gabbling his way through disastrous dates and office flirtations (with a hilariously vamping colleague played by Dakota Goldhor). Once Erik is turned into a vampire â€” and an irresistible sex machine â€” the ludicrous action turns into a kind of wish fulfillment, but with a few indignities intact.

With a bite to the neck, a pale stranger in a suit does the deed one night in some deserted Brooklyn badlands. By then, Erikâ€™s girlfriend (Anna Margaret Hollyman) has dropped him, and his arrogant laziness has put his office job in jeopardy. What keeps all this from being a poor loserâ€™s tale of redemption is that Erik is frequently and blithely offensive. (â€œKeep the wound elevated,â€ù he obliviously tells another man with a gushing neck.)
Itâ€™s all mellowly funny rather than creepy, something like a stand-up conceit elaborated into scenes. But who would want to be stuck with this running monologue for eternity?

You might look at the pudgy, salt-and-pepper-haired, bespectacled Erik in â€œSummer of Bloodâ€ù and think heâ€™d have something thoughtful to say. Until he opens his mouth. In Onur Tukelâ€™s vampire sex comedy, Erik â€” played by the director â€” quickly proves to be a self-absorbed, insufferable dope pushing a lovable-neurotic shtick. Itâ€™s clear heâ€™d be better off undead.

Philip, as this scene and the title suggest, isnâ€™t one for listening, especially to people he knows. â€œListen Up Philipâ€ù is partly about his agonies both as a writer and as a human being, the two seeming â€” at least for him â€” sometimes mutually exclusive. To an extent itâ€™s a portrait of the artist as an insufferable jerk, but, more interestingly, itâ€™s one that opens and expands beyond that classic framework to show the life usually seen milling about in the background. Much of the story involves Philip, but it makes generous room for the women he knows, specifically his girlfriend, Ashley Kane (a brilliant Elisabeth Moss), a photographer finding increasing success. The story opens with the couple on the verge of a crisis thatâ€™s emerged as her attention has shifted from Philip to her own art.

At one point, Mr. Perry, partly inspired by a similar strategy in William Gaddisâ€™s novel â€œThe Recognitions,â€ù leaves Philip and his miseries to focus on Ashley and her story. Having decided to take up Zimmermanâ€™s offer to write in the country, Philip has left her alone in Brooklyn for the summer, a reckless decision with catastrophic consequences. This narrative split is a bold formal move and a relief because it gives you a break from all that male ego. Itâ€™s also pleasurable because Ms. Moss is rapidly emerging as one of the most exciting actresses in American movies, and thereâ€™s great joy in just watching this intensely expressive, empathetic performer. Thereâ€™s mischief in her eyes and smile, but she has a silent screen actressâ€™s wistfulness and a gift for conveying an inner stillness that can suggest depths of melancholy.

Philip is, in all respects, a real piece of work, but it takes a while to understand what manner of bastard â€” vainglorious artist, average narcissist, straight-up nut case â€” he is. The cruelty of his jabs plants early doubt about whether you should even be smiling, all while Mr. Perry slyly pumps the laughs. The casting of Mr. Schwartzman is crucial to keeping you and the humor off balance. With his caterpillar brows, doe eyes, epic nose and compact size (heâ€™s Groucho Marx by way of a fawn), the actor is such a naturally amusing screen presence, at once adorable and absurd, that he canâ€™t help but temper Philip. Itâ€™s no wonder that the more Philip gorges on rage, as he hurls insults and violently slaloms through the cityâ€™s slow-moving herds, the more foolish, and at times infantile he appears.

Mr. Perry attacks the screen with the slashing strokes of an abstract painter on a tear, filling the frame with sweating bodies, giant heads, claustrophobic rooms and singularly unromantic glimpses of New York. The images have a gritty, stubborn beauty thanks to the Super 16 millimeter film, but the agitations of the cinematography, which suggests instability, can get under your skin almost as thoroughly as Philip does. Even as it grates, the visual style proves a seamless fit for this story because the embodied camerawork â€” you intuit the person behind the machine with every tremor â€” is as much an assertion of authorship as the filmâ€™s on-and-off narrator (an unseen Eric Bogosian). Mr. Perry is announcing that heâ€™s telling a story about Philip, who, in turn, is living that story like a character â€” a â€œnovelist.â€ù

Words do more than hurt, they also slash and burn in this sharp, dyspeptic, sometimes gaspingly funny exploration of art and life, men and women, being and nonbeing, and the power and limits of language. Philip is making his name with words (his second novel, â€œObidant,â€ù is about to be published), but itâ€™s what he does with them off the page that interests the writer-director Alex Ross Perry. The movie opens with Philip going to meet a former girlfriend, Mona (Samantha Jacober), who arrives late. This engenders an angry torrent from Philip that begins with a generalized complaint about Monaâ€™s punctuality, briefly detours into chitchat, only to gather force and escalate as he condemns her past behavior toward him, attacks her character (then and now) and asserts his supremacy.

â€œListen Up Philipâ€ù is itself exhilarating because, for all its brutal comedy, itâ€™s a serious work about the struggle to follow your muse and be fully alive in a world shared with other people. Zimmermanâ€™s tragedy, one that surfaces in his lacerating asides and battles with his daughter, Melanie (Krysten Ritter), is that heâ€™s sacrificed life â€” and loved ones â€” nominally for his art, though more truly for his devouring narcissism. As Philip seems headed to embrace Zimmermanâ€™s self-immolating example, the film moves in another direction. Nothing speaks better to this than the astonishing coda to a late, bitter fight in which Mr. Perry and Ms. Moss together create â€” with a lingering close-up and eddies of triumph, despair, elation and regret â€” a masterwork about what it is to live for love and not just the self.

In the biliously, often hilariously funny tragicomedy â€œListen Up Philip,â€ù the alternately self-regarding and self-loathing novelist played in 50 shades of black by a peerless Jason Schwartzman stalks New York like a madman or, perhaps, a murderer. Philip Lewis Friedman doesnâ€™t have blood on his hands (at least not yet), though he routinely goes in for the kill. If he looked shabbier, less domesticated, he could be mistaken for one of those thrown-away men who roam city streets muttering into the void of other peopleâ€™s indifference. When the movie opens, he seems willfully teetering on the edge of that terrible darkness, inching ever closer to its maw with each furiously detonated word.

The little woman, subordinate and subservient, is a sad commonplace in tales about male artists. In Philip Rothâ€™s masterly novel â€œThe Ghost Writerâ€ù â€” one of Mr. Perryâ€™s obvious touchstones â€” the narrator, Nathan Zuckerman, looking back at his 23-year-old self, describes the wife of his literary hero, E. I. Lonoff, as having â€œthe obedient air of an aging geisha when she dared to speak or to move.â€ù The young Nathan should know, having made the pilgrimage to the great manâ€™s country home nominally hoping to become his â€œspiritual son,â€ù if one who hasnâ€™t yet grasped (or admitted) the Oedipal implications of that journey. Philip has his own literary hero and foil, Ike Zimmerman (Jonathan Pryce, excellent), an angry, reclusive novelist who invites the younger man to his country home ostensibly to write.

Pvt. Norman Ellison (Logan Lerman), who has yet to earn a nickname, serves as both the smooth-faced newbie â€” afraid of dying and appalled by the callousness of his comrades â€” and as the crewâ€™s designated egghead. Transferred from the typing pool, he reads Hemingway and plays classical piano, and is clearly more sensitive than the others, who are cut from coarser cloth and have been further battered by grueling campaigns in North Africa, Italy and Normandy.

The first time we see Mr. Pitt in â€œFury,â€ù he leaps from his tank, tackles a German officer and stabs him through the eye. Then he calms the dead manâ€™s beautiful white horse and sets it free across the battlefield. Later, he will order the summary execution of an SS officer who has just surrendered, after confirming that the man was responsible for the deaths of children.
And then itâ€™s time to move on and get back to the business at hand.

Now, with the war in its endgame, they face a vicious and desperate enemy. In their retreat toward Berlin, the Nazis have taken to conscripting children and murdering uncooperative parents. With his military collapsing on both the Eastern and Western fronts, Hitler has ordered a suicidal last stand of total destruction. The Germans still have plenty of tanks, though, many of them superior to those of the Americans, and while momentum is on the side of the Allies, victory still seems far away.

These killings are staged with an air of grim necessity, and Mr. Ayer, a hard-boiled screenwriter (â€œTraining Dayâ€ù) and action director (â€œSabotage,â€ùâ€œEnd of Watchâ€ù) venturing into ambitious genre territory, has a way of filming violence that is both intense and matter-of-fact. Like many other post-â€œSaving Private Ryanâ€ù combat movies, this one emphasizes the chaotic immediacy of battle, staking its claim to authenticity on the unflinching depiction of bloodshed: Heads are vaporized by mortar rounds. Limbs are severed by bursts of automatic-rifle fire. Human flesh is charred by flames and shredded by shrapnel.

And why shouldnâ€™t it be? The world is a complicated place, and war, as a subject for novels and movies, often presents a tangle of moral ambiguity and a fog of confusion. But while the Allied fight against Germany may sometimes raise thorny questions about ends and means, it also retains an ethical clarity, a righteousness, that at least partly accounts for its durable appeal among commercial filmmakers and their audiences. Nazis are just about the only real-world figures who consistently merit the fates reserved, in other genres, for zombies, aliens and orcs.

The men under him are the kind of motley, semi-diverse assortment that usually anchors this genre. Gordo (Michael PeÃ±a), who is Mexican-American, and Coon-Ass (Jon Bernthal), from somewhere in the American South, disguise their loyalty to each other in profane insults and occasional bursts of bigotry. Bible (an excellent Shia LaBeouf), while he occasionally lets fly an obscenity or two, is more apt to quote Scripture and warn his comrades about the wages of sin. There is a tenderness between him and Wardaddy that is one of the filmâ€™s subtlest and most intriguing touches.

â€œFury,â€ù which takes its title from the name painted on the barrel of the tankâ€™s big gun, is less an epic than a series of tense and focused episodes. Itâ€™s about the grind of tactics rather than the sweep of strategy, the struggle for local objectives rather than ultimate goals. The battle scenes are staged with blunt, ground-level virtuosity, and with a welcome regard for spatial and visual coherence. When the tank needs to cross an expanse of muddy ground, you feel every jolt and swerve. And there is a lot of muddy ground to cover.

There is also a brief respite, during which Mr. Ayer pauses to consider the humanity of the soldiers and the extent to which it has been tested and damaged by war. Wardaddy and Norman discover two German women (Anamaria Marinca and Alicia von Rittberg) hiding in an apartment in a newly captured town, and the encounter is both delicate and terrifying, a dysfunctional family dinner in the midst of a nightmare. It gestures toward a conflict that is bigger and deeper than the war itself â€” the struggle, among and within individuals, between savagery and civilization, decency and raw need.

But within this gore-spattered, superficially nihilistic carapace is an old-fashioned platoon picture, a sensitive and superbly acted tale of male bonding under duress. Wardaddy â€” an archetypal squad leader, tough and quiet, with sad eyes that testify to the terrible things heâ€™s seen â€” is in charge of four other men, and the long hours they spend together, in constant danger and the limited space of the tank, result in an atmosphere of rough and unpretentious intimacy.

â€œWeâ€™re in the killing Nazis business. And cousin, business is a-booming.â€ù So said Brad Pitt (in the person of Lt. Aldo Raine) in Quentin Tarantinoâ€™s â€œInglourious Basterds.â€ù Five years later, and nearly 70 years after World War II, Mr. Pitt returns to combat in â€œFury,â€ù playing the leader of an American tank crew fighting its way across Germany in the spring of 1945. His character, Sgt. Don Collier (nicknamed Wardaddy), is a wearier, less garrulous fellow than Raine, and the filmâ€™s director, David Ayer, has a more linear and literal sensibility than Mr. Tarantino, but the business of Nazi killing remains brisk.
â€œFuryâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Slaughter and swearing.

In the romantic comedy â€œRelationship Status: Itâ€™s Complicated,â€ù Ben (Manu Payet), a wedding videographer in Paris, is 30 and set to marry the low-key, sensible Juliette (AnaÃ¯s Demoustier) in two weeks. But his world explodes when he encounters Vanessa (Emmanuelle Chriqui), the girl who got away in high school and is back after years in America.

Egging him on to follow his heart (or libido) are his best man, JÃ©rÃ©mie (Jean-Charles Clichet), and the burly, blustery Sylvain (Jean-FranÃ§ois Cayrey). Also factoring in his decision is Vanessaâ€™s dad, Armand (a hammy Philippe Duquesne), a frazzled and over-animated burnout with persistent love troubles.

But the directors do have the good sense to let Ms. Demoustier shine at major moments. And when, after a meeting with Vanessa, an exultant Ben is joined spontaneously by a street chorus line dancing to Harry Belafonteâ€™s calypso classic â€œJump in the Line,â€ù the movie gives a hint of the dizzying heights it might have attained.

Mr. Payet, who is one of the filmâ€™s directors and screenwriters, is a comedy star in France, and this movie is facile with its comic rhythms and dramatic flow. At times, it exudes a Neil Simon vibe (â€œThe Heartbreak Kidâ€ù comes to mind), with little of the verbal spark but much of the sentiment. (Yes, there is an inevitable and climactic crosstown dash to Benâ€™s true love.) The filmmakers conveniently lampoon Vanessaâ€™s family and Julietteâ€™s, though Benâ€™s is nowhere to be seen.
So does the movie, whose baldfaced deviousness robs it of credibility and emotional truth.

The movie doesnâ€™t show the shootings, which Sam learns about from a live television report while waiting for Josh to join him for lunch. After cursorily observing the ensuing media frenzy, the movie leaps ahead two years to find Sam working as a house painter. Once a hotshot adman, he has abandoned his career to hide out on a boat, where he seethes with rage and despair and drowns his sorrows in booze.

â€œRudderless,â€ù the misbegotten directorial debut of William H. Macy, is so dishonest, manipulative and ultimately infuriating that it never recovers after its bombshell revelation two-thirds of the way into the movie. Not that its coyly withheld disclosure is all that unexpected. What is surprising is that Mr. Macy, who wrote the screenplay with Casey Twenter and Jeff Robison and plays the owner of tavern, didnâ€™t know better than to be so coy.
â€œRudderlessâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for strong language.

In a cache of his sonâ€™s belongings, Sam discovers Joshâ€™s homemade CDs. Impulsively, he teaches himself one of the songs and performs it as his own at an open mike at a local hangout. The song attracts the attention of Quentin (Anton Yelchin), a socially awkward young musician who pesters his way into Samâ€™s life. He pressures the reluctant Sam to form a band named Rudderless to perform â€œhisâ€ù songs, which he neglects to credit as the work of his son. Playing Quentin in his whiny Matthew Broderick mode, Mr. Yelchin overacts, and his performance quickly curdles.

This story of grief, recovery and delayed reckoning after a campus massacre at the fictional Central Plains State University, has a taut lead performance by Billy Crudup as Sam, the embittered, divorced father of Josh (Miles Heizer), one of the dead students.

The young Dawson (Luke Bracey) and Amanda (Liana Liberato) look and act nothing like their grown-up selves. When they meet again, she is unhappily married, with a teenage son, and he has been working on an oil rig after serving time for an accidental shooting. What brings him home is the reading of a will after the death of his avuncular mentor and guardian angel, Tuck (Gerald McRaney), the movieâ€™s omniscient commentator.

Reconnecting after a 20-year separation, Dawson Cole (James Marsden) and his childhood sweetheart, Amanda Collier (Michelle Monaghan), discover that although they were separated by geography, they listened to the same song at the same time, while dreaming of each other.

The teenage girls sitting around me at the screening, who had sighed wistfully at the loversâ€™ first kiss, eventually lost patience and began to giggle. Even the movieâ€™s target audience recognized when â€œThe Best of Meâ€ù became too much of a bad thing.
â€œThe Best of Meâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned), for tepid sex scenes, violence and strong language.

The two come from opposite sides of the tracks in a small Louisiana town. Dawsonâ€™s glowering father and siblings are dentally challenged, gun-toting hillbilly roughnecks who viciously abuse the sensitive Dawson. Amanda is from a â€œgoodâ€ù family, and her disdainful father offers to pay for Dawsonâ€™s college education if he breaks off the relationship.

In the latest weepathon from the Nicholas Sparks suds factory, the star-crossed lovers in â€œThe Best of Me,â€ù in the years they are apart, detect signs every so often that they share a mystical, spiritual bond.

And, on two occasions, when Dawson is near death, a vision of his sweetheart appears to him. Dawson has a habit of gazing up at the stars and musing out loud about destiny. And Mr. Marsden, still a perfect specimen at 41, has the pinwheeling blue eyes that signal infinite depths of feeling. Ms. Monaghan does not have the same light in her eyes, and the performance by this usually reliable actress is stiff and guarded.

But enough about the plot, of which there are yards and yards, none of it particularly believable or compelling, except in the most generalized way. The only thing â€œThe Best of Meâ€ù really wants is to weave a teary-eyed romantic spell by any means necessary. The screenplay is so haphazardly constructed that when the movie seems to be ending, it refuels with preposterous new developments.

Once Maria returns to San ÃÅngel, her form has ballooned in all the familiar places, turning into a kind of walking, talking hourglass adorned with a luxurious cascade of hair. Sheâ€™s a doll, or rather a tasty animated dish, one who, as the movie continues, is fought over by her two friends turned warring suitors. This romantic blather is both a bore and a clichÃ©d encumbrance, and it pulls the movie down even when the animation lifts it up. The script chugs along, despite some scenes in the land of the dead; someone, however, does slip in a case for being nice to animals along with what seems like a nod to JosÃ© Guadalupe Posada, the Mexican artist who made skulls grin and skeletons dance.

If swirls of gorgeous, gaudy color were all it took to animate an animated movie then â€œThe Book of Lifeâ€ù â€” with its showy splashes of acid purples and greens, its tangerine-dream sunsets and big blue-gray moon â€” would be bursting with as much energy and life as a Warner Bros. cartoon classic. As it is, this often beautiful and too-often moribund, if exhaustingly frenetic, feature tends to be less energetic than the dead people waltzing through it.

The director Jorge R. Gutierrez, who shares script credit with Doug Langdale, has a far stronger visual sensibility than story sense. â€œThe Book of Lifeâ€ù instantly pulls you in with its eye-poking palette and amusingly exaggerated character designs that with a few touches, telegraph entire personalities, like the strange doll eye and floppy candy-colored mops of the museum kids. Both the colors and character designs morph once the scene shifts to Manolo, Joaquin and Maria (voiced by Diego Luna, Channing Tatum and ZoÃ« Saldana) who, with their big block heads and articulated joints, have been wittily rendered to look somewhat like those flexible wooden figurines used by artists for anatomical studies. (Some townspeople look more like clothespins with Mr. Potato Head lips.)
â€œThe Book of Lifeâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). You see dead people.

Itâ€™s a drag how frequently the stories in feature animations get in the way of the visuals. Such is the case in â€œThe Book of Life,â€ù which opens with a handful of kids who, during a museum visit, are introduced by a guide (voiced by Christina Applegate) to the Book of Life. Once cracked open, this magical tome disgorges the rather less-enchanted story of three other tots: Manolo, the scion of a bullfighting family; Joaquin, the son of a heroic soldier; and Maria, whose father runs the Mexican-fantasy town of San ÃÅngel. After some frolicsome, choreographed high jinks, Maria is sent away only to return as the base in a formulaic love triangle.
Directed by Vivien Lesnik Weisman
1 hour 31 minutes; not rated
Opens on Friday
THE HACKER WARS

With its insider feel and clear bias, â€œThe Hacker Warsâ€ù does itself no favors in reaching a wider audience. Yet the behavior it scrutinizes speaks to the essence of democracy and the very definition of citizenship, and, as such, it merits a calmer, more reasoned forum than this one.

Interviewees like the journalist and lawyer Glenn Greenwald and the National Security Agency whistle-blower Thomas A. Drake provide respite from the flurry of acronyms and uninhibited commenters. Around two-thirds of the way in, however, the film catches hold, as the disturbing claims of its subjects â€” mostly unsubstantiated but nevertheless persuasive â€” accumulate and clarify.

Making no pretense of balance or objectivity, Vivien Lesnik Weismanâ€™s excitable documentary â€œThe Hacker Warsâ€ù is a forceful indictment of the United States governmentâ€™s surveillance and prosecution of computer hackers and journalists.

In particular, the complicated cases of the journalist Barrett Brown (who, at one point, faced more than 100 years in prison on a variety of charges) and the hacker Jeremy Hammond (who recently began serving a 10-year prison term) raise such troubling issues of mass surveillance and data collection that they deserve far greater depth and detail.

Surveying four main legal actions, including the one against Andrew Auernheimer, a.k.a. Weev, who embarrassed AT&T by revealing weaknesses in its security systems, Ms. Weisman offers a deluge of information. But for those not already versed in the lingo or the people involved, the movie plays like a blurry primer to an anarchic, mysterious world. Hyperkinetic editing and an overabundance of montage are no help as we watch fuzzy faces in grainy video and listen to mumbled words on poor, sometimes subtitled recordings.

Kaguya enters the world more bewilderingly than most: Sheâ€™s discovered nestled within a radiant bamboo flower by a woodsman, who raises her with his wife. Her salt-of-the-earth upbringing and friends are normal, but she matures in unearthly leaps and bounds, crawling one moment and walking the next. Then gold and robes magically appear to her father in the forest, leading him to move the family to the capital to raise the girl as a princess.
2 hours 17 minutes

â€œPrincess Kaguyaâ€ù looks like a departure from Mr. Takahataâ€™s most famous film, â€œGrave of the Fireflies,â€ù or his last, â€œMy Neighbors the Yamadasâ€ù (though that one included a reference to this folk story). But his artistry and his feeling for his main character are just as deeply felt here.
THE TALE OF THE PRINCESS KAGUYA
In Japanese, with English subtitles

Kaguya is groomed to join the aristocratic classes and cosseted indoors; a parade of comically obsequious suitors follows. But despite all the attention, wealth and good intentions of her parents, she nurtures a certain despondency, and thereâ€™s plenty to recognize in her struggle to find her footing and her need to insist on her independence.

â€œThe Tale of the Princess Kaguyaâ€ù is the first animated feature in over a decade directed by Isao Takahata, the 78-year-old Studio Ghibli stalwart. Exquisitely drawn with both watercolor delicacy and a brisk sense of line, the film finds a peculiarly moving undertow of feeling in a venerable Japanese folk tale about a foundling country girl who canâ€™t shake a sense of being out of place.
â€œThe Tale of the Princess Kaguyaâ€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested) for some violent action.

Directed by Edet Belzberg
2 hours; not rated

The human-rights pioneer Raphael Lemkin once wrote an especially dire note to self: â€œDo not cease to exist.â€ù They were the words of a man consumed by his mission to secure legislation against genocide, to the detriment of his health, as mentioned in Edet Belzbergâ€™s â€œWatchers of the Sky.â€ù The story of Lemkin â€” an indefatigable petitioner of the United Nations, driven by the Armenian massacres and his own familyâ€™s slaughter in World War II â€” is the spine of this sprawling, big-hearted examination of genocide.
WATCHERS OF THE SKY

Ms. Belzberg shifts among Lemkinâ€™s lamentable saga and other agents of justice: Samantha Power, the United States ambassador whose book â€œA Problem From Hell: America and the Age of Genocideâ€ù inspires the film; Luis Moreno-Ocampo, the first chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, assembling a case against Darfurâ€™s leader; Emmanuel Uwurukundo, a Rwandan survivor who runs refugee camps in Chad; and Benjamin Ferencz, a nonagenarian Nuremberg trials prosecutor.
â€œWatchers of the Skyâ€ù is a film that can dash hopes about humanity but also raise them in depicting the stories of these tireless defenders.
Opens on Friday

That a case against genocide needed to be made may surprise those of us not versed in the vagaries of international law, a morass that Ms. Belzberg helps express visually through screens filled with Lemkinâ€™s laborious handwriting. Most ambitiously, she conveys the multiple fronts and time frames for combating genocide, connecting, for example, the shame of the Srebrenica massacre, the Darfur crisis and the diplomatic loose ends Lemkin couldnâ€™t resolve. Lemkin himself died poor and isolated, which could do with more explanation here.

Bullet casings and shrapnel are probably not the most requested gifts by children whose parents travel for a living, but then most children donâ€™t have parents like Anna Neistat and Ole Solvang. As emergency investigators for the international organization Human Rights Watch, they have raised a son whose keepsake preferences owe more to war zones than to vacation guides.

Though two other members of the emergency team, Fred Abrahams and Peter Bouckaert, are also profiled, â€œE-Teamâ€ù clearly views them as supporting players. Their contributions are gripping, but we canâ€™t hang about: Ms. Neistat has given birth, and thereâ€™s a new baby to film.

That detail is emblematic of the problem with â€œE-Team,â€ù a documentary that purports to chronicle the sober and urgent work of those who ferret out human-rights abuses, but instead plays like a portrait of a rather glamorous marriage. Attractive and dedicated, Ms. Neistat and Mr. Solvang calmly endure a hairy 2013 border crossing into Syria, dodge cluster bombs and interview distraught survivors. Their findings from missions like this, disseminated in the news media and at conferences, illuminate oppressive regimes and can influence national policies.

But the filmmakers, Ross Kauffman and Katy Chevigny, appear more dazzled by the personal than by the political. Hovering over Mr. Solvang as he plays piano in the coupleâ€™s cozy Paris apartment, or zooming in on Ms. Neistat applying lipstick before testifying at a significant event, the directors dilute the gravity and peril of the work itself. In one particularly offensive scene in Syria, Ms. Neistat wrestles with a too-short abaya, to the approving comments of male onlookers. â€œSexy,â€ù one murmurs when her calf is briefly exposed.

Heroic messenger or adrenaline addict? Truth teller or vulture? In â€œ1,000 Times Good Night,â€ù Rebecca (Juliette Binoche), a celebrated, morally self-righteous war photographer hooked on risk-taking, leads two lives that are in continual conflict.

The character is a stand-in for the filmâ€™s Norwegian director, Erik Poppe, a former photojournalist who, in a statement, recalls his thinking in that earlier career: â€œI wanted to tell my readers all over the world, â€˜This is what you should be concerned about.â€™Â â€ù My skeptical retort to that in todayâ€™s hyperactive media culture, in which more pictures of horror are spread than can possibly be assimilated, amounts to four words: â€œGood luck with that.â€ù
That truth can be ugly. When Rebecca is shown crouching over a fresh corpse and aiming her camera, she suggests nothing so much as a ravenous bird of prey.

Rebecca is so avid to be at the center of the action that she rides in the car carrying the bomber into the heart of the Afghan capital. After hurriedly exiting on the street, she canâ€™t resist taking one more shot. When the police notice, the bomb is prematurely detonated and Rebecca, who later blames herself, is seriously injured. The scene brings up the subject of how a photojournalistâ€™s presence can shape events. Her guilty conscience is no palliative for lives lost.

These glossily photographed domestic interludes resemble a high-end magazine spread in which the camera slavers over images of virtuous, beautiful people savoring the good life. You have the impression that, to a degree, Rebeccaâ€™s hazardous work is a form of atonement for good fortune that she feels she doesnâ€™t deserve.

Rebecca, who suffers a punctured lung, returns home. When Marcus insists she stop covering wars, she halfheartedly agrees. The movie brings in, then wisely drops, a half-baked subplot about possible government censorship of photojournalists.

Rebecca has already explained to her daughter that she is gripped by an unassuageable anger. Even when Ms. Binoche smiles, it registers as a shadow of sorrow on the face of someone who has seen too much of the worldâ€™s horrors to forget them. She is one of a few screen actors who can convey multiple conflicting emotions in a single glance. With an astonishing transparency, she disappears into the truth of her characters.

What makes â€œ1,000 Times Good Nightâ€ù more than a dramatic essay on wartime journalism is Ms. Binocheâ€™s wrenchingly honest portrayal of a woman of conscience driven by a mixture of guilt, nobility and self-importance, reckoning belatedly with her destructive impulses. Her final challenge is a trip with Steph to the Kakuma refugee camp in Kenya to help her daughter gather material for a school project on Africa. On a journey that she is assured involves no risk, a surprise attack on the camp puts them in harmâ€™s way, and Rebecca disobeys orders and compulsively rushes into the melee.

Between grueling assignments in which she faces death by venturing into the heart of the fray, camera in hand, Rebecca returns to a picture-perfect existence at her home on the Irish seacoast. She is married to Marcus (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau, from â€œGame of Thronesâ€ù), a dashing marine biologist who frets every time she departs for a war front. They have two daughters; the elder, Stephanie (Lauryn Canny), is a teenager and a precociously talented artist.

As the movie begins, Rebecca, while working undercover on a story about life inside the Taliban, is snapping pictures of explosives being strapped onto a female suicide bomber by other women. The screenplay, by Harald Rosenlow Eeg, implicitly compares Rebeccaâ€™s willingness to die for her work with the womenâ€™s embrace of sacrifice for a religious cause.
â€œ23 Blastâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned) for a small amount of teenage drinking.

Itâ€™s a high school football tale (the title is one of the teamâ€™s running plays), inspired by a true story but taking too many liberties with it. Travis Freeman (Mark Hapka), a student in Corbin, Ky., loses his eyesight to a disease, but with the encouragement of a grizzled coach (Stephen Lang) and a no-nonsense mobility therapist (Becky Ann Baker), he continues playing football.

Although the film has moments when itâ€™s serious about exploring the challenges that someone in Travisâ€™s situation faces, it ultimately prefers to be just another football movie with a hokey big-game ending. The Christian message is nicely muted â€” the real Travis Freeman, appearing as a preacher in a dream sequence, provides most of it â€” but the movie ultimately equates â€œinspirationalâ€ù with â€œtouchdown.â€ù Thatâ€™s too bad; there was a more thoughtful film to be made out of Mr. Freemanâ€™s story.

Two-thirds of the way into â€œ23 Blast,â€ù it seems as if this inspirational Christian-themed film just might have the ingredient that almost none of its cousins in the genre do: restraint. But then comes the ending, so predictable and clichÃ©-filled and lacking in credibility that it overshadows the decent work done earlier.

The documentary â€œAlgorithmsâ€ù applies the durable â€œSpellboundâ€ù template to the milieu of blind chess in India. It follows three aspiring champions â€” Anant, Sai Krishna and Darpan â€” and a former one, Charudatta Jadhav, who coaches them and has a habit of increasing the pressure even when heâ€™s trying to be supportive.

Showcasing scenes of home life â€” Darpan explains his daily routine in exacting detail â€” as well as tournaments, â€œAlgorithmsâ€ù doesnâ€™t succeed in conveying a sense of game play. (Blindness is a difficult subject for the screen.)

â€œAlgorithmsâ€ù is shot in striking black-and-white video and seems oddly trustworthy for not having a crowd-pleasing finale. Still, the movie is an object lesson in how a remarkable subject can be turned into a less remarkable film.

Nor is this movie as informative as it might have been. Away from the boards, a player at a competition in Serbia raises a point that never receives adequate follow-up. Since there arenâ€™t enough fully blind players, he says, â€œThey are letting anyone with a small eye problem to play in the blind category.â€ù

As a younger man, Charu, as heâ€™s known, says he won national titles after losing his vision. As much as he covets a prize at the World Junior Blind Chess Championship, he considers competitive play against the â€œsightedâ€ù as the ultimate aim. More broadly, he approaches teaching chess to blind students as a way of giving them confidence about competing in India at large.

It is everywhere and nowhere, the leviathan whose belly is our native atmosphere. Mr. Snowden, unplugging the telephone in his room, hiding under a blanket when typing on his laptop, looking mildly panicked when a fire alarm is tested on his floor, can seem paranoid. He can also seem to be practicing a kind of avant-garde common sense. Itâ€™s hard to tell the difference, and thinking about the issues Ms. Poitras raises can induce a kind of epistemological vertigo. What do we know about what is known about us? Who knows it? Can we trust them? These questions are terrifying, and so is â€œCitizenfour.â€ù

Maybe some of this is ordinary-guy shtick, but it hardly matters. What makes Mr. Snowden fascinating â€” a great movie character, whatever you think of his cause â€” is the combination of diffidence, resolve and unpretentious intelligence that makes him so familiar. Slightly hipsterish, vaguely nerdy, with a trace of the coastal South in his voice (he was born in North Carolina and grew up mostly in Maryland), he is someone you might have seen at Starbucks or college or Bonnaroo. One of us, you might say.

There are two ways to look at â€œCitizenfour,â€ù Laura Poitrasâ€™s documentary about Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor whose revelations of widespread surveillance launched a hundred Op-Ed columns a year ago. The first and most obvious is as a piece of advocacy journalism, a goad to further argument about how security and transparency should be balanced in a democracy, about how governments abuse technology, about how official secrets are kept and exposed. The second is as a movie, an elegant and intelligent contribution to the flourishing genre of dystopian allegory.

And â€œCitizenfour,â€ù much of which consists of conversations between Mr. Snowden and Mr. Greenwald, emphasizes his bravery and his idealism, and the malignancy of the forces ranged against him. This is obviously a partial, partisan view, and several journalists on the national security and technology beats â€” among them Fred Kaplan at Slate and Michael Cohen (formerly of The Guardian) at The Daily Beast â€” have pointed out omissions and simplifications. Those criticisms, and George Packerâ€™s long, respectful and skeptical profile of Ms. Poitras in a recent issue of The New Yorker, express the desire for a middle ground, a balance between the public right to know and the governmentâ€™s need to collect intelligence in the fight against global terrorism.

â€œCitizenfour,â€ù happily, suffers no such fate. Cinema, even in the service of journalism, is always more than reporting, and focusing on what Ms. Poitrasâ€™s film is about risks ignoring what it is. Itâ€™s a tense and frightening thriller that blends the brisk globe-trotting of the â€œBourneâ€ù movies with the spooky, atmospheric effects of a Japanese horror film. And it is also a primal political fable for the digital age, a real-time tableau of the confrontation between the individual and the state.

Mr. Snowdenâ€™s face is by now well known â€” it has been printed on demonstratorsâ€™ masks and stylized posters â€” but when he first encounters Ms. Poitras and her camera, he is anonymous and invisible, a nervous young man in a Hong Kong hotel room. He is shy, pale and serious, explaining his actions and motives in a mixture of technical jargon and lofty moral rhetoric. While he seems almost naÃ¯ve about the machinery of celebrity that is about to catch him in its gears, he is adamant in his desire to take public responsibility for his actions, partly to protect others who might be blamed. At the same time, he defers to Mr. Greenwald and Ewen MacAskill, a reporter for The Guardian, about when, how and how much of the information he is passing on will be shared with their readers.

But if he is us, then who is them? The officials from the Obama and George W. Bush administrations who have defended the N.S.A. in court, before Congress and on television, promising that the rule of law and the rights of citizens are being respected, even as the bad guys are being chased down and spied upon? Those presidents themselves, who preach liberty even as they expand the prerogatives of the executive branch? The telecommunications executives who collude in the collection of data?

â€œCitizenfourâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Not because of the nightmarish spectacle of unchecked state power, but because of the swearing it occasionally provokes.

Those who regard Mr. Snowden as an unambiguous hero, risking his freedom and comfort to expose abuses of power, will find much to agree with in Ms. Poitrasâ€™s presentation of his actions. This film is an authorized portrait, made at its subjectâ€™s invitation. In 2013, Mr. Snowden, using encrypted email under the alias â€œcitizen four,â€ù contacted Ms. Poitras and the journalist Glenn Greenwald, inviting them to meet him in Hong Kong, where he would share what he had learned about the N.S.A.â€™s capacity to intercept data from the phone calls, emails and web wanderings of American citizens. When asked why he had chosen her, Mr. Snowden, his identity still electronically shrouded, replied that she had selected herself, based on her previous work as a journalist and filmmaker, including a short documentary about William Binney, an N.S.A. whistle-blower who also appears in â€œCitizenfour.â€ù

Mr. Greenwald, a prolific writer and prodigious talker (in Portuguese, too!), has made his case against secrecy and surveillance in numerous articles, blog posts, books and television appearances. Ms. Poitras, who does not appear on camera in her film and speaks only when reading Mr. Snowdenâ€™s emails to her, pursues a slightly different project. She deploys the tools of her trade â€” spooky music and fluid editing, subtle camera movements and suggestive compositions â€” to try to coax a specter into view.

Fair enough, I guess. Such balance may be a journalistic shibboleth; it is not necessarily a cinematic virtue. â€œThe Fifth Estate,â€ù last yearâ€™s nondocumentary attempt to tell the story of Julian Assange and WikiLeaks, bogged down in the pursuit of sensible moderation, losing the chance to write history in lightning.

All of the above, but maybe also not quite any of them. Plenty of movies have tried to imagine the contours of state power, but â€œCitizenfourâ€ù stands alone in evoking the modern state as an unseen, ubiquitous presence, an abstraction with enormous coercive resources at its disposal. To some extent, Ms. Poitras and Mr. Greenwald are engaged in a theoretical inquiry, a kind of speculative mapping, of the shape and reach of this mysterious entity. That is not to say that the United States governmentâ€™s data collection program is not real, but rather that its extent and implications are only beginning to be understood.

Another day, another cabin in the woods and another hairy monster with titanic tootsies. It was only a few months ago that Bobcat Goldthwaitâ€™s â€œWillow Creekâ€ù sent a pair of innocents into the shrubbery on a found-footage hunt for Bigfoot. Now â€œExists,â€ù with its five young-and-dumb vacationers, offers Sasquatch a more substantial meal.
Directed by Eduardo Sanchez
â€œExistsâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Buttocks are bared, joints are smoked, and stupidity is punished.
1 hour 26 minutes

Featuring the usual fractured visuals, generic victims and pinballing cameras â€” both hand-held and mounted on bike helmets â€” â€œExistsâ€ù nevertheless has an unusually dreamy opening and a few surprisingly entertaining tweaks. As he proved in his 2012 creeper, â€œLovely Molly,â€ù Mr. Sanchez is adept at managing mayhem in confined spaces, and here he turns the inside of a tumbling trailer into a tossed salad of broken bodies.
EXISTS
And at least this time, the African-American isnâ€™t the first to die.
Opens on Friday

It also offers viewers a more tangible view of a critter (played by the 6-foot-7 creature actor, Brian Steele) thatâ€™s commonly presented as an amorphous shape lumbering through undergrowth and peeking from behind tree trunks. As envisioned by the director Eduardo Sanchez, this Bigfoot is virtually Norma Desmond, its King Kong mug leering in the cabin windows and confronting the camera with more emotional range than its human co-stars. And boy, can it move: In one scene, a hapless young man sets off on his bicycle to find a cellphone signal. What he finds instead is the equivalent of a furry locomotive on his tail.

The specimens under examination are Tomas (Johannes Bah Kuhnke) and Ebba (Lisa Loven Kongsli), an attractive Swedish couple on a family ski vacation in the French Alps. Both initially come across as so smug in their contentment that they appear unaware of any seams or cracks in their relationship. An early scene of them asleep in bed with their two beautiful children, Vera and Harry (the real-life siblings Clara and Vincent Wettergren), provokes a twinge of envy. In advertising language, they are â€œliving the dream.â€ù

Tomas and Ebbaâ€™s escalating conflict spills over to another couple, Mats (Kristofer Hivju) and Fanni (Fanni Metelius), a divorced parent and his 20-year-old girlfriend. As Mats sympathizes with Tomasâ€™s instinctive fearfulness, the discussion becomes a battle of the sexes, in which the men defend their honor and manliness with explanations that, however reasonable, donâ€™t satisfy their partners. The surest sign that the men feel guilty and ashamed of their behavior is that neither can sleep. The knowledge that in some fundamental way theyâ€™ve been found out gnaws at the men. In examining machismo, the movie touches on themes found in Ernest Hemingwayâ€™s story â€œThe Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber.â€ù

The jolt that shatters the coupleâ€™s serenity comes on Day 2 of their five-day vacation, when an avalanche rolls toward the outdoor cafe where the family is eating lunch. As it draws closer, panic takes hold. Without thinking, Tomas grabs his gloves and iPhone and flees, leaving his wife and children to fend for themselves. In minutes, the danger is over, and everything returns to normal. No one was hurt. What had loomed as a catastrophe was just a side effect of a controlled avalanche that stopped well short of the cafe.

But within the family, everything has changed. Ebba is chilly and remote, and the children upset and fearful. Tomas acts a little sheepish but pretends that nothing is seriously wrong. Later, when they meet with friends, Ebba pointedly brings up what happened and tells her side of the story, implying that Tomasâ€™s spontaneous instinct for self-preservation, without regard for his family, was unforgivable. When he refuses to engage her and explain his side of the story, Ebba can no longer contain her fury and contempt.

Observed in the eerie blue snow light, the resortâ€™s upkeep is a nonstop struggle to manage the environment at a very high altitude. Some might call the effort hubristic. And the scenes of skiers, blithely sweeping down the slopes while equipped to the teeth, suggest the same hubris. Besides the explosions, the soundtrack is punctuated by ominous squeaks, groans and creaking noises that convey the strain of all the mountain machinery.
â€œForce Majeureâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for some strong language and brief nudity.

In the most excruciating scene, Tomas breaks down uncontrollably in front of the children, while the disgusted Ebba tries to soothe them. Mr. Kuhnkeâ€™s Tomas is all the creepier, because even when sobbing hysterically, his display of emotion seems a half-faked, groveling play for pity.

Just under the surface of a seemingly blissful marriage run fissures that a sudden jolt can tear open to reveal a crumbling edifice. Thatâ€™s the unsettling reality explored with a merciless lens in the Swedish director Ruben Ostlundâ€™s fourth feature film, â€œForce Majeure.â€ù This brilliant, viciously amusing takedown of bourgeois complacency, gender stereotypes and assumptions and the illusion of security rubs your face in human frailty as relentlessly as any Michael Haneke movie.

What makes â€œForce Majeureâ€ù much more than a clinically accurate depiction of a middle-class marriage in crisis is its keen understanding of how, in modern civilization, people increasingly imagine that they can control nature. But what about human nature? Until it smacks them in the face, they ignore their irrational, atavistic drives. No matter how well we talk the talk of technological mastery and rationality, there are crazy parts of us that remain beyond the reach of language to explain or resolve.

From this point, â€œForce Majeureâ€ù doesnâ€™t know quite where to go. Although there are more little dramas to come, and Tomas tries to redeem himself, something is irreparably broken. What is painfully clear is that fear and denial are the emotional modus operandi of both parents.

Earlier in the movie, we have witnessed her conversation with another guest at the resort, who shocks Ebba with her blasÃ© description of her own open marriage. Ebba is horrified, and we see how her innate fearfulness has spread like a fever to her supersensitive children, who, at the first sign of tension between their parents, cry and fret over the thought of divorce.

The upscale resort they visit, with its polished blond-wood interiors and breathtaking views, looks as picture-perfect as their marriage. Tomas and Ebba take it for granted that they are safe in this luxurious cocoon, despite the explosions that are regularly detonated on the mountain to manage the accumulated snow through controlled avalanches.

Does the tour seem a little exploitative, given Mr. Campbellâ€™s condition? Maybe. But family members address that, defending it as an awareness vehicle and a gift to his longtime fans. In any case, the film is a rare combination of instructive and poignant.

Mr. Campbellâ€™s wife, Kim, is the main voice in the film, which shows just enough of the worst moments of Alzheimerâ€™s â€” the raging, the inability to recognize loved ones â€” to make you appreciate how drastically the disease affects everyone close to the person who has it. Itâ€™s a sight that occurs repeatedly in â€œGlen Campbell ... Iâ€™ll Be Me,â€ù a documentary that chronicles Mr. Campbellâ€™s final concert tour, which he undertook in 2011, even as Alzheimerâ€™s was tightening its hold on his mind. Infused with codes and totems â€” like the dog collar and bracelet carefully aligned on Johnâ€™s bedside table â€” â€œJohn Wickâ€ù conjures a natty netherworld of lethal temperaments and impeccable tailoring. Johnâ€™s quest may be one-note, but that note could not be more perfectly pitched.

When a movie characterâ€™s last name is synonymous with â€œfuse,â€ù the audience will be wondering when to expect his meltdown. In â€œJohn Wick,â€ù that happens not when Johnâ€™s beloved wife â€” who has finally succumbed to a long illness â€” has been laid in the ground, and not when Iosef (Alfie Allen), the loutish son of a Russian mob boss, accosts him at a gas station. For John (Keanu Reeves), the ultimate insult comes when Iosef and his thugs break into Johnâ€™s upscale home and kill his dog.

Brilliant in its simplicity, the setup of â€œJohn Wick,â€ù like the rest of the movie, passes swiftly and efficiently. Harboring few ambitions beyond knock-your-socks-off action sequences, this crafty revenge thriller delivers with so much style â€” and even some wit â€” that the lack of substance takes longer than it should to become problematic. Until then, weâ€™re content to tag along as John, revealed as the ne plus ultra of former assassins, comes out of retirement and into the cross hairs.

And then thereâ€™s Mr. Reeves, always more comfortable in roles that demand cool over hot, attitude over emotion. Never at ease as one of a pack or as a romantic lead, heâ€™s a loner with a dancerâ€™s walk (from the hips, not the knees) and a physical charisma that the camera locks on to. Filming in New York City and Rockland County, Mr. Stahelski (who was Mr. Reevesâ€™s stunt double in â€œConstantineâ€ù and two of the â€œMatrixâ€ù films) proves an elegant and inventive choreographer of movement. Annika lives with her sarcastic, heartbroken dad, Craig (Sam Rockwell), her mother (Gretchen Mol) having run off some time ago to become a lingerie model. Like Ms. Sheltonâ€™s earlier films (â€œYour Sisterâ€™s Sisterâ€ù and â€œHumpdayâ€ù), this one takes place in and around Seattle, a place apparently full of unpretentious white people, neither intimidatingly cool nor tediously generic. The rough, lived-in, naturalistic look belies a soft sitcom heart, and every foray into risky emotional territory prefigures a retreat into clichÃ©.
