Jean-Luc Godard, who will soon celebrate his 84th birthday, holds a special place in the pantheon of modern cinema. He is an imp who is venerated as a deity, a Rorschach test, a lightning rod, a fighting word. His name seems to divide the world into skeptics and worshipers, with not much middle ground. Analogous figures can be found in other zones of 20th-century art: Andy Warhol, Bob Dylan, Ezra Pound. They have their singularity in common. They also tend to confound easy distinctions between genius and trickery, and to marshal armies of exegetes in what may be the futile enterprise of figuring out what they mean.

But it is worth noting that the man and the woman have, within the film, distinct functions and positions. Not only does she remain standing while he conducts his business, but her own business is also, in no small part, to be displayed as an object for contemplation and erotic reverie. He, too, is naked, but the camera is far more interested in looking at her.

In the 1960s, as Mr. Godard ascended to international culture-hero status, one of his most eloquent English-language champions was Susan Sontag. Nearly 50 years later, he may be returning the favor by making movies that uphold the arguments of her great essay â€œAgainst Interpretation,â€ù which protested culture and criticismâ€™s tireless and tiresome hunt for meaning.

Mr. Godard has a habit of blending gravity with whimsy. His latest film, a 70-minute 3-D visual essay called â€œGoodbye to Languageâ€ù (â€œAdieu au Langageâ€ù), exhibits the formal and philosophical mischief that has been his late-career calling card. It is baffling and beautiful, a flurry of musical and literary snippets arrayed in counterpoint to a series of brilliantly colored and hauntingly evocative pictures â€” of flowers, boats, streets, naked bodies and Mr. Godardâ€™s own dog, a mixed-breed scene-stealer identified in the credits as Roxy MiÃ©ville.

Itâ€™s not all about pleasure, though. Much of the film is spent with a couple in a state of casual undress and post-coital ennui. She speaks in philosophical riddles and proverbs, the sources of which can be inferred from the cryptic bibliography that appears, along with a list of composers, in the end credits. He sits on the toilet, defecating loudly and opining that this action represents the only true form of human equality. â€œA position and a functionâ€ù that we all share.

There is also the suggestion of a plot, or rather a gesture in the direction of a weave of narratives involving political intrigue and adultery and touching on some of the filmmakerâ€™s recurrent preoccupations. These include the nightmares of the European, with special attention to imperialism and the Holocaust; the alienation of human emotion under capitalism; and the contradictory nature of cinema itself as both the repository and the destroyer of memory. â€œGoodbye to Languageâ€ù is divided into chapters with the headings â€œNatureâ€ù and â€œMetaphor,â€ù suggesting the basic division, fundamental to human thought, between the world we encounter and the names we assign to its phenomena.

â€œIn place of a hermeneutics we need an erotics of art,â€ù she concluded, and â€œGoodbye to Languageâ€ù rewards just such an approach. If you try, especially on a first viewing, to crack its code or plumb its depths, you are likely to pass a frustrated hour and 10 minutes. But if you surrender, you might have a good time. The earth might even move.

He is delighted by paradoxes of flatness and depth, for example, the way the flat surface of a television showing an old-fashioned two-dimensional movie changes the volume of a room. He also, just for fun, superimposes one person on another, creating a jarring hallucination. At another point, he films a naked woman holding a platter on which a pitcher and a bowl of fruit have been arranged, combining two major genres of painting (the nude and the still life) into a moment of naturalistic surrealism.

Mr. Godardâ€™s embrace of digital video â€” most notably in his 2001 film, â€œIn Praise of Loveâ€ù â€” helped to reveal that formatâ€™s latent aesthetic potency. He accomplishes something similar with 3-D in â€œGoodbye to Language.â€ù There are none of the usual special effects to be seen here: Mr. Godard has no interest in capturing the magic of flight or making monsters seem real. Instead, the everyday world is made vivid and strange, rendered in a series of sketches and compositions by an artist with an eccentric and unerring eye.

An old cinematic god can hardly be expected to learn new tricks, and womenâ€™s bodies have often served Mr. Godard â€” and not only him, goodness knows â€” as convenient metaphors for the mysteries of nature and the forces that lie on the far side of language. That is, no doubt, a topic for further discussion. In any case this movie, its title notwithstanding, is unlikely to be the filmmakerâ€™s last word.

The movieâ€™s most vivid description of the Mekonsâ€™ amateurish early sound comes from Mary Harron, a rock journalist turned filmmaker (â€œThe Notorious Bettie Pageâ€ù) who profiled the musicians in 1979. She noted their combination of â€œsophisticated theory and technical incompetence.â€ù The Mekons later infused their songs with folk and country instrumentation that the critic Greg Kot of The Chicago Tribune says in the film created something â€œbeautiful and profoundâ€ù by getting country music wrong.

Thereâ€™s far more fun in seeing the singer Sally Timms egg on Jon Langford, a Mekons co-founder, as he does a goofy â€œRiverdanceâ€ù-esque routine than there is in watching surgical close-ups of Mick Jagger mindlessly twist through Martin Scorseseâ€™s â€œShine a Lightâ€ù (2008). Adapting to the times, both in sensibility and in membership, the Mekons are depicted less as a band than as a democratic ideal â€” or perhaps an attitude, which the movie makes contagious.

â€œRevenge of the Mekonsâ€ù captures the group in the years surrounding its album â€œAncient & Modernâ€ù (2011), both in dive-y gigs and in more relaxed, extracurricular settings. Not every punk group has a violinist, like Susie Honeyman, who runs a gallery in London. Late in the film, we see glimpses of a conceptual theater piece the band staged for the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

Deftly balancing music appreciation with reminiscences from past and current Mekons, as well as figures theyâ€™ve influenced (Will Oldham, Jonathan Franzen), the movie is clearly a fanâ€™s portrait, even to excess. But â€œRevenge of the Mekonsâ€ù is ultimately not so much an examination of the Mekonsâ€™ fidelity to the punk philosophy, or of where they stand politically relative to Gang of Four or the Clash, as it is an ode to creative reinvention.

The collective, as itâ€™s often called, now stretches from Los Angeles to Siberia. The members compose when theyâ€™re together. â€œNo one person can have an idea,â€ù the singer Lu Edmonds says facetiously about their songwriting sessions in a radio interview.

In the liner notes for a 1982 record from the Mekons, the critic Lester Bangs wrote that the band would â€œgourmandiseâ€ù rock. (He also suggested that he was paid $1,500 to write the essay.) â€œRevenge of the Mekons,â€ù an infectious new documentary from Joe Angio, is a celebration of that voracity. The film is both a generous primer on the band, which grew out of the punk movement in Leeds, England, in 1977, and a celebration of its longevity.

Amid the cynicism, evasion and denial, a local hero stands out. Roosevelt Harris, a volunteer at a food pantry in Bayou La Batre, billed as Alabamaâ€™s seafood capital, advises the embittered and despairing workers who lost their jobs and homes to file claims. Such is their lack of faith in the system that they would rather not bother.

One of the most revealing scenes shows the chief executives of top oil companies answering questions before Congress and sounding like guilty, overgrown boys facing a grade school principal after being caught cheating. In another scene, a smug industry honcho gloatingly surmises that the American thirst for oil is so enormous that if the supply were cut off, the economy would collapse within hours.

Since the catastrophe, which began with an oil rig explosion that killed 11 workers and led to a discharge of millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico, the company that operated the rig, BP, has cleaned up less than one-third of the spill, according to the film. More than four years later, Congress has yet to pass any safety legislation for the petroleum industry. Of the multibillion-dollar profits made by BP over a recent three-year period, the film says, less than a tenth of 1 percent was spent on safety. After a brief moratorium on offshore drilling, the ban was lifted, and there are now more rigs in the Gulf of Mexico than before the disaster.

The film, for which BP executives declined to be interviewed, is not a thunderous, finger-pointing exposÃ© of corporate greed and mismanagement. Nor is it a dry, fact-filled history of the disaster or an analysis of the technology of oil drilling. The 92-minute movie also leaves it for others to explore the spillâ€™s ecological and environmental impact. There are a few obligatory images of sea birds coated with oil and aerial shots of oil slicks destined for the Gulf Coast.

The filmâ€™s portrayal of the trust fund, administered by Kenneth R. Feinberg, suggests that money was mismanaged and cut off prematurely. Many who were promised restitution received one or two small checks, then nothing. Mr. Feinberg, who comes across as highhanded and grandiose, acknowledges that he â€œoverpromisedâ€ù prompt delivery of relief.

Caught in the middle are people like Douglas Harold Brown, the Deepwater Horizonâ€™s chief mechanic, who was aboard the rig when the explosion took place. Mr. Brown delivers a moment-by-moment account of the disaster, while the screen shows the inferno of billowing smoke and flames. Mr. Brown details how he and the workers on the rig were pressured to eliminate jobs to save money. â€œEverybody knewâ€ù the dangers, he says. â€œIt makes me feel guilty, because I played along. I knew what I was doing was wrong.â€ù He links that failure to a macho culture in the oil business that glorifies risk-taking.

The new filmâ€™s ground-level perspective includes interviews with several people who received minimal compensation from the $20 billion trust fund established to settle claims from the spill. The mistrustful attitude of these tough, independent workers near the bottom of the economic ladder toward those near the top is the underlying theme here. The glaring contrast between grim oyster shuckers and idled fishermen and Houston executives crowing about the fundamental importance of oil to the economy suggests a tragic disconnect between societyâ€™s haves and have-nots.

The principal focus is on the everyday people whose lives were disrupted. A similar emphasis on human beings informed Ms. Brownâ€™s acclaimed 2008 documentary, â€œThe Order of Myths,â€ù an exploration of Mardi Gras culture in Mobile, Ala.

â€œThe Great Invisible,â€ù Margaret Brownâ€™s quietly infuriating documentary film about the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill, includes depressing information that many would probably be happier not knowing.

Ms. Kidman gives the role all sheâ€™s got and practically drowns in her own tears as sad new facts come to light, and Mr. Firth proves he can play nasty as well as nice. If it werenâ€™t for the diligent performances of its stars, who inject some emotional depth into this bogus claptrap, â€œBefore I Go to Sleepâ€ù would be an unwatchable, titter-inducing catastrophe.
â€œBefore I Go to Sleepâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian) for brutal violence and strong language.

A damsel in distress with amnesia and a creepily solicitous mate: Thatâ€™s really all you need to know about the story, in which Christineâ€™s memory begins to return after 13 years with the help of Dr. Nasch (Mark Strong), a grim neuropsychologist who fancies her. The plot conceit, in which Christine forgets each dayâ€™s events as soon as she goes to sleep, has a vague resemblance to â€œGroundhog Day.â€ù But this movie, directed by Rowan Joffe (â€œBrighton Rockâ€ù), doesnâ€™t have an ounce of levity.

Unknown to Ben, the good doctor telephones Christine each morning, reidentifies himself and directs her to a camera buried in her closet so she can record a video diary. Her memory begins to return in jarring flashbacks. Questioned by Christine, Ben reveals that she lost her memory in a violent assault.

The opening image of â€œBefore I Go to Sleep,â€ù a preposterous thriller adapted from S. J. Watsonâ€™s best-selling novel, is an extreme close-up of a blue, bloodshot eye. That orb belongs to Christine (Nicole Kidman), a damsel in distress afflicted with that hoary soap-opera device, amnesia. When Christine wakes up every morning, she has no idea where she is and not a clue about the man in bed with her who claims to be her husband, Ben (Colin Firth).

Narrated by Sigourney Weaver (and having precisely nothing to do with the Beatles), the movie focuses on migrant families who have crossed from Myanmar into Thailand, where they live without documents and state services. The police can fine them for not having papers. The children are at risk of kidnapping and trafficking.

â€œAll You Need Is Loveâ€ù grew out of an education project spearheaded by Suzy Amis Cameron, one of the executive producers and the wife of the filmmaker James Cameron. (She is not related to this filmâ€™s director, Stuart Cameron.) The blatantly pedagogical mission shows. Only during a brief scene of a man catching a fish outside his flooded house does the movie seem interested in anything more than raising awareness.

The school, founded by Paw Ray, an advocate of migrant education, teaches them free of charge. The film observes much, from the crowded classroom activities to the cook to duck-duck-goose. Itâ€™s shot, scored and explicated in a button-pushing manner. â€œFailure was never an option for the children at Good Morning School,â€ù Ms. Weaver narrates over footage of the students taking tests.

If youâ€™re looking for an informational video on why the Good Morning School in Mae Sot, Thailand, may need donations, â€œAll You Need Is Loveâ€ù fits the bill. If, on the other hand, what you want is a theatrical documentary â€” something with a narrative shape, vivid subjects and the spark of an artistic impulse that might elevate it above uncomplicated advocacy â€” this film falls woefully short.

Sadra, who has two spouses, frequents a red light district (but not for sex, he insists). One wife lives with their children in a separate home, though she hasnâ€™t divorced him. Divorce is legal in Bali, but custody laws invariably favor fathers. Sadraâ€™s other wife has suffered dearly from his beatings â€” as did his mother from his fatherâ€™s violence.

Tuaji, 80, of royal blood, has five surviving spouses out of 10, two of them sisters. His wealth and reputation for ferocity during Indonesiaâ€™s turbulent 1960s make him an unquestioned household head.

There is nothing remotely salacious about â€œBitter Honey,â€ù an agonizing documentary examination of polygamy in Bali, Indonesia, from the U.C.L.A. anthropologist Robert Lemelson. There is only vivid evidence of a society that, despite limp efforts at discouraging domestic abuse, remains mired in ancient patriarchy, sanctioning polygamy and, implicitly, often attendant violence. (A â€œhoney,â€ù we learn, is an old regional expression for a second wife.)
The heroine here is Luh Putu Anggreni, a womenâ€™s-rights lawyer who stages an intervention at Sadraâ€™s home with his employer present. Her struggle appears entirely uphill.

Darma, a burly bruiser, stages cockfights and exudes palpable aggression. He deceived four of his five future wives about his marital status, and one describes how she was courted while she was in junior high. At a rare gathering of his entire brood, he canâ€™t remember the names of all of his children, many of whom say they have no desire to emulate his domestic arrangement.

An introductory text on screen for the vampire flick â€œBlood Ransomâ€ù offers a wordy explanation of how this movieâ€™s bloodsuckers differ from the usual variety: Theyâ€™re impervious to crucifixes; they can run around in sunlight (though they prefer not to); and their passage into full-fledged vampiredom can take a week or so. I can add that they donâ€™t change into bats or seem to sleep in coffins.

So whatâ€™s left? Two British vampires (Caleb Hunt and Jamie Harris) in Southern California, hunting an escaped vampire-in-the-making (Anne Curtis); a smitten man (Alexander Dreymon) who takes her on the lam; his best friend, a detective (Darion Basco) trying to conceive with his wife while pursuing a mystery surrounding his dead father; and the detectiveâ€™s office partner (Clifton Powell), who questions his motives. Itâ€™s all very solemn, convoluted and a bit bloody, but not engrossing, despite impressive cinematography by Jasmin Kuhn and Mr. dela Torre and the best efforts of a hard-working cast.

Ms. Curtis, a Filipino-Australian actress making her American film debut, suffers nobly, with full lips and heavy eyelashes, parading in leather and occasionally acquiring fangs, a veiny complexion and flaring red eyes. She is not without charisma, but this is not her proper vehicle. It would be interesting to see her in a role of more down-to-earth dimensions.

Originally developed in the mid-1870s to house the workers for Andrew Carnegieâ€™s first steel mill (two furnaces remain operational), Braddock holds a significant place in the history of American labor, one that the filmmakers take pains to establish. Vintage scenes of happy families and strutting young men give way to more doleful sights of imploding factories, leaving only magnificent ruins where the ghosts of generations jostle and whisper.

â€œA long time ago, things got broken here,â€ù a 2010 Leviâ€™s advertising campaign, filmed in Braddock, intones, as if the townâ€™s few thousand remaining residents needed to be told. Itâ€™s through the voices and mettle of those hardy few (including the filmmaker, Tony Buba) that â€œBraddock Americaâ€ù pierces the skin. Whether in a council meeting or a near-empty church, they offer a heartbreaking look at what industrialization wrought and globalization wrecked.

A blue collar poem threaded with old-timer memories and present-day pain, â€œBraddock Americaâ€ù pays bittersweet tribute to a once-thriving Pennsylvania steel town and those who stuck around to bear witness to its decline.

Walking the line where prosperity ended and destitution began, the directors, Gabriella Kessler and Jean-LoÃ¯c Portron, work with silent sensitivity to shape moving oral testimony and haunting black-and-white film into a despairing Rust Belt memoir. Images of belching smokestacks illustrate fond recollections of waking up to air thick with blast-furnace grit (â€œno dirt, no jobs,â€ù one man reminds us) and dust that clogged the throat and blurred the eye. Nowadays, men tear up for different reasons.

Rickyâ€™s best friend, Seth (Will Sasso), shows him â€œBody Heatâ€ù to point out what would seem obvious to any sentient being: Ricky is dating a femme fatale. But Ricky is so smitten, and feels he has so little to lose, that heâ€™s willing to proceed even after it emerges that the husband (Jed Rees) is a former rabbi turned crime novelist â€” apparently a nice guy.

The filmâ€™s writer and director, Ricky Blitt, has worked on â€œFamily Guy,â€ù and he contributed to one of the more dire sections of â€œMovie 43.â€ù Given how often characters knock on Rickyâ€™s apartment door, â€œHit by Lightningâ€ù often resembles a laugh-deprived â€œSeinfeldâ€ù episode.
Opens on Friday

The catch â€” hinted at by the way she disappears without notice â€” is that sheâ€™s married. Because her husband would kill her if she were ever to leave him, she says, she needs Ricky to kill him first.

Mr. Sasso â€” Curly in the Farrelly brothersâ€™ remake of â€œThe Three Stoogesâ€ù â€” has the only role with multiple traits: Seth progresses from a backslapping chauvinist to a devoted pal who will help his buddy with anything, including murder. But even with a few late twists, concept exceeds execution.

Online dating gets yet another cautionary tale in â€œHit by Lightning,â€ù a tiresome parody of â€œDouble Indemnity.â€ù Ricky (Jon Cryer), the 40-something manager of a Dennyâ€™s-like restaurant, is afraid that heâ€™ll be the last of his high school friends to be married. He joins EHappily.com only to meet his ideal woman, Danita (Stephanie Szostak), on the first outing.
1 hour 29 minutes; not rated
Directed by Ricky Blitt

One morning, a fellow named Ig Perrish, played with overcaffeinated intensity by Daniel Radcliffe, wakes up to discover that a pair of horns have sprouted around his hairline. Like poor Gregor Samsa in Kafkaâ€™s â€œThe Metamorphosis,â€ù Ig never really understands why this transformation has taken place, but if the causes are mysterious, the effects are truly bizarre.

In spite of its Halloween opening, â€œHorns,â€ù directed by Alexandre Aja and adapted by Keith Bunin from a novel by Joe Hill, is not exactly a horror movie. It is nasty and creepy, for sure, with snakes and devils and a horrible murder, but not especially scary in the traditional sense. Gruesome occurrences are more likely to be mined for laughs than for gasps of terror, and the supernatural developments are played out in a mood of metaphysical melodrama.

Not that Ig is altogether innocent, at least in the eyes of his family, friends and fellow citizens. Before the arrival of the horns, he had been branded as evil, accused of the murder of Merrin Williams (Juno Temple), his girlfriend since childhood and the great love of his life. Her death haunts him, and the narrative momentum of â€œHornsâ€ù is supplied by his effort to find Merrinâ€™s killer and clear his name.

People who encounter Ig donâ€™t seem especially bothered by his changed appearance, but they do find themselves compelled to tell him the truth. Specifically, they are eager to confess, without any guilt or shame, their ugly desires and secret sins. He becomes a sponge for all the lust, bigotry and plain meanness in his Washington logging town, and there seems to be a lot to go around.
â€œHornsâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Bloodshed and swearing.

And a bit let down at the end, when all the noise, color and energy resolve into a basic whodunit decked out in weak special effects and spiritual swamp gas. But along the way, you can enjoy a garish, eccentric haunted-house tour in the company of some interesting actors, including Max Minghella, Heather Graham, Kelli Garner and David Morse. And you can also appreciate Mr. Ajaâ€™s lurid, hysterical visual sensibility â€” his bright, wet colors and weirdly beautiful compositions â€” even if you sometimes wish it were employed in a more coherent movie.

Mr. Hillâ€™s book is long, feverish and messy, an unwieldy but never unreadable stew of mean satire, sincere feeling and quasi-religious mumbo-jumbo. Mr. Aja, whose previous films include the grisly French thriller â€œHigh Tensionâ€ù and the toothy exploitation-fest â€œPiranha 3D,â€ù honors his source in letter and in spirit. There are so many red herrings and plot twists, such a dense barrage of flashbacks and quick cuts, that you may find yourself as rattled and breathless as Ig himself.

Mr. Carbee, who died in 2005, was a commercial artist, hobby shop owner, resourceful tinkerer and shy gentle giant, whose obsession comes across as slightly more sweet than creepy. (His wife, who died in 1997 after 54 years of marriage, had nonetheless advised him, he says, against telling the neighbors.) After an impromptu visit, Mr. Workman found himself drawn into a voluminous correspondence with Mr. Carbee, and here he builds upon an earlier short film.

At one point in the interminable, self-narrated opening, Mr. Workman half-jokingly lists the festivals where his short film played â€” time that might have been better spent on further exploring Mr. Carbeeâ€™s work.

Ten years ago, the outsider artist Henry Darger was the subject of Jessica Yuâ€™s documentary â€œIn the Realms of the Unreal,â€ù which animated his baroque collage world of frolicking and warring girls. Now comes Jeremy Workmanâ€™s â€œMagical Universe,â€ù an overworked, home-video introduction to Al Carbee and his glam Barbie photography, which filled his cavernous Maine house (alongside tanks of guppies and much else).

Mr. Carbeeâ€™s work has a professional polish and a svelte pop beauty, and his softly voiced, sincere commentary and the opaque video quality suggest a dreamy public-access TV show. But while Mr. Workman evidently respects Mr. Carbeeâ€™s talent, he also frames his movie as a trite narrative about a kind of lovably odd acquaintance who comes out of his shell, without many incisive ideas about shaping or broadening the material. (He also doesnâ€™t acknowledge the craziness suggested by Mr. Carbeeâ€™s writings, shown in multipage, handwritten letters.)

A self-taught â€œcrash course in manhoodâ€ù is how Matthew VanDyke, the subject of Marshall Curryâ€™s incisive, queasy-making documentary â€œPoint and Shoot,â€ù describes the several years he spent filming a 35,000-mile motorcycle trip through North Africa and the Middle East, beginning in 2007.

Mr. VanDyke returned to the United States in late 2010, but the Arab Spring movement beckoned him back to Africa, where he rejoined a group of Libyan friends he had met on his earlier travels. He crossed the border into Libya and joined a rebel army seeking to oust Muammar el-Qaddafi.

Mr. VanDyke makes no apologies for his self-centeredness, but he tries to deflect criticism by disingenuously wondering out loud, â€œAm I performing?â€ù Yes, he is. But the message conveyed by his unexamined reflections on manhood and how he has changed isnâ€™t nearly as positive as he seems to imagine.

Mr. VanDyke, a pampered only child from a middle-class background in Baltimore, struggles with obsessive-compulsive disorder. And in the light of his derring-do, thereâ€™s something comical about his list of tics, which include compulsive hand-washing and a fear of sharing eating utensils. From early childhood, he devoured action films and video games. â€œLawrence of Arabia,â€ù from which a clip is shown, was a particularly potent stimulant.

â€œPoint and Shootâ€ù suggests that Mr. Curry, whom Mr. VanDyke approached to direct, turned the tables on his subject. In extensive interviews conducted by Mr. Curry, Mr. VanDyke comes across as smugly grandiose. In the most squirm-inducing footage, Mr. VanDyke documents what he solemnly says will be his first experience shooting someone, aims his gun out a window and misses his target.

Among other topics, this shameless exercise in vanity addresses the thrill of war-making, a subject also explored in recent documentaries like â€œRestrepoâ€ù and â€œKorengal,â€ù both set in Afghanistan. Making war alongside other men and handling guns, the soldiers in those films acknowledge, made them feel more alive than anything else. For some, it was the ultimate adrenaline high.

Soon he was captured by Qaddafiâ€™s forces and endured more than five months of solitary confinement in a filthy hellhole. During his isolation, he began to hallucinate that the entire world was fixated on his predicament. Because he was deprived of a camera, the prison scenes feature surreal animation by Joe Posner. The exact circumstances of his release are never clarified.

A loner for much of his life, Mr. VanDyke first experienced the power of belonging when, as a freelance war photographer, he tagged along with American soldiers fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan. He was on his way to becoming the star of his own adventure film under a comic-book pseudonym, Max Hunter.

â€œPoint and Shoot,â€ù which won the best documentary feature award at the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival, is many things, not the least of them one manâ€™s preening self-advertisement for his acquired machismo. The film speaks to the inner child in every latter-day Walter Mitty who fantasizes a life of swashbuckling adventure. You might even view it as a self-produced Hollywood screen test.

The charge of combat while bonding in a brotherhood so intimate that soldiers sacrifice their lives to save a fellow warrior is the guilty secret that both of those films expose. But â€œPoint and Shootâ€ù goes further to suggest that the addictive rush of battlefield adventure is hard-wired into the male psyche. Whether we like it or not, many men are warriors.

As his business starts to grow, Lou tangles with rivals and hires a wide-eyed sidekick (Riz Ahmed), all the while explaining himself in the jargon of management and self-help. He is a fast learner, and his amoral zeal causes him to evolve from eager voyeur into something much worse. His earnest belief in himself is both funny and dismaying, and his complete indifference to ethical boundaries makes for some slightly guilty fun. But nothing much beyond that. â€œNightcrawlerâ€ù is a slick and shallow movie desperate, like Lou himself, to be something more.

But a creepy disposition does not an antihero make, and â€œNightcrawlerâ€ù never attains anywhere near the gravity or the impact of â€œTaxi Driverâ€ù and â€œThe King of Comedy.â€ù Its message â€” that the news media feeds a morbid fascination with atrocity â€” is hardly implausible, but the target is more than a little shopworn, and the stance of queasy outrage feels secondhand, not to say a bit hypocritical. Local news, embodied in a desperate, cynical producer played by Rene Russo, may be a snake pit of tawdry, ratings-driven exploitation, but in the age of TMZ, in which everyone with a smartphone is a potential video journalist, there is something quaint about the filmâ€™s hyperventilating sense of scandal.

Adrift in a violent and gloomy Los Angeles, where he lives alone in a small apartment, Lou hatches an ambition that quickly blossoms into an obsession. Learning that local television stations will pay good money for video of accidents, fires and crime scenes â€” the bloodier, the better â€” he sets out to corner the market. With a police scanner and a cheap video camera, he speeds through the nighttime streets, looking for horrible images he can sell.

Really, though, the chasing after important themes is a distraction. â€œNightcrawlerâ€ù is a modest and effectively executed urban thriller, suspenseful and entertaining in its clammy, overwrought way. Mr. Gyllenhaalâ€™s performance, while not remotely persuasive, is disciplined and meticulous in its creepiness, and Mr. Gilroy keeps the audience off balance, fascinated and repelled, half rooting for Lou to succeed, and half dreading what he will do next.

In another sense, Lou aspires to be something much grander than a purveyor of grisly footage for the evening news. His dream â€” or rather the dream of Dan Gilroy, the writer and director of â€œNightcrawler,â€ù and perhaps of Mr. Gyllenhaal as well â€” is to join the ranks of Travis Bickle and Rupert Pupkin, classic â€™70s and â€™80s sociopaths, created by Martin Scorsese and Robert De Niro, who held a grim, unflattering, endlessly fascinating mirror up to the society that produced them. â€œNightcrawlerâ€ù is besotted by the sleaze and corruption that Lou both uncovers and represents, and it is also eager to turn his petty, predatory endeavors into raw material for social commentary.
â€œNightcrawlerâ€ù is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). Graphic violence and ugly language.

Lou Bloom, the title character of â€œNightcrawler,â€ù is a youngish man who possesses a strong work ethic, tireless curiosity and very little in the way of conscience or human feeling. Played with a precise repertoire of tics by Jake Gyllenhaal, Lou usually smiles when he speaks, but that seems more like learned behavior than genuine friendliness, since he is too literal-minded to understand jokes or social cues.

Mr. Ollivierâ€™s fans include Pik Botha, South Africaâ€™s foreign minister under apartheid; Chester Crocker, a Reagan administration official who pressed a â€œconstructive engagementâ€ù policy; even Winnie Mandela. No one person is responsible for the triumph of immense political movements. But â€œPlot for Peaceâ€ù demonstrates the truth that an Ollivier admirer notes: â€œAfrica is a place where a single individual can still have a great effect.â€ù

Directed by Carlos AgullÃ_ and Mandy Jacobson for the African Oral History Archive, â€œPlotâ€ù tells the little-known tale of Jean-Yves Ollivier, a French commodities trader who made his fortune doing business, he says, in â€œdifficult countriesâ€ù â€” including the internationally shunned South Africa. In 1981 he concluded that apartheid was unsustainable and began to use his contacts to help make sure its end came peacefully.

Through interviews with diplomats, intelligence officers and heads of state, the film delivers a crash course in African history and the role Mr. Ollivier played. In the mid-â€™80s, the continentâ€™s southern third was militarized, with South Africa attacking African National Congress outposts in neighboring countries and fighting a proxy Cold War battle in Angola against Cuban troops. As President Denis Sassou Nguesso of the Republic of Congo explains, peace in the entire region could not be established â€œwithout the demise of apartheid.â€ù
A fascinating account of off-the-books diplomacy in the 1980s, â€œPlot for Peaceâ€ù is that rare documentary that both augments the historical record and is paced like a thriller.

Efforts were incremental, but after a false step or two, Mr. Ollivier organized and financed an enormous exchange of prisoners in 1987. One accomplishment led to others: In multiparty peace talks he helped assemble in 1988, Cuba and South Africa agreed to withdraw troops from Angola, and Namibia gained its independence. Slightly more than a year later, Nelson Mandela was released as a â€œhumanitarianâ€ù gesture. Apartheidâ€™s days were numbered. Mr. Ollivier twice received the Order of Good Hope medal â€” once from the apartheid government and once from Mandela himself.

Nongovernment operatives often go where a nationâ€™s official representatives cannot, but Mr. Ollivier, a portly man who favors cigars and suspenders, was a freelancer, geopoliticking on his own. His family had to flee Algeria when it achieved independence in 1962, and he hoped to avoid a similar mass exodus of whites when apartheid fell. In time he became an honest broker, a provider of access and a reliable courier for parties in and out of South Africa.

Dragging scenes out like melted taffy, the director, Pat Oâ€™Connor (using Simon Readeâ€™s adaptation of a Michael Morpurgo novel), allows us plenty of time to nap between the rustic 1908 childhood of two English brothers (George MacKay and Jack Oâ€™Connell) and their 1916 comeuppance in a trench on the Western Front. Along the way, flash-forwards tease us with the firing-squad execution of one unidentified sibling, probably in expectation that weâ€™ll care which one.
Itâ€™s war calibrated for the â€œAntiques Roadshowâ€ù demographic in â€œPrivate Peaceful,â€ù a World War I fable thatâ€™s as stiff as an Eton collar and as plodding as a draft horse.

While we anticipate the inevitable, the two fall for the same girl, save the same decrepit hound and endure John Lynchâ€™s overacting as their sergeant at boot camp. Confrontations with a crotchety lord of the manor (Richard Griffiths); a crabby aunt (Frances de la Tour); and a stalwart, widowed mum (Maxine Peake) unspool with stifling decorum, as do scenes of slow-motion slaughter at the hands of the â€œfilthy Hun.â€ù

â€œWeâ€™re fightinâ€™ the Germans, but weâ€™re at war with your kind, too,â€ù one brother tells his betters, as if we didnâ€™t know that those with dirty hands were the real heroes. But with its fusty air and glumly earnest performances, this unnecessary reminder of Steven Spielbergâ€™s soppy 2011 staging of another of Mr. Morpurgoâ€™s novels, â€œWar Horse,â€ù is about as entertaining as trench mouth. The death of a parent flies past, but the sackcloth-and-ashes palette endures to the end.

In the spring of 2012, the beleaguered city of Stockton, Calif. â€” twice named Americaâ€™s most miserable city by Forbes Magazine â€” faced rising violence, imminent bankruptcy and a City Hall in foreclosure. Not the most attractive proving ground for a virgin politician and aspiring City Council member, but Michael Tubbs, just 21 and a senior at Stanford University, was undaunted. Smarting from the murder of his cousin the year before, and despairing over the decline of his hometown, Mr. Tubbs exchanged his studies for a grass-roots campaign.

Rough-hewed but naturally inspirational, â€œTrue Sonâ€ù gains heft from its portrait of a city sharply segregated by race and income. â€œThere are a couple of Stocktons, and they donâ€™t sit well with each other,â€ù a local news reporter tells us as Mr. Tubbs applies his just-do-it thinking to barriers both legal and financial. As you might imagine, they donâ€™t stand a chance.

This approach, while admirably avoiding manipulation, is also beholden to a daily grind of door knocking and strategy meetings that are singularly lacking in drama or back story. How, for instance, did a young man raised in poverty by a single mother (the delightfully spirited Racole Dixon) and with an incarcerated father make his way to Stanford?

â€œTrue Sonâ€ù documents that journey with a fly-on-the-wall style and a modesty and inexperience that mirror those of its subject. Shadowing Mr. Tubbs as he assembles a crude campaign staff, rallies a small army of mostly young volunteers and overcomes his discomfort with fund-raising, the director and photographer, Kevin Gordon, maintains a hands-off deference.

Bobby eventually turns to Joe (Jerry Oâ€™Connell), a drug dealer and onetime college basketball star who, like anyone with that rÃ©sumÃ©, just wants money for his cooking show. Fortunately, Joe and his brother (Justin Long) know Lacey, a dead ringer for Sadie also played by Ms. Jacobs. But she is working undercover to deliver Joe, her dealer, to the cops.

Throw in Luis GuzmÃ¡n as a gambling-debt collector and Scottie Thompson as Joeâ€™s new love â€” a deaf amputee who secretly has cancer â€” and â€œThe Lookalikeâ€ù scarcely lacks for high-concept ideas. A full accounting is perhaps unfair, as the screenwriter, Michele Gray (who is married to the filmâ€™s director, Richard Gray), seems to have sought a dense, dark and slightly absurd texture approximating an Elmore Leonard novel.

Nonstop scheming and some grimy New Orleans locations prevent â€œThe Lookalikeâ€ù from being boring. But the movie, instead of embracing its budgetary limitations, gives off a distracting sense of trying to punch above its weight class. (An explosion scene is particularly overwrought.) Muddy sound from the Blu-ray projected at the lone New York theater screening the film spoiled both the mood and the dialogue.

â€œSordidâ€ù seems too mild a word for â€œThe Lookalike,â€ù an arch, clotted new noir. A convoluted plot begins when Sadie (Gillian Jacobs) agrees to sleep with her fatherâ€™s former business associate for $500,000. The assignation will leverage a drug connection for a gangster, Bobby (John Corbett, sounding like Jeff Bridges). Then Sadie dies in a freak accident: Bobbyâ€™s criminal partner (Steven Bauer) shakes a desk, causing a chandelier to fall on her. Hey, it happens. But it leaves the men scrambling to find a double.

The explicit subject of Frederick Wisemanâ€™s magnificent documentary â€œNational Galleryâ€ù is the stately museum that rises at the northern end of Trafalgar Square in London. Like most of Mr. Wisemanâ€™s work, the movie is at once specific and general, fascinating in its pinpoint detail and transporting in its cosmic reach. Itâ€™s about art and process, money and mystery, and all the many, many people gazing and gawping and, at times, lining up to see a blockbuster show. That â€œNational Galleryâ€ù is also about movies is surely a given.

Itâ€™s possible to enjoy â€œNational Galleryâ€ù just for its privileged three-hour virtual tour of the museum, including the behind-the-scenes sections. Some of the more engrossing involve various conservation efforts, including a talk in which a conservator, much like an art history Sherlock, speculates on a mysterious, ghostly image beneath the layers of dark paint on a Rembrandt portrait. As the conservator speaks, he metaphorically peels away strata of paint and varnish, an engagement with the portrait that reverses the work of the artist (and earlier restorers), humanizes Rembrandt and closes the distance between his time and ours. The painting has been taken off the wall and the artist plucked from mythologizing history to be briefly returned to his studio.

Mr. Wiseman wants us to remember that history, too, because, as he quietly argues, the story of all art is also the story of human endeavor and the complex weave of relationships, of labor, commerce, patronage and the sometimes gross exploitation of bodies (as with those slaves), most of which are not beautifully immortalized in museums.

With cool intelligence and a steady camera, Mr. Wiseman guides you through the museum and past its masters, pausing to look but also to listen to what becomes a museumwide conversation on form, content and context. In one scene, a woman discusses the composition of a cityscape by Camille Pissarro in a room filled with visually impaired people, whose fingers glide over embossed reproductions of the painting. In another, a guide invokes the ephemeral while discussing a Dutch still life of a lobster that no longer exists and of a drinking horn that does. Elsewhere, a woman in a lecture hall passionately enjoins her audience to ask: What did the artist mean?

What does this artist mean? As is customary for a Wiseman documentary, â€œNational Galleryâ€ù lacks voice-over, talking-head interviews or explanatory text, including identifiers. Mr. Wiseman tends to make you work more than documentarians who spell everything out, which is a problem only if you demand that images reveal themselves completely in the moment you first see them. Mr. Wiseman could have identified Nicholas Penny, the man with the silvery hair who seems to be running the joint, yet Mr. Pennyâ€™s body language, sighs and restrained impatience make it obvious that he is the boss. Not knowing didnâ€™t impede my pleasure; it spurred my curiosity.

With its emphasis on process, this analysis of the painting echoes Mr. Wisemanâ€™s own layering and how he builds meaning, scene by scene, creating complexity and building density associatively so that sound and image become motifs. One guide, for instance, goes into gruesome detail describing how the British painter George Stubbs, in order to understand horse anatomy, used a pulley system to hang their skinned carcasses so that he could draw them. Sometime later, thereâ€™s a short, lovely sequence in which a man and a woman perform a pas de deux before some Titian paintings, a sequence that draws a line from Stubbsâ€™s skinned horses to several life drawing classes in the documentary to the figures in the Titian canvases and, finally, to the straining muscles of the dancers.

At another point, Mr. Wiseman cuts to a nighttime scene of people suspended on ropes from the top of the museum as they unfurl a Greenpeace banner bearing the words â€œItâ€™s no oil paintingâ€ù across the building front. Some online sleuthing fills in the blanks. Seeking to draw attention to Shellâ€™s plan to drill in the Arctic, activists raised the banner the night of a company event at the museum in February 2012. (Shell is the sponsor for a current exhibition, â€œRembrandt: The Late Works.â€ù) Mr. Wiseman doesnâ€™t include any of this, although his camera does linger on the banner, and you may notice that the â€œoâ€ù in â€œoilâ€ù looks like the yellow Shell logo. Even so, itâ€™s not evident how the banner scene fits.

Yet it does â€” this is, after all, a Frederick Wiseman mosaic â€” because one of the most insistent refrains in â€œNational Galleryâ€ù is the role of money in art, a subject that surfaces when the delightfully named Mr. Penny and a woman discuss whether the museum, as a public institution, needs to do more to make itself attractive to the actual public, and a separate, testier conversation about the institutionâ€™s budget. These dovetail with a scene in which a guide explains to some students that itâ€™s crucial to remember that the museumâ€™s origins can be traced to the slave trade: The foundation of the National Galleryâ€™s collection originated with John Julius Angerstein, a celebrated art patron whose fortune was partly amassed through Grenada slave estates.

That sounds heavier than I mean it to or than how the movie plays. Mr. Wisemanâ€™s touch is deft but light here, and the experience of watching â€œNational Galleryâ€ù is pleasurable and immersive because heâ€™s a wonderful storyteller. It is also unexpectedly moving. Because his other great theme is how art speaks to us, one he brilliantly expresses in the relay of gazes that finds us looking at museumgoers looking at portraits that look right back â€” at artists, art lovers and moviegoers â€” even as Mr. Wiseman, that sly old master, looks at all of us in turn.

But â€œGravityâ€ù and â€œInterstellarâ€ù are both ultimately about the longing for home, about voyages into the unknown that become odysseys of return. And â€œInterstellarâ€ù may take its place in the pantheon of space movies because it answers an acute earthly need, a desire not only for adventure and novelty but also, in the end, for comfort.

Like the great space epics of the past, Christopher Nolanâ€™s â€œInterstellarâ€ù distills terrestrial anxieties and aspirations into a potent pop parable, a mirror of the mood down here on Earth. Stanley Kubrickâ€™s â€œ2001: A Space Odysseyâ€ù blended the technological awe of the Apollo era with the trippy hopes and terrors of the Age of Aquarius. George Lucasâ€™s first â€œStar Warsâ€ù trilogy, set not in the speculative future but in the imaginary past, answered the malaise of the â€™70s with swashbuckling nostalgia. â€œInterstellar,â€ù full of visual dazzle, thematic ambition, geek bait and corn (including the literal kind), is a sweeping, futuristic adventure driven by grief, dread and regret.

Trying to jot down notes by the light of the Imax screen, where lustrous images (shot by Hoyte van Hoytema and projected from real 70-millimeter film) flickered, I lost count of how many times the phrase â€œIâ€™m sorryâ€ù was uttered â€” by parents to children, children to parents, sisters to brothers, scientists to astronauts and astronauts to one another. The whole movie can be seen as a plea for forgiveness on behalf of our foolish, dreamy species. We messed everything up, and we feel really bad about it. Can you please give us another chance?

Of course, the film is more than that. It is in the nature of science fiction to aspire to more, to ascend fearlessly toward the sublime. You could think of â€œInterstellar,â€ù which has a lot to say about gravity, as the anti-Gravity.â€ù That movie

column5: A lot of other stuff happens, too, as it tends to out in space. A cynical critic might suppose that the last two hours of â€œInterstellarâ€ù were composed in a fit of spoiler hysteria. Nondisclosure pleas from the studio have been unusually specific. Forget about telling you what happens: Iâ€™m not even supposed to tell you whoâ€™s in the thing, aside from the people youâ€™ve seen on magazine covers. I guess I can disclose that Cooper and Brand are accompanied by two other astronauts, played by a witty, scene-stealing David Gyasi and a deadpan Wes Bentley, and also by a wry robot who speaks in the voice of Bill Irwin.
â€œInterstellarâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). A few expletives, a lot of peril.

The touches of humor those characters supply are welcome, if also somewhat stingily rationed. Nobody goes to a Christopher Nolan movie for laughs. But it is hard to imagine that his fans â€” who represent a fairly large segment of the worldâ€™s population â€” will be disappointed by â€œInterstellar.â€ù I havenâ€™t always been one of them, but Iâ€™ve always thought that his skill and ingenuity were undeniable. He does not so much transcend genre conventions as fulfill them with the zeal of a true believer. It may be enough to say that â€œInterstellarâ€ù is a terrifically entertaining science-fiction movie, giving fresh life to scenes and situations weâ€™ve seen a hundred times before, and occasionally stumbling over pompous dialogue or overly portentous music. (In general, the score, by Hans Zimmer, is exactly as portentous as it needs to be.)

The head of the family in question is Cooper (Matthew McConaughey), a widower who lives with his two children and his father-in-law (John Lithgow). Once a NASA pilot, Cooper now grows corn, the only thing that will grow after a blight has wiped out most of the planetâ€™s other crops. The human population has shrunk to a desperate remnant, but the survivors cling to the habits and rituals of normal life. For now, there is plenty of candy and soda and beer (thanks to all that corn); there are parent-teacher conferences after school; and Cooperâ€™s farmhouse is full of books and toys. But the blight is spreading, the dust storms are growing worse, and the sense of an ending is palpable.

Dick Cavett, a son of Nebraska, used to ask (quoting Abe Burrows), â€œHow you gonna keep â€˜em down on the farm, after theyâ€™ve seen the farm?â€ù Cooper and â€œInterstellarâ€ù are clearly marked for something other than agrarian pursuits, but the first section of the movie is the richest and most haunting, establishing a delicately emotional tone and clear moral and dramatic stakes for the planet-hopping to follow. Cooper is devoted to his children, in particular his daughter, Murph, played as a young girl by the preternaturally alert and skeptical Mackenzie Foy and as an adult by Jessica Chastain. When her father is recruited for a secret NASA mission to search for a habitable new planet, Murph is devastated by his departure. Her subsequent scientific career is both a tribute to his memory and a way of getting even.

The Nolans cleverly conflate scientific denialism with technophobia, imagining a fatalistic society that has traded large ambition for small-scale problem solving and ultimate resignation. But Christopher Nolan, even in his earlier, more modestly budgeted films, has never been content with the small scale. His imagination is large; his eye seeks out wide, sweeping vistas; and if he believes in anything, it is ambition. As it celebrates the resistance to extinction â€” taking as its touchstone Dylan Thomasâ€™s famous villanelle â€œDo Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night,â€ù with its repeated invocation of â€œrage against the dying of the lightâ€ù â€” â€œInterstellarâ€ù becomes an allegory of its own aspirations, an argument for grandeur, scale and risk, on screen and off.

The Nolans are fond of doubled characters and mirrored plots, and so â€œInterstellarâ€ù is built around twinned father-daughter stories. Among Cooperâ€™s colleagues on board the spaceship is Dr. Brand (Anne Hathaway), whose father, also called Dr. Brand (Michael Caine), has developed the theories behind their quest. He and Murph remain on the ground, crunching the numbers and growing older in the usual earthly way, while Cooper and the younger Brand, thanks to relativity, stay pretty much the same age. (Cooperâ€™s son, Tom, played by TimothÃ©e Chalamet as a boy, matures into Casey Affleck). The two pairs of daughters and dads perform variations on the theme of paternal and filial love, finding delicate and moving passages of loyalty, rebellion, disillusionment and acceptance.

What our planet and species need saving from is a slow-motion environmental catastrophe. Rather than explain how this bleak future arrived through the usual montages of mayhem, Mr. Nolan (who wrote the screenplay with his brother Jonathan) drops us quietly into what looks like a fairly ordinary reality. We are in a rural stretch of North America, a land of battered pickup trucks, dusty bluejeans and wind-burned farmers scanning the horizon for signs of a storm. Talking-head testimony from old-timers chronicles what sounds like the Dust Bowl of the 1930s, until we spot a laptop on the table being set for family dinner.

The possibility that such a â€œyouâ€ù might be out there, in a position to grant clemency, is one of the movieâ€™s tantalizing puzzles. Some kind of message seems to be coming across the emptiness of space and along the kinks in the fabric of time, offering a twinkle of hope amid humanityâ€™s rapidly darkening prospects. For most of â€œInterstellar,â€ù the working hypothesis is that a benevolent alien race, dwelling somewhere on the far side of a wormhole near one of the moons of Saturn, is sending data across the universe, encrypted advice that just may save us if we can decode it fast enough.
A MERRY FRIGGINâ€™ CHRISTMAS

The parental equivalent of Billy Bob Thorntonâ€™s â€œBad Santaâ€ù character, Virgil had a neglectful, tough-love child-rearing style that has left his son, Boyd (Joel McHale, from â€œCommunity,â€ù like the director, Tristram Shapeero), now grown, obsessed with preserving the illusion of Santa for his own 6-year-old. Coaxed to Wisconsin from Chicago for a rare family visit, Boyd and his wife, Luann (Lauren Graham), leave behind a stack of presents.

Yet, shot in burnished tones by the cinematographer Giovani Lampassi, the movie exudes a low-key warmth. Luann gets liquored up with Boydâ€™s mother (Candice Bergen, in a nice turn). Virgil â€” still so unhinged that he serves squirrel to his returning son and yells, â€œIs your name on the mailbox?â€ù to assert his authority â€” instantly turns from vicious to sad. Itâ€™s the screenwriterâ€™s equivalent of a holiday miracle.
â€œA Merry Frigginâ€™ Christmasâ€ù is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). Talk of alcohol abuse and sex.
1 hour 22 minutes
Opens on Friday

The modestly scaled (and accordingly successful) â€œA Merry Frigginâ€™ Christmasâ€ù is too slight to bear the freight of featuring one of Robin Williamsâ€™s final roles. Itâ€™s a testament to Williamsâ€™s energy that even in an unfortunate part as Virgil, an angry, alcoholic dad, he comes across as the most vivid member of the cast.
Directed by Tristram Shapeero

This prompts an all-night father-son road trip, involving a boozing Santa (Oliver Platt), a genial highway trooper (Mark Proksch), portable toilets and antics generally suited to â€œNational Lampoonâ€™s Christmas Vacation.â€ù

Maybe he didnâ€™t want to get involved with the film, or maybe heâ€™s beside the point. â€œActressâ€ù is not a novel but a portrait, one focused on Ms. Burreâ€™s frustrations and ambitions and on the challenges facing not-quite-young women in her profession. Mr. Greeneâ€™s impressionistic style and rough, off-center compositions create an atmosphere of intimacy, as if the viewer were being invited to read Ms. Burreâ€™s diary or her mind. After an hour and a half in her company, you might feel as if you know her very well, even as you have no idea who she really is. That might be the result of her existential condition, or it might just be her job.

In a sense she is. The movieâ€™s title should be taken at face value, which is to say with an awareness of its double meaning. Ms. Burre is never not aware of the camera, and this all-access slice of life is also a highly constructed artifact, with some notable slants and omissions. As elliptical as an Ann Beattie short story, leaving a great deal unsaid, it chronicles the end of a relationship and the limbo that follows.

In the first shot of â€œActress,â€ù Robert Greeneâ€™s elusive and intriguing new film, Brandy Burre stands at her kitchen sink, wearing a red dress that matches the symmetrically placed poinsettias on the windowsill. In a voice-over, she muses that she is a â€œtype Aâ€ù personality, which she defines as someone â€œwho breaks things.â€ù

Later, the audience will be reminded that similar words were spoken by Theresa Dâ€™Agostino, the political consultant Ms. Burre played on â€œThe Wire.â€ù (In the third and fourth seasons, Theresa had an affair with Jimmy McNulty and helped Tommy Carcetti become mayor of Baltimore.) And the overlap might make us wonder about the boundary between actors and the characters they play, especially when, as in this film, an actress is playing herself.

Thatâ€™s a common enough phrase, but the more you think about it, the stranger it sounds. And as Mr. Greeneâ€™s camera follows Ms. Burre through the routines of her life in the Hudson Valley, where she and Tim Reinke are raising their two young children, you might wonder just what kind of performance you are watching. At times, Ms. Burre, her acting career dormant, seems to be throwing herself into the role of housewife (though she and Mr. Reinke are not married) and mother as if it were an especially demanding part. In the course of her daily activities â€” cleaning the house, buying groceries, planning birthday parties, ferrying the kids to play dates and dance classes â€” she gives off a glint of self-consciousness, as if she were offering a glimpse not of her everyday reality but of her creative process.

Early on, Ms. Burre says that she has more than once asked Mr. Reinke, who manages some restaurants and bars the couple owns, to move out of their house. He sticks around, but they donâ€™t seem very happy together. His shyness around the camera makes his side of things hard to figure out, and at times the movie turns coy about what exactly is going on. On a trip to New York, Ms. Burre seems to be involved with someone else, but while this loverâ€™s existence is alluded to a couple of times, he is never named or clearly seen.

â€œBhopal: A Prayer for Rainâ€ù dramatizes the buildup to the 1984 poisonous-gas leak from a pesticide factory in Bhopal, India. The leak, sometimes called the worldâ€™s worst industrial disaster, killed 3,000 almost instantly and has left a legacy of contamination and adverse health effects.

Although independently financed, the film favors the melodramatic overemphasis thatâ€™s become something of a Bollywood house style. It mines every chemical drip and gurgle for suspense. (The disaster itself is intercut with a wedding celebration.) This is crudely mounted, earnest advocacy, getting its points across at any cost.

Martin Sheen plays the American chief executive of a chemical company as a combination of populist and unapologetic capitalist, eager to take advantage of a country with laxer regulations than those in the United States. (The character is identified as Warren Anderson, the former leader of the Union Carbide Corporation, who died in September.) Kal Penn plays a journalist in Bhopal, reporting on a story that no one wants to hear. A safety supervisor (Joy Sengupta) fruitlessly pushes back against a managerâ€™s cost-cutting measures. A doctor provides a worker (Om Prakash), soon to be killed, with a pamphlet and says the chemicals at the plant arenâ€™t harmful.

In opening title cards, the movie is up front about taking liberties for effect â€” and about its goal of drawing attention to a further form of justice for Bhopal residents. At the same time, the film is equal-opportunity in its hand-wringing. It finds fault with major characters across all levels of its ensemble cast.

Directed by Don Hall and Chris Williams, â€œBig Hero 6â€ù opens with a borderline-frenetic action sequence that announces its tone and PG-rated turf with swaggering humor, signaling that this is no once-upon-a time kiddie kingdom. In a dark corner of the whimsically named city of San Fransokyo (it is a small world), a rowdy crowd has gathered for illegal fights in which remote-controlled robot combatants square off. Here, amid cheers, swooping visuals and the scoreâ€™s pounding beats, the 14-year-old prodigy Hiro Hamada (Ryan Potter) makes like a seasoned hustler with a shark smile and a robot annihilator, a triumph that leads to a getaway, a failed race to the rescue and a stint in jail.

Have the Walt Disney and Pixar animation studios become Walt Pixar, or maybe Wixar or Dixar? Itâ€™s getting hard to tell these once-distinct siblings apart. Disneyâ€™s latest animated feature, â€œBig Hero 6,â€ù is a bright, visually sumptuous 3-D computer-animated feature that gives you a bit of an emotional workout. It doesnâ€™t have some of the familiar Disney markers: There are no eardrum-busting anthems or warbling critters, and it isnâ€™t a fairy tale, exactly, mostly because itâ€™s about a boy. Itâ€™s a Disney superhero movie with a story from a Marvel comic book, if one rendered with the wit and texture often associated with Pixar, which I guess makes it a Walt Pixar Marvel.

Hiroâ€™s journey is rather more pedestrian, resembling that of the classic hero â€” the writers are Robert L. Baird, Daniel Gerson and Jordan Roberts â€” retrofitted to the information age with some space-age filler. Hiro is called to adventure only to refuse that call and then, after receiving help from a magical helper, or rather Baymax, crosses the threshold, enters the belly of the beast and so on. More specifically, a tragedy radically upends Hiroâ€™s world, putting the kibosh on his plans to attend the university and plunging him into a very sad place. He emerges almost by accident when he stumbles across a villain, a discovery that sets him and the story down a path thatâ€™s so well-trod it feels discouragingly inescapable: that of the genius turned superhero.

Once Hiro has been sprung from jail by his Aunt Cass (Maya Rudolph), the story pieces begin sliding into place. Hiro and his older brother, Tadashi (Daniel Henney), live with Cass above her San Fran-cool bakery and cafe. Sheâ€™s a disappointingly bland maternal creation, by turns screechy and huggy, and Tadashi isnâ€™t much better, even if heâ€™s a hunky brainiac who studies at an institute of higher nerdiness alongside a Scooby Doo-like posse: a slacker, Fred (a funny T. J. Miller); a tough chick, GoGo (Jamie Chung); a priss, Honey Lemon (Genesis Rodriguez); and a dude with dreads, Wasabi (Damon Wayans Jr.). The group is as harmoniously balanced as a university diversity committee, and largely distinguished by safe quirks of personality rather than stereotypes and unfunny accents.
â€œBig Hero 6â€ù is rated PG (Parental guidance suggested). The movie features a death and several fight sequences.

Both Baymax and the backgrounds, with their amusing excesses and startling photorealistic detail, make the story seem fairly superfluous, at least until youâ€™ve settled in. Like the portmanteau name San Fransokyo, the movie fuses different source materials, drawing on diverse cultural traditions, urban landscapes, architectural visions and futurist ideas.

The designs for these characters are gently exaggerated, with innocuous looks to go with their friendly, unthreatening temperaments. They pale next to Baymax, whose pleasing plumpness and symphony of cartoon sounds â€” when he walks, his legs produce muffled boing-boing noises â€” make him the embodiment of kawaii and the Japanese culture of cute. Created by Tadashi, the robot is a palpably tactile and charming screen presence who in time becomes Hiroâ€™s supersize Jiminy Cricket, part folk philosopher, part moral compass. What makes Baymax so memorable and emotionally potent is that heâ€™s also something of a Proustian Marshmallow who triggers an irresistible chain of elemental pleasures: Heâ€™s a stuffed animal, a warm blanket, a cozy chair, a warm embrace.

Mr. Hawking is both an important scientist and a fixture of popular culture, the author of best-selling books that seek to explain concepts comprehensible only to specialists. â€œThe Theory of Everything,â€ù James Marshâ€™s biographical film about the British theoretical physicist Stephen Hawking, tries very hard to live up to its title: It wants to show a remarkable man in full, to explore his ideas, his emotional life and his struggle with illness.
